title: WINE TALK
description: Advertisements appeared recently offering Bordeaux wines of the 1968 vintage, at what appeared to be exceptionally low prices. The interest in these offerings, particularly that of the 1968 Chateau LafiteRothschild, was intense and the wine was sold out in a matter of days, if not hours.

title: Ali Retains Title as Fight Is Stopped After 14th
description: MANILA, Wednesday, Oct. 1In the most brutal confrontation of their fiveyear rivalry, Muhammad Ali retained the world heavyweight boxing championship today when Joe Frazier's manager, Eddie Futch, surrendered from the corner moments before the bell was to ring for the 15th round.

title: $126Million F.B.I. Building, Named for Hoover, Dedicated in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30There is one small bit of color in the new J. Edgar Hoover Building on Pennsylvania Avenue herein the rug and desk implements from the office of J. Edgar Hoover, part of which has been recreated for the amusement (or inspiration) of the tourists who are expected to flow through the new structure at the rate of 500,000 a year. Everything else in the building is so neutral that it can fairly be said that the color scheme runs the gamut from white to beige.

title: Japan Payments Deficit
description: TOKYO, Sept. 30 (AP)Japan registered a $268million overall balanceofpayments deficit in August, compared with a $57million surplus in July and a $513million deficit a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said today in a revised report. Provisional totals, announced at mid month, put last month's deficit at $270million.

title: FORD ASKS REVIEW OF FUNDS FOR CITY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30President Ford has ordered two Cabinet officers to review Federal allocations to New York City, at the behest of Senator James L. Buckley, New York ConservativeRepublican, who complained to the President that the city was shortchanged.

title: Lodi Residents Oust Mayor for Tax Rise And Elect New One
description: LODI, Sept. 30 (UPI)Residents here, upset over a recent propertytax increase, voted today to oust Mayor John Bombace and two Councilmen and elected Christopher Paci as their new Mayor.

title: U.S. ELECTION UNIT ACTS ON LOOPHOLE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The Federal Election Commission moved today to urge Congress to plug a serious loophole in the law limiting spending by Presidential aspirants in the 1976 election.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, Sept. 30, 1975

title: Medicare Patients To Pay 13% More For Hospitalization
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) The Government announced today that the nation's 24.1 million Medicare beneficiaries will have to pay 13 per cent more next Jan. 1 toward their hospitalization costs.

title: Building Viewed as Dullest of a Dull Lot
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30There is one small bit of color in the new J. Edgar Hoover Building on Pennsylvania Avenue herein the rug and desk implements from the office of J. Edgar Hoover, part of which has been recreated for the amusement (or inspiration) of the tourists who are expected to flow through the new structure at the rate of 500,000 a year. Everything else in the building is so neutral that it can fairly be said that the color scheme runs the gamut from white to beige.

title: College, School Results
Entertainment Event
description: Theater

title: Carey Names Parks Aide
description: ALBANY, Sept. 30 (UPI)Governor Carey today announced the appointment of Clare Beckhardt as general manager of the State Park and Recreation Commission for New York City. The post carries a salary of $29,000.

title: A KEY BRITISH AIDE LOSES PARTY FIGHT
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 30Chancellor of the Exchequer Denis Healey was thrown off the Labor party's ruling council today by party militants only hours after Prime Minister Harold Wilson had pleaded for an end to interparty strife.

title: Aitken's Fables Opera Bows Oct. 23 in Jersey
description: Hugh Aitken's Fables, a new chamber opera based on 10 of Jean de la Fontaine's versions of fables by Aesop and others, will be given a preview performance Oct. 23 at Shea Center for the Performing Arts at William Patterson College in Wayne. N.J.

title: About Education
description: Connecticut today becomes the latest of a growing number of states with laws allowing public employes to organize into unions, and the state's large and varied public college and university system can expect a surge of union activity on its public campuses.

title: Food Prices Drop Slightly
description: Sharp increases in the price of meat were offset last week by significant drops some, fruit and veget?? prices and the cost of fee?? a family of four in New Y?? City declined slightly by ?? per cent, the City Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday.

title: Yale Sets Up School Of Administration With Dual Purpose
description: Yale University will announce today the establishment of a Graduate School of Organization and Management to train leaders for both business and government service.

title: Duran Beats Viruet
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Sept. 30 In a startling, often comic, never dull 10round nontitle fight, Roberto Duran, the lightweight champion, won a unanimous decision tonight from Edwin Viruet, his dancing, mimicking opponent.

title: William Donovan, 73, Dies; Headed Engineering Firm
description: William Ernest Donovan, former president and board chairman of L. P. Graner, inc., consulting engineers, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home at 250 East 65th Street. He was 73 years old.

title: THOMAS E. CLANCY
description: Thomas E. Clancy, who retired last Jan. 1 as day makeup foreman of The New York Times composing room, was killed with his wife, the former Muriel Halpin, in an auto accident during the storm on Friday near Point Pleasant, N.J. He was 64 years old and his wife was 55.

title: Books of The Times
description: Art is long and relevance is short, says Robert Brustein in The Culture Watch. The word revolution, when applied to theater, is usually no more meaningful than when it is used to describe detergents. The radical left resembles the bourgeoisie in trying to use the theater: one as a pacifier, the other as a bomb. The avantgarde is being corrupted by uninformed praise: it has so many new friends, it doesn't need enemies.

title: WNET Drops 2 Shows As Adams Costs Mount
description: As a result of sizable cost overruns for the production of the dramatic series, The Adams Chronicles, WNET/13 here has dropped two local public affairs series scheduled this fall and has cut back two others.

title: MADRID REJECTS FOREIGN PROTESTS
description: MADRID, Sept. 30Premier Carlos Arias Navarro tonight angrily denounced international protests against Spain over the execution of five terrorists and called an the Spanish people to unite behind Generalissimo Francisco Franco and the Government.

title: Compared to What?
description: Unwarranted expectations and the national addiction to quick, easy fixes have sunk many promising public policy initiatives. The danger is great that methadone maintenanceheralded as the brightest new hope in battling New York City's drug problem not so long agomay suffer that fate. A recent report by the Community Service Society, while finding that methadone maintenance had become the predominant and most effective method yet devised for dealing with a stubborn medical and social problem, nevertheless concluded that the very future of methadone maintenance is in doubt because of its political vulnerability and loss of public confidence.

title: Americans Look at Gold Again But Focus on Coins, Not Bullion
description: The American gold boom of 1975, which quickly dissolved into a bust last January before it ever got fully under way, has suddenly revived.

title: Policemen Dies of Wounds
description: BARCELONA, Spain Sept 30 (AP)A Barcelona policemen died today of wounds suffered in a holdup believed to have been carried out by the Basque separatist movement.

title: PRESIDENT ASKS $13MILLION MORE FOR PROTECTION
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 30President Ford, after asking Congress today for $13.5million more this year for Secret Service protection, said tonight that he would continue traveling across the country not in any foolhardy spirit, but by every prudent and practical means.

title: Dollar Off Abroad; Gold Shows Gains
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 30 (UPI)The dollar brought its lowest rates in more than a week on most European money markets (today, following predictions that the United States will have large budget deficits.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two New York State Senate committeesFinance and the Select Committee on Crimehave started preliminary investigations of the negotiations on a possible purchase of Madison Square Garden by the Offtrack Betting Corporation. One aspect of investigation is to determine possible organized crime involvement in the Garden.

title: SENATE UNITVOTES BANKING CHANGES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (Reuters)The Senate Banking Committee voted today to allow savings and loan associations the right to offer checking accounts and credit card as part of a bill to reform the United States financial structure.

title: U.S. Will Let Vietnamese Who Ask to Go Back Do So
description: ASAN, Guam, Sept. 30The United States has decided to allow 1,600 Vietnamese refugees here to return to their homeland as they have requested despite the new Saigon Government's apparent reluctance to accept them.

title: Bremen's World Message
description: The sharp Social Democratic setback in legislative elections in Bremen, the smallest of West Germany's eleven states, is a major political rebuff for the party's Iron Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt, who faces national elections next year. It also has an important message for President Ford, whom Mr. Schmidt will be visiting in Washington this week.

title: HIROHITO ARRIVES FOR TOUR IN U.S.
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 30Emperor Hirohito stepped off a Japan Air Lines jet plane at nearby Patrick Henry Airport this morning to begin a 15day visit to the United States.

title: SUSPECT ARRESTED IN V.A. HOSPITAL CASE
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 30 (UPI)An unidentified suspect in an apparent attempt to murder a patient at the Veterans Administration Hospitalscene of 11 mysterious respiratory deaths  has been turned over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, hospital officials said today. The officials said the suspect was not an employe.

title: SENATE UNIT ASKS WORD FROM FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, under pressure from President Ford to act quickly to approve the stationing of Americans in the Sinai passes, urged Mr. Ford today to certify that no secret assurances to Israel or Egypt were being withheld from Congress.

title: British Headmasters' Quandary
description: LONDON, Sept. 30The Latymer Upper School in the West London borough of Hammersmith is a proud place; its headmasterMaurice Lawrence Reginald Isaac a proud man.

title: Business Briefs
description: Pan American World Airways reported yesterday that it had concluded an interim credit arrangement with a group of 36 banks that would pave the way for a new financial package designed to meet the company's seasonal cash needs.

title: Visitors to Colonial Williamsburg Find It Beset With 20thCentury Problems
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 30Like the kings queens and other distinguished visitors who have come here to see the wonders of historic restoration at Colonial Williamsburg, Emperor Hirohito and Empress Nagako of Japan will not walk their knees numb tomorrow, stand in a long perspiring line for a bowl of cream of peanut soup in an authentic tavern or be surprised by what it costs to tour the popular recreation of Virginia's preRevolutionary capital.

title: Hoechst Postpones Plant
description: SOMERVILLE, N. J., Sept. 30 (UPI)The American Hoechst. Corporation said today it had postponed indefinitely a plan to build a new chemical plant at Port Arthur, Tex. But the company said it would keep the site which was bought in 1974 for possible future use.

title: Schools Defend Cost Estimate of Teachers' Pact
description: The Board of Education, in a sharply worded statement, challenged Governor Carey's la bor consultants y esterday to substantiate their contention that the new teachers' contract could cost the city $140million this year, which would be near ly $100million more than what the board said it would cost

title: PRICES ARE LOWER ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market fell yesterday for the second consecutive day. Volume fell on the Amex but rose slightly in the counter market.

title: Rights and Copyrights
description: First came the wordlong before such multiple disseminators as the photocopying machine, microfiche and the computer. And before the creaking copyright law of 1909 was enacted came its rationale in the Constitutionthe provision giving authors and inventors the exclusive right to their writings and discoveries for limited times in order to promote the progress of science and useful arts for the people.

title: Samuel Latimer Jr. Dies; South Carolina Editor, 83
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 30 (UPI)Samuel L. Latimer Jr., who rose from office boy to chief editor and publisher of The State, died yesterday at Veterans Hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: LAG ON NORTHROP IN PENTAGON SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) Senate investigators accused the Pentagon today of holding back the results of the Defense Department's continuing inquiry into the Northrop Corporation's use of a hunting lodge to woo leading members of Congress, Congressional aides, military officers and Pentagon officials while Northrop was trying to sell jet fighters to the Government.

title: People and Business
description: Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said yesterday that although the country was well into an economic recovery, its strength and durability were uncertain.

title: Portugal's Premier Removes Troops From Radio and TV Stations
description: LISBON, Wednesday, Oct. 1 Portugal's Premier called off the military occupation of leftistcontrolled radio and television stations early today, reversing a move he made two days ago to counter rising threats of disorder.

title: U.S. Energy Goal, Zarb Says, Is to Aid Jobs and Industry
description: The emphasis in any futurel energy allocation program would be to save jobs and keep industries going, Frank G. Zarb, head of the Federal Energy Administration, said yesterday.

title: I.B.M. Increasing Prices; Texaco Lifts Fuel Costs
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced price increases yesterday for most data processing products and services from its data processing and general systems division. The company said the higher prices represented the partial recovery of the generally increasing cost of doing business. A spokesman said that the price increases excluded certain equipment on which cuts of 10 to 15 per cent in purchase prices were announced on July 1. Those cuts involved the IBM System 370 models 115 and 125 central processing units and a number of terminal communications products, along with certain magnetic tape disc storage units, printers and optical recognition devices.

title: Facts in Musicians' Strike
description: Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, representing 300 members of the theater department. Max Arons, president. I. Philip Sipser, special counsel to the theater department.

title: Mayor Says It Never Dawned On Him to Ask Black Caucus Aid
description: Mayor Beame said last night that it never dawned on me to approach the Congressional Black Caucus for aid in getting Federal help during the city's financial crisis.

title: 7 PROFESSORS SUE U. OF TEXAS HEAD
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 30Seven professors at the University of Texas filed suit yesterday against the new university president and Board of Regents, charging that their rights under the First Amendment had been violated.

title: GrainReserve Plan Opposed Abroad
description: LONDON, Sept. 30A United States proposal to create a 30millionton world grain reserve as security against food shortages in the third world drew opposition from the European Common Market today over the method for releasing the grain.

title: Miss Moore Tried to Call Ford Guards Five Times
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Top Secret Service agents told a Congressional hearing today that only a few hours before Sara JaneMoore allegedly tried to assassinate. President Ford she made five attempts to telephone the agents protecting him but was never able to reach them.

title: In This Corner, World Auto Champion, What'sHisName
description: The world champion was in a neutral corner of the world yesterday. Oh, some people recognize me, said Niki Lauda of his day in New York. Then they ask me who I am.

title: Notes on People
description: A little over three weeks after Boris Spassky charged that Soviet officials had jeopardized his marriage plans, the former world chess champion and Marina Stcherbatcheff were married in a twominute ceremony yesterday at the Moscow Wedding Palace. The 38yearold grand master, a divorc, and the 30yearold secretary at the French Embassy, the daughter of Russian emigrs, arrived in his red stationwagon. Unlike most of the brides, who appeared in white gowns and veils, Miss Stcherbatcheff wore white slacks and a white pullover with a string of big blue beads. Mr. Spassky wore a brown sport jacket and russet slacks.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 1, 1975

title: Yale Sets Up School Of Administration With Dual Purpose
description: Yale University will announce today the establishment of a Graduate School of Organization and Management to train leaders for both business and government service.

title: Engagements
description: FishmanFisher

title: U.N. COUNCIL PUTS SPAIN ISSUE ASIDE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30Without a formals vote, Security Council membert decided today against discussing Mexico's demand that Spain be expelled and punished by an economic boycott because of her execution of five terrorists.

title: Everybody Picks on Jet Defense
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 30As if it didn't know, the Jets' defense had to hear it from all sides today about how badly it has been playing. The trouble is, there appears to be no easy answer to help the unit straighten itself out.

title: Pepsico Net Rises 21%
Debate on Sinai Pact Grows in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Three questions are coming to dominate a debate in Washington on the recent Sinai disengagement agreement between Israel and Egypt.

title: POLISH NEGOTIATION CONFIRMED BY G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation confirmed yesterday that it was negotiating with the Polish Government for the design and construction of alighttruck plant in that country.

title: $54,000 RANSOM FREES 4 IN FAMILY
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 30 (AP)The wife and three sons of a General Motors executive were released unharmed today after a $54,000 ransom was paid to their kidnappers.

title: The New Man at Yale
description: When William H. Donaldson was very young he was very poor. But after winning scholarships to preparatory school, Yale University and the Harvard University Graduate School of Business Adrninistration, he founded his own Wall Street concern with $20,000 in borrowed money, married a debutante and made a fortune.

title: Portuguese Timor Raided by lndonesia; A Base Is Wiped Out
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 30 (Reuters)  Indonesian troops, in a strike across the border, wiped out a rebel base in Portuguese East Timor, informed sources said today.

title: Lisbon Lifts Troops
German Trial Will Go On Without the Defendants
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Sept. 30 (Reuters)Disorder broke out today when the chief judge trying alleged leaders of the BaaderMeinhof anarchist group ruled that the trial would continue without the defendants being present.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: Rosemary pooler, executive director of the New York State Consumer Protection Board, has proposed that the new state auto repair law be implemented through a series of tough, consumeroriented regulations.

title: Connors Triumphs As Foe Is Injured
description: KAANAPALI, Hawaii, Sept. 30 (AP)A mishap left Jimmy Connors with little work to do last night in the opening round of the $50,000 Island Holidays tennis tournament.

title: FARMERS' PRICES UP 3% IN MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) Prices farmers receive for raw agricultural products, the first step up the consumer food ladder, jumped 3 per cent from Aug. 15 to Sept. 15, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Student at Queens College Knifed on Flushing Campus
description: A 33yearold Queens College student was stabbed in the back with a pocket knife by an unknown assailant yesterday on the college's Flushing campus.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 30 (AP)  The 84th Tattersalls standardbred yearling sale got off to a record start yesterday with a record handle of more than $2million and a record price paid for a trotting filly. Stanley Dancer, acting as agent for A. M. Cuddy, paid $115,000 for Weeping Cherry, a Castleton Farm yearling by Speedy Scott out of Gay Blossom. The previous record for a filly was $110,000 paid for Romette Hanover in 1972 at Harrisburg, Pa.

title: C.I.A. YIELDS DATA TO MUSE INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The Central Intelligence Agency delivered tonight the bulk of the national security documents subpoenaed two weeks ago by the House Select Committee on intelligence. The move appeared to resolve the stalemate between the committee and President Ford, committee sources said.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City officials reminded landlords and tenants that from today through next May 31 heat is required in all residential buildings when temperatures fall below certain levels. Between 6 A.M. and 10 P.M., an indoor temperature of at least 68 degrees must be maintained when the outdoor reading drops below 55. Between 10 P.M. and 6 A.M., the indoor temperature must be at least 55 when the outdoor temperature is below 40.

title: Amid Heavy Security, Ford and Levi Eulogize the Late Director
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30With pomp, prayer and a President, the Federal Bureau of Investigation dedicated today its new, $126million headquarters building, a buffcolored concrete fortress named for the bureau's late director, J. Edgar Hoover.

title: AIR FARES TO GO UP IN EUROPE, MIDEAST
description: GENEVA, Sept. 30 (Reuters) Air fares in Europe, the Middle East and Africa will go up by 3 to 5 per cent April 1 to meet rising costs, revenue requirements and marketing demands, the International Air Transport Association announced tonight.

title: U.S. Will Let Vietnamese Who Ask to Go Back Do So
description: ASAN, Guam, Sept. 30The United States has decided to allow 1,600 Vietnamese refugees here to return to their homeland as they have requested despite the new Saigon Government's apparent reluctance to accept them.

title: No Legislative Solution Is Foreseen in Coma Case
description: TRENTON, Sept. 30The cosponsor of a bill that would make the cessation of vital brain functions the statutory definition of death in New Jersey said today he did not foresee a Legislative solution to the legal problems posed by the case of Karen Anne Quinlan.

title: Stengel's Death at 85 Widely Mourned
description: Casey Stengel, who died Monday night in California at the age of 85, was mourned yesterday by a public that had marveled for more than 60, years at his antics and achieveIments as a baseball player, coach, manager and nonstop showman.

title: Economic Index Is Steady After Five Months of Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) The Government's index designed to anticipate future economic trends gave an inconclusive signal today, showing no change during August.

title: Chiropractic, Long Ignored as Unscientific, Now Is Increasingly Scrutinized by Health Specialists
description: Chiropractic, long shunned by medicine and assailed as an unscientific cult, is corning under increasing scrutiny by health care specialists, many of whom now regard it as an inevitable part of the American therapeutic scene.

title: Dow Falls 11.35 to 793.88 On InterestRate Worries
description: Stocks retreated along a wide front for the second consecutive day yesterday, reflecting continued investor uneasiness over the prospects of increased Federal borrowing and higher interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial avera?? fell 11.35 points at 793.88.

title: Volcano May Be Test Of Theories on Ozone
description: A 4,000foot volcano, looming over 14 offshore oil rigs in Alaska's Cook Inlet, is swelling ominously and may erupt shortly, according to specialists who have been monitoring it.

title: PENTAGON REMOVES CURBS ON STUDENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) The Pentagon lifted restrictions today on advanced schooling for military students at 14 universities that dropped the Reserve Officers Training Corps during the Vietnam War protest years.

title: Burns's Case for Basic Reforms
description: The major policy statements of Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, often reverberate for months or even years. They sometimes foreshadow important policy changes. Contrarily, they may reflect Dr. Burn's determined resistance to a major policy change be ing pressed by others. One way or another, however, the Burns addresses represent the effort of one of the most literate and experienced economic minds to come to grips with the real economic issues rather than academic shadows that flit on the wall.

title: Kissinger and Madrid Aide Confer on U.S. Bases Pact
description: Pedro Cortina Mauri, the Spanish Foreign Minister, had what American officials termed good talks with Secretary of State Kissinger here today on an agreement to continue American military bases in Spain.

title: Jobs, Prices, Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Is the critical issue facing the country the number of unemployed or the danger of inflation as expressed in the size of the Federal budget deficit?

title: The Cast
description: PAS SI MECHANT QUE CA (Not Really That Bad; English title: The Wonderful Crook), directed by Claude Goretta; screenplay (French with English subtitles) by Mr. Goretta; executive producers. Yves Gasser and Yves Peyrot; director of photography, Renato Berta; editor, Joele van Effenterre; musk, Aria Dzlerlatka; produced by Citel Films, Artco Films, Action Films and M.J. Productions. Running time: 112 minutes. At the New York Film Festival, Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center. This film has not been rated.

title: Court Acts to Aid Mortgagee of Fort Lee Project
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Sept. 30The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company contended today that Hyman R. Shapiro, the builder, had defaulted on a $21.2million mortgage the company held on the 30story Colony apartment building in Fort Lee. The insurer got a court order directing Mr. Shapiro to show why the property should not be put under the control of a receiver.

title: Split on School Pact
Electronic Devices Used To Scan Chicago Crowd
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 30Police officers, equipped for the first time with electronic screening devices, scanned the crowds near President Ford tonight as security precautions during his carefully arranged visit here were increased.

title: SCHOOL AID BACKED IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 30 (UPI)The New Hampshire Supreme Court upheld today limited state aid to parochial schools.

title: About New York
description: Changing neighborhoods is a term that does not always mean neighborhoods that are being transformed. One of the city's charms, sometimes questionable, depending upon which way you are going, lies in the sudden scene shifts that confront a stroller, even on a short walk.

title: Conduct of Prosecution In Carter Trial Defended
description: The new Prosecutor of Passaic County, N.J., Burrell. I. Humphreys, said yesterday that there had been no misconduct by his office or the Paterson Police Department in the triple  murder convictions of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis.

title: Endangered Rescue
description: The threeweekold, emergency state effort to save this cityand the state itselffrom the threat imminent default has been gravely imperiled as the result of a court ruling that the Legislature exceeded its powers in ordering the investment of state and city employe pension funds in Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds.

title: UNIONS IN BAYONNE REACH AGREEMENT
description: BAYONNE, N. J., Sept. 30 (UPI)A tentative wage agreement was reached tonight between this city and five municipal unions who last week held a work stoppage for six days.

title: Mayor and Schools Head Win in Cleveland Primary
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 30 (UPI) Mayor Ralph J. Perk and the school board president, Arnold Pinkney, won the city's nonpartisan Mayoral primary election today and will vie in the Nov. 4 runoff.

title: Loews President Heads a City Panel For the Convention
description: Mayor Beame yesterday appointed Preston Robert Tisch, president of the Loews Corporation, as chairman of a citizens committee to make the 1976 Democratic national convention at Madison Square Garden the most exciting, the most memorable and most successful convention in history.

title: A Block in Flushing Dries Out After Crippling Blow by Floods
description: It looked like a flea market in Naples. Or a gigantic thrift shop. Or the evacuation of houses threatened by the impending eruption of a volcano.

title: Dollars for Pounds: An Interim Report
description: Fat's still selling for more than filet mignon out in Spring. Grove, Ill., and Jim Miller hasn't backed down from his offer to buy all he can get.

title: Congressional Wives Now Involved In Establishing Their Own Careers
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30A year ago, Joan Mondale, the wife of Senator Walter F. Mondale of Minnesota, suddenly found herself unemployed. Her last child no longer came home for lunch and she had cleared her life of all volunteer work as I was planning to help my husband run for President  and he isn't.

title: Kuwait Still at Odds With Gulf and B.P. On an Oil TakeOver
description: KUWAIT, Sept. 30 (AP)Oil Minister Abdel Muttaleb alKazimi, who earlier announced he had concluded a pact with the Gulf Oil Corporation and the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., on the takeover of their operations, late today said he had decided to end negotiations unless they agreed to his proposals.

title: Kissinger's Rating Up In Latest Harris Poll
description: With a 63 per cent positive jobrating from the American people, Secretary of State Kissenger now evokes more confidence from the public than any other member of the Ford Administration, including the President, the Harris Poll says.

title: Harness Drivers Balking at Lie Tests
description: The possibility of a walkout by harness drivers at Roosevelt Raceway arose yesterday after management demands that four drivers take liedetector tests.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
People in Sports
description: Dale Rolfe doesn't have any stiffness or a limp remaining from an ankle injury he suffered in a hockey game on March 2. But Monday night the 6foot4inch Ranger defenseman was advised by the team physician to end his professional career.

title: 4 DEAD IN BEIRUT IN NEW FIGHTING
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 30Fighting between rightist and leftist factions erupted anew today in the southeastern part of Beirut, but banks and stores reopened in other parts of the city.

title: RALPH E. TROWER
description: BROCKTON, Mass., Sept. 30 Ralph E. Trower, formerly for 25 years treasurer of the Tenney Service Company of Boston, parent company of more than 10 utilities concerns, died here today at his home. He was 74 years old.

title: DELIVERIES MARK SUGAR CONTRACTS
description: Notices of large numbers of deliveries marked the end of trading in the October world sugar futures contract ont he New York Coffee and Sugar Exchage yesterday.

title: Word Awaited From Contact on Hoffa Burial Site
description: DETROIT, Sept. 30  Two Senate investigators were awaiting further instructions from their contact with a Mafia family who has promised to mark the site where James R. Hoffa is supposed to be buried.

title: Bridge:
description: Some plays at the bridgetable are so routine that the average player not unnaturally assumes that they are always correct. An example is the defender who has a doubleton queenten and has the opportunity to cover the jack. One might think that it could never be wrong to coverbut it can.

title: Colleges Turn From Resisting to Aiding Students Who Decide to Take a Year Off
description: Some colleges are doing more than just facing up to he pheomenon of the stopout, the increasingly common practice by students to take a year out from college to test themselves in the outside world.

title: Big Quake Recorded In Area of Indonesia
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Oct. 1 (AP)A major earthquake struck on or near the Indonesian island of Sumatra today, the United States Geological Survey reported.

title: Ali Takes Prize Before the Fight
description: MANILA, Wednesday, Oct. 1 (AP)Just before the Muhammad AliJoe Frazier heavyweight championship fight began here, it was announced that the winner would receive a trophy.

title: Joe Was Still Coming In
description: MANILA, Wednesday, Oct. 1When time has cooled the violent passions of the sweltering day and the definitive history is written of the fiveyear war between Muhammad All and Joe Frazier, the objective historian will remember that Joe was still coming in at the finish. For more than 40 minutes, the former heavyweight champion of the world, who was now the challenger, attacked the twotime champion with abandoned, almost joyous, ferocity. For seven rounds in a row he bludgeoned his man with hooks, hounding him into corners, nailing him to the ropes. And then, when Ali seemed hopelessly beaten, he came on like the good champion he is. In the 12th round, the 13th and all through a cruel 14th, Ali punched the shapeless, grinning mask that pursued him until Eddie Futch could take no more.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WEST SIDE VERSE Poetry is alive and well in New York these days. Better yet, it's flourishing: Observers note that there are innumerable poetry workshops, a relatively large quantity of poetry is being published and readings abound.

title: Split on School Pact
Film Festival: Cutting, Radiant 'Xala'
description: Dancing and jubilation in the seaside African capital, where coconut-icing skyscrapers loom over the shanties, the trees are gray with dust and the bougainvillea is like a terminal illness.Africans in bright-colored togas move into the big building in the main square, order out the white men and remove the busts of Napoleon. Next scene: the Africans, in expensive European suits, sit around the table, the white men stand importantly behind as "advisers" and pass them briefcases stuffed with money, the black soldiers push back black crowds and rid the streets of unsightly beggars.In a way, therefore, Osmane Sembene's cutting, radiant and hilarious film "Xala," which opens at the New York Film Festival this evening, is "Animal Farm" applied to Africa independence.It is part fable and part satire, but it is much more: with the greatest fineness and delicacy, Mr. Sembene, the Senegalese writer and director who made this picture, has set out a portrait of the complex and conflicting mesh of traditions, aspirations and frustrations of a culture knocked askew by colonialism and distorting itself anew while climbing out.Mr. Sembene sets his fable not among the new politicians but the new businessmen. The President and his cabinet are in fact the president and governing body of the Chamber of Commerce, but they represent the new lite of corrupt power and corrupt money combined.The story centers on the downfall of El Hadji, one of the pillars of the chamber. El Hadji, a tall, aging man who wears his corruption as a flaring innocence, runs the town's import business. He brings in whisky, perfume, yoghurt and bottled water, which is used, among other things, to wash his white Mercedes-Benz.El Hadji is taking a third wife, and the garden party to celebrate the marriage, attended by the cream of this clotted society, is a comic and mordant masterpiece. Cabinet ministers arrange deals among the whisky, two businessmen discuss plans for "le weekend" and wonder what the English word for it is, a new automobile for the bride arrives tied up in ribbons.It is the series of quick scenes between El Hadji and his first two wives that adds humanity and social dimension, however, Adja, the first wife, is traditional African: a woman with dignity, presence and an angry acceptance of her displacement. The second wife, Oumi, is a fading sexpot, a modern Africanof the nineteen-fifties, with no training whatsoever in acceptance.Bitter rivals at the start, the two women are slowly pushed together by the new threat of the third marriage. In one splendid shot they sit side by side along the wall, bypassed, each holding a plate of food and a glass of Coca-Cola.El Hadji is alone with his young bride and discoversshatteringly  that someone has laid a curse (the "Xala" of the title) upon him. He is impotent.It is a catastrophe: a public one. He consults the President, who sends him to his private witch doctor. El Hadji, in his Paris-made suit, sits in a bush hut being magicked, but to no avail. A second witch doctor is tried, with somewhat better results.But the lionhe is a jackal, really, but the charity Sembene shows to his personages at the same time he is being ruthless with them allows El Hadji dignity as well as squalor  is wounded and must fall. He is implicated in a financial scandal and his fellow thieves at the Chamber of Commerce expel him.Wife Number Two moves out, Wife Number Three is removed by her mother; Wife Number One remains with the stunned and broken El Hadji. His impotence, furthermore, is back upon him: the check he gave the second witch doctor bounced.In comes a procession of crippled beggars that has been seen at various points during the film. El Hadji can become himself again  not himself as a profiteer but himself as a man and an Africanif he will strip and let himself be spit upon.He does, and the end comes with a visual and symbolic wrench. It is too sudden and didacticfurthermore, as is almost inevitable when it is a matter of relentless decline and fallthe movie has already begun to drag.It is a fault but not a ruinous one: "Xala" is an instructive delight.

title: LEE SCHOOLER
description: Lee Schooler, founder and chairman of the Public Relations Board, Inc., group of companies and president of the Chicago Crime Commission, died of cancer on Sunday in Evanston (Ill.) Hospital. He was 52 years old.

title: Followers of Sun Myung Moon Solidify Their Base and Now Look for Respectability
description: It has been just about a year since the benign face of Korean man in a business suit gazed at New Yorkers from, it seemed, every billboard, construction site and subway station in the city.

title: ExMayor Testifies He Paid Freeholders For Favorable Votes
description: MORRISTOWN, Sept. 30 Albert Scaletti, a former Mayor of Riverdale, testified here to day that he had paid $7,000 in bribes to two Passaic County Freeholders in exchange for their votes for the purchase of his commercial garage for $450.000.

title: StateBacked Bonds Drop In Wake of Court Ruling
description: Prices dropped sharply yesterday for New York Staterelated bonds and notes, and trading activity came virtually to a stop in the wake of news that the state's highest court had voided a law designed to help rescue New York City from defaulting on its debt.

title: 2 Get 3Year Terms In Bilking of Aged At a Bronx Home
description: The operator of a Bronx nursing home and a former Fordham Hospital social worker were each sentenced yesterday to three years in jail for looting the bank accounts of two elderly patients at the home, the Bronx District Attorney, Mario Merola, announced.

title: Mike Quarry Defeats Rossman
description: Mike Rossman, who had been beaten only once in 24 fights, never had a better showcase to display his wares than he did last night in Madison Square Garden, but Mike Quarry was the winner by a unanimous decision.

title: Silbert Nomination Voted By Senate Judiciary Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)  The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today the longstalled nomination of Earl J. Silbert, the original Watergate prosecutor, to be the United States attorney for the District of Columbia.

title: Bridge:
description: Some plays at the bridgetable are so routine that the average player not unnaturally assumes that they are always correct. An example is the defender who has a doubleton queenten and has the opportunity to cover the jack. One might think that it could never be wrong to coverbut it can.

title: Stengel Eulogized As a Folk Hero
description: From coast to coast, sometimes in his own idiom, Casey Stengel was eulogized yesterday as a splendid and fairly amazing man who had enlivened baseball and who led the New York Yankees to 10 pennants in 12 years.

title: Film Festival: 'Mechant':An Understated Swiss Comedy by Goretta
description: Switzerland, Swiss film makers seem to be telling us, is a perfect Swiss movement that doesn't deliver the correct time. None of the best Swiss films we've been seeing here recently"La Salamandre," "The Middle of the World" and "The Invitation," among otherscould be easily categorized as social or political in content. They share a comically reserved manner that is hardly the thing for agit-prop. Yet each in its way is as deeply concerned about the quality of life as any of Godard's more revolutionary films.Such a film is "Pas Si Mchant Que Ca" "Not Really That Bad"), the second feature by the extremely gifted Claude Goretta, whose first, "The Invitation," remains one of the most finely boned comedies to be released in New York this year. The new film will be shown at the New York Film Festival tonight at 6:15 and repeated there Friday at 9:30."Pas Si Mchant," which will be titled "The Wonderful Crook" when it is released here commercially, is not a comedy that will have you rolling in the aisles or tossing your hat in the air or even laughing all that much. Which may be a terrible thing to say about a comedy early in a review, but I suspect that audiences need a bit of preparation for this particular Swiss film.It deals in small events, in details so practical that one is apt not to notice the comic attitude it wears. Its method is either carefully elliptical or understated. Indeed, even its overstatements are understatedand it is delightful."Pas Si Mchant" is the story of a not quite perfect son's coming of age in a perfect world. There is some irony in this, of course. He is Pierre (Gerard Depardieu), a happy-go-lucky fellow, married to a sweet, earthy girl and the father of a small child. Pierre works, though not very hard, in his father's small furniture factory, where everything is fashioned with care by hand, of wood that, his father says, breathes.When Pierre's father is incapacitated by a stroke, Pierre must take over the factory and learns to his sorrow that it's such a financial failure it's on the edge of bankruptcy. To meet the payroll Pierre takes to robbing post offices and banks. Each month he packs up a load of furniture that has been ordered by bogus customers, drives into the country where he burns it, and then stops by a bank just before closing for a quick illegal withdrawal.Something is obviously wrong when the kind of workmanship represented by this one factory can no longer be afforded, but then there is also something wrong with Pierre. Mr. Goretta apparently has a cheerfully open mind about bank robbing, which is one of the pleasures of the film, but not about Pierre, which is what gives the film its impact.Pierre, as charming as he is, deceitfully implicates everyone he would protect, including both his wife, Marthe (Dominique Labourier) and the plucky young woman, Nelly (Marene Jobert), whom he meets in the course of a heist and who subsequently becomes his mistress.Pierre has style and he displays a good deal of grace under pressure, but he's a crybaby too. With the best of intentions, he winds up failing everyone, especially Nelly, who has joined his life of mini-crime with her eyes wide open.Mr. Goretta's direction looks deceptively simple. The characters and situations seem familiar at the start, yet little by little, scene by scene, you realize that the film is not simple at all, as when Pierre, rough-housing with his son, becomes just as excited and semihysterical as the child. In another scene the patrons of a corner bar watch an Italian immigrant worker dancing drunkenly with a vase of flowers, making everyone desperately uncomfortable. Obliquely we learn more than we ever thought possible.Mr. Depardieu is very funny and complex in the pivotal role, which is not totally appealing, though the women's roles are. Philippe Leotard, the hero of "The Middle of the World," is fine in a supporting role, as is Michel Robin, the lonely bachelor of "The Invitation." A whole different subject is the superior quality of the ensemble acting in these new Swiss productions.

title: Philadelphians, With Stern, Return to Carnegie
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra began its concert at Carnegie Hall Monday night with Beethoven's Leonore Overture No. 3, but Home, Sweet Home might have been a good choice, too. After giving its annual New York series for the last 12 seasons at Lincoln Center in Avery Fisher (n Philharmonic) Hall, the Philadelphians came back to West 57th Street for the first of eight concerts they will present in Carnegie this season.

description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Music: Year of the Tuba
description: This may he the year of the tuba for New York City. There will be no fewer than 10 programs by tuba players in Carnegie Recital Hall, presented by Harvey Phillips, himself a tubist, and Twentieth Century Innovations. The series was initiated appropriately enough, on Monday night by Roger Bobo, a pathbreaker in the field, who gave the first tuba recital here in 1961. At that time he was a member of the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra. Since 1964 he has been solo tubist with the Los Angeles Philharmonic.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Merrill Lynch Turns Bullish on Seminars
description: The bullish boys at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith apparently believe that a little education can make the investing public similarly bullish. Hence, on Oct. 27 at 300 locations, the country's largest brokerage firm initiates a weeklong program of seminars and forums under the engaging title of How to Manage Your Money in Today's Changing Economy.

title: Tickets for Ford's Dinner Selling Like Cold Cakes
description: TRENTON, Sept. 30Republican leaders here said this evening that thus far they had sold only about half the $100aplate tickets they hoped to sell for President Ford's fundraising appearance in Newark on Saturday.

title: PROFESSORS ASSAIL CHARTER CHANGES
description: Forty urban experts at colleges and universities in the metropolitan area said yesterday that the 10 proposed revisions of the City Charter would, if approved, foster dismemberment of the city, place power in the hands of parochial party figures and generally weaken city government.

title: ConsumerCase Backlog Held Eased
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Sept. 30 State consumer officials said today that a new system of handling consumer complaints had cleared up a backlog of nearly 10,000 cases since January

title: Letters to the editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mortgagee Goes to Court to Request Receivership for Colony Apartments
description: HACKENSACK, Sept. 30The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company contended today that Hyman R. Shapiro, the builder, had defaulted on a $21.2million mortgage the company held on the 30story Colony apartment building in Fort Lee. The insurer got a court order directing Mr. Shapiro to show why the property should not be put under the control of a receiver.

title: C.I.A YIELDS DATA TO HOUSE INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The Central Intelligence Agency delivered tonight the bulk of the national security documents subpoenaed two weeks ago by the House Select Committee on Intelligence. The move appeared to resolve the stalemate between the committee and President Ford, committee sources said.

title: HIROHITO ARRIVES FOR TOUR IN U.S.
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 30Emperor Hirohito stepped off a Japan Air Lines jet plane at nearby Patrick Henry Airport this morning to begin a 15day visit to the United States.

title: McDonnell Douglas Seeks A Joint Venture in Canada
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation of St. Louis announced yesterday that it had made a proposal to restructure the Canadian aerospace industry at the request of Canada if that country would commit itself to procure 127 CF15 Eagle air superiority fighters. Money terms of the pro posal were not disclosed, but similar planes in this country have an average price of $12million, making the deal worth more than $1.5billion.

title: Chairman Pike's Pique
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The statements on Capitol Hill these days sound more and more like communiqus from a battlefield. In its zeal to restore the balance of power with the executive branch, the Congress seems in danger of losing its own balance.

title: BANKS RESISTING NEW STATE ISSUE OF NOTES FOR CITY
description: A second crucial element in the financial package for staving off a New York City default appeared jeopardized yesterday by a growing unwillingness of bankers to buy the $500million In shortterm notes the state is due to issue over the next two months on the city's behalf.

title: Advertising
description: Account people who don't work for agencies in the top 25 are generally happy that they don't.

title: Bubba and Baby Reunited by Oilers
description: The Houston Oilers have signed Charles (Bubba) Smith, en action that prolongs the career of a star defensive lineman who deserved the extension. The Houston coach, Bum Phillips, told Smith that he was satisfied with his threeman line of Elvin Bethea, Curly Culp and Lawrence (Tody) Smith, that Bubba would not be playing right away, but that the Oilers were happy to have him.

title: Stengel's Death at 85 Widely Mourned
description: Casey Stengel, who died Monday night in California at the age of 85, was mourned yesterday by a public that had marveled for more than 60, years at his antics and achieveIments as a baseball player, coach, manager and nonstop showman.

title: ExIm Bank Head Put Stock in Trust, Profited on Its Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Henry Kearns, when he was head of the Government's ExportImport Bank in 1972, promoted an apparently highly profitable sale of stock he had placed in a blind trust and received some of the proceeds of the sale, it was disclosed today.

title: TV: A Fine Edward II in Classic Theater Series
description: Public television's latest cultural tour, packaged by Boston station WGBH, is called Classic Theaterthe Humanities in Draina. The classictheater portion consists of 13 British Broadcasting Corporation productions, spanning four centuries of literature. The humanities are displayed rather selfconsciously in special background previews created for the series in this country. Designed as visual playbills, the previews feature Joan Sullivan, WGBH producer, interviewing scholars and actors.

title: Meat Seller Held in Bribe to Get City Approval of Tainted Ham
description: The head of a major meat company in Queens was indicted by a Kings County grand jury yesterday on a charge of bribing a state Inspector in an effort to sell 4,500 pounds of contaminated fresh hams that had been impounded. But the inspector reported the bribery attempt and the meat was never released.

title: A Chastened, Sore Ali Praises His Rival
description: MANILA, Wednesday, Oct. 1 (AP)He could have whupped anybody in the world except me, a chastened Muhammad Ali said after having successfully defeated his world heavyweight boxing crown today with a 14thround knockout against a name Joe Frazier.

title: $650MILLION DEFICIT POSSIBLE FOR STATE
description: The state's deficit may run as high as $650million, $50million more than Governor Carey warned, according to budget offocials analyzing revenues and expenditures for the first half of the AprilMarch fiscal year.

title: Astronaut Tour in Soviet Taps a Flood of Warmth
description: VOLGOGRAD, U.S.S.R., Sept. 28The crowds are everywhere. Outside the hotels and restaurants, near the monuments and in the parks where the astronauts are expected to appear, people stand and wait, sometimes for hours.

title: Ellen Rotberg Kraemer Wed to Murray Chass
description: Ellen Rotberg Kraemer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Rotberg of Short Hills, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Murray Chess, a sports writer with The New York Times.

title: Islamic Ministers At U.N. Ease Stand On Ousting Israel
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y, Sept. 30Foreign ministers of 40 Islamic countries, grouped in the Islamic Conference, met at United Nations today and revised an earlier resolution concerning Israel.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: New Jersey will implement a broad plan of social services made possible through a Federal grant of $88million, Governor Byrne said yesterday. Mr. Byrne said the plan, administered by the state Department of Institutions and Agencies, would allow New Jersey to receive its total Federal allocation during the current fiscal year.

title: MADRID REJECTS FOREIGN PROTESTS
description: MADRID, Sept. 30Premier Carlos Arias Navarro tonight angrily denounced international protests against Spain over the execution of five terrorists and called on the Spanish people to unite behind Generalissimo Francisco Franco and the Government.

title: FIRST BARGES GET TO PRUDHOE BAY
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Sept. 30In a path hacked through the ice by two Coast Guard cutters, the first of 15 barges with key pipeline supplies reached Prudhoe Bay today.

title: About Real Estate
description: In a corner of Middle Village in Queens near the tracks of the Long Island Railroad, there was a cornmeicial laundry many years ago. Now the same building is a warehouse. Around the corner someone is making industrial springs in a former garage. Nearby, another small industrial building that used to be a machine shop is producing ribbons.

title: Howard Cosell vs. the World
description: America might not have known it, but it faced a delicate crisis a short while back. Howard Cosell had hinted that unless he catapulted from the puerile precincts of sports, he might run for the U.S. Senate.

title: City Gives Breakdown Of Financial Package
description: The following table indicates the elements of the $2.3billion emergency financial plan for New York City and how much of each has been committed so far, according to the Municipal Assisance Corporation and the New York City Controller's office.

title: Israel and Syria Give the U.N. Assembly Divergent Views on Possibility of Golan Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30Irael and Syria presented sharply conflicting views to the United Nations today.

title: MAN IN FORD CASE SUES NEWSPAPERS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30 (AP)Oliver W. Sipple, the exMarine credited with thwarting, an apparent attempt to assasinate President Ford, filed a $15million lawsuit today against the press for reporting that he was homosexual.

title: Dr. James Cusick, Taught Economics at Dartmouth
description: Dr. James F. Cusick, professor emeritus of economics at Dartmouth College and a former Ford Foundation consultant on curriculum evaluation at other colleges, died Monday in Hanover, N. H. He was 77 years old.

title: TRIAL OF CARTER IS CALLED PROPER
description: The new Prosecutor of Passaic County, N.J., Burrell I. Humphreys, said yesterday that there had been no misconduct by his office or the Paterson Police Department in the triplemurder convictions of Rubin (Hurricane) Carters and John Artis.

title: Market Place
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission may inadvertently have caused a delay in plans by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenper & Smith, Inc., to institute an innovative program to help the small investor cut commission costs, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: Prosecutors in Hearst Case to Meet; Her Attorneys Warn of a Breakdown
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30A group of toplevel law enforcement officers concerned with possible state and Federal prosecutions of Patricia Hearst and members of the socalled Symbionese Liberation Army will meet tomorrow in the offices of United States Attorney James L. Browning Jr., who is pressing for a bank robbery indictment against Miss Hearst.

title: BANKS RESISTING NEW STATE ISSUE OF NOTES FOR CITY
description: A second crucial element in the financial package for staving off a New York City default appeared jeopardized yesterday by a growing unwillingness of bankers to buy the $500million in shortterm notes the state is due to issue over the next two months on the city's behalf.

title: PRESIDENT ASKS $13MILLION MORE FOR PROTECTION
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 30President Ford, after asking Congress today for $13.5million more this year for Secret Service protection, said tonight that he would continue traveling across the country not in any foolhardy spirit, but by every prudent and practical means.

title: Fuji Bank Chairman Sees Japan Facing a Period of Economic Woes
description: TOKYOA leading Japanese banker has issued a warning that the Japanese banking community is facing a period of trouble as this nation's economy shifts from high to low rates of growth.

title: Kissinger and Senior Official Deal With Dizzying Host of Issues at U.N.
description: Secretary of State Kissinger sits at a 45degree angle in an armchair, his head back against the wooden frame, his leg?? stretched out to the carpet.

title: HOUSE CUTS FUNDS FOR RIFLE TRAINING
description: oetaoin shrdlu shrdi shrdlud WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) The House removed today from a Department of Defense appropriations bill the funding for a program of Armysupported civilian rifle training that had existed since 1903.

title: SexShift in Australia: A Cyclone Named Alan
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 30 (Reuters)Australia's next cyclone will have a masculine name, putting an end to a long list of exclusively feminine cyclone code names, it was announced today.

title: STATE WILL OFFER TOLLBRIDGE PLAN
description: The Carey administration plans to submit a substitute proposal in the hope of revising or replacing the new Federal directive requiring tolls by mid1977 on all bridges across the East and Harlem Rivers. Details will be worked out later.

title: Europe's Outcry at Spanish Executions Reflects Repugnance at Franco's Rule
description: ROME, Sept. 30The protests against the execution of the five Spanish terrorists continue in Western Europe, the faces of the dead peer out from posters, ambassadors are being called home from Madrid and the repercussions from the work of the firing squad are far from over.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in The New York Times last Saturday listed incorrect figures for oil production in September, 1973, by several member states of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. A corrected version of the table appears on Page 77.

title: Lefkowitz Seeks Penalties On Late Filing on Lobbyists
description: ALBANY, Sept. 30 (AP)State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz brought actions today seeking penalties against two corporations for failing to meet the deadline on financial statements on lobbyists hired for the 1975 state legislative session.

title: A State Financing Agency Finds Loan Market Is Shut
description: Officials of the state's Housing Finance Agency, facing the need to raise $69million in the next two weeks, have been told by bankers that the borrowing market is closed to it for the foreseeable future.

title: Diplomat Rejected In Bid to Replace Hostage in London
description: LONDON, Sept. 30 (Reuters) Italy's consul general in London tonight offered to take the place of one of six Italians held hostage here by three gunmen, but the police refused to agree.

title: Ford to Nominate Attorney
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)President Ford said today that he would nominate Peter R. Taft of Santa Monica, Calif., as Assistant Attorney General for Land and Natural Resources. A White House announcement said Mr. Taft, 39 years old, would succeed Wallace H. Johnson Jr., who resigned Sept. 2.

title: F.T.C. GIVES VIEW ON COOPERATIVES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 30 (UPI) Agricultural cooperatives appear to dominate the markets for milk, fruits and nuts andthrough Government regulationsmay have an impact on prices that runs counter to some consumer interests, a Federal Trade Commission report said today.

title: Market Continuing Sluggish In FixedIncome Securities
description: Growing concern over the Government's mounting budget deficit and the possibility of higher interest rates continued to keep most of the fixedincome securities market in the doldrums yesterday.

title: Women Are Still Hesitant About Aiming High in Politics
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 28Although more and more women are running for public office, very few expect to make a try for the highest offices, even at the peak of their careers, according to a study on women's attitudes.

title: A Mule Trader at Yale Gives Glimpse of Past
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 30I mean there'd at least $150 of hamburger meat in this here horse. This is a right healthy animal. Usually, at this age, they have more knots than a cedar tree.

title: Forget Redskin Horror
description: Still smarting from their embarrassing 4913 defeat at the hands of the Washington Redskins on Sunday, the New York Giants worked out a little more than usual yesterday at their Pleasantville, N. Y.. training camp.

title: Teachers' Union in Parsippany Fined $100,000
description: MORRISTOWN, Sept. 30Judge Jacques H. Gascoyne of Morris County Court fined the striking ParsippanyTroy Hills Education Association $100,000 today and threatened to jail its leaders if the strike did not end by tomorrow morning. The leaders pleaded guilty to criminal contempt charges as the strike continued for a 10th day in defiance of a court order.

title: ExBank Executives Arraigned in Case On Shipping Scheme
description: Three former bank executives and a businessman were arraigned yesterday on charges stemming from an alleged scheme led by two Greek shipowners to defraud American and British banks of more than $60million, United Press International reports.

title: U.S., Alone in Vote, Vetoes Admissions Of Vietnams in U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 30The United States today vetoed the admission of North and South Vietnam to the United Nations in an action that found it isolated from its friends as well as its critics.

title: An Alleged Gift by N.M.U. To Ford Splits 2 Agencies
description: The United States Attorney for New Jersey and the Internal Revenue Service have become embroiled in an intense dispute over each agency's handling of an allegation that Gerald R. Ford may have received an unusual payment from leaders of the National Maritime Union around 1968.

title: Callaway Says Ford Faces Two Very Difficult Primaries Against Reagan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30President Ford faces a very difficult time in winning early Presidential primaries next year in New Hampshire and Florida against former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California, Mr. Ford's campaign manager said today.

title: Cooking in the New French Style and Cutting Down the Calories
description: PELHAM, N.Y.As anyone conversant with French cooking can testify, the chef who is currently hailed as the messiah of the French kitchen is a notably slender, 5foot 3inch, boyishlooking, 42yearold chef.

title: C.I.A. Budget Reported In Air Force's Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)Representative Robert N. Giaimo, Democrat of Connecticut, said today that the topsecret budget for the Central Intelligence Agencytraditionally hidden in allotted outlays for other agencieswas concealed in a $2billion appropriation for the Air Force.

title: An Alleged Gift by N.M.U. To Ford Splits 2 Agencies
description: The United States Attorney for New Jersey and the Internal Revenue Service have become embroiled in an intense dispute over each agency's handling of an allegation that Gerald R. Ford may have received an unusual payment from leaders of the National Maritime Union around 1968.

title: Dunlop Favors Continuing Tax Cutbacks Indefinitely
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Secretary of Labor John T. Dunlop said today that he favored indefinite continuation of the individual and corporate tax cuts that were enacted earlier this year as an antirecession measure.

title: MUCH TORTURING OF BASQUES CITED
description: LONDON, Sept. 30Basque prisoners have been tortured on a massive scale, an Amnesty International report said today.

title: Miss Moore Tried to Call Ford Guards Five Times
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Top Secret Service agents told a Congressional hearing today that only a few hours before Sara Jane Moore allegedly tried to assassinate President Ford she made five attempts to telephone the agents protecting him but was never able to reach them.

title: Manila Excited; Fans Searched
description: MANILA, Wednesday, Oct1 (AP)  Everybody was searched at Clio gate.

title: REARING STARTED ON HEALTH AGENCY
description: Health care here now is a fragmented, costly and inefficient system, speakers agreed at a hearing yesterday designed to meet a Federal mandate to devise a more efficient system, but there was no unanimity on who should control the system.

title: JOB ACTION PLANS ON CAMPUS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30F. David Mathews, Secretary of Health, Educatio and Welfare, said today that he did not think colleges and universities should be exempted fromaf firmative action plans to end employment discrimination in higher education.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Tuesday.

title: '75 Data Show Slight Drop In Rate of U.S. Crime Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)  The nation's serious crime rate tapered off slightly in the first six months of 1975 but this statistic offers no great solace, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: Kodes Is Hero, Roche Goat as the Davis Cup Comes Up With a Rare AllEuropean Final
description: Jan Kodes was the hero and Tony Roche the goat as the Davis Cup came up with a raritythe first allEuropean final since 1933. Czechoslovakia, which beat Australia, will play Sweden for the coveted trophy Dec. 28 indoors in Stockholm.

title: British National Theater To Open at Last, Actually
description: LONDON, Sept. 30For 11 years, Britain's National Theater has suffered from a situation that would do justice to Catch22: it wasn't ready to open because it wasn't properly financed, and it wasn't properly financed because people doubted whether it would ever open.

title: BETTER CARE VOWED BY KENNEL'S OWNER
description: The owner of Campo Lindo, a vacation home for pets in Margaretville, N.Y., has signed an agreement with the State Attorney General's office to discontinue practices that resulted in more than a score of complaints.

title: 15 Die in Thai Explosion
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 30 (UPI)A grenade exploded at a protest meeting in southern Thailand today, killing 15 people and wounding at least 16, the police reported. The explosion came as a highranking police officer sought to negotiate a settlement in a protest against foreignowned mining companies in the coastal Phangnga Province, 500 miles southwest of Bangkok.

title: Financial Writers Follies Set
2 State Senate Units Study OTB Plan to Buy Garden
description: The State Senate Finance Committee is looking ino negotiations on the possible purchase of Madison Square Garden by the Offrack Betting Corporation, and the State Senate Select Committee on Crime is investigating possible organizedcrime involvement in the operations of the Garden, officials of both committees said yesterday.

title: Brooklyn Diocese Says It May Close One of 4 Schools Disrupted by Strike
description: The superintendent of schools in the Brooklyn diocese suggested Yesterday that the diocese might have to permanently close one of the four high schools where classes have been disrupted by the fourweek strike by lay teachers.

title: ETHIOPIA COMBATS CHALLENGE BY LABOR
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 30 (Reuters)Ethlopta's military Government declared a state of emergency today in Addis Ababa and the surrounding area in the face of a mounting challenge from workers and students.

title: ExIm Bank Head Put Stock in Trust, Profited on Its Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Henry. Kearns, when he was head of the Government's ExportImport Bank in 1972, promoted an apparently highly profitable sale of stock he had placed in a blind trust and received some of the proceeds of the sale, it was disclosed today.

title: Eastern Airlines Requests Weekend Shuttle Fare Cut
description: The airrailbus fare battle in the Northeast intensified yesterday with word from Eastern Airlines that it was seeking Government permission to slash the price of shuttle tickets on weekends.

title: Under law, rape was at first a crime only against a father's property. But that has changed.
description: The difference between human beings and cows, someone once told me, is that cows may have a genealogy but only human beings have a history. When I first became concerned with rape as a human phenomenon, the idea seized my mind that rape must have a history, too.

title: JERSEY CITY LEASE SIGNED BY WEEDEN
description: Efforts of New York City to head off the departure of Weeden & Co., the big New York brokerage house, to New Jersey failed yesterday with the disclosure that Weeden had signed a fiveyear lease for space in a new 15story building in downtown Jersey City.

title: Panel Can't Decide to Take Up Tax on Multinational Concerns
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The House Ways and Means Committee, after debating the Issue all day before a standingroomonly crowd of corporate lawyers and lobbyists, was unable to decide today whether or not even to take up the issue that had attracted the crowd.

title: No More Magic Tricks
description: In warning that the new agreement between the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers would have to be voided if its cost exceeds the budget, Governor Carey has faced up to an issue that transcends this particular union contract. Alerted by the Emergency Financial Control Board to the possibility of a costoverrun that could amount to more than $80 million, the Governor put the spotlight on a major source of the city's fiscal disorderthe longstanding habit of reaching labor settlements at a cost far in excess of the amounts presented to the public.

title: Labor Leaders Assert the Economic Situation Is a Dangerous Mess
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations described the economic situation in the United States today as the most dangerous mess in 40 years and warned of a slow recovery with high unemployment continuing to persist.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Two seasons of modern dance with 12 participating companies will be presented at the Roundabout Stage One on West 23d Street.

title: Rangers Put A.H.L. Club To Rout
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 30 (AP)Pat Hickey, former World Hockey Association star, led the New York Rangers of the National Hockey League to a 94 exhibitiongame victory over the New Haven Nighthawks of the American Hockey League tonight. Hickey had three goals.

title: Foundling Hospital Honour President of Advisory Board
description: The New York Foundling Hospital last night presented its first Elizabeth A. Seton Humanitarian Award to John A. Coleman, a member and longtime president of the hospital's advisory board.

title: Costly Music Strike Spreads to Midwest
description: As the financial impact of the musicians' strike that has shut 12 Broadway musical productions deepened here yesterday, contract disputes with the American Federation of Musicians also forced postponement of performances by the symphony orchestras in Pittsburgh and Detroit.

title: HUSSEIN MEDIATES ON SINAI PACT RIFT
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 28King Hussein of Jordan has been quietly attempting to soften the war of words between Egypt and Syria over the new Sinai pact and bring about a reconciliation between President Anwar elSadat of Egypt and President Hafez alAssad of Syria, according to authoritative sources here.

title: A State Financing Agency Finds Loan Market Is Shut
description: Officials of the state's Housing Finance Agency, facing the need to raise $69million in the next two weeks, have been told by bankers that the borrowing market is closed to it for the foreseeable future.

title: Congress Takes Slowly To the Age of Computers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 Bells signaling a rollcall vote were ringing as the Representative sped through the long tunnel connecting one of the House office buildings to the Capitol.

title: Rangers Sparkle In Victory
description: The Rangers looked ready to open their National Hockey League season last night. Playing a nearperfect game, they routed the Boston Bruins, 40, held the great Phil Esposito to a single shot on goal, afforded Gilles Villemure and Ed Giacomin the utmost protection around the net and outshot their rivals, 3721.

title: Bauxite Tax Testing Arbitration Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. ?? The United States Government has taken a keen interest in a slowmoving, but probably precedentsetting, international ??itration proceeding involving three big United States aluminum companies and the Government of Jamaica over taxes on bauxite.

title: CORRECTION
Pope and Greek Premier Confer on Diplomatic Ties
description: ROME, Oct. 1Pope Paul VI and Premier Constantine Caramanlis of Greece today discussed the possible establishment of full diplomatic relations between Athens and the Vatican.

title: Garden Halts Negotiation On Sale of Arena to OTB
description: The Madison Square Garden Corporation yesterday called off negotiations on the possible sale of the Garden to the Offtrack Betting Corporation, declaring that vilification and public misconception had clouded the negotiations.

title: MALPRACTICE RATE UP 50% IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 1Premium rates for medical malpractice insurance for New Jersey physicians will increase by an average of nearly 50 per cent, the state's Insurance Commissioner, James J. Sheeran, announced today. The rates for new policies will be effective immediately. For renewal policies, they will be effective Nov. 1.

title: 3 POLICEMEN SLAIN AS FRANCO RALLIES THRONGS IN MADRID
description: MADRID, Oct. 1  As vast throngs gathered in Madrid today to cheer Generalissimo Francisco Franco, gunmen shot and killed three policemen in various parts of the city and badly wounded a fourth.

title: Baseball's Larry MacPhail Dies; Started Night Games, Led Y anks
description: Larry MacPhail, one of the great innovators and impresarios of baseball and the man who brought night games to the major leagues 40 years ago, died yesterday in Miami. He was 85 years old.

title: Film: Violent 'Framed':Corruption Triumphs in Story of Gambler
description: Although its plot is convoluted, "Framed," which arrived yesterday at Loews State 2 and other houses, is basically uncomplicated. Crime, it's obvious here, is not subtle. The writer-director star team of Mort Briskin, Phil Karlson and Joe Don Baker, who previously struck a bonanza with "Walking Tall," are now simply fighting gunfire with gunfire and beatings with beatings. "Walking Tall" may have-dramatized the true story of a crusading, if violent, Tennessee sheriff, but "Framed" is not so much the business of justice triumphing as it is corruption and violence triumphant.Our hero-gambler-night-club-owner's luck is bad from the start when he wins a big bundle at poker. Almost immediately he runs into a murderous, if mysterious, ambush, a slugging match with a deputy he kills in self defense and a frame-up by the cops and shadowy political types that lands him in jail. But our tough boy takes no pushing around and, with the aid of a gangster big shot who admires his guts and gambling, he's out, muscles quivering and gun in hand, to get his framers and, of course, his loot.As the indestructible gambler, Joe Don Baker convincingly combines a linebacker's physique and a laconic Southern talk to absorb a going-over that hospitalizes him and then engages in a succession of bloody clashes that dispatches a platoon of the rough opposition, including one whose ear he shoots off.All this action is not that unusual, of course, but it does include some workman-like performances by, among others, Gabriel Dell, as Mr. Baker's prison pal and a hit man; John Marley, as the gang boss who aids him, and Brock Peters, as an honest deputy. Conny Van Dyke, our hero's pretty girlfriend as well as singer and partner, who has been mauled and raped by the bad guys, may not be just plain folks but she is awfully logical when she says after one gory bout, "I just don't understand you."

title: Personal Finance: Alimony Lawsuits
description: A new matrimonial law that went into effec in New York Sept. 1 requires compulsory financial disclosure by both parties in all divorce proceedings where alimony or support is an issue. Each party must swear to a statement of net worth that will be made available to the other party before the trial starts.

title: Bankers to Suggest Ways To Avert H.F.A. Default
description: A panel of banking experts is expected to recommend today a series of changes, including special legislative action, in an attempt to strengthen the State Housing Finance Agency so the troubled agency might regain entry to the borrowing market.

title: Casual Audience Applauds Casual Dior Styles
description: It's not quite the same as the revolution the late Christian Dior unleashed to a receptive world close to 30 years ago. With his 1947 New Look, Dior put bones into bodices, pads into hiplines, petticoats into skirts, and linings into everything. To say a dress was stiff enough to stand by itself was not only a clich: frequently it was true.

title: Venezuelan Sees Waning of 3d World Barking
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 1 (UPI)Venezuela's President, Carlos Andres Perez, warned today that dangerous pressures threaten to erode support by the world's developing countries of actions taken by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: 3 Sisters Defend Sun Myung Moon Sect Against Sheeran's Kidnapping Charges
