description: While New Jersey's State Insurance Commissioner stood outside accusing the Unification Church of brainwashing his three daughters, the daughters were saying at a news conference yesterday that it was their father who had been duped and that they feared their parents would try to kidnap them.

title: Triborough Ageney Cites Traffic Drop Since Toll Increase
description: With higher tolls in effect since Sept. 1, motorvehicle traffic at the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority facilities was down by 7.8 per cent in the first three weeks of September, compared with the same period last year. But revenues were up 35 per cent.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Members of the ParsippanyTroy Hills Education Association approved a tentative contract agreement with the Board of Education, and the teachers have returned to classrooms, ending a 10day walkout. The agreement calls for salary increases totaling 16 per cent over a twoyear period. The district's 10,800 students will go back to school this morning.

title: TV: CBS Dramatizes John Faulk's Fear on Trial
description: Tonight at 9 o'clock, CBSTV performs quite impressively in the cause of quality drama but considerably less so in the service of the unvarnished truth. The occasion is a twohour dramatization of Fear on Trial, the autobiography of John Henry Faulk, a radio and TV performer whose broadcasting career was virtually destroyed by blacklisting horrors of the McCarthyite nineteenfifties

title: Negotiator Reports On Talks
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 1 (UPl)A high United States negotiator said today grain talks with the Soviet Union were running smoothly and he hoped he could quickly wrap up the latest round of negotiations for a longterm deal. He added, however, he still did not know when an agreement could be reached.

title: Goal at Buzzer Wins For Nets
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., Oct. 1 (AP)AI Skinner, a secondyear pro from the University of Massachusetts, connected on a. 25foot 3point goal as the buzzer sounded tonight to give the New York Nets a 107104 victory over the Denver Nuggets in an American Basketball Association exhibition game.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Wednesday.

title: Tribunal Tested
Cubs' Thornton Cited
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 (AP)  Andy Thornton, Chicago Cubs first baseman, was named today National League player of the month for September. Thornton batted .321 with 27 hits, eight home runs, and 21 runs batted in.

title: House Panel Votes to End Overseas Tax Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to terminate over a fouryear period the special tax advantages that are available to most Americans who work overseas. An exception was made for persons who work for charitable, educational, religious and similar organizations.

title: Camden Detective Is Slain; DrugRaid Link Rejected
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 1A 24yearold undercover detective was shot to death here this afternoon, eight hours after he had participated in a series of police raids in Camden and Gloucester Counties in which 25 drugdealing suspects arrested.

title: 6 Killed in Quebec in Blast At an Explosives Factory
description: BELOEIL, Quebec, Oct. 1 (AP)An explosion in a building at an explosives plant in nearby McMasterville today killed at least six persons, the police reported.

title: Islanders Tie
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 1 CAP)Billy Harris scored a goal midway in the final period tonight to give the New York Islanders a 11 tie with the Atlanta Flames.

title: Garden Halts Negotiation On Sale Of Arena to OTB
description: The Madison Square Garden Corporation yesterday called off negotiations on the possible sale of the Garden to the Offtrack Betting Corporation, declaring that vilification and public misconception had clouded the negotiations.

title: France to Tax Fuel Oil
description: PARIS, Oct. 1 (Reuters)The French Government announced today it was instituting a new tax on industrial fuel oil consumption.

title: Petula Clark Is at Empire Room With Medley of Her Biggest Hits
description: Starting with Downtown in late 1964, Petula Clark enjoyed a threeyear series of pop hits in this country. Since 1967 she has continued her career in clubs, concerts, television and films, even if her record sales haven't kept pace with her successes of the midnineteensixties. And Tuesday night she opened a run at the WaldorfAstoria's Empire Room that will continue through Oct. 11.

title: House Rejects, 267147, Move to Disclose C.I.A. Budget to the Public
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The House of Representatives decided overwhelmingly today to continue to keep the budget of the Central Intelligence Agency secret from the public.

title: Facts in Musicians' Strike
description: Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, representing 300 members of the theater department. Max Arons, president. I. Philip Sipser, special counsel to the theater department.

title: Books of The Times
description: It may sound like a routine spy thriller. The assassin stalks a high British Government official, lately the Number Two man in Belfast. The assassin corners his quarry in front of his London home, guns him down while his wife and children look on. and makes a clean escape back to his own home in Ulster. The Prime Minister demands immediate action, fearing that if the Irish Republican Army Provisionals get away with the murder it will prove an incitement to further highlevel assassination. Scotland Yard recruits an undercover man, an army captain and former intelligence agent named Harry James Brown, and dispatches him to locate the killer and gun him down. Harry holes up in Belfast and begins to grub around for his man. The I.R.A. catches on and turns the fox on the hound. The two begin to grope for each other, opponents playing chess in the dark. Pawns fall by the wayside. Tension mounts.

title: New Shares of A.T. &T. Sell Well at $46
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday priced its big offering of 12 million shares of common stock at $46 a share, and its underwritersled by Morgan Stanley & Co.formally put the stock on the market and reported the sale a success.

title: U.S. Is Rated Low on Energy Saving; OPEC Is Warned on Loss of Confidence
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The United States ranks near the bottom of a list of oilconsuming nations' energy conservation efforts since the 1973 Arab oil embargo, the 18nation International Energy Agency says.

title: Hooton Again Honored
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 (UPI)Burt Hooton of the Los Angeles Dodgers was named National League pitcher of the month for September. He also won the honor for August.

title: Rumors of Arms Flow, Even of a Coup Plan, Circulate in Lisbon
description: LISBON, Thursday, Oct. 2Reports circulated through Lisbon last night that leftist miliLary units were distributing arms to civilians.

title: Carey Lobbies for Federal Help Here
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Governor Carey proposed Federal legislation today to guarantee municipal loans, lobbied among some of his old friends In Congress, but acknowledged that he did not have the votes.

title: Frazier's Plans Still in Limbo
description: MANILA, Thursday, Oct. 2 Joe Frazier delayed today a decision on retirement from boxing until late next week in Philadelphia, when he will sit down and discuss his plans with his manager, Eddie Futch.

title: Life in Beirut Again Disrupted by Strife; 6 More Are Killed
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 1Rightist and leftist factions battled through last night in the southeastern part of Beirut, and police sources said today that six people had been killed and 11 wounded.

title: Market Loses More Ground; Dow Slides by 9.72 to 784.16
description: The stock market lost more ground yesterday in moderate trading. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 24.72 points on the first two trading days this week, fell another 9.72 points to close at 784.16.

title: Nassau's Long Count
description: The people of Nassau County may yet get a oneman, onevote legislaturebut then again they may not. In November they will be voting for legislators who may not have a legislature to sit in. Both major parties have now nominated candidates for the legislature, but the Republican leaders who dominate the Board of Supervisors are campaigning against the legislature itself.

title: Airlines of the World Support 3% Fare Rise
description: OSLO, Norway, Oct. 1 (UPI) Faced with an increase in fuel prices, executives of the world5s airlines today overwhelmingly recommended a worldwide 3 per cent fare increase effective Dec. 1.

title: Emperor Hirohito Tours Colonial Williamsburg
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 1 Emperor Hirohito, who symbolizes the unity and continuity of the Japanese nation, today had a look around Colonial Williamsburg, a reconstruction of part of America's past.

title: A Quadriplegic Lawyer Scores Entrances to Public Buildings
description: Curtis Brewer, a lawyer who is a quadriplegic, was surprised when his specially equipped rented car received a parking ticket in Manhattan last October, so he decided to appear at a hearing.

title: NET INCOME IS UP BY 12% FOR A.&P
Hurricane Watch Is Issued For North Carolina Coast
description: MIAMI, Oct. 1 (AP)A hurricane watch was issued tonight for portions of the North Carolina coast, but forecasters were still hopeful that Hurricane Gladys would miss the United States mainland.

title: The Reign in Spain
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1America's interest in Franco's reign in Spain falls mainly on the planesthat is, the air and naval bases we have been renting, whose leases are now being renegotiated.

title: CITY URGED TO TAP ITS PENSION FUNDS FOR A CRISIS LOAN
description: Governor Carey's top fiscal advisers, still trying to avert collapse of the $2.3billion state plan for New York City, are now proposing that the city's five publicemploye pension funds lend the city up to $4billion after the rescue money runs out in December.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Wednesday.

title: PRESS IN BRITAIN WINS MAJOR TEST
description: LONDON, Oct. 1In a major decision that could significantly alter the relationship between press and Government in Britain, a High Court judge rejected today the Government's plea to stop publication of a volume of diaries by the late Richard Crossman, a Cabinet minister.

title: Judge Sued on Outburst Over Terrible Coffee
description: An angry Suffolk County judge who last April had a vender brought to his chambers in handcuffs to explain why his coffee was so bad, was confronted yesterday with two reactions: a state commission recommendation that he be dismissed and a $5million suit for damages.

title: It Wasn't Easy, All Declares
description: MANILA, Oct. 1Eight hours after Muhammad Ali left the ring following his epic in brutality with Joe Frazier, the champion's face tonight resembled a mask that had been stretched to fit. His narrowed eyes appeared to be underlines in purple crayon. His forehead had small lumps on it. The bridge of his nose was scraped pink. When he walked, he moved stiffly, almost in limp.

title: Suffolk Commuters Defy City's Bus Service Ban
description: The men and women of Bus 103 from Suffolk County cheerfully commuted to New York yesterday in defiance of a city directive that would have them ride the Long Island Rail Road instead.

title: Amin, at U.N., Appeals to Americans to Rid Their Society of Zionists
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1President Idi Amin of Uganda, in a visit to the United Nations today, appealed to the American people to rid their society of the Zionists.

title: 2 Sex Offenders Sent to Prison After Plea for Castration Fails
description: SAN DIEGO. Oct. 1 (AP)Two convicted sex offenders who asked to be castrated rather than put behind bars have been sent to prison for indefinite terms because they could not find a surgeon willing to perform the operations.

title: Aid to Portugal Expected
description: BONN, Oct. 1The nine members of the European Economic Community are ready to grant Portugal the aid package they held up in July when she seemed in danger of becoming a dictatorship, according to a West German spokesman.

title: City Council Acts on New Arts Agency
description: The first City Council action to dismantle a superagency created in the Lindsay admin istration was taken yesterday when the Council's Committeed on Charter and Governmenta Operations approved in a 7to 2 vote the creation of a nevi agency for cultural affairs, with the proviso that the Parks Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration be abolished.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state has no hope of winning back the accreditation of Trenton State Hospital unless voters approve a $112million institutions bond issue, a spokesman for the Department of Institutions and Agencies said yesterday. The spokesman, Mitchell Leon, also said that without the bond issue, continued approval for Ancora State Hospital could be in danger. However, the state plans to ask the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Hospitals to accept new information that might persuade it to reinstate accredtation for Greystone Park State Hospital, Mr. Leon said.

title: Reported Threat Investigated
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) Officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today were looking into a reported assassination threat against President Ford and Emperor Hirohito, allegedly involving three men traveling from Montreal to the United States, a bureau spokesman said.

title: U.P.I. Communications Again Severed by India
description: NEWDELHI, Oct. 1 (UPI) For the second time in two months, the Indian Government severed all communications of United Press International's New Delhi bureau today for violation of the country's selfcensorship rules.

title: MORTALITY DROP LINKED TO CRISIS
description: The severe gasoline shortagesin the winter of 1974 was accompanied by a dramatic drop in deaths from all causes, and especially from heart and chronic lung diseases, in two California counties.

title: SOVIET DENOUNCES CRITICS IN WEST
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 1The Soviet Union, apparently stung by, criticism from the West, has mounted an increasingly active campaign denouncing those who have questioned its sincerity in carrying out the humanitarian provisions of the European security declaration signed at Helsinki.

title: HOUSE VOTES TODAY ON AID FOR TURKEY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1On the eve of a crucial vote in the House of Representatives on lifting the military embargo against Turkey, leaders of proGreek forces said today that they would offer an amendment linking resumption of arms deliveries to Turkish concessions on Cyprus refugees.

title: New Rules in Use For an Old Device: Letter of Credit
description: New procedures for using the letter of credit, the basic document governing the terms of shipment for a substantial portion of world trade, went into effect yesterday.

title: G. L. Marhoefer And Lee Arthur Have Nuptials
description: Lee Arthur, a former sports announcer for WCBSTV here, was married yesterday afternoon in Pittsburgh to Gilbert L. Marhoefer, a realtor there. The ceremony was performed in Trinity Episcopal Cathedral by Canon Alan M. Miller.

title: Suffolk Commuters Defy City's Bus Service Ban
description: The men and women of Bus 103 from Suffolk County cheerfully commuted to New York yesterday in defiance of a city directive that would have them ride the Long Island Rail Road instead.

title: Marsh Disqualifies Himself
description: GANTON, England Oct. 1 (UPI)  Graham Marsh of Australia took the firstround lead in the $42,000 Dunlop Masters tournament today and then disqualified himself. He carded a oneunderpar 70 but failed to notice an error in his scorecard and notified officials.

title: CORRECTION
Washington Post Is Shut by Pressroom Vandalism
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The Washington Post, the nation's seventhlargest newspaper, was forced to cease publication temporarily today by what company officials called an antimanagement outburst of vandalism in its pressroom by striking members of a pressmen's union. All of The Post's 72 printing units were said to have been sabotaged.

title: Human Use Reviews
description: Somehow, the Army hasn't yet activated its program of following up on the 550 soldiers it subjected to LSD experimentsalthough the effort was announced ten weeks ago. Moreover, the. Army says it doesn't even intend to try to reach and examine approximately 900 civilians who were the subjects of experiments which it sponsored but which were carried out by civilians.

title: 5 Indicted on Charge of Manipulating Belair Stock
description: Two stockbrokers were indicted here yesterday on charges of fraudulently inflating a stock's market price is a scheme that allegedly cost the public many hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: On Board 3, at 8 Years of Age.
description: When I play Black, I use the Sicilian Defense, Michael Sanchez said yesterday as he prepared for a transAtlanticTelex chess tournament between outstanding players in New York and Geneva.

title: Jordan Prospers as Island of Calm in a Sea of Unrest
description: AMMAN, JordanThe hotels are packed with businessmen seeking contracts, house rentals have climbed to as high as $1,000 a month, and a new Chinese restaurant has opened offering grilled shrimp at $9 a plate.

title: Kuwait Offers Compensation To B. P. and Gulf Oil Corp
description: KUWAIT, Oct. 1 (Reuters)Kuwait has offered British Petroeum Company, Ltd., and the Gulf Oil Corporation $66million in compensation for the takeover of their remaining 40 per cent stake in the Kuwait Oil Company, the country's oil minister, AbdelMuttaleb AlKazemi, was quoted as saying here.

title: Advertising
description: Gail Smith of General Motors, the country's second largest national advertiser, is concerned that the state of the world has shaken the spirit of confidence that the ad game is famous for.

title: ADDED RULES SOUGHT IN BANK DISCLOSURE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) Federal bank regulatory agenagencies proposed today rules to increase bank disclosure of financial conditions and income.

title: Bayonne Employes Accept Raises Starting in '76
description: BAYONNE, Oct. 1 (UPI) City negotiators have reached a tentative wage and benefit settlemeht with Bayonne's five municipal unions, ending a contract dispute with 950 police, fire, sanitation and clerical employes.

title: Pike Panel Agrees to Ford Conditions on Secret Papers and Accepts the Files Submitted by Colby
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The House Select Committee investigating the Federal intelligence agencies agreed today to abide by President Ford's insistence that it not unilaterally make public secret materials or testimony given to it by the executive branch.

title: Sisters Defend Sun Myung Moon Sect
description: While New Jersey's State Insurance Commissioner stood outside accusing the Unification Church of brainwashing his three daughters, the daughters were saying at a news conference yesterday that it was their father who had been duped and that they feared their parents would try to kidnap them.

title: Daylin's Stores Closings
Metropolitan Briefs
description: An angry Suffolk County judge who last April had a vender brough to his chambers in handcuffs to explain why his coffee was so bad, was  confronted yesterday with two reactions: A State commission recommendation that he be dismissed and a $5million suit for damages.

title: Italy Announces an Agreement With Yugoslavia Over Trieste
description: ROME, Oct. 1Premier Aldo Moro formally announced today that the Governments of Italy and Yugoslavia had agreed to end a 30yearold territorial dispute involving the port city of Trieste and its area.

title: Attention Washington
description: The rapidly deteriorating fiscal situation in New York, where the unraveling of Albany's emergency plan to rescue the city from default is menacing the state's own credit standing, demands urgent reappraisal in Washington of the national implications of a fiscal collapse here.

title: Hammer Enters Plea In Nixon Fund Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Armand Hammer, the millionaire oilman and art collector who pioneered in United StatesSoviet trade, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court today to three misdemeanor charges of making illegal contributions in the names of other persons to the 1972 Nixon reelection campaign.

title: Washington Post Shut
A Plaque for Casey
description: Casey Stengel, who died Monday night in California, will be memorialized in a plaque that will be installed in Yankee Stadium, where he managed the New York Yankees to 10 pennants and seven world championships in 12 years.

title: 3 POLICEMEN SLAIN AS FRANCO RALLIES THRONGS IN MADRID
description: MADRID, Oct. 1  As vast throngs gathered in Madrid today to cheer Generalissimo Francisco Franco, gunmen shot and killed three policemen in various parts of the city and badly wounded a fourth.

title: Busy Designer Breeds Lhasas
description: Dogs, Tiffany's and the White House have all played a part in Mrs. Susan Clark Hutchins's life.

title: Prof. Jane W. Smyser, 61, Wordsworth Scholar, Dies
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. Prof Jane Worthington Smyser, a member of the Connecticut College faculty since 1942 and chairman, of the English department from 1969 to 1971, died today at UncasonThames Hospital in Norwich, Conn. She was 61 years.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND OTC DROP
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market dropped again yesterday for the third straight session as volume rose slightly.

title: Dollar Plunges to 2Week Low In Many Centers as Gold Rises
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 1 (UPI)The dollar fell sharply on all European money markets except London for the second consecutive day today, hitting twoweek lows in most capitals. The British pound briefly hit a new low of $2.0275 during trading. The price of gold rose.

title: Fiscal FollowThrough
description: President Ford has still not decided what his position will be on continuing 1975's corporate and personal income taxes into next year. He is seeking to couple any extension of the tax cuts to a pledge by Congress that it will accept his spending ceiling. His superconservative Secretary of the Treasury, William Simon, burnisherup of the Administration's superconservative image, continues to chasten Congress over the size of the budget deficitestimated at somewhere between $70billion and $80 billion this year and probably $60 billion nextas though that enormous deficit were not the result chiefly of the deep slump into which fiscal and monetary mismanagement dumped the economy. The urgent task is to avoid fiscal monetary blunders.

title: Auto Production Off
description: DETROIT, Oct. 1The four United States auto makers have scheduled production of 747,000 cars in October down about 97,000, or 11 per cent, from the 843,859 cars manufacLured in the corresponding month last year, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.

title: HOFFA INFORMANT IS GIVEN DEADLINE
description: DETROIT. Oct. 1William Gallinaro, an investigator for a Senate subcommittee, has given an informant a deadline of 72 hours to live up to an agreement to help find the body of James R. Hoffa, the missing president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The deadline is supposed to expire at 3 P.M. tomorrow.

title: UTILITIES ACCUSED ON FUEL CHARGES.
description: A Congressional committee investigating alleged abuses of the controversial automatic fuel adjustment clause says that many utilities have used the clause to overcharge their customers by millions of dollars.

title: West German Chief Visits
Shows Closed
description: The shows closed by the strike of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians:

title: City U.'s SEEK Program Assailed in State Report
description: A confidential State Education Department staff report criticizes the City University's SEEK program to help disadvantaged students for engaging in poor administrative practices, for allowing SEEK students to move at too slow a pace and for duplicating existing college functions.

title: Separate U.S.Soviet Grain and Oil Talks Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) The Senate Agriculture Committee said today that the United States should negotiate separate deals for the sale of American grain to the Soviet Union and Soviet oil to this country.

title: Senate Rejects a Plan To End Gas Regulation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Senate Democrats easily deefated today a perfunctory Republican proposal to end Federal regulation of new natural gas onshore and offshore. The vote was 57 to 31.

title: EXCITEMENT GONE FROM INDIAN PRESS
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 1One of India's bestknown editors sat at his desk the other day, despondently riffling through a manuscript just back from the Government censor's office.

title: Rise in Distillates And Gasoline Adds To Winter Supply
description: Stocks of gasoline and distillate oil rose in the nation last week apparently putting the United States in a sound supply position for the coming winter, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Mich. St. Relieves Director
description: Michigan State University relieved Burt Smith as director of athletics yesterday, citing concern for his health. The university has been under investigation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association in recent weeks for alleged violations of recruiting football athletes. Jack Breslin, Michigan State's executive vice president, said that the 58yearold Smith would be reassigned outside of the department of athletics. However, Breslin did not name the new job. He did say that to relate Smith's reassignment to the N.C.A.A. investigation was completely withsubstance.

title: Iran Deposits Funds
description: PARIS, Oct. 1 (Reuters)Iran has deposited $400million with the Bank of France under the $1 billion credit agreement signed last year, a senior Finance Ministry official said today. The official said the payment would be included for the first timein the monthly reserves fo?? October due in early November.

title: Fight Proceeds Go To Build Complex
description: MANILA, Oct. 1 (UPI)Net proceeds from the Muhammad AliJoe Frazier fight will go to a modern sports complex to be built in the greater Manila area, government officials said today.

title: RedPirate Playoff SouthpawSlanted
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 1 (UPI) The two lefthanders the Cincinnati Reds will pitch the first two games of the National League playoffs are at contrasting points in their careers, but both figure they are hot now.

title: Fiscal Problems Continue To Depress State's Issues
description: Prices for New York Staterelated bonds and notes continued to fall yesterday against a background of renewed fiscal crisis. Dealers reported that some notes that fell due Sept. 15 are being offered at prices sufficiently lower to raise the original yields by as much as four percentage points. Some older New York State note issues are being quoted at even higher rates.

title: Secret Service Protection Accepted by 4 Democrate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) Four Democratic Presidential hopefuls have accepted the Government's offer of early Secret Service protection.

title: A's Holtzman To Face Tiant
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 1Preparing for their fifth straight American League championship playoffs, the last three of which they won, the Oakland A's are going through the usual light workouts on the field. But they are also having unusual team meetings called by Charley Finley, the owner, to study the extensive scouting reports he ordered.

title: Baseball's Larry MacPhail Dies; NightGame Pioneer Led Yanks
description: Larry MacPhail, one of the great innovators and impresarios of baseball and the man who brought night games to the major leagues 40 years ago, died yesterday in Miami. He was 85 years old.

title: Reuss at His Peak
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1 (UPI) Jerry Reuss, the lefthander who will open for the Pittsburgh Pirates Saturday against the Reds, says a combination of maturity, confidence and discipline resulted in his best year on the mound. His record was 18 victories and 11 defeats.

title: Prince Calls for Saving of Rain Forests
description: Tropical rain forests, which contain 10 per cent of the earth's mammals, birds and plants, are being destroyed at the rate of 14 acres a minute and must be saved, Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands warned yesterday.

title: PRINCIPALS WARN ON SCHOOL SAFETY
description: The city's high school princi pals have warned the Board of Education that they cannot guarantee the safety of their students because of recent cuts in security guards and other school budget reductions.

title: Cosmos Explosion Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) A Soviet Cosmos unmanned spacecraft exploded into 114 pieces Sept. 6 while in orbit hundreds of miles in space, Aviation Week & Space Technology said in its current edition. The explosion came one day after it staunching from Plesetsk while the Cosmos was in an unusual orbit that ranged from 113 miles to 218 miles above the earth, it said.

title: On Board 3 at 8 Years of Age.
description: When I play Black, I use the Sicilian Defense, Michael Sanchez said yesterday as he prepared for a transAtlanticTelex chess tournament between outstanding slavers in New York and Geneva.

title: Bridge:
description: If the reader of a newspaper bridge column finds the auction totally incomprehensible, there are three possible explanations: an exotic system or convention is in use; there has been a typographical accident, or there has been a bridge accident.

title: JOSEPH WINTERS
description: Joseph Winters, a partner in the accounting firm of Winters, Pittard & Lederman here, died Monday of cancer in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 140 East 28th Street.

title: Security Forces Prepare For Ford Visit to Newark
description: NEWARK, Oct. 1  Secret Service agents have been busy since Monday checking em ployes and facilities at Newark International. Airport and at the Robert Treat Hotel and inspecting routes between the two to prepare for President Ford's visit Saturday.

title: FirstClass Mail Service To Equal Airmail Oct. 11
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)  The United States Postal Service announced today that its plan to upgrade firstclass letter mail service to a level equal to or better than airmail will go into effect Oct. 11.

title: Diocese Says It Will Shut 2 Schools if Strike Goes On
description: The Brooklyn Diocese said yesterday that it would be forced to close two Roman Catholic high schools, one in Brooklyn and one in Queens, if there was no settlement by tomorrow afternoon in the monthlong strike by lay teachers.

title: 32 Injured as Amtrak Train Derails on Trip to Florida
description: PULASKI, Tenn., Oct. 1 (AP) At least 32 persons were hospitalized today when 11 cars of Amtrak's 12car Floridian passenger train derailed near the AlabamaTennessee border.

title: ANNE SMITH WALSH
description: NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 1Anne Smith Walsh, a former art editor of Asia magazine, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital. She was 65 years old and lived at 9 Burr Road, Westport.

title: Criminal Vandalism
description: The pressroom employes of The Washington Post who went on strike early yesterday morning dishonored their own cause and did grave disservice to organized labor when they accompanied their walkout by committing serious acts of vandalism against the newspaper's property. Extensive damage was caused by a fire in the pressroom, which police said had been deliberately set by the same disruptive elements who broke windows and destroyed printing equipment. A foreman who tried to extinguish the blaze was set upon and injured by the mob.

title: Dr. Gerson Service Sunday
description: A memorial service for Dr. Helen Moshovitz Gerson, a former leader of the Bronx County Dental Society, will be held Sunday, at 2:30 P.M., at the Bensonhurst Fraternal Society Center. 2018 86th Street, Brooklyn. Dr. Gerson, a widow, died Aug. 2, at the age of 91.

title: Buffalo Finds No Bidders On BondAnticipation Notes
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 1The city of Buffalo was unable to attract any bidder today for a $17.5million offering of bondanticipation notes.

title: DRUG USE CALLED UP AMONG YOUTHS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Although drug exerimentation and use among American teenagers is soaring and is beginning at an earlier age than before, addiction among heroin users is only a fraction of what had been believed, studies released today by the National Institute on Drug Abuses said.

title: CITY URGED TO TAP ITS PENSION FUNDS FOR A CRISIS LOAN
description: Governor Carey's top fiscal advisers, still trying to avert collapse of the $2.3billion state plan for New York City, are now proposing that the city's five publicemploye pension funds lend the city up to $4billion after the rescue money runs out in December.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Pension Purchase Plan just the Latest In a String of Moves to Ease Crisis
description: The proposal yesterday to have the city's five pension funds buy $4billion worth of Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds is the latest effort in what has been a series of actions aimed at easing the city's cashflow problems and encouraging the national investment market to become more receptive to city securities.

title: TIME LIMIT IS SET ON FELONY TRIALS
description: The statewide administrative judge announced a series of steps yesterday designed to assure that by Jan. 1, 1979, all felony cases will be disposed of within six months after indictment.

title: Notes on People
description: Mayor Beame had an invitation from Grand Rapids, Mich., to speak Oct. 8 at the rededication of an auditorium. But Lyman S. Parks, the Republican Mayor of President Ford's hometown, phoned Tuesday to call it off. Since Mayor Beame once tried to establish New York as worthy of Federal assistance by telling the President that people don't come to this country to visit a place like Grand Rapids, speculation arose at City Hall yesterday that the cancellation might have stemmed from Presidential pique. Not so, said Mayor Parks, who added that he had never heard of Mr. Bedme's gibe. In a telephone interview he said arangements for the dedication were incomplete and that when it was rescheduled Mayor Beame would be reinvited.

title: Jets' Garrett Denies He's Missing Person
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 1One thing that Carl Garrett, the New York Jets' running back, wanted to make clear before practice today was that he had not been missing the last two days.

title: EXTEACHER SAYS HE KIDNAPPED GIRL
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct. 1 (UPI)Thomas R. Lippert, a 25 year old former college professor, pleaded guilty today in Federal court to two counts of conspiracy in connection with a kidnapping and attempted kidnapping of Indiana coeds.

title: BLUE CROSS OFFICIAL ON STAND AT HEARING
description: A top Blue Cross official said yesterday that the hospital insurance plan had been less than successful in curbing wasteful procedures in hospitals that are driving up costs excessively and may be doing the patients more harm than good.

title: PORTUGUESE LEADER STARTS SOVIET VISIT
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 1President Nikolai V. Podgorny today told the Portuguese President, Francisco da Costa Gomes, that the Soviet Union remained opposed to any interference in Portugal's internal affairs.

title: A Quandary for Levitt
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt's refusal to use the state pension funds now to hail the city out of its cash' crisis stems from builtin conflicts in his official responsibilities, tiscal experts said yesterday.

title: work Is Ignored For Fight
description: MANILA, Oct 1It was calendared a working day but Manilans declared themselves an Ali  day and stopped work this morning to watch the Muhammad AliJoe Frazier heavyweight championship bout.

title: A Guarded Racial Peace Follows Brooklyn Killing
description: Sadness and fear and bitter memories of antiSemitism pervade the Jewish community of the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn following the slaying last Friday night of an Orthodox Jew who had nothing to give to an attacker because Jewish law forbids the carrying of money on the Sabbath.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Diamond M Drilling Company said yesterday it was withdrawing its previously announced registration of 400,000 shares of common stock. The proposed offering is being withdrawn, the company said, because current price levels are unattractive for the sale of common stock.

title: Ford Will Charge Less To Buyers in California
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 (AP) The Ford Motor Company says it will fight foreign competition by charging California customers about $200 less than residents of other states must pay for certain smaller models.

title: Congress Enacts 5% Rise in Pay For Itself and Federal Workers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The House gave final approval today to a 5 per cent pay increase for members of Congress and 15 million other Federal employes.

title: Meditation Begun in Connecticut Schools
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 1 Elaine Bernstein opened the school day this morning by asking her fifth grade class at the Northeast Elementary School here, Who can tell me what meditation is?

title: For Which We Stand: II
description: BOSTON, Oct. 1When Americans hear about repression in another country, about concentration camps and torture, our concern is often limited by a sense of distance from the horror. After all, what has it to do with us? In any case, what can we be expected to do about it? There are so many wrongs in the world....

title: Amin, at U.N., Appeals to Americans to Rid Their Society of Zionists
description: UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., Oct. 1 President Idi Amin of Uganda, in a visit to the United Nations today, appealed to the American people to rid their society of the Zionists.

title: Indians Lost $500,000
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 (UPI)  Cleveland Indians' stockholders were told today that the team lost $500,000 in 1975. The Indians' president, Ted Bonda, asked the stockholders to invest an extra $500,000 for working capital and they indicated they would. Home attendance last season was 977,039 compared with 1,114,262 in 1974. Bonda said an attendance of 1.2 million was the breakeven point in the past.

title: Title IX Exemptions Unlikely for RevenueProducing Sports
description: WASHINGTOON, Oct. 1The Senate Subcommittee on Education is trying to decide whether to push further the exemption of revenueproducing, intercollegiate sports from sex discrimination laws.

title: People and Business
description: United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., which last week reported a $24million loss in its fourth fiscal quarter ended June 30, Yesterday announced major changes in is management personnel. United Merchants, sales of $921million in its last fiscalyear, is one of the country's largest textile producers and also operates the Robert Hall clothing chain.

title: Cleanup Gains, but Workers Leave Early
description: Two weeks after Mayor Beame found East Harlem just filthy and suspended two Sanitation Department officials because men were leaving work early, residents of the area say there has been a marked improvement, but some sanitationmen are still leaving early.

title: New Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1975

title: Secret Service and Bay Police Differ Over Whether Sara Moore Was Considered a Threat to the President
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  The controversy surrounding the failure of law enforcement groups to detain Sara Jane Moore before she allegedly attempted to shoot President Ford deepened at a Senate hearing today when Secret Service agents and San Francisco policemen gave differing versions of whether she had indeed been considered a threat to the President.

title: JOHN R. M'KENNA
description: John R. McKenna, librarian at Middlebury College in Vermont, died Tuesday at Porter Medical Center in Middlebury. He was 58 years old and lived in Middlebury.

title: Tanner and Ashe Give U.S. 20 Lead
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Oct. 1 (UPI)Roscoe Tanner took only 48 minutes to defeat Joaquin LoyoMayo, 62, 60. and Arthur Ashe beat Raul Ramirez, 36, 63, 76, to give the United States a 20 lead after singles action today against Mexico in the Nations Cup.

title: TaxCut Extension Linked By Ford to Spending Curb
description: OMAHA, Oct. 1President Ford strongly suggested here today that he might recommend a continuation next year of individual income tax cuts if Congress would agree to hold Federal spending within a specific limit.

title: PRINCIPALS WARN ON SCHOOL SAFETY
description: The city's high school princi pals have warned the Board of Education that they cannot guarantee the safety of their students because of recent cuts in security guards and other school budget reductions.

title: People in Sports
description: Gene Mauch the only manager in the Montreal Expos' history, became yesterday the seventh major league baseball pilot to be dismissed since last August. The 49yearold Mauch, who managed Montrai since the team joined the National League as a 1969 expansion team, also served 8 years as manager of the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Dr. D. A. Brody, a Pioneer In Heart Research, Dies
description: Dr. Daniel A. Brody, a pioneer in research on the functioning of the human heart, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, in his office at the University of Tennessee Center for Health Sciences in Memphis. He was 60 years old.

title: NIGERIA SETS DATE FOR CIVILIAN RULE
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 1 (AP) Nigeria's new military rulers announced today that they would hand over power to civilians by Oct. 1, 1979, and restore multiparty democracy.

title: Famula Pair Wins By 2 Shots in Golf
12 Hurt as Racial Brawls Shut Danbury High School
description: DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 1Years of tension between black and white students at Danbury High School here broke out into open violence early this morning as 12 persons were injured and another 12 arrested in a series of brawls and one pitched battle.

title: 2 Kansas Utility Companies Sue Westinghouse Electric
description: The Kansas Gas and Electric Company and the Kansas City Power and Light Company said yesterday that they had sued the Westinghouse Electric Corporation over a contract involving Westinghouse's agreement to supply nuclear fuel to the companies.

title: Miss Hearst Investigated In Bank Robbery Murder
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1Patricia Hearst, the 21yearold kidnapping victim who allegedly became a radical, is under investigation in the murder of a woman in a bank robbery, a Federal prosecutor said here today.

title: $350,000 Bond in Hijacking
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (UPI)A man who is charged with hijacking an airplane from Chicago to Havana in 1971 is being held under $350,000 bond. Walter C. Hines was arrested by Deputy United States marshals in San Juan, Puerto Rico, last Saturday and charged it with aircraft piracy in connection with the Feb. 4, 1971, hijacking of Delta Air Lines. Flight 379. The plane had been scheduled to fly from Chicago to Nashville, when the hijacking occurred.

title: SAMUEL WALKER, 61, AD EXECUTIVE, DEAD
description: Samuel Polk Walker, who retired in 1971 as a vice president of the J. Walter Thompson Company, the advertising agency, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Southport, Conn., and on St. Martin in the Caribbean.

title: Indochina's New Rulers
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 1 With the quiet departure of Prince Norodom Sihanouk back into the exile in Peking that has been his way of life for more than five years, an uncertain stillness has descended again over the Cambodian capital. The quiet raises questions of leadership and power in all three of the Indochinese capitals that were taken over this year by Communist governments Saigon, Vientiane and Phnom Penh.

title: Anne Hearst's Off Probation
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 1 (AP)Anne Randolph Hearst, 19 years old, younger sister of Patricia Hearst, has finished serving four months probation on a Federal drug possession charge. Anne Hearst was arrested in Niagara Falls March 4 after agents found 12 amphetamine tablets in a car she occupied with two men friends.

title: A Quandary for Levitt
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt's refusal to use the state pension funds now to bail the city out of its cash crisis stems from builtin conflicts in his official response bilities, fiscal experts said yesterday.

title: Play That Relies on Gentleness, and Other Fun for Children
description: Much of children's theater relies on slapstick. A show that does it with a gentle touch is Bags of Rags, the first children's show by The Comedy Stage Company, Inc., now in its third year.

title: TaxCut Extension Linked By Ford to Spending Curb
description: OMAHA, Oct. 1President Ford strongly suggested here today that he might recommend a continuation next year of individual income tax cuts if Congress would agree to hold Federal spending within a specific limit.

title: Ford Maintains Stand On Opposing City Aid
description: SKOKIE, III., Oct. 1President Ford told the mayors of 33 suburban communities in Illinois, Indiana and Michigan meeting here today that your constituents wouldn't tolerate it if you ran your cities as badly as New York City has been run.

title: 1,000 Attend Show To Benefit Blacks Studying Medicine
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 1 In a classic combination of a good time and a good cause a thousand black people gathered at the Westchester Premier Theater tonight for a benefit performance to aid minority group medical students.

title: You Could Look It Up
description: It never seems time for the book to close on any life, but at least Casey Stengel wrested every bit of verve and enjoyment from his 85 years. He left some delicious gifts for the rest of us as well.

title: Policeman Killed At Site of Fight
description: MANILA, Oct. 1 (UPI)A policeman was killed today while reportedly playing with his .38 caliber revolver in Joe. Frazier's dressing room at the Philippine Coliseum, the police said.

title: FREEHOLDER LINKED TO BRIBE PAYMENT
description: MORRISTOWN, Oct. 1Edward Gola, a Passaic County Freeholder, received $1,000 on Jan. 16 as a bribe from the former Mayor of Riverdale, according to a taped conversation between the two men that was played here today.

title: Washington Post Shut
GOING OUT Guide
description: MIDTOWN SEEDS With cool weather approaching, New York today will welcome its only annual, largescale flower show to be held in the heart of Manhattan, as Bryant Park plays host to a lavish display of blooms, greenery and plants. The seventh citysponsored event continuing through Tuesday will again occupy the space behind the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue, between 40th and 42d Streets. While the theme of the free show is a. Bicenetennial Red, White and Blooming, other arrangements and species of flora will be represented and open for inspection after 10:30 A.M. today, when various New Yorkers will receive awards for city beautification in a brief ceremony.

title: POTATO FUTURES SHOW ADVANCES
description: Potatoes and pork bellies tested their recent contract highs in futures trading yesterday but failed to move above them.

title: Drill for Paris Race Is Slow and Wrong
description: Will Intrepid Hero be slow enough to win Sunday's prestigious Prix de I'Arc de Triomphe in Paris?

title: It Takes Two to Make a Fight
description: MANILA, Oct. 1A gaggle of pretty girls got aboard an elevator for the press center in the Bayview Plaza Hotel, where they had been working for the last 10 days. It's over, one of them said, and we're glad. Were they satisfied with the way it had ended? Nor they said, No, every one of them. How about you? a girl asked a man on the lift. I'm neutral, he said, but I'll say one thing: Joe Frazier makes a better fighter and a better man of Muhammad Ali than anybody else can do. Right, the girls said, all together, that's right.

title: INVENTORIES DROP AT U. S. FACTORIES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI)  Manufacturers' inventories fell in August for the sixth consecutive month, the longest period of continuous drops in 17 years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Presi Governo Mayor
description: WASHINGTONNew York City's financial adaptation of the Perils of Pauline has so many characters and so complex a plot that we tend to lose sight of a central point of the drama. Neither the city nor the state can fulfill a critical constitutional function of all state and local govern ment: As presently structured geographically, politically and financially, neither can provide decentralized counterpoints to Presidential powerand none of the proposed solutions will remedy this sorry situation.

title: Jersey's Malpractice Premiums Increased an Average of 49.5%
description: TRENTON, Oct. 1Premium rates for medical malpractice insurance for New Jersey physicians will increase by an average of nearly 50 per cent, the state's Insurance Commissioner, James J. Sheeran, announced today. The rates for new policies will be effective immediately. For renewal policies, they will be effective Nov.

title: A DISPUTE FLARES ON MIDEAST LEAKS
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 1High Administration officials said today that the State Department, before giving Congress secret documents about United States assurances to Israel, had made stylistic changes to be able to trace future leaks to the press.

title: Iran's Revenues Rise
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 1 (AP) The national Iranian oil company reported that starting today Iranian oil revenues will increase by $5million a day under the new price guidelines set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. The statement said August crude oil exports reached 4,909,176 barrels a day. At this level, the Government's annual earnings will now increase by $1.8billion to $2billion.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report on changes in stock ownership by large stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not make an insiders' report yesterday.

title: Pacific Islands Become A New Colony of Britain
description: SUVA, Fiji, Oct. 1 (AP) The Ellice Islands in the central Pacific proclaimed themselves the new British colony of Tuvalu today, ending their ties with the Gilbert Islands dating from 1915.

title: Showcase Code Is an Off Off Standoff
description: The defeat by the membership of Actors Equity of a proposed revision of the showcase code regulating actors' participation in Off Off Broadway productions was not the end of the debate between Off Off Broadway and the leaders of Equity.

title: Triborough Agency Cites Traffic Drop Since Toll Increase
description: With higher tolls in effect since Sept. 1, motorvehicle traffic at the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority facilities' was down by 7.8 per cent in the first three weeks of September, compared with the same period last year. But revenues were up 35 per cent.

title: Market Place
description: The nation's troubled economy, its financially embarrassed cities and a falling stock market have investors longing for a safe haven.

title: Common Market Urged to Suspend Talks With Spain
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 1Aroused by the execution of five Spanish terrorists last weekend, the European Communities Commission called on the ninenation Common Market today to suspend its talks with Spain ?? the liberalization of trade.

title: A.F.LC.I.O. to Study Farm Union Vote
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1The Executive Council of the A.F.LC.I.O. directed a threeman committee today to investigate alleged fraud and harassment in the critical election battles between the United Farm Workers and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters for the right to represent California farm workers.

title: Miss Hearst Investigated In Bank Robbery Murder
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1Patricia Hearst, the 21yearold kidnapping victim who allegedly became a radical, is under investigation in the murder of a woman in a bank robbery, a Federal prosecutor said here today.

title: Meditation Begun in Connecticut Schools
description: STAMFORD, Corm., Oct. 1 Elaine Bernstein opened the school day this morning by asking he fifth grade class at the Northeast Elementary School here, Who can tell me what meditation is?

title: DEBT ACCORD IS SET FOR UNIT OF CHASE
description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust, the nation's largest real estate and investment trust, disclosed here yesterday that its 41 creditor banks had agree dto restructure the trust's $761million bank debt.

title: CHERRYBURRELL TO BE ACQUIRED
description: The Dominion Bridge company, Ltd., announced in Montreal yesterday that its United States subsidiary, the Amca International Corporation, had agreed to acquire the CherryBurrell Company of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, a subsidiary of Paxall, Inc., of Chicago, and a second unrelated company, Desa Industries, Inc., of Park Forest, Ill.

title: Trustees of City Pensions Wary of More City Bonds
description: The city's five pension systems have assets totaling $8.5billionof which more than $1billion has already been invested in Municipal Assistance Corporation, city and cityrelated securities.

title: FORD VETOES A RISE IN TOBACCO SUPPORT
description: OMAHA, Oct. 1 (AP)President Ford announced today his veto of a bill, that would have increased tobacco price supports and eventually could have raised the price of a pack of cigarettes by a penny.

title: NADJARI WINS CASE, BUT ANGERS A JUDGE
description: A Federal judge issued a decision yesterday that assailed the conduct of Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, but rejected a move to bar the prosecution of a case resulting from the alleged misconduct.

title: WALLACE SHUNNED 1972 SECURITY TIP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama said today that he ignored Secret Service advice not to appear at the Maryland shopping center rally where he was shot while campaigning in 1972.

title: Pro Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Sports Today
Buddhas and Spilled Ice Cream Catch the Eye in Model Rooms
description: Members of the New York Junior League and their escorts trooped to Bloomingdale's the other night for a benefit party that marked the opening of the store's latest model roomsthose superchic enclaves on the fifth floor that give decorating ideas to some New Yorkers and inferiority complexes to others.

title: Jerome S. Adlerman, 73, Dead; Lawyer Aided Senate Inquiries
description: Jerome Sidney Adlerman, former general counsel to the Senate Permanent Subccrmmittee on Investigations, died yesterday at Cedars of Lebanon Hospital in Miami. He was 73 years old and lived in the Miami area.

title: Miss Moore Given Tests
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 1 (UPI) The first round of secret psychiatric examinations to determine if Miss Moore is competent to stand trial on charges of trying to kill President Ford, began today.

title: BETHLEHEM SETS CLOSING OF UNITS
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, Uniroyal, Inc., and Dow Chemical of Canada, Ltd., announced yesterday plans for closing some of their operations.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 2, 1975

title: Alcan Price Cuts Set
description: The Alcan Aluminum Corporation, the United States subsidiary of Alcan Aluminum, Ltd., of Canada, announced yesterday that it was following the other major producers with price cuts for certain flat and coiled specification sheet aluminum. The present round of cuts in the form of discounts from list prices was instituted a week ago Monday by Martin Marietta Aluminum, Inc. Alcan's price cuts will amount to 2.7 cents a pound.

title: WITNESS DISPUTES NIXON DEED DATE
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1Edward L. Morgan, a forme White House aide, testified to day in Federal District Cour here that no draft deed for Richard M. Nixon's gift of his pre  Presidential papers was drawn up in his presence on April 21, 1969 as Mr. Nixon's former tax lawyer, Frank De Marco Jr., is reported to have asserted.

title: FEUD WITHIN G.O.P SEEN FLARING ANEW
description: TRENTON, Oct. 1 (AP)There were signs today that the feud between moderate New Jersey Republicans and the conservative Sandman wing of the party had resumed during preparations for a Presidential visit to the state.

title: Mail Linked to Arrests
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 (AP) The break that led to the capture of. Miss Hearst came because the F.B.I. checked the mail addressed to the father of Stephen and Kathleen Soliah, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported in its Thursday editions.

title: Business Briefs
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit in Denver has stayed for seven days an order of the Federal Trade Commission that required the Kennecott Copper Corporation to file yesterday a specific plan for divesting itself of the Peabody Coal Company, the nation's largest coal producer. The appeals court also referred a Kennecott motion for reopening the entire F.T.C. divestiture case to the threejudge panel that ruled on the original case in 1972.

title: Prince Calls for Saving of Rain Forests
description: Tropical rain forests, which contain 10 per cent of the earth's mammals, birds and plants, are being destroyed at the rate of 14 acres a minute and must be saved, Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands warned yesterday.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MIAMI, Oct. 1 (UPI) Storer Broadcasting Company completed its sale of the Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League and the Boston Garden to SportsSystems Corporation of Buffalo, last night in Boston, it was confirmed here today. William Michaels; chairman of the board of Storer, confirmed that the final papers had been signed, but he declined to disclose the price. Michaels said the deal included a longterm contract for Bruins' television rights for WSBKTV, a Storer station in Boston.

title: CHINA CELEBRATES 26TH ANNIVERSARY
description: PEKING, Oct. 1 (Agence, FrancePresse)  Hundreds of millions of Chinese celebrated ??he 26th anniversary of the proclamation of the People's Republic of China today at festi??als throughout the nation.

title: TIME LIMIT IS SET ON FELONY TRIALS
description: The statewide administrative judge announced a series of steps yesterday designed to assure that by Jan. 1, 1979, all felony cases will be disposed of within six months after indictment.

title: PRESEASON HOCKEY
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Coaches Applaud New Football Format
description: After one game, a winning coach and a losing coach have cast their votes in favor of the new alignments for Public Schools Athletic League football. For the first time the stronger schools are grouped together and will compete for one championship, While the smaller schools are in a separate division with a separate title game. Last Monday two of the have schools met in a raindelayed opener and when it was over Jefferson appaired like a good choice for a second straight title, while Lincoln faced the season hoping that someone else could knock off the Jeffs.

title: The Numbers Aren't Everything
description: The unemployment rate has become a misleading statistic. As a former United States Commissioner of Labor Statistics, it pains me to say this, and I do not mean to imply that the figures are in any way distorted or manipulated. They are just misleading. Since they are so widely followed, this is important.

title: Ballet: Joffrey in Autumn
description: Well, in this autumn of our discontent, at least some musicians are playing rather picketing, and the City Center Jeffrey Ballet opened as scheduled last night its fiveweek fall season at the City Center 55th Street Theater.

title: JOHN J. CASALE
description: TORRINGTON, Conn., Oct, 1 (AP)Retired Superior Court Judge John J. Casale of Torrington died yesterday at Charlotte Hungerford Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: Hirohito
description: Most Americans of middle age can remember the days when the name of Hirohito was routinely cited along with other wartime enemies as one whose life and deeds would live in infamy. Today Emperor Hirohito of Japan arrives at the White House, an honored and warmly welcomed visitor to the United States.

title: Mayor Fails to End the Theater Deadlock
description: Disturbed by the impasse in the musician' strike that has shut down 12 Broadway musical productions, Mayor Beame met in joint session late yesterday at City Hall with both sides, but failed to end the stalemate.

title: Schoolboy Fullback Dies
description: WESTFIELD, N.Y., Oct. 1 (UPI)Brett Duncan Smith, 17yearold captain of the Westfield Academy football team, died yesterday in St. Vincent Hospital in Erie, Pa., apparently of head injuries suffered in a game Sept. 19. Smith, a senior fullback, apparently struck his head when tackled by two members of the Falconer High School team. He complained of slight headaches during the week, but the following. Friday said he felt fine and played against Gowanda.

title: European Football
description: By Reuters

title: Striking Teachers Agree To Settle in Parsippany
description: PARSIPPANY, Oct. 1Six hundred fifty striking teachers here approved a tentative contract with the Board of Education today and returned to their schools to prepare for the resumption of classes tomorrow.

title: In Memoriam
description: ALPERNMARY N. Her kindliness, graciousness, compassion and concern for the less fortunate created a heritage and everlasting inspiration to her family, relatives, friends and all who knew her.

title: Miss Evert Beats Youngster, 61, 61
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Oct. 1 (UPI)Chris Evert scored a 61, 61 victory over 16yearold Lea Antonopolis, of Glendora in the second round of the $50,000 Mission Viejo women's tennis tournament today.

title: Joyce Resigns His Post On Camden Utility Unit
description: CAMDEN, Oct. 1 (UPI)The Camden County Democratic Chairman, James Joyce, who was cleared of bribery charges last month, resigned today as vice chairman of the Camden County Muncipal Utility Authorny.

title: Shows Open
description: Shows that are not affected by the strike:

title: Diocese Says It Will Shut 2 Schools if Strike Goes On
description: The Brooklyn Diocese said yesterday that it would be forced to close two Roman Catholic high schools, one in Brooklyn and one in Queens, if there was no settlement by tomorrow afternoon in the monthlong strike by lay teachers.

title: CHILDREN TERMED IN DISEASE PERIL
description: Millions of American children lack adequate protection against such serious infectious diseases as polio and measles, creating the lingering possibility that new epidemics may flare up, experts said yesterday as the third annual Immunization Action Month began.

title: Chess:
description: Jan Timman, a 23yearold Dutch grandmaster, took first prize in the 12th annual international tournament in Netanya, Israel. While Timman lost three games in this hardfought competition in which no one went undefeated, his winning punch accounted for eight victories and his aggressive play granted his opposition but two draws.

title: AliFrazier Gross Likely to Set Mark
description: Indications are that the closedcircuit telecast of the Muhammad AliJoe Frazier world heavyweight title fight in Manila was as much a financial success as it was a classic ring battle.

title: SovietNorwegian Dispute Is Unfolding Over Barents Sea Oil
description: OSLO, Norway, Sept. 27A quiet and tense drama between Norway and the Soviet Union is unfolding over each nation's sovereignty in a remote Arctic area.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Hammer Enters Plea In Nixon Fund Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Armand Hammer, the millionaire oilman and art collector who pioneered in United StatesSoviet trade, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court today to three misdemeanor charges of making illegal contributions in the names of other persons to the 1972 Nixon reelection campaign.

title: Stun Guns Recovered; Couple Accused of Theft
description: MIAMI, Oct. 1 UPI)The police have recovered seven of nine electronic stun guns and arrested a young couple in connection with their theft and use in a service station holdup two weeks ago.

title: PRESS IN BRITAIN WINS MAJOR TEST
description: LONDON, Oct. 1In a major decision that could significantly alter the relationship between press and Government in Britain, a High Court judge rejected today the Government's plea to stop publication of a volume of diaries by the late Richard Crossman, a Cabinet minister.

title: Troy Draws Criticism For Letter on Business
description: City Councilman Arthur J. Katzman, chairman of the Council's Standards and Ethics Committee, said last night that he believed that Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., had committed a gross impropriety in using Council stationery to advance a private business.

title: CLINIC TIES URGED IN NURSING HOMES
description: A dearth of physicians interested in the aged and in the problems of long  term care requires special steps by nursinghome operators and the State Department of Health according to a report released yesterday.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Oct. 2, 1975 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: TAX CUT EXTENSION GAINS IN CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Elements of a consensus appeared to emerge today in Congress and in Congressional testimony on a simple extension through next year of the temporary 1975 antirecession tax reduction.

title: LongEmbattled Sinkiang Building a New Life
Crime Aid to States Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)Attorney General Edward H. Levi told the Senate. Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Criminal Laws and Procedures today that the program of Federal grants to the states to combat crime was fundamentally sound and urged it be continued another five years.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Heavy Firing in Cyprus
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 2 (Reuters)Heavy firing flared across the Green Line dividing the Greek and Turkish quarters of Nicosia tonight. The firing, involving heavy machine guns, lasted for less than a quarter of an hour and apparently came from only one side of the line.

title: At Stage Strike Center, the Walker
description: By Broadway definition a walker is a musician getting paid for not doing anything.

title: American Aides Boycott Dinner Given by the Uganda President
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 2United States officials boycotted a social function given by President Idi Amin of Uganda today in a gesture of displeasure over some of his remarks at the United Nations General Assembly yesterday.

title: Islanders Beat Penguins, 32
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 2 (AP) Ed Westfall and Brian Trottier scored thirdperiod goals less than a minute apart and carried the New York Islanders to a 32 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight in a National Hockey League exhibition game.

title: About Real Estate
description: As Sigmund Sommer tells it, he picked up a telephone one day last spring and called his old friend J. Kelly Farris in San Francisco.

title: DR. ETHAN COLTON JR.
description: Dr. Ethan T. Colton Jr., who retired in 1968 as chief of staff of the department of surgery of the Montclair (N.J.) Community Hospital, died there Wednesday. He was 70 years old and lived at 103 Overlook Road inUpper Montclair.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LENSESCamera fans can attend tonight's award presentations for outstanding work in the field at 8 o'clock, when the 1975 winners are honored by the Society of Photographers in Communications. The 30yearold group of professionals is meeting in the McGrawHill auditorium, 1221 Avenue of the Americas (at 50th Street). The tab for outsiders is $5; for reservations, call 6616450. Seating is limited.

title: U.S. GROUPS SEEKING HELP FOR VIETNAMS
description: A campaign to assist North Vietnam and South Vietnam was opened yesterday by American church and civic groups under the name Friendshipment.

title: Burn, Baby, Burn!
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The pressmen of The Washington Post have finally succeeded in doing to their own newspaper what former President Nixon and his Attorney General John Mitchell tried and failed to do during the Watergate conflict: They have stopped the presses at The Post.

title: Other Credit Market Sectors Also Gain
description: Prices of all Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds staged a strong rally yesterday in the taxexempt market following their recent weakness. Quotations also firmed in the government and corporate areas of the bond market. Trading in the three areas was slightly more active than in previous sessions. The improvement in the three M.A.C. issues resulted mainly from New York State Controller Arthur Levitt's agreement yesterday to invest $250million of state employe pension funds in state borrowing to aid New York City.

title: A Town Regains Its Seal From MuseumAlmost
description: Few of the visitors at the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday afternoon even paused to glance at the small ceremonial group clustered below the Sardis Column. But for the Ulster County community of Marbletown, N.Y., (population 5.000) the moment was a historic one.

title: 19 Researchers Evacuated
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 2 (AP) Nineteen members of a University of Washington research team have been evacuated from a camp in the Beaufort Sea, north of Alaska, after the ice floe on which the camp was established split up. Four members of the team remained at the camp, according to Richard Trowbridge, associate project director. He said there had been no injuries.

title: Hopes for Peaceful Change Wither in Spain
description: MADRID, Oct. 2Only a few months ago many Spaniards were counting the days until, after 35 years of rigidly authoritarian rule, they could make a fresh start with a less anachronistic political system and one more in consonance with the rest of Western Europe, of which they very much wanted to be a part. Dissidence was in the air, Generalissimo Francisco Franco was getting older and more infirm every day and his authority and prestige were slipping. The time seemed ripe for change but it was to be peaceful, change; nobody wanted another civil war.

title: Lawyer for Quinlans Outlines Argument For Removal of LifeSustaining Device
description: MORRISTOWN, Oct. 2The lawyer for the family of Karen Anne Quinlan said today the state would be guilty of cruel and unusual punishment if it did not permit removal of a respirator that has been sustaining her life for more than five months.

title: BOND RATING CUT FOR CITY, STATE
description: Moody's Investors Service lowered its ratings of New York State and New York City securities yesterdayan action that worsened the financial difficulties of both governments and promised to raise their future borrowing costs.

title: BARNARD DEFENDS 2HEART SURGERY
description: Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard, who is in the United States to describe his doubleheart procedure to American cardiologists, said yesterday he was prepared to try the transplant technique again although two of the three patients who underwent it died within a few months of surgery.

title: Money Supply Fell $1.9Billion in Week
description: A $1.9billion drop in the nation's money supply in the week ended Sept. 24 was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: African Area to Get Independence
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 2The paramount chief of the Transkei tribal area said today that South Africa would grant his reservation independence on Oct. 26 of next year.

title: Alexander's Raises Profit 94% in Quarter
Retail Store Sales Up 7%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Department of Commerce said today that total retail store sales for the week ended Sept. 27 were an estimated $10.9billion, up 7 per cent from the corresponding week a year ago, when retail sales were an estimated $10.3billion. Department store sales for the same week were an estimated $1.11billion, up 4 per cent from the corresponding week a year ago when the total sales were an estimated $1.06billion.

title: Playoff Forecast: Sunny
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 2 (AP) The United States Weather Service has forecast sunny skies for the start of the National League championship playoff series here tomorrow. Temperatures are expected, to be in the 70's.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Estimate Board Votes to Retain Counsel to Advise on City Debts
description: To help the city meet its obligation to the Emergency Control Board and submit a repayment plan in the event of a default, the Board of Estimate yesterday approved the retention of Weil, Gotshal and Manges of 767 Fifth Avenue, a law firm with a large corporate practice and a specialty in the rights of creditors.

title: Vesco Court Order Appeal
Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 2 (UPI)The European Common Market charged today that the growth of protectionism in the United States is endangering the future of world trade talks. A note from the European Economic Community's executive commission to the United States Government protested specifically about an American investigation into whether European cars are being dumpedsold at unfairly low priceson the American market.

title: W. T. Grant Asks Court For Bankruptcy Status
description: The W. T. Grant Company, one of America's largest retail chains, yesterday filed a petition in voluntary bankruptcy, listing debts of more than $1billion.

title: The Pop Life
description: Rock is a young person's music. This is partly a simple question of agethe audiences are mostly teenagers, especially those for live concerts, and young performers are easier for fans to identify with. It's difficult to charge out on stage for 15 years singing about my generation when your generation is 35 years old, lives in the suburbs and has a wife and three children.

title: Article 5  No Title
G.M. DEFENDS PLAN FOR CHILE OPERATION
description: DETROIT, Oct. 2 (AP)The General Motors Corporation defended today its decision to resume business in Chile, saying it did not believe its presence would strengthen the military government there.

title: Returning Migrants Find Puerto Rico Inhospitable
description: TOA BAJA, P. R., Oct. 1When Carmen Paz was 40 days old, in 1955, her father packed the family's belongings and took his newborn daughter, his wife, and three older children from San Juan to New York City in search of a better life.

title: Lawyer Outlines Arguments He'll Use in Coma Case
description: MORRISTOWN, Oct. 2The lawyer for the family of Karen Anne Quinlan said today the state would be guilty of cruel and unusual punishment if it did not permit removal of a respirator that has been sustaining her life for more than five months.

title: Advertising
description: It is standard operating procedure at D'ArcyMacManus & Masius to assemble its top brass in platoon strength when announcing major management changes.

title: Black Police Provide Presence for Rosedale Home
description: Offduty black policemen have started appearing regularly at the Rosedale, Queens, home of a black couple that was fire  bombed last New Year's Day, in an effort to discourage what they say is continual verbal and physical harassment.

title: Israeli Cargo Is Expected To Use Suez Canal Soon
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 2 (UPI)A ship carrying cargo to or from Israel will pass through the Suez Canal in the near future, IsraeliGovernment sources said today.

title: U.S. Judge Here Overturns a Law On Flag's Display
description: A Federal judge has assailed a New York City ordinance that requires the display of the United States flag at assemblies and parades.

title: House Unit Calls on Kissinger for a Memo on Cyprus
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The House Intelligence Committee today shifted its battle for classified information to the State Department by voting to subpoena from Secretary of State Kissinger a memorandum that is reported to criticize the mismanagement of this country's diplomatic reaction to last year's invasion of Cyprus.

title: Miss Navratilova Wins in Two Sets
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Oct 2 (UPI)Martina Navratilova, encountered little difficulty in defeating Val Ziegenftis, 62, 64, today in a thirdround match of the $50,000 Mission Viejo women's tennis tourney.

title: China's Biggest Province Is Industrializing Rapidly
description: URUMCHI, China, Sept, 27This is the time of the 26th anniversary of the People's Republic of China, but for the eight million people of Sinkiang it is also the 20th anniversary of its founding as an autonomous region where 12 minority peoples and ethnic Chinese live together.

title: Critic's Notebook: Puff and Circumstance at Festival
description: This city has a lot wrong with it, but pretentiousness Is not one of its faults. Its ceremonials are homely ones: Macy's parade and painting the stripe on Fifth Avenue green are about as close as it comes to panoply. Grander efforts look a little silly and often come unstuck.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, S. Howard Woodson Jr., asked the Attorney General yesterday to investigate very serious charges by an Assemblyman that several legislators had received political contributions to block a medical malpractice insurance bill.

title: SENATE UNIT FINDS TAX DATA MISUSE BY F.B.I. AND C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation used the Internal Revenue Service, apparently illegally, to harass groups they felt were politically threatening, according to evidence presented today at a Senate hearing.

title: CHRYSLER TO LIFT 1976 BASE PRICES
description: DETROIT, Oct. 2  The Chrysler Corporation announced today that the base price of its 1976 model cars would increase by an average of $122, or 2.8 per cent, compared with 1975 models.

title: Article 2  No Title
In Memoriam
description: GREENEElsa and Oscar. In memory of my mother and father, Elsa and Oscar Greene, October, 1965, October, 1972.

title: Pirate Slugger Troubled by Long Lull
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 2 (UPI) Willie Stargell, the slugging first baseman for the Pittsburgh Pirates, is unhappy with having to wait almost a week for the baseball playoffs to start. Who decides this kind of schedule, anyway? he said today. Do they ever ask the players how they feel about it?

title: Burns Says City's Crisis May Harm U.S. Recovery
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that if the [New York City] financial crisis is not resolved it could injure the recovery process that is now under way in our national economy.

title: LEVITT TO INVEST HIS PENSION FUNDS TO TIDE OVER CITY
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt agreed yesterday to use $250million from two state employe pension systems to help tide the city over its cash shortages through, this month and pledged to ask another state pension system, not under his control, to help the city next month.
