title: HOUSE APPROVES EASING ARMS BAN AGAINST TURKEY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2In a significant victory for the Ford Administration, the House of Representatives voted tonight to reverse itself and ease the eightmonth arms embargo against Turkey.

title: Intelligence Inquiry...
description: The agreement between the White House and the House Select Committee on Intelligence barring unilateral release of classified information indicates, that the nation's vital intelligence operations can be protected while Congress effectively investigates abuses, violations of the law and the efficiency of intelligence procedures.

title: People and Business
description: The Treasury confirmed yesterday previous reports that George P. Shultz, the former Secretary of the Treasury, would represent the United. States at a secret fivenation meeting in New York this Sunday and Monday to explore the prospects for an economic summit meeting of the heads of state of the United States, Britain, France, West Germany and Japan.

title: 5 Wounded in Soccer Brawl
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 2, (UPI)Five spectators were wounded by gunfire and one arrested tonight in a brawl between fans at a soccer match. The police said five men received .22caliber bullet wounds in the legs at Velez Sarsfield Stadium, where the local club was playing the River Plate team, the current professional champion. The police were unable to find the weapon used in the shooting. One man was arrested but it was not known what charges would be brought against him.

title: HITLER MEMORABILIA ARE AUCTIONED HERE
description: A collection of purportedly authentic memorabilia of Hitler's were auctioned at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel last night, according to United Press International, but the most expensive itema Nazi armband worn by the dictatorwent for only $1.100.

title: Rightists in Madrid Stage Protest at Police Funerals
description: MADRID. Oct. 2Shouts of Death to the Communists! No more clemency! and of demands that the army seize power disrupted the funeral of three slain policemen here today.

title: Jets' Crew Piles Up Yardage
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.. Oct. 2What may be Long Island's biggest camp trunk already is filled as the boys prepare to spend another weekend away from home.

title: JOHN D. M'MASTER
description: John D. McMaster, a New York and Jersey City lawyer, collapsed and died, apparently of a heart attack, in a Madison Avenue restaurant yesterday. He was 78 years old and lived at 2474 Kennedy Boulevard, Jersey City.

title: Study Urges Big Increase in National Arts Fund
description: A new, nationally oriented report on funding for the arts urges an appropriation of at least $225million for the National Endowment on the Arts next year, more than three times its current $75million budget.

title: SCHMIDT CRITICIZES RESTRICTIVE U.S.
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany said yesterday that he was rather disturbed about United States economic policies, which he described as too restrictive, despite a degree of optimism about the possibilities for moving out of the current recession.

title: BANK BILL CLEARED BY UNIT OF SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)The Senate Banking Committee completed action today on a bill that would restructure, the nation's banking institutions.

title: About New York
description: The sidewalks of New York run along streets of all shapes, widths and lengths that intersect almost 50,000 times in the city. Each street, if it is not lettered or numbered, is named for something animal, vegetable or mineral and the problem is to put up a sign with the names of the streets at each cross. ing.

title: Satellite Hot Line Linking All Capitals Is Urged by Sarnoff
description: GENEVA, Oct. 2Robert W Sarnoff, chairman of the RCA Corporation, proposed today linking the capitals of all nations with a global hot line using communications satellites.

title: Chosen to Head S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2At the height of the battle between Representative Otis G. Pike, Democrat of Riverhead, L. I., and the White House over the publication of national security data, Mr. Pike fired off a letter to President Ford calling for the summary dismissal of one of the President's senior staff aides. He charged that the staff man had misplaced a folder with national security data in it.

title: Saints' Fans Turn Out, But They Want Refunds
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 2 (AP)Frontoffice personnel held the line today against a rush by disgruntled New Orleans Saints' fans, seeking refunds on tickets for the remaining six home games of the football season.

title: City Corrects a Statement On Fees Paid to JobFinders
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs has announced that the effects of new amendments to the State Employment Agency Act had been erroneously reported in a press release.

title: Dr. Terwilliger Elected Dallas Diocese's Bishop
description: The Rev. Dr. Robert E. Terwilliger has accepted election as Suffragan Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Dallas, Trinity Church announced yesterday.

title: BedfordStuyvesant Complex Is Opened
description: Isn't it spectacular? said a beaming Franklin A. Thomas, president of the Bedford; Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation, as she welcomed guests yesterday to the opening ceremonies of the corporation's new $6million commercial center.

title: OverdueBook Holders Are Posted As Newark Library Hunts Scofflaws
description: NEWARK, Oct. 2A copy of the Newark city ordinance covering overdue books and other crimes against the library is on the wall of the registration office of the Newark Public Library. The law apparently is an irresistible challenge for some despite the threat of a $500 fine, 90 days in jail, or both.

title: Bridge:
description: New York's biggest and most successful duplicate bridge club will divide itself like an amoeba Into two parts today.

title: People in Sports
description: For the first time in the 51year history of the Boston Bruins, the club's official family will not include a member of the founding Adams family. Weston Adams Jr., who succeeded his father as club president two years ago when the Bruins were sold to the Storer Broadcasting Company, was replaced yesterday by Paul Mooney of Buffalo.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1975

title: OLEG V. SOICH
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 2 (UPI)Oleg V. Soich, a leading Ukrainian Communist party offical and a member of the Supreme Soviet, has died after a long illness, the party newspaper Pravda said yesterday. He was 60 years old.

title: BERTHE JACOBSON
description: Berthe Poncy Jacobson, a concert pianist and teacher, died yesterday of an aneurysm at the University of Washington Hospital in Seattle. She was 81 years old and lived in Seattle.

title: HIROHITO EXTOLS JAPANESEU.S TIES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Welcomed by President Ford amid all the pomp the White House can muster, Emperor Hirohito today voiced regret about World War II and said he hoped his visit would contribute to everlasting friendship between the people of Japan and the United States.

title: Retail Chains' Sales In Gains of 3 to 25% Above a Year Ago
description: The nation's retail chains geneerally reported yesterday that their September sales rose by less than the 10 per cent annual rate of inflation in consumer goods, indicating a drop in unit sales. The gains ranged from 3 to 25 per cent above the yearearlier level.

title: One Killed, 4 Are Hurt In Oil Burner Explosion
description: At least one person was killed and four others injured, two of them critically, early today when an explosion heavily damaged a twostory frame house in the Richmond Hill section of Queens, the police reported. None of them was immediately identified.

title: HONEYWELL MAY BID FOR UNIT OF XEROX
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 2 (Reuters)  Honeywell, Inc. said today, it was holding discussions with the Xerov Corporation regarding aquisition of the Xerox Data Systems division.

title: Making It Count
description: Today, tomorrow and Monday are registration days. New York State has permanent personal registration; but registration is necessary for those voters who failed to vote in November 1973 or 1974. Reregistration is also necessary for those who have changed their addresses. And, of course, new voters who are or will be 18 by Nov. 4 must register.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Racially troubled Danbury High School will be open Monday for seniors only as community leaders attempt to soothe tensions following a brawl that left 13 persons injured. The school was ordered closed for the weekend after fighting, in which 12 students were arrested, broke out Wednesday. Pasqualle Nappi, Superintendent of Schools, said he hoped to have students at all grade levels return by the end of next week.

title: Burns Says City's Crisis May Harm U.S. Recovery
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that if the [New York City] financial crisis is not resolved it could injure the recovery process that is now under way in our national economy.

title: Catholics Protest a Plan To Shut Down 2 Schools
description: Several hundred parents and students from Roman Catholic high schools marched in front of the Brooklyn Diocese school offices for three hours yesterday to protest a plan by the diocese to close two schools because of a monthlong strike by lay teachers.

title: Market Place
description: There has been plenty of grim news to depress the market for bank stocks. The threat of default of New York City and a deteriorating market for bonds of New York State haven't helped the banks, which hold massive quantities of taxexempt bonds issued by both.

title: L. Roy Blumenthal Is Dead; Publicity Aide for Bonn, 67
description: L. Roy Blumenthal, board chairman of Roy Blumenthal International Associates, Inc., who had been public relations cotinsel on American affairs to West Germany since 1951 and West Berlin since 1961, died Tuesday of cancer in Doctors Hospital. He was 67 years, old and lived at 126 Ease 19th Street.

title: House Approves Defense Bill; Resistance Foreseen in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The House approved today, 353 to 61, a $112billion defense appropriations bill that would cut about $6billion during this fiscal year from programs requested by the Defense Department.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Off
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Association of American Rail roads said today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the week ended Sept. 27 totaled an estimated 15.8 billion tonmiles, 10.1 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the week ended Sept. 27 totaled 488,374 cars, 9.8 per cent below the corresponding week of 1974 but 0.6 per cent above the preceding week of this year. The American Trucking Association said that truck tonnage was down 11.7 per cent from the corresponding week a year ago.

title: MEANY CRITICIZES FORD ON ECONOMY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2George Meany, in his opening address here today to the convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, blamed the policies of the Nixon and Ford Administrations for continuing inflation and high unemployment and called for new national leadership.

title: Message From Spain
description: ROME, Oct. 2Among the voices lifted in spontaneous international protest against the execution of five terrorists in Franco Spain, that of the United States was scarcely to be heardand then only after the shots had been fired. Press reports in Europe do not suggest much American public indignation, and the Government, so far from making strong official protest, is continuing to negotiate for continued American use of military bases in Spain.

title: Czechoslovak Women
description: CALI, Colombia, Oct. 2 (UPI)Czechoslovakia pulled away from Colombia in the second half tonight for an 8444 victory in the women's world basketball championships. The taller and more experienced Czechoslovaks were up by just 6 points at halftime but broke Colombia's tight defense wide open in the final stage.

title: High Bail Set in Slaying Of Policeman in Camden
description: CAMDEN, Oct. 2, (UPI)Gerald Gibson, accused of murdering an offduty narcotics officer during a neighborhood feud, was held in the Camden County Jail today in lieu of a $200,000 bond.

title: Cut in Fromme Bail Denied
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2 (UPI)An appeal for reduction of the $350,000 bail set for Lynette Alice Fromme, accused of trying to shoot President Ford in Sacramento on Sept. 5, has been denied by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. The court denied the request in a brief order. Her attorney, E. Richard Walker, a Federal defender, had argued for the reduction.

title: ...and Arms Control
description: The expensive and highly sophisticated technical means American intelligence agencies now use to monitor Soviet military developmentsand verify arms control agreementsare a special case in point. Dr. Fred Ikl, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, rightly warns that disclosure of the details of American armscontrol monitoring methods provides a potential violator with a road map for deception or countermeasures, thus making the verification methods in some cases ineffective.

title: Grain Officials Linked to Inspection Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Two executives of a grain company were partners in a private agency authorized by the Department of Agriculture to inspect and grade the company's grain, according to sources close to an investigation of alleged corruption in the grainexport trade.

title: Ali, Frazier Not Eager To Retire
description: MANILA, Oct. 2Muhammad All and Joe Frazier both looked back with some satisfaction today on their third and greatest fight together, and both looked forward vaguely to more boxing, but not against each other.

title: House Panel Approves 33% Cut In Tax Incentives for Exporters
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The House Ways and Means Committee approved changes today in what is known as the DISC program of tax incentives for American exporters. The changes would cut by approximately onethird the tax savings to corporations.

title: Corporate Profile
description: The W. T. Grant Company, which filed for bankruptcy yesterday opened for business almost 69 years ago, expanded by the nineteen sixties to become the nation's thirdlargest variety chain and then overexpanded in the nineteen seventies to amass its mountainous $1billion debt.

title: Sports Today
Town in Connecticut Seeks To Preserve Busing Plan
description: WILTON, Conn., Oct. 2School officials here have come under increasing pressure from parents, teachers and others to clear away the obstacles blocking a fiveyearold voluntary school busing program that brought black children from nearby cities into the schools of this affluent, largely white town in Fairfield County.

title: House Unit to Back Civilians for Sinai
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The International Relations Committee of the House of Representatives cleared the way today to vote formal approval tomorrow for the Administration's request to station 200 American civilian technicians in the Sinai passes to help monitor the recent EgyptianIsraeli accord.

title: Books of The Times
description: Until I read On the Track or Murder by Barbara Gelb, I had not realized how desensitized I had become to the fact of murder as a result of seeing it so often on television or in the movies. It had tended to turn into a dramatic convention, a mere stage in the development of a plot. In the sort of mystery novels I prefer to read, the actual murder plays an ever smaller part, the emphasis shifting to the respective characters of the murderer and the detectives.

title: Owners to Union: Negotiate Salaries
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI)The National Football League owners challenged the players' union at a Congressional hearing today to negotiate every player's individual salary, from  the lowest rookie to established stars.

title: Notes on People
description: The next Watergate Special Presecutor, succeeding Henry S. Ruth, will be Charles Frederick Carson Ruff, a 36yearold Justice Department lawyer and a former member of the Special Prosecutor's staff. Now the chief inspector at the Drug Enforcement Administration, Mr. Ruff successfully tried the Government's case in 1972 against W. A. Boyle, president of the United Mine Workers, for illegal campaign contributions.

title: How to Get There, Which Is Half the Fun
description: To get to Peters Valley the long way, which, is to say the scenic way, take Interstate 80 to the Delaware Water Gap and get off at the last exit in New Jersey (you might want to pick up a map at the information center on the other side of the highway), turning right, in the direction of Milbrook.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  The French archeologist Franoise Claustre stared into the camera, desolate. For 17 months she had been a hostage of rebel guerrillas in Chad. Whether she lived or died depended on whether the French Government acceded to their demands for $2 million worth of arms and aid.

title: Littler, Courtney Tied at 65
Oil Company Says Libya Holds Its Employes There
description: The Libyan Government is preventing 520 nonLibyan employes of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, including 230 Americans, from leaving Libya, the oil company said yesterday.

title: TV: Comedy and Voting
description: Monty Python's Flying Circus has done well enough on public television to make the commercialTV committees itchy. Pythonesque humor tends to get broadcasters nervous. It's so unpredictable, and all that. Even on its British home ground, the Monty Python company regularly sets off slight quavers of disgust within the staid corridors of the British Broadcasting Corporation.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
Eddie Knew It Only Takes One Punch
description: MANILA, Oct. 2During the 14th round, Eddie Futch was watching Joe Frazier from the steps below the corner, watching the sweat and the water spin off Joe Frazier's face every time Muhammad Ali hit him with a right hand, watching Joe Frazier squinting to see that right hand through his left eye that had narrowed into a slit. But in a crevice of his mind, Eddie Futch was watching Davey Moore and Jimmy Doyle and Talmadge Bussey and a young middleweight named Billy back in Detroit where he first was around fighters. Somewhere else in Eddie Futch's subconscious, Bob Dylan was singing, Who killed Davey Moore, why, what's the reason for? Up in the ring now as Eddie Futch watched, Joe Frazier kept getting hit in the face with that right hand because he couldn't see it coming. And when Joe Frazier tottered back to his stool after the 14th round, Eddie Futch looked at that left eye and he knew what he had to do. But he knew that he had to talk to the fighter about it.

title: Giardino Disputes Nyguist on Effects of City U. Fees
description: All but the poorest families would be faced with increased costs of sending their children to the City University if undergraduates at the university paid as much as those at the State University do, according to the chairman of the Board of Higher Education.

title: Parley in U.S. Canceled Over Visa for Italian Red
description: ROME, Oct. 2 (Reuters)  A highlevel international conference scheduled to be held in New York later this month has been called off because of the apparent unwillingness of the United States to grant an entry visa to a leader of the Italian Communist party, it was announced here.

title: Grain Officials Linked to Inspection Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Two executives of a grain company were partners in a private agency authorized by the Department of Agriculture to inspect and grade the company's grain, according to sources close to an investigation of alleged corruption in the grainexport trade.

title: Soviet Appears to Bay Grain Under Loophole
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI)Soviet officials appear to have found a loophole in the temporary United States moratorium declared in August on grain sales to Russia, an Agriculture Department report indicated today.

title: Washington Post Prepares to Publish
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2An executive of The Washington Post said this afternoon that, despite the newspaper's inability for a second day to operate its damaged presses, 550,000 copies of an abbreviated Friday issue were being prepared using the facilities of six nonunion printing plants outside the Washington area.

title: Amoco Production Acquiring Pasco's Wyoming Properties
description: A definitive agreement has been signed covering the purchase by the Amoco Production Company of the Wyoming oil and gas producing properties of Pasco, Inc., for about $225million, it was announced yesterday. Pasco is 55.5 per centowned by StudebakerWorthington, Inc., and Amoco is a whollyowned subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana).

title: Susan Parker Cobbs, Dean At Swarthmore, Classicist
description: Susan Parker Cobbs, who retired as dean of Swarthmore College in 1969, died Sunday at the University Hospital in Birmingham, Ala. She was 69 years old and lived in Greensboro, Ala.

title: Simpson of Giants Learning the Ropes
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y. Oct. 2Usually there is not as much pressure on a secondround draft pick to be exceptional unless he's on a football team that had no firstround pick. Just ask Al Simpson, the New York Giants rookie offensive tackle out of Colorado State.

title: Wood, Field&Stream
description: LANDER, Wyo.  Have you ever hunted sage hens? asked Jack Brodie, a Lander rancher, as we sipped our brandies standup style in the dim, noisy, crowded confines of the Pronghorn Lodge Bar.

title: City's Borrowing Crisis
description: An irony is being savored by the city's union leaders in the suggestion now being made that their pension funds buy anywhere from $2billion to $4billion worth of Municipal Assistance Corpo ration bonds to help the city avoid default.

title: JOHN S. SHERMAN
description: John Seward Sherman, a civil engineer, who retired from the construction industry in 1960, died Wednesday at a nursing home in Newtown, Pa. He was 84 years old and formerly lived in Smith Orange, N. J.

title: Mets to Name Manager
description: The New York Mets will hold a major news conference at Shea Stadium this morning at which they are expected to name their manager for next season. Joe McDonald, the general manager, would not comment on their selection but it was indicated that Roy McMillan, who replaced Yogi Berra on Aug. 6, would not be rehired and would be replaced by Joe Frazier, the Mets' top minorleague manager.

title: Article 3  No Title
Commodity Price Index Off From Last Week's Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 205.8 last week.

title: HIROHITO EXTOLS JAPANESEU.S. TIES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Welcomed by President Ford amid all the pomp the White House can muster, Emperor Hirohito today voiced regret about World War II and said he hoped his visit would contribute to everlasting friendship between the people of Japan and the United States.

title: ALLIS CHALMERSWINS INSUIT AGAINST G.&W.
description: The Allis Chalmers Coropration said yesterday it had won a $2.4million claim against Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., but lost a $10million claim against the company, both involving charges of insider trading in Allis stock.

title: FAILURE OF CHAIN HAS BROAD IMPACT
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company wrote off $35million yesterday on a loan extended to the W. T. Grant Company as the effects of the bankruptcy filing by the giant retailer quickly reverberated throughout the banking, merchandise and realestate industries.

title: Man Dies Alter Kidney Machine Is Disconnected at His Request
description: LOMA LINDA, Calif., Oct. 2 (UPI)  Eleven weeks ago, Chuck McCracken, blind, partly paralyzed and in pain, had his lifesaving kidney machine disconnected and waited to die in dignity. Last night he died.

title: Bomb Blast in Addis Ababa
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 2 (UPI)A bomb exploded at the telecommunications center today, disrupting services and shattering windows. Communications were quickly restored. A state of emergency is in effect in the capital amid widespread strikes.

title: Senate Beats Bid to Kill A Gas Deregulation Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Administration, won an important victory today in its running energypolicy battle with Congress when Senate Democrats failed to kill legislation that would partly end Federal controls on wellhead prices of natural gas.

title: Card of Thanks
description: WESLOCK (Rosenstein)Dr. Viola Weslock (Mrs. Sylvan Rosenstein) wishes to express her appreciative thanks for the many expressions of sympathy which she has recelved from colleagues, coworkers and friends on the death of her beloved husband, Sylvan Rosenstein.

title: JoblessAid Total Drops
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)  Unemployment  insurance benefits for the week ending Sept. 13 were received by about 5.6 million peoplethe lowest total since January, the Labor Department announced yesterday.

title: SENATE UNIT FINDS TAX DATA MISUSE BY F.B.I. AND C.I.A
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation used the Internal Revenue Service, apparently illegally, to harass groups they felt were politically threatening, according to evidence presented today at a Senate hearing.

title: G.A.O. Seeks Wider Power
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)The General Accounting Office asked the Senate today to approve bills to extend its authority, including one that would require the agency to audit the Internal Revenue Service. Another would let it subpoena private records related to Government contracts.

title: Prices at Wholesale Showing Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Government's Wholesale Price Index for September signaled continuing inflation today, as both agricultural and nonagricultural prices rose substantially.

title: Kumaraswami Kamaraj Dead; Power Broker in Indian Politics
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 2Kumaraswami Kamaraj, the South Indian power broker who in stalled Prime Ministers Lal Bahadur Shastri and Indira Gandhi, died of a heart attack in Madras today. He was 72 years old.

title: Vietnamese on Guam Explain Why They Want to Return Home
description: ASAN, Guam, Oct. 2Tran Thanh Tong summed up simply his reasons for wanting to go back to Vietnam: I think Vietnam is myfatherland, and in Vietnam is my family.

title: Atlanta Hotel Tops South And Raises City's Spirit
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 2The South's tallest building, the 723foot Peachtree Center Plaza Hotel, was topped out here today, the most visible symbol yet of the vitality of the socalled New South.

title: Psychiatric Guidelines in Hearst and Moore Cases
description: The questions that psychiatrists are asking Patricia Hearst and Sara Jane Moore to determine their mental states stem from a discipline combining law and psychiatry whose area and scope are not perfectly defined.

title: Returning Migrants Find Puerto Rico Inhospitable
description: TOA BAJA, P. R., Oct. 1When Carmen Paz was 40 days old, in 1955, her father packed the family's belongings and took his newborn daughter, his wife, and three older children from San Juan to New York City in search of a better life.

title: SAMUEL TRESS
description: Samuel Tress, who had been a men's wear retailer in this city for many years, died yesterday of cancer in Doctors Hospital. He was years old and lived at 11 Riverside Drive.

title: Martin Marietta Offers a Discount Of 3% in Its Prices
description: Price Changes

title: Shift of Arab Funds Puts Pound at Low
description: LONDON, Oct. 2 (UPI)The pound fell to a record low today in the wake of Arab withdrawals of oil money from Britain. The dollar, also hit by reported Arab selling, dropped marginally on world money markets after rather sharp losses the previous two days.

title: Food Stamp Overhaul Is Sought In Senate Bill to Change Base
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Senator Robert Dole, Republican of Kansas, and Senator George McGovern of South Dakota, Democrat, introduced today a bill that would establish income ceilings on eligibility for food stamps and overhaul the administration of the $6billion a year program.

title: Lottery to Educate 8 Grandchildren
description: CLIFTON, Oct. 2 (AP)A Newark widower who operates a forklift for a living won $250,000 today in the Jersey Jackpot lottery drawing here.

title: House Unit to Back Civilians for Sinai
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The International Relations Committee of the House of Representatives cleared the way today to vote formal approval tomorrow for the Administration's request to station 200 American civilian technicians in the Sinai passes to hqlp monitor the recent EgyptianIsraeli accord.

title: Hospital Is Ordered To Close by Nov. 16 In Bankruptcy Case
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge yesterday ordered the closing of the French and Polyclinic Medical School and Health Center by Nov. 6.

title: GANDHI MEMORIAL IS MARKED BY INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 2India today solemnly celebrated the birthday of her national hero, Mohandas K. Gandhi.

title: Bribe Trial Heart A Freeholder Deny Any Understanding
description: MORRISTOWN, Oct. 2A Passaic County Freeholder charged with accepting a bribe from Albert scaletti, a former Mayor of Riverdale, told Mr. Scaletti in a taped conversation played here that he was not aware of an understanding, apparently referring to a bribe scheme.

title: Indoor Track Restored To P.S.A.L. Programs
description: Judging that two halves are better than one whole, the Public Schools Athletic League is prepared to reinstate its indoor track program.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 2 (AP)The National Hockey League confirmed today that the California Seals, under a group headed by Mel Swig of San Francisco, would open the season as scheduled next Wednesday. The Seals' owners were told to go ahead with plans to meet the Flames in Atlanta following a daylong meeting of the N.H.L. board of governors. There had been speculation that the Seals, whose ownership had been transferred in late July to Swig from N.H.L. trusteeship, would not operate because Swig had failed to put up a $1.5million guarantee.

title: Firewood Shortage Perils Poor Lands
description: A severe shortage of firewood exists in most poor countries of the world, where ninetenths of the people depend on wood as fuel for cooking and heating.

title: Issue and Debate
description: If a single catchword has emerged from among the complex proposals to revise the New York City Charter, that word is coterminality.

title: F.B.I. Reported to Have Found Writings on Hearst Kidnapping by William Harris
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2Two fragments of what appear to be a memoir manuscript written by William Harris, an activist in the self:styled Symbionese Liberation Army, were found by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the apartment where he lived with his wife, Emily, sources familliar with the Investigation said today.

title: Newark Police Overtime For Ford Visit Is $30,000
description: NEWARK, Oct. 2The city plans to spend about $30,000 in overtime payments for some of the 450 policemen who will provide security for President Ford's visit here Saturday, and a wood and metal snow fence has been set up in Military Park to deny unauthorized persons access to the Robert Treat Hotel, where the President will attend a Republican fundraising event.

description: Some of the largest bankruptcies in recent years include the following:

description: The Other News

title: Family Outings: Retreat From Beaches and Head for the Hills
description: The people who live near it say that in another few days the Old Mine Road in northwestern New Jerseybuilt about 1650 to carry copper from the Kittatinny Mountains to the Hudsonwill be at its most spectacular.

title: F.B.I. SAYS IT OPENED 1,000 LETTERS HERE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation opened approximately 1,000 letters between 1959 and 1966 as part of a mail surveillance program conducted in New York City, a top official of the bureau said yesterday.

title: Paring Aid to Israel
description: WASHINGTONThe case usually, made for the Sinai agreement is that it is one step in a stepbystep process that will lead to peace. As a result of conversations in August with President Anwar elSadat, King Hussein, Premier Yitzhak Rabin and other Arab and Israeli leaders, I fear that Congressional approval of the Sinai package in its present form could push the prospect for peace further than ever from our grasp.

title: HOUSE APPROVES EASING ARMS BAN AGAINST TURKEY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2In a significant victory for the Ford Administration, the House of Representatives voted tonight. to reverse itself and ease the eightmonth arms embargo against Turkey.

title: Troy Use of Council Stationery Prompts Ethics Panel Inquiry
description: The city Councils Standards and Ethics Committee will consider today whether there was a conflict of interest in the use of official Council station ery by Matthew J. Troy Jr., chairman of the Finance. Committee, to advise close friends of his new insurance business.

title: Atmosphere Launching Set
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 2 (UPI)The launching of an unmanned spacecraft designed to explore in detail the earth's outer atmosphere has been rescheduled for Monday morning. The ExplorerD originally was scheduled for launching yesterday, but problems in its telemetry and command systems forced the delay.

title: The Screen:Cold, Bright 'Katharina Blum' Is at Festival
description: "The Lost Honor of Katharina Blum," based on Heinrich Bll's German novel that was published here in English this year, is movie that looks as if it had been made out of steel. It is cold and bright and has dozens of lethal edges. It's very difficult to like even though it has things to admire. The film, a dramatized polemic about what it sees as the excesses of freedom in the democracy of West Germany today, makes its point, with tiny variations, as relentlessly as someone dealing in Revealed Truths.The movie will be shown at the New York Film Festival this evening at 6:15 and again on Monday at 9:30.Volker Schlondorff, the German director ("Young Torless," "The Sudden Wealth of the Poor People of Kombach," etc.), and Margareth von Trotta, his actress-wife, with whom he has collaborated on his recent screenplays, including "A Free Woman," share both the writing and directing credits on this new film."The Lost Honor of Katharina Blum" is about the systematic victimization of a poor but proud young woman, who works as a housekeeper and waitress and who has the bad luck to pick up and take home from a party, for one night only, a young man who is suspected by the German police of being a terrorist. Katharina had never met the young man before, but circumstantial evidence makes it appear as if she had been his mistress for months.In a period of several days, Katharina's privacy and, particularly, her honor are destroyed, first by the police, who terrorize her, and then by the yellow press, which creates in her name the image of a politicized Bonnie Parker, beautiful, heartless and on fire for the Communist cause.Though Katharina is quite quickly cleared, her life has been ruined. When she decides to take a gun to the reporter who was instrumental in her downfall, someone piously declares that the shots Katharina fired were aimed not at the reporter but at the freedom of the press.One of the difficulties with the way Mr. Schlondorff and Miss von Trotta handle their subject matter is that although everything happens in the course of the movie, it is completely without surprises. There are no unusual" insights, no progressions of understanding. Paradoxically, this is not true of Mr. Bll's novel, though the book opens with the act of violence that the film saves until the end.Mr. Bll tells Katharina's story mostly in terms of secondhand informationin official police reports and in the words of people who knew her, and only once in her own terms, and that's an official statement that continues to keep Katharina at a distance from the reader.The film sees Katharina frontally close up. The mystery, of her passion and her resolve is maintained only by the carefully controlled, implacable performance of Angela Winkler, a handsome, dark-haired woman who looks a good deal like Susan Sontagan unimportant fact, perhaps, but one that makes it difficult to believe Katharina as a waitress.I'm not familiar with the German press, and it may be that it's as outrageous as the movie describes. "We have to help simple people express themselves," says a wicked reporter while he puts words into the mouth of Katharina's dying mother. The corruption portrayed by the film is so pervasive that one expects it to challenge us more. It doesn't. Instead it has the effect of numbing us. Its singleminded intensity nails the imagination to the floor.This may be exactly what the film makers intended to do, but it's not the kind of movie that greatly interests me. "The Lost Honor of Katharina Blum" is less a drama than a neo-Brechtian demonstration of a known lack of principles.

title: O'Brien Tells Lakers To Fulfill Wiles Pact
description: Commissioner Larry O'Brien of the National Basketball Association acted last night to bring an end to the growing controversy between Wilt Chamberlain and the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Veeck Reported in White Sox Deal
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (UPI) Bill Veeck, who has owned and operated three American League baseball clubs, is seeking an option to buy the financially troubled Chicago White Sox for $10million. John Allyn, the club owner, said last night in a television interview, that Veeck was seeking the necessary funds. Veeck, now a resident of Easton, Md., owned the franchise in 19591960.

title: After a Rousing British Labor Parley, Rhetoric Yields to Reality
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 2Harold Wilson has emerged from the annual Labor party conference with his power intact and his policies unchanged. He received. much criticism, and the stormy behavior of many of the 3,000 delegates who assembled here this week left little doubt that Britain's governing party remained divided and emotionally insecure.

title: Key Indicator Ends Session at 794.55
description: The stock market halted a threeday decline yesterday as bargain hunters cautiously moved off the sidelines. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, off a total of 34.44 points through Wednesday, closed with a gain of 10.39 points to 794.55.

title: 12 COUNTIES TO GET FLOODDAMAGE AID
description: President Ford yesterday named 12 New York State counties, including Queens, Westchester and Rockland, as major disaster assistance areas following last week's crippling rains.

title: Yesterday's Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: LISBON FACTIONS TRADING CHARGES
description: LISBON, Oct. 2Charges and countercharges increased here today in the wake of warnings by the Socialist party last night that the extreme left was about to stage a coup.

title: Furs by Partos Bestow All the Femininity That Money Can Buy
description: There are a lot of reasons why it might be nice to be rich, and Emeric Partos is one of them. But even the rich would, and do, have their problems with Mr. Partos who, earlier this week, showed his 21st fur collection at Bergdorf Goodman.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY. OCTOBER 3. 1975

title: Bankers Urge State Aid to Finance Unit In Credit Squeeze, but Carey Resists Idea
description: Governor Carey was advised by a panel of banking experts yesterday that it would take an infusion of $142million in state funds to strengthen the Housing Finance Agency to the point where it might be able to regain investors confidence and raise, on its own, the money it needs.

title: LEVITT TO INVEST HIS PENSION FUNDS TO TIDE OVER CITY
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt agreed yesterday to use $250million from two state employe pension systems to help tide the city over its cash shortages through, this month and pledged to ask another state pension system, not under his control, to help the city next month.

title: Move to Curb Office Accounts Upsets Congressmen at Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Federal Election Commission's proposal to regulate Congressional office accounts as a form of electionyear political spending ran into a storm of criticism at a Senate hearing today.

title: Protests on Spain
description: The Security Council has wisely sidetracked Mexico's demand that Spain be suspended from the United Nations for executing five men convicted of murdering policemen. Individual governments can protest the executionsmany have done sobut it would be monumental hypocrisy to suspend Spain for a practice indulged in to a far greater extent by other U.N. members: Ethiopia, for example, or Burundi, or Uganda, whose Presidenta racist murdererhas just received an ovation from the General Assembly.

title: PORK BELLIES UP 1C A POUND LIMIT
description: Pork bellies for February delivery jumped the daily limit of 1 cents a pound yesterday to set a new high for bellies. The contract closed at $1.02 6/10 on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, up from $1.01 1/10.

title: A's Star Eager to Test Thumb in Boston
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 2The Oakland A's took off for Boston today, looking for their fourth straight pennant, still uncertain about the availability of Joe Rudi, but very aware of what their healthy relief pitchers could mean in the threeoffivegame series for theAmerican League championship starting Saturday.

title: EDWIN A. WAGNER
description: Edwin A. Wagner, an advertising salesman with Story & KellySmith, Inc., newspaper representatives, died yesterday of asphyxiation following a fire at his home. 8726 Marengo Street in Hollis, Queens. His age was 48. He had apparently been smoking in bed.

title: Cheap Shots
description: Wherever he goes these dayswhether in Yugoslavia or in Illinoisthe President of the United States does not seem able to resist sniping at the City of New York. Perhaps he thinks his cheap shots at this premier American city make for good politics at home and abroad. In reality, they only betray his own incredible insensitivity to a potentially disastrous situation that could affect every city in this country.

title: Gunmen End Siege Of Cafe in London; Leader Shoots Self
description: LONDON, Friday, Oct. 3 (AP)  Three gunmen who had seized a London restaurant and then held out in its basement storeroom for five days released their six Italian hostages unharmed early today, Scotland Yard announced.

title: CANCELING OF FAY IS CALLED PROPER
description: Lee Grant referred to him as the mad programer when she recently discussed on the Tonight show the swift cancellation of her comedy series, Fay, after only three televised episodes.

title: Music: Fennimore Plays Own Works
description: Joseph Fennimore is a pianist and composer who has been working on behalf of other composers for the last few years by presenting a series called Hear America First. Wednesday night he gave a program of his own music in Carnegie Recital Hall, and it would be tempting to say that he was still working for other cornposers.

title: STATE TO GET PLAN ON FLUORIDATION
description: TRENTON, Oct 2Mandatory fluoridation of New Jersey's drinking water is expected to be recommended soon by Dr. Peter Preuss.

title: I.R.S. Said to Seek $100,000 In Back Taxes From Rebozo
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Oct. 2 (AP)  The Internal Revenue Service says that Charles G. Rebozo, close friend and confidant of former President Richard M. Nixon, owes more than $100,000 in back income taxes, the Knight Newspapers said today.

title: SOME RESTRAINT SEEN ON OIL PRICE
description: PARIS, Oct. 2  Assistant Treasury Secretary Gerald L. Parsky said today the full extent of a 10 per cent increase in prices decreed by the oil exporters cartel last weekend will not be taken by all member states because of the present weakness in demand.

title: Oil Company Says Libya Holds Its Employes There
description: The Libyan Government is preventing 520 nonLibyan employes of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, including 230 Americans, from leaving Libya, the oil company said yesterday.

title: Informant in Hoffa Search Gets a 24Hour Extension
description: DETROIT, Oct. 2The Informant who is providing information to two Senate investigators in an effort to find the body of James R. Hoffa got in touch with them this afternoon, saying that the effort was continuing and asking for 24hour extension.

title: BedfordStuyvesant Complex Is Opened
description: Isn't it spectacular? said a beaming Franklin A. Thomas, president of the BedfordStuyvesant Restoration Corporation, as he welcomed guests yesterday to the opening ceremonies of the corporation's new $6million commercial center.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: In a town where the competition is rugged and the citizenry has developed a fairly sophisticated palate held in check, recently, by an increasingly watchful eye on the wallet, the best recommendation a restaurant can have, is, consistent popularity over an extended period of time. For a change of pace this week, let's report briefly on 4 few such establishments instead of chronicling voyages of discovery for fellow explorers.

title: Atlanta Hotel Tops South And Raises City's Spirit
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 2The South's tallest building, the 723foot Peachtree Center Plaza Hotel, was topped out here today, the most visible symbol yet of the vitality of the so called New South.

title: Class Sizes and Rehiring Still Plague City Schools
description: Two weeks after the end of the citywide teachers' strike and after a settlement that was supposed to provide limits on oversized classes, shorter school days for pupils and the rehiring of 2,400 laidoff teachers  conditions in many schools are reported to be confused, uncertain and in open violation of some contract provisions.

title: Stephanie M. Lee, S. L. Maier Jr. Wed
description: Stephanie Maria Lee and Samford Lee Maier Jr. were married here yesterday evening in the Central Synagogue by Rabbi Lewis: Bogage. The bridegroom is a member of the International Banking Group of the First National City Bank in San Juan, P. R., where the couple will live.

title: Nancy E. Cronkite Is Married To Gifford Cochran Whitney
description: Nancy Elizabeth Cronkite, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Cronkite, was married here yesterday afternoon to Gifford Cochran Whitney. The Rev. Thomas F. Pike performed the Episcopal ceremony at the LivingstoneLearmonth Gallery, which the bride room represents.

title: W. T. Grant Asks Court For Bankruptcy Status
description: The W. T. Grant Company, one of America's largest retail chains, yesterday filed a petition in voluntary bankruptcy, listing debts of more than $1 billion.

title: Firewood Shortage Perils Poor Lands
description: A severe shortage of firewood exists in most poor countries of the world, where ninetenths of the people depend on wood as fuel for cooking and heating.

title: Playoff Umpires Named in A.L.
description: The American League president, Lee MacPhail, announced yesterday the assignment of six umpires for the playoff series between the Boston Red Sox and Oakland A's, beginning tomorrow in Boston.

title: C. H. JELLSTADT, EXSEARS HEAD
description: Charles H. Kellstadt, former chairman and chief executive officer of Sears, Roebuck & Co. and the General Development Corporation of Miami, one of the country's largest community developers, died Wednesday in Chicago. He was 78 years old and lived in Chicago and LauderdalebytheSea, Fla.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: A Step Back in Time at a Big Price.
description: Dinning deep to make news, NeimanMarcus, the Dallasbased department store, is dredging up the ghost of preChristmas past as the expensive and imaginative gift suggeston that is an annual feature of its Yule catalogue.

title: Spanish Airline Cancels Flights In the Face of Boycotts in Europe
description: Boycotts by trade unions in Europe prompted Spain's Iberia Airlines to cancel flights to Italian and Scandinavian destinations yesterday.

title: Busy Shea Season to Open With Jets Pick Over Patriots
description: On Sunday the Jets and the New England Patriots will play the first of 14 pro football games scheduled for Shea Stadium this season, and the Jets are favored to win. Because the game is sold out, it will be televised locally, Channel 4, 1 P.M. The Giants will be in St. Louis playing the Cardinals, Channel 2, 2 P.M. Because the Jets are at home there will be no late game telecast in the New York area. Elsewhere it will be the EaglesRedskins contest.

title: A. T. & T. Oversubscribed In Common Stock Offer
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's public offering of 12 million shares of common stock priced. Wednesday at $46 a share  was overscribed yesterday, Morgan Stanley & Co., the leading underwriter, reported.

title: Hoboken School Strikers Are Ordered Into Court
description: JERSEY CITY Oct. 2Leaders of the striking Hoboken Teachers Association were ordered today by Judge Thomas O'Brien to appear in Superior Court here tomorrow morning to explain why the union had not paid $35,000 in fines levied against it for violating a backtowork order.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: WESTINGHOUSE SUED BY VIRGINIA ELECTRIC
description: The Virginia Electric and Power Company filed suit yesterday against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation over its contract that calls for Westinghouse to supply the utility with uranium to fuel its nuclear power plants.

title: Family Dispute Delays Funeral Rites
description: A funeral service at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church was delayed briefly yesterday after a son of the deceased protested the widow's arrangements for private rites, and insisted that his father's wishes be followed and that he be buried in his uniform with appropriate flags and regalia.

title: City's Medical Chief Proposes Hybrid Unit to Run Health Care
description: The city's Health Commissioner endorsed yesterday the establishment of a hybrid health agencycombining both municipal and volunteer servicesto insure more efficient medical care here.

title: 11 Killed in Ulster In Day of Shooting And Bomb Incidents
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 2Eleven persons were killed today in a spate of renewed activity by bombers and gunmen in Northern Ireland.

title: AMEX INDEX IS UP BY 0.12 TO 82.37
description: Stocks on the American Stock Exchange edged upward a little in slow trading yesterday, with the index closing at 82.37 for a gain of 0.12. In the overthecounter market trading was also slow, with the NASDAQ industrials, closing slightly higher at 78.61, up 0.42.

title: She Saddles a Winner at 18
description: Even if you're a former fashion model, like 18yearold Laure Connelly, you don't wear a dress to saddle a race horse.

title: PRESEASON HOCKEY
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: KOSYGIN WILLING TO SELL OIL TO U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 2Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin was reported to have told an American visitor that the Soviet Union was willing to negotiate longterm sales of oil to the United States.

title: Islamic Art at Met Is Timeless Wonder
description: Half an hour is enough of anything, Edith Wharton used to say. But it distinctly is not enough for the new Islamic galleries, which as of tomorrow will rank among the glories of the Metropolitan Museum.

title: French Concern to Build Fertilizer Plant in Syria
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 3 (AP)France has agreed to build a $300million nitrogen fertilizer plant that officials said would save Syria $400million now spent yearly to import fertilizer.

title: Sihanouk Arrives for Address at U.N.
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's titular head of state, arrived in New York yesterday and said that he would not assume the responsibility of government in Phnom Penh but that neither would he become the roving ambassador that Western diplomats have speculated would be his chief role under the new Communist regime.

title: 7 Avowed Democratic 1976 Candidates (And Humphrey) to Be at Forum Today
description: Like the referee in a boxing match, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey will have maximum exposure and minimum bruising today at one of the major New York Democratic party events of the year. It will be a rare political happeningthe joint appearance of seven Democratic contenders for the, Presidency.

title: Belmont Jocket's
Payoffs to Assemblymen On Malpractice Charged
description: TRENTON, Oct. 3A Democratic Assemblyman who charged that several legislators had received political contributions of more than $500 to block a medical malpractice bill, said today that one of the Assembly's Democratic leaders had been promised future legal business to help kill the measures.

title: Oil Making Norway a Wary Economic Giant
description: OSLO, Norway, Sept. 29This austere., sparsely populated nation, which has played a quiet role in Europe for generations, is rapidlyand somewhat reluctantlyemerging as an economic and political power.

title: U.S. Safety Aide Replies To Renomination Critics
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3A member of the National Transportation Safety Board defend ed today her actions in accepting free transportation from a, railroad and owning stock in an airline; both of which had suffered accidents that were being investigated by the board.

title: Olga Kerensky Dies at 90
description: LONDON, Oct. 3 (Reuters)Olga Kerensky, former wife of Alexander Kerensky, died in Southport, England, on Wednesday at the age of 90. Mr. Kerensky was premier of the Provisional Government of Russia from July, to October, 1917, after the abdication of Czar Nicholas II and before the Bolsheviks seized power. He died in 1970 in New York.

title: Gunmen Storm Beirut Airport; 3 Persons Are Reported Killed
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Saturday, Oct. 4 (UPI)Five gunmen attacked Beirut international airport at dawn today, killing or injuring an undetermined number of civilians waiting to board planes. One terrorist attempted to commandeer a waiting airliner.

title: The New Inflation
description: The continuing upward march of wholesale prices is disheartening. It foreshadows sharper rises in living costs for American consumers and high,er production costs for American industry. Even more alarmingly, it exposes the bankruptcy of the Administration's doctrine that what may be called the new inflation can be stopped by increasing the money supply at a moderate pace and keeping plenty of slack in the economy.

title: Lawyer Says Miss Hearst Was Not Affidavit Source
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3The story that Patricia Hearst was broken down by mistreatment at the hands of her kidnappers, recounted in an affidavit that she signed, came first from an anonymous source and not from Miss Hearst, according to one of her lawyers.

title: TV: In Mexico, Each Channel Is Kept a Class Apart
description: Nobody paid much attention last week to An Evening of Mexican Television at Alice Tully Hall, even though a swarm of media heavies  presidents, vice presidents, news and entertainment executives from all three networks  were on hand, in black tie, for the ceremonies and a dinnerdance afterward in the Empire Room of the WaldorfAstoria.

title: Judges, Despite Criticism, To Meet on Desegregation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 About 20 Federal district judges from around the country are scheduled to meet here this weekend in closed sessions to discuss school desegregation cases and how to handle them. At least three of those scheduled to attend are among the judges now involved in desegregation litigation.

title: China Seeking Advanced U. S. Computer
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 China is seeking to buy an advanced Americanmade computer that would enhance her search for oil and could also strengthen her defense capabilities, according to Administration officials.

title: City May Zone Out the Massage Parlors
description: A new and unusual zoning ordinance designed to shut down socalled massage parlors will be proposed for Times Square, Mayor Beanie said yesterday.

title: Bicentennial Inventory Ends in a Major Art Show in Jersey
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Oct. 3A major exhibition of privately owned American paintings, which were found by volunteers who visited hundreds of homes in the Princeton area for the Smithsonian Institution, will open Sunday at the Squibb Gallery here

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Carey Broadening Inquiry To Include Suffolk Politics
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Oct. 3Governor Carey has reportedly broadened the mandate of his special state prosecutor here to include not only the investigation of the Suffolk Police Commissioner and the District Attorney but also political corruption and other matters In the county, wellplaced state and local officials said tonight.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Barges Penetrate Ice To Reach Prudhoe Bay
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3The Atlantic Richfield Company said today that the last of 15 barges, whose delayed voyage under severe ice conditions had threatened to postpone the development of Alaska's North Slope oil, arrived at their destination, Prudhoe Bay, late last night.

title: Can the South Bronx Save New York?
description: Although distance and a different magnitude of problems separate City Hall from the South Bronx, their nowcommon miseries can perhaps be useful in solving their common problems. New York City spends approximately $1 billion a year to subsidize the South Bronx. What a relief it would be to us all if somehow this huge subsidy could be converted into a positive flow of money into the city's treasury.

title: New Chef for Mets Joseph Filmore Frazier
description: The new manager of the Mets never went to college because, as he says, he couldn't add worth a damn. He found a simple solution to his arithmetical shortcomings by marrying a mathematics teacher. With this kind of straightline logic applied to baseball, Joseph Filmore Frazier has hopped from pennant to pennant in the Mets' farm system (four in the Iast five years) and now has made the big leap into the Big Apple as resident manager at Shea Stadium.

title: TURKEY PRAISES EASING OF CURBS
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 3Turkey's Foreign Minister praised the United States Congress today for easing the Turkish arms embargo but said American installations here would not be allowed to function again immediately.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1975

title: Stockholder Suit Hits W. T. Grant; Receiver Is Urged
description: A classaction suit was filed yesterday on behalf of 36,000 shareholders against the W. T. Grant Company, which entered a petition in voluntary bankruptcy Thursday. The suit accused the company of having issued misleading statements in the last two years to conceal its true condition.

title: RALLY IS STAGED BY BRITISH POUND
description: LONDON, Oct. 3 (UPI) The British pound moved closer to the $2 level in early trading today, but then rallied And closed the day almost unchanged from yesterday.

title: Danbury School Head Quits After Racial Battles
description: The chairman of the Danbury school board stepped down last night and 16 students at Danbury High School in Connecticut were suspended for 10 days in the aftermath of battles last week between black and white students at the school, the local school superintendent said.

title: Cash in 200 State Funds Studied for Use in Crisis
description: Governor Carey is considering a plan to tap 200 special funds scattered within the vast state bureaucracy for up to $1.5billion as a ready cash replacement for the money it can no longer borrow in the private credit market.

title: Cash in 200 State Funds Studied for Use in Crisis
description: Governor Carey is considering a plan to tap 200 special funds scattered within the vast state bureaucracy for up to $1.5billion as a ready cash replacement for the money it can no longer borrow in the private credit market.

title: FORD IS ADAMANT ON CITY CRISIS AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Ford Administration, in the person of Press Secretary Ron Nessen, went out of its way today to say that there had been no change in its position that it would not and could not take direct action to alleviate New York City's financial problems.

title: DATA SHOW ARMY USED INFORMANT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The United States Army placed an informant among a group of American lawyers defending soldiers before military courts in West German garrisons, according to documents made public today at the Federal District Court here.

title: VIOLATIONS CITED IN BUILDING MISHAP
description: A sixStory Harlem tenement whose stairway collapsed early Thursday injuring a 14yearold boy, had 90 code violations including one that officials tentatively believe caused the collapse.

title: MET STAGEHANDS EXTEND CONTRACT
description: The Metropolitan Opera company reached an agreement yesterday with the stagehands' union to extend its contract through Dec. 31 and said that its talks with the musicians' union appeared to be progressing in a healthy manner.

title: Nance: Burmese Triumph
description: Like many performers of Asian classical dance theater, the Dancers and Musicians of the Burmese National Theater present allegorical dramas that teach moral truths.

title: Art: Empathy of Gordon Parks
description: The art of photography is an art of representation. But what is represented in it varies greatly, not only in the documentary but in the expressive sense. The world out there, observed and studied and recorded in a fraction of a minute, may be basic donne, but what we see in the picture that results owes its special character to the quality of feeling invested in it. In this art, as in others, there are no valuefree representations. Every image is the direct expression of an emotion.

title: Judge Refuses to Dismiss SchoolingDeficiency Suit
description: NEWARK, Oct. 3A Superior Court judge refused today to dismiss an unusual suit that charges a school system with failing to educate properly a pupil suffering from dyslexia, a disorder that causes the brain to distort visual images.

title: Dow Shows Increase of 18.66 to 813.21
description: Stock prices registered a broad advance yesterday in moderately active trading. The upturn, which topped gains scored on Thursday, was attributed to hopes that the Federal Reserve Board might be easing its monetary policy.

title: SUIT ON SCHOOLING OF DYSLECTIC SET
description: NEWARK, Oct. 3A Superior Court judge refused today to dismiss an unusual suit that charges a school system with failing to educate properly a pupil suffering from dyslexia, a disorder that causes the brain to distort visual images.

title: U.S JOBLESS RATE EDGED OFF TO 8.3% FOR SEPTEMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The nation's job situation improved slightly in September, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Plan to Drop Slower Students Offered to Save City U. Funds
description: The chairman of the Board of Higher Education suggested yesterday that the City University might have to begin forcing out lagging students as a means of coping with current budget stringencies.

title: Beame Turns On the Charm for Bankers
description: Mayor Beame was smiling and selfassured last night as the host of a champagne reception welcoming the American Bankers Association to its 100th annual convention.

title: Food Stamp Program Called Monster by Mormon Aide
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 3 (UPI)  A Mormon leader warned the opening session of the church's semiannual general conference today that the food stamp program was a monster that threatens us all.

title: Commonwealth Oil And Tesoro Corp. Exploring Merger
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation and the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company announced yesterday that they were exploring the possibility of a merger. The announcement was made in connection with another made by Tesoro that the company had obtained a sevenyear bank credit of $220million and that it will lend $20million to Commonwealth Oil.

title: POTATO FUTURES EQUAL A RECORD
description: Potatoes jumped ahead in futures trading yesterday to match their previous record high level before moving down somewhat in late trading.

title: In Memoriam
description: SHULMANBill, Cherished and loving memories, you are always in our hearts. Sondra, Mark, Diane, Jackie and William.

title: Labor's Big Wage Goal
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3Doubledigit wage increases will be labor's goal at the bargaining table in next year's heavy round of contract negotiations in such strategic industries as automobiles, rubber, trucking, electrical manufacturing and construction. That is the consensus among the heads of major unions assembled here for the 20th anniversary convention of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

title: Ballet: Cranko's Opus I Joins Joffrey Repertory
description: When John Cranko's Opus I was first presented in Stuttgart on Nov. 7, 1965, it created comparatively little stir. Indeed, critical attention at its premiere was taken up largely by Kenneth MacMillan's Song of the Earth, having its premiere on the same program. Yet the Cranko piece, set to Webern's Passacaglia, Opus 1, has proved oddly resilient.

title: Holtzman, Tian the Starters in Boston
description: BOSTON, Oct. 3The Boston Red Sox talked today. about the success they've en joyed in their confrontations with the Oakland A's in recent years, but those clashes occurred when the A's psychological switch was turned off.

title: Sense and Nonsense
description: The usual flapdoodle which government spokesmen bring to labor gatherings was refreshingly absent from the remarks made by W. J. Usery Jr., Chief Federal Mediator and President Ford's special assistant for labor affairs, at the A.F.L.C.I.O. convention in San Francisco this week.

title: Taxpayer Checkoffs May Not Cover Full Campaign Subsidies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Treasury Department may not have enough cash in a special account next year to pay full campaign subsidies to all the Presidential candidates in 1976 who may be eligible to receive this new political benefit.

title: Executives Resign At Rockland Utility
description: Charles H. Tenney 2d announced yesterday his intention of resigning as chairman, chief executive and a director of Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., at the annual meeting next April. James F. Smith, vice president, treasurer and a director, also resigned from the upstate utility.

title: Film Festival: Nostalgia:'Hearts of West' Views Early 30's Hollywood
description: The early nineteen-thirties in Hollywood: sound is still a new toy, Clark Gable, Greta Garbo and Joan Crawford are virtually kids at M-G-M, and the Warner brothers are beginning to turn out those terrifically popular films about gangsters and G-men, and imposing historical personages who look like Paul Muni. Hollywood is approaching its Golden Age and Americans can't get their fill of the talkies, formerly referred to as photoplays.That's one side of the old Hollywood. The glamorous side. The other side is the scroungy, tacky world of B-pictures  Westerns, war movies, raucous musicals, shot on shoestrings on back-lots and in the nearby hills, by fly-by-night operators who make the major studio film makers look like Cellinis.This is the eccentric world recalled with such affection and good humor by "Hearts of the West," the benign comedy directed by Howard Zeiff that will be shown at the New York Film Festival tonight at 9:30. The film, which will be shown again at the festival Tuesday evening at 6:15, will open its regular commercial run at the Sutton Theater on Wednesday."Hearts of the West," written by Rob Thompson, a brand-new Hollywood writer, is a kind of testimonial to innocence. There's not a truly nasty person in the movie, though it has its share of operators and con artists, each of whom fails with varying degrees of ineptitude.The film tells the remarkable adventures of an Iowa farm boy named Lewis Tater (Jeff Bridges), whose father is called Pa Tater and who dreams of becoming a writer of Western novels like Zane Grey.To this end Lewis goes west to pick up local color and winds up, instead, reluctantly being groomed as a Western star of B-pictures directed with a stunning hysterical lack of talent by a Mr. Kessler (Alan Arkin). When Kessler is shooting on location and running behind schedule, he likes to hear his "cowboys" sitting around the campfire at night yelling encouraging cowboy yells. It gives him reassurance."Hearts of the West" is full of delightful detailsmost notably, Mr. Arkinbut it is sometimes too innocent for its own good. It meanders in a way that would horrify any B-picture maker. It develops characters and situations and then doesn't do anything much with them, which is a luxury that even A-pictures have never easily afforded. And, in Lewis, it has a hero who must be two things at oncea comic dunderhead, a sort of a Merton-of-the-movies, to give the film comic drive, as well as straight man, to give it poignancy. It doesn't always work.Instead, the film is carried by the consistent intelligence of its observations and the sweetness with which it tolerates ineffectual rogues, rascals and fanatics of a very parochial kind. These include a cowboy "extra" who says proudly of his own profile, "Reeks character, that's what they said," as well as Mr. Bridges's Lewis, who is always writing in his head. Suffering a setback in his Hollywood career, he bucks himself up by rewriting his life: "Living by his wits . . . he met the challenge of this womanless land."The film is also consistently well played by Mr. Arkin and Mr. Bridges and the large supporting cast, including Blythe Danner, Andy Griffith, Donald Pleasence and by Richard B. Shull and Anthony James, who recall Twain's Duke and Dauphin as operators of a phony correspondence school for writers."Hearts of the West" may well be the kind of imperfect movie that is as much as it is just because of the ways in which it is imperfect. This was one of the charms of Mr. Zeiff's "Slither," and it could be that Mr. Zeiff's talent is one we must learn to appreciate without wishing it were more conventionally slick.

title: Jail in Dutchess Restricts Inquiry By State Agency
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 3 An administrator of the Dutchess County Jail, which has a history that includes inmate suicides and rioting, has issued an order denying access to investigators of the newly reconstituted State Commission of Correction unless they are accompanied by jail supervisors.

title: Air Force FieldGoal Kicker Seeks Mark in Navy Game
description: Dave Lawson kicked only one extrapoint when he played high school football in Shawnee Mission, Kan. The defensive lineman never tried a field goal in high school and got the chance for the conversion only because the regular placekicking specialist was hurt that day.

title: Burke Touchdown Wins for Iona, 126
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Oct. 3Kevin Burke ran around left end 24 yards for a thirdquarter touchdown and led Iona to a 126 Metropolitan Eight Football Conference victory over Fairleigh Dickinson University tonight.

title: No Blank Check
description: Influential members of Cpngress are still haunted by the fear that a favorable vote on any aspect of the IsraeliEgyptian Sinai accord will be interpreted ini retrospect as blank check approval of a massive new American commitment in the Middle East. Memories of the 1964 Gulf of Tonkin resolution, and its subsequent misuse by the Johnson Administration, loom large.

title: NORTHROP'S GUESTS ESCAPE PUNISHMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (Reuters)The Defense Department said today it did not plan to punish 33 top Pentagon officials who were entertained at a Northrop Corporation hunting lodge although they had violated the intent of a Defense Department regulation.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Major league baseball, led by Los Angeles and Cincinnati in the National League and Boston in the American League, recorded its thirdbest attendance in history, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn said yesterday. The unofficial total for 1975 was 29,811,942 by the 24 clubs. That was down 213,666 from a year ago, but the decrease was blamed on 17 weather postponementsincluding 10 cancellationsin the final month.

title: MILTON WEILL, 84, FEDERATION CHIEF
description: Milton Weill, president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York from 1951 to 1954, died Thursday night in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Sarasota, Fla.

title: Ulster Protestant Force Is Outlawed by Britain
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Saturday, Oct. 4 (Reuters)The British Government today outlawed the Ulster Volunteer Force only hours after the Protestant paramilitary organization admitted responsibility for a 24hour wave of bombings and shootings against Roman Catholic targets in which 12 persons were killed.

title: Moody's Cuts Security Ratings of 3 More City Agencies
description: Moody's Investors Service yesterday downgraded the credit rating on three additional types of New York City securities, further blocking access to credit markets that have already refused to buy virtually any note or bond with the city's name attached to it.

title: Colombia Explains Aid Refusal
description: As he ended a state visit here this week, President Alfonso Lpez Michelsen of Colombia explained his Government's decisionunusual for a Latin American nation  to forego further United States aid and restrict new foreign investments sharply. He also said that Colombianizing of existing foreign operations would continue.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: One person was killed and five were injured when a boiler exploded in a house in Richmond Hill, Queens. John Chapman, 25 years old, was killed in the blast. The injured were William Berkley, 15, who lost his right leg; his mother, Courtney, 33; Mrs. Betty Grizzel, 33; her sort, Robert Simmons, 15, and Tania Garcia, 27.

title: Mental Patient Held In Upstate Slayings Of Mother, 3 Sisters
description: A 21yearold patient in a state mental hospital allegedly shot to death his mother and three younger sisters in their home last night and then set fire to the house in the rural upstate village of Interlaken.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DIG US This is West Side Day at the American Museum of Natural History, an openhouse celebration of the traditional sights, sounds and diversions offered to the public at Central Park West and 79th Street in an informal, carnival atmosphere, also heralding more treats to come in the new season. Judging by the daylong program, which reportedly drew more than 40,000 visitors to last year's fifth annual day, there might be something for everybody from 10 A.M. to 4:45 P.M.

title: Greeks Stress Cyprus
description: ATHENS, Oct. 3Diplomatic sources said today that the reek Government was hoping that the American decision to lift part of the arms embargo against Turkey would break the stalemate over Cyprus.

title: MOYNIHAN ASSAILS UGANDA PRESIDENT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3Daniel P. Moynihan, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, made an approving reference today to a description of President Idi Amin of Uganda as a racist murderer.

title: Chamberlain Deal Still at an Impasse
description: The New York Knicks and the Los Angeles Lakers talked again about Wilt Chamberlain yesterday, but the impasse over the retired center's return to basketball remained unresolved.

title: Asheville Bids Thomas Wolfe, Come Home
description: ASHEVILLE, N. C., Oct. 3  The long spiritual exile of Thomas Wolfe, the bitter, impassioned young genius who felt he could not go home again after his first novel was published, ended today as the city of Asheville folded her arms around her native son 37 years after his death.

title: CHAPTER XI FILED BY VAN DYK CORP.
description: The Van Dyk Research Corporation filed a petition for reorganization yesterday under Chapter XI in the United States District Court in Newark. Failure to complete a $10million public offering of securities last month and inability to obtain adequate alternate financing necessitated the action, the company said.

title: New Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1975

title: New jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey School system was plagued with another walkout yesterday as 300 Howell Township teachers struck for higher wages and to protest personnel cutbacks. The strike came just one day after teachers in the ParsippanyTroy Hills district reached a contract agreement ending a twoweek strike in Morris County's largest school system.

title: Lottery Drawing Set On the Unsold Winners
description: The New York State Lottery will hold a special drawing Oct. 31 to give away nearly $1.4million in surplus funds that have accumulated from unsold winning tickets of the weekly lottery, which was changed last month. Tickets for the special drawing go on sale next Wednesday.

title: Tie Is Tied To a Cause
description: Question for those fascinated by the messages on clothing: Does the tie of the moment with its pattern of nibbled apples symbolize: A) the downfall of Adam and Eve, B) a promotional campaign by the apple industry, C) the salvation of Grand Central Terminal?

title: He Has Shown Us He Can Win
description: Down on the field at Shea Stadium, goal posts and freshly chalked football stripes obscured the contours of the baseball diamond. And upstairs in the empty Diamond Club yesterday, the fresh smell of disinfectant rose from oak floors being mooned by an attendant.

title: Dr. Henry Allen Moe Dead at 81; Administered Guggenheim Fund
description: Dr. Henry Allen Moe, principal administrator of the Jdhn Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation from, its founding in 1.925 to his retirement in 1963, died Wednesday at the Hospital for Special Surgery. He was 81 years old and had homes in Riverdale, the Bronx, and Sherman, Conn.

title: Kidnapping Victim, 20, Shows Up Unharmed
description: A 20yearold Trumbull, Con., woman, an apparent victim of a kidnapping and the subject of an F.B.I. search, walked into a classroom at Solomon Shecter High School in the Flushing section of Queens yesterday, safe and unharmed.

title: Big Board Seat Up
E.P.A. Acts to Cut Emissions Of Steelmaking Furnaces
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency has announced standards sharply limiting the airpolluting emissions from new or modified electric arc steelmaking furnaces.

title: City Is Laying Off 23 Aides On the Management Level
description: Twentythree city management officials at the middle and high levels will be laid off shortly as part of the impending reorganization of three of nine superagencles, John E.
