Zuccotti, chairman of the City Planning Commission, said yesterday, adding that the dismissals would save the city $511,000 a year.

title: Upturn Eludes Hardship Unemployed
description: DETROIT, Oct. 3  If the economy is turning up, you cannot prove it by Doug McNamara, a 35yearold autodesign technician with a wife and three children, who has been out of work for the last 10 months.

title: TAX FRAUD CASE SEEKS 1.5MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Justice Department today charged a prominent California tax lawyer, a bank in the Netherlands Antilles and two other individuals with having conspired to defraud the Government of nearly $1.5million in Federal taxes allegedly owed but not paid by the lawyer's clients, who the department said included a number of prominent California doctors and lawyers.

title: Todorov Sets Lift Mark
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Oct. 3 (AP)George Todorov, a Bulgarian weight lifter, set a world record for the 132pound weight class today when he snatched 281 pounds in an international tournament at Varna on the Black Sea, the Bulgarian press agency BTA reported. The previous record of 280 pounds was held by Norair Nourikyan, also of Bulgaria.

title: Old Chinese Tale, Modern Puzzle
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 3Several weeks ago the Chinese press began an unexpected and seemingly baffling denunciation of one of the great classics of Chinese literature, The Water Margin, a picaresque saga of banditry and rebellion set in the 12thcentury Sung Dynasty.

title: At Arlington Cemetery, a Wreath From the Emperor and Empress of Japan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3While a bugler sounded taps, Emperor Hirohito stood with his head bowed today before the Tomb of the Unknowns at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Alexandra W. Sanford Is Married
description: Alexandra Willim Sanford, financial vice president of the New York Junior League, was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Rowland Compton, a broker with Blyth Eastman Dillon here. The Rev. Dr. John B. Coburn performed the ceremony in St. James' Episcopal Church, and a reception was held at the Colony Club.

title: Student Loan Plan Is Assailed; Curb on Fraud Urged in House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3To combat fraud in the federally insured student loan program, which he called one of the most gigantic ripoffs in the country, Representative Robert H. Michel, Republican of Illinois, today introduced legislation that would invoke criminal penalties against profitmaking schools and financial institutions cheating the Government or students.

title: E.P.A.Is Prohibited From Placing Tax Or Ban on Parking
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) Congress voted today to prohibit the Evironmental Protection Agency from taxing, limiting or banning automobile parking in urban areas.

title: Asheville Bids Thomas Wolfe, Come Home
description: ASHEVILLE, N. C., Oct. 3  The long spiritual exile of Thomas Wolfe, the bitter, impassioned young genius who felt he could not go home again after his first novel was published, ended today as the city of Asheville folded her arms around her native son 37 years after his death.

title: People and Business
description: The Midwest, the nation's industrial heartland is in trouble, Ralph R. Widner, president of the Academy for Contemporary Problems, said yesterday at a seminar of the Ohio Foundations Conference in Cleveland.

title: 1,000 Don Masks to Aid Theater
description: PRINCETON, Oct. 3More than 1,000 New Jerseyans turned out for a festive masked ball here tonight for the benefit of the threeyearold McCarter Theater Company, a nonprofit repertory group.

title: Dee Feet In Shacahgo
description: The Chicago Tribune has finally abandoned its long, lonely struggle to simplify English spelling and, so, another good cause bites the dust. Like so many good causes that fail, it was undertaken with the innocent notion that an evil easily identified is an evil easily corrected.

title: Teamsters' Strike Brings Halt To Construction of 20 Buildings
description: Construction on 20 buildings throughout the city was halted yesterday by a teamsters' strike after a breakdown of negotiations with building contractors and suppliers concerning overtime and various other issues.

title: Upturn Eludes Hardship Unemployed
description: DETROIT, Oct. 3  If the economy is turning up, you cannot prove it by Doug McNamara, a 35yearold autodesign technician with a wife and three children, who has been out of work for the last 10 months.

title: Antiques: Jewelry Skill
description: Some period jewelry experts rely on their knowledge of style, others their understanding of materials to separate the real from the ersatz, the fine from the mediocre.

title: Sharp August Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) Consumers increased debts significantly again in August, but record repayments of old loans indicated they were cautious about the economy's future, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: TURKEY ARMS BILL VOTED BY SENATE AND SENT TO FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Senate gave final approval today to a measure partly lifting the embargo against the shipment of American arms to Turkey.

title: Mrs. Bower Takes Senior Golf Crown
description: BARRINGTON, R. I., Oct. 3 (AP)Mrs. Albert Bower of Pelham, N.Y., shot a oneunderpar 73 at the Rhode Island Country Club today and won the United States Golf Association's senior women's championship by six strokes with a 54hole total of 234.

title: 2 Aussies Gain at Coast Net
description: MISSION VIEJO. Calif., Oct. 3  Who are in the semifinals of the $50,000 Mission Viejo women's tennis classic? Cynthia Doerner and Dianne Fromholtz, a couple of littleknown Australians, were the first to gain the bracket.

title: Washington Post, After Missing A Day, Prints 24Page. Paper
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Washington Post recovered today from the sabotage of its pressroom and published a 24page edition after missing publication only one day.

title: Article 2  No Title
White Sox Agree to Sell To Veeck
description: CHICAGO Oct. 3 (AP)Bill Veeck, who owned the Chicago White Sox when they won the American League pennant in 1959 and sold the team two years later, has joined a group that has made a tentative agreement to buy the White Sox, the club announced today.

title: Lawyer Says Miss Hearst Was Not Affidavit Source
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3The story that Patricia Hearst was broken down by mistreatment at the hands of her kidnappers, recounted in an affidavit that she signed, came first from an anonymous source and not from Miss Hearst, according to one of her lawyers.

title: Senators Defy Kissinger, Declassify Sinai Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Senate Foreign Relations Committee ended its drawnout dispute with Secretary of State Kissinger today by overriding his formal objections and declassifying four documents, already printed by the press, dealing with American assurances to Israel and Egypt.

title: Bond Buyers CheeryAbout Elsewhere
description: Wall Street is tired of New York's endless financial crisis and, the money experts say, it has shifted its attention to other, lesstroublesome areas. Its interest in New York State securities was rekindled briefly on Thursday when Controller Arthur Levitt agreed to use state pensionfund money to buy state notes at in turn would be used to help the city get past yet another cash shortage. But Moody's Investors Service quickly quashed whatever optimism had developed by downgrading New York City and New York State securities, leaving bond dealers limp once again.

title: Baseball Playoffs Open Today; A's Seeking 4th Straight Tite
description: CINCINNATI, Oct 3 (UPI) The Cincinnati Reds and Pittsburgh Pirates, both powerhitting teams, know they will need more than power to win their threeoffivegame series that opens tomorrow for the National League pennant and a berth in the World Series.

title: Yonkers Nay Cut 450 School Jobs For Lack of Funds
description: YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 3Unless the City Council here can raise $4.3million by next week, the Yonkers Board of Education will have to lay off 450 school district employes.

title: Shows Open
description: Shows that are not affected by the strike:

title: Music: Beethoven Ninth
description: The notes for Thursday night's New York Philharmonic program made a valid point about the close historical connection between Beethoven and Wagner. But then the concert itself came along and badly, bruised one's belief in that connection. Given no more evidence, that is, than backtoback performances of Wagner's Liebesmahl der Apostel and Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, who would care to recognize any similarities?

title: Books of The Times
description: South Street, for those not familiar with Philadelphia, is one of those vestigial landmarks now common to almost every large American citylandmarks bequeathed to inner cities by decades of neglect, middleclass flight to suburbia and, usually, aided by illconceived urban renewal programs one amuck. It is one of the gutted bastions of the downandout, the hopeless, the poor, and of the predators who feed on them. In this exceptional first novel, David Bradley takes us on a guided tour. We are ushered behind the dingy facade of burnedout boardedup bashedin storefronts dotted with bars, liquor stores and transient hotels; a facade that we've all hurried past, probably with a twinge of disgust and a small dose of cold fear. More important, Mr. Bradley introduces us to the street people who thrive in these cramped spaces, and brings them vividly to life.

title: Lauda, in Training Car, Paces Qualifying at Glen
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Oct. 3 (AP)Niki Lauda of Austria found the extra speed he had been seeking today, driving his training Ferrari to a quick time in the first of two days of qualifying for the United States Grand Prix here Sunday.

title: Senators Defy Kissinger, Declassify Sinai Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Senate Foreign Relations Committee ended its drawnout dispute with Secretary of State Kissinger today by overriding his formal objections and declassifying four documents, already printed by the press, dealing with American assurances to Israel and Egypt.

title: Notes on People
description: A former aide in the Nixon Administration, Maria J. Downs, was appointed by Betty Ford yesterday as White House social secretary. The 43yearold Mrs. Downs, at one time a professional model in Chicago, was an assistant to Anne Armstrong, as cochairman of the Republican Party and later as counselor to former President Nixon. Since February she has been liaison officer between the White House and the Bicentennial Commission. Her husband, John E. Downs, is a public relations consultant in Washington.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O, URGES A SLASH IN HOURS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3Delegates to the convention here of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations called today for a 35hour work week and an increase in the minimum wage to $3 an hour.

title: BEATRICE MOLINSKY
description: Beatrice Cushman Molinsky, mother of the comedienne Joan Rivers, died Thursday in New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. She was 69 years old and lived in ??archmont, N.Y.

title: I.B.M. AND TELEX HALT LITIGATION
description: The long legal battle between the International Business Machines Corporation and the Telex Corporation came to a surprise close yesterday when the companies announced they were terminating their actions against each other.

title: German Leader Advises Ford Of MonetaryPolicy Problems
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 Chancellor Helmut Schmidt told President Ford today of Bonn's problems with inwardlooking United States monetary policies today.

title: TURKEY ARMS BILL VOTED BY SENATE AND SENT TO FORE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Senate gave final approval today to a measure partly lifting the embargo against the shipment of American arms to Turkey.

title: EDITORIAL UNION IN NEWSDAY PACT
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 3A tentative contract agreement between Newsday and its 300 editorial employes was reached today. It calls for a 21 per cent wage increase over 18 months.

title: Court to Weigh Essex Charter Issue
description: NEWARK, Oct. 3A struggle by an earnest group of Essex County residents to make sweeping reforms in their county government will face another court test in Trenton Monday, when their case will be heard by the Appellate Division of State Superior Court.

title: Northeast Bloc Decries Drain of Defense Sites
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1In an unusual display of unity, 82 Representatives and 17 Senators from nine Northeastern states have assailed the Defense Department and the Army for what they say is a concerted effort to close or reduce installations in their area while expanding elsewhere.

title: Shopping Carts: Carrying the Load Across U.S.
description: Everybody knows about Henry Ford and the Wright Brothers.

title: Art: Abstract Show Recreated
description: In the month of March, 1945, World War II had still some of its grimmer surprises to spring. Life everywhere was pretty much at a low ebb. There were not many people around whose hearts would beat faster at the thought of a, show of American abstract painting in Philadelphia. Even to think up such a thing called for the instincts of a crusader.

title: Uncertain Use of Power by Consumers Upsets Ability of Utilities to Forecast
description: Despite generally increased use of electric power this year after virtually no growth in 1974, many of the nation's utilities have found that their customers are still using less electricity than they had predicted. This has increased uncertainty within the uitility industry about its ability to forecast future demand.

title: Strike Up the Bands
description: With all the musicals closed down and future ones in peril because of the strike by Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, the electrifying sparkle in the streets of the theater district has been shortcircuited. This needless strike hurts, above all, the creative performers and craftsmen on both sides of the footlightsincluding the Musicians. Audiences willing to pay for highpriced tickets to musicals are being alienated, now and for seasons to come, just at a moment when Broadway has begun to bounce back with a variety of fine shows.

title: F.D.A. Recalls Cologne
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration announced yesterday the recall from California drug stores of about 66,000 bottles of Faberg cologne. The recall involves all 1.58ounce bottles of Music spray cologne, manufactured by Faberg Inc., of New York. The F.D.A. said that some of the bottles had exploded.

title: Chess Prodigy Loses, but Wins Praise of Opponent
description: Mickey Sanchez, the Manhattan Chess Club's 8yearold prodigy from Maplewood, N. J., met defeat yesterday in his international match with an accomplished adult member of a Swiss team playing from Geneva, but he earned an admiring salute from his opponent.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: CATHOLIC SCHOOLS CONTINUE TALKS
description: Some progress in efforts to settle the fiveweekold strike by Roman Catholic lay school teachers was reported by both sides as negotiations continued into last night despite a settlement deadline for yesterday afternoon set by the Brooklyn Diocese.

title: Reds Are Favored, A's TossUp Today
description: RENO, Oct. 3, (AP)Harrah's Racebook listed Cincinnati today as a 32 favorite to defeat Pittsburgh in the first game of the National League baseball playoff series.

title: Hoff a Search Is Marked By Vexation and Elation
description: DETROIT, Oct. 3William Gallinaro jumps up quickly when the red phone rings in his motel room here and he answers with expectation in his voice.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES SCHOOL LUNCH BILL THAT WIDENED AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 3President Ford, accusing Congress of broadening school lunch subsidies for nonneedy pupils, vetoed today a $2.7billion extension of Federal child nutrition programs.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE EDGED OFF TO 8.3% FOR SEPTEMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The nation's job situation improved slightly in September, the Labor Department reported today

title: C.I.A. Assassination Unit Described
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP)  The Central Intelligence Agency established an official group during the early nineteensixties to develop plans for removing foreign leaders by means that included assassination, two Senators and two former intelligence officials said today.

title: City May Zone Out the Tressage Parlors
description: A new and unusual zoning ordinance designed to shut down socalled massage parlors will be proposed for Times Square, Mayor Beame said yesterday.

title: The Art of Planning, or Watching You Get It All Together
description: I believe in planning in all thingslarge and small. I know the penalties of not thinking ahead, not planning for tomorrow. Take this season's trip to our cabin in the Colorado mountains as a case study in How Not to Plan.

title: Market Place
description: Several Wall Street retail analysts said yesterday that they considered W. T. Grant's petition to reorganize under the bankruptcy laws a nonevent insofar as it might affect the profits and shares of other retailers.

title: Mets Appoint a Manager From the Minor Leagues
description: Joe Frazier, a onetime major league pinchhitter who spent 17 years playing baseball in the minor leagues and 10 more years managing teams there, vaulted into the front trenches yesterday when he was named manager of the New York Mets.

title: Guy Mae Is Dead at 69; Led France in Suez Crisis
description: Guy Mollet, the French Socialist leader who, as Premier, ordered French troops to join with those of Britain and Israel in the illfated invasion of Egypt in 1956, died of a heart attack yesterday at his Paris home. He was 69 years old.

title: Agony and Finery
description: Under the slogan Furs Are OutAnimals Are In, the World Federation for the Protection of Animals has launched a campaign to contest the assumed right of humans to clothe themselves in the skins of their wild fellowcreatures. The federation, an international organization based in the Netherlands and Switzerland, is marking today as World Day for Animals by declaring war particularly on that most wanton of all human inhumanities, the taking of wild animals by means of traps.

title: State's Realtors and Bar Agree on ContractWriting
description: The New Jersey Association of Realtors and the New Jersey Bar Association have worked out a proposed settlement of a controversy that has been raging between them for the last severt yearswhether licensed realestate brokers have the right to prepare contracts.

title: Robyn Smith Rides 3 Straight Winners
description: Robyn C. Smith, the model who turned jockey in 1969, scored the first riding triple of her career at Belmont Park yesterday, turning in the feat in consecutive faces for a perfeet afternoon. It was the first time three victories had been registered by a woman on a major New York track.

title: U.S. Presents Plan To Liberalize Size Of I.M.F. Credits
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (Reuters)The United States has formally presented a plan to liberalize the International Monetary Fund's compensatory financing facility by increasing the amounts member countries can borrow, informed sources said today.

title: Pistons Pin 118111 Loss On Knicks
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 3 (UPI) Kevin Porter, in his first game with the Pistons, scored 25 points tonight to spark Detroit to a 113111 victory over the New York Knicks in the National Basketball Association exhibition opener for both teams.

title: Hostages Safe in London Siege, And Scotland Yard Takes Bow
description: LONDON, Oct. 3 (Reuters)The fiveday siege of an Italian restaurant here ended today with the hostages safe, three gunmen under arrest and Scotland Yard expressing satisfaction with its handling of the case.

title: January's 64134 Sets Pace by Shot
description: NAPA, Calif., Oct. 3 (AP)Don January, making a tour comeback at age 45, exploited nearperfect playing conditions today for an eightunderpar 64 that put him into the secondround lead of the $175,000 Kaiser international open golf tournament.

title: Company Hires Grain Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) An Agriculture Department trade official has resigned to join one of the five companies that handle 80 percent of the nation's grain export trade. The move was the latest in a series of switches in which officials have shuttled between grain companies and the department that plays a major role in Federal grain export policy. The Continental Grain Company of New York announced today the hiring of Richard J. Goodman to head its Washington office effective Oct. 13.

title: PAKISTANI ATTACKS ISRAEL ON SHRINES
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3Pakistan, one of the largest Islamic nations, warned Israel today to refrain from committing outrage against the religious susceptibilities of Moslems throughout the world.

title: Ian Fleming's Son Dies
description: LONDON, Oct. 3 (AP)Caspar Fleming, the only child of Ian Fleming, creator of the ficbonal secret agent James Bond, was found dead at his London home today. He was 22 years old. The police said that some pills had been found near Mr. Fleming's body, but we don't know if there is any connection yet. Mr. Fleming inherited more than $630,000 from his father, who died in 1964.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES SCHOOL LUNCH BILL THAT WIDENED AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3President Ford, accusing Congress of broadening school lunch subsidies for nonneedy pupils, vetoed today a $2.7billion extension of Federal child nutrition programs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Over to Turkey
description: For those who had hoped for prompt and positive results from the significant easing by Congress of the arms embargo against Turkey, the initial reactions from Ankara will be deeply disappointing. Foreign Minister Caglayangil said the move was only a start toward removing the shadow that has fallen on TurkishAmerican relations, and added that full reactivation of the United States military bases in Turkey was still out of the question.

title: Spain, Rejecting Protests, Vows Motor Effort to Halt Terrorism
description: MADRID, Oct. 3The Spanish Government declared today that the killing of three more policemen this week strengthened its determination to use the full weight or the law to stamp out terrorism.

title: Bridge:
description: The simplest of all bridge systems is illegal in tournament play, although it has been known to have modest successes. It consists of passing at every possible opportunity.

title: People in Sports
description: Bob Howsam, the architect of four Western Division titles and two National League championships, signed a new fiveyear contract yesterday as president and chief executive of the Cincinnati Reds. Howsam joined the Cincinnati organization in 1967 and had been named to his present position in March of 1974.

title: MOSCOW AND LISBON AGREE TO NEW TIES
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 3 (Reuters)The Soviet Union and Portugal said today that they would set up a regular system of consultations on bilateral and world problems and work to expand cooperation in the political and economic fields.

title: Forest Products Week Set
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) President Ford today declared the week beginning Oct. 19 as National Forest Products Week to call attention to the material and spiritual benefits of the nation's forest resources.

title: Students Protest Oversized Classes
description: Student resentment against oversized classes and reductions in school services triggered demonstrations yesterday at five Brooklyn high schools, keeping at last 6,500 students out of classes.

title: Banking Agencies Change Regulation On Business Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP)Two Federal bank regulatory agencies have announced that they have changed their regulations to permit corporations and other profitmaking organizations to maintain savings accounts at federally insured banks.

title: Hand Lettering Is Utilized by Computer
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3  A handprinted character, such as the letter F, can be used to convey figures to a computer. The letter and its exact location on a tablet determine the digital information that the computer gets.

title: Track Drug Case
description: The year's biggest thoroughbred payoff ($11,338 for $2) at Belmont Park on Sept. 18 was brought into focus again yesterday when the New York State Racing and Wagering Board reported a positive finding in urine and blood samples taken from the winner.

title: Article 1  No Title
Javits, Buckley Critical Of Ford's City Remarks
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican, and Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican, criticized President Ford yesterday for slighting remarks he has made about this city's management in connection with its fiscal crisis.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Tiffany's may have its diamonds by the yard, but Alexander's is into gemstones by the pound.

title: Boston Teachers Accept Pact Providing a 6% Raise
description: BOSTON, Oct. 4 (UPI)The Boston Teachers Union, which struck the city's public schools for six days last week, voted today by a 7to1 margin to ratify a new oneyear contract providing for a 6 per cent pay rise.

title: Business Briefs
description: DETROIT, Oct. 3 (Reuters) The Chrysler Financial Corporation confirmed today it reached an agreement in principle with its major banks for an additional $300million in funding. Gordon Areen, Chrysler Financial's president, said the additional funding would be obtained by selling the banks' retail receivables on a nonrecourse basis.

title: Stuckey: N.F.L.'s Flashiest Dresser?
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y. Oct. 3Two things are still up in the air in the career of Henry Stuckey, a cornerback with the New York Giants. First, he wonders how much he will be able to play on Sunday against the St. Louis Cardinals, and second, he is concerned about who is the flashiest dresser in the entire National Football League.

title: Noble Rogue Trot Victor In Kentucky
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 3 (AP)K. D. Owen's Noble Rogue, after a dismal first heat, put together two victories today and won the $100,000 Kentucky Futurity, the third jewel.of trotting's triple crown for 3yearolds.

title: U.S. GROUP LEAVES FOR VISIT TO CHINA
description: A group of leaders of American organizations devoted to public education on world affairs left yesterday for an 18day visit to China, where they expect to have discussions with Chinese officials in Peking and to visit other areas.

title: MOYNIHAN ASSAILS UGANDA PRESIDENT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3Daniel P. Moynihan, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, endorsed today a description of President Idi Amin of Uganda as a racist murderer.

title: LUDLUM CANCELS SOME PRICE RISES
description: The first sign of price weakness in the steel industry appeared yesterday as the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation withdrew an average 5 per cent increase on stainless steel sheet and strip that was to have become effective on Wednesday. There were reports in the industry that others, including the Crucible Stainless Steel division of Colt Industries, Inc., would follow this action. A spokesman for the Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest steelmaker, said his company was studying the situation.

title: Shows Closed
description: The shows closed by the strike of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians:

title: 4 CONCERNS ORDERED TO PAY IMPORT FEES
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 3 (AP)Four oil companies were ordered by a Federal judge yesterday to pay more than $30million in contested oil import fees imposed by the Federal Energy Administration.

title: Postal Rate Increases Take Effect Dec. 28
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP)Postal rate increases including a 3cent rise in the cost of mailing a firstclass letter, take effect Dec. 28 and are expected to produce $2.4billion a year in extra revenues for the United States Postal Service, the agency says.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX AND OTC CLIMB
description: The American Stock Exchange index rose sharply yesterday, closing at 83.21, up 0.84. Volume was up slightly to 1,510,000 shares, from 1,307,000 the day before.

title: Treasury Bills Fall 30/100 of a Point
description: Interest rates tumbled swiftly yesterday afternoon as the credit markets became convincedrightly or wronglythat the Federal Reserve had suddenly decided to shift toward easier money. Treasury bill rites dropped as much as 30/100ths of a percentage point, a big oneday move. Longterm government, corporate and taxexempt bond yields moved down as much as 20/ 100ths of a pointalso goodsized moves.

title: Morgan Leaves Padres
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 3 (AP) Tom Morgan, pitching coach of the San Diego Padres, is leaving the team by mutual agreement, a spokesman for the National Leaguz club said today.

title: Auto Sales Rate Off 4.1%; Consumer Debt in Surge
description: DETROIT, Oct. 3  American automakers sold cars on the domestic market last month at a 4.1 per cent lower rate than in September, 1974.

title: Compromise Bin on Housing Passed by House, 33441
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) The House passed today a compromise $49.3billion money bill for the Department of Housing and Urban Development and other related activities such as disaster relief and the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: Mets Appoint a Manager From the Minor Leagues
description: Joe Frazier, a onetime major league pinchhitter who spent 17 years playing baseball in the minor leagues and 19 more years managing teams there, vaulted into the front trenches yesterday when he was named manager of the New York Mets.

title: Rangers Beat Farm Club
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 3 (UPI)  Derek Sanderson scored three goals tonight as the New York Rangers recorded a 73 victory over the Providence Reds in an exhibition game at the Providence Civic Center.

title: Alaska Pipeline 42% Done Despite Delays
description: PRUDHOE BAY, AlaskaThe brutal Arctic winter is fast approaching on Alaska's North Slope, and across rivers and over the tundra, through mountain passes, valleys and forests, the once controversial transAlaska pipeline is slowly nearing the halfway mark.

title: Joan Payson Dies at 72
description: Joan Whitney Payson, principal owner of the New York Delets and Greentree Stable, died at 72. Page 63.

title: Pyramid
description: On the subject of Egyptology, youthful generations have had to make do with the highly colored tableaux in The National Geographic's pages, augmented by Saturday matinees of Mummy's Curse movies. Such romance and mystery are missing from David Macaulay's Pyramid, but the raising of man's mightiest monument is told in a sort of countdown that encapsulates the years of labor and the many skills involved in building a pyramid, circa 2500 B.C.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: DoubleCharging by Utilities Over Fuel Costs Is Alleged
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) A House subcommittee says some electric utility companies doublecharge customers by abusing fuel adjustment clauses that are designed only to let the utilities quickly recover incrased fuel costs.

title: TV VIEW
description: Public television can be almost touching in its cultural contortions. Always in need of a dollar, the system has devised ingenious, and sometimes irritating, schemes for putting together kultur packages. The latest, and generally quite impressive, example is entitled Classic Theaterthe Humanities in Drama. It is being presented by Boston station WGBH but, minus the elaborate trappings, the basic series consists of 13 dramatic productions plucked from the archives of the British Broadcasting Corporation. We are, dear lovers of the arts, once again in the land of imports.

title: GUARDS FOR FORD IN BONN ASSAILED
description: BONN, Oct. 4A highranking West German police official says President Ford's security guards were arrogant and overbearing and sometimes hampered protection for the President during his 36hour visit here last July.

title: What's Doing in RHODE ISLAND
description: THE STATERhode Island, the smallest state (1,214 square miles) with the longest name (State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations), has untrammeled woodlands, some of the finest examples of Colonial, Federal and Victorian architecture in the nation and more than 400 miles of inviting shore. Although it is known as a summer vacation area, Rhode Island in the fall is a kaleidoscope of color and activity. Pumpkins gleam in golden fields. The maples, red oaks and ashes of the northern and western parts of the state turn crimson and copper and amber. Wood fires crackle on Colonial hearths and smoke curls from Colonial chimneys. Bluefish and striped bass dart through the waters of Narragansett Bay, and long after most yachtsmen have put up their boats for the winter, Rhode Islandersbecause of the protection the land offers the bay are able to fish and sail. In winter there is ice boating, ice skating, ice fishing and a little skiing. Beachcombers roam the shores.

title: W. Michigan Loses To Bowling Green
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, Oct. 4 (AP)Marcus Johnson left the bench in the first quarter today and went on to lead Bowling Green State University to a 280 MidAmerican Conference victory over Western Michigan.

title: McNamara to Visit Bolivia
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 4 (Reuters)  Robert MacNamara, president of the World Bank, will visit Bolivia for three days from Nov. 18, a Bolivian government minister announced here this week. Planning minister Juan Lechin Suarez said that President Hugo Banzer would take the opportunity to present some development plans for which we require finance.

title: Slow Start for New Funds
description: Despite the flurry of initial interest, the public offering of computermanaged commodities funds is off to a slow start.

title: Celebration Is Mostly Words
description: PORT JEFFERSON  For most high school students, a dictionary is a sometimes useful tool, not something to celebrate.

title: Gullett, Winning Pitcher, Hits Home Run
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 4  The Cincinnati Reds, who won 108 games this season, made it 109 today as they swarmed over the Pittsburgh Pirates, 83, in the opening round of the playoffs for the National League pennant.

title: Calculators
description: Edward L. Withey doesn't believe in wasting space. As president of the Instrument Research Company in Lincoln, Mass., makers of precision generators, he is replacing a blank panel on the company's Model 909 with one containing a pocket calculator.

title: AARON A. SCHEYER
description: Aaron A. Scheyer, president of the Reliance Picture Frame Company, Inc., of Dover, N.J., died Friday at his home in Morristown, N.J. He was 94 years old.

title: Ruth Urban Engaged to C.C. Smith
description: Ruth Woodward Robinson Urban, a legal assistant with the firm of Hogan & Hartson in Washington, plans to be married next month to Carleton Craig Smith of Washington, who is on the financial staff of the President Ford Committee, the Republican campaign group for the President's nomination.

title: Miss Wood Engaged To John D. Whitaker
description: Mrs. George Robert Wood has announced the engagement of her daughter, Kathryn Elizabeth Wood, to John David Whitaker, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Whitaker of Southampton. Pa.

title: Remodeling Funds For Far Rockaway
description: The city has received $1.3million in Federal Community Development funds for the first phase of a program to revitalize the Central Avenue shopping area in Far Rockaway Queens.

title: Seatrain Is Part Of a Dead Heat
description: WESTBURY, Oct. 4Nero's pacing battle with Seatrain in the $100,000added Messenger stakes next Saturday night took on a new dimension tonight when George Sholty's Truxon Hanover finished in a dead heat with Seatrain in a $15,000 pace.

title: G.O.P.'S '76 RULES UPHELD BY COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The power of political parties to manage their affairs without court interference, even in the face of charges of unconstitutional discrimination, was reaffirmed this week by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

title: Correction
description: A chart in The Review of Sept. 28 had incorrect figures for Taiwan and Switzerland. The correct figures for Taiwan are: Per capita income, $700; overall balance of payments, minus $52.2million; compulsory education, 613 years; infant mortality, 14 per 1,000 live births; life expectancy for males 67.49, females 72. For Switzerland the correct per capita income is $6,013 and the overall balance of payments is plus $1.07billion.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not avaiin time to appear in Section 2:

title: Schmidt Fears Effects of City Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany has told President Ford of his fear that New York's fiscal crisis could have a domino effect, striking at other financial centers as far away as Frankfurt and Zurich, officials in Washington said today.

title: She Has Another Date With the Devil
description: WESTPORT, Conn. The back lots of Hollywood are salted down with the bones of performers who crashed through as stars in their first movie after a nationwide talent search only to be forgotten. Has anyone heard from Rudolph Valentino's look alike, Anthony Dexter, lately? And what ever happened to May Wynn since The Caine Munity?

title: The British Spa of Bath: 2,000 Years Old and a Picture of Health
description: BATH, selfstyled Queen City of the West (the West of England, that is), lies 107 miles from London on a meandering Ioop of the River Avon, in a natural amphitheater of wooded hills. By all odds Britain's bestpreserved example of unified 18thcentury Georgian architecture, this city of 85.000 offers Roman and medieval remains to boot, and is also the country's oldest spa, where first the early Saxon kings, then the Roman invaders, then all of fashionable Georgian society happily dunked themselves and sipped the healing waters.

title: Old Waterfront Photos Shown Here
description: An exhibition of 70 old waterfront photographs opened yesterday under the Brooklyn end of the Brooklyn Bridge. The pictures, dating from 1880 to 1930 and printed from old glass negatives recently rediscovered by the city's Economic Development Adminisstration, went on view in the old fireboat station at Fulton Street and the East River.

title: Memorial Services
description: HARROWERGordan, Memorial service Oct. 7 at 2:30 P.M., St. James Church, Madisbo Ave. and 71st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the GordonHarrower Memorial Fund, DayKimball Hospital, Putnam, Conn.

title: As Trade Deficit Mounts, China Must Decide Which Imports Are Vital and Which She Can Do Without
description: PEKING, Oct. 4  Half of a new factory vas being moved slowly down Chang An, the wide main street of Peking. A long cavalcade of trailer trucks hauled big chemicalprocessing tanks, and on their sides was written, Made in Japan.

title: Costly Fuel May Bring A Long, Cold Winter
description: New York City's coldweather task of keeping fuel flowing to apartment houses whose owners have run out of credit appears likely to be compounded this season.

title: Convergence in Italy
description: ROME, Oct. 3In Italy, one of this city's most experienced foreign diplomats said recently, we may be seeing the development of a sort of Dubcekian orthodoxy among Western Communist parties.

title: Temple Pulls Out A 2117 Victory
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 (AP)Tom Dcff plunged yard for a score with 1 minutes left to give Temple a 2117 football victory over Cincinnati today.

title: Rutgers Coeds Shifting Goals
description: NEW BRUNSWICKRutgers College the oldest and largest division of the state university, has been coeducational since 1972, and since that time most of its women students have opted for the traditional female courses. However, statistics compiled recently indicate that this trend may be changing.

title: PRODIGIOUS SARAH
description: The fullblown eccentric is not regarded as a national treasure by most Americans. True spawn of the Puritans, we tend to look askance at unconventional people. We do notknowinglyentrust great deeds or high office to the oddball, except perhaps in politics or the military. With a narcissism that history does not entirely justify, we reward most highly the personality that most closely resembles our conception of the ordinary American. All of which makes the offcenter career of Sarah Caldwell an American phenomenon worth attending to.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: President Ford nominated Roderick M. Hills last week to be chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to succeed Ray. Garrett Jr., who has headed the agency during its postWatergate crackdown on corrupt businesses practices.

title: Martha Jeanne Carter Fiancee of Thomas M. Hillstrom
description: Dr. and Mrs. Seymour L. Hess of Tallahassee, Fla., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hess's daughter, Martha Jeanne Carter, to Thomas Maynard Hillstrom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maynard K. Hillstrom of La Grange. Ill.

title: Thirteen
description: About 10 years ago there was a show at the School of Visual Arts gallery with the agrarian sounding name of Combines. It was actually an exhibition of paintings or drawings, each by two artists. Each team developed their own methodology. One person began, the other finished; some groups exchanged several times, others preferred working simultaneously. In every case the participating artists reported that the experience was stimulating and useful. None of them ever repeated the experiment.

title: Michigan 317 Victor Before 104,578 Fans
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 4 (AP)Michigan rediscovered its running game today behind the quarterbacking of Rick Leach, a freshman, and the Wolverines handed Bo Schembechler hii 100th career victory by smashing Missouri, 317.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 4 (AP)The New York Knicks of the National Basketball Association, showing a lot incentive against the American Basketball Association champion Kentucky Colonels, scored a 107102 exhibition victory at the Capital Centre tonight. A sellout crowd of 19,035 watched as Earl Monroe of the Knicks led all scorers with 26 points, including 8 in the fourth period. Walt Frazier finished with 19 points. Louie Dampier led Kentucky with 23 points, Artis Gilmore had 21.

title: In the Wake of Harry Truman
description: ATHENSThe Truman Doctrine is dead as a doornail in Greece and Turkey, the area it embraced. Although Washington still intends to defend the two countries against attack, the fact is little appreciated and any vestiges of popular gratitude are gone.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The winds of legislative fortune often change swiftly in Washington. A bill was introduced into Congress last summer (reported here July 27) that called for the return of the 2cent piece as a circulating coin. Although at that time there didn't seem to be much real chance for its passage, the bill was characterized as a good thing if only because it should stir increased interest in the country's numismatic history. But now the measure is no longer just something to think about, and the prospects for the revival of this 19th century coin denomination look much brighter.

title: 'Companero,' and 'Princess,' a Double Bill of Longing and Lament
description: "The English florists simply do not know how to make a garland. I had to show them how to do it," the Princess (Madhur Jaffrey), daughter of a maharajah, complains daintily to her guest as she flutters about the tea table in her posh London town house. The princess affects the mannerisms and vocabulary of the English aristocracy and laments the passage of an India that weighed its princes in gold and sent its royal children to English boarding school where, after a few years they had no idea if they were English or Indian.The occasion is a party for two marking the birthday of the Princess's late father. It's an annual occasion. The garland hangs over the full-portrait of the maharajah, whom her aging guest James Mason had served first as a tutor and then as a secretary of state.The guest, whom the Princess calls Cyril Sahib, is a singular sort of man who, as he recognizes his own disappointments, tries politely to correct the Princess's statements about the past. Though she never quite understands him, he indulges her. She is the last link he has to the past.James Ivory's 60-minute film, "Autobiography of a Princess," is a delicate, autumnal satire, funny at some moments, bitter at others, and illuminated throughout by the kind of appreciation for lost civilizations that is shared by all of Mr. Ivory's films about India, from "Shakespeare Wallah" through "Bombay Talkie."It will be seen at the New York Film Festival this evening at 6 on a bill with "Compaero," a 60-minute film about Victor Jara, the Chilean folk singer who was one of the victims of the right-wing revolution that overthrew the Government of the late President Salvador Allende in 1973. The two films have very little in common but it's a moving program.By far the more interesting cinematically, is "Autobiography of a Princess," which is to conventional feature-length films what a novella is to a novel. It is a compact movie, dense with information and contradictory feelings.Through the interplay between the Princess and Cyril Sahib, and with the aid of some home movies that the Princess shows, Mr. Ivory and Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, who wrote the screenplay, manage to bring three very curious characters to life. They are the Englishman who went to India for a year and stayed, effectively, until he was drained of his life, the spoiled, silly Princess who is out of place in both India and England, and her father, "Dear Papa," who was obviously a tyrant though the Princess persists in thinking of him as some sort of libertarian."Why," says the Princess, "there were hardly any suttees.""What about your great-aunt?" asks Cyril Sahib."That was different," the Princess replies crossly. "She loved her husband so much she didn't want to live without him."There are awkward moments in the film. Mr. Ivory introduces a television interview with the Maharani of Jaipur and her son, which is funny and informative but doesn't match the quality of the fiction that he is spinning so economically with Miss Jaffrey and with Mr. Mason.The latter has one especially marvelous moment when he recalls his creeping awareness of the rot that was destroying his life in the final Indian years. "Those ceremonies," he says. "As the years went on the ceremonies blended together. I knew less and less.... All those crowds, and always the waiting, and the confusion about how the thing was to be done.""Autobiography of a Princess" is a small, elegant, oblique film. "Compaero" is small, angry and straightforward, composed mainly of an interview with the late Mr. Jara's English-born wife, Joan Turner, who talks at length and in extremely affecting terms about her husband, his commitment to the revolution, his talent, and his murder in the Santiago soccer stadium two days after the coup.The film was directed by Martin Smith, an Englishman, and the soundtrack carries Mr. Jara's voice singing the songs that made him such a popular figure in his own country.

title: STUDY IS RELEASED ON SAYING ENERGY
description: Regional energyconservation measures could cut the annual rate of increase in demand for electricity in the New York area from 6 per cent to 4 per cent, and for all energy sources from 3 per cent to 2 per cent, according to a study that was reported last week.

title: Red Bank and Matawan Stay on Winning Trails

description: NEW BRUNSWICK  Almost anyone who has studied European painting knows that the French Impressionists were influenced by Japanese prints, for they adopted unconventional views of their subjects, Japanese flatness and vigorous color.

description: BRICK TOWNSHIP  The state's disorganized system of disciplining those schoolboard employes protected by tenure has been brought into the open by a dispute that has most of the local Board of Education facing jail terms.

description: Union snapped Westfield's 12game winning streak yesterday with a 1210 upset triumph produced by the power running of Larry Kubin.

description: Most city people like to spend a day in the country. Some go as guests of realty salespeople. Looking at new suburban housing may be their favorite outdoor sport. They go with the idea of buying only if they find an outstanding bargain. Unfortunately, most of these Sunday viewers do not really know what to look at and look for.

description: By Jean Raspail. Translated from the French by Norman Shapiro. 311 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $8.95.

description: Family togetherness will come back into vogue when the Suffolk County Girl Scout Council holds a twoday Happening for Scouts and their families on Oct. 18 and 19 at the Student Union Building of the State University at Stony Brook.

description: To the Editor:

title: Libya Is Spending Millions to Promote Spread of the Islamic Faith
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Oct. 4 (AP)Libya is spending some of her oil income on a center to spread the Islamic faith in Africa as well as among Christians in Europe and North and South America.

description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 4 Peter Kessell scored on a 45yard touchdown pass play late in the fourh quarter and set up another touchdown with a fumble recovery as Boston University upset Harvard, 139, at the Harvard Stadium today.

description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Oct 4 (AP)The passing combination of John Andress to Dick Barvinchak set up a second period touchdown and field goal today that carried 10thranked Penn State to a 103 victory over Kentucky.

title: Laotians Being Reeducated by Reds
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 1A few days ago a village woman who sells vegetables in the market here was making a joke about the Pathet Lao to another vender. A Pathet Lao soldier overheard her and hustled her off to jail.

title: Late Score Wins, 76, For Nanuet
description: Nanuet scored in the final two minutes and then held off a North Rockland drive that reached the 2 as it scored a 76 victory in the Rockland Public Schools Athletic League, yesterday. Suffern defeated Clarkstown North, 60, in the only other game.

description: Comparable to all the greats, exclaimed Rolling Stone critic Dave Marsh in a recent rave review of Bruce Springsteen, a new idol of the rock music scene. By greats, Marsh made it clear he had in mind Bob Dylan and The Who's Pete Townshend as a couple of Springsteen's peers.

title: Roebling Sketches Are Going To Museum
description: The Brooklyn Museum is going to be the depository for Washington Augustus Roebling's original engineering sketches for the design and construction of the Brooklyn Bridge.

description: MOSCOW, Oct. 4  With pledges of further cooperation in space, the three Apollo astronauts ended their twoweek tour of the Soviet Union today, exactly 18 years after the first manmade satellite, a Soviet sputnik, was launched into orbit around the earth.

description: The nation's capital: The postal clerk who sends Congressional mail to the Central Intelligence Agency.

description: Lady Ramsey, widow of Adm. Sir Charles Gordon Ramsey of the British Navy, died Friday in Stuart, Fla. She was 90 years old and lived in Hobe Sound, Fla., and had also resided in Greenwich, Conn., and in Scotland.

description: A proposed law that would allow speedier demolition of certain sizes of vacant buildings as part of the city's campaign against arson in the South Bronx, and other areas has been submitted to the City Council by Mayor Beame.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The bitter labormanagemen trouble at The Washington Post, which briefly silenced the nation's seventh largest newspaper this week, is part of a general struggle for survival in the publishing industry, according to officials on both sides of the dispute here.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Are you really interested in arguing whether or not the New York Film Festival is necessary? I'm not. I do it under duress. Twelve years was nothing for an early Christian debate on a tiny point of dogma, but it's maybe nine or 10 years too much for a debate about a film festival when the circumstances and the selections of that festival change each year. It's like debating popsicle flavors. By the time one reaches any conclusion, the things have melted away.

title: Paperbacks
description: THE BERMUDA TRIANGLE MYSTERYSOLVED, by Lawrence David Kusche. (Warner, $1.95.) A research librarian tracks down every last scrap of information available about those mysterious plane and ship disappearances and explains them all as consequences of natural causes or human error.

description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 4A $5million gift has been made to the University of Virginia to establish a center for the study of public policy, Dr. Frank L. Hereford Jr., the university president, announced.

title: H.E.W. Project Disputed On Testing of Students
description: DENVER, Oct. 4The National Assessment of Educational Progress, the Federal Government's largest educational research project, is struggling to win acceptance as more than simply another test in a field flooded with statistics measuring pupil achievement.

title: 75% in Harris Poll Oppose Busing for School Balance
description: Desegregation of public schools meets the approval of Americans by 56 to 35 per cent, but a 75 to 20 per cent majority opposes busing as a means of achieving racial balance, a Harris Poll reports, according to The Associated Press.

description: Sarah Frances Brown, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ernest M. Brown Jr. of Merion, Pa., was married yesterday afternoon to Paul Lazo Hallingby, who is with the investment concern of Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis In Philadelphia.

title: SAIGON IS PRESSING EXODUS TO FARMS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 4 (Agence FrancePresse) South Vietnam's revolutionary authorities are stepping up their efforts to encourage a return to farming with a plan to send 1.5 million people in Saigon back to the land over the next 15 months.

title: New Roberta Flack Sings Less Softly at Felt Forum
description: Roberta Flack reached a high point in her career two years ago, with her album called Killing Me Softly. But then she went into a twoyear seclusion from which she has reemerged only recently, and her early show at the Felt Forum on Friday nightthe first of four in that hall over two nightsrevealed a rather different Roberta Flack from the one we used to know.

title: CENSORS KEEP GRIP ON SOUTH AFRICANS
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 4 (AP)Several years after It went on sale here and long after the movie version, the novel The Odessa, File was banned by South Africa's censors in another assault on objectionable literature.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: I sometimes think one should never go to see a production a second or third time. Not because its initial impact, whatever that may have been, is bound to be diminished, or at least different. I can't, for instance, come away from Equus now as I did on its opening night in London several years ago, feeling as though that spike that had blinded six horses had been at least swung at my own forehead if not driven through it. If a play has been stunning on first acquaintance, it cannot be stunning in the same way again. You've flipped to the back of the book and know all the answers, which means that you can never again be a true participant, only a knowing observer.

title: Price Controls on Natural Gas Urged
description: TRENTONAs New Jersey prepares for what could be a major shortage of natural gas this winter, a member of the state's Board of Public Utility Commissioners urged Congress last week to maintain price controls on the fuel.

title: Innocent in Senator's Deaths
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 4 (UPI)A Circuit Court jury has found Alexander T. Sakamoto, 40 years old, innocent of the slaying in 1970 of a Hawaiian State Senator, Larry Kuriyama. A retired dairy man, Alfred Ruis, has been charged with asking a gangster to hire someone to kill the Senator.

title: Vibes in Cincinnati
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 4  As the Pittsburgh Pirates were taking batting practice before today's opener of the National League championship series, the electric scoreboard above center field in Riverfront Stadium flashed, There are a limited number of World Series tickets available at the advance window. It was as if the Cincinnati Reds were telling the Pirates that if you want to see the World Series, buy a ticket to see the Reds play in it. After having won 108 games to finish 20 games ahead of the Los Angeles Dodgers in the Western Division, the Reds have now won 109 with their 83 victory. To win the World Series, they need 115 victories.

McGraw, founder of McGrawHill, Inc., has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. William Holland Scully of Stamford, Conn. The Wedding is planned for next year.

description: NEWARKThe New Jersey State Opera has appointed Patricia Kelly as chairman of its board of directors in a reorganization aimed at improving the company's business structure and reducing its deficit of $250,000.

description: CHICAGO, Oct. 4It might have been coincidental, but the two formally declared candidates in the race for Illincis Governor each made his announcement of candidacy the day after a Muhammad Ali fightone this summer and one this week.

Adams of Framingham, Mass., to Kenneth E. Dougherty Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dougherty of Huntington, L.I.

title: The U.S. Secret Service Is a Necessary Branch
description: WASHINGTONIt isn't the way they look, it's the way they look; the best way to spot the purposely inconspicuous Secret Service agents in a crowd is to look for the men or women who are looking at the crowd, not at the President.

title: Art of Americans Abroad
description: Museums have been caught in the financial crunch too. They have had to make retrenchments, such as reductions in staff, both on the curatorial and administrative sides, fewer exhibitions and cutbacks in the number of days their collections are open to the public. Many have had to decrease the funds available for acquisitions and others have curtailed lending policies.

description: VALLEY STREAMAfter nearly decades of laying down when playing dead to the Green Acres Shopping Center, Rockaway Avenue is coming alive again.

description: A State Senate study of felony convictions has found that judges in New York City generally impose lighter sentences for major crimes than judges in the rest of the state.

title: Point of View
description: With the relentless certainty of a Greek tragedy, New York's housing debacle unfolds before us. The unequivocal statistics of foreclosure, mortgage default and real estate tax arrears offer a picture clear to all but those whom theologians call invincibly ignorant.

title: Pauline Harrison Dent, Teacher, Bride of Thomas Bray Ketchum
description: Pauline Harrison Dent, daughter of former Secretary of Commerce Frederick Baily Dent and Mrs. Dent of Washington and Spartanburg, S. C., was married yesterday in Washington to Thomas Bray Ketchum, who is with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Malcolm Ketchum of Dorset, Vt.

title: No Charges in Suicide
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Oct. 4 (UPI)  No charges will be brought against William Plachta, who stood by while his wife committed suicide, the. Riverside County District Attorney said yesterday. The official, Byron Morton, said that Mr. Plachta had acted out of love and compassion for his terminally ill wife. But he warned that helping another person commit suicide was still violation of the law.

title: The Nation
description: Retreating from a confrontation with the Ford Administration, the House Select Committee on Intelligence has relented from its insistence that it, as well as the executive branch, has the authority to declassify confidential intelligence documents.
