description: Early in the summer the police arrested a youth after he allegedly hit a man on the head with a golf club and stole his radio. The youth was booked and brought to the Criminal Courts Building at 100 Centre Street, where a felony complaint was drawn up.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONAn unofficial count of the bills signed into law by Governor Byrne during the last two years shows that Byron M. Baer, Democrat of Bergen County, is the most productive legislator in the Assembly.

title: DeepSea FishingJust a Subway Ride Away
description: THE sun wasn't yet visible behind Manhattan's skyline as the boatload of fishermen headed across the Hudson from the Hoboken docks. On the New York side, waiting to be picked up by the boat, a dozen more anglers stood on a bulkhead almost under the West Side Highway. By 7:30, they were sailing under the Verrazano Narrows Bridge.

title: Lamy of Santa Fe
description: The Vicarate of New Mexico still pitifully calls itself a Catholic country, and tries to keep the forms of religion without instruction. The old mission churches are in ruins. The few priests are without guidance or discipline. They are lax in religious observance, and some of them live in open concubinage. If this Augean stable is not cleansed, now that the territory has been taken over by a progressive government, it will prejudice the interests of the Church in the whole of North America.

title: Nat Turner redux
description: Nat Turner's Fierce Rebellion By Stephen B. Oates. 187 pp. New York: Harper and Row. $7.95.

title: Gambles Paying Off So Far for Cowboys
description: The Monday night television game tomorrow matches an interesting team, the Dallas Cowboys, against a lesser foe, the Detroit Lions, playing inside a fascinating new stadium in Pontiac, Mich. This is the stadium with the fabric roof kept aloft by corn pressed air, like a tennis bubble. It is a neat, cozy place for a football game, with 80,399 seats.

title: HUMANITIES UNIT IN PLANNING STAGE
description: In an effort to apply more effectively the insights of the humanities toward modern problems, a group of the country's leading scholars is planning to establish a National Center for the Humanities.

title: LIMERICK MARCHERS ASSAIL KIDNAPPING
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 4Thousands of people marched in the provincial city of Limerick today demanding the safe return of Tiede Herrema, a factory manager from the Netherlands who was kidnapped yesterday on his way to work.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: W. T. GRANT, 17th largest retailer in the country, filed a petition in voluntary bankruptcy under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act with liabilities of $1.030billion, including $641million In bank debt, and assets of $1.016billion... The Wholesale Price index rose 0.6 per cent in September, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported, to 177.7 [1987 = 100]. . . . Far mprices rose 3 per cent from Aug. 15 to Sept. 15, the Department of Agriculture said. . . . Unemployment in September fell to 8.3 per cent from 8.4 per cent in August.

title: LETTERS
description: Steel Price

title: Atlanta's Planet of Apes
description: ATLANTA (AP)The Yerkes Regional Primate Research Center at Emory University here is the largest such center in the world, housing more than 150 great apes and more than 870 smaller primates.

title: Marybeth Ryan Bride in Suburb
description: Marybeth Ryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James V. Ryan of Rye, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Edward Frederick Heuer, sort of Mrs. John H. Heuer of Tamarac, Fla., and the late Mr. Heuer.

title: NEOFASCIST VISIT TO U.S. STIRS ITALY
description: ROME, Oct. 4A visit to Washington by the leader of the Italian neoFascist party and his meeting with American Government officials has touched off a political storm here, embarrassed the American Embassy and left many Italians wondering whether the United States was now backing the extreme right in Italy.

title: U.S. Paper Recycling Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) The Environmental Protection Agency has suggested to the Government that it could save $10million a year by recycling some of its own wastepaper. Under the proposal Thursday, most Government employees would be told to separate highgrade paper, such as computer printout paper, punch cards and ledger paper, instead of throwing it into the trash. The paper would be sold.

title: NEW RULES URGED FOR ASBESTOS RISK
description: The United States Department of Labor has proposed a new standard to protect workers and their families from the lungscarring and cancercausing effects of asbestos, a mineral of a thousand uses to which millions of American workers are exposed.

title: Lindenhurst 346 Victor in an Upset
description: Lindenhurst turned defensive play into three thirdquarter touchdowns yesterday and upset Whitman, the defending conference champion, 346, in their league A.A.A.1 opener. The Bulldogs' victory is the second straight over a defending conference champion; they beat Amityville, the A champion, last week.

title: Miller Posts 68 for 203, Leads Open by a Stroke
description: NAPA, Calif., Oct. 4 (AP)Johnny Miller, slumpridden and frustrated since his recordsetting exploits of the early season, birdied his last two holes for a 68 that lifted him into a onestroke lead today in the third round of the $175,000 Kaiser international open golf tournament.

title: A DISPUTE BURNS OVER SAHARA LAND
description: RABAT, Morocco, Oct. a (AP)Deep in the western Sahara, Moroccan and Algerian troops are lined up 20 miles apart, ready for confrontation over 103,000 square miles of desert containing one of the world's richest phosphate deposits.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: This might be called a radical piece on the relevance of history. Or it might be looked at as an excursion into pure, selfish pleasure. What it concerns is the work of Sebastiano Serlio (14751555), the Bolognese theorist, architect and painter of the Italian Renaissance, as seen in a small rare exhibition of his books and drawings from the incomparable collections of Columbia's Avery Architectural Library.

title: Wisconsin Antitrust Inquiry Planned on 2 News Services
description: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 4 (UPI) An inquiry into an alleged violation of Wisconsin antitrust laws by two major supplemental news services will begin Friday, according to Bronson C. La Follette, the state attorney general.

title: Mayor Beame's Observations on the Crisis
description: Mayor Beame, in his interview with reporters and editors of The New York Times, made a number of observations about the men, institutions and issues he has been involved with during the city's fiscal crisis. Here is a sampling of them:

title: Article 1  No Title
description: GARDENS GARDENS

title: Organized Crime Held Society's Foe
description: PATERSONBurrell Ives Humphreys, the Passaic County Prosecutor, has announced a new policy in cases involving organized crime and illegal gambling.

title: Portable School Burns
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 4 (UPI)Antibusing militants were believed responsible for a fire early today that destroyed a threeclassroom portable addition to Iroquois High School in the Jefferson County school district. Another morning blaze in the district was under investigation. No arrests were reported.

title: Parent and Child
description: By the time the mass media explode a new social truth, it's so old, spread so far, accepted so commonly as to be already on the wane or absorbed totally into the porous morality of most Americans. Betty Ford's casual acceptance of the idea of her teenaged daughter's prospective affair is a perfect example of how we divide what we know into what is true and what is permissible to say out loud. The shock waves she created were like courtesy nods in the direction of eras long past. But even though the President's wife was calm about it all, and even though most parents would prefer to have their 15yearolds in bed with a friend rather than imbibing hard drugs, stealing cars or running away to distant cities, the subject of adolescent sexuality is still a tender, raw spot on the bruised and bent soul of the older parent.

title: ATOMWAR PERIL TO OZONE IS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Arms Control and Disarmament Agency concluded in a study made public today that a nation conducting a major nuclear attack could suffer from ecological backlash against its environment and economy.

title: SIMON PROPOSES CITY'S BANKS CALL DEBT MORATORIUM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon proposed today that banks holding New York City notes declare a form of debt moratorium to head off a city default, provided the new Emergency Financial Control Board produces soon a credible plan for bringing the city's budget back into balance.

title: South Vietnam to Be Given $16Million Swedish Grant
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 4 (Reuters) Sweden has announced an emergency grant of more than $16million to South Vietnam for postwar reconstruction.

title: Canterbury 14, Hopkins 8
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 4Trailing 80, in the fourth period today, Canterbury got two breaks that led to a 148 defeat of Hopkins Grammar. The visitors secovered a fumble on Hopkins Grammar's 12yard line and went on to score: a few minutes later, they recovered another fumble on the 18 and scored on the next play.

title: Lisbon: Still in Crisis
description: There was never a chance that either the Portuguese Communists and their military allies or the tiny but militant factions even further to the left would accept without struggle the momentous events of the last few weeks that have turned the country back toward moderation, and democracy. In all probability, the far left has lost its chance to take over Portugal; but the unrest in Lisbon of the past few days gives warning of the mischief it still can generate, particularly In the armed forces.

title: TV Notes: Where Have All the Creative Types Gone?.
description: Ted Kotoheff, the film divector (The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz), recently observed at a media symposiumin Canada that the most damning thing to be said about American television is that the country's best writers and directors won't work for it. Kotcheff developed his career in the Canadian TV system and, though he main ly makes theatrical films sow, still crosses back into television from time to time in Canada.

title: Hanoi Plans Hungary Visit
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Oct. 4 (Agence FrancePresse)  A North Vietnamese delegation is to make an official visit to Hungary, a foreign ministry communiqu issued here said. No date was given.

title: Army Routed By 6714
description: STANFORD, Calif., Oct. 4 Army's football team ran into outandout disaster today as Stanford, unable to win in three games, exploded for a 6714 victory.

title: Columbia Set Back by Tigers, 277
description: Opening Ivy League play yesterday at sunny Baker Field against Princeton, the Columbia Lions delighted the crowd of 6,215 by marching 87 yards for a touchdown the first time they had the ball.

title: Editors' Choice
description: THE FIRST CASUALTY, by Phillip Knightley. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $12.95.) A narrative account, by a London Sunday Times reporter, of the correspondent's role as hero. propagandist and myth maker, in wars from the Crimea to Vietnam; it is truth, he concludes, that always bites the dust first.

title: Naked in a Public Place
description: By Elizabeth Gandy. 163 pp. New York: Harper and Row. $6.95.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: John F. Kelly 3d, who shot and killed a Roman Catholic priest in 1971, was released from Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital in New Jersey for the second time in a month after doctors again determined that he need not be confined. In a report to Judge William E. O'Connor Jr., in Superior Court, Dr. C. Shin, a psychiatrist, said an episode at Mr. Kelly's house in Brick Township that had led to his reconfinement last month was caused by a temper tantrum and not because of psychosis.

title: Frizette Taken by Optimistic Gal
description: To the surprise of few in yesterday's crowd of 27,841 at sunny Belmont Park, Mrs. Bertram R. Firestone's Optimistic Gal not only won the 28th running of the rich Frizette but the superb young daughter of Sir Ivor did so emphatically.

title: Fellow Heir Scores
description: BOWIE, Md., Oct. 4 (AP) John D. Marsh's Fellow Heir turned in a speedy sixfurlong time of 1:10 4/5 today and won the $27,850 Sasscer Stakes by threequarters of a length, returning $9 for $2. The prerace favorite, CanAm Stable's Gentle King, developed ankle trouble and had to be withdrawn.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1975

title: Cuban Guitarist Shines in Debut
description: Enrique Gardano is a 27yearold Cubanborn guitarist who has lived and studied in this country since 1961. Last Tuesday night he made his debut at Carnegie Recital Hall in the New Talents of the Guitar series, giving a large share of his modest program to the works of 20thcentury LatinAmerican composers.

title: What has been done and should be done
description: Recently, Betty Friedan traveled to France to talk with Simone de Beauvoir, in search of someone wiser, older, with whom to discuss my own groping tear of the movement's coming to a possible dead end. Their conversation, which was printed in Saturday Review, was disappointing to the American feminist. Among other things, the author of The Second Sex told the author of The Feminine Mystique that such interim gains as better jobs for women, token positions and apparent sexual integration were counterproductive within the existing political system. The role of feminists in France, she said, is to sap this regime but not play their game. Their politics is not to take part in politics.

title: West German Illiterate Wins the Right to Drive
description: MUNSTER, West Germany, Oct. 4 (Reuters)Motorists in West Germany can qualify for a driving license without being able to read or write, a Mnster court has ruled.

title: Family Day Today At Newark Museum
description: NEWARKFamily Day at the Newark Museum today will have a Bicentennial theme. From 1 to 5 P.M., the museum will offer activities, films, demonstrations and talks on life in New Jersey 200 years ago.

title: Beame Drafts Plan Urging Radical City Restructuring
description: Mayor Beame, taking what he describes as a first step toward a radical restructuring of the city bureaucracy, plans to have the Fire and Highways Departments managed as if they were modern businesses rather than government agencies.

title: No White House Comment
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4  A spokesman for President Ford has said that the White House, would have no comment about allegations of arrogant and overbearing conduct by American security agents who accompanied Mr. Ford to Bonn.

title: NEW SEWAGE PLAN STUDIED ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4  A novel new system of sewage treatment, in which some components are used to purify the rest, is going to get a fullscale trial here.

title: Rutgers Schedules LaborAid Sessions
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  For the 16th year, grievancehandling workshops are being offered by the Rutgers University Extension Division.

title: Engagements
description: EisdorferGold

title: Elisabeth Evans Plans to Marry
description: Mrs. Joseph E. Evans of Pelham Manor, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Elisabeth Jane Marie Evans, to Peter V. Foukal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jaroslav Foukal of Montreal. A wedding in December is planned.

title: Cornell Downs Bucknell, 216
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 4Cornell used pass interceptions to score one touchdown and set up another today in a 216 victory over Bucknell. An interception and 15yard runback by Don Papich, a linebacker, set up the first score, which came on a 1yard plunge by Don Fanelli, a fullback. Dave Johnson, a halfback, ran 59 yards with an interception of a pass by Kerry Snow for the visitor's third score.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: A death diminishes everyone. Two deaths in the dance world this past summerthat of John Kriza, a pioneer with American Ballet Theater, and of Rudolf Benesh, the creator of the Benesh system of dance movement notation seem especially sad, if only because both men were comparatively young. In fact, this has been a summer of particular sadness for the dance world in that the obituary columns have been uncomfortably crowded with the names ofand tributes toan inordinate number of dance luminaries: Charles Weidman, Pavel Virsky, Heinz Bosl (a 28yearold who was regarded as Germany's finest premier danseur), Alexander Lapauri and Paul Nickel. All these men had contributed a great deal to their field; but here I want to talk about Kriza and Benesh. The first because he was one of the archetypal American dancers, one of the very pillars upon which Ballet Theater was built, and the other because, although not himself a dancer, he developed a system of movement notation that has had a major influence on dance throughout the world.

title: Miss Lombardi Aims At Auto Sex Barrier
description: Being one of the first women drivers in Formula One hasn't impressed Lella Lombardi as much as it has other people.

title: Milk, Fruit Feel the Stirrings of Antitrust
description: WASHINGTONSome 70 per cent of the milk and, very roughly, onethird of the grain, cotton, fruits and vegetables produced by the nation's farmers are sold through cooperatives these days.

title: MISS CIRAULO SINGS CITY OPERA SALOME
description: Salome is a difficult role, dramatically and musically. But it cannot be said that Marianna Ciraulo, who took over the title part in Richard Strauss's opera Thursday night with the New York City Opera, did a very good lob with us.

title: Lunger Qualifies for Glen Race As Lauda Gains Pole Position
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Oct. 4Brett Lunger, as expected, did not win the pole position today for the Grand Prix of the United States. In fact, he came dangerously close to crashing his way out of tomorrow's $350,000 event, the richest auto race in the world with righthand turns.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Frankfurter

title: Tiresome job All the Livelong Day
description: The Meaning and DeMeaning of Routine Work. By Barbara Garson. 221 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $7.95.

title: Jeffrey Miller And Dania Paul Plan Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Halliburton Paul of Greenwich and Old Saybrook, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Dania Taylor Paul, to Jeffrey Scott Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Merton Miller of Amsterdam and Batchelorville, N. Y. A wedding next summer is planned.

title: FEWER CHECKING ON AIR AND WATER
description: A broken water main flooding a subway tunnel during night hours or a leaking sewer line may not be repaired as fast as they once were. Incinerator operators who violate the city's airquality standards may not be visited by an inspector as rapidly as before.

title: Carey's Defense And Streak Wilt
description: Fred Rosenberg scored four touchdowns yesterday against a Carey team that was fast becoming a legend for its defense. His effort enabled Great Neck North to win its Nassau Conference V opener from last year's champions, 2812.

title: For Women: A Wardrobe Consultant
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  A former fashion, coordinator and professional model has come out of retirement at the age of 34 to provide what might be the only service of its kind in New Jersey.

title: Desert Fruit
description: In what he says is the biggest deal in trees of all history, Georges Delbard, a 69yearold French nurseryman, recently committed himself to deliver and plant 3.5 million fruit trees in Iran.

title: For young readers: Leonardo's boy and some picture stories
description: Often a biography written for children is like a timid plaster cast. The author was too scrupulous to deviate from known facts but lacked the power to recreate in lifesize a human being who strode through time, changing the course of history.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: A new medicalcare project to improve services in rural areas has been announced by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation. The foundation, a major private philanthropy in the health field, is providing $14million to establish medical groups in about 25 rural communities that either have no doctor at all or that have meager medical facilities.

title: Smith of St. Louis Relishes Rivalry
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 4The first time Jackie Smith, the tight end for the St. Louis Cardinals, played against the Giants, what impressed the rookie from Columbia, Miss., the most was Y.A. Tittle's red neck with all the wrinkles. Tomorrow, at age 35, Smith will line up against the Giants for the 23d time. He may notice that Craig Morton, one of many successors to Tittle, does not have wrinkles about the neck even after the Washington Redskins finished twisting it last Sunday.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Memorable Riding in Wyoming
description: DUBOIS, WyoAs our horses scrambled through Shoshone Pass at sunset, nearly 10,000 feet above sea level, I was grateful that our outfitter Bob Jacob, had told me to lash a heavy wool shirt or jacket behind my saddle, for with the arrival of twilight the high, thin air was suddenly cold.

title: Pointers on Maintaining Gutters
description: The gutters around the roof of every house should perform two important functions: (1) drain roof water off harmlessly so it doesn't run down the walls of the house and thus cause streaking and staining; and (2) carry water safely away from the house foundation so as to minimize the likelihood of causing a flood in the basement, or causing possible washouts of lawn and foundation plantings.

title: Ali Gets A Sendoff In Manila
description: MANILA, Oct. 4  Still sporting a black eye from his hardwon victory over Joe Frazier here last Wednesday morning, Muhammad All left the Philippines today with a shower of kisses and about $60million in business deals.

title: Hudson County Maps Huge Park Project
description: JERSEY CITYA plan that would more than double the size of Lincoln County Park here has been unveiled by the rejuvenated Hudson County Park Commission as part of the agency's first effort in 12 years to improve the seven countyoperated preserves.

title: Researchers Discover Litter Is Piling Higher
description: PELLSTON, Mich., Oct. 4 (UPI)Scientists at the University of Michigan's biological station at Douglas Lake near Pellston began a rather modest project to help determine whether Michigan heeded a bill banning throwaway containers.

title: BRIDGE
description: Europeans tend to give low marks to American bridge experts. One reason is the abrasiveness of some of the Americans who have represented us in world championships. Another is the history of cheating accusations levelled by Americans against Europeans: justified or not, this invariably results in transatlantic friction. A third, less obvious but equally important, is the difference in approach to the application of the laws of the game.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times last Sunday about Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland said that Senator J. Glenn Beall Jr. headed the prosecution team against Vice President Agnew. It was the Senator's older brother, George Beall, who led the prosecution in the case.

title: Moynihan Criticism of Amin Has U.N. People Buzzing
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4African and other delegations said today that they were stunned to learn that Daniel P. Moynihan, the chief American representative at the United Nations, had approvingly quoted a characterization of President Idi Amin of Uganda as a racist murderer.

title: Diaconate Class Is Set for Ordination
description: NEWARKThe first class in the permanent diaconate program of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark was formally accepted as candidates for ordination last night in ceremonies held at St. Joseph's Church, 221 West Market Street. The 94 men in the class will be ordained at Sacred Heart Cathedral on Dec. 14.

title: Speakers Available From the Bergen Bar
description: HACKENSACK The Bergen County Bar Association is once again offering the services of its Speakers Bureau to business groups, community organizations, clubs, schools and other groups throughout the county.

title: Early Taxes Pouring In As City Pays a Discount
description: Spurred by the city's offer of an 8 per cent discount, property owners here have prepaid more than $370million in real estate taxes so far in the current fiscal year.

title: For losing China they lost their jobs
description: On the eve of his proclamation of the People's Republic of China in 1949, Mao Tsetung was moved to castigate as a naive idea the notion that the new Communist state would need to turn to the United States and Britain for assistance. Sun Yatsen, he recalled, had appealed countless times to the capitalist countries for help and got nothing but heartless rebuffs. Sun had suffered; he had been deceived, Mao said. It wouldn't happen again; if the new regime needed help, it would know where to turn tothe friendly Soviet Union.

title: The Rozelle Rule, Workers and Pro Football Peace
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Indrani Is Confident In Stylistic Blend Of Orissi Dancing
description: Indrani's regular visits here began in 1961, and she has quite thoroughly captivated her audiences each time. A climax of official recognition was reached when she received the key to the city on a visit two years ago. This time she scheduled two performances for Hunter College on Friday and yesterday and presented her mixture of styles and dances with assurance and flair.

title: Los Angeles School Board Bars Corporal Punishment
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 (UPI) The city school board has abolished spanking as a means of punishment but has called on school officials to discover new and more effective means of student discipline.

title: At 81, George Meany Is Still Mr. Labor
description: SAN FRANCISCOThe merged labor movement is marking its 20th anniversary here this week with George Meany more firmly in command than he was when 20 years of civil war between the old American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations ended with his election as president at the 1955 merger convention in New York.

title: Inmates Trying Hand at Art
description: A young man wearing a brown plastic apron was sitting at the potter's wheel fashioning a vase. Another was putting the finishing touches on a selfportrait while a third was trying to duplicate a picture from a Bible that he was balancing on his lap.

title: Trenton Museum Becomes Bazaar
description: TRENTON  The State Museum has taken on the exotic air of a picturesque bazaar in a faraway land.

title: S. E. C.'s Tough Guy
description: WASHINGTON  Listening to Stanley Sporkin talk is like watching a good tennis game. Your head goes hack and forth, as he paces restlessly up and down in his plain fourthfloor office at the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Herbert Hendin looks at youth and finds trouble
description: There are a great many jokes about psychoanalysts, most of them turning on the same device: If a patient declares that he hates his father, the analyst nods gravely and makes a note of it. If a patient declares that he loves his father, the analyst nods even more gravely and notes, Patient has repressed his hatred of his father.

title: Temple of Understanding To Hold Conference Here
description: A summit conference of world religions will be held here for six days, beginning Oct. 19, under the auspices of the Temple of Understanding, a nonprofit corporation pledged to foster ecumenical education and understanding.

title: Ford's Campaign Has Found Its Natural Theme: Bad New York
description: WASHINGTON President Ford has made it clear, during his nonpolitical travels of the last few months, that he intends to present himself to the American electorate as the apostle of fiscal sanity, the President who will finally bring Government spending under control and ease the burden on the taxpayers. He has also pictured himself as the prototypical Middle Westerner, open, affable, free of specious sophistication.

title: Rutgers Tops Hawaii, 73, On ThirdPeriod Score
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 4 (AP)Matt Allison, a quarterback, sneaked from the 1 at the end of the third period today to give Rutgers a 73 victory over Hawaii.

title: Harbor Springs Is First By Head in Rich Futurity
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 4 (AP)  Louis Lee Haggin's Habor Springs rallied from just off the pace in the final strides today and took the $130,725 Breeders Futurity by a head at Keeneland.

title: So. Conn. Conquers Springfield, 2417
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 4Phil LaRosa set up the winning touchdown today with an interception and then stopped a Springfield drive to lift Southern Connecticut State College to a 2417 victory over Springfield at Bowen Field.

title: King Olav of Norway Is in City; Tour to Honor U.S. Immigrants
description: King Olav V of Norway flew to New York yesterday to begin a 26day tour of the United States commemorating the 150th anniversary of the first organized Norwegian emigration to this country.

title: Women Bad Luck at Sea? Not to This Cadet
description: KINGS POINT One day after the container vessel Lightning dropped anchor in New York, Midshipman Frances Yateswith but an afternoon to spare before boarding a second merchant flag ship the Mormac Lynxwas back at the United States Merchant Marine Academy to tell all about life on the high seas.

title: Indian Drive Against Rats
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 4 (Reuters) Students, voluntary organizations and officials throughout India are to unite in an effort to exterminate an estimated six billion rats under a fiveyear plan announced here.

title: Growing Up Rich
description: By Anne Bernays. 343 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $7.95.

title: Reagan Seeks G.O.P Backing in West While Rockefeller Campaigns for Ford
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 4Former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California, stumping the country energetically in his search for encouragement for a possible race against President Ford, has brought his campaign to the Western States Republican Conference here.

title: CLOCK MAKER DIES IN ATTACK AT HOME
description: WEYMOUTH, Mass., Oct. 4 (UPI)Elmer Stennis, described as an internationally known maker of grandfather clocks, was shot and killed early today by two masked men who burst into his suburban Boston home and sprayed the bedroom with gunfire, the police said.

title: PENSION TAPPING URGED ON CAREY
description: Democrats in the Legislature are urging Governor Carey to consider tapping the multibilliondollar state pension systems to meet the state's borrowing obligations next spring if the state is still frozen out of the credit markets.

title: The Death Of Mr. Baltisberger
description: Bohumil Hrabal is a Czech writer, now 60, with a splendid ear for the trivia, the ephemera that make up so much of our discourse. The conversation at a bar, at a family picnic, even on a lover's walk reveals a design essentially patternless and, when juxtaposed to events of some weight or significance, results in a series of weird, grotesque tales. It is precisely the contrasts in this collection of stories that hold the elements together.

title: Vetoing Children
description: Asserting that the Child Nutrition Act of 1975 is worse than last year's legislation, President Ford has vetoed the best child feeding bill Congress has ever passed. Mr. Ford apparently proceeds on the assumption that the extension of any Program in this area is bad on its face.

title: Nancy L. Hayward Wed in Delaware
description: Nancy Lloyd Hayward, daughter of Mrs. Ellice McDonald Jr. of Montchanin, Del., and the late Nathan Hayward Jr. of Wayne, Pa., was married yesterday afternoon to Arthur Ward Burian, son of Arthur J. Burian of Boca Raton, Fla., and Margaret W. Burian of Remsenberg, L.I.

title: IS BRIBERY DEFENSIBLE?
description: It has been above 110 degrees each day in the dusty Middle Eastern capital city. The American sales representative has already, been through two bout; with dysentery; worse yet, the only liquor available is a foul substance called ponzoo. After three months of presentations before lesser officials. the American is finally granted an audience with the Minister. For the nth time, he goes through his product's performance, his company's reputation, the attractive price. The Minister listens, obviously bored, then points to a round little man in the hack of the room. This is Mr. Faud, he says. Mr. Faurl will pay a visit upon you tonight.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1975

title: Strong Berner Finish Pays Off
description: Berner, upset winner over Syosset a week ago, struggled through three periods before breaking out for 29 points and a 429 victory over Freeport yesterday in Nassau Conference II.

title: Saved by incest
description: By Randall Reid. 224 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $7.95.

title: PILOT LIGHT FOUND TO BE GAS WASTER
description: How much does the pilot light on common home gas appliances cost?

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times last Sunday about Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland said that Senator J. Glenn Beall Jr. headed the prosecution team against Vice President Agnew. It was the Senator's older brother, George Beall, who led the prosecution in the case.

title: David Pine to Marry Dale Elyse Weinstock
description: Mr. and Mrs. William S. Weinstock of Hewlett, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dale Elyse Weinstock, to David J. Pine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Pine of Manhasset, L.I.

title: Design: Ward Bennett's way
description: At 57, designer Ward Bennett is approaching the age and reputation when his influence on contemporary American design can be assessed. Beginning with the first apartment that he designed, for a distant relative in 1944, the Bennett interior has carried a special signature. It is crisp and spare, but totally unlike, say, the cold, sterile Bauhaus interiors of the nineteenthirties. Instead, it exudes a sense of comfort and elegance, the characteristic sparseness softened with rich wood grains, handwoven and handdyed textiles, furs and leather upholstery, plants and fine art. Wherever possible, the furniture is built in. Sunken conversation pits and seating platforms topped by upholstered pads replace sofas. Cabinetry, lighting and cantilevered shelves for paintings and books are a part of the room's architecture.

title: Ford Marches and Shakes Hands in West Virginia
description: ELKINS, W. Va., Oct. 4 Thousands of West Virginians cheered and applauded President Ford today as he rode and walked more than a mile through this small mountain town as the grand marshal of an annual festival.

title: The Troubles Never End For the I.R.A.
description: Why isn't every man in Ireland out with the I.R.A.? Up with the barricades, up with barricades . . . .

title: SOLO AT SPINDLETOP BY MAXENE ANDREWS
description: In the beginning, Maxene Andrews was one of the three Andrews Sisters. Last year, in the musical Over Here! she was one of two Andrews Sisters. And now she is out there all by herself, doing a single for the first time at Upstairs at the Spindletop, 254 West 47th Street.

title: Card of Thanks
description: COHENMrs. Louis Cohen and family sincerely thank their friends and relatives for their kind expressions of sympathy in their recent bereavement. Peace.

description: Allaire Brisbane Chandor of Philadelphia, who teaches religions of mankind at the Philadelphia Community College, was married yesterday afternoon to James Stanley Brumfield, a student at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School.

title: Moth That Damaged Soviet Wheat Crop Now Found in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)The cereal stem moth, which has heavily damaged winter wheat and rye crops in the southwestern part of the Soviet Union, has turned up in the United States, the Smithsonian Institution says.

title: Music: Monteverdi Choir at Carnegie
description: Three years ago, in one of Lincoln Center's international choral festivals, the Monteverdi Choir of the University of Hamburg in West Germany made a most favorable impression singing a varied selection of short choral pieces under Jurgen Jrgens's direction.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Moving in a bit on Paul E. Erdman's territory (Erdman being the writer who specializes in complicated international financial capers), Ross Thomas has come out with THE MONEY HARVEST (Morrow, $8.95). The location, as in so many Thomas novels, is Washington, where a very old man, a famous veteran of politics, overhears some important conversation. Before he can tell what he has heard, he is killed. An old friend flies in to investigate, with next to nothing to work on.

title: Newarker of Old Reflects
description: NEWARK When it comes to recalling the Newark of yesteryear, Mary Fitzpatrick Zeller can step right to the ?? of the class. Mrs. Zeller was 100 years old yesterday, an event marked by a family party at the Short Hills home of Mrs. Robert Cronheim, one of her 15 grandchildren, and in a recent interview she recalled some of the highlights of her 80 years here.

title: Football: It Pays the Bills, Son
description: Football is one of my favorite games. I was, in fact, a high school football coach for 15 years.

title: Lagos Sets Constitution Unit
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 4 (Agence FrancePresse)Nigeria's military Government today appointed an allcivilian 50  man constitution drafting committee as a first move toward an avowed return to civilian rule in 1979.

title: Truck Driver Charged
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 4 A Chicago truck driver is being held in $50,000 bond here on charges of importing 28 pounds of Mexican heroin. Agents of the Drug Enforcement Administration said that the cache had been found in the back seat of a truck driven by Rudolpho Willars, 38 years old.

title: Turnovers Help Elis Win, 2410
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 4Colgate committed four costly turnovers today on two fumbles and two interceptions and Yale turned three of them into scores for a 2410 victory.

title: For Sharers, Half a House Is Plenty
description: JERSEY CITY, N. J.Jo Marcus and Howard Singer lead separate lives, with separate friends and separate interests, but they do have some things in common.

title: South African Air Show
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 4 (Agence FrancePresse)The first international air show to be held in southern Africa opened this week at the new Lanseria airport 12 miles north of Johannesburg with entries from Britain, the United States, Canada, Australia, Japan and France. The show, open to blacks and whites, was inaugurated by Defense Minister Pieter Willem Botha and is to be held from now on every two years.

title: LEADS REPORTED IN INQUIRY ON C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Thal Senate Select Committee on Intelligence is investigating several new leads on whether Robert F. Kennedy had a role while he was Attorney General in ordering a plot by the Central Intelligence Agency to kill Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba, sources familiar with the investigation said today.

title: Neil Weintrob Excels at Violin
description: Neil Weintrob's background Is certainly impressive: the violinist, who made his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday, has studied with Oscar Shumsky, Ivan Galamian, Raphael Bronstein, Yehudi Menuhin and Nadia Boulanger. He has taught at the Manhattan School of Music and the Amherst Summer Music Center.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The suspect had been sitting for hours in the squad room, staring at the walls and floor, refusing to answer. Most of the questions had been softly voiced by a detective sergeant. A good detective always tries persuasion first but, when persuasion fails, he will abruptly change his tack. A good detective is both psychologist and actor.

title: Lincoln Tops New Utrecht On Late Pass by Sajecki
CAMERA VIEW
description: Although home video tape recording is still quite expensive, there has been a great deal of interest in it lately on the part of many photographers and home moviemakers. Compact home systems are available Which will plug into most home television redeivers, although these will record only in blackandwhite and prices start at about $1,500 (color systems are more expensive, costing about four times as much). However, for people who don't want to produce their own tapes, there are systems available which cost about onethird less and which enable one to view commercially made programs. In addition, a new system, the videodisk, will be on the market soon and it will offer a playback device for as little as $500 or $600, with fulllength motion pictures that; will cost under $20.

title: Looking for A Wave
description: By J. M. Couper. 155 pp. Scarsdale, N. Y.: Bradbury Press. $6.95.

title: Is Nuclear Too Costly?
description: Skyrocketing construction costs and puzzling patterns in the use of electricity have slowed the development of nuclear energy in the United States in a way that the opponents of nuclear power probably never imagined, in their wildest dreams.

title: Tuck in the Terrace for Winter
description: Most annuals, after a vivid, eventful summer, are in the last scene of all, sans buds, sans blossoms, sans everything and they should be pulled up and discarded.

title: Headliners
description: Three prominent baseball figures died last week. Casey Stengel, 85, a betterthanaverage ballplayer and a worsethanaverage manager when he joined the New York Yankees in 1949, piloted the team to 10 pennants and seven world championships in the next 12 years, a succession not matched before or since by any professional team in any sport. But younger fans may remember him best as the double talking wit who transformed a collection of baseball retreads and hasbeens known as the New York Mets into a comic boxoffice success. Larry MacPhail, also 85, a front office publicist not nearly as flamboyant as Stengel, introduced night baseball in Cincinnati (President Roosevelt himself turned the lights on), and came up with the idea of broadcasting games on the radio. Joan Payson, 72, was the principal owner of the Mets and one of the team's most fervent fans.

title: Long Run Sets Up Spartan Victory
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 4 Tyrone Wilson's 76yard burst set up Levi Jackson's 4yard touchdown run with 3 minutes 50 seconds left, as Michigan State upset eighthranked Notre Dame, 103, today.

title: Now Lebanon Is Taken
description: JERUSALEMPractically since its creation as an independent state in 1945, Lebanon has been the ignored party in the wars and crises that have swept over the Middle East. Rarely directly involved in the fighting against Israel, she has seldom participated in the political negotiations that followed. As a political and military factor, Lebanon, with her weak central government and miniscule armed forces, simply didn't count.

title: N.H.L. Teams Begin Chasing Flyers Again as 59th Season Opens Tuesday Night
description: Like the economy, the National Hockey League seems to have come to a standstill. Unlike the economy, however, the N.H.L., which opens its 59th season on Tuesday, may have averted any backtracking by preserving the expansion that had already taken place and stabilizing the status quo.

title: Women's Bowling Takes Giant Step
description: Judy Soutar and Vesma Grinfelds, two topranked members of the Professional Women's Bowling Association tour, express cautious optimism about the future of women's bowling. Although both hope for better things, neither anticipates drastic changes in women's professional bowling imediptely or in the near future. First we have to get rid of the stigmas held about bowling; that it is a recreation and not a sport, and that women bowlers aren't ladylike, said Mrs. Soutar during a recent interview at the St. Regis Hotel in New York. Then we have to obtain major sponsors for our tournaments and get some kind of television exposure.

The move was the latest in a series of switches in which officials have shuttled between grain companies and the department that plays a major role in Federal grain export policy. The Continental Grain Company of New York announced today the hiring of Richard J. Goodman to head its Washington office effective Oct. 13.

The notes in question are Handel's, and Miss Horne will have a lot of them when she goes to the Houston Opera in the middle of this month to sing the title role in the first staged production in the United State of Handel's Rinaldo  And I'm back in trousers, I'm a general again, she added with a just perceptible sigh. She has held similar rank in Handel's Semele and. Rossini's Siege of Corinth, and it is clear that these military gentlemen are formidably musical: there are six arias and one accompanied recitative with orchestra for Rinaldo. description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 (AP)A law requiring women to clothe their breasts while men are allowed to go barechested is not unconstitutional, a state appeals court has ruled.

title: Sixth Rock n Roll Spectacular Presents a Look Quite Familiar

But judging from Friday's show at Madison Square Gardenthe sixth anniversaryit appeared to be a change in name only. The Five Satins, along with Sha Na Na, appeared at Mr. Nader's first show. Chuck Berry, the headliner, and the coasters have been regular attendees, and Jay Black and the Americans, who make a return in this particular series, are also familiars at this kind of enforced nostalgia.

title: The Political Underground Is Small, and Often Violent
description: It is a life of fear, excitement, tension, compact joys, boredom, quiet satisfactions, and hard work. It is a life that can encompass political bombing, shoplifting, midnight bus trips, waiting on tables, writing, organizing and picnicking in the park. It is a life of few grays and much starkness, of commitment and dedication, of paranoia and uncertainty. It is the life of the American political underground.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4At 10 A.M. Monday the Justices of the Supreme Court will enter their marblecolumned courtroom for the official start of the new Court year. It will be a year of uncertainty, largely because of the health of Justice William O. Douglas, who suffered a stroke last Dec. 31.

title: The Damn Fools Are Ruining Boating for the Tired Old Salts
description: Not long ago, I took my youngest daughter out in her 11foot sloop on Lake George to give her a sailing lesson. All went well until a speedboat came rushing around the end of an island and almost rammed us. Only at the last moment did he swerve. We were half swamped by his wake, and now my daughter thinks that piling is too terrifying a sport to be much fun.

description: Wajima, bought for $600,000 as a yearling, has been syndicated for a record sum of $7.2million.

title: Doctor Rated Accused Slayer Not Troublesome

Y., near Cayuga Lake, was not a troublesome boy, according to Dr. Regnar K. Karlsson, deputy clinic director of the Willard Psychiatric Center in nearby Ovid.

description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 4Two new programs designed to bring reforms to the criminal justice system are being introduced in Westchester County.

He has created more than half the works staged by the Joffrey, and it is entirely likely that his new Bicentennial ballet, Beautiful Dreamer, set to Stephen Foster's music, which premieres Thursday night, will once again make him a center of controversy.

description: PARIS, Oct. 4About 20,000 people marched in an angry but disciplined demonstration in Paris today to protest a rapid increase in youth unemployment.

But after running the division for four years, Gerber wanted to sell it or close it down, according to John Carter, then a San Francisco stockbroker trying to find a buyer for the distributor.

title: Alive & Well By the Dead Sea
description: YOU couldn't pay people to live in Sodom. It's at the bottom of the world's deepest natural hole. True, 1,000 Israelis work there, extracting chemicals from the Dead Sea waters evaporating in the blazing heat, but when the plant lets out, the workers race no the steep cocoahued hills one homes on the breezy plateau. At one time the stateowned venture was actually so hard up for labor that the Government paroled convicts who would work there.

title: Anna Barron Lamberton Fiancee

title: Cool hand in Thailand
description: BANGKOK. On a sultry night not long ago, a mob of drunken policemen marched on the home of Premier Kukrit Pramoj, the suave, silverhaired novelist, journalist, teacher, dancer and movie star who has headed the Thai Government since March. Fortified by impassioned speeches and mekhong, the potent local whisky, they were demanding that Kukrit appear and explain why he had released nine activist students and farmers in northern Thailand several days before, thereby causing the police who had arrested them to lose face. When he failed to show up by the midnight deadlinehe was at a nearby police station, explaining his decision to another group of protestersthe crowd broke through the gates and proceeded to smash windows and furniture in the elegant, Thaistyle house, free his pet birds from an aviary and wre??k the beautiful garden that he had personally planted with loving eare.

title: GAS RISE APPEAL CALLED A THREAT
description: The head of the State Consu mer Protection Board has characterized as a serious threat to consumers a proposal by the state's 12 major naturalgas companies to pass on to consumers the cost of exploration for new sources of natural gas.

description: Stamford and Brien McMahon tied, 2020, yesterday.

title: Israel was as good as ever
description: In the Six Day War of 1967, as in the Sinai campaign of 1956, the Israelis owed a dazzling victory largely to bold use of their air power. The Arab states, when preparing for the next round of the contest, were, therefore, provided by their Soviet suppliers with large numbers of surfacetoair missiles. Could the Israelis nonetheless have not achieved as brilliant a success once more in 1973 had not political considerations held them back? Or did they make the mistake of so seriously underrating their opponents that they were lucky to escape defeat?

title: Marcia Magrill Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edwin S. Magrill of Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marcia Susan Magrill, to Ian Lawrence Brecher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Brecher of Inwood, L.I. The couple are graduates of the State University College at Albany.

title: W. T. Grant in Bankruptcy
description: The retailing industry and its supplying industries, reverberated with shock late last week as a longfeared possibility materialized: The country's sixth largest retailer, the W. T. Grant Company, filed on Thursday for court protection under the provisions of the Bankruptcy Act. It listed debts of more than $1billion, the secondlargest insolvency to that of the Penn Central Transportation Company five years ago when liabilities totaled $3.3billion.

title: Creative Sewing Offered in Nassau
description: Free courses in creative stitchery and in advanced quilting will be offered to residents 18 years old and over by the Nassau County Department of Recreation and Parks beginning this month.

title: JACK SCOTT FACES A NEW U.S. INQUIRY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4It had to be bad news for Jack Scott, the radical sports figure, when a spokesman for the Department of Justice this week described an article in the magazine Rolling Stone as essentially correct.

title: S. K. Scovil 3d And Janet Fates Plan to Marry
description: Janet MacLaren Fates and Samuel Kingston Scovil 3d, who graduated with the class of '73 from Yale College, plan to be married on Jan. 3.

title: Film Notes: From Sequel Mania to Disappearing De Niro
description: The way things are going, it won't be long before almost every new movie is a sequel to an old movie. A couple of openings in New York in the next few days illustrate the point: Let's Do It Again, with Sidney Poitier and Bill Cosby, a sequel to Uptown Saturday Night; and Rooster Cogburn, with John Wayne and Katharine Hepburn, a sequel to True Grit.

title: C. D. Bradford Weds Miss Connally
description: Susan Jane Connally, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Edward Connally of Annapolis, Md., and Charles E. Bradford were married yesterday afternoon in Radnor, Pa. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Fiske Bradford of Cambridge, Mass. His father, former Governor of Massachusetts, is a lawyer with the Boston firm of Palmer & Dodee.

title: Fashion
description: What is a bag? Something to carry the groceries home in (or the jewels from Tiffany's), what potato chips are packaged in, a status symbol, what doctors carry their equipment in and lawyers their briefs, an art work by Andy Warhol, what most women and some men use to tote around their everyday necessities. All these forms of the bag and many more are being celebrated in an exhibition call Homage to the Bag, running from Oct. 10 to Jan. 4 at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts.

title: Couple With Guns Seized in City; Plot On Hirohito Feared
description: Hours before the arrival here yesterday of Emperor Hirohito of Japan, United States Secret Service agents raided a Brooklyn apartment where they seized a cache of arms that they believed might have been intended for use in an assasination attempt on the Emperor.

title: Letters
description: Handle with care

title: Police Posing as Fences Seize 41 in Bronx for Stolen Goods
description: Fortyone burglary suspects, most of them lured by the promise of $5,000 in counterfeit currency, were captured Friday night and early yesterday as the police sprung a trap in a West Bronx store where undercover detectives had been fencing stolen goods for six months.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Gallant Bob Triumphs
description: CORNWELL HEIGHTS. Pa., Oct. 4 (AP)Heavily favored fifth straight stakes victory and 11th of the season today, capturing the $27,525 Penn Treaty Stakes at Keystone Race Track. Carrying 119 pounds and jockey Garland Gallitano, Robert P. Horton's Gallant Bob finished two lengths ahead of Tinton Falls Stable's Talc. Daybreak Farm's Real Value finished third, another two lengths back.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Angelo Dundee, Muhammad Ali's trainer, on the heavyweight champion's late round rally to beat Joe Frazier. My guy sucked it up when he looked completely out of gas, he put on another gas tank.

title: CHARTER REJECTION URGED BY CITY AIDE
description: Alphonse E. D'Ambrose, the city's Personnel Director, called on voters yesterday to reject the Charter Revision Commission's recommendations on personnel as costing the taxpayers millions of dollars to carry out.

title: Patriots to Test Jets' Defense; Cards to Test Giant Tradition
description: Playing at home for the first time since last December, the Jets also will be looking for new answers to old questions today when they face the New England Patriots at Shea Stadium.

title: Hirohito Given Scientific Treat in Visit to Cape Cod Laboratory
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass., Oct. 4 For a few minutes today the Emperor of Japan departed from the ceremony that has marked his visit to the United States, and looking through a microscope at the Marine Biological Laboratory here, immersed himself in the watery world of primitive, jellyfishlike creatures known as hydroids.

title: Spaniards Parade in Support of Franco
description: MADRID, Oct. 3 (AP)Hun dreds of thousands of Spaniards today demonstrated in support of Generalissimo Francisco Franco in an attempt to counter foreign protests over the execution of five young terrorists.

title: World News Briefs
description: AGANA, Guam, Oct. 4 (AP) South Vietnam said in a Hanoi radio broadcast today that the United States should abandon plans to give South Vietnamese repatriates on Guam a ship on which to return home.

title: Simplified Printing in Braille
description: Ezekiel Jacob, of Brooklyn, has what he hopes will soon be a patented solution to the stubborn problem of how to reproduce, cheaply and legibly, the threedimensional white  on  white of braille literature  through photocopying.

title: Buckeyes Conquer U.C.L.A.
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 (AP)  Cornelius Green, the quarterback, scored two touchdowns and set up bhree others tonight as Ohio State whipped U.C.L.A., 4120, in a game that began with both teams unbeaten.

title: City's Budget Crisis Forces Marine Police Theft Unit Cuts
description: One of the casualties of New York City's budget crisis has been the marine police. The force has been cut in half and its highly regarded, but experimental, vessel theft unit disbanded.

title: Remembering Poets
description: I remember William Carlos Williams, the subject of our lead review, from the summer of 1950 at Yaddo, that rentfree playground for writers, painters, composers on an old family estate in Saratoga Springs, adjoining the race track. Williams as the guest of honor that season was given the tower room in the mansion for his studio. From his window he could look across the sloping English lawn (where the poets battled at croquet in the evenings) to the ornate rose gardens. He was then hard at work on Paterson, his long poem.

title: CANADIANS OPEN BIGGEST AIRPORT
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 4Canada today formally opened her new Mirabel International Airport, billed as the world's largest and designed to protect the environment and provide for the nation's air travel needs well into the next century.

title: ADS ON FOOD STAMPS CALLED MISLEADING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Food Research and Action Canter, Inc., a public interest law firm that represents recipients of Federal food programs, is suing the sponsors of controversial food stamp advertisements published during the summer.

title: DRUG LOSSES CITED AT 9 V.A. HOSPITALS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) Nearly half the drugs withdrawn from stocks in nine Veterans Administration hospitals in a twoweek period disappeared, according to an audit last year by the General Accounting Office.

title: Dentists to Test Blood Pressure
description: MINEOLAA concentrated effort to involve dentists on Long Island in administering hugeblood pressure tests has begun at the Hofstra University Student Center in Hempstead.

title: October
description: Geese honk high, in October, and ducks take off from the river or the pond in a shower of diamond drops, southward bound. After September's tropical storms have passed and the skies have cleared again, October can be bright as a bittersweet berry. It has the daytang of walnut hulls and sumac berries and windfalls souring in the orchard. It has the night calls of barred owls and restless foxes.

title: Planned Commercial Complex Fought by Rego Park Store
description: The specter of a monumentaland perhaps permanent traffic jam where Queens Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway intersect has been raised by opponents of a proposed $150million complex of stores, offices and condominium housing in Rego Park, Queens.

title: Ford Now Favors SevenNation Talk On Recession and Exchange Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 Agreement in principle has been reached for an economic meeting in France of the heads of government of probably seven countries before the end of this year, West European officials disclosed today.

title: A Light Assembly Vote Looms
description: TRENTON  Leaders of both political parties expressed mounting concern this weekend that the Assembly elections next month could produce an unusually low turnout at the polls.

title: $813MILLION SPENT IN VOTES IN 4 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) American local governments spend nearly a quarter of a billion dollars each year for elections, a new Federal study showed today.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayCocker Spaniel Club of Long Island specialty and obedience, MidIsland Shopping Plaza, Route 106, Hicksville, L. I.; 112 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: Hirohito Remains The Father Figure
description: TOKYOThirty years ago on Aug. 15, Emperor Hirohito of Japan went on the radio to tell his people in delicate phrases that, after almost four years of fighting the Americans: The war has developed not necessarily to Japan's advantage. Then, without mentioning the words defeat on surrender, the Emperor said that it is according to the dictate of time and fate that we have resolved to pave the Way to peace for 10,000 generations by enduring the unendurable and suffering the insufferable.

title: Doubts & Joys In Chattanooga
description: AS long as I can remember, while traveling in the South I have been urged by signs on barns and the like to see Rock City and Ruby Falls In Chattanooga, Tenn. Now, I have never been much of one for tourist attractions and have long suspected that the physical, financial and emotional strain of vacations is a major hidden cause of both the generation gap and the collapse of the American family. But I am a trained reporter and I went with open mind and a good heart to see Rock City and Ruby Falls. In the process I discovered that Chattanooga is a mecca for Civil War enthusiasts, is full of railroad lore and memorabilia and is a city with a longestablished tradition of supporting the arts. I also learned a little about myself and my attitude toward vacations.

title: Buckley Sparkles For Exeter Again
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Dispute on A.B.A. Player
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 4 (UPI)  A spokesman for the Kentucky Colonels said today that the American Basketball Association team would not take hack Jim Bradley from the Baltimore Claws. The Claws said earlier they had suspended the forward for violating training regulations and were returning to the Colonels, from whom they obtained him.

title: Shopping Malls Going Small
description: The look and the approach are different, often vastly different, but the goal is the same: small shopping centers mostly without department stores or other large anchor units.

title: The WineMaking Revolution Keeps Growing and Growing
description: HESSTON, Ind.The harvest of Carl Banholzer's vineyards is almost finished, but on a slope overlooking the winery is a small group of vines that will not be picked until next week.

title: YOUTH GROUP SHIFTS SUPPORT TO REAGAN
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 4 (AP)The Young Americans for Freedom have shifted their support from President Ford to Ronald Reagan, former Governor of California, the group's national chairman, Jeffrey Kane of Portland, announced Thursday.

title: Shorter's Bid Fails
description: CROWLEY, La., Oct. 4 (AP) Frank Shorter, the Olympic gold medalist, failed today in an attempt to break the United States record for the marathon. He ran alone from Lafayette to Crowley in 2 hours 16 minutes 29 seconds, about 8 minutes short of the record.

title: Joan Whitney Payson, 72, Mets Owner, Dies
description: Joan Whitney Payson, who devoted her life to civic causes, racing stables and her beloved New York Mets, died yesterday morning at New York Hospital. She was 72 years old.

title: Sport of Falconry Is Topic of Debate
description: FRANKLIN LAKES Should falconry, the old sport of kings, be permitted in New Jersey, as it is in some other states?

title: J.J. Dolan Jr. Fiance Of Mary McGuire
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. McGuire of Bayonne, N. J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary Celine McGuire, to James J. Dolan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dolan of Southport, Conn.

title: Highlevel acceptance
description: Business executives who use bribery as a commercial tool in foreign countries almost never pass money directly. They use middlemen, who appear on their rosters as agents or consultants. Middlemen come recommended to the American company by local lawyers and hankers and even U. S. Government officials. Usually natives of the country in which they operate, they are sufficiently trusted by local Government officials to handle the ticklish matter of payoffs in comfort and secrecy.

title: Angola Rivals to Join Talks
description: KAMPALA Uganda, Oct. 4 (UPI)The three warring Angolan nationalist movements have agreed to meet with members of a conciliation commission of the Organization of African Unity in Angola, a spokesman said today.

title: Barringer Registers Another Shutout
Man, 62, Dies in Plane Crash
description: WESTFIELD, N. Y., Oct. 4 (UPI)  A strong wind gust apparently caused a light plane to crash just after taking off from a landing strip southwest of this Chautauqa County community Friday night, killing one person and injuring three others, authorities said. Sheriff's deputies said one of the plane's four passengers, Gordon Hawk, $2 years old, of Westfield, died in the crash.

title: Reds Trounce Pirates in Playoff Opener, 83; Red Sox Defeat A's, 71, on 3Hitter by Tiant
description: BOSTON, Oct. 4  In a display that might tempt Charles O. Finley to dismiss his whole defense and hire a platoon of designated fielders, the Oakland A's stumbled and bumbled their way to a 71 loss to the Boston Red Sox today in the opening game of the American League playoffs.

description: Bauman

title: Politics Before Policies
description: With more than a year to go until the Presidential elections, President Ford acts as if he were in the windup phase of the hustings. White House attention to the nation's business traditionally tends to sag in weeks Immediately preceding the elections. The risks of putting politics ahead of policies are intolerably compounded, however, when an incumbent President hits the campaign trail a year ahead of schedule.

title: 22 Are Arrested, Including Berrigan, At East Hartford
description: EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 4  Philip F. Berrigan was arrested here today along with 21 of his followers after they threw a redcolored liquid on aircraft at a national air show.

title: Hard Life of Charley Finley
description: BOSTON, Oct. 4With two out in the first inning, Carl Yastrzemski singled and Carlton Fisk lashed a shot that handcuffed Sal Bando, the third baseman. Bandothe village idiot, Charley Finley called him during their contract negotiations last springbacked up on the ball and it got past him for a twobase error. Claudell Washington was surrounding the ball in the left field corner when Yaztrzemski, traveling under forced draft as he always does, raced into third base. It was obvious that Yaz had no intention of stopping at third, and the official scorers, reasoning that a good throw might get him at the plate, gave Washington an error when his shabby throw eluded Bando, the Cutoff man. Yaz scored easily. Then Fred Lynn's smash bounced off the foot of Phil Garner, the second baseman, letting Fisk run home from second. It was the third error of the inning, a record for postseason play between halfchampions of the American League.

title: The natural province of Mordecai Richler
description: By Mordecai Richler. 128 pp. Washington, D. C.: The New Republic Book Company. $6.95.

title: Straub's Version of 'Aaron and Moses' by Schoenberg Is Uncompromising
description: At first, movies were silent images: Then sound was added. For some time now, the German director Jean-Marie Straub has been at work trying to remove the images.In his latest filmit can't be called a movie because virtually nothing moves, neither the camera nor what it is photographing  Mr. Straub has come close to purging the screen of anything to see. At the same time, he will come close to purging the movie theater of anybody to watch.Some kind of anchorite ideal is being approached here: a motionless screen in an empty theater with angry, monotone voices on the soundtrack reading out pamphlets to music.Some people  more in Europe than herefervently admire Mr. Straub for his aridity. Dryness in our still lush and overnourished civilization can seem a virtue. "Aaron and Moses," which will be shown at Lincoln Center this afternoon and Tuesday night as Mr. Straub's entry in the New York Film Festival, is one great Sahara.It is a filmed version of the atonal opera by Arnold Schoenberg, whose work was attacked in its day for uncompromising severity and even now is rarely whistled. Schoenberg, considering himself no minor prophet, modeled Moses upon himself. In the opera his Moses stands for the gaunt, unadorned religious Idea, conveyed solely through words and without images. Aaron argues that a living people needs imagesthe Golden Calf, for instanceand other aids to be able to grasp and fulfill the Idea.The opera is about the conflict. Schoenberg uses his technique to reinforce it: Aaron's tenor has musical phrases to sing; Moses' bass keeps to an atonal sung speech.Mr. Straub too seems to identify with Moses the image-breaker. He uses his cinema techniques in an attempt to reinforce the musical effect sought by Schoenberg. The first section, where Moses is present, is almost without motion. Moses' opening, lasting nearly five minutes, is rendered by the camera's fixing itself on the back of the singer's head. When he enlists Aaron, a second lengthy scene is done with the two men performing simultaneously, the camera merely showing them face to face.The Chosen People is represented by the Chorus of the Austrian Radio standing in a motionless block, like workers posing for pictures at a factory picnic. At times the screen goes blank or black for minutes on end, allowing the tiny light flaws skipping across to make up one of the film's visual high points.When Moses is up on the mountain and Aaron is in charge, the figures move a bit more. The Golden Calf is set up, there is a bit of dancing and a tiny orgy. It is done in detached, drugged fashion, with deliberate pictorial dullness.Dullness can be a statement, and in the case of Mr. Straub, whose control of his material is not in doubt, it obviously is. (The one major nondeliberate error is the subtitles. With so much emphasis on the singing and talking, and nothing much else happening, they assume a major importance. They are so bad, so Germanic, that sometimes it seems that this is a movie about present participles.)The reason for making dullness into a statement is less clear. But it seems to amount to a radical rejection of the successive cinematic fashions that generally try to heighten or vary the image, not to deaden it.Mr. Straub is making a minimal film, in other words, the equivalent of minimal painting. It is an antimovie and this would be fine except, maybe, for the people who go see it. Could they get in, perhaps, with anti-money?

title: Brothers Keepers
description: Another of Donald Westlake's amiable farces. This one focuses on a minimonastic order, located across the way from the Racquet and Tennis Club. The 16 brothers, who belong to the Order of St. Crispin are faced with the biggest crisis in the monastery's history: the imminent loss of their 200yearold lease. This gives Mr. Westlake the opportunity to send 16 otherworldly eccentrics out among the fleshpotsto meet with muggers, builders, speculators and the Municipal Landmarks Commission. The score is Fleshpots 4; Brothers 0, until youngish brother Crispin changes his habit for beach attire and pursues the landlord's daughter in Puerto Rico. The plot machinery is not as intricate as in some of the author's other contrivances, but it shows the same disdain for reality.

title: Food
description: GUADALAJARA, MexicoOne of the best soups in Mexico and one of the best fish soups we've tasted anywhere can be found at a small, tacky roadside stand here that would not command a second glance from a finicky and unadventurous tourist. It is called Chino's and is located at the corner Of Calle Libertad and 8 de Julio. It is an openair, sidewalk affair with one rectangular oilclothcovered table that is shared by random customers. Overhead is a torn cloth canopy to shield tie patrons from sun (or rain), and the principal sound is that of a stereogenerally the voices of Frank Sinatra. Peggy Lee or other American idols, piped from a small room somewhere in the rear.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Immediate Federal action should be taken to resolve the New York City  New York State credit crisis. If steps are taken promptly. they could perhaps be limited; If action does not take place until the brink of default is reached, whatever is done will have to be more extensive. Action will obviously become necessary at some point, and should be taken now before the entire credit market is more adversely affected. Congress must now understand that only the Federal Government has the capacity to do the job.

title: Westchester, Amid Opposition, Plans to Take Over Road Costs From Localities
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 4Westchester County is preparing to lift the burden of road maintenance and construction costs from its municipalities, but opponents of the change say it will create more problems that it will solve.

title: 2,500 CivilRights Complaints Still Awaiting Action by State
description: TRENTONIn Somerville, Detective Willie Akins has waited almost a year for some action on his employment complaint; in Basking Ridge, Caroline Hebard has waited 28 months for resolution, of her complaint against the Basking Ridge Fire. Department.

title: Atlanta's Planet of Apes
description: ATLANTA (AP)The Yerkes Regional Primate Research Center at Emory University here is the largest such center in the world, housing more than 150 great apes and more than 870 smaller primates.

title: The Army Terminal Vacated
description: First it was the Brooklyn Army Terminal, then it became the Military Ocean Terminal, and now it is simply 53 acres of prime harbor front property waiting for a new owner and a new name.

title: N.C. State Trounces Indiana
description: RALEIGH, N. C. Oct. 14 (AP)  North Carolina State used three freshman running backs in grinding out a 270 victory over Indiana today.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: In conversations with businessmen, financiers, economists and politicians in the last few weeks, it is apparent that few of them have generated great enthusiasm over the obvious resurgence of the American economy from the recession's deep trough last spring.

title: A Water Resource on L.I.
description: PORT WASHINGTON Private engineers here are seeking answers to a World Health Organization estimate that by 1980 nearly 55 per cent of the world's developing urban areas abroad will be running out of proper drinking water.

description: Today United States Grand Prix (200 miles) at Watkins Glen, N.Y., 3:05 P.M. 10lap Volkswagen race at 2 P.M.

title: FollowUp On The News
description: For years, Mount Baker, a 10,778foot volcano near the town of Concrete, Wash., has been letting off steam sporadically. But last March the United States Forest Service began to worry; the United States Geodetic Survey reported a fourfold increase in the steam.

title: A Double Treat for Art and Archeology Lovers
description: Sandwiched between Peru to the south, with its spectacular Inca heritage, and Mesoamerica, to the north, with its Aztec, Mayan and other monuments, Ecuador has seemed a curiously sterile region in America's preHispanic history. But sterile ix exactly the wrong word. Seminal the right one, as shown by a new exhibition, Ancient Ecuador, at the Center for InterAmerican Relations.

title: Basic Care Taught At Medical School
description: NEWARKIn a move designed to return the personal touch to medicine and counteract recent trends toward highly specialized training, the New Jersey Medical School has established a program embracing primary health care.

title: The Dance: Joffrey in Jooss, Tudor and Ashton
description: The first performance this season of Kurt Jooss's The Big City, and major cast changes in Antony Tudor's Offenbach in the Underworld and in two Sir Frederick Ashton ballets, The Dream and Monotones, provided the highlights of City Center Jaffrey Ballet's performances at the City Center 55th Street Theater yesterday afternoon and Friday evening.

title: A New Nuclear Plant Is Challenged
description: TRENTONA public interest organization is challenging the construction of a nuclearpower plant in the lower Delaware River on the ground that the facility would be in violation of a new coastalprotection act.

title: WARREN A. SCHENCK
description: Warren A. Schenck, a SpanishAmerican War Veteran and a lawyer, died Thursday in the Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 96 years old and lived at the New York Athletic Club.

title: Endpaper
description: In recent years, sports has been called America's real religion. If there is any truth to thisoffered in evidence are attendance figures and television ratings, as well as intragame schisms and media saintsthen this week is the holiest of the year: As college and professional football, basketball, hockey and track begin to gather the momentum of their regular seasons, baseball concludes the week with its saturnalia, the World Series.

title: GRANVILLE BENNETT, EPISCOPAL BISHOP
description: BARRINGTON, R.I., Oct. 4 (AP)  The Right Rev. Granville Gaylord Bennett, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Rhode Island from 1946 to 1955, died yesterday at his home. He was 92 years old.

title: R.V.Cosel Jr. Weds Carol F. Humstone
description: The Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Carol Fontaine Humstone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Millard Humstone of Douglaston, Queens, to Robert Vincent Cosel Jr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cosel of Pelham, N.Y.

description: In the Golden Age of Steam the chuffing of the locomotive, the sight of a steam plume wafting against the prairie landscape, a forlorn whistle in the dead of night, and the trainman's reassuring wave were all part of the American scene.
