description: Picture Credits

title: Regional Theater Notes: George M. Cohan Would Approve
description: Clyde Fitch? Why would anyone want to dig up a play by the author of Captain Sinks of the Horse Marines? One reason, says Arvin Brown, artistic director of New Haven's Long Wharf Theater, is that Fitch was the reigning American playwright of the early 1900's. So The House of Mirth, Fitch's adaptation of the Edith Wharton novel, will be part of the Long Wharf's upcoming season. Nor is the Long Wharf alone in its attention to early American drama. Plays by George M. Cohan and William Gillette are being dusted off in Cleveland and Los Angeles, respectively. Langdon Mitchell's The New York Idea, which first saw the light of Broadway in 1906, will be revived by the McCarter Theater Company of Princeton, N.J., which is also preparing a production of The Royal Family, by George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber. In addition, theatergoers around the country will be seeing revivals of works by Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder, Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller, Robert Lowell and Edward Albee. And the Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C., is well into its American Bicentennial Theater series. Regional theater, which is thriving, obviously is doing its Bicentennial best to celebrate the American playwright, although homegrown works are by no means the whole story of a national roundup.

title: Music in Review
description: Although it is only early October, the program given by Sheila Marie Allen in Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday night may well turn out to be one of the best to be given by an artist making a debut this season. The soprano, Californiaborn and a product principally of Oberlin Conservatory and the Eastman School of Music, is already a seasoned singer, who has toured widely. Two years ago she was a finalist in the Metropolitan Opera auditions and she teaches at the State University of New York at Fredonia. Contributing to the high quality of the recital as pianist was David Yeomans, the singer's husband and a soloist in his own right.

title: Jean L. Berke Bride of William H. Zietz
description: Jean Louisa Berke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Berke of Lakeville, Conn., and William Hugh Zietz were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Zietz of Silver Spring, Md. His father is a geophysicist with the United States Geological Survey, and a lecturer at George Washington University.

title: Concert by Hines, Blake and Taylor Traces Jazz Eras
description: The Overseas Press Club Jazz Club is fortunate in having as its honorary president Earl Hines, the jazz pianist, who is willing to make himself available when the club holds a benefit. He not only was available Thursday evening, when the jazz club started its sixth series of programs with a concert in the Grand Ballroom of the Biltmore Hotel to benefit the professional and cultural activities of the Overseas Press Club Foundation, but also brought with him two other pianists, Eubie Blake and Billy Taylor.

title: Three on the Tower
Daughter to the Greshes
description: A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Sean Gresh of Waterville, Vt. on Sept. 9 at the Medical Center Hospital of Vermont in Burlington. The child has been named Kristen Ann.

title: ANGELO J. FIORINI
description: Angelo James Fiorini, a vice president of Ted Bates & Co., an advertising concern died Wednesday in Pascack Valley Hospital, Westwood, N.J. He was 59 years old and lived at Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

title: Nevada Publisher Resigns
description: RENO, Oct. 4 (UPI)Richard J. Schuster, president and publisher of The Nevada State Journal and Reno Evening Gazette, has resigned. Ronald H. Einstoss, publisher of the Visalia, Calif., TimesDelta, is to succeed him.

title: Notes: Congress Mulls Future of Passports
description: FOR nearly a halfcentury, the United States passport has been relatively constant in size and format. But now changes are in the works, and the document has become the center of a Congressional controversy.

title: Shows Closed
description: The shows closed by the strike of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians:

title: Robin Adam Bride of Leonard Hall 3d
description: Christ Chapel of Trinity Episcopal Church in Buffalo was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Robin B. Adam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Borthwick Adam, to Leonard Parke Hall 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hall Jr. Both families reside in Buffalo.

title: Soviet Monument to Victims of Nazi Massacre Is Rising in Quiet Woods on the Site of Babi Yar in Kiev
description: KIEV. U.S.S.R.A monument is being built at Babi Yar. Past the thin woods, in the ravine where tens of thousands of Jews were ?? by the Nazis, a bullbdozer works. A truck brings in new earth. A woodden form for concrete stands on a small rise.

title: M. D. Batchelder Weds Miss Tomlinson
description: Merrill Gay Tomlinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ford Tomlinson of New Vernon, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Marvin Dice Batchelder, son of Mr. and Mrs. William George Batchelder of Medina, Ohio. The Rev. William L. Nieman performed the ceremony in Grace Episcopal Church in Madison, N. J.

title: Transit Plan at Complex Lags
description: EAST RUTHERFORDAlnough completion of the sports Complex in the meadowlands here seems certainby next September, plans for masstransit facilities in the area appear to be lagging badly.

title: Talks Resume in AllOut Effort To End the Strike by Musicians
description: What State Mediation Chairman Vincent D. McDonnell described as an allout effort to end the 17dayold theatrical musicians' strike began yesterday afternoon at the Americana Hotel.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The New York Nets of the American Basketball Association, who would like to join the National Basketball Association, will face the N.B.A.'s New York Knicks Wednesday in Nassau Coliseum at 8 P.M. in an exhibition game.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on military construction authorization bill, which passed, 72 to 1, Sept. 29.

title: Conservation Failure
description: The failure of the United States to establish anything like an adequate energyconservation program and reduce waste has now been confirmed by the International Energy Agency. In the agency's first review of the individual programs of its 18 member countries, the United States is shown to be fourth from last in conservation efforts among the major oilimporting nations. Only Belgium, Austria and Norwaythe last an oil exporterhave done more poorly since the 1973 Arab oil embargo. Britain and Sweden have done the best.

title: flow to get there and how to get around there
description: Remember the ballyhoo that accompanied Richard Nixon's preparations to visit China in 1972? Even his reading list stirred speculation. Which books would shape the President's image of revolutionary China? Pundits pontificated on the implications of choosing one author over another.

title: ART VIEW
description: We have been waiting a long time for an exhibition that would do justice to the splendor of Elie Nadelman's achievement as a sculptor and draftsman, and at last we have one in the show that John I. H. Baur has organized at the Whitney Museum of American. Art. Few exhibitions in recent memory have been as beautiful as this one, and those who see it will cherish the experience for a lifetime.

description: Shows that are not affected by the strike:

title: Miss Winslow, Bruce Wagner Are Wed Here
description: Elizabeth Pearsall Winslow and Bruce S. Wagner were married here yesterday afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration by the Rev. Allan Warren. A reception was held at the Colony Club.

BQLI Bulletin Board

title: Dog Shelter Closing Protested in Queens
description: The A.S.P.C.A. shelter at 158th. Street in Jamaica, Queens which has provided a refuge for thousands of the city's homeless and hungry Gals and dogs, closed its doors last week after 40 years of service.

title: 6 Presidential Hopefuls Speak To New Hampshire Democrats
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Oct. 4 Reveling In unaccustomed success, New Hampshire Democrats were courted here last night by a half dozen Presidential hopefuls.

title: BROWN TO NAME FARM LABOR UNIT
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 4Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. says he has decided to appoint a special force of lawyers and Investigators in an attempt to unclog quickly the machinery of California's new farm labor election law.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: In discussing music there are words that need to be used sparingly, not because they are meaningless but because they mean too many different things to too many people. Romanticism and Classicism, for instance, are drugs upon which one can develop a dependency, since they generally serve to dull thought. The finer one's ability to detect distinctions in style and substance between, say, Berlioz and Mozart, the less need there is for reliance on the methadone of such Brand concepts.

title: Lindsay Shore Bride of A. E. Ulmann Jr.
description: Lindsay Shore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sig Shore of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Alexander E. Ulmann Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ulmann of New York. The Rev. William Nagle performed the ceremony in St. John's Roman Catholic Church.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Study Says 77% in Unions Own Their Homes
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4A survey by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organization has found home ownership more extensive among union members than is the average for American households.

title: Economic Studies, a Growth Industry
description: Higher prices and jobs hardertocomeby have made economics a major political issueand principles of economics one of the fastest growing areas of student and professorial concern.

title: Ford's Son, 23, Says He Smoked Marijuana
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 4Jack Ford, the President's 23yearold son, was reported today as saying that he had smoked marijuana and believed the law should treat the substance as it does beer and wine.

title: The Cameraman Comes Out of the Ocean, See?
description: From the beach at San Clemente, the Nixon compou?? was barely visible on top of a steep bluff shaded by cyprus trees. More evident were the surveillance cameras and searchlights, tucked among the branches like bird nests.

title: Prices on London's Fine Old Homes Plummet, Victims of Inflation, Recession and New Tax Regulations
description: LONDON, Oct. 4A few years ago the practice of accepting a prospective buyer's bid and then playing it off against a previous bidder flourished in London, making housing here among the most expensive in the world. But now the practice is dead.

title: News of The Realty Trade
description: The NCR Corporation will more than double its space at Rockefeller Center as a result of a lease it has signed for more than 30,000 square feet of office space for about 19 years at an approximate aggregate rent of $6million.

title: Margaret Hamilton Is Married To Jesse Davidson Saunders
description: Margaret Dorrance Hamilton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel M. V. Hamilton of Wayne, Pa., was married yesterday to Jesse Davidson Saunders, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart T. Saunders of Richmond.

title: Chapin Rustic Retreat Was Family Endeavor
description: BYRAMInstead of hiring a builder, the Chapin brothers have made the completion of their rustic retreat here a family project.

title: BYRNE SCORES FORD FOR JOBLESS RATE
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., Oct. 4. (UPI)Governor Byrne today criticized the Ford Administration for allegedly failing to improve the nation's job market.

title: Ernest & Scott In Paris
description: [Fitzgerald] asked me why liked this cafe [the Closerie des Lilas] and I told him about it in the old days and he began to try to like it too and we sat there, me liking it and he dying to like it, and . . . he fold me that he and Zelda, his wife, had been compelled to abandon their small Renault motor car M Lyon because of bad weather and he asked me if I would go down to Lyon with him on the train to pick up the car and drive up with him to Paris.

title: As a Source Of Energy, The Sun Has Drawbacks
description: WASHINGTONImagine a President peering sincerely into a television camera and intoning: My fellow citizens, I am happy to be able to report to you tonight an important breakthrough in our drive for energy independence for the United States. We have discovered a source of energy that is infinitely abundant and is found throughout the land. It is clean energy that will not contaminate our air or water or create dangerous residues. Nor does it require deep holes in the ground, the stripping of prairies or mountains or the construction of huge processing plants.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: The Romantic Revival has been with us a while now. We've reclaimed Liszt, which was necessary, and discovered Alkan, which was fun. A lot of unimportant pianists, sometimes accompanied by unimportant orchestras, have made diverting, disposable records of unimportant music, most of it going chiefly to show that there are only two directions in which a figuration, or an arpeggio, no matter how ingeniously stretched across the keyboard, can go up and down.

title: Kurt Hopwood Marries Pamela Morey
description: Pamela Aileen Morey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry William Morey Jr. of Weston, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Kurt Franz Hopwood, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stafford L. Hopwood of Stamford, Conn.

title: Monroe Is Defeated By Evander, 266
description: Evander defeated Monroe yesterday, 266, behind the running of Mike Forsett and the tackling of Sal Ficarotta in a nonleague game at Evander. Forsett, a senior tailback, ran 10 times for 182 yards and two touchdowns in contributing to Evander's 360 yards of offense. Ficarotta led a defense that scored four sacks and held punchless Monroe to five first downs. Ficarotta had 13 unassisted tackles. Evander is 11 and Monroe 02.

title: Helen Danforth Jackson Betrothed
description: Helene Danforth Jackson of Carversville, Pa., and Amagansett, L. I., and Winfield Scott Magill of New Hope, Pa., plan to be married next Saturday in East Hampton. L. I.

title: Black Broker
description: Daniel & Bell, Inc., a small brokerage firm that made it's mark on the Big Board four years ago when it became the first blackowned concern to join the 183yearold New York Stock Exchange, has expanded its horizons.

title: Theater Gets a New 'J.J.
description: UNION  The J. J. strolling through Shubert Alley in Manhattan last week bore little resemblance to J. J. Shubert, the theatrical empirebuilder who once frequented that tiny Broadway thqroughfare. Nor would he want to, it seems.

title: State Home Construction Off Despite Summer Rebound
description: TRENTONDespite a rebound in homeconstruction activity during the summer, the statewide figures on new dwellings authorized this year are running far behind thpse of 1974, which were the lowest in a generation.

title: Jersey Consumer Notes
description: The State Board of Medical Examiners said that beginning last year there had been a sharp rise in the number of physicians whose medical licenses to practice in New Jersey had been permanently or temporarily taken away.

title: Red Baron, a Lakeland, Captures Terrier Show
description: AMBLER, Pa., Oct. 5Ch. JoNi's Red Baron of Crofton finally made it at Montgomery County, the allterrier show that drew a record field of 1,285 to the Temple University Music Festival grounds today.

title: 100th Computer Switchboard For LongDistance Calls Opens
description: Long distance calls from more than half the nation's 115 million Bell System telephones now are assisted by operators using a littleknown type of electronic switchboard that was installed first in Morristown, N. J., in January, 1969.

title: Former Professor Holds Seminars For President and His Top Advisers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 Robert A. Goldwin describes himself as a teacher with a vocation for bringing men of affairs and thinkers togethers in useful discussions of broad public issues. It takes a special tact and talent, he explains in patient, teacherly fashion, to find the chemistry of persons, topic and atmosphere that turns such gatherings into real encounters.

title: Inmates Win Chance to Contest Federal Special Offender Status
description: Federal prisoners are entitled to a hearing before they can be classified as special offenders and deprived of prison privileges, according to a decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Forums of Justice
description: In setting up new standards for more rapid disposition of criminal cases, family court proceedings and civil actions, the administrative board for the New York State court system has put judges, attorneys and litigants on notice that endless delays will no longer be tolerated. if timetables are met, courts in the city and state will attain the level of speedy trial and disposition of cases generally prevailing in the Federal courts.

title: Simon Proposals for City Puzzle and Please Officials
description: State and city elected officials expressed some puzzlement and some pleasure yesterday over Treasury Secretary William E. Simon's threestep plan to extricate New York City from a fiscal morass and the threat of default.

title: SISTER OF KENNEDY DISAPPEARS BRIEFLY
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP) The mentally retarded sister of Senator Edward M. Kennedy wandered away from a morning church service today and was found walking down the street looking in the windows five hours later.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Pursuant to a column here that recently outlined a recipe for French potato pancakes, we received a note from Pauline Gleichenhaus of the Bronx enclosing her favorite recipe for the dish, one which she says she has used for more years than I care to remember.

title: SYNTHESIZER GROUP AT WBAI'S STUDIO C
description: Mother Mallard's Portable Masterpiece Company's appearance at the season's opening night program of WBAI's Free Music Store (Studio C, 359 East 62d Street) on Saturday once again proves the point that synthesizers are not the dehumanizing machines or instruments that their detractors contend. They are, in fact, capable of reflecting an individual's perspective.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5The Central Intelligence Agency made actual attempts to kill Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba in the Administrations of three Presidents, Senator Frank Church said today.

title: Money for the Arts
description: AUSTIN, Tex.The arts are flourishing in this country. There is no crisis in the arts. There is a money crisisa big difference. In 1965, the National Endowment for the Arts functioned with a $2.5million budget. Ten years later we have a $75million budget. We cannot be complacent or satisfied, because there are a great many cities in this country that don't give one nickel toward their own cultural institutions. The arts are still considered a dispensable luxury.

title: 26 Killed in Attack On Argentine Post; Rebels Hijack Jet
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 5At least 26 people were killed tonight when leftist guerrillas attacked an army regimental headquarters in the northern Argentine city of Formosa, army headquarters announced.

title: Socialists Win Austrian Vote, Gaining a Seat in Parliament
description: VIENNA, Monday, Oct. 6Austrian voters apparently increased the majority of Chancellor Bruno Kreisky's Socialist party in parliamentary elections yesterday.

title: I.R.S. IN SETTLEMENT OF ILLINOIS ESTATE
description: VIENNA, Ill., Oct. 5 (UPI)The job of unsnarling the estate of Paul Powell, former Illinois secretary of state, is nearing completion after a settlement of Internal Revenue Service claims against it.

title: When Britain Needed Oil, America's Hamilton Brothers Found It
description: DENVEROn the wall of his spacious office looking out over downtown Denver and the front range of the Rocky Mountains, Frederic C. Hamilton has a triptych of framed photographs. The earliest, dated 1930, shows two tots carrying a water bucket near a natural gas pipeline in Illinois. The second, dated 1949, shows two strapping young men in front of an oil rig in Texas. The third, dated 1970, shows the same two, now dressed in mature business suits, looking properous.

title: RAYMOND JOHNSON AND COMPANY DANCE
description: Raymond Johnson's penchant for humor is a ray of light in the drear landscape of much concert dance. He has a natural gift for the throwaway gesture, the resigned glance and other essential tools of the humorist's trade. His company is absorbing his expert timing, and a concert Saturday evening at Brooklyn College was a lively demonstration of witty observation.

title: About New York: House Seats for a BigCast Show
description: The freedom of peaceable assembly is not only a right but it is also a pleasure, and New Yorkers have alwkys been among the best assemblers there are.

title: Reagan Due To Press Bid In This Area
description: Ronald Reagan, who is expected to announce his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination within the month, will make three major appearances in the metropolitan area  Vice President Rockeller's turf  later this month. The Cali fornian, who is viewed as a potential challenger to Mr. Rockefeller if his Presidential quest does not succeed, will be the principal speaker at the Conservative party state dinner at the Americana Hotel on Oct. 20 and the Suffolk Republican organization dinner in Hauppauge on Oct. 22. These appearances will sandwich a speaking engagement at Yale University, Oct. 21.

title: Jersey Symphony Union Rejects OneYear Contract
description: NEWARK, Oct. 5Members of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra voted yesterday to reject a oneyear contract offered by management. The vote, by members of Local 16 of the American Federation of Musicians was 51 to 11.

title: ROCKEFELLER ASKS CONGRESS WEIGH SOME AID TO CITY
description: Vice President Rockefeller says that Congress should consider whether there should be some temporary Federal help for New York City. He says this should be considered after the city acts to restore fiscal integrity by moving, to balance its budget and trim its $3billion shortterm debt.

description: Partial first of scheduled meetings fee week fol lows:

title: TV Review
description: Public TV's In Performance at Wolf Trap series and the AtlanticRichfield Company, series underwriter, recognize a perfect opening when they get one. Last year tree series, recorded in the giant openair arena outside Washington, began with Beverly Sills in The Daughter of the Regiment. This season, in fact tonight at 8, it begins with Beverly Sills in Roberto Devereux.

title: Nadjari Beset by Problems In His Fight on Corruption
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, has reluctantly abandoned a novel kind of undercover work that he says is essential to prosecutirig corrupt judges and that his critics say is illegal.

title: Bonn Has Been Secretly Paying Since '61 For Thousands to Leave East Germany
description: BONN, Oct. 5  Two buses carrying 82 prisoners from East German jails arrived recently at the West German border in the Thuringian hills at Wartha. A police escort left the convoy before the final fivemile passage to the heavily guarded customs and police checkpoint next to the railroad track. A few minutes later the group was in Herleshausen, in the West, and on its way to freedom.

title: Sri Lanka Leader Plays Her Strong Card
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Sept. 30 The anniversary of the assassination of Prime Minister S.W.R.D. Bandaranaike is normally an occasion of mourning and prayer In Sri Lanka.

title: Going for Broke . . .
description: President Ford continues to grease the skids for a default by New York City, as though such an unprecedented disaster would not involve other cities or the nation's shaky recovery. But the warning of Chairman Burns of the Federal Reserve Board that a default by New York City could injure the recovery mayeven at this late hourhelp restore some sense of economic reality and apprehension to an Administration that has been playing the most irresponsible politics with the city's fate.

title: Catholic School Students Find Strike Can Be Boring

description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Ballet: Jeu de Cartes
description: Igor Stravinsky's ballet Jeu de Cartes was one of the very few works the composer actualy composed for his longtime collaborator, George Baanchine. Ironically, it failed dismally. Called various names, it was last revived in 1951, as Card Game, by New York City Ballet, and it was pretty much a disaster. Perhaps Mr. Balanchine never really understood poker, on which the ballet is based.

title: Music: A Goode Recital
description: All serious pianists play Beethoven's Hammerklavier Sonata. Some even play it in public. And a few grand masters of the keyboard reach the point where they are able to transcend the work's technical demands and make it a musical experience. For the most part, Richard Goode's performance at Hunter College yesterday afternoon was strong enough to put him in the company of the blessed few.

title: HARVEST IN SOVIET MAY DROP FURTHER
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 5 (Reuters) Fears that this year's Soviet grain harvest will be one of the worst in this decade appear to be confirmed by official indications that production in the vital Ukrainian lands will fall below expectations.

title: Doctor Tests State Law by Arranging Adoption of Patients' Unwanted Babies
description: HACKENSACK, Oct. 5A prominent New Jersey physician who successfully challenged the state's antiabortion laws is now the target of a Bergen County grand jury investigation into charges that he is illegally arranging the adoption of unwanted babies that he delivers.

title: The Theater: CSC and Shakespeare
description: In the theater, growth is everything. Institutions are always either on their way up or on their way down. It is one of those life patterns that everyone notices, but few people want to talk about. The CSC Repertory has been around for eight years. It has infested lofts and basements, and once found a home in a shoe factory. The shoes had left.

title: ABC CHIEF SCORES CUTS IN TV SERIES
description: The swift cancellation of television series by NBCTV this fall was deplored by a competitor, Frederick S. Pierce, president of ABC Television, as unfair to the people producing the shows and performing in them.

And so does Judy O'Neil of the White House staff, Alger Hiss and Alexander Gerschenkron and Georges Simenon. Likewise Charles Silberman and Matthew J. Bruccoli, the writers, and Dennis Potvin, the hockey star for the Islanders, and Representative Millicent Fenwick. Sherlock Holmes also was famous for it.

description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 5  Northern Ireland, locked in a spiral of terrorist violence, is facing a constitutional crisis over the role of the Roman Catholic minority in future governments.

title: Victor Muscat Dies at Age of 56; Led Fifth Avenue Coach Lines
description: Victor Muscat, an unpredictable businessman who once headed a financial empire with controlling or large interests in 28 companies, including four banks, six steel concerns and five bus companies, died yesterday of a heart attack in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 56 years old.

title: Herbert W. Christenberry Dead; U.S. Judge in New Orleans, 77
description: KENTWOOD, La., Oct. 5 (UPI) United States District Judge Herbert W. Christenberry of New Orleans died of a heart attack today while en route to Jackson, Miss., on court business. He was 77 years old.

title: Pathet Lao, After Closing U.S. Unit, Is Reported Angry at Ending of Aid
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 1The Communistled Pathet Lao, having seized and closed the once vast United States aid mission here during the summer, is now reportedly angry with the United States for having cut off further economic assistance, including a promised $5million contribution to a large dam project.

title: Hirohito Waited for Another Touchdown
description: In about two hours, Hirohito, the Emperor of Japan, would be scouting the New York Jets and the New England Patriots as potential sumo wrestlers. But now in the elevator ascending to the Diamond Club at Shea Stadium, Pete Rozelle, the Czar of Pigskin, was discussing with Howard Cosell, the Vicar of Vitriol and Variety, the protocol of the occasion.

title: Friendship Sail Goes To Recluta
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 5  The Stamford Denmark Friendship sailing race, which has grown from a fleet of 23 cruising yachts, celebrated its 10th anniversary today with a record fleet of 206 on Long Island Sound.

title: Ranger Pride Beats Islanders
description: UNIONDALE, LI., Oct. 5A victory in the exhibition season does not count for much, but the New York Rangers' 21 victory over the New York Islanders tonight in Nassau Coliseum was worth something to them. The previous time the clubs met was last April, when the Islanders knocked the Rangers out of the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: Hanoi Premier Predicts Unification in Short Time
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 5 (Agence FrancePresse) North and South Vietnam will become a single country officitlly in a short time, Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam was quoted as having said in a report published here today.

title: F.B.I. Checking of Radicals Vent On Beyond Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5The Federal Bureau of Investigation continued to employ at least one of the techniques that characterized a controversial counterintelligence operation for two and a half years after April, 1971, the date the bureau gave for formally terminating the program, according to previously classified documents made public today.

title: Books of The Times
description: The world loves a winner, and so sometimes do the Japanese, observes Ivan Morris, professor of Japanese at Columbia University, in the introduction to this unusual historical survey. But: There is another type of hero in the complex Japanese tradition, a man whose career usually belongs to a period of unrest and warfare and represents the very antithesis of an ethos of accomplishment. He is the man whose singleminded sincerity will not allow him to make the maneuvers and compromises that are so often needed for mundane success. During the early years his courage and verve may propel him rapidly upwards, but he is wedded to the losing side and will ineluctably be cast down. Flinging himself after his painful destiny, he defies the dictates of convention and common sense, until eventually he is worsted by his enemy, the successful survivor, who by his ruthlessly realistic politics manages to impose a new, more stable order on the world. Faced with defeat, the hero will typically take his cwn life in order to avoid the indignity of capture, vindicate his honor and make a final assertion of his sincerity. His death is no temporary setback which will he redeemed by his followers, but represents an irrevocable collapse of the cause he has championed: in practical terms the struggle has been useless and, in many instances, counterproductive.

title: Bridge:
description: The annual experts invitation night at the Harmonie Club here Thursday produced an interesting problem and a curious puzzle. The problem relates to the diagramed deal from the event: Can NorthSouth make a game against best defense, and if so in which denomination?

title: Observation Shows WorkRule Abuses By Sanitationmen
description: Despite a major effort by Mayor Beame to improve the Sanitation Department, widespread abuse of work rules continues to waste countless manhours, cost the city millions of dollars and leave streets in Manhattan needlessly dirty.

title: Sox, Reds Triumph; Jets Win,Giants Lose
description: The Boston Red Sox and the Cincinnati Reds took 20 leads in baseball's league championship playoffs yesterday. The Red Sox rallied to defeat the Oakland A's, 63, in Boston as Carl Yastrzemski and Rico Petrocelli hit home runs. The Reds downed the Pittsburgh Pirates, 61, in Cincinnati with the aid of seven stolen bases.

title: Adoption Law in Jersey Is Challenged by Doctor
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Oct. 5A prominent New Jersey physician who successfully challenged the state's antiabortion laws is now the target of a Bergen County grand jury investigation into charges that he is illegally arranging the adoption of unwanted babies that he delivers.

title: Petty Outspeeds Pearson In Close 500Mile Race
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 5 (AP)Richard Petty beat David Pearson by an eyelash today in winning the National 500 stock car race for his second straight victory at what was once called his iinx track.

title: Jets Wallop Patriots by 367
description: Coolly, with the arrogance of a card player who knows everyone's hand, Joe Namath directed the Jets' offense to a crushing 367 victory over the New England Patriots yesterday.

title: Genetic Quandary
description: In no area of medicine has the research information explosion been more voluminous than the field of genetic diseases. These ailments are either transmitted from generation to generation through the parents' genes, like hemophilia, or  like mongolism  caused by an unexplained chromosomal defect in the mother's fertilized egg. More than 2,000 genetic diseases are now known, and more are discovered every year, some of them defects afflicting only a small number of people. Thus the Joseph family disease publicized recently is known affect only descendants of a Portuguese sailor who jumped ship in San Francisco in 1845.

title: PATRIOTS RALLY TO BESIEGED SPAIN
description: MADRID, Oct. 5Ascensin Lopesino Alvarez, 50 years old, has been beaten, fined, imprisoned and indicted for aiding subversion because she objected to a group of young demonstrators roaming the streets after a rally in support of Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

title: Polkas, Bands and Floats Spell Pulaski Day Here
description: Somber World War II veterans in faded uniforms with red Poland shoulder patches marched amid swirling dancers, polka bands and briskly stepping fifeanddrum corps yesterday at the 39th annual Pulaski Day parade.

title: Hospitals Must Post Notices
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UPI) The 6,000 hospitals and nursing homes receiving Federal HillBurton construction funds must begin posting notices that charity care is available, the Department of Health. Education and Welfare said today. The notices must be written in appropriate languages and should advise lowincome patients that they may apply for free care, the agency said.

title: U.S. Geological Survey Studies Coal Resources
description: WASHINGON, Oct. 5 (UPI)  The United States has 23 per cent more coal resources than perviously thought, according to a new estimate issued today by the United States Geological Survey.

title: U.S. Oil Technicians Arrive To Assist Transfer in Sinai
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 5Three American oil technicians arrived at Sudr in Israelioccupied territory on the Gulf of Suez today to inspect installations in the oilfield there in preparation for the return of the field to Egypt under the interim accord on Sinai.

title: Marjorie Margolies of NBC Wed to Rep. Edward Mezvinsky
description: Marjorie Sue Margolies, a reporter with NBC News in Washington, was married yesterday afternoon to Rep. Edward Mezvinsky, Democrat of Iowa. Rabbi Alan Fuchs performed the ceremony in Trappe, Md., at Martin's Point Farm, which Mr. Mezvinsky used this past summer as a country retreat.

title: Memorial Services
description: HARROWERGordon. Memorial service Oct. 7 at 2:30 P.M., St. James Church, Madison Ave and 71st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Gordon Harrower Memorial Fund, DayKimball Hospital, Putnam, Conn.

title: Colorado's Coach Defends Try for a Tie
description: A reckless, gambling approach enabled previously unbeaten Colorado to get within one play of ending Oklahoma's winning streak, the longest in the nation, on Saturday. Then, with 79 seconds to go, the Buffaloes' coach, Bill Mallory, turned conservative and Colorado lost the big opportunity for an upset and the game as well, 2120, as Oklahoma increased its victory streak to 24 games.

title: Screen: British 'Conduct Unbecoming':Film of the Hit Play Is Taut and Polished Army Officer Is Tried in Victorian India
description: Like some wines, "Conduct Unbecoming" travels well. Barry England's play about a messy officers' mess in Victorian India was a hit in London before landing on Broadway five years ago, and it has lost none of its flavor in the British-made movie that opened yesterday at the Baronet. Dealing with a scandalous mystery exposed in a trial at a frontier army post, it is largely a suspenseful period piece that lovingly recalls and jibes at Hollywood's India as seen in the likes of "Lives of a Bengal Lancer."Michael Anderson, the director ("Around the World in 80 Days," etc.), shot "Conduct" in Pakistan with enough scarlet-coated officers and mountainous backgrounds to satisfy the "Lancer" fans. But the play and Robert Enders's devoted adaptation are concerned mostly with dissecting officers who are not precisely gentlemen and their shibboleths of regimental pomp, ceremony and special codes of honor.A newly arrived junior officer is accused of assaulting the pretty, flirtatious widow of the regiment's revered hero. The kangaroo tribunal wants to get the beastly matter over with quickly. The officer an dthe callow subaltern directed to defend him have inherited regimental traditions as sons of illustrious officers. But there's a twist. The accused has never wanted any part of either defending the empire or army traditions, while his timorous but tenacious advocate sees them as shining ideals.Of course, his persistent investigation reveals more than the innocence of his client and the actual culprit. It projects some expert play acting that shatters those ideals. Yet it still clings affectionately to the colorful, if old-fashioned, views of the pig-sticking, drinking (but very proper) thin red line of resolute cavaliers who held those rebel tribesmen off at the Khyber Pass in 1878.Michael York is genuinely appealing as the indomitable defender torn between his "bourgeois principles" of honor and integrity and the hollow men he sees mocking them. James Faulkner is properly cynical as the innocent defendant, and Susannah York is decorative and distraught as the allegedly wronged woman.As the sole American in the cast, Stacy Keach is convincingly British in a strong stint as the trial's presiding adjutant, whose rigid beliefs are changed by the evidence. Trevor Howard, as the bewhiskered, beloved colonel determined to maintain the honor of the regiment he is soon to leave, and Christopher Plummer and Richard Attenborough, as senior officers contributing to its dishonor, effectively delineate both the hypocrisy and the fierce pride of their lite group.In a nuclear age, "Conduct Unbecoming" may seem a somewhat quaint view of a romantic past. But its taut construction, mounting tension and polished performances make for a fascinating entertainment.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Lisbon Extremists Mob Socialist Chief
description: LISBON, Oct. 5 (Reuters)Angry leftists shouting Fascist! and Assassin! today mobbed Mario Soares, leader of the Socialist party, despite an appeal from President Francisco da Costa Games for order and discipline.

title: Article 2  No Title
Observation Shows WorkRule Abuses By Sanitationmen
description: Despite a major effort by Mayor Beame to improve the Sanitation Department, widespread abuse of work rules continues to waste countless manhours, cost the city millions of dollars and leave streets in Manhattan needlessly dirty.

title: Texas Impeachment Trial
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 5 (AP)The Senate convenes tomorrow for the first impeachment trial in Texas in 44 years. It will sit as a jury for District Judge O. P. Carrillo, who was convicted on Income tax charges by a Federal jury Thursday.

title: Olav V Responds With Handshakes After a Greeting Here Fit for a King
description: King Olav V of Norway blew out 150 candles and charmed hundreds of NorwegianAmericans at a church coffee hour yesterday by asking to shake hands with every one of them.

title: Voters in Austria Return Socialists With Gain of Seat
description: VIENNA, Monday, Oct. 6Austrian voters apparently increased the majority of Chancellor Bruno Kreisky's Socialist party in parliamentary elections yesterday.

title: U.N. Lament: Partying Is Relentless
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 5Delegates from a number of countries flew to Vermont in a charter plane over the weekend for a glimpse of New England in the fall, others were stewing in saunas here to get the toxins of too much diplomatic conviviality out of their systems, and a European ambassador said ruefully: In four years in New. York I haven't yet managed to visit Brooklyn.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EYEFUL Not everyone knows much about Gustave Eiffel, creator of the Eiffel Tower, one of the most famed manmade structures and the symbol of Paris. With his bestknown work, built for an 1889 exposition, at the center, a retrospective exhibition paying homage to the French engineer, who died in 1923, goes on view today through Oct. 30 at the French Institute / Alliance Franaise Gallery, 22 East 60th Street.

title: Boston Rally Downs A's, 63
description: BOSTON, Oct. 5  The scrappy Boston Red Sox shoved the Oakland A's within one step of extinction today with a 63 victory, and Reggie Jackson summed up the game briefly but significantly.

title: Don't Mine Death Valley
description: As surprising as it may seem, open pit mining may soon begin to desecrate one of the most scenic and popular parts of Death Valley National Monument California. The Interior Department has ruled that the National Park Service is powerless to prevent the private exploitation of this extremely fragile desert landscape.

title: CITY RESTORATION FACING CUTBACKS
description: Many of the city's key preservation projects for Lower Manhattan are being jeopardized by the fiscal crisis.

title: Kansas City Ousts 59 Striking Firemen For Refusing Work
description: KANSAS CITY. Oct. 5 (AP)City officials began to dismiss striking firemen tonight, discharging 59 of the 1858member force who did not respond to telegrams ordering them to work. A wave of fires, some suspicious, continued.

title: Moreland Hearing On Financing Units Calls Rockefeller
description: Vice President Rockefeller and former Attorney General John N. Mitchell are among those scheduled to testify at hearings into financial problems of the Urban Development Corporation and other state financing agencies.

title: Winnipeg Triumphs
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 5 (AP)Tom Scott caught a pair of touchdown passes from Ralph Brock today as the Winnipeg Blue Bombers topped the Montreal Alouettes, 2621, in a Canadian Football League game.

title: ROCKEFELLER ASKS CONGRESS WEIGH SOME AID TO CITY
description: Vice President Rockefeller says that Congress should consider whether there should be some temporary Federal help for New York City. He says this should be considered after the city acts to restore fiscal integrity by moving to balance its budget and trim its $3billion shortterm debt.

title: Louisville Man on Bond
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 5 (AP)  A man who allegedly fired a gun at a crowd of antibusing demonstrators last night has been freed on bond. The authorities identified him ?? Edmund L. Drake, 31 years old, of eastern Jefferson County.

title: Coast Woman, 27, Mistreated and Forced to Take Part in Bank Robbery, Is Serving a 30Month Term
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5The story of a young woman who was held prisoner, mistreated, threatened and forced to take part in a bank robbery rests in the Federal District Court files here.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Preseason Basketball
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Small Investors Bypass Brokers' Plans To Cut Fees, Preferring the Old Ways
description: The small investor may be interested in getting a bargain once in a while, but he apparently is not interested enough to change his way of doing business.

title: Teachers in 2 Cities Prepare to Strike
description: Nearly 1,100 teachers and other school personnel were told by their union to strike the 23 public schools in Elizabeth today as negotiations over a 10 per cent pay increase dragged on yesterday with no signs of progress.

title: 100 in Jewish Protest Seized at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) More theft 100 demonstrators from various Jewish activist organizations were arrested today in front of the White House, a spokesman for the United States Park Police said.

title: Three Children Die With Their Father In Brooklyn Fire
description: A father and his three children died when fire swept their apartment early yesterday in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn.

title: Janice Meryl Sloan Wed to Steven Mann
description: Janice Meryl Sloan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Sloan, was married yesterday afternoon to Steven Jay Mann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Mann. Both families live in East Meadow, L.I., where Rabbi Israel Nobel performed the ceremony in the East Meadow Jewish Center.

title: HIROHITO SAMPLES AMERICAN WAYS
description: Emperor, Hirohito took tea in lacquered cups with Vice President Rockefeller at Mr. Rockefeller's Japanese house in Pocantico Hills yesterday and then savored a different dimension of leisure Americaa raucous football game at Shea Stadium.

title: Malaria Surges in India Despite Vast Drive
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 5  The recent increase in crude oil prices, which is expected to make insecticides more costly, has seriously jeopardized India's chances of controlling a growing epidemic of malaria, according to Indian and World Health Organization experts.

title: Star Appeal, 11 81, Takes Rich 1'Arc
description: PARIS, Oct. 5Traveling has never bothered Star Appeal, and after today his jockey, Graville Starkey, may follow the horse around the world.

title: L.I. Man Dies in Roof Mishap
description: LEVITTOWN, L., I. Oct. 5 (UN)  A 49yearold father of two children was electrocuted this morning as he tried to install a radio antenna on the roof of his home here, the Nassau County Police reported. The victim, Kenneth Bourne of 9 Spool Lane, was installing a citizens band antenna on the roof of his home when the antenna struck some hightension wires overhead killing him instantly, the police said.

title: MARTHA MITCHELL HAS BLOOD DISEASE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UPI) Martha Mitchell is suffering from a blood cell disorder and is undergoing treatment at Northern Virginia Doctor's Hospital.

title: Dr. Hicks Bride Of J.S. Wulach
description: Dr. Sandra Jana Hicks, a resident in psychiatry at St. Luke's Hospital here, was married yesterday afternoon to James Stephen Wulach, a doctoral candidate in psychology at City College.

title: Miller Tube Mill to Shut
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 5 (AP)The Miller Company weld tube mill, which employs, 44 persons, plans to halt operations Oct. 24 because of decreased business, a company official said today.

title: Advertising
description: Bob Marker, after a shortlived newspaper career in Dallas, is back in town and back in the agency business at a high level.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Meter Maids Decry Assaults on Ranks By Irate Motorists
description: They ere kicked and spat upon. They are yelled at, cursed and sometimes slugged, all in the course of their business. They are possibly the city's roost unpopular public servants, the parking enforcement agents, colloquially known as meter maids, even though there are men among their ranks.

title: Squires' Calvin Out
description: HAMPTON, Va., Oct. 5 (AP)Mack Calvin, the allstar guard obtained by the Virginia Squires in an American Basketball Association trade earlier this year, will be out of action for two months because he tore a tendon in his left knee last night in an exhibition game.

title: Leaders of Organized Labor Convene to Hear Pro Forma Speeches About Predictable Resolutions
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5In the midst of the nation's gravest economic crisis since the nineteenthirties, organized labor is meeting here without any new program and without any sense of urgency about finding one.

title: Palestinian Issue
description: The Foreign Minister of Israel, Yigal Allon, has now opened the door to a discussionwhich his Government tried for many years to avoidover the status and aspirations of the Palestinian Arabs. His address to the United Nations General Assembly contained some welltimed remarks that need to be followed up.

title: Simpson Runs Season Total to 538 Yards as Bills Win, 3814
description: Buffalo turned The Juice, O. J. Simpson, loose again yesterday, and he became the first National Football League player to gain more than 500 yards rushing through three consecutive games as the Bills routed the visiting Denver Broncos in Rich Stadium, 3814. Simpson gained 138 yards to go with the 400 yards rushing in his two previous games.

title: ANALYSTS BULLISH ON BOND MARKETS
description: Many Wall Street analysts expect the government and corporate bond markets to improve sharply in the next few weeks after months of sliding prices.

title: ...In the Nation, Too
description: While that close scrutiny is going on, it might as well be enlarged to take in the rest of the nation. A New York City default would deal a heavy blow to the ability of cities throughout the nation to borrow and would give another upward push to interest rates. Some wishful thinkers contend that the municipal bond market has already discounted the impact of a New York City default, but this is almost surely wrong. How could an uncertain event be fully discounted? There has, to be sure, been a drop in municipal bond prices and a rise in interest rates, as a result of speculation that New York City might defaultbut there have been those willing to speculate that New York would make it well as those speculating that it would not. Actual default by the nation's largest city would strike a second blow at the value of New York's and other cities and states' securities and borrowing costs.

title: Union Chief Has Key Stake in British WagePolicy
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 3This city is Britain's Coney Island, only more depressing, especially when the wind howls in off the Irish Sea, and sullen parents tug crying children along the garish boardwalk, thinking morosely that once again they have forfeited a cheerful vacation in June for the cheaper hotel rates of October.

title: St. Francis Trounces Spellman
description: St. Francis Prep failed to win the Catholic Schools Football League title last season after two consecutive titles, but with two victories in two games this season, it seems the Little Terriers have no intention of missing out again.

title: 3 Spanish Civil Guards Slain In Bomb Attack in Basque Area
description: MADRID, Oct. 5Three civil guards were killed and two were badly injured today when their LandRover was blown up near the Basque town of Aranzazu.

title: Bales of Marijuana Seized
description: FALL RIVER CITY, Kan., Oct. 5 (UPI)  A ranch with almost seven acres of planted marijuana plants and seven bales of the processed weed was raided yesterday in what Kansas authorities say is the biggest such arrest in the state. Greenwood County Sheriff Charlie Samuels said six persons were arrested, including four illegal aliens.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS LEADER WINS AWARD HERE
description: Lucille Rose, the head of New York City's Department of Employment and a civil righs leader, was cited yesterday by a major national Orthodox Jewish organization for her programs to alleviate the plight of the economically disadvantaged among various ethnic groups.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Representative Joseph G. Minish, Democrat of West Orange, says he will start an investigation this week into activities of the Unification Church, whose members allegedly assaulted State Insurance Commissioner James Sheeran. The Congressman said that his investigation was designed to determine if a fullscale Congressional inquiry was necessary into the Christian sect founded by Sun Myung Moon, Korean evangelist. The church members allegedly attacked Mr. Sheeran last Aug. 28 when he tried to take three of his daughters home from the church center in Barrytown, N. Y. Mr. Minish said he would also investigate reports that Mr. Moon's followers were selling flowers, peanuts and candies on street corners but were not receiving decent wages. The Congressman said there could be an alleged violation of the Federal minimum wage law.

title: 1,900YearOld City Unearthed in Yugoslavia May Produce Data on the Huns
description: SENTA, YugoslaviaA dam project here has unearthed the remains of a 1,900yearold city that may yield important discoveries about the Sarmatians, Huns and other predatory neighbors of the Roman Empire.

title: Miss Hearst Called Erratic
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5 (UPI)While psychiatrists put the finishing touches on their report on whether Miss Hearst was mentally competent to stand trial on armed bank robbery charges, one of her attorneys said today that she was so erratic at times that she has absolutely no interest in her fate.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: F.T.C. and Peoples Drug In Consent Order on Leases
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission issued a consent order today prohibiting Peoples Drug Stores, Inc., one of the largest drugstore chains in the East, from signing anticompetitive shopping center leases.

title: Nadjari Beset by Problems In His Fight on Corruption
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor has reluctantly abandoned a novel kind of undercover work that he says is essential to prosecuting corrupt judges and that his critics say is illegal.

title: SOLIAHS' FATHER GAYE F.B.I. A TIP
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5 (AP)The father of a 27yearold housepainter charged with harboring Patricia Hearst in San Francisco says it was information from him that put the Federal Bureau of Investigation on the trail that led to the fugitives.

title: Lisbon Tries to Turn Attention to Economic Crisis
description: LISBON, Oct. 5  Foreign Minister Ernesto Melo Antunes took off today for talks with the Common Market in hope of getting emergency aid for the Portuguese economy. Before leaving he said that he thought the situation had finally settled down enough here to make it possible to discuss financial problems.

title: Japanese Beetle, Immune to Insecticides, Is Starting to Make an Unwelcome Comeback
description: NEW HAVENThe Japanese beetle, which came up a loser in one of the early 20thcentury manversusbug battles, is staging a rapid comeback.

title: Americans Have Turned Their Thumbs Up on Hitchhiking Despite Laws and Propaganda Again
description: David Elmendorf has two cars, his own small business and enough money to buy gasoline even at today's prices. But there he was in the California sun, standing alongside the Pacific Coast Highway at Malibu, his thumb in the air and San Francisco on his mind.

title: Susan Lager Bride Of Kenneth P. Jaffe
description: Susan Jill Lager, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Lager of Atlantic Beach, L. I., was married there yesterday afternoon to Kenneth Peter Jaffe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Jaffe of Stamford, Conn. The ceremony was performed at the Lager home by Rabbi Sol Roth of the Atlantic Beach Jewish Center.

title: A CITY PLANS CODE TO SAVE ENERGY
description: DAVIS, Calif., Oct. 5The Davis City Council is ready to approve a novel building code that is designed to save the owners of new homes close to 50 per cent on their heating and cooling bills.

title: About New York: House Seats for a BigCast Show
description: The freedom of peaceable assembly is not only a right but it is also a pleasure, and New Yorkers have alwkys been among the best assemblers there are.

title: At Last, Seedy Oakland Has 3 Reasons to Cheer
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 5When the earthquake of 1906 struck northern California, it virtually destroyed the city of San Francisco. But here across the bay in Oakland its deadly tremors were hardly felt.

title: Mrs. Rice's Proud Delta Triumphs
description: A crowd of 24,860 at Belmont Park saw what probably was the last race of the prominent Rice Stable yesterday. And it was a winner for the stable as Ada L. Rice's Proud Delta triumphed in the $46,275 Suffolk County Handicap.

title: F.B.I. Checking of Radicals Went On Beyond Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5The Federal Bureau of Investigation continued to employ at least one of the techniques that characterized a controversial counterintelligence operation for two and a half years after April, 1971, the date the bureau gave for formally terminating the program, according to previously classified documents made public today.

title: Facts in Musicians' Strike
description: Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, representing 300 members of the theater department. Max Arons, president. L Philip Sipser, special counsel to the theater department.

title: Personal Finance: Singles Estate Plans
description: Most professional estateplanning analyses concentrate on the problems normally faced by married persons. But single individuals, particularly working women, are likely to encounter special difficulties in developing estate plans.

title: HIROHITO SAMPLES AMERICAN WAYS
description: Emperor Hirohito took tea in lacquered cups with Vice President Rockefeller at Mr. Rockefeller's Japanese house in Pocantico Hills yesterday and then savored a different dimension of leisure Americaa raucous football game at Shea Stadium.

title: Amin Called Surprised At Moynihan Criticism
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Oct. 5 (AP)President Idi Amin of Uganda said today that he was surprised that Daniel P. Moynihan, the United States delegate at the United Nations, had endorsed a characterization of President Amin as a racist murderer.

title: For Which We Stand: III
description: BOSTON, Oct. 5A leading Soviet authority on American affairs, Georgi A. Arbatov, recently deplored violations of human rights in the United States. He told the readers of Izvestia that Americans suffer such abuses as wiretapping, the keeping of Government dossiers on individuals and shameful court reprisals against dissidents.

title: ConsumerConfidence Surveys: Economists Turn to Psychology
description: The American consumer, still shaken from years of inflation and high unemployment, holds the key to the current economic recovery. Without a surge in consumer spending which accounts for twothirds of the nation's total output the current recovery could be shortlived, economists fear.

title: Socialist Coalition Sought
description: COLOMBO, Oct. 5 (Reuters) The Lanka Sama Samaja party, which was expelled from the cabinet last month, is hoping to form a socialist united front with leftist elements in Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike's Government.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Prices paid by consumers for food purchased for home consumption in the New Yorknortheastern New Jersey area declined by 0.3 per cent in August, according to Herbert Bienstock, assistant regional director for the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The August decline followed increases of 2.0 per cent in June and 3.0 per cent in July, but was less than seasonally expected.

title: Dodge Estate Auction Starts In Madison Mansion Tomorrow
description: MADISON, Oct. 5 (AP)A collection of items from precicus jewels to junk, amassed over 91 years by the late Ceraldine Rockefeller Dodge, goes on sale this week. It is expected to raise more than $5million most of it for a foundation for dogs.

title: Joan Cooper Married To Walter R. Uhrrnan
description: Joan Cooper, a clinical psychologist, and Walter Richard Uhrman, a professor of theater arts at the State University of New York College at Brockport, were married here yesterday afternoon. Rabbi Fredric S. Dworkin performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. Herman E. Cooper.

title: Israeli Doctors on Strike
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 5 (Reuters)More than 6,000 Israeli physicians went on strike today in protest over the killing of a colleague who was shot by a patient as he examined him.

title: 1775 Quebec Battle Reenacted
description: QUEBEC, Oct. 5American forces attacked Quebec yesterday for the second time in 200 years and lost again, as planned, but this time Canadian crowds applauded the invaders.

title: Ford, in Shift, Supports Aid to Medical Schools
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5At the urging of its new Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, the Ford Administration has agreed to continue to endorse the program to support the operation of medical and dental schools rather than phase it out.

title: Ford Plays a Round of Golf With Some Old Colleagues
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UPI) President Ford played golf today with three old friends from his Congressional daysthe House Republican leader, John J. Rhodes of Arizona, and former Representatives Melvin R. Laird and John Byrnes, both Republicans of Wisconsin.

title: Lauda Wins Grand Prix At The Glen
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Oct. 5Niki Lauda, the world driving champion, won the Grand Prix of the United States today but a record crowd of more than 100,000 at the Glen was deprived of watching the Austrian race. Because of the tactics of a teammate no other driver was able to challenge Lauda in the lead position.

title: U.S. Official Urges Taxing Municipal Bond Interest
description: A high official of the Ford Administration proposed yesterday a change in the tax exempt status of municipal bonds that could lead to a basic restructuring of the nation's system of municipal finance and perhaps help cities raise money.

title: Miss Evert Victor, Hits $300,000
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Oct. 5By beating the almost unknown Cynthia Doerner of Australia, 61, 63, in the final of the $50,000 Mission Viejo tennis tournament, Chris Evert vaulted today into the $300,000 class.

title: Opera: Tales of Debuts
description: Five days after her successful New York City Opera debut as Antonia in Offenbach's Tales of Hoffmann, Clamma Dale made an equally fine impression as Giulietta, the courtesan who captivates the hero in the second act. There is less solo singing to be done here, but the ensemble numbers were nicely balanced, and Miss Dale used her smoky voice and sinuous figure to decidedly sultry advantage.

title: Miller Wins by 3 With 272
description: NAPA, Calif., Oct. 5 (AP) Johnny Miller, pausing to wave to his children at play on the lawn of his golfcourse house, shot a threeunderpar 69 today for a threestroke victory in the Kaiser international open golf tournament.

title: Pilot Dies in Glider Crash
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 5 (AP)A glides crashed in the Pine Cobble Mountain area today, killing the pilot, Roger Halverson, 34 years old, of Mechanicville, N.Y., the police said.

title: Banker Holds Public Opposes Aid to City
description: The majority of the nation's taxpayers do not favor any Federal aid to New York City or any other municipality the presidentelect of the American Bankers Association, J. Rex Duwe suggested yesterday.

title: Giants Beaten, 26 to 14
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 5The New York Giants played football respectably todayin the second half. But the first half was what really counted and the St. Louis Cardinals won that part easily en route to a 2614 victory.

title: Leafs' Ellis Retires
description: TORONTO, Oct. 5 (AP)Ron Ellis, a right wing who played 11 seasons with the Toronto Maple Leafs of the National Hockey League, announced his retirement yesterday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 6, 1975

title: Still True: You Get No Bread With One Meatball
description: WASHINGTONThe doctor at the Veterans Administration responsible for the care provided to over a million patients a year and for the operation of 171 V.A. hospitals is paid a $40,000 Federal salary. A typical neurosurgeon in private practice earns about $70,000, a general practitioner in the Northeast about $45,000.

title: Reds and Red Sox Triumph For 2Advantages in Playoffs
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 5 The running game had a few of its finest hours in baseball history today when the Cincinnati Reds stole seven bases in seven attempts, routed the Pittsburgh Pirates, 61, and moved within one game of the National League pennant.

title: 5 YOUTHS ACCUSED OF ARSON IN BRONX
description: Five Bronx youths, all allegedly members of an arson gang, were arrested yesterday on charges that they had set five fires last week in four tenements in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, the police reported.

title: Skipper, 15, Outruns Adults In Central Park Sailing Race
description: Under a sun that wove in and out of the clouds and in a wind that sometimes blew heartily but more often did not, members of the Central Park Model Yacht Club yesterday took the top 10 spots in a national championship race for the International 10Rater class of model sailboats.

title: Fund Raiser Quits Group Of Rightists
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5In the 16 years since Charles A. McManus founded Americans for Constitutional Action, the organization has helped raise millions of dollars for conservative Republican candidates and has compiled the definitive conservative ratings on House and Senate voting records. But Mr. McManus quit the A.C.A. last weekin total and complete frustration, he said, with the organization's imitators in conservative politics, particularly in the fundraising business.

title: Memorial Services
description: HARROWERGordan. Memorial service Oct. 7 at 7:30 P.M., St. James Church, Madison Ave. and 71st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Gordon Harrower Memorial Fund, DayKimball Hospital, Putnam, Conn.

title: Article 2  No Title
8 JAILED IN BRIBERY IN BUILDING TRADES
description: Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts sentenced one former senior construction inspector in the city's Buildings Department and seven businessmen to jail yesterday, saying that incarceration would serve to deter, if not end, bribery in the buildings industry.

title: GRANT CLOSINGS AND LAYOFFS SET
description: The W. T. Grant Company, now operating under the voluntary Chapter XI proceedings of the Bankruptcy Act, plans to close 225 to 250 stores and discharge about 13,000 persona by Dec. 31, the company disclosed yesterday.

title: Woman Swimmer Circles Manhattan On Her 2d Attempt
description: Diana Nyad, a 25yearold marathon swimmer, successfully swam around Manhattan, Island yesterday, on her second attempt in 11 days. Exhausted, but triumphant, she was helped from the slimy waters of the East River off Gracie Mansion at 7:32 P.M., seven hours and 57 minutes after starting out from the same Point.

title: Wright's 68 Leads At Port Jefferson
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., Oct. 6Jimmy Wright of Inwood shot a fourunderpar 68 over the 6,693yard Harbor Hills course today to take the lead in the $10,000 Port Jefferson open golf tournament.

title: ThaiVietnamese Talks
description: TOKYO, Oct. 6 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Chatichai Choonhavan of Thailand said today that he would visit Hanoi and Saigon before the end of the year for talks aimed at normalizing relations with North and South Vietnam. The minister arrived in Tokyo Saturday night for political and commercial discussions.

title: I.T.T. Financial Unit Is Continuing to Buy Accounts Receivable
description: The I.T.T. Financial Corporation, a subsidiary, of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, is continuing to purchase, from various finance companies, accounts receivable resulting from inventory financing of home electronic equipment and appliances.

title: Bridge
description: If there were any way to determine the most active and energetic personality in the world of bridge, the top ranking would probably go to New York's Harold Ogust.

title: Chess
Bunis Upsets Ruffels in Tennis
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 6 (AP)Henry Bunis of Cincinnati, former Columbia University player, upset Ray Ruffels of Australia, 76, 26, 75, in the first round of the $50,000 South Pacific tennis championships today. Cliff Richey beat Bob Rheinberger, 62, 76, and Nick Saviano, a Californian, ousted Raz Reid, 26, 62, 64, in matches involving Americans. In a contest between two Aussies, Geoff Masters overcame John James, 61, 46, 60.

title: Cost of Technical Rising in N.B.A.
description: Memo to National Basketball Association players and coaches: Curb your tempers and your acting; the cost of technical fouls has been increased sharply. The first violation will cost $75, instead of $50 and the second, which also calls for automatic ejection from the game, will cost $225 instead of $150.

title: Summary of Various Actions Taken by the U.S. Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: No Link to Hirohito Seen in Arrest of 2
description: A ChineseAmerican couple whose apartment allegedly yielded an arsenal of weapons when it was raided by Secret Service agents Saturday morning were ordered held in $25.000 bail each at their arraignment in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday.

title: ARGENTINE TOLL 30 IN REBEL RAIDS
description: FORMOSA, Argentina, Oct. 6 (Reuters)Leftist guerrillas made three coordinated assaults here yesterday, leaving at least 30 people dead, but police sources said today that the attackers failed to achieve what appeared to be their major objectivethe freeing of imprisoned comrades.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SONG OF NORWAY Tourists fortunate enough to have inspected Norway firsthand and New Yorkers aware of the colorful NorwegianAmerican heritage will have an opportunity tonight at 8 o'clock to renew, that appreciation in a multimedia program at Carnegie Hail. The accent, naturally, will be musical, ranging from folk to contemporary, with a 96member choir directed by Rolf Stang, the Norwegian Folk Dance Society of Greater New York, the visiting Norwegian National Broadcasting Orchestra under Oivind Bergh, and other performers.

title: Douglas Stirs Interest At Reopening of Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6After the eight other justices swept through the parted velvet curtains today, Justice William O. Douglas was left seated all by himself behind the raised bench, confronted by an entire courtroom that was standing and staring in his direction.

title: Hearst Lawyer Quits
description: Terence Hallinan, Patricia Hearst's lead defense counsel since her arrest on Sept. 18, resigned yesterday, saying his services were no longer required. Page 22.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A former Republican State Senator, James Turner, lost a bid for reversal of a briberyconspiracy conviction and a threetofiveyear prison sentence that stemmed from a plan to frame a fellow legislator on drug charges. The Appellate Division of Superior Court rejected every argument in the appeal by Mr. Turner, who contended that the guilty verdict by a Superior Court jury in Mercer County in 1973 was against the weight of evidence.

title: COURT TO REVIEW VOTING FUND LAW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The Supreme Court, on the opening day of its new Court year, agreed today to a full review of the new campaign financing legislation that restructures the way the nation's political campaigns are waged.

title: Refugees Get Foster Homes
description: FORT CHAFFEE, Ark., Oct. 7 (UPI)Fiftythree refugee children who left Vietnam without their parents have been placed with foster parents in the United States, a state department lawyer and legal advises here said today.

title: RAILROADS GET HIGHER TAX RATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) The Supreme Court upheld today the right of states to tax railroads at a higher rate than other industries. The justices affirmed a lower court ruling that found constitutional a Tennessee law providing higher tax rates for railroads. Tennessee listed railroads in a higher tax categoryas utilities, rather than industries.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The State Transportation Commissioner warned that fare increases would not balance the budgets of masstransit systems, and he proposed statewide or regional tax increases to keep buses, subways and commuter railroads running in New York State. Without endorsing any particular tax, the Commissioner, Raymond Schuler, said money could be raised for mass transportation through increases in property taxes, automobile registration fees, gasoline taxes, personal income taxes, sales taxes or payroll taxes on employers.

title: Whirlpool Is Expanding
description: BENTON HARBOR, Mich., Oct. 6 (UPI)The Whirlpool Corpration says it will build a $5.4million plant at Cottage Grove, Minn., a suburb of St. Paul, for the production of vacuum cleaners. The company said the plant would serve as an assembly point for vacuum cleaner components produced elsewhere. The plant is slated to be completed next May.

title: Feminist Play Is Drawing Male Audiences in Cairo
description: CAIRO, Oct. 6An old male chauvinist folk tale with a new feminist aspect has become the opening wedge of the fall theater season in Cairo. It is also an expression of a growing social debate here.

title: Beame Requests Bankers To Urge U.S. Aid for City
description: Mayor Beanie appealed yesterday to members of the American Bankers Association to urge the Federal Government to aid New York City because of the national and international impact that was likely to result from a default on the city's bonds and notes.

title: Youth Killed by Train
description: A 20 yearold Dutchess County youth was killed yesterday by a PennCentral passenger train after he and some friends placed pennies on the track to flaten them. Authorities said the victim, Dale Petrus of Fishkill, apparently did not notice the train coming.

title: Soviet and East Germany To Sign a New Amity Pact
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 6 (Reuters)The Soviet Union and East Germany announced today that they were ready to conclude a new friendship treaty, expected to alter the objectives of the existing 1964 treaty for eventual German reunification.

title: State Considers Being Its Own Banker for ShortTerm Loans
description: Governor Carey is considering a longrange financial plan that would, in effect, turn New York State into its own banker and end for the forseeable future the state's need for shortterm borrowing in the private credit markets.

title: Senate Liberals Push New Bill On Oil and Natural Gas Pricing
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6Liberal Democrats in the Senate began a vigorous effort today to stitch together support for a combined oilandnaturalgas pricing bill that they portray as a last, best chance for the Democrats to write a broadgauge energy program of their own.

title: Ford's Tax Plan Seen as Cornerstone of His '76 Race
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The tax reduction plan that President Ford laid before the nation tonight is plainly designed as a cornerstone of his campaign to win the Presidency in his own right. The President, to the surprise of almost everyone, went far beyond a simple proposal to continue the antirecession tax cuts that were enacted in March. He even went considerably beyond what most politicians and tax experts had thought would he his maximum possible proposal: that was continuation of the 1975 tax cuts, plus a relatively small additional cut to take care of a technical problem to make sure that nobody's withholding taxes would be increased as of the first of next year.

title: Musicals Thrive in a Class at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 3The thin, reedy voice of Irving Berlin singing his Oh, How I Hate to Get Up in the Morning, from the 1918 production of Yip Yip Yaphank, came pouring scratchily out of the loudspeakers and 20 eager Yale students soaked up every word.

title: Isue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6A Senate subcommittee will formally begin considering tomorrow an overhaul of the $6billion food stamp program.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: President Changing Role at Lehman
description: F. Warren Hellman, the 41yearold president of Lehman Brothers, Inc., disclosed yesterday that he expected to move from New York City to New England and that Lehman would pick a new president, probably within the next few months. After that occurs, he said, he will retain important duties with the firm.

title: Thousands See Hints of Past They Never Knew
description: MADISON, N.J.They came by the thousands, swarming down the walks shaded by oaks and hemlocks, past vast stretches of velvety lawn and fencedin dog runs and then through bronze portals to see Giralda, the turnofthecentury chateau that was the home of the late Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge for 62 years.

title: RALPH HALPERN, 85, QUEENS G.O.P. LEADER
description: Ralph Halpern, who retired in 1971 after 25 years as secretary of the Queens County Republican Committee and 50 as a Republican State Committeeman, died yesterday at his home, 14010 84th Drive, Jamaica, Queens. He was 85 years old.

title: Trading in Options Studied by Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange is studying the feasibility of introducing options trading, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: Federal Reserve Votes to Maintain Present Fund Rate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (Reuters)  The Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Committee voted to maintain the Federal funds rate within a 6 to 6 per cent range in early September even though money supply growth was running at or below the lower end of its target range, the board reported today.

title: Nonunion Machinists Repair Presses Sabotaged in Washington Post Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6Hopes for an early settlement of the fivedayold strike by printing pressmen at The Washington Post appeared to have suffered a setback today when the company announced that it had reluctantly brought nonunion machinists into its plant to repair presses damaged by sabotage as the pressmen's walkout began last Wednesday.

title: Teachers Stage AllNight Protest In West Hartford
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 6Public school teachers in West Hartford began an unusual sort of job action this morning  apparently determined to work in shifts around the clock for three days and two nights instead of striking to protest the long stalemate in their contract talks.

title: Arts Council Members Query Joan Davidson's Memo on His Service in Strike
