description: Henry Calvin, known for his portrayal of Sergeant Garcia on the Zorro television series of the nineteenfifties, died. Monday in Dallas. He was 57 years old.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Goldman Indicted on Bribery Charge
description: Irving Goldman, the president of the Shubert Foundation, was charged in a new indictment yesterday with giving $4,350 in bribes to a witness to flee to Mexico City to avoid a subpoena.

title: MEXICAN CAUTIONS ADVANCED NATIONS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 7The President of Mexico, in an official visit to United Nations Headquarters today, told the advanced societies that they could not ignore the developing nations and warned the developing countries against revolutionary mythology, radical oratory and moralizing.

title: Lennon Wins Fight
description: John Lennon, the British rock star, won a major decision here yesterday barring United States immigration officials from deporting him for a marijuana conviction in Britain. Page 42.

title: UsedCar Dealer Ordered To Trial in Deaths of Four
description: TULSA, Okla., Oct. 7 (UPI)A usedcar dealer accused of negligence in selling a car in which a family of four died of carbon monoxide poisoning was ordered today to stand trial on a charge of seconddegree manslaughter.

title: A Political Chimera
description: With the economy still subject to dangerous imponderables as it emerges from a severe slump, it is deeply unfortunate that President Ford has chosen to play political and ideological games. His tax message is not the serious program of a responsible leader; it is a political chimera projected by a candidate playing for votes in a yearoff election instead of seeking realistic answers to the challenge of unemployment and inflation.

title: Deportation of Lennon Barred by Court of Appeals
description: John Lennon yesterday won a major court decision here barring United States immigration officials from deporting him for a marijuana conviction in Britain.

title: Communist Laos
description: When Communist Pathet Lao troops and political cadres began their provincebyprovince seizure of Laos, after the fall of South Vietnam last spring, neutralist Premier Souvanna Phouma decreed an orderly surrender of power, without a resistance that clearly would have been futile. This decision and the gentle nature of Laos' three million people undoubtedly help to explain the relatively peaceful takeovercapped by the administrative absorption of Vientiane, the capital, six weeks agothat has spared Laotians the harsh fate of their neighbors in Cambodia.

title: Stricter Gun Law Urged as a Curb on Assassins
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI)A former Secret Service official told Senators today that stricter gun control laws would lessen the probability of assassination attempts against Presidents.

title: HOSTAGE DEPICTS ORDEAL IN BANK
description: As eight terrified hostages and his girlfriend watched a young Dutch actor hurled himself against a gunman who had taken over a Manhattan bank Monday in a hold attempt to gain freedom for himself and the others.

title: Red Sox Dethrone A's in Three Games; Reds Beat Pirates, 53, in 10th for Flag
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 7The Cincinnati Reds swept the National League playoffs and won their third pennant in six years tonight when they defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 53, in 10 innings, despite a dramatic 14strikeout pitching performance by a rookie John Candelaria.

title: Senate Committee Backs 200 Technicians for Sinai
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted approval today for the Administration's request to station 200 American civilian technicians in the Sinai passes to monitor the latest EgyptianIsraeli agreement.

title: WINE TALK
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif.  It looked like the kind of room they set up in a high school for blood donations: folding tables covered in white; a curtainedoff area for the technicians and lots of people walking around in illfitting white coats.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Economists Expect Rates to Stabilize
description: A group of leading economists predicted yesterday that interest rates, which have been climbing for several months, would stabilize near their current levels soon and perhaps decline somewhat next year.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A 59yearold working woman has won her battle to get a preferred checking account at a local bank without having her husband cosign the application. She has also received a check from the bank for $259.45, which she plans to use to start the account.

title: Wassau Merger Set Into Glatfelter In Share Exchange
description: The P. H. Glatfelter Company of Spring Grove, Pa., and the Wassau Paper Mills of Brokaw, Wis., have agreed to merge Wassau into Glatfelter through and exchange of stock worth about $13.5million. Wassau shareholders would receive 0.525 of a share of Glafelter common for each Wassau share they own. Glatfelter said that if all Wassau warrants and options were exercised, the transaction would involve about 525,000 Glatfelter shares.

title: Access to TV Time Is Creating Issue of Its Own for '76
description: It is already apparent that access to television will be one of the disturbing issues surrounding the 1976 national election campaigns. The incumbent President's claim to air time as a prime newsmaker was strengthened by a recent action of the Federal Communications Commission to exempt news conferences from equaltime requirements. White the networks welcomed the exemption it made them so wary of being improperly used that CBS and NBC both declined to carry President Ford's address to the nation Monday night outlining his new tax proposals.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Salomon Brothers Doubles Its Income
description: The investment banking house of Salomon Brothers reported yesterday that beforetax income soared in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 to $46.3millionmore than double the $22million reported a year earlier.

title: POLL OF BANKERS PREDICTS DEFAULT
description: More than 60 per cent of the bankers polled at the annual meeting of the American Bankers Association here this week said they believed New York City's financial crisis had worsened to the extent that the city faced certain default on some of its outstanding securities.

title: National Council of Churches Is Under Pressure to Take Less Provocative Stands
description: Financial troubles, conflict over social issues and frank appraisal of the recent past have put pressure on the National Council of Churches to alter its role from that of a super agency taking provocative policy stands to that of a coordinating agency mirroring a diversity of views.

title: President Opens Drive to Sell Programs, Scoffing at Critics
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 7President Ford, beginning what he called his effort to sell his new tax and budgetcutting programs to the American people, took sharp issue today with members of Congress who said his proposal was not feasible.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CLEMSON, S.C. Oct. 7 (AP)Clemson University officials appeared shocked today at the penalties imposed on the school's basketball program by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for recruiting violations. The university's legal counsel, Joseph B. McDevitt, said, It's a persecution, not a prosecution. However, the school will not appeal. Clemson was placed on three years' probation and banned from postseason competition and appearances on N.C.A.A.controlled game telecasts. The probation also reduces the number of basketball scholarships allowed to the school.

title: W.F.L. to Try New Marketing
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 7 (UPI)Chris Hemmeter said today the World Football League would begin a national marketing program in an effort to boost sagging attendance figtires in the 10 franchise cities.

title: ANITA O'DAY GIVES VOCAL JAZZ DISPLAY
description: Anita O'Day's way with a song can sometimes seem so casual, so offhand that, if her accompanists are unfamiliar with her approach, the delicate musical house of cards that she constructs collapses. During her present fourweek stand at Michael's Pub, However, she has the backing of a quartet led by Lennie Hambro (a saxophonist who, like Miss O'Day, was in Gene Krupa's orchestra in the nineteenforties) that gives her the freedom and assurance to try whatever she wants.

title: U.S. Protestant Minister Expelled by South Vietnam
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 7 (UPI)An American Protestant minister who remained in Da Nang after the Communist takeover of South Vietnam in April was expelled from the country today.

title: 6 Killed by Fire in Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 7 (Reuters)Six persons were killed when fire touched off by an exploding truckload of insecticide today destroyed 13 homes at Chupei, about 35 miles south of here, the police said. The explosion occurred when a barrel of insecticide spray overturned in the truck.

title: ELECTIONS BOARD REVERSES ITSELF
description: In a vote that reflected a bitter party split, the Board of Elections reversed itself yesterday and decided to bar the State Charter Revision Commission from adding a 10th question to be put to voters on Nov. 4.

title: Shows Closed
description: The shows closed by the strike of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians:

title: British to Sit Apart From Bloc at Parley
description: LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 7Britain announced here today that she would represent herself at the forthcoming conference of energy producers and consumers in Paris and not go as part of the Common Market delegation.

title: Microsurgery Successful In Vasectomy Reversals
description: A University of California urologist has developed a microscopic surgical technique that he says has thus far proved completely effective in reversing a vasectomy, a means of male sterilization that is ordinarily regarded as permanent.

title: Ugandan, in U.N., Rejects U.S. Charges
description: UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., Oct. 7The chief delegate of Uganda, Khalid Younis Kinene, in a statement at the General Assembly tonight rejected what he said were wild allegations by the United States against his country and its President, Gen. Idi Amin.

title: MISS ZIRKULI GIVES A BASSOON PROGRAM
description: The bassoon is not necessarily, in spite of an unfortunate rhyming, the buffoon among instruments. In some older musjc it has silly, dull things to do, but its importance as an ensemble voice has long since been established. And the bassoon has a beguiling solo voice as well, as Bernadette Zirkuli showed at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night.

title: Home Winemaking on Increase Over State
description: PATERSON, Oct. 7Winemaking, a gentle groundswell growing from the new wave of American wine drinkers, is in season. Home vintners are busy sniffing and tasting a number of California wine grapes to search out those with which they expect to, stock their cellars in the days ahead.

title: People and Business
description: Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman of the RCA Corporation, said yesterday that the whole subject of American business activity abroad had been inflamed by recent disclosures of large bribes and other questionable payments to foreign agents and officials.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AT THE WHEEL Although his directional career spanned nearly three deccades, Joseph von Sternberg is best known to movie audiences for directing the seven films that brought fame to Vlarlene Dietrich, from The Blue Angel (1930), the Berlinmade drama of passion and ruin, to The Devil Is a Woman (1935), one of the most artistically stylized movies ever to come from Hollywood.

title: KING OLAV VISITS STATUE OF LIBERTY
description: King Olav V of Norway visited the Statue of Liberty yesterday, and touched a responsive chord in the children of immigrants who clustered to view him.

title: Musicians at the Met Agree to Extend Contract to Dec. 31 as Talks Continue
description: The opening of the Metropolitan Opera Company's new season nest Monday night seemed assured yesterday as a result of an agreement by the company and its musicians to extend the expired union contract until Dec. 31.

title: PAULINE N. SPELKE

But they were confused and somewhat worried by the Administration's broad new plan to cut taxes further next year and to trim Federal outlays by some $28billion.

description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 7J. J. Jones did his Fran Tarkenton imitation today. But he didn't fool people. For one thing, Tarkenton has sandyblond hair.

description: Publishing has its bestseller lists. Disk jockeys have their Top 40. Fashion watchers deliver their bestdressed. Industry has its top 500.

description: GRIFFINIn Portland, Maine, August 24, Mrs. Mary B. Griffin, wife of Arthur B. Griffin. Memorial Service Friday, October 10 at 11:00 o'clock at the First Presbyterian Church, Englewood, New Jersey.

title: Standard & Poor's Sees Default by City
description: A default by New York City on its debt will be an absolute certainty unless the Federal Government steps in with loans to alleviate the city's fiscal crisis, a leading municipalbond expert said yesterday.

title: Oakland Errors Help Boston Win. 53
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct, 7 Oakland's dreams of winning a fourth straight World Series ended abruptly tonight as the Boston Red Sox completed a threegame sweep of the American League's championship series with a 53 victory.

title: In Memoriam
description: SOLOMON  S. Mark. Your twentyninth birthday, we miss, love and will always remember you. Rest in peace. Love.

title: Oil Barge Spills 30,000 Gallons Into East River Off The Bronx
description: A 340foot barge carrying 4.2 million gallons of No. 6 fuel oil struck a submerged object near North Brother Island in the East River last night, ripping open a portside tank and discharging 30,000 gallons, of the residual oil, according to Coast Guard estimates.

title: South Africa to Open More Jobs to Blacks In Economy Drive
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 7 (AP) South Africa will open more jobs to blacks in an effort to increase production and counter 17 per cent inflation.

title: Senate Committee Backs 200 Technicians for Sinai
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted approval today for the Administration's request to station 200 American civilian technicians in the Sinai passed to monitor the latest EgyptianIsraeli agreement.

title: Student Ambulance Unit at Issue
description: GREENCASTLE, Ind.What began 17 months ago as a public service by students at DePauw University has turned into a major controversy in this small, central Indiana community.

title: CONGRESS VOTES TO OVERRIDE FORD ON PUPIL LUNCH AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7Congress easily overrode today President Ford's veto of a $2.7billion extension and broadening of Federal school lunch and child nutrition programs.

title: Timing Becomes Critical In Federal Aid for City
description: Is New York City going to escape financial default? Answering that question involves dealing with tricky political and economic problems  and guessing whether the default will came before adequate help comes. The basic political question is whether the Administration's adamant refusal to rescue New York City has been broken. Those who believe it has contend that recent statements by Federal Reserve Board chairman Arthur F. Burns, Secretary of the. Treasury William E. Simon, Vice President Rockefeller and.Under Secretary of the Treasury Edwin H. Yeo 3d represent the orchestration of an Administration effort to help the city in recognition of the intolerable effects of a default, as the New York City Controller, Harrison J. Goldin, put it in an interview yesterday.

title: Marguerite Duras's 'India Song,' a Four-Hankie Story
description: Marguerite Duras's new film is titled "India Song" but it might be more accurately called "Leprosy," since leprosy provides the film with its most vivid metaphors. "Lepers," someone explains early on, "burst like sacks of grain," almost happily or, at least, without pain.So too bursts poor, elegant Anne-Marie Stretter (Delphine Seyrig), the promiscuous wife of the French Ambassador in Calcutta in the mid nineteen-thirties. Anne-Marie has what is variously diagnosed as leprosy of the soul and leprosy of the heart, which is a fancy way of saying she's bored out of her skull with her hus-band, with her lover, with all of her would-be lovers, and the members of Calcutta's diplomatic corps who live, like lepers, cut off from the life of the India that surrounds them.Anne-Marie doesn't have the good grace to blow up on the screen, and thus add a touch of melodrama to the otherwise static "India Song." She simply walks into the sea, off-screen, her soul and heart having burst simultaneously. So it goes in this kind of romantic nonsense that isn't too different in essential content from the four-hankie movies of the nineteen-thirties and forties."India Song" will be shown at the New York Film Festival tonight at 6:15 and again Friday night at 9:30.Miss Duras is a writer of fascinating novels and screenplays ("Hiroshima, Mon Amour") but I've yet to see a film directed by her that didn't seem a carefully thought out, overly intellectualized mistake. "India Song," based on an as-yet unproduced play commissioned by Peter Hall for the British National Theater, is no content and all style, some of it quite beautiful.Most of the so-called action takes place in a corner of the drawing room of the French Embassy in Calcutta, where we see Anne-Marie, usually in a stunning red evening dress, dancing with her lover, her suitors and finally with the mysterious French Vice Consul from Lahore (Michel Lonsdale), who has been sent to Calcutta in disgrace. One night he apparently had the bad manners to start shooting at the beggars and cats in the garden below his residence.None of this information comes to us directly. There is, in fact, no synchronized dialogue in the film. Instead the images are attached to disembodied voices, mostly those of embassy guests but sometimes those of Anne-Marie and the Vice Consul, who tell us in gossipy terms the terrible scandals Anne-Marie has been involved in, as well as (near the start of the film), the bad end she came to.The irritating thing about the film (which may well be consciously effected is that the characters do seem interesting in a terribly distant sort of way. The movie looks and sounds like something shot underwater, that is, everything except the fine, schlocky, thirties musical score by Carlos d'Alessio, which gives the film a life that has been carefully drained from the individual performances.Miss Seyrig is marvelous to contemplate, as the camera does endlessly, reminding us from time to time of a somewhat patrician version of Rita Hayworth, back in the days when she was making stuff like "Gilda." "India Song," at its mushy center, isn't very different.

title: St. Louis Pressmen Laid Off
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 7 (UPI)Then The St. Louis PostDispatch. today laid off 51 of its 225 pressmen and flymen, members of a union that has failed to reach agreement on a new contract with the newspaper. The union's leaders, who have been authorized by the membership to call a strike, had no immed??ate response to the announcement of the layoff

title: Portugese Leftists Take Over Barracks
description: LISBON, Oct. 7Leftwing troops and their civilian supporters moved into the compound of a sympathetic artillery regiment in the north of Portugal today after demonstrating all night outside the locked gates of the local transport regiment, which was disbanded for insubordination over the weekend.

title: Magnet Schools in Houston Stir Mixed Reaction
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 7An effort to increase integration in Houston schools through 34 magnet school programs has met with mixed reactions.

title: G.E. RAISES PROFIT 7% IN 3D QUARTER
CONSUMER NOTES
description: It costs anywhere from 5 cents to a quarter to photocopy one page. Yet a New York woman named Palmer recently paid $9.98 for copies of six pages of public document on the chance that she might be an heir of John Palmer who died in San Francisco in 1972 with an unclaimed estate of $18,412.55.

title: Cost of Food Down Slightly For Family of Four Here
description: Supermarket specials on many items brought the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City down 0.6 per cent last week, even though there were no indications in sight of relief from the high prices of common foodstuffs.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Seeking a Law To Let Public Employes Strike
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7The A.F.L.C.I.O. wound up its convention here today after calling for Federal legislation to give all public employes the right to strike despite an effort from the floor to substitute compulsory arbitration in disputes involving policemen and firemen.

title: Vacant Navy Yard Urged for Museum Of Kennedy Library
description: BOSTON Oct. 7 (UPI)The Boston Redevelopment Authority and Harvard University have joined forces to urge that the Charlestown Navy Yard, which is now vacant, become the future location for the museum portion of the proposed John F. Kennedy Library.

title: Eased Turkish Embargo Signed Into Law by Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI) President Ford today signed into law a measure approved by Congress last week that eases the embargo against shipments of United States arms to Turkey, the White House announced.

title: U.S. Penalizes State $2Million For Failure on Health Screening
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The Department of Health, Education and Welfare informed Governor Carey today that New York State would be penalized $2.3mllion of its Federal welfare funds for failing to implement fully a health screening and treatment program for poor children.

title: Victims of Floods Find Getting Relief Is Frustrating
description: A program of flooddisaster relief initiated this week for victims of recent heavy rains is proving to be confusing and frustrating for many seeking assistance.

title: REAGAN INDICATES HE'D RUN AS NO. 2
description: ALTOONA, Pa., Oct 7 (UPI)  Former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California indicated today that he would consider accepting the Republican VicePresidential nomination if he felt it was good for the party and if he was asked to accept it.

title: A Major New Newspaper Planned for Italy's Left
description: ROME, Oct. 7Two Italian publishing houses announced, today the foundation of a new national daily, La Repubblica.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: Females of the Species: Semonides on Women, translation and commentary by Hugh LloydJones, with photographs by Don Honeyman of sculptures by Marcelle Ouinton (Noyes Press, Park Ridge, N.J., $19.50).

title: Playoff Protests Pour in at NBC
description: League preferences determined which areas would see which telecasts in baseball's playoffs, a spokesman for the National Broadcasting Company explained yesterday.

title: ACCOUNTANT JAILED IN PHILLIPS OIL CASE
description: TULSA, Okla., Oct. 7 (UPI)An official of an accounting concern who refused to produce documents requested by a Federal grand jury investigating the Phillips Petroleum Company, has been ordered jailed.

title: Kleppe Approved By Senate Panel To Head Interior
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI) The Senate Interior Committee voted today to recommend confirmation of the Small Business Administrator, Thomas S. Kleppe, as Secretary of the Interior after he agreed to remove securities of companies dealing with natural resources from a blind trust.

title: AGENCY NEGOTIATING BOND SALE TO BANKS
description: The Project Finance Agency, a New York State agency set up last February to help the Urban Development Corporation after it defaulted on its notes, is intensifying its negotiations to sell $230million of bonds to savings banks in the state.

title: Rise in 8% Prime Rate Predicted by Bankers
description: Bankers polled at the annual meeting of the American Bankers Association this week predicted that the prime interest rate, currently at 8 per cent, would rise slightly by the end of the year, and would continue to increase gradually through the first half of 1976.

title: Helen Stevens Stoll Dead; Led Medical Aid to China
description: Helen Stevens Stoll, executive director of the American Bureau for Medical Aid to China from 1941 to 1947, died Friday evening in the Princeton (N. J.) Medical Center. She was 81 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: About Education
description: A pioneering project by the State Education Department to separate the wheat from the chaff in the abundance of doctoral programs that sprouted at colleges and universities during the nineteen sixties has moved into its second phase.

title: Wornen's Calls for Advice Lead to a Divorce Handbook
description: In the early 1970's, volunteers at the Philadelphia Women's Center realized that most of their telephone calls for help were from distraught women who were going through separation or divorce, and didn't know what to do.

title: Microsurgery Successful In Vasectomy Reversals
description: A University of California urologist has developed a microscopic surgical technique that he says has thus far proved completely effective in reversing a vasectomy, a means of male sterilization that is ordinarily regarded as permanent.

title: In This Family, It's an Apple Dish a Day
description: QUAKER HILL, N. Y.Apples figure prominently on the menus of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Bell whether they are entertaining in the former tenant farmer's home they own in this section of Pawling or at their home in Washington Square.

title: TALKS RESUMED IN SCHOOL STRIKE
description: Negotiators for the striking Elizabeth Education Association and the Board of Education returned to the bargaining tablelast night after teachers and other school employes ignored a backtowork court order and continued their strike for a secand day.

title: In 6 Paes and 10.8Million Copies, Pravda Gives Kremlin's View
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 7The newspaper runs a scant six pagesfour on Mondaywith the important news sometimes buried inside. It carries no advertisements, unless one counts the incessant paeans to the wisd??m and foresight of the Commanist party.

title: People in Sports
description: Nona Schallau, who paired with Billie Jean King of the New York Sets to form the league's top doubles team, was traded yesterday to the Indiana Loves of World Team Tennis for Phil Dent and a player to be named later.

title: Dollar Shows Drop On Europe Markets
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 7 (UPI)The dollar and the pound retreated against major European currencies today. The price of gold rose more than $5 an ounce in London.

title: Science Academy in Soviet Marking 250th Anniversary
description: MOSCOW, Oct.7The Soviet Academy of Sciences opened its belated 250th anniversary celebration today with Leonid I. Brezhnev urging scientists to work more persistently in the service of the Soviet Union and its Communist ideology.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 8, 1975

title: The Odds Are Chancy That You'll Get Your Furniture in One Piece These Days
description: For countless consumers, buying furniture has turned out to be a gamble. They took a chance on getting their beds, tables, sofas and chairs in good shape, and they lost.

title: House Stops Bid to Block Panama Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The House of Representatives turned back today a legislative attempt to prevent the Ford Administration from negotiating a new Panama Canal treaty.

title: Ban on Women as Priests Assayed by Catholic Prelate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI) Although the Ronan Catholic Church will suffer if women are shunted to secondary roles, them are still compelling reasons they should not be ordained to the priesthood, the president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops said.

title: TV : Jennie Offers Exquisite Portrait
description: Jennie: Lady Randolph Churchill, a sevenpart series beginning on the Public Broadcasting Service at 9 this evening, is another of those British productions that, with exquisite manners, humiliate the lowestcommondenominator ambitions of American television. Produced for Thames TV, a commercial British organization, the series uses the life of Winston Churchill's American mother for a period portrait of uncommon intelligence and charm.

title: Red Sox, Reds Win
description: The Boston Red Sox defeated the Oakland A's last night, 53, sweeping the American League baseball playoffs, 30, and dethroning the champion A's. The Cincinnati Reds, also in a sweep, beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 53, for the National League title. [Page 31.]

title: SAIGON SHIPPING U.S. GOODS NORTH
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 7 Huge quantities of civilian and military goods left behind in South Vietnam by the United States are being shipped out of the port of Saigon to North Vietnam, according to Western officials and refugees recently arrived from Saigon.

title: CONGRESS VOTES TO OVERRIDE FORD ON PUPIL LUNCH AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7Congress easily overrode today President Ford's veto of a $2.7billion extension and broadening of Federal school lunch and child nutrition programs.

title: Can't See Price Tag? There's a Reason
description: Have you ever wondered what that pretzel is doing standing in front of a store jewelry display case?

title: New Hampshire Sets Its Primary on Feb. 24
description: CONCORD, N. H., Oct. 7 (UPI)The New Hampshire Presidential primary, traditionally the nation's first, has been set for Feb. 24, 1976. Secretary of State Robert Stark said yesterday.

title: TV Phone to Link Lawyers In City to Judges in Capital
description: Two lawyers will present oral arguments next week in a small room in a telephone company building here to three judges sitting in Washington.

title: Panamanians Cynical Over Canal Issue
description: PANAMA CITY, Oct. 5Despite the impatient and fiery rhetoric of Panama's military Government, delays in the conclusion of a new United StatesPanama treaty on the Panama Canal appear to be generating a mood of apathy and cynicism in the Panamanian population.

title: Jersey State Police Agree to Job Quota Of Blacks, Hispanics
description: The New Jersey state Police agreed yesterday to bring the employment level of blacks and Hispanics, to at least 14 per cent of its uniformed force within five years.

title: Girl in Coma Not Legally Dead, Says Expert
description: Karen Anne Quinlan, the 21yearold woman who has been in a coma for almost six months and whose parents are seeking court permission to turn off a respirator that has been sustaining some of her vital functions, can breathe occasionally without the machine and cannot be considered legally dead, according to a physician who has been consulted by medical experts in the case.

title: About Real Estate
description: The Essex House, one of the pillars of dignity that line Central Park South, had a troubled childhood. She was built in 1930 as an apartment  transient hotel and quickly fell victim to the Depression. The New Deal's Reconstruction Finance Corporation took command of her in 1932 after a foreclosure. Not until 1946 did she return to private hands.

title: Car Blast Kills Witness
description: TEMPE, Ariz., Oct. 7 (UPI) Louis Bombacino, 52yearold Government witness whose testimony sent oJhn Philip Cerone Sr. of Chicago and four other persons to prison on gambling charges, was killed yesterday in an exposion that ripped his car apart. The police and Federal officials said, Mr. Bombacino had been the target of an underworld contract hit.

title: William M. Laas, Author And a Newspaperman, 65
description: William M. Laas, author and former newspaperman, died Monday at Cabrini Health Care Center. He was 65 years old and lived at 3343 Crescent Street, Long Island City Queens.

title: Nastase and Borg Victors in Madrid
description: MADRID, Oct. 7 (AP)Ilie Nastase of Rumania and Bjorn Borg of Sweden, won secondround matches in the $75,000 Madrid open tenths tournament today.

title: Reciprocity After Helsinki
description: MOSCOWAfter the Final Act was signed at the Helsinki Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, the West began making attempts to reduce the significance of the conference to two propositions: the consolidation of the postwar European frontiers (which the West claims is a great concession to the Soviet Union for which the West expects repayment), and what is termed in diplomatic language the third basket, covering questions of cooperation in the humanitarian and other fields.

title: TREASURY'S NOTES ARE SOLD AT 8.14%
description: The Treasury sold $2.5billion of 38month notes yesterday at an average yield of 8.14 per cent, which was well above Wall Street estimates. Another surprising aspect of the latest auction to help finance the Federal deficit was the relatively low participation of individual investors. Prior to the sale, dealers had expected the auction to bring an average yield of 8 per cent or slightly less.

title: Beame Will Halt All City Construction Except Projects Well Under Way
description: Mayor Beame intends to sign an executive order today bringing to a standstill any new city construction projects except those well in progress and for which a legal obligation exists.

title: President Opens Drive to Sell Programs, Scoffing at Critics
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 7President Ford, beginning what he called his effort to sell his new tax and budgetcutting programs to the American people, took sharp issue today with members of Congress who said his proposal was not feasible.

title: Lennon Wins Fight
description: John Lennon, the British rock star, won a major decision here yesterday barring United States immigration officials from deporting him for a marijuana conviction in Britain. Page 42.

title: Cowboys Dust Off Old Shotgun
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 7The Giants began watching films of the Dallas Cowboys today, and before the week is over there will be plenty of reruns because these are not the same Cowboys the Giants have come to know and generally lose to. The Giants open their home season against Dallas next Sunday at Shea Stadium.

title: 3 U.S. Officials Optimistic On Impact of City Default
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 8The three Federal bank regulatory agencies gave Congress today a detailed and generally reassuring account of the impact that a New York City default would have on the nation's banking system, but they conceded they did not yet have a full picture of what the impact would be if New York State issues also got into trouble.

title: PowerPlay Goal by Rangers Ties Hawks, 22, in Opener
description: The Rangers and the Chicago Black Hawks began their 50th year in the National Hockey League last night by skating to a 22 tie. To nearly everybody but the raucous sellout crowd of 17,500 at Madison Square Garden, it was poetic justice.

title: KING OLAV VISITS S.I. AND BROOKLYN
description: Norway's King Olav V visited Brooklyn and Staten Island yesterday, where NorwegianAmericans rolled out red carpets, waved Norwegian flags and shouted lenge lever Kongen (long live the King).

title: HOUSE APPROVES U.S. SINAI AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The House of Representatives approved overwhelmingly tonight the stationing of up to 200 American civilian technicians in Sinai to monitor the recent EgyptianIsraeli accord.

title: Smile, a Film Satire on Having Fun
description: Middle America is not exactly the fastestmoving target in the world. You don't have to be a sharpshooter to hit it. It just sits there like someone on a giant billboard, wearing an eartoear grin, the eyes sparkling in anticipation of achieving some new plateau of pleasure, waiting to be defaced by anyone who has the price of a can of spray paint.

title: Alaska Oil Companies Sued for Trespass
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct. 8 The United States Department of Interior filed a trespassing suit today against 126 companies, including Alyeska Pipeline Service Company and a dozen other major oil companies, that could result in millions of dollars of settlement to Alaska's Eskimos on the North Slope.

title: A.B.A. Champions Defeat N.B.A.'s
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 8 (UPI)Mary Roberts scored 20 points and Wilbert Jones limited Rick Barry to 9 tonight as the Kentucky Colonels defeated the Golden State Warriors, 9390, in an exhibition basketball game between the two league champions.

title: Heard Gains Semifinal in Match Play
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 8 (AP)Bob Stanton of Australia and Jerry Heard posted double victories today in the rainmarred $117,500 International All  Star golf matches.

title: Three Schoolboy Elevens Find Success in Battling Adversity
description: Playing football in the city is never easy. Strikes often disrupt the season. Fields are often rutted and ragged, when they are available. There are not always large numbers of candidates for a team, and star players often wind up ineligible. And this year, moneyor the lack of itis an added problem.

title: BRAXTON IS NIMBLE AS JAZZ MUSICIAN
description: Anthony Braxton is a young saxophonist who developed in the exploratory jazz atmosphere in Chicago in the late nineteensixties, which also produced Lester Bowie, Roscoe Mitchell, Joseph Jarman, Muhal Richard Abrams and Leroy Jenkins, among others. All of them work in what might be considered an impressionistic rather than a swinging style. But Mr. Braxton, who is leading his own quartet this week at the Five Spot, 2 St. Mark's Place, is a much more readily accessible musician.

title: SHOOTING ERUPTS IN LEBANON ANEW; AT LEAST 25 DEAD
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Thursday, Oct. 9The latest ceasefire between warring Christian and Moslem factions, proclaimed three days ago, was shattered early yesterday by heavy fighting here in the capital and in the northern part of the country.

title: Mental Home Escapee Free for Doctor's Role
description: FRANKLIN, Ind., Oct. 8 (UPI)  Dr. Roberet Hales, who escaped from a mental hospital, practiced medicine in several places and finally joined the medical staff of a state prison before being apprehended, has been given his freedom and is looking forward to a new medical career.

title: Canucks Beat Stars, 32
NO WELCOME MAT FOR AFRICA GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8A delegation of mostly black politicians from the obscure ana longdisputed territory of SouthWest Africa came to Washington this week to explain their conservative point of view and found that almost nobody would talk to them.

title: Gleaners Gather After Reaper to Feed World's Poor
description: EUREKA, Ill., Oct. 6  It was hard, dusty stoop labor, but the line of college students moved cheerfully through the cornfield today, kicking up the flattened stalks and occasionally stuffing an ear of corn in their gunnysacks.

title: Indonesia Denies Attack Into Portuguese Timor
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 8 (Reuters)The Indonesian Defense Ministry denied today that Indonesian troops had launched a major attack on the strategic town of Batugade in Portuguese Timor.

title: Public Employes in Puerto Rico Protest New Civil Service Law
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 8 (UPI) Thousands of public workers on a oneday walkout marched through the streets of San Juan today to protest a new civil service law as a weekold maritime strike left the island with only four days' supply of food.

title: Oporto Clashes Bring a Confrontation; Portuguese Reds Hail Unrest in Army
description: LISBON, Oct. 8 (Reuters)Rebel troops and loyal units faced each other with armored cars in the northern city of Oporto tonight after clashes between rival civilian demonstrators left at least 45 people injured.

title: Allied Chemical Net Off 48.7% in Quarter
Slush Funds Upheld
description: The Senate rejected, 48 to 47, a curb on political use of Congressmen's private office accounts, often referred to as slush funds. Page 25.

title: NEW LAW MAY AID PATRICIA HEARST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8The Department of Justice, whose attorneys have argued that Patricia Hearst is likely to run away if she is admitted to bail, may have to release her on her own recognizance if she has not been brought to trial by Dec. 27

title: Jackson and Muskie to Be at Liberal Fete Tonight
description: Two Democratic Presidential contenders and seven Democratic Senate prospects will share the dais at the annual Liberal party dinner tonight.

title: Writers Receive Prizes Here for Works They Will Never See
description: A Japanese acupuncturist, a Dutch music critic, an Israeli author who had fought in the Soviet Army and a young American ex  convict were among a group of writers who received $1,000 prizes yesterday afternoon as winners of an unusual literary contest.

title: Indian Leader Arrested
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (UPI)The police arrested the Illinois director of the American Indian Movement last night and confiscated drugs, five sticks of dynamite and two guns from the AIM office. The arrested men, Larry Ellard, 29 years old, was charged with possession of a controlled substance and unlawful use of weapons.

title: F.T.C. Aide Rules in Favor Of CocaCola and Pepsico
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. S (AP)A Federal Trade Commission administrative law judge ruled today that exclusive bottlers' licenses issued by the nation's top two softdrink manufacturers, the CocaCola Company and Pepsico, Inc., increase competition and do not represent an illegal restraint of trade.

title: People in Sports
description: From Louisville to Baltimore to Denver. Dan Issel, the fivetime AllStar forward of the American Basketball Association, hopes that's the end of his travels.

title: Scientists Say Collisions of 3 Continents Formed Asia
description: Chinese geologists, after scaling Mount Everest and roaming remote regions of Central Asia, have concluded  as have American scientists looking down from space  that Asia is the product of the collisions of at least three small continents. The pressure of one of them, the Indian subcontinent, is still crumpling and twisting the landscape.

title: Tables on Tax Liabilities
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The following tables, cornpiled from Treasury Department figures, show the tax liabilities of families of different sizes and at different income levels, assuming average itemized deductions or use of the standard deduction, whichever is larger.

title: FORD GAS PROGRAM BACKED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The Ford Administration won a key Senate vote today when a coalition of Republicans and Democrats from Southern and Border states defeated an attempt by Democratic liberals to kill a bill that would gradually end Federal ceilings on interstate natural gas prices.

title: NATIONALISTS LET PEKING RETURN 60
description: HONG KONG, Thursday, Oct. 9Sixty Chinese Nationalist agents who had been captured on the Chinese mainland in the nineteensixties were sent by boat yesterday to the Nationalistheld island of Quemoy. Five others arrived in Hong Kong.

title: Soviet Builds Influence in Laos As a Rival of Hanoi and Peking
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 1With the era of American dominance in Laos ended by the Pathet Lao take  over last spring, the Soviet Union has moved rapidly to enlarge its Influence here.

title: Schools and Union Assail Rejection of Agreement
description: School and teacher leaders declared yesterday that, as far as they were concerned, the agreement that ended last month's fiveday teachers' strike was still in effect, despite its rejection Tuesday by the Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: Reds to Test Boston Wall; Hunter's Absence Hurt A's
description: The Cincinnati Reds were welcomed home by 10,000 fans in the hours before dawn yesterday after winning their third pennant in six years, and then turned to the final test of the baseball season: assaulting the Great Wall of Fenway Park.

title: GOLDMAN LOSES SHUBERT POSTS
description: Irving Goldman, who started out as an errand boy making deliveries to Shubert theaters and rose to become president of the Shubert Foundation, was suspended yesterday from all. Shubert organization and foundation activities.

title: Skateboards Make Comeback As Older Boys and Girls Join In
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8After a 10year decline into the pits of discarded fads, the skateboard is roaring back upon clear plastic wheels in a revival as umnistakable as a skinned elbow.

title: Officer Accused of Murder In Beating of Prisoner Here
description: A 26yearold Bronx police officer was indicted for murder yesterday following an investigation into the beating of a man who died of internal bleeding a few hours after his arrest for firing a shot at the police through his apartment door.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A New York accountant pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Newark to conspiring to bribe an Internal Revenue Service agent auditing the hooks of the accountant's client. Morton Brenner, 59 years old, of Long Beach, L.I., admitted before United States District Judge Herbert J. Stern that he had asked the president of Hudson Muffler Corporation of West New York for $5,000 to give to an I.R.S. auditor checking Hudson Muffler's accounts.

title: HARVEY GILLESPIE
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct 8 (AP) Harvey T. D. Gillespie athletic director at Moravian College for 36 years, died last night at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 67 years old.

title: Diego Garcia Base Funds Are Approved by House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (Reuters)The House of Representatives tonight approved a $3.8billion military construction appropriations bill including funds for facilities on the Britishowned island of Diego Garcia.

title: ...and Two to Go?
description: As if the Hills and Kleppe appointments were not sufficient cause for concern, President Ford has chosen two other nominees for significant posts whose qualifications or lack of themare even more disturbing.

title: Bridge:
description: It seldom happens that the organizers of a bridge tournament have a concrete reason for hoping for a particular result, but the NassauSuffolk Bridge Association was in an exceptional position last weekend.

title: Rexnord Closing a Plant
description: Rexnord, Inc. announced yesterday it would close its conveyor systems equipment plant in Ellwood City, Pa., which employs 160 people. Downturns in market demand for materials handling equipment and operating costs have created losses of more than $200,000 a month and are expected to exceed $2million for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, according to an official of Rexnord.

title: The Wall, The Turf and The Psyche
description: In the World Series that opens Saturday, the inanimate might he as much a factor as the animate. Out there in left field at Fenway Park is The Wall, tall and green and inviting for righthanded hitters, the most controversial area of the venerable 63yearold playground where the Boston Red Sox entertain and/or frustrate their loyalists; almost all over Riverfront Stadium is The Turf, smooth and green and inviting for groundball singles, the most controversial area of the mod fiveyearold cylinder where the Cincinnati Reds have developed their machinelike precision, Through all the World Series of the past, the Red Sox never played the Reds but now they will. Already the Reds are thinking about The Wall, already their righthanded hitters, such as Pete Rose, Johnny Bench, Tony Perez, George Foster and Dave Concepcion, are measuring it in their minds315 feet down the line, 37 feet high, just a long flyball into the screen atop it for a home run. Already the Reds' manager, Sparky Anderson, is talking as if he were about to sight a prehistoric monster.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times last Tuesday erroneously identified The Frederick (Md.) News and Post as one of six nonunion newspapers in the Washington area that have been printing The Washington Post during a strike against The Post by union pressmen. The Frederick newspaper has not been assisting The Post.

title: Article 5  No Title
ZARB IN A PLEDGE TO GAS UTILITIES
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 8Federal Energy Administrator Frank G. Zarb told skeptical natural tias utility executives today that Federal policy makers will give increased attention to natural gas utilities in mapping an energy program for the nation. Natural gas accounts for about onethird of the nation's energy.

title: Algeria Crude Oil Price Up
description: ALGIERS. Oct. 8 (AP)Algeria has decided to raise the price of its crude oil from $11.75 to $12.75 a barrel following the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' decision, the official news agency, Algerie Presse Service. said today. The price is retroactive to Oct. 1, the agency said.

title: PENTAGON VOICING DOUBT ON DETENTE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The Defense Department is circulating an intelligence estimate asserting that the Soviet Union is using the policy of dtente to gain dominance over the West in all fields. Administration officials said today.

title: Giving Youngsters a Touch of the Farm
description: University schools of agriculture don't only educate college studentsthey frequently educate children, too, by opening up their barns to youthful exploration.

title: Business Briefs
description: PITTSBURGH. Oct. 8 (UPI)The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today it was relying on the legal doctrine of commercial impracticality as a defense against suits by several electric utility companies to force Westinghouse to supply them with nuclear fuel at prices well below current market levels.

title: Film: Diana Ross in Slick Mahogany
Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled that law enforcement officials using evidence derived from warantless searches must be able to show they had obtained the consent of an individual to conduct such a search. The court noted that in cases where the state seeks to justify a search on the basis of consent, it has the burden of showing that the consent was voluntary. It said an essential element of voluntary consent is knowledge of the right to refuse consent. The ruling applied to Arthur Johnson of Newark who contended that evidence used against him in a narcotics indictment had been obtained illegally.

title: BURNS EASES VIEW ON FEDERAL ROLE IN CITY'S CRISIS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today softened his opposition to Federal intervention to ease New York City's fiscal crisis and proposed five guidelines for Congressional action.

title: State Transferring Funds To Avert Agency Default
description: State officials yesterday were putting the final detail on a plan to enable the Housing Finance Agency to avoid default for another month.

title: Senate Calls for Protection Of U.S. Interest in Panama
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) The Senate approved and sent to the White House yesterday a vaguely worded resolution expressing the sense of Congress that any new agreement concerning the status of the Panama, Canal must protect the vital interests of the United States.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CENTER FIELD A free outdoor community festival of the arts, with entertainment, dancing and food, will be held tonight from 6 to 11 o'clock on the eve of the dedication of the Henry Street Settlement Arts for Living Center, 466 Grand Street.

title: Slush Funds Upheld
description: The Senate rejected, 48 to 47, a curb on political use of Congressmen's private office accounts, often referred to as slush funds. Page 25.

title: Shows Open
description: Shows that are not affected by the strike:

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: Pact Ends Teacher Strike Against Catholic Schools
description: Lay teachers voted last night to end their fiveweek walkout against five high schools in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and return to work this morning.

title: W.F.L. Team Takes Pay Cut
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., (AP)  The San Antonio Wings of the World Football League voted today to take a reduction in fray ranging from 25 to 40 per cent.

title: Shows Closed
description: The shows closed by the strike of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians:

title: Nation's Poor Would Lose Under Ford Tax Program
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Millions of the nation's poorest households those with children and with incomes of $5,000 a year or lesswould be worse off under President Ford's proposed new tax program than they are now.

title: COMPANY REPORTS
description: For periods ended Sept. 30 unless otherwise indicated.

title: Barrueco, Guitarist
description: The increase in both numbers and quality of classicguitar players in the last two decades has been extraordinary, and conservatory  trained guitarists are now appearing with increasing frequency.

title: Two SmallCollege Streaks on the Line
description: Franklin and Marshall of Lancaster, Pa., has won 15 consecutive football games for the longest smallcollege winning streak extant and second only to Oaklahoma's 24 straight. Swarthmore has lost 31 in a row for the longest losing streak, just eight short of the record of 39 set by St. Paul's Poly (now St. Paul's College) of Lawrenceville, a., in 19481953.

title: Ford Backs Moynihan On Criticism of Amin
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI)  President Ford fully supports Daniel P. Moynihares use of the term racist murderer to describe President Idi Amin of Uganda, the White House said today.

title: UNESCO's Board Votes For Softer Stand on Israel
description: PARIS, Oct. 8The executive board of UNESCO voted overwhelmingly today in favor of softening the antiIsraeli action that the organization took last November. The board decided to recommend to the general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization that it adopt procedures that would make it more difficult for Arabs to keep Israel out of the agency's European regional group.

title: 2 Women on Outing Drown in Greenwood Lake
description: Two women of River Edge, N. J., drowned in Greenwood Lake near Warwick, N. Y., yesterday when a cabin cruiser carrying a group of elderly people swerved suddenly and capsized.

title: PROF. PHILIP TAYLOR, ECONOMIST, 67, DEAD
description: Dr. Philip E. Taylor, professor emeritus of economics at the University of Connecticut, died Tuesday at his home in Storrs, Conn. at the age of 67.

title: CITY UNIONS WEIGH A GENERAL STRIKE
description: Leaders of the city's municipal labor unions said yesterday that they would consider, a general strike to protest the threeyear wage freeze and potential layoffs called for in the financial plan Mayor Beame has proposed to the Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: STARR QUESTIONS FORECLOSURE BILL
description: Roger Starr the city's Housing and Development Administrator, said yesterday that he doubted the effectiveness of proposed legislation that would permit foreclosure by the city of any property owner delinquent in realestate taxes for one year.

title: $1Million for Auto Crash
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 8 (UPI)Kenneth E. Porter, 52 years old, will receive $1million from the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company for injuries suffered in an automobile crash that he said was caused by a faulty tire. Firestone attorneys announced the settlement yesterday shortly before jury selection was to begin in a civil trial.

title: Lehman High Is Tense but Quiet After Racial Clashes and 24 Arrests
description: Herbert H. Lehman High School in the northeast Bronx experienced an uneasy quiet yesterday following racial incidents between black and white students Tuesday in which one, student was assaulted and at least 24 persons were arrested.

title: People and Business
description: Predicting a 21 per cent increase of industrywide ear and truck sales in 1976 from this year, Thomas A. Murphy, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, said yesterday that he was not willing to rule out price increases during the new car model year.

title: 4 School Strikes in State Showing Some Movement
description: There was some movement in all four of New Jersey's school strikes yesterday as negotiators began bargaining or scheduled meetings.

title: PISTOL BAN URGED BY POLICE CHIEFS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The chiefs of police of some of the nation's largest cities told a Senate committee today that they would prefer no new guncontrol law to one that did not ban the manufacture, sale and private possession of handguns.

title: Methods of Future Displayed Here
description: Bankers are moving with all deliberate speed into the age of automation and electronics, if the exhibition accompanying the centennial convention of the American Bankers Association can be used as an indicator of industry trends.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1975

title: Ramsey Clark Reprimanded For Kent State Comments
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 8 (AP)A Federal judge has reprimanded former United States Attorney General Ramsey Clark for commenting on the civil damages trial stemming from the Kent State University shootings, but the judge dropped contempt of court charges against Mr. Clark.

title: Puerto Rican Ships Struck
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 8 (UPI)  National Maritime Union pickets prevented the loading and unloading of a Puerto Rican container ship at the Blount Island container terminal today.

title: City Agencies Join Forces In Times Sq. Cleanup Drive
description: A team of 25 former addicts and officials and volunteers with the city's Office of Neighborhood Services yesterday joined the regular Sanitation and Parks Department forces in the Times Square area for a morninglong cleanup that included vacuuming sidewalks and planting shrubbery in the middle of the square.

title: British Engineer's Wile Missing; Federal Agents Called into Case
description: HAWORTH, Oct. 8 (AP)The police said today that they were seeking clues in the disappearance of a British engineer's 28yearold wife. She was last seen two days ago in the garden of her home in this Bergen County community.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Hard Times, a Stylish Poke at PickUp Fighters
Common Market and Its New Use of Power
description: BONN, Oct. 8The European Common Market has recently made dramatic use of its economic and political power in an attempt to move Spain and Portugal toward democratic rule. But it s?? appears uncomfortable in this unaccustomed role. Recently a top trade official of the community was asked whether the Market wanted to be the new policeman of the world by giving and withholding economic benefits on political grounds. No, was the cautious reply, we are just deciding what we want to do with whom.

title: Volkswagen Puts a Rise Of 4.2% on 1976 Prices
description: The suggested retail prices on 1976 Volkswagens will be going up by an average of $186, or 4.2 per cent, over comparably equipped 1975 models. Volkswagen of America announced today. The actual increases range from $46, or 0.9 per cent, on the Scirocco coupe to $395 or 7.7 per cent, on the sevenseater bus. The new models are scheduled to he introduced between late this month and midNovember.

title: Japan to Meet India
description: TOKYO, Oct. 8 (AP) Japan will meet India in the second round of the Davis Cup Eastern Zone eliminations here Dec. 5.

title: Pillsbury to Add Unit
description: The Pillsbury Company has agreed in principle to purchase Steak and Ale Restaurants of America. Inc., for $102million in Pillsbury stock. Page 68.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1975

title: Two Down ...
description: Roderick M. Hills is an experienced and personable lawyer. He has served for the last several months as counsel to President Ford, and he is also the husband of Carla A. Hills, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. By his own admission, he knows very little about the securities industry or about the daytoday work of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Yet President Ford has nominated Mr. Hills to be chairman of the S.E.C.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Increase Challenged
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The Council on Wage and Price Stability challenged as unjustified today a price increase of 67 cents a gallon for antifreeze announced by the leading manufacturer, the Union Carbide Corporation, to take effect Nov. 1.

title: Harris Says His Election Funds Qualify Him for a U.S. Subsidy
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 8Fred R. Harris, the former Oklahoma Senator who calls his campaign a people's movement, moved today onto the lengthening list of Democratic Presidential candidates who report they have raised enough money to qualify for Federal subsidies for the primary campaign.

title: Caterpillar Dividend Raised
description: PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 8 (Reuters) The Caterpillar Tractor Company said today its directors raised the quarterly dividend to 50 cents from 45 cents, payable Nov. 20, to shareholders of record Oct. 20.

title: Court Asserts a Person's Consent Is Needed in Warrantless Search
description: TRENTON, Oct. 8 (AP)The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that lawenforcement officials using evidence in such cases must be able to show they had had the consent of an individual to conduct a warrantless search.

title: A 'French Provincial' Jeanne Moreau
description: Jeanne Moreau has a genius for the particular. She could be marched off for execution and her fretful gait, her expression, her silences would argue so strongly against any mere universal application of law that the firing squad would fall apart arguing.In "French Provincial" the young director Andr Tchin has sent Miss Moreau trundling down a long, heavily furnished corridor of a movie about the multigenerational rise and fall of a French bourgeois family. By no subtle extension it argues through its particular provincial setting the decline and dissolution of bourgeois France.Miss Moreau implants all kinds of cross-rhythms in Mr. Tchin's ponderous though talented work, with its air of a nineteenth-century novel. She arrests the predictable playing-out of his cards; she enhances his uneven strengths."French Provincial," which will be shown tonight and tomorrow at Lincoln Center, is set around the fortunes of a family-owned foundry in a small French town. It was founded by Pedret, a young immigrant from Spain who by hard work and a driving vision built it up out of a simple smithy, and married the daughter of a prosperous local family as well.This is told in flashback. Most of the film takes place when Pedret has become the family patriarch, running the business with his three grown sons and dominating the life of the town. One trenchant scene shows the family going to the local movie theater in the same hierarchial fashion that an English squire and his family would go to church.Sturdy as one of his iron boilers, bearded and mystically devoted to the foundry, old Pedret represents for Tchin the vitality the bourgeoisie once had. The three sons, in different ways, are the class in decadence.There are two marriages. One brings in Rgina, a cold, spoiled girl who nests in the family like a leech, and eventually runs off with an American soldier. The other brings in Berthe, the town laundry woman.Berthe  Jeanne Moreauis vital, passionate and strong. She has an affair with Hector, most likable of the three sons, and when the family intervenes, threatens to leave town.Miss Moreau flickers fiercely, unpredictably, a hawk who lets herself be caught. Take one scene, for example. She has been snubbed by the family, and her laundry business is being boycotted.We see her in her kitchen, making herself dinner. She beats the omelet, muttering banal phrases on the lines of "It will pass," "What's the difference?" She chops salad, she pours wine. Each action is like assembling a bomb. The bomb goes off. In a magnificent Moreanuvian reversal she suddenly sweeps out  abandoning omelet, salad and wine  goes to the foundry, and rallies Hector to defy his family.Old Pedret can't afford to lose Hector, who is the works manager, so he pragmatically decides they must marry. The lesson: The bourgeoisie will co-opt members of the proletariat when necessary.Berthe is new blood: when Pedret dies she takes over. Emotionally she is of the peopleat the film's start she gets a job for Pierre, who will eventually lead the workers in strike against herbut she is pulled unwillingly away. Only during the warwhen she drives a munitions truck for the resistance group run by Pierredoes some of the old emotional unity come back. As did France's.The war ends. She, not Pierre, gets a medal. Pierre, the militant union man, is won over to the bland new European style of worker-management cooperation. But the foundry itself is going under, in competition with big multinational firms. Only American money can save it. It comeswith Regina and her American lover who also happens to be a big businessman. At the end we see Regina and the American making love under the portrait of old Pedret.By this time the movie has collapsed under the increasingly coarse style that Tchin adopts to symbolize his thesis of capitalist collapse. It isn't helped by the fact that his Americans, speak English with grotesque French and German accents and look like something out of Krokodil.Miss Moreau lies helplessly in bed. She can do no more to save the foundry: It will probably go on, but it won't be hers or even French. On the other hand, she has almost saved the movie.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: RevenueSharing Program Praised and Denounced
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The nation's current $30.2billion Federal general revenuesharing program was praised and denounced at two Congressional hearings today, with municipal officials calling for its extension and representatives of civil  rights groups charging that it ignored antidiscrimination laws.

title: PORT UNIT SCORED ON TRADE CENTER
description: Two state legislators labeled yesterday as extravagant the plan, of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to spend $20million to outfit new restaurants at the World Trade Center, including $6million for a private club.

title: Trieste as Symbol
description: At a time when a cynical world is in crying need genuine statesmanship, Italy and Yugoslavia have contributed a worthy example. They have settled at last the Trieste question, which in the period immediately after World War II, when Yugoslavia was allied with Moscow, threatened not merely war between the two countries but conflict between the Soviet Union and the West. The recent settlement required political courage from both parties but especially from Premier Aldo Moro's shaky coalition; for Italy unquestionably made the greater sacrifice.

title: ABC and ExReporter in Dispute Over Nixon Link
description: The American Broadcasting Company is involved in a dispute with its former White House correspondent over whether the network kept too close liaison with the White House during the Presidency of Richard M. Nixon.

title: BLACK PUPILS SHUN SOUTH BOSTON HIGH
description: BOSTON, Oct. 8 (UPI)Two busloads of black students, protesting a lack of black teachers and policemen, refused to enter South Boston High School today, school officials said.

title: Contract Awards
description: A contract worth more than $130million has been awarded to the Dravo Construction, Ltd., subsidiary of the Dravo Corporation, by Sidbec. Montreal, for a sixmilliontonayear ironore pelletizing plant at PortCartier, Quebec.

title: Poland's Leaders Draft Austerity Steps and Worry About a Hostile Reaction
description: WARSAW, Oct. 1Poland's Communist leaders expect to have to perform some unpopular belttightening for their country soon and they are worried about the possible political consequences.

title: Cleanup of a 35,000Gallon Oil Spill Continues Here
description: Cleanup operations continued yesterday at an East River pier where a barge lost about 35,000 gallons of No. 4 heating oil after striking a submerged object near North Brother Island.

title: Officer Accused of Murder In Beating of Prisoner Here
description: A 26yearold Bronx police officer was indicted for murder yesterday following an investigation into the beating of a man who died of internal bleeding a few hours after his arrest for firing a shot at the police through his apartment door.

title: Memorial Services
description: GREENESamuel. Memorial service Tuesday, October 14, 5 P.M., Council of the Americus, 680 Park Avenue, New York City, 2nd Floor. In lieu of flowers contributions to Fundacion del Centavo, care of Council of the Americus will be appreciated.

title: India Cuts Communications Of Reuters and Its Reporters
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 8 (Reuters)The Indian Government today cut off the telex and telephone lines of the Reuters office in New Delhi and the home telephones of its three correspondents.

title: World Series Schedule
description: BOSTON VS. CINCINNATI

title: 10 MORE FOOD SPOTS TERMED VIOLATORS
description: The city's Health Department announced yesterday the names of 10 more food establishments that it said had failed to correct firstinspection violations at the time of a second inspection, and the results of final inspections of eight other establishments. They were as follows:

title: Woman Keeping Vigil at U.N. Collapses After Plea Fails
description: Sylva Zalmanson, a 30yearold woman who had been on a hunger strike and a daily vigil near the United Nations since Sept. 23, collapsed yesterday, sympathizers said, after receiving word that the Soviet Embassy had turned down her plea to visit her husband in a Soviet prison.

title: Ford Going to Detroit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) President Ford will hold regional news conference in Detroit Friday afternoon during a day of activity there that will include an address to a Republican fundraising dinner.

title: It's a Bird! It's a Plane! It's a PizzaEater!
description: TOPSHAM, Me.  It's been a poor year for fishermen on Casco Bay. The striped bass never made their migratory arrival in late May, June went by as quietly as if the winter ice had never left, and the balance of the year has run its arid course, leaving me bereft of the bass and blues that formerly fattened the menu.

title: Funds Given for Refugees
description: GENEVA, Oct. 8 (Reuters)The United States. Britain, the Netherlands and Sweden today announced new contributions to the United Nations High Commission for Refugees. The United States gift was more than $5million to an appeal for laid to displaced people in Thailand.

title: Meany in Absolute Control at Labor Convention; Gotbaum and Shanker Encounter Difficulties
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8From beginning to end, the man in charge of the justconcluded A.F.L.C.I.O. convention was George Mew, the only president the labor federation has ever had. At 81 years old, he was still in absolute control.

title: Show Biz Aiding Ailing French Hospital
description: French and Polyclinic Hospital, which has cared for hundreds of actors and actresses over the years, got a shot in the arm yesterday from one of Broadway's most famous lightsEthel Merman.

title: Tying of Safeguards to Aid Is Urged
description: Paul W. McCracken, a former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Richard M. Nixon, suggested yesterday that the Federal Government should play a role in helping New York City escape from its fiscal crisis.

title: Genesco Aide Is Set as Bonwit Chief
description: John Schumacher, who last August became president of the women's specialty store group of Genesco, Inc., will shortly be named chairman and chief executive officer of Bonwit Teller while continuing his present corporate assignment.

title: Article 4  No Title
Air Force Asks F.B.I. for Inquiry Of Northrop Fees
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)The Air Force has called in the Federal Bureau of Investigation to check into alleged overbillings by Northrop Corporation.

title: Felsenstein, Opera Director, Is Dead
description: Walter Felsenstein, the renowned opera director who headed the East Berlin Kornische Oper for the last 28 years, died yesterday of cancer in an East Berlin hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: DISPUTE PUTS OFF SYMPHONY SEASON
description: NEWARK, Oct. 8The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra has postponed indefinitely its opening concert of the season because of a breakdown in talks on a new contract with Local 16 of the American Federation of Musicians. The New Jersey State Council on the Arts formed a special committee to assist in seeking a resolution of the dispute.

title: Chess:
description: Since the final object of the game is checkmate, why not get down to it at once?

title: STATE AIDE DECRIES U.S. HEALTH PENALTY
description: A $2,275,110 Federal penalty, against New York State for asserted inadequate compliance with a preventive medicine program for children eligible for Medicaid was attacked yesterday by Stephen Berger, State Commissioner of Social Services, as clearly unwarranted and uncalled for.

title: Fantastic Jumping Victor
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Oct. 8 (UPI)  Fantastic, ridden by Susan Hutchison, took first place in the jumpers and thoroughbreds class at the International Forum horse show last night. Fantastic led the way over the jumps that ranged from 4 feet to 4 feet 9 inches, with spreads from four to six feet. In second place was Texas, ridden by John Simpson.

title: BUNGE IS GUILTY IN THEFT OF GRAIN
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 8The Bunge Corporation, one of the world's largest grain companies, was judged guilty today after pleading nolo contendere, o'r no contest, to two Federal counts of conspiracy in systematic thefts of grain and in a coverup of the thefts and was required to spend more than $2million over the next three years on procedures to guard against corruption.

title: U.S. Pioneer Chooses Scali, McCabe, Sloves
description: U. S. Pioneer Electronics, which spends more than $4million a year to advertise its highfidelity components, has just named Seali, McCabe, Sloves as its agency. It is the seventh piece of new business to come into the agency this year and Marvin Sloves estimates that the shop, which ended 1974 with $28.2million in billings, is now billing at an annual rate of $41million.

title: Scientists Say Collisions of 3 Continents Formed Asia
description: Chinese geologists, after scaling Mount Everest and roaming remote regions of Central Asia, have concluded  as have American scientists looking down from space  that Asia is the product of the collisions of at least three small continents. The pressure of one of them, the Indian subcontinent, is still crumpling and twisting the landscape.

title: MARTHA M'COY
description: Martha McCoy, a retired English teacher, died yesterday at Beekman Downtown Hospital. She was 74 years old and lived at 205 West 15th Street.

title: World Grain Supply Registered Decline For the Last 2 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) The world grain supply declined in the last two months with lower than expected output in the United States, the Soviet Union and Western and Eastern European countries, the Agriculture Department has reported.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW ADVANCES
description: Soybean futures advanced yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid a spate of rumors and confusing news.

title: OCCIDENTAL OIL ACTS TO HALT LIBYA SALES
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8 (Reuters)  The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, under a Libyan order not to export oil from that country, today cautioned customers against buying its subsidiary's products directly from Libya.

title: SAVING OUTFLOWS UP IN SEPTEMBER
description: Outflows from the nation's savings institutions, which began in August, apparently accelerated in September as depositors continued to move their money into higher interestearning investments elsewhere.

title: Escalators Installed By M. T. A. in Exit At Columbus Circle
description: It's the answer to my prayer, a very large woman sighed yesterday as she rode serenely up to street level in 36 seconds on one of the two parallel escalators just put into service at the Columbus Circle subway station.

title: Kenneth Anger In 4Film Show At the Whitney
description: At first impression, the films of Kenneth Anger seem unlikely candidates for the New American Filmmakers Series at the Whitney Museum of American Art. After all, the four films that opened there yesterday for a run through next Tuesday are scarcely the work of a film maker who is new in the sense of emergent.

title: RailFare Hearing Is Termed Illegal In Hempstead Suit
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 8The Town of Hempstead filed a suit in State Supreme Court here today against the Metropolitan Transportation Authority asking that its public hearing in August on a fare increase for the Long Island Rail Road he declared illegal because it failed to include its new offpeak ticket fares.

title: Montreal Trounces Kings, 90
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 8 (UPI)Guy LaFleur, Jacques LeMaire, Jim Roberts and Bob Gainey scored twice apiece tonight to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 90 victory over the Los Angeles Kings. It was the season opener for both teams.

title: Paper Strike in Canada
description: PORTAGE DU PORT, Canada, Oct. 8 (AP)A strike by 350 employes was called yesterday at the ConsolidatedBathurst pulp and paper mill here, bringing to 24.000 the number of Canadian Paperworkers Union members on strike across Canada.

title: Caldwell Sees Tobacco Road' in Cities Now
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 8  It has been 40 years since Franklin D. Roosevelt declared the South to be the nation's No. One economic problem and Erskine Caldwell teamed up with Margaret BourkeWhite to portray that problem poignantly in a book entitled, You Have Seen Their Faces.

title: Freeholders' Bribe Case Goes to Morristown Jury
description: MORRISTOWN, Oct. 8A Superior Court jury began deliberations late this afternoon to determine whether Donald A. Farinella and Edward Gola, two Passaic County Freeholders, accepted $7,000 in bribes to vote for the purchase of a commercial garage last year from Albert Scaletti.

title: Notes on People
description: After a 21month impasse, Earl J. Silbert was confirmed by the Senate yesterday as United States Attorney for the District of Columbia. The 84 to 12 vote came on a nomination that was first submitted by Richard M. Nixon and resubmitted three times by President Ford. Mr. Silbert has held the job on an acting basis since 1974.

title: Strutters
The
description: I cannot say just why you did it, you and all the others. The hunger for soil, yes, but there must have been deeper hungersthe eternal craving of man for rebirth, for the second chance.

title: HAMMER ACCUSED OF FOREIGN BRIBES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The former general manager of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's Venezuelan subsidiary has charged in a suit that Armand Hammer, the corporation's chairman, caused Occidental to pay more than $3million in bribes and campaign contributions to Venezuelan Government officials and political candidates.

title: Crude Oil Imports Rise Sharply In Anticipation of Higher Price
description: Crude oil imports climbed to a high level in the week ended Oct. 3 as the oil companies moved to import oil before the price increase by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
