title: 2d Threat on President Returns Man to Prison
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 8 (AP)A man who served five years for threatening to kill President Nixon got another fiveyear term today for threatening the life of President Ford on Aug. 15.

title: Susan Brandeis Gilbert Is Dead; Lawyer Was Daughter of Jurist
description: Susan Brandeis Gilbert, a lawyer and daughter of the late Associate Justice Louis D. Brandeis of the Supreme Court, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 82 years old, lived at 404 Riverside Drive and was the widow of Jacob H. Gilbert, also a lawyer.

title: Books of The Times
description: My last review was of a very difficult book one that attempted to explain nothing less than the origin and nature of human evil. Yesterday's Spy, by Len Deighton suggested a welcome change, a little resting on the oars while Mr. Deighton spunnot out of anthropology, sociology or psychoanalysis, but simply his own fantasyhis view of human evil. After the anguished conclusions of the scientist, the antic projections of the suspense writer. Everybody needs a vacation from the human condition.

title: WAKEMAN AND CHOIR PERFORM AT GARDEN
description: The last time that Rick Wakeman appeared at Madison Square Garden he surrounded himself with a choir and orchestraall the trappings of of a rock n roll event. But on Tuesday in the same hall, it was a slimmeddown Mr. Wakeman, just himself and seven other musicians, although he has not quite given up on excessplaying a total of 14 keyboards throughout the evening.

title: 2 Sides in Theater Strike Meet in New Bid to Settle It
description: The state's top mediator called negotiators for both sides in the Broadway musicians' strike to a meeting at the Americana Hotel yesterday in an effort to settle the dispute.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW ADVANCE
description: Stock prices showed a slight upturn on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, moving up 0.36 to 84.07 as measured by the exchange's index. Volume was 1,588,000 shares, up from 1,352,000. In the overthecounter market the NASDAQ industrial index closed at 81.23, up 0.80.

title: House Panel Voids IncomeTax Break For Gasoline Levy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) The House and Means Committee voted today to eliminate the Federal incometax deduction for state and Iocal gasoline taxes, now a savings totaling more than half a billion dollars for those who itemize deductions.

title: Ford Proposes Cut in Controls Over Airline Service and Fares
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 Charging that Federal regulations force American travelers to pay unnecessarily high prices for their tickets, President Ford asked Congress today to reduce Government economic controls over domestic airlines.

title: Viking Takes Aim at Namath
description: The man who leads the Minnesota Vikings in sacks of opposing quarterbacks said yesterday it would be sort of like an honor to dump Joe Namath on Sunday.

title: New Order of Rhetoric
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Back in 1971, when Israel's best friend in Africa was Uganda's Idi Amin, an Israelibuilt passenger jet was put at the disposal of the new leader, piloted by two Israelis.

title: Study Finds a Certain Stability in Life of Calcutta Street People
description: CALCUTTA, India  The pavement dwellers of Calcutta, who are widely regarded as among the most destitute people in the world, lead a much more stable life than previously believed, according to a study sponsored by the World Health Organization.

title: DOLLAR MOVES UP IN TRADING ABROAD
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 8 (UPJ)The dollar reversed a downward trend on most European money markets today, recovering part of the losses it has suffered this week. The price of gold fell to $139.25 an ounce, down from yesterday's $143.25 in Zurich and $143 in London.

title: About the Islanders...
description: With New York carrying 20 players, one more than can dress for a game, Ralph Stewart did not play.... Andy Ford of Bethel, Conn., a 24yearold shipping clerk, made a 36hour bus trip to attend the Islanders' opener in Kansas City.... Billy Harris was beginning his fourth N.H.L. season without missing a game. He has played in all 236 Islander games.

title: ARGENTINE ARMY ASKS BIGGER ROLE
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 8Two major leftwing guerrilla attacks against the Argentine Army in the last few days have spurred the military into demanding a greater role in government and have sharply increased pressure on the vacationing President, Isabel Martinez de Perlin, to resign.

title: SHOOTING ERUPTS IN LEBANON ANEW; AT LEAST 25 DEAD
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Thursday, Oct. 9The latest ceasefire between warring Christian and Moslem factions, proclaimed three days ago, was shattered early yesterday by heavy fighting here in the capital and in the northern part of the country.

title: Paperboard Capacity Estimate For This Year Is Cut by Group
description: The American Paper Institute reported yesterday that paper and paperboard capacity by the end of 1975 would be 1.4 million tons lower than it had estimated a year ago. Norma Pace, senior vice president of the trade association, said that the annual survey now placed total capacity of 67.4 million tons, down from the 68.8 million tons.

title: For Which We Stand: IV
description: BOSTON, Oct. 8Last summer Fidel Castro was asked by James Reston of The New York Times about efforts to export his revolution to the rest of Latin America, He answered that he was doing no exporting it was the United States that was exporting counterrevolution.

title: Article 1  No Title
BASIL BREWER DEAD; NEWSPAPER OWNER
description: CHATHAM, Mass., Oct. 8 (AP)Basil Brewer, former publisher of The New Bedford StandardTimes and other newspapers, died Sunday evening at his summer home here. He was 92 years old.

title: Yonkers School System Preparing to Lay Off 450
description: YONKERS, Oct. 8  The Mayor, City Council, City Manager and Board of Education failed today in an effort to raise the $3.8million needed to pay school teachers the 12.5 per cent raise called for in their contract, and as a result 450 employes of the Yonkers school distract may have to be laid off.

title: 52 Honest Pleasure Captures Cowdin
description: Horses with pleasure in their names added up to a lot of pair for formplayers at Belmont Park yesterday in the 53d running of the $55,950 Cowdin Stakes. Honest Pleasure, owned by Bertram Firestone, won the seven  furlong race for 2yearolds by eight lengths and Whatsyourpleasure finished second. Both are Floridabred sons of What a Pleasure.

title: The Met Foresees a Good Season After All
description: Last Thursday was gloomy at the Metropolitan Opera House. On the stage, Boris Godunov was being rehearsed. The peasants were in revolt. In the pit, drowned out by the clashing brasses and thundering drums, the musicians were crying for more bread.

title: The Met Foresees a Good Season After All
description: Last Thursday was gloomy at the Metropolitan Opera House. On the stage, Boris Godunov was being rehearsed. The peasants were in revolt. In the pit, drowned out by the clashing brasses and thundering drums, the musicians were crying for more bread.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI)The House Judciiary Subcommittee on Monopolies said today it would take testimony from Pete Rozelle, commissioner of the National Football League, and Ed Garvey, executive director of the N.F.L. Players Association on Tuesday. Representative Peter Rodino, Democrat of New Jersey chairman of the full Judiciary committee as well as of the subcommittee, said the scheduled session was part of a series of hearings held on a bill to protect the civil and constitutional rights of professional athletes.

title: UNESCO's Board Votes For Softer Stand on Israel
description: PARIS, Oct. 8The executive board of UNESCO voted overwhelmingly today in favor of softening the antiIsraeli action that the organization took last November. The board decided to recommend to the general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization that it adopt procedures that would make it more difficult for Arabs to keep Israel out of the agency's European regional group.

title: Jail for LoanShark Figure
description: BOSTON, Oct. 8 (AP)William Kazonis, described as a top man in the high levels of organized crime loansharking by United States Justice Department officials, was sentenced to eght years in prison in United States District Court yesterday. Mr. Kazonis, 39 years old, was convicted on charges of conspiracy and attempted extortion of payments on a loan to a Boston barber.

title: Caldwell Sees Tobacco Road in Cities Now
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 8  It has been 40 years since Franklin D. Roosevelt declared the South to be the nation's No. One economic problem and Erskine Caldwell teamed up with Margaret BourkeWhite to portray that problem poignantly in a book entitled, You Have Seen Their Faces.

title: Attach in Paris Shot
description: PARIS, Oct. 8 (Reuters)Spain's deputy military attach here was shot and seriously wounded today outside his apartment in a Paris suburb.

title: EUGENE MORI, 77, TRACK'S FOUNDER
description: Eugene V. Mori, a promoter who parlayed racetrack revenues into a multimilliondollar business empire, died yesterday after a long illness at a nursing home in Medford, N. J. He was 77 years old.

title: Islanders Gain 11 Deadlock With Scouts on Harris Tally
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 8The scoreboard at Kemper Arena held a warning for the visitors: Islandersa tidal wave is coming your way. The Kansas City Scouts were not as allenveloping as that, but they did cover the New York Islanders like a wet blanket tonight and held them to a 11 tie.

title: Vilas, Orantes Advance; Nastase Is Nearly Upset
description: MADRID, Oct. 8 (AP)Guillermo Vilas of Argentina heat a countryman, Ricardo Cano, 63, 64, in the third round of the $75,000 Madrid Open tennis tournament today.

title: FORD SEES TAXES AS A KEY '76 ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Key Ford Administration spokesmen made it clear today that President Ford expected his new tax and budget proposals to be a major issue in his campaign to retain the Presidency in 1976.

title: Grant to Meet With Its Creditors on Wednesday
description: The W. T. Grant Company has set next Wednesday as the date for the first formal meeting with creditors since the giant retail chain entered bankruptcy proceedings Oct. 2. Grant also reported yesterday a 17 per cent sales drop for the month through last Thursday.

title: De Marco Is Seeking Dismissal Of Charges in Nixon Tax Case
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8A defense attorney moved today for a dismissal of charges against Frank DeMarco Jr. on the ground of prosecutorial misconduct during the fourth week of Mr. DeMarco's trial here in Federal District Court.

title: Distiller Plans Expansion
description: The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to expand its U.S.L. chemical division production facilities and is arranging private placement of a term loan of $100million. This would be used along with other funds to finance new projects.

title: Chileans in Buenos Aires Occupy U.N. Office
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 8 (AP) Chilean refugees protesting against their living conditions in Argentina seized 14 hostages in the offices of the United Nations High Commission for Refuge?? here, then gradua?? released nine of them.

title: Civil Service Funds Asked WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI)
description: President Ford asked Congress today to give the Civil Service Commission $1.35million additional during the next 12 months. The budget director, James T. Lynn, said that the money was needed mainly to pay salaries and expenses for employes assigned to implement amendments to the Voting Rights Act of 1965 that extend coverage to nonEnglish speaking minorities.

title: In Memoriam
description: GRIFFINIn Portland, Maine, Auoust 24 Mrs. Mary B. Griffin, wife of Arthur ??. Griffin. Memorial Service Friary, October, 10 at 11:00 a clock at the First Presbyferian Church, Englewood, New Jersey.

title: Five Slain in Barcelona by Cross Fire Outside Police Station
description: MADRID, Oct 8  Five persons were killed in Barcelona today when they were caught in an exchange of gunfire, according to an official police account.

title: France Will Withdraw Military Mission in Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 8France will withdraw her military mission in Laos before the end of this year, the French Embassy here has announced.

title: PILLSBURY PUNS TO ADD FOOD UNIT
description: The Pillsbury Company, the Minneapolisbased producer of flour and baking mixes as well as an operator of fast food outlets, has agreed in principle to purchase Steak and Ale Restaurants of America, Inc., for $102 million in Pillsbury stock. The agreement involves the exchange of 0.318 shares of Pillsbury for each of the 4.2 million shales of Steak and Ale outstanding. If consumated, a total of 1.4 million Pillsbury shares would be exchanged . The deal, however, must be approved by directors and shareholders of both companies.

title: Isabelle Forst, ExOfficial Of City Schools, Is Dead
description: Isabelle Fitzsimons Forst, retired assistant superintendent of schools, died at her home in Roxbury, N.Y., on Saturday. She was in her eighties.

title: The Show Keeps Getting Better
description: Glen Baker and his brother, Howard, strolled down the aisle of Avery Fisher Hall Monday night, both resplendent in white suits. Glen wore his with an opennecked red and white sports shirt. His brother's had a matching vest, which he wore imaginatively over a black turtleneck shirt.

title: Show Is Produced With Touch of Class
description: Among many fanciers, the Talbot Kennel Club, on the Eastern Shore of the Chesapeake, and Mrs. Lane are synonomous. I stewarded at the first show Talbot held 17 years ago, said the Marylander. Since then, I've held every office in the club except treasurer.

title: City's Cash Shortage Imperils Plan for a Roosevelt Memorial
description: A monument to the President who led the country out of the great Depression of the nineteenthirties may become a victim of the recession of the seventies.

title: Reds 32 Favorites
description: RENO, Nev., Oct. 8 (AP)Harrah's Tahoe Racebook listed the Cincinnati Reds as 32 favorites today to beat the Boston Red Sox in the World Series. The Reds were made 65 favorites to win the opening game.

title: Patrol Cars Under Study After Policeman's Death
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 8 (AP)The Baltimore Police Department has removed 200 Plymouth patrol cars from active duty and started an investigation to determine if exhaust system defects have contributed to the death of one officer and the hospitalization of another.

title: FOOD STAMP CURBS URGED BY BUCKLEY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) The present condition of the Federal food stamp program is a dire threat to the American treasury and an affront to every American who labors unaided to feed his family without government assistance, Senator James L. Buckley, Conservative, Republican of New York, said today

title: Escalators Installed By M.T.A. in Exit At Columbus Circle
description: It's the answer to my prayer, a very large woman sighed yesterday as she rode serenely up to street level in 36 seconds on one of the two parallel escalators just put into service at the Columbus Circle subway station.

title: Hopes for an Easing on Credit Indicated
REAGAN DRIVE OPENS IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 8Supporters of Ronald Reagan for President opened New Hampshire headquarters today for the former California Governor to start his expected early primary challenge agains President Ford.

title: BUNGE IS GUILTY IN THEFT OF GRAIN
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 8The Bunge Corporation, one of the world's largest grain companies, was judged guilty today after pleading nolo contendere, or no contest, to two Federal counts of conspiracy in systematic thefts of grain and in a coverup of the thefts and was required to spend more than $2million over the next three years on procedures to guard against corruption.

title: Ford Proposes Cut in Controls Over Airline Service and Fares
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Charging that Federal regulations force American travelers to pay unnecessarily high prices for their tickets, President Ford asked Congress today to reduce Government economic controls over domestic airlines.

title: Two Women Drown On Outing of Aged At Greenwood Lake
description: Two women drowned in Greenwood Lake yesterday when a cabin cruiser carrying a group of elderly people swerved suddenly and capsized.

title: Sinai Plan Advances
description: The House approved the stationing of American technicians in Sinai by a 341to69 vote. The measure was also being considered by the Senate where many amendments are pending. Page 7.

title: New Law Requires Special Equipment To Aid Handicapped
description: TRENTON, Oct. 8 (AP)New Jersey took another step today to aid the handicapped, as Governor Byrne signed laws to require special equipment for handicapped persons in new or renovated buildings.

title: Professional Boards Are Criticized
description: PARAMUS, Oct. 8A warning to consumers to he aware of the influence that professional boards, ranging from physicians to morticians, have on the lives of most people has been voiced by Virginia Long Annich, director of the State Division of Consumer Affairs.

title: CITY UNIONS WEIGH A GENERAL STRIKE
description: Leaders of the city's municipal labor unions said yesterday that they would consider a general strike to protest the threeyear wage freeze and potential layoffs called for in the financial plan Mayor Beame has proposed to the Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: Litton Unit Scanner Device
description: The Sweda International division of Litton Industries introduced yesterday a new optical scanning device for use at supermarket checkout counters. The machine is said to be able to read accurately the new universal product code symbols for market products regardless of the position of the products as they pass over the scanner at the checkout counter. The new scanner is slated for customer use in mid1976. It will sell for about $3,950.

title: 8 Convicted as Members Ring a Drug Ring for Blacks
description: Eight members of what Federal officials have called the largest drug ring in the country selling to blacks were found guilty yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn of conspiring to import, distribute and sell millions of dollars worth of cocaine and heroin.

title: City Opera: Season's First Lescaut
description: Manon Lescaut is one of those works of definite though modest appeal that lurk at the fringes of the operatic repertory, never really out of favor and yet never attaining oldchestnut status, either. The season's first performance of Puccini's third opera Tuesday night by the New York City Opera at the State Theater made plain its enduring charms while not disgdising its crippling weaknesses.

title: MISLEADING ADS LAID TO JAY NORRIS CORP.
description: The Federal Trade Commission yesterday charged a leading mailorder advertiser, the Jay Norris Corporation of Freeport, L.I., with unfair, deceptive and misleading business practices.

title: Lebanon Valley Coach
description: ANNVILLE, Pa., Oct. S (AP) Frank Satalin, assistant basketball coach at Le Moyne College, was named head coach today at Lebanon Valley College. Satalin succeeds Pete Wilhelm, who died Sept. 22.

title: SENATE REJECTS SLUSH FUND CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The Senate disapproved by a single vote today a proposed regulation of the Federal Election Commission that would have held all members politically accountable for money they spend from private, socalled office accounts while they are seeking reelection.

title: N.A.A.C.P, DROPS L. I. ZONING SUIT
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 8The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which charged in a suit more than four years ago that the Town of Oyster Bay's zoning ordinances barred blacks from living there, has withdrawn the suit, John W. Burke, the Oyster Bay Supervisor, said today.

title: The Stage: Quality Takeover Trend
description: The other day a suggestion was made that there should be a special Tony award given each year for the best takeover performance, male or female, of the Broadway season. It could appropriately honor what has become a major trend on Broadway in recent seasons the extremely high quality of replacement casts.

title: Potomac Awakening?
description: A sense of urgency finally appears to be developing in Congress on the need for swift Federal action to head off default by New York City, with all its disastrous consequences for the national economy.

title: 8 Counties Show Losses in Population
description: Population losses for five New Jersey counties between 1970 and 1974 have been reported in new Federal census data. Three other counties were said to have had such losses between 1973 and 1974.

title: Crash of Army Helicopter Kills Four and Injures Six
description: FORT CARSON, Colo., Oct. (UPI)An HU1H Army helicopter crashed into a steep ravine on a routine training mission yesterday, killing four soldiers and injuring six others.

title: 19% Drop Reported For U.S. Merger Plans
description: Thirdquarter merger announcements declined 19 per cent to 527 from 654 last year, according to a report yesterday of W. T. Grimm & Co., Chicagobased merger consultant. In the first two quarters of this year respective drops of 34 per cent and 21 per cent were recorded.

title: Article 2  No Title
Listing to Starboard
description: Sergio Segre, head of the Italian Communist party's foreign affairs section, inquired discreetly of the American Embassy in Rome last month about obtaining a visa to attend an international conference and speak at a dinner given by the Council on Foreign Relations in New York. He was given a signal that a visa application would be rejected.

title: Saigon May Export Rice
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam. Oct. 8South Vietnam reaped good rice harvest this year and the country might become rice exporter next year, officials at the Agricultural Sciences Institute reported today.

title: About the Jets . . .
description: As far as Coach Charley Winner is concerned. Fran Tarkenton is a son of a gun and I'd like to see him outlawed. . . . David Knight may see action Sunday. The scar on the wide receiver's knee is slightly red. They tell me when it's white, I'll be perfect, he said. The cuts he makes when he runs patterns are 60 per cent mental and 40 physical, he added. . . . Some fans might have wondered if Emerson Boozer was used as a messenger once during the Patriot game. He went in and out before a play was completed. When he went on the field, the team was in a shortyardage situation, in which he would be used as a blocking back. However, the team had been penalized 5 yards. End of shortyardage situation. . . . Carl Barzilauskas has the flu, but it won't keep him out of the Minnesota game.

title: MANFRED ROSENTHAL
description: Manfred Rosenthal, retired supervising accountant for the Multnomah County, Ore., Department of Judicial Administration, died Tuesday night following a heart attack in (Portland, Ore., where he lived. He was 67 years old.

title: Beathard Joins Raiders
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct, 8 (AP)Pete Beathard, a quarterback with several teams in the National and World Football Leagues, joined the Oakland Raiders today and Larry Lawrence, who had been the backup man to Ken Stabler, was placed on the N.F.L. injured reserve list. Lawrence will undergo surgery to repair a knee injury suffered Sunday at San Diego. He started the game in place of Stabler, with had a minor knee injury.

title: Reamon of Express Hurt
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 8 (UPI)  Tommy Reamon. Jacksonville Express running hack and the World Football League's most valuable player in 1974, was hospitalized today with a partlycollapsed right lung. We put Tommy in the hospital today and he'll remain there at least through the weekend. the team physician. Dr. Charles Mabry, said. It's a probability he'll miss up to three weeks, and a possibility he could be out the rest of the season.

title: Nets Top Knicks in TuneUp
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 8The Knicks and the Nets played 48 minutes of basketball tonight to find out which players won't be around when the regular season opens. The Knicks have to cut three players and the Nets six.

title: Personal Finance: BankDepositor Lures Widen
description: The opening of a new office of a financial institutionparticularly of a savings and loan association or savings bankhas long occasioned promotional hoopla. Extensive advertising, circuslike decorations at the branch and particularly gifts of merchandise are often featured to lure additional customers.

title: Charge of Attack Renewed
description: DARWIN, Australia, Oct. 8 (Reuters)An official of Portuguese Timor's Fretilin faction said tonight that Indonesian, forces temporarily overran the border town of Batugade but were later driven out by Fretilin troops.

title: 5 Women Raped in Apartment; West Side Police Hunt 4 Youths
description: Four youths are being sought in the alleged rape of five young women in their West Side apartment early last Sunday.

title: U. S. Bonds Post Mild Price Gain; Stocks Rise in a Active Session
description: Prices advanced in more active trading in the stock market yesterday, with glamour and bluechip issues leading the upturn.

title: Article 6  No Title
CUBA, IN U.N., HAILS PUERTO RICO UNIT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8Cuba's chief delegate told the General Assembly today that the movement for the independence of Puerto was an admirable example of national resistance said his Government would not reduce its support of the movement to improve its relations with the United States.

title: Pact Ends Teacher Strike Against Catholic Schools
description: Lay teachers voted last night to end their fiveweek walkout against five high schools in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and return to work this morning.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The New York Times last Tuesday erroneously identified The Frederick (Md.) News and Post as one of six nonunion newspapers in the Washington area that have been printing The Washington Post during a strike against The Post by union pressmen. The Frederick newspaper has not been assisting The Post.

title: Fred Morrison Dies at 69; ExAide of G.O.P. Committee
description: OLDTOWN, Md., Oct. 8 (AP) Fred W. Morrison, a former radio and television newsman and director of public, relations for the Republican National Committee, died today at his home here. He was 69 years old.

title: Cohn Attacks Lesser Plea By a Suspect in Extortion
description: Roy M. Cohn yesterday challenged pleabargaining accepted by the Manhattan District Attorney and the city's Criminal Court judges, who allowed a New Zealand seaman, who had allegedly confessedto felony charges of extortion and grand larceny, to plead guilty to a misdemeanor.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: An offering of one million new common shares of the Rochester Gas and Electric Company, at $15.375 a share, was completed yesterday by underwriters headed by First Boston Corporation and E. F. Hutton & Co.

title: Advertising
description: Most artists feel about their works much as mothers feel about their children. And the artists of advertisingthe copywriters and art directors who supply the words and graphicstre usually just as proud and protective about their creations.

title: FORD SEES TAXES AS A KEY '76 ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Key Ford Administration spokesmen made it clear today that President Ford expected his new tax and budget proposals to be a major issue in his campaign to retain the Presidency in 1976.

title: Moscow Says U.S. Is Silent on Spain Because of Bases
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 8The Government newspaper Izvestia charged today that Washington cynically withheld criticism of Spain's executions of terrorists last week to obtain an agreement on American military bases there.

title: Herstatt Creditors Will Get 30% More
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, Oct. 8 (Reuters)Bank and local authorities that are creditors of Bankhaus Herstatt, K.G.A.A., will be paid a further 30 per cent of their settlement quota around the end of October or early November, the settlement manager and liquidator said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: Yesterday's editorial, . . . Not Serious Program, erred in failing to note that the Administration had in fact readjusted its budgetary figures to reflect the inclusion of Social Security and other trust fund outlays.

title: Hartford National Corp. Posts $18.3Million Loss for Quarter
description: Unfavorable real estate operations produced a thirdquarter loss of $18.3million for the Hartford National Corporation, the parent company of the Hartford National Bank and Trust Company reported yesterday.

title: BURNS EASES VIEW ON FEDERAL ROLE IN CITY'S CRISIS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today softened his opposition to Federal intervention to ease New York City's fiscal crisis and proposed five guidelines for Congressional action.

title: SWISS SAY NORTHROP DIDN'T PAY COMPANY
description: BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 8 (Reuters)The Swiss Defense Ministry denied today that the Northrop Corporation paid a Swiss company to insure that Switzerland placed a contract for its F5E Tiger fighter planes.

title: Market Place
description: Critics of efforts by Dominion Textile, Ltd., to merge with DHJ Industries, Inc., say they are baffled by a $5.6million DHJ loss for the fourth fiscal quarter ended May 31 reported to shareholders in materials concerning the merger plan.

title: NAVY IS DISPUTED ON NEW LIGHT JET
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  A Senate subcommittee heard sharply divergent testimony today on the proposed F18 lightweight Navy fighter from admirals backing the project and the Grumman Aerospace Corporation, struggling against heavy odds for increased F14 orders.

title: Technical Snags in City Delay Implementation of Pay Freeze
description: The modified wage freeze for municipal employes decreed by Mayor Beanie to take effect Sept. 1, has still not been imposed for most of the affected workers, city officials said yesterday.

title: Two Defense Bills Totaling $34.6Billion Signed by Ford
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 8 (UPI) President Ford signed defense bills today authorizing spending of $34.6billion for new weapons and military construction and authorizing women for the first time to enter military service academies.

title: Joffrey Performs Robbins's Export With Snap and Brio
description: Jerome Robbins's New York Export Op. Jazz served as a choreographic sketch for West Side Story much as his first ballet, Fancy Free, did for On the Town. They both were steeped in their respective milieus yet Export seems dated, while Fancy Free has the lovely niche of an authentic period piece. The difference is 15 years, which says a lot about our perception of time but little about the worth of the dances. The City Center Joffrey Ballet presented Export for the first time this season on Tuesday evening, at its 55th Street Theater.

title: AllMale Direction Of Schools Upstate Deplored by Nyquist

title: Energy Authority Proposal Under Broad Attack
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The Ford Administration's proposal to create a powerful new $100billion energy authority has developed so many opponents attacking it from so many directions that it is given little chance of being approved by Congress. According to interviews with Senators, Representatives, Congressional staff aides and knowledgeable industry officials, the critics include environmentalists worried about pollution, liberal Democrats opposed to giving handouts to big business, philosophic conservatives concerned about the growing power of the Federal Government, fiscal conservatives worried about the possible threat to the free flow of capital and oil state representatives uneasy about assisting energy competitors.

United asked for removal of restrictions requiring that flights serving Pittsburgh and a point west of Chicago also serve Chicago.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9 (AP)Miss Hearst's lawyers today withdrew a request to Federal District Court Judge Oliver J. Carter to appoint their own psychiatrist to examine her.

title: U.S., Soviet Remain at Odds on Grain

title: Nixon Plays Golf With Fitzsimmons At Resort Built With Teamster Loans

Nixon emerged from his seclusion at San Clemente today to play golf in a tournament that has drawn the high command of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and some men indentified by law enforcement sources as linked to organized crime.

title: National Academy of Design Celebrates Its 150th Anniversary
description: Academician is not nowadays a title that confers instant and unquestioned honor. It suggests, on the contrary, something staid and reactionarya point of view suspicious of all change and firmly resistant to its disruptive effects. To be academic in an age that has seen the avantgarde given every reward for its assault on the pieties of the past is, at best, a dubious fate. The moment would not seem propitious, then, for the National Academy of Design to be celebrating the 150th anniversary of its founding. And indeed, had this anniversary occurred 10 years ago, or even five, it would likely have met with a dim and ironical response. Cultural life in the nineteensixties, whatever its special merits, was not famous for creating a climate favorable to the disinterested appreciation of tradition.

title: NYQUIST REPEATS TUITION PROPOSAL
description: State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist yesterday repeated, in stronger terms than before, his call for the imposition of tuition at the City University.

description: A 15yearold boy was stabbed to death yesterday in a dispute between two groups ofl youths at a Bronx bus stop yesterday.

description: PORTLAND, Ore. Oct. 9 (AP) The Federal Government has authorized payment of $29,289 so far to tourists plagued by gastrointestinal illness after visiting Crater Lake National Park while its water supply was contaminated last summer.

description: Paul O'Dwyer wore a tuxedo and a determined air of lowkey amiability.

The fact that the drowning of more than 100,000 porpoises a year is incidental to the taking of an important foodfish, the yellowfin tuna, serves only to point up the irony.

We're prepared to offer $14million for the Giants and to build a sports complex in the city of San Jose for operation of the franchise, said Gordon Eldridge, senior vice president of American Funding Company of Beverly Hills, Calif., today.

Both the city and state face possible default and insolvency, with ripple effects being felt already in cities and states around the country. The future has become the subject of unabashed speculation, much of it contradictory, from experts in and out of government.

description: Following is a transcript of President Ford's news conference in the Executive Office Building in Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: A. Rothstein and the World Series
description: Thirtyfive years have passed since the first and last time the Cincinnati Reds won an honest World Series. They have represented the National League seven times in the past, but only in 1940 did they win by their own efforts. They also won in 1919 by the efforts of eight members of the Chicago White Sox, thereafter designated as Black Sox. Most accounts of that business venture say Arnold Rothstein put up the money to bribe Chick Gandil, Eddie Cicotte and their playmates but it is probable that Rothstein participated only as a bettor. He knew about the fix, but had refused to bankroll it. We now hear from Phil Bieber, who knew Rothstein well.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Judge Dismisses Charges Against Nixon Tax Lawyer
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9Federal District Judge Warren J. Ferguson dismissed today all charges against Frank DeMarco Jr., the former tax attorney for Richard M. Nixon, on the ground that the conduct of the Watergate Special Prosecutor had deprived Mr. DeMarco of a fair trial.

title: Senate Confirms Kleppe as Interior Secretary
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) The Senate confrimed tonight President Ford's nomination of Thomas S. Kleepe as Interior Secretary.

title: TV Picks Jets Over Giants But Neitheris Picked to Win
description: Two of the best quarterbacks in pro football, Joe Namath and Fran Tarkenton, will be on view on the same television screen Sunday afternoon when the Jets play the Minnesota Vikings. Channel 2, the CBS station here, will televise the game rather than Channel 4, which turned that privilege back to the National Football League because of a conflict with its presentation of the World Series from Boston. The N.F.L. in turn offered the game to Channel 2, which took it, preferring the event in Minnesota to the Giants against the Dallas Cowboys before a sellout crowd at Shea Stadium. The Giants do not lose any money because of the defection, merely prestige.

title: Philadelphia Prosecutor Faces Hearing on Ethics
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 When F. Emmett. Fitzpatrick walked into Courtroom 2 in the old Federal Building here this morning, it was not as a man entering unfamiliar territory.

title: Peace Scientist
description: In the summer of 1953, the Soviet Union exploded the world's first hydrogen bomb, the first deliverable weapon based on thermonuclear fusion. That Soviet feat spurred the arms race as have few other events before or since; and it would have seemed unthinkable then that the Nobel Peace Prize could ever be bestowed on one of the key scientists responsible for that Soviet achievement. Yet the award yesterday of the Nobel Peace Prize to Academician Andrei D. Sakharov will certainly receive universal approval outside the Soviet Union, especially in the United States.

title: 'The Master Gunfighter," From Makers of 'Billy Jack' Films
description: "The Master Gunfighter" starts with a procession of riders filmed in slow motion on a Pacific beach. The camera speeds up after a bit, but the picture never does. It is long, stilted, self-conscious, badly acted and boring. Apart from that, there is little to recommend itMade by the people who made the vastly successful "Billy Jack" movies, it is a dim and grandiloquent account of how one group of the oppresseda Mexican ranch family overtaken by the United States acquisition of California  massacres another group of the oppressedthe Indians.It is done, of all reasons, to get hold of the Indians' gold in order to pay United States taxes. From the standpoint of the crack-brained brand of mystical individualism preached in the Billy Jack pictures, taxes would seem to be a wicked thing and one is to feel sympathy for the desperate lengths to which the Mexicans are driven as well as for the Indians.Not too much sympathy, though. Up rides the Master Gunfighterplayed by Tom Laughlin, who also played Billy Jackand ends up massacring just about everyone in sight. He does it as much with a sword as with his 12-shooter revolvereven the revolver is exaggeratedand he does it reluctantly, sighing. With each sigh, about 17 people perish.After avenging the dead Indians and preventing a second massacre he literally rides off into the sunset followed by his wife, who happens to be one of the few survivors of the Mexican ranch family.The sword fighting seems to be patterned on stylized Japanese movements. The dialogue sounds as if someone had translated it from the Japanese, too. Some of the photography is arresting, but mostly it manages to make the splendid California coastline look stuffy.

title: Now In New York
description: Boy have I got news for you! There's II be no more brainrattling trying to decipher stock market quotations from now on. I stumbled across my own little public brokerage firm at lunch hour last Wednesday! You know where? At the Chicago Restaurant at 407 Park Avenue (between 54th & 55th), right in the heart of Rig Business City. All the real savvy guys  those threepiece suited types who've made the move up from the street to civilized midtown  come into Chicago regularly and let their hair down. And if you position yourself strategically, either at the bar or in the upstairs dining room, you can catch an earful as I did! And believe me, a reliable tip on how to get that dollar to stretch is a welcome treat nowadays. But be discreet  sit down, relax, enjoy a Chicagostyle executive lunch which will hardly make a dent in your wad! And even if you don't find yourself on Easy Street come morning, you'll have had the supreme satisfaction of dining at Chicago the restaurant which makes you feel like a millionaire without spending like one.

title: About New York

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Tenants who can prove that their landlords did not take reasonable precautions to safeguard them can recover damages from the landlords when they are the victims of theft, the State Supreme Court ruled unanimously yesterday, upholding lower court decisions that awarded $6.100 to Nathan and Olga Braitman of West New York from their landlord, the Overlook Terrace Corporation. The court agreed with the Braitmans that Overlook had been negligent in failing to fix a defective lock the couple had reported in need of repair eight days before a burglar broke into their apartment and stole property worth $6,100.

title: The Pop Life
description: Dickie Goodman is a nervously affable man from West New York, N. J. He admits to being 39 years old, and for nearly 20 years he has been cranking out a particular kind of novelty pop record. The format is always the same  a spot news announcer pretends to be on the scene at some momentous happeningthe landing of a flying saucer or the encounter of Superfly and Shaft or the marauding of a giant, killer shark. And then the announcer asks the participants a series of questions, and their responses consist of manic snippets from currently popular hits.

title: Consider the Armadillo
description: Try to imagine the quality of life of the people of New York City if every man, woman and child suffered from malaria. 40 per cent had tuberculosis, one in 30 were afflicted with leprosy, and 4 in 10 children died before age 5 from measles. This is the quality of life, differing only in detail, endured by 500 million people in parts of Africa, Asia and Latin America.

title: Enough Is Enough

Yet, according to F.B.I. documents recently obtained by the Socialist Workers' party in a lawsuit against the bureau, some Cointelpro techniques were being employed at least as late as December, 1973.

title: National Academy of Design Celebrates Its 150th Anniversary
description: Academician is not nowadays a title that confers instant and unquestioned honor. It suggests, on the contrary, something staid and reactionarya point of view suspicious of all change and firmly resistant to its disruptive effects. To be academic in an age that has seen the avantgarde given every reward for its assault on the pieties of the past is, at best, a dubious fate. The moment would not seem propitious, then, for the National Academy of Design to be celebrating the 150th anniversary of its founding. And indeed, had this anniversary occurred 10 years ago, or even five, it would likely have met with a dim and ironical response. Cultural life in the nineteensixties, whatever its special merits, was not famous for creating a climate favorable to the disinterested appreciation of tradition.

title: In 'Sweet Movie,' Politics With Syrup
description: "Sweet Movie," Dusan Makavejev's fifth feature film, which was the major scandal at the 1974 Cannes Film Festival, has finally arrived in New York (at the D. W. Griffith Theater) with approximately four of its more scatalogical minutes removed. The excision makes the film easier to sit throughless aggressively idiosyncratic  while the over-all work remains a courageous example of a personal kind of film making that, to me, leads nowhere."Sweet Movie," like Mr. Makavejev's "WR: Mysteries of the Organism," is a collage movie, with a structure that its producers describe as "open and nonauthoritarian . . . made up of nonverbal elements." This is a fairly intimidating way of saying that if you find it heavy-handed, obscure, unfunny, boring, self-indulgent and not terribly stimulating on any level, there's something wrong with you, not the movie.For a film so full of concern for the political and social sanity of man. "Sweet Movie" is, paradoxically, litist. If one doesn't share Mr. Makavejev's knowldege of the history of Communism and Reichian psychology, much of it is incomprehensible.What are comprehensible are the two intercut lines of visual action, both having the style of political cartoons. The first follows the farcical adventures of a Miss Canada (Carole Laure) who is married by Mr. Kapital (John Vernon), discarded by him when she objects to the manner in which he gets his sexual kicks, then is subjected to numerous fates worse than death and, when last seen, is being dunked in a vat full of chocolate syrup for a TV commercial.The second, which is much more vivid, furious and compellingis a political metaphor: a barge named the Survival, which carries a huge, papier-mach likeness of Karl Marx on its prow, steams through the canals of a European city. Its captain (Anna Prucanl) stands on Marx's brow, luring innocents abroad. Her principal victim is a young, ever-optimistic sailor (Pierre Clementi) off the Potemkin, whom she eventually destroys.As Mr. Makavejev has brilliantly demonstrated in his earlier films  particularly "Man Is Not a Bird"he can make films of comparatively conventional form if he wants to. Now he obviously doesn't want to. This independence of spirit is laudable, but when it involves the large amounts of money that apparently went into "Sweet Movie," it begins to seem decadent. Too much money is being spent for the benefit of the few."Sweet Movie" rolls around in foodmostly sugar, eggs, milk, chocolate syrupto such an extent that one's mind wanders from the intellectual concerns of the director to the logistics of the film making. When Miss Prucanl and Mr. Clementi make love in a bed full of sugar, one forgets the metaphor and starts to worry about how they got all that sticky stuff off after the scene was shot. On two occasions male actors urinate onscreen, once in a close-up. Is this real or were some sort of devices used?When the audience begins to wonder how an effect was achieved instead of why it has been done, a film's claim to seriousness flies out the window. "Earthquake" and "The Towering Inferno" made no such claims. "Sweet Movie" doesand fails.

description: Senator Henry M. Jackson charged last night that the Ford Administration was waging civil war on New York City because the Administration had decided to write off New York for political purposes.

title: World Series Schedule
description: BOSTON VS. CINCINNATI

title: State Outlines View on Coma Patient
description: NEWARK, Oct. 9The New Jersey Attorney General's office outlined today for the first time the arguments It is prepared to use in opposing a petition to turn off the respirator that is sustaining Karen Anne Quinlan.

title: City's Fiscal Ills Spur Retirement Rush
description: The city's fiscal crisis has been accompanied by a rapid increase in retirement applications by municipal employes a doubling from policemen, in recent months and a tripling from firemenin what officials consider a reaction against the prospects of curtailed pension enrichments and harder working conditions.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: We're small enough to give you personal, oldfashioned service on any domestic or foreign car of your choice... with abase to fit your particular needs.

title: Nixon, Just Fine but Looking Tired, Golfs With Teamsters' Fitzsimmons
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., Oct. 9In a rare public appearance, former President Richard M. Nixon emerged from his seclusion at San Clemente today to play golf in a tournament that has drawn the high command of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and some indentified by law enforcement sources as linked to organized crime.

title: British Tories Shift to the Right
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 9The more than 3,000 Conservative party members gathered here have moved substantially to the right in a bid to get control of the Government for their party's new leaders.

title: Belmont Entries
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Labor Government Accepts Ruling on Crossman Diaries
description: LONDON, Oct. 9The Labor Government announced today that it would not appeal the decision of the High Court to permit publication of the first volume of the late Richard Crossman's diaries.

title: U.S. and Soviet Explore SpaceMonitoring Pact
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 9Soviet and American space officials have been exploring the possibility of exchanging ground equipment to enable the two countries to monitor data directly from each other's weather and research satellites.

title: VLADIMIRN. NICHOLS
description: Vladimir N. Nichols, who retired as acting assistant city transportation administrator in 1973, died Tuesday in Boulevard Hospital, Astoria, Queens. He was 67 years old and lived in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Algeria Raises Her Oil Price by $1 to $12.75 a Barrel
description: ALGIERS, Oct. 9 (Reuters)Algeria has increased the price of her crude oil by $1 to $12.75 a barrel, effective Oct. 1, following a decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise oil prices, the official news agency, A.P.S., said today.

title: Deaths
description: ADELMANDavid, beloved husband of Ber nice, devoted father of Judith Bacher, dear brother of Dr. Arthur Adelman, Malcoins Adelman, and Dorothy Adelman, cherished grandfather of Jane Bacher. Services Sunday, Oct. 12, 11 A.M., The Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Books of The Times
description: The international sport of digging up the past is played by amateurs and professionals, novelists and archeologists, and is eagerly followed by readers and trippers. Modern journeys are pursued in search of Periclean rather than postjunta Athens. Remove the Roman Forum and you are left with Roman inflation. The Mediterranean stretches from the Menorah to the Minoan civilization, neither of which is threatening to NATO or the Warsaw Pact or other reminders of the troubled present. Homer's winedark sea and words flow over the broken shards of our time, infinite links to the wars and glories of the Western heritage.

title: President Disapproves Marijuana, Praises Son
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 9President Ford said tonight that he did not approve of young people using marijuana. but he called it a very honorable thing for his 23yearold son, Jack, to have acknowledged psing it.

title: Textbooks Vary on Blacks' Life
description: NEW ORLEANSIn October, 1974, an extraordinary revisionist history book for high school students was published. Mississippi: Conflict & Change is the only state text in Mississippi that documents the recent years of the civil rights movement and sociopolitical changes.

title: Said to Flee Jersey
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 9 (UPI) The F.B.I. said today that Peter Fittipaldi of Goshen in Cape May County and Margaret Turcich of nearby Delanco were believed to have left the state.

title: TWINS ARE SEIZED IN WEST SIDE RAPE
description: Eighteenyearold twin brothers were arrested yesterday on charges of raping five young women in a West 70th Street apartment early last Sunday.

title: International Paper Net Is Off 39% in 3d Quarter
description: Earnings of the International Paper Company were down 39 per cent in the third quarter and 27 per cent in the first nine, months, the world's largest paper producer reported yesterday. Sales fell 7 per cent in the quarter and 1 per cent in the nine months.

title: Article 3  No Title
MSGR. PATRICK J. BARRY
description: Msgr. Patrick J. Barry, who retired in 1966 as pastor of St. Kevin Roman Catholic Church in Flushing, Queens, and was formerly rector of the Immaculate Conception Seminary in Huntington, L.I., died Tuesday in the rectory of the church. His age was 89.

title: U. S. RELIEF FUNDS FOR PORTUGAL DUE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The Ford Administration has prepared an emergency economicaid package of more than $80million for Portugal, a high State Department official said today.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Rosenbaum in G.O.P. Post
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) Richard M. Rosenbaum, the New York Republican chairman, was named today chairman of the Republican State Chairmen's Association. He succeeded John W. McDonald of Iowa, who resigned.

title: PRESIDENT SEES NO JUSTIFICATION FOR HELP TO CITY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 President Ford said tonight that he could not see any justification for the enactment of legislation to bail out New York City and that he did not believe Congress would pass such legislation.

title: Fare Rise Hit Buses Harder Than Subway,M.T.A. Says
description: Public buses lost one eighth of their passengersfar more than the subwaysduring the first full month of the new 50cent fare compared with the same period in 1974, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority disclosed yesterday.

title: U.S. Lifts Crop Estimates; Ban on Polish Sale Ended
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 10The Agriculture Department released today a new estimate of record corn and wheat harvests that appeared to be large enough to accommodate resumed grain sales to the Soviet Union.

title: Farm Incomes Drop
description: New York State farmers suffered a 23 per cent drop in net income in 1974 and the downward trend is continuing this year, according to the New York Crop Reporting Service. Page 32.

title: For Sakharov, New Hope
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 10  The award of a Nobel Peace Prize to Andrei D. Sakharov has given his crusade for demo cratic reform new impetus. cheered his embattled fellow dissidents and presented the Kremlin with a headache un, pike any since Aleksande I Solzhenitsyn was expelled 20 months ago.

title: It's One, Two, Three Strikes, You're OutLocked OutBy Exploitative Capitalist Bosses
description: As the superpowers of East and West (mid) begin competing for hegemony today in Boston here is how the Soviet press might report the class significance of the World Series.

title: Nearby Golf Results
description: AT DELLWOOD C. C.

title: School Districts' Deadline For Session Cuts Expires
description: The deadline for the city's 32 community school districts to comply with the central Board of Education's orders for them to cut two class sessions a week passed yesterday, but the central board refused to disclose how many districts had failed to meet the 3 P.M. deadline.

title: Summit Talks on Economy Set in Paris
description: PARIS, Oct. 10President Ford and the leaders of several other major Western nations will hold a threeday economic summit conference in the Paris area Nov. 15 through 17, it was announced today in Paris and Washington.

title: T.W.A. Pilots Win 7% Raise But Won't Collect for a Year
description: The 3,500 pilots for financially pressed Trans World Airlines have won a 7 per cent wage increase but they will wait a year before collecting it.

title: $20Million Loan to Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan. Oct. 10 (Reuters)The United States will lend Pakistan $20million dollars for a fiveyear malaria control program under an agreement signed today. The lowinterest loan is repayable over 40 years, with a 10year grace period.

title: A.W.J. van der Mije Marries Marie B. Lee
description: BethesdabytheSea Episcopal Church in Palm Beach, Fla., was the setting yesterday evening for the marriage of Marie Brenda Lee to A. W. J. van der Mije of New York. The Rev. John G. Macort Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Memo Pads That Underwrite a Cause
description: Bloomingdale's will, very soon, make the act of spending money a virtue.

title: Pessimism Increasing on Debt Of State as Complications Rise
description: Concern over the outlook for the securities of New York State, once a proud tripleA that commanded the unquestioned respect of investors, has intensified as the result of the state's growing involvement in New York City's fiscal crisis.

title: So. Connecticut Victor
description: DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 10 Ed Swicklas, the quarterback, ran for two touchdowns and passed for a third tonight as Southern Connecticut College scored a 216 victory over Western Connedticut.

title: Delius Village Romeo Is Staged by City Opera
description: Frederick Delius's A Village Romeo and Juliet, that strange dreamlike pastoral tragedy, was never destined to become a popular work. It is dramatically too fragile and musically too undulant and ruminative to stir the average listener. It had to wait almost threequarters of a century after it was composed to get a staging here, two years ago by the New York City Opera.

title: Emanuel Davis, Cartoonist, Helped Create Terrytoons
description: Emanuel Davis, a pioneer in animated cartoons, who was long associated with the late Paul H. Terry in creating Terrytoons, with Mighty Mouse and the crows Heckle and Jeckle, died Thursday in New York Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in the Benjamin Franklin Hotel.

title: Cordier Memorial Set
description: A memorial service for Dr. Andrew W. Cordier, 15th president of Columbia University and former Under Secretary to the Secretaries General of the United Nations, will be held Tuesday at 4 P.M. in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia. Secretary General Waldheim is scheduled to speak. Dr. Cordier died July 11.

title: New Yorkers Chided By Ford on Officials
description: DETROIT, Oct. 10 (Reuters) President Ford today suggested that New Yorkers should be more careful in the future in choosing their representatives in city government.

title: Brooklyn 41, Manhattan 22
description: Gerry Wright, a freshman, scored two touchdowns tonight in the leading Brooklyn College to a 4122 victoryover Manhattan, in a Met Eight Conference game at the winner's field.

title: U.S. Crop Estimates Rise; Ban on Polish Sale Ended
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 10The Agriculture Department released today a new estimate of record corn and wheat harvests that appeared to be large enough to accommodate resumed grain sales to the Soviet Union.

title: Dublin to Free Prisoners
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 10 (Reuters)The Irsh Government tonight announced an amnesty for, 84 prisoners to mark the canonization next Sunday of Oliver Plunkett, the first Irish saint or more than 700 years.

title: $18Million Effort Revives A Onetime Utopia in Indiana
description: NEW HARMONY, Ind.Helen Elliott, a retired school teacher whose voice and movement belie that she was a child when the 20th century was born, sat in a corner of her large living room surrounded by books and periodicals and talked about utopia.

description: ALBANY, Oct. 10New York state farmers suffered a 23 per cent drop in net income in 1974 and the downward trend is continuing in 1975, according to figures released here today by the New York Crop Reporting Service.

title: Prices of Stocks Seesaw And Close Down by 0.63
description: The stock market yesterday went through what might best be described as a nothing day.

title: Rangers Win, 21, In Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 10Mark it down, Ranger fans: Tonight the Rangers took first place in the Patrick Division of the National Hockey League.

title: Once Again At Greece's Helm
description: ATHENS  Constantine Caramanlis readily acknowledges to friends that the most impressive man he ever met was Charles de Gaulle. The first time he saw the generalwhen the Greek statesman was Premier and not yet a political exile in Paris  de Gaulle guided him to a chair, sat across from him, hands folded across his stomach, and said: I am listening. What do you want?

title: SIX POLICE GUM IN A GRAFT SETUP
description: Six police sergeants have pleaded guilty in departmental proceedings to participation in an illegal, grafttaking sergeants club between 1967 and 1971 in the 114th precinct in Astoria, Queens, department officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Hoax Theory in mystery Of Hoffa Case Is Debated
description: DETROIT, Oct. 10The mysterious disappearance of James R. Hoffa has spawned another mystery.

title: Ford Sends Congress Plan for $100Billion Energy corporation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10President Ford sent Congress today a plan for a $100billion Government corporation to help finance projects to make the United States independent of foreign sources of energy by 1985.

title: 91 and 180 Day Notes Show Yield Decline
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities. The average rate for the threemonth bill was 6.045 per cent, down from 6.239 per cent for the preceding week. The average rate for the sixmonth bill was 6.243 per cent, down from 6.571 per cent for the previous week.

title: Preseason Basketball
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: For Sakharov, New Hope

title: PORTUGUESE CITY HAS A NEW CLASH
description: LISBON, Saturday, Oct. 11Portugal's coalition Government warned yesterday that it would punish those responsible for the escalation of violence, especially by members of minority political groups.

title: ECONOMIC UPTURN SEEN CONTINUING
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 10 (AP)The nation's recovery from recession will continue through 1976, the Business Council forecast today, but corporate leaders said a major economic shock such as the bankruptcy of New York City could upset the comeback.

title: GRAINS STEADY; REPORT AWAITED
description: Wheat, corn and soybean futures continued to show little change yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as traders awaited the important Department of Agriculture crop report due after the close of trading. Most guessed correctly that crop estimates would be raised from September levels.

title: MANY HERE WATCH FORD NEWS PARLEY
description: President Ford's news conlerence Thursday night had an audience of approximately 2.5 million in the New York area, according to the Nielsen overInight ratings for this area. The national ratings will not be available for several days, but projections by Marvin Mord, vice president of research for ABCTV, are that the televised news conference reached a total audience of around 46 million viewers nationally.

title: Contract Awards
description: A new fiveyear contract has been concluded by Avis, Inc., with the Chrysler Corporation for Avis to lease Chrysler models for the majority of its rental fleet, it was announced yesterday. The agreement, runs until Aug. 31. 1980, and replaces one that would have expired in 1977. It calls for Chrysler to reimburse Avis for a portion of the advertising find promotion that features Chrysler cars. The dollar value of the contract was not disclosed.

title: Austin Stevens Dies at 58; ExReporter for The Times
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Austin Stevens, a former reporter for The New York Times, died here today in Veterans Hospital. He was 58 years old.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Transportation Commissioner, Alan sagher, said yesterday that passage of the $600million transportation bond issue would ease the financial burden on counties and municipalities throughout the state. Besides relaxing the financial squeeze, he said, the bond issue would make possible significant improvements in local road and public transit facilities. Of the $600million, $100million would go towards local road projects, he said, adding that it would not be used for maintenance, which would continue to be the localities' responsibility.

title: DRIVE UNDER WAY ON CHARTER VOTE
description: A group that described itself as nonpolitical and nonpartisan promised yesterday to do battle against City Hall to press for changes in the City Charter.

title: SmallTown Kansan Set To Head Big Bank Group
description: At latest count, the village of Lucas in the central Kansas grain belt had 595 citizens. One of them was J. Rex Duwe, who as president of the Farmers State Bank there is a leading local businessman.

title: Wallace Prepares For European Trip To Show He Is Fit
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 10Gov. George C. Wallace is scheduled to head for Western Europe late tomorrow on a twoweek trip that he hopes will convince voters that he is healthy enough to run for President and well informed not only on national but also on international issues.

title: Missing Pilot's Mother Told of Charge for Data
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI)The Air Force has told the mother of a pilot shot down over North Vietnam that she must pay $14.25 for documents relating to his disappearance, Representative Patricia Schroeder said today.

title: A.T &T. Purchases Madison Ave. Site For Possible Office
description: The American Telephone & Telegraph Company disclosed yesterday that it had acquired for $18million a site on Madison Avenue on which it is considering building a new corporate headquarters.

title: Top Spot Is Likely to Hinge On Oklahoma  Texas Again
description: If Oklahoma manages to beat Texas by a point in their annual football warfare in the Cotton Bowl today or if Texas wins by a point, the result will be much more impressive than an Ohio State victory over Iowa by 50 or 60 points. So it is possible that the Sooners or the Longhorns could jump over Ohio State into the top position in the national rankings if you go by the Woody Haves theory.

title: Times Square: Zoning
description: The question about the Times Square area is not why it hasn't been cleaned up, but why it hasn't been cleaned up before this. The issue is not what can be done, but why it hasn't been done yet.

title: Democrats Elect Nominee For Tennessee House Seat
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 10Clifford Allen, the 69yearold NashvilleDavidson County tax assessor and former State Senator, won easily the House nomination yesterday to fill the Fifth District House vacancy caused by the resignation of Richard Fulton.

title: S.M.U. Sends T.C.U. To 15th Loss in Row
description: DALLAS, Oct. 10 (AP)A freshman safety, David Hill, tipped away a 2point conversion pass and returned an intercepted pass for a touchdown late in the fourth period tonight, carrying Southern Methodist to a 2813 Southwest Conference victory. It was Texas Christian's 15th consecutive loss.

title: Scores on WQXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given over WQXR, on the 6 P.M. news broadcast and in other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times for scores; the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and radio station.

title: Nicklaus, Weiskopf Score
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 10 (AP)  Jack Nicklaus and Tom Weiskopf each won $8,000, Johnny Miller $5,000 and Lee Trevino drew a blank today in a $1,000ahole exhibition among four of pro golf's leading career moneywinners.

title: Series Opens in Boston Today; Reds UP Against Wall and Tiant
description: BOSTON, Oct. 10  The Oakland A's were absent for a change, but the Great Wall and baseball's balk rule were present today with intrigue and controversy as the Cincinnati Reds and Boston Red Sox braced to open the World Series tomorrow in 63vearold Fenwav Park.

title: DATSUN RAISES COST OF '76 MODELS 4.9%
description: Nissan U.S.A. has raised the price of its 1976 Datsuns, which will go on sale next week, an average of 4.9 per cent, or $179, above the price of the 1975 Datsuns, the company announced yesterday.

title: Judge Frees Rep. Hinshaw Of Eight of 11 Charges
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Oct. 10 (UPI)A superior court judge has dismissed eight felony charges against Representative Andrew J. Hinshaw, Republican of California, but ordered Mr. Hinshaw to stand trial next month on three remaining bribery counts.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Westchester Is Ending Free Juror Lunches
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 10The free lunch continued its dedine as a Westchester institution today with an announcement that jurors, begining Nov. 3, will pay for their ow midday meal.

description: Horses listed in order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing FIRST$8,000, cl., 2YO, 6f.

title: Fahmy of Egypt Reports Ford May Meet Syrian
description: CAIRO, Saturday, Oct. 11 (UPI)Egypt's Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy said today that American and Syrian officials were seeking to arrange a meeting between President Ford and President Hafez alAssad to discuss the possibility of a second SyrianIsraeli disengagement agreement on the Golan Heights.

title: ARTHUR C. HILLMAN
description: Arthur C. Hillman, a former Mayor of East Paterson, N. J., and president of Hillman Golfland, Inc., of Elmwood Park, N. J., died Thursday in Miami. He was 76 years old and lived in Elmwood Park.

title: Day With Soares: History and Politicking
description: COIMBRA, Portugal, Oct. 10At the end of a long, frenetic day Wednesday, the Socialist leader, Mro Soares, and a carload of aides pulled into the one roadside restaurant that was still open on the way back to Lisbon.

title: Rail Carloadings Off 5.5%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The Association of American Railroads reported yesterday that Freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled 16.5 billion tonmiles, the highest level in more than 10 months, but 3.8 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same week totaled 506,097 cars the first time this year the loadings have exceeded the 500,000 mark. Carloadings however were 5.5 per cent below the corresponding week of 1974. The American Trucking Association, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 9.4 per cent below last year.

title: 2 Columbus Parades Rekindle Protests
description: As many as 150,000 people will troop up Fifth Avenue to. morrow and Monday in honor of Christopher Columbus, and the prospect has rekindled protests from residents along the parade route.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Antiques: Country Sale
description: Long before the sale opened yesterday morning, it was standing room only in the auction tent behind Giraldo, the turnofthecentury chateau in Madison, N.J., that was the late Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge's home for 62 years.

title: An Action by Spinola
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 10Former Portuguese President Antonio de Spinola announced today that he had called on the United Nations and the Red Cross to help evacuate those Portuguese in Angola who want to leave, to avoid one of the most barbarous genocides in modern history.

title: Other Games Today
description: Home teams are listea first

title: RANDOLPH NEWMAN, REPARATION LAWYER
description: Randolph H. Newman, a New York lawyer who specialized in reparation cases, died Thursday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 1 Gracie Terrace.

title: Board of Estimate Blocks Funds to Finance Agency
description: Three members of the Board of Estimate last night blocked la complicated state plan to save the Housing Finance Agency from default, saying that they wanted concessions from the state for the striking tenants of Coop City before they would allow $20million in state money to be channeled through Coop City to the finance agency.

title: Naumburg String Contest Is Won by Elmar Oliveira
description: Elmar Oliveira, a 25yearold violinist, was named winner of the string competition conducted by the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation in Carnegie Hall yesterday. His prize includes $1,500, two recitals in Alice Tully Hall and a management contract with the Judd Concert Artist Bureau. He has been a pupil of Raphael Bronstein at the Manhattan School of Music.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLUMENTHAL Mimi., Your birthday, dear Mimi you are with me deep in my heart and thoughts forever. With all my love.

title: Ford Sure of Solution
description: DETRIOT, Oct. 10 (UPI) President Ford called the disappearance of James R. Hoffa a very strange case today, but said he was optimistic on prospects that the Federal authorities would solve the mystery.

title: Wings and W.F.L. Face Crisis
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 10 (UPI)Another financial crisis in the World Football League apparently has been put off until pay day arrives next week. The San Antonio Wings, which W.F.L. owners have said was the pivotal team in the crisis, agreed to play against the Portland Thunder in Oregon. Sunday despite the team's financial troubles. Monday is payday and the team then will decide whether to accept or reject a 25 per cent pay cut management said was necessary to get through the season.

title: 10 Refugees Free Argentina Captives And Fly for Algeria
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 10 (AP) Ten Chilean and Brazilian refugees freed five hostages tonight from a United Nations office and later boarded an airliner with seven of their relatives for a flight toward asylum in Algeria.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Friday Oct. 10, 1975 CHICAGO GRAINS

title: MISS FROMME GETS A NEW COCOUNSEL
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 10 (UPI)  Lynette Alice Fromme was given a new cocounsel today, but a Federal judge denied her request to visit the Federal Bureau of Investigation office to look at news film of her allegedly trying to assassinate President Ford.

title: Amex Index Dips; Counter Market Is Mixed at Close
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange weakened in quiet trading yesterday, while prices in the overthecounter market (finished mixed as volume there also fell.

title: Halting Respirator on Woman in Coma Is Homicide, Brief by the State Holds
description: MORRISTOWN, Oct. 10Opposing legal briefs were filed in Superior Court here today In the fight over the life of Karen Anne Quinlan, the young woman in a coma.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.5 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 205.3 from 205.8 last week.

description: PARIS, Oct. 10Poland is considering buying commercial jet aircraft from Western manufacturers, including the McDonnell Douglas Company or the Boeing Company, Commerce Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton said at a news conference today.

title: Article 1  No Title
Art: Fresh Drawings by Soyer
description: The paintings of Raphael Soyer have many admirers, but the present writer is not among them. Sometimes touching in the attitudes they depict, these paintings, suffer, in my view, from two conspicuous weaknesses. In feeling they are unrelievedly banal, and in their painterly surfaces they lack a requisite vitality. Looking at Mr. Soyer's paintings in the past, I have often thought: Yes, life is frequently as dull as that, but must art add to he sum of such dullness?

title: Nero Fit as Fiddle For Pace Tonight
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 10 The $154,222 Messenger Stakes, with a 10horse field, provides the major item tomorrow night as Roosevelt Raceway concludes its 72program meeting with Nero, as the headline pacer.

title: SIMON PLAN CALLS FOR SHIFT M LAW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10A key element of the plan of Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon for meeting New York City's financial problema moratorium, of stretching out of the city's debt would require a change it the country's bankruptcy law. Mr. Simon has said.

title: Walk Readjusts His Thinking To Fill a Bid Role With Knicks
description: While the Knickerbockers wait for the Wilt Chamberlain trial balloon to burst or take off in California, Neal Walk is tending to basketball business in New York.

title: Byrne Nominates Capt. Pagano As State Police Superintendent
description: TRENTON, Oct. 10 (AP)Capt. Clinton L. Pagano of Milford was named by Governor Byrne to be the superintendent of the New Jersey state police. He is 97 years old and a 23year veteran of the force.

title: 3 DEMOCRATS RUN CAMPAIGN DEFICIT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Financial pressures on the large field of Democratic Presidential candidates are threatening to narrow the competition even before the election year opens.
