title: Reaction in the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) Senator Russell B. Long, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said today that there was no way Congress could pledge in advance a $28billion spending reduction, to offset President Ford's proposed tax cut.

title: NOW Banking
description: One certain result of banking legislation now before both houses of Congress would be a widening of consumer choiceand institutional competitionin personal banking habits. Less certain, but worth anticipating all the same, is a potential enlargement of the pool of funds available for mortgage lending in the nation's cities.

title: Market Place
description: A number of growthoriented mutualfund managements have added bond funds to their array of investment vehicles within the last two years to take advantage, of the high yields available in fixedinterest securities relative to those in the stock market.

title: RABBIS ANNOUNCE NEW PRAYER BOOK
description: The rabbinic organization of American Reform Judaism yesterday announced the publication of its first new prayer book in 80 years. The book, issued by the Central Conference of American Rabbis, has more Hebrew prayers than its predecessor and takes cognizance of the Holocaust and the establishment of the State of Israel.

title: Issel Trade Is Discussed By A. B. A.
description: A meeting of the American Basketball Association board of trustees here broke up yesterday without any clear indiction that accord had been reached on the Dan Issel trade.

title: GRANT WARDS OFF CHAPTER X MOTION
description: A Federal judge yesterday dismissed a motion to shift the bankruptcy proceedings of the W. T. Grant Company from the voluntary Chapter XI provisions to Chapter X, in which a court  appointed trustee would administer the company's affairs.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: TODAY, OCT. 11

title: Orantes And Vilas Defeated
description: MADRID, Oct. 10 (AP)Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, Manuel Orantes of Spain and Ilie Nastase of Rumania, the three topseeded players, were defeated today in the quarterfinals of the Madrid Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: Phone Company To Provide Scores
description: The New York Telephone Company will provide World Series scores on Sports Phone. The number is 9991313.

title: Welfare Cases Upstate Increase 16.5% While Rising 3.5% Here
description: Upstate New York welfare caseloads soared 16.5 per cent in number of recipients and 33.4 per cent in costs for the first half of this year compared with a year ago. The rate of increase far surpassed New York City's rise of 3.5 per cent in numbers and 9.7 per cent In costs.

title: Big Parade Displays Taiwan's Weapons On National Holiday
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 10 With an earshattering display of locally produced jet fighters, helicopters, tanks and artillery, Taiwan celebrated today its first national day without its longtime leader President Chiang Kaishek.

title: People in Sports
description: I hope my enthusiasm will rub off, it always did everywhere else I managed, said Dave Bristol yesterday after he became the eighth manager of the Atlanta Braves since they moved south from Milwaukee in 1966. Bristol, 42 years old, managed at Cincinnati from 1966 to 1969 and at Milwaukee from 1970 until May, 1972. He signed a oneyear contract.

title: Occidental Bribe Report Halts Venezuelan Talks
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 10Venezuela's President, Carlos Andres Perez, ordered last night an immediate halt to..talits on nationalization compensation between the Occidental Petroleum Corporation and the Government until reports about an alleged bribery of Venezuelan officials were clarified.

title: Screen: 'Lisztomania':It's Ken Russell's Spangled Post-Beatles Rococo and Manic Look at Composer
description: Ken Russell blows up his colored balloons with ether: They bob prettily, and when they burst we pass out."Lisztomania," which opened yesterday at the Ziegfeld, is the latest of his spangled flights of fancy. Fancy it is, but hardly a flight.It is a tiny, potentially appealing weed of a picture, absurdly dragged down by a mass of post-Beatles rococo. For Mr. Russell, the shortest line between two points is a pretzel, preferably painted gold and doped.It is a pity. For the first half-hour or so, Mr. Russell's treatment of Franz Liszt and Richard Wagner as the pop stars of their day is manic and extremely funny. Then it relapses into a noisy bit of pretentiousness in the manner of its predecessor, "Tommy": full of flashing lights, satin spacesuits, chrome-lucite furniture and mock agony.The opening scene with Lisztplayed by Roger Daltrey, the star of "Tommy"making love to a countess to the beat of a rhinestone metronome is of limited appeal. But things improve when the count comes in. Liszt and his mistress are strapped inside a piano while the count gleefully pounds out one of the noisier Liszt pieces. "Perhaps this will teach you not to bang on the piano," he chortles.The next scenes show Liszt, rendered in Mr. Daltrey's best Liverpudlian accents, at the height of his pop-star success. One takes place in a crowded musicians' cafe. Mendelssohn is putting down an admirer: "Music, shmusic; it's a living." Rossini circulates with a tray of chicken. "Eat or you'll get sick," he tells Berlioz. Infantile, but it works.So does Liszt's concert scene. The place is packed with 19th-century groupies. Liszt strikes a chord, and he's mobbed by hundreds of berserk yellow bonnets.Then Liszt goes to Russia to look up one of his loves, the Princess Caroline, and the movie founders. There is a repulsive scene in her antechamber in which Liszt belts out a rock number while circled by some voracious-looking women. It culminates with a spidery Princess Caroline presiding over a feigned sexual mutilation involving an enormous plastic phallus.Nothing improves after that. Richard Wagner appears as Liszt's arch-rival, a kind of Nazi Antichrist, with his own groupie cult. Lisztby this time he has become a priestis sent by the Popeplayed by Ringo Starrto destroy him.Liszt breaks into Wagner's turreted castle and does him in by playing "Liebestraum" at him on a fire-belching piano. Before Wagner dies, however, he creates a Nazi Frankenstein's monster, and it takes Liszt, in a celestial rocket ship, accompanied by all his mistresses, to destroy it.To the degree one chooses to find symbolism in all this, it is ludicrous. Equating Wagner's music with Nazism in this fashion is absurdly simplistic. It is even more absurd to set up Liszt's music as some kind of counterforce to Wagner's, let alone one that is capable of overbearing it.Now it can be argued that Mr. Russell, with all his dazzle, is not intending, but aping symbolism. Or that he is not so much being pretentious as mocking pretention. Try mocking a quicksand by somersaulting artistically into it: The rate at which you sink is just the same, and only your closest admirers will be interested in pulling you out.

title: Snub Angers Disney Golf Director
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 10 (AP)Bobby West, the Walt Disney World golf director, attacked some of the biggest names in golf today for forsaking American tournaments in favor of foreign events. He was angered by the decisions of Jack Nicklaus, Tom Weiskopf and Lee Trevino to bypass the $200,000 national team championship at Disney World later this month for tournaments in Australia and Japan. The players ... made their money and stardom here and their allegiance should be to sponsors on the United States tour, West said. He also expressed his anger to the Professional Golfers' Association commissioner, Deane Bentan, in a telephone call.

title: Ginseng Root Is a Minor Cash Crop for Georgians
description: BLAIRSVILLE, Ga.  The ancient Chinese believed that ginseng, the manroot, was born one summer night when lightning struck a mountain stream, transforming it into heavenly fire in the form of a man, and that the stream then burst from the ground to serve as a cure for all mankind's illness.

title: Wallace Prepares For European Trip To Show He Is Fit
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 10Gov. George C. Wallace is scheduled to head for Western Europe late tomorrow on a twoweek trip that he hopes will convince voters that he is healthy enough to run for President and well informed not only on national but also on international issues.

The unaudited figures also showed a profit for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 of $5.4million, or $3.20 a share, contrasted with a yearearlier loss of $7.2million.

title: Art: Met Showing Master Drawings
description: In any great museum the department of prints and drawings is one to which visitors are likely to respond with a peculiar poignancy. Drawing is the exposed nerve of art. Drawings by their very nature are fragile. Through the centuries there has existed a fraternity of drawings fanciers, and we communicate with them in an unprovable but entirely authentic way by following the ins and outs of their preferences. The sight of a particular collector's mark on a drawing is not only a proof of excellence; it also means that the sheet in question fired a particular imagination and thereafter kept great company.

title: Screen: Lester's 'Royal Flash' Opens
description: Harry Flashman is not quite a scoundrel. He is, rather, a hero who is thoroughly, irretrievably flawed. He lies and cheats. He's chicken-hearted. He's vain. When the going gets tough and the tough get going, Harry flees or, if all exits are closed to him, he hides. When caught, he cries. Once, during a battle in the Crimean War, when his side was losing, Harry almost broke his neck trying to surrender. The thing about Harry is that whatever he does, he does hard.As played with fine, manic intensity by Malcolm Mc-Dowell in Richard Lester's new comedy, "Royal Flash," Harry can't even smile straight. The corners of his mouth go up in the expected fashion but in the middle of it there's a misplaced leer. Ever optimistic, Harry keeps his leer at the ready, even though he's the sort who loses when playing strip poker with a girl.Harry Flashman is good comic company and "Royal Flash," which opened yesterday at the Coronet, is good comic fun. The screenplay is by George MacDonald Fraser, based on his novel about the adventures of the young English Army officerpart rogue, part twitwho romances Lola Montez and finds himself up to his neck in Bismarck's schemes to unite the German princely states.Though "Royal Flash" is set in the mid-19th century, the manners and morals look very much like those of Mr. Lester's "The Three Musketeers" and "The Four Musketeers," the two films he made out of the Dumas novel with screenplays by Mr. Fraser.If the seams between the gags are beginning to show in "Royal Flash," and if the pace seems occasionally a little less than breathless, it may be due as much to our expectations ofand our familiarity withthe Lester method as to any lack of invention on the part of the film makers.Mr. Lester throws away more gags in "Royal Flash" than some comedy directors think up in an entire career. Now and then you wish he'd take time to develop a routine a little more, to give it a classic beginning, a middle and an end, instead of rushing on to the next sequence. He is profligate with his talents, which is, of course, very much a part of the method of any Lester comedy.Another part is the impeccable casting. Charlton Heston was never better in "Ben-Hur" than he was as Cardinal Richelieu in the "Musketeers" films. There are no plums of such size in "Royal Flash," though Mr. McDowell is very good, and actors like Alan Bates, Oliver Reed and Florinda Bolkan give the enterprise heft it might otherwise lack.One typical Lester sequence: Lola Montez (Miss Bolkan) dances before Ludwig of Bavaria, who is enchanted with her, though not as history has told us, because of her shape or her beauty. Giggling with pleasure, he asks, "Are they real?" Being mad, Ludwig means the cardboard spiders that she uses as props in her dance. It's low-comedy and almost nonstop.

A general 10 per cent rate rise was granted the railroads earlier this year, but that did not include an increase on recyclable goods.

description: Peter Serkin not only is one of our more gifted younger pianists but has long been a leader in protesting the stale traditions and customs of modern concert life. When he appeared as soloist with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night, for instance, he typically wore his hair tied back, Siouxfashion, and he sported an outsized, multicolored necktie. The orchestra and Pierre Boulez look pretty stuffy in their black ties and drab dinner jackets.

Oct. 10The police chief of suburban Jefferson County said today that he had made a strong recommendation to the Secret (Service last week that planned visit to Louisville by President Ford be canceled because of possible security risks posed by crowds of antibusing demonstrators.

title: Issue in Turkish Vote Tomorrow: To Save the Old or Pursue the New

When he was asked to name the most important issue in the elections Sunday for part of the Turkish Senate he said: I want the winner to be true to God, then to his successor, Mohammed, and then to the nation.

The cigarette idea is an outgrowth of a machine he patented in 1969 to test the effects of tobacco smoke on animals. Cancer was found in some hamsters.

title: Film: 'Sidecar Racers'
description: Australia may be photogenic, its young men may be daring, and speeding motorcycles can be thrilling, but "Sidecar Racers," which roared into local theaters Wednesday is merely scenic and noisy about its racers and their cycles. Aside from its uncommon views of the dangerous, Australian two-man sport of sidecar motorcycle racing, the film is familiar melodrama, no more exciting than its uninspired story and largely native cast.The script by an Australian novelist, Jon Cleary ("The Sundowners," etc.) involves a visiting American, Ben Murphy, playing a onetime Olympic swimming champion as the sidecar passenger who teams with an Australian cyclist, John Clayton, to win the big race. Naturally, there's also some offtrack romantic rivalry between them for Wendy Hughes, daughter of the other American in the cast, Peter Graves, playing a tire tycoon who makes a few token appearances before they all reach the finish line.Even though there are clashes between some tough guys and our heroes and a couple of tragic crashes, "Sidecar Racers" leans heavily on its thunderous racing footage, which eventually becomes a mite redundant. Although the handsome, boyish Mr. Murphy chooses to give up both his chances of glory and the girl to the dark, properly resentful Mr. Clayton, they both emerge as sincere but slightly sophomoric figures. Miss Hughes, however, appears to be a spoiled, indecisive prize, hardly worth all their wrangling.Under Earl Bellamy's pedestrian direction, Australia is colorful but hardly worth the trip, even in those rocketing racers.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Following is a table showing New York City's per capita expenditures and public employment per 10,000 population, with an adjustment for the fact that New York City provides many public services that are paid for in other locations by a county or state government. The figures are those of the Congressional Budget Office.

title: Israel Signs Protocol Of New Pact on Sinai
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 10Israel today signed the protocol of the new Sinai accord with Egypt and set in motion the process that will lead to her withdrawal from some 1,900 square miles of occupied Egyptian territory over the next five months.

title: COST FOR STADIUM PUT AT 66MILLION
description: On the basis of the latest estimate of the total cost to the city of buying and rehabilitating Yankee Stadium, the Budget Bureau yesterday put the price tag at $66.4millionor $42.4million more than the original estimate in 1971 by Mayor John V. Lindsay and almost $10million more than has already been spent.

title: Inquiry. Urged in Selling of Degrees
description: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 10A black candidate for Governor has demanded an investigation of what he called selling of degrees by the recently resigned director of records at the largely black Jackson State University.

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: 1975. by Triangle Publications, Inc. The Daily Racing Form)

title: Newark Airport Shifts Runway in Use, Nullifying Jet Noise Tests in Elizabeth
description: ELIZABETH, Oct. 10A microphone dangled from a firetruck ladder beside the black slate church steeple, and on the street below a mobile noisetesting laboratory from the State Department of Environmental Protection was poised to record the sounds.

title: INQUIRIES AFFECT SHAPP CAMPAIGN
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 10Although still embryonic, the (Presidential candidacy of Milton J. Shapp is already taking on some familiar trappings.

title: Sinai Pact Stirs Misgivings Among Arabs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 3Many Arab diplomats, scholars and journalists outside Egypt, believing that the Sinai agreement has crucially weakened the Arab side, are convinced that the pact will prove an obstacle to peace rather than a step toward it.

title: Probable LineUp For Series Opener
Retail Sales Rose in Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The Department of Commerce reported today that departmentstore sales last week were an estimated $1.16billion, up 6 per cent from the yearearlier $1.1billion. Total retail store sales were about $11.77billion, up 10 per cent from last year's $10.73billion.

title: U.S. to Sell 60 Jets to Seoul
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (Reuters)The Defense Department said today it intended to sell 60 advanced F5 jet fighters to South Korea for $205million. Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger visited South Korea last August to discuss a strengthening of the armed forces.

title: M.I.T. Examines the Life Of a Saintlike Woman
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 7Simone Well is not in the calendar of saints, and nothing save the example of her life seems likely to put her there.

title: CANADA PLANNING TO HELP ECONOMY
description: OTTAWA, Oct, 10The Canadian Government is planning a farreaching economic recovery program that is expected to include steps to restrain wage and price increases and cut back on government spending.

title: ??r in Nassau Puts OldFashioned Skills on Display
description: OLD BETHPAGE, L. I., Oct 9People still make things with theirhands. People still grow vegetables in their gardens. People still took specialties from recipes handed down from their ancestors.

title: U.N. GIVES STATUS TO ISLAMIC GROUP
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 10The Islamic Conference, a group of 42 countries with a common religious and cultural heritage, gained permanent observer status in the United Nations today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LAST CALL Tomorrow will be the final opportunity this season for New Yorkers to go aboard the 106foot sloop Clearwater for an afternoon festival of food and entertainment, as she berths at Pier 15 near the South Street Seaport Museum, 16 Fulton Street. Proceeds will go to the boat's traditional Hudson River cleanupactivities. The event is admissionfree but apples, apple cider and assorted homebaked goods will be on sale. Folk singing will continue throughout the afternoon, starting at 1 o'clock.

title: Seoul Committee Approves The Ousting of Legislator
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 10A parliamentary committee of South Korea's National Assembly today approved a motion seeking to oust an opposition legislator who criticized president Park Chung Hee and his policies on the assembly floor early this week.

title: Israelis Prepare to Quit Last Post on Suez
description: OUTPOST BUDAPEST, Occupied Sinai, Oct. 6Viewed through the shimmering heat waves rising off the salt flats, the outpost has the low, hulking shape of a Mayan temple. Its ziggurat profile bristles with slowly twirling radar antennas and thick coils of barbed wire. In the distance, the apartment towers of Port Fuad and Port Said poke into the midday haze.

title: Spain Is Bolstering Civil Guard Units To Fight Terrorism
description: MADRID, Oct. 10The Spanish Government announced the appointment of a tough new commander for the nation's paramilitary civil guard as part of increased efforts to suppress terrorist violence.

title: GEORGE H. BUNYAN
description: George H. Bunyan, retired senior vice president of the RoyalGlobe Insurance Companies, died yesterday in Darien, Conn., where he lived. He was 64 years old.

title: Port Authority Will Aid Development of 3 Cities
description: TRENTON, Oct. 10The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has approved an agreement under which the agency will undertake a project aimed at revitalizing the economic and industrial capacity of Newark, Jersey City and Elizabeth.

title: Amid Sniping and Burning Buildings, Lebanese Seek 'Decisive End to Crisis
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 10Gunmen continued to control the entrances and exits of this Lebanese capital today while Government officials and Palestinian guerrilla leaders exerted fresh efforts to bring about what Interior Minister Camille Chamoun described as a decisive end to the crisis.

title: Boom in Coal Products
description: DETROIT (UPI)The slow but steady changeover of many companies to coal instead of oil or gas as a fuel has created a boom in the manufacture of mechanical stokers and other coalhandling equipment, says the Jervis B. Webb Company.

title: Redundant Parade
description: The tradition of two separate Columbus Day parades, with the Hispanic organizations marching on Sunday and the Italian groups on the official holiday, has never done much to enhance the idea of one nation indivisible. . . .

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1975

title: U.S. SEEKS TO CURB ELECTION AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) The Justice Department argued in an unusual brief filed in the Supreme Court late today that the Federal Elections Commission should not have been given power to enforce, campaign laws because it is a branch of Congress.

title: FISCAL PRESSURE ON CITY IS DECRIED IN CONGRESS STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10An attempt to force New York City rapidly toward a balanced budget would hasten the exodus of businesses and middleand upperincome families from the city and make it harder for the city to support even a reduced level of public services, the Congressional Budget Office said today.

title: The Reds Survey The Wall
description: BOSTON, Oct. 10Near the batting cage at Fenway Park today, Johnny Bench looked up at The Wall in left field.

title: Bridge
description: The inexperienced bridge player thinks of deals as being exciting in direct proportion to the level of the contract. Grand slams, they feel, are more exciting than small slams, and so on.

title: Arraignment of Harrises Is Concluded
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10Emily and William Harris, members of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army who were captured on Sept. 18, were arraigned in Superior Court here today. However, their pleas to an 11count indictment were postponed a week so that their lawyers could review the grand jury transcript that has just became available.

title: FISCAL PRESSURE ON CITY IS DECRIED IN CONGRESS STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Art attempt to force New York City rapidly toward a balanced budget would hasten the exodus of businesses and middleand upperincome families from the city and make it harder for the city to support even a reduced level of public services, the Congressional Budget Office said today.

description: New York State Debt

title: Books of The Times
description: Say you are at a dinner party during which, from soup to nuts, nothing is spoken but conventional wisdom. Everybody nods so much that there's a real danger their heads will fall off and frighten the cats. Then a quiet man at the end of the table bangs his spoon on a glass, declares that the conventional wisdom happens to be balderdash, produces a sheaf of statistics from his inside coat pocket and thumps your pieties unto a concussion.

title: A Contractor, Busy Now, Fears for Future
description: RADISSON, N. Y.Frank Williams, a black construction contractor, Is angry. Not because of an inability to obtain contracts now, but because of fear of what will happen in the future. For Mr. Williams, whose corporation specializes in general construction, is busy these days helping to build a new brewery for the Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company in this town 12 miles from Syracuse. He will have done about $500,000 worth of business on the Schlitz site by the end of this month and expects to be awarded more contract packages before the giant $150million brewery is completed.

title: Joffrey Ballet Triumphs With New Arpino Work
description: Well, the City Center Joffrey Ballet has come up with its own contribution to the Bicentennial, and it is, to say the very least, an extravaganza. Even an extravagant extravaganza. I loved it. The audience loved it. Even the ballet's flawsand there are quite a few at present seemed lovable. The ballet is Gerald Arpino's Drums, Dreams and Banjos, and it had its pemiere Thursday night at the City Center 55th Street Theater. It should prove a major hit, the kind of ballet that, like Mr. Arpino's earlier Trinity, has people flocking to the theater. But is a very curious piece.

title: Contempt Trial Is Delayed In Elizabeth School Strike
description: A trial on contempt charges against four negotiators for the Elizabeth Education Association was recessed yesterday until next Tuesday by Judge Harry Osborne Jr., in Union County Superior Court.

title: MRS. ROY LAYTON, GIRL SCOUTS CHIEF
description: Mrs. Roy F. Layton, who served as national president of the Girl Scouts of the United States of America from 1951 to 1957, died Wednesday in Arlington, Va. She was 77 years old And lived in Arlington.

title: Jacklin Leads by Stroke
description: PARIS, Oct. 10 (AP)Tony Jacklin carded a fiveunderpar 67 today that gave him a onestroke lead at the halfway point of the Lancome Trophy golf tournament. He had a 36hole total. of 137.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Tomorrow is ddaydollar day. The Mint has announced that the Bicentennial Eisenhower dollar (illustrated at right) will be officially released into circulation at a special ceremony tomorrow morning in Atlanta in the Monetary Museum of the Atlanta Federal Reserve ??ank's headquarters.

title: Card of Thanks
description: CARVER MRS. MARIE wishes to thank the many friends of William R. Carver for their kind of expressions of sympathy.

title: Skeptics Continue To Question Ruling On Robert Kennedy
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11Despite the conclusion of a panel of firearms experts that the gun wrestled from the hands of Sirhan B. Sirhan was apparently the only weapon involved in the assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, a few skeptics are refusing to abandon the socalled second gun theory.

title: The U.S. watchmen in the Sinai sand may resemble advisers' in Vietnam and trip wires in Berlin. But they will have a unique mission, both real and symbolic.
description: The images in the news magazines and on the television screens will be familiar: files of young, fitlooking Americans boarding an aircraft to fly to a distant part of the world. They will recall images from another era: the first wave of American advisers embarking for South Vietnam. The parallels will be obvious. But so will the differences. The Americans departing for the Sinai desert as part of the recent withdrawal agreement between Israel and Egypt will be civiliansalthough it is likely that all will have served in the armed forces, some until very recently. They will be only 200 number. And they will be going not to support one side against another in a bitter, ongoing civil war but to police a buffer zone between two armies whose leaders have solemnly agreed that the conflict between them... shall not be resolved by military force but by peaceful means.

title: Britons and Indians on the edge
description: June, 1945, and the skies over India are a depressing gray, turning red with fear. The raj, British dominion over the subcontinent of India, is dying because World War II is ending. The English are exhausted, and Britain is near bankruptcy. Containing Hindu and Moslem nationalism is like trying to hold Ganges water in the hands.

title: Theater: A Rich Texture
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 11 Death is not usually the subject of comedy, but then Lloyd Gold's new play A Grave Undertaking, which was given for the first time at the McCarter Theater last night is hardly a comedy. Yet it is at times very funny. Mr. Gold has written a richly textured play full of a certain density, surprising in the strength of its emotions, rewarding in the range and scope of its imagination. Undoubtedly Mr. Gold is a playwright to be reckoned with.

title: Phone Company To Provide Scores
description: The New York Telephone Company will provide World Series scores on Sports Phone. The number is 9991313.

title: Oil Prosperity Brings Problems to Alaskan Village
description: BARROW, Alaska  Prosperity of a sort has reached Barrow, the northernmost community in the United States and home of the nation's largest Eskimo concentration, and the village cannot decide whether this new development is good or bad. There are traffic jams now, and a drug problem, too.

title: Hospital Increases XRay, Lung Aids
description: Deepdale General Hospital in Little Neck, Queens, has added new equipment that will enable it to expand its Xray and lung disease services, according to Dr. Raphael P. Nenner, president of the hospital.

title: $216MILLION SAVED BY EMPLOYE IDEAS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) Nearly 58,000 ideas dropped in the Government's suggestion box by Federal employes were adopted during 1975 and quickly saved taxpayers $216.4million, the Civil Service Commission said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor.

title: New Masque of Clouds By Tom Johnson Unclear
description: If Tom Johnson is still best known locally as the newmusic critic of The Village Voice, his reputation as a composer has been growing steadily, too. Mr. Johnson works in both abstract and theatrical forms. His piano music owes its debts to Steve Reich, Philip Glass and others of the structuralist persuasion, but has a sweet gentleness all its own. And his theatrical piecesabove all his Four Note Operahave allowed that gentleness to assume an overt role, producing music somewhere beyond Sir Arthur Sullivan, Virgil Thomson and John Cage.

title: WASHINGTON POST FIRM OVER STRIKE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11In the second week of the strike by pressmen at The Washington Post, the nation's seventh largest newspaper, the editorially liberal, prolabor daily has apparently begun to reveal a care fully prepared and determined strategy to lessen its unions' power to disrupt publication by using their principal weapon the withholding of labor. On Wednesday, the mailers' and photoengravers' unions joined! the strike.

title: Under the Gleaming Chassis
description: PARIS, Oct. 11Whatever happened to the lowpriced automobile? It moved behind what used to be known as the Iron Curtain.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch of Oct. 5 should have said that former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California would not run a divisive campaign if he sought the Republican Presidential nomination in 1976. Another sentence in the dispatch should have read that delegates to a Republican conference on the West Coast were seemingly recovering from the postWatergate blues.

title: Two Suppressed Documentaries: A Happy Ending
description: Two significant documentaries that last spring seemed in danger of never being seen by the public  Swedish Broadcasting's Harlem: Voices, Faces and Marcel Ophuls's The Memory of Justicehave been resurrected in recent weeks and will soon be on view.

title: BRIDGE
description: The gap between the greatest players and the general body of experts got slightly narrower during the past year. Eight of the world's finest performers competed in a contest organized by the International Bridge Press Association and sponsored by the Bols Liquor Company of Holland. Each competitor offered a Bols Tip, &useful piece of advice that might help to bridge the gap between the good and the great.

title: ROCKEYELLER CALLS HELP IN CONGRESS FOR CITY CRUCIAL
description: Vice President Rockefeller called yesterday for swift Congressional action to assist New York City once Mayor Beame and the new Emergency Financial Control Board begin implementing a plan to eliminate the city's $800million budget deficit by 1978.

title: Tatum O'Neal And Matthau: A Winning Team?
description: CHATSWORTH, Calif. Walter Matthau and Tatum O'Neal, Hollywood's newest odd couple, are in the deep end of a sandlot baseball dugout filming a scene for The Bad News Bears, and it seems to be a standoff.

title: 26 in Baptist Church Group Hurt in Virginia Bus Crash
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) A charter bus crashed today over an embankment on Route 40, injuring 26 of 29 members of a Virginia Baptist congregation who were on their way to Long Island, the police reported.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Much of the discussion of the socalled capital shortage issue may be beside the point. Too often the argument begins with a laundry list of necessary or socially desirable investments, takes a look at probable levels of savings and then strikes an ominous mindboggling dollar total representing the looming shortages of investment funds in the economy.

title: The Lady Can't Park
description: During the last dozen years I have spent an inordinate amount of time driving around in circles. That's because. one must go to great lengths, sometimes miles and miles, to keep a nasty little secret such as mine. I can't park an automobilenot parallel that is.

title: Rudy Vallee Leads Maine U. Throng in Stein Song
description: ORONO. Me., Oct. 11 (AP) Rudy Vallee, returning to the University of Maine for its 100th homecoming, led bandsmen and spectators today in a rousing performance of The Maine Stein Sone.

description: The little brown car was going round the bend at more than 100 miles an hour and a pack of spectators moved closer to the track as it approached, ready to strike up matches and cigarette lighters.

title: BALTIC FISHERMEN CRITICIZE ACCORD
description: LUBECK, West GermanyThe fisherman of Lbeck feel that they have been cheated out of their rights by a new EastWest border agreement that they say deprives them of an ancient privilege to fish Baltic waters off the coast of what is new East Germany.

title: Cumberland Relies On Paper Balloting
description: BRIDGETONCumberland County will stand alone next month as the only one in the state still using paper ballots, and then waiting all night for the final tabulation.

title: OCTOBER 12,1975
Tugboat Crewmen Strike In Baltimore and Norfolk
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 11 (AP)Tugboat fleets in Baltimore and Norfolk, Va., were idled by a strike today; bringing ship movement virtually to a standstill in the third and fourth busiest ports on the East Coast.

title: FIRST AMENDMENT HELD CURB ON U.S.
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 11The First Amendment to the Constitution is simply, solely, expressly and utterly nothing more and nothing less than a limitation upon the Congress of the United States and the powers of the Federal Government, according to a recent 3 to 2 opinion of the Utah Supreme Court.

title: Children's Aid Gets AWoman President For the First Time
description: The Children's Aid Society, the city's largest nonsectarian voluntary childcare agency, has named a woman as its board president for the first time in its 122year history.

title: U. S. Ready For Games In Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 11 (UPI)  The United States Olympic Committee was reorganized after the fiasco of Munich and that reorganization will be put to the acid test during the next 14 days at the VII PanAmerican Games.

title: New Life for a Farmer, 75
description: EAST BRUNSWICK  A dream has come true for 75yearold Charles Skistimas and his wife Atta Mae, 80. After more than 45 years of marriage, they have finally moved into their own home in this Middlesex County township.

title: Rape as the ultimate exercise of man's domination of women
description: Rape is a metaphor of our times. Men rape the land and ravage the oceans. They even penetrate the skies. And, as a sort of environmental afterthought, they rape women.

title: TieMaker Has Sideline: Landscaping
description: GRIGGSTOWNAfter graduation from Columbia Law School in 1966, Martin Blackman spent two years in the Army in Colorado and then returned East to begin his careernot as a lawyer, but as a designer and wholesaler of neckties.

title: Mr. Magic The TV Newscast Doctor
description: On the morning of Oct. 27, when ABC's foundering newsfeature program A.M. America appears in an entirely new format (it will also be rechristened Good Morning, America) much of its new look will be the result of suggestions from a man whose advice the original producers chose to ignore.

title: Two Nominations Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) The Senate has confirmed the nominations of Ralph G. Thompson to be United States District Judge for the Western District of Oklahoma and William G. Rosenberg of Michigan as Assistant Administrator of the Federal Energy Administration.

title: Colleges Expanding Courses for Young
description: CRANFORDA growing number of New Jersey colleges are offering collegecredit courses to high school students, and the oncesharp demarcation between high school and college is thus beginning to blur.

title: Ellen McGarry Plans Marriage to Ensign
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. McGarry of Island Park, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Ann McGarry, to Ens. John E. Crowley Jr., U.S.C.G., son of Mr. and Mrs. Crowley of Minneapolis. The wedding is planned for next September.

title: Capozzoli's Runs and Kicks Forge St. Dominic's Victory
description: Tony Capozzoli of St. Dominic's changed his scoring formula yesterday. Capozzoli, who had thrown 56 touchdown passes going into yesterday's game with St. John the Baptist, didn't register any that way. But he scored two touchdowns, one on a 60yard run, kicked field goals of 36 and 47 yards, and passed for a conversion in a 280 victory.

title: CUT IN DRUG ADS ON TV IS SOUGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The Attorneys General of 17 states have asked the Federal Communications Commission to ban the advertising of overthecounter drugs on television between 6 A.M. and 9 P.M. on the ground thatt such advertising leads to drug abuse among children.

title: What's Doing in LOS ANGELES
description: CHANGING LOS ANGELESNeil Simon, the New York playwright who became an expatriate resident in Los Angeles in June, says he thinks the city is on its way to becoming what London was thought to be in the early sixties not a swinging city as London was mislabeled, but a city with a fresh intellectual breeze running through it that is stimulating ideas and the arts and attracting young, talented people. Although it's too soon to pass judgment on the accuracy of his prophecy, Los Angeles is showing signs of change and maturity. The jokes about Southern California cliches still abound: about the smog, the endless freeways, the absence of a sense of city, the rampant materialism, the usedcar salesmen in white shoes and the housewives shopping with their hair in curlers, and so forth. Yet, Los Angeles is developing a firstrate theater; it is talking seriously about building a rail rapid transit system; there are the beginnings of an effort to restore the city's shabby downtown area, and believe it or not, pollution experts say atmospheric conditions are getting better.

title: Deaths in Bombings Rise By 21 Over Eight Months
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) Bombing incidents caused 38 deaths and 229 injuries during the first eight months of this year compared to 17 deaths and 141 injuries during the same period of 1974, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has reported.

title: White Parents Found Increasingly in Favor of School Integration
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 11In 1963, the allblack Douglass High School was the center of civic and recreational activities and was the pride of the southeast ghetto of this sprawling metropolis.

title: Audubon Fall Fete A Soaring Success
description: CAPE MAYWave after wave of birdwatchers descended on this seacoast town last week for the New Jersey Audubon Society's 30th annual Fall Cape May Weekend. And they were not disappointed, either by the weather or the birds themselves.

title: Future of Pond Is Debated
description: SAYREVILLEOnly memories remain of ice skating and fishing at Crossways Pond, in the Morgan section of this Middlesex County borough.

title: Blues Fall Victim To Canadiens, 72
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 11 (UPI) Doug Riseborough and Pete Mahovlich scored two goals apiece as the Montreal Canadiens continued their awesome display of offense tonight by defeating the St. Louis Blues. 72.

title: World Football League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME PHILADELPHIA AT HAWAII STANDING OF THE TEAMS

title: Electronic Gadget Built in Class By a Prisoner Helps 5 to Escape
description: MARION, III., Oct. 10 (AP)Police and Federal agents hunted today for five convicts who opened the gates of the Federal Government's topsecurity penitentiary with an electronic gadget made in a prison shop course.

title: Community Orchestras Stress Professionalism for Year
description: New batons on podiums, new ideas on programs, even a new name... Long Island orchestras, both professional and community, have, in the last two years, seen many changes.

title: Letters to The Editor.
description: German Apartments

title: Vandalism Issue Topic of Parley
description: SOUTH ORANGEA conference exploring the question of vandalism was conducted yesterday at Seton Hall University.

title: Dodge Sale Sets Record
description: A world record for a house sale was established yesterday at the Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge mansion in Madison, N. J. The auction totaled $1,310,115, eclipsing the previous record of $1.2million established at the Louise Morgan sale in June, 1974. The auction was held by Sotheby Parke Bernet.

title: Vermont Nuptials for Joan McBean
description: Joan Cochran McBean, daughter of Mrs. Peter C. McBean of Bronxville, N.Y., and Dummerston Center, Vt., and the late Mr. McBean, was married at noon yesterday to John Nash Scherer, son of Dr. and Mrs. William F. Scherer of Bronxville.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Comparatively little, in archeological terms, is known of the barbarian hordesamong them, the Vandals, the Franks, the Alemmani, the Goths (Ostro and Visi)that in the first centuries of the Christian era threatened the Roman Empire.

title: TV VIEW
description: What is the reality of television? Volumes, valuable volumes, have been written about the more philosophic aspects of the medium as mirror or purveyor of shadows in a Platonic cave. But a definition has yet to be formulated on a considerably more practical level. For the vast majority of American broadcasters, and for a good many supposedly objective observers of the industry, TV reality is embedded in balance sheets showing healthy and growing profits. For many professional critics and, I suspect, an expanding portion of the general public, television is a depressing landscape of mediocre programing.

title: Design
description: Some say it is a reaction to the stereotyped modern interior; others theorize that the simple furniture used on farms and in small towns in 19thcentury rural America suit today's relaxed lifestyles. Mary and John Emmerling give another reason for the current popularity of countrystyle antiques. Life in New York is so frantic, Mary explains, I like to open the door of my apartment and forget where I am.

title: Horse Riding Proposal Bridles Park Supporters
description: A proposal to build a privately operated riding academy in Alley Pond Park has run into community opposition.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State fax.)

title: CIVIL SERVICE AIDE CHARGES ABUSES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The United States Civil Service Commission, which is charged with seeing that Government jobs are awarded on merit, has operated a political referral system, according to testimony by a commission official.

title: DR. C.L. CHRISTENSON, INDIANA ECONOMIST
description: Dr. Carroll L. Christenson, who retired as professor of economics at Indiana University in 1972, died yesterday in Bloomington, Ind., where he lived. He was 73 years old.

title: U.N. Aide to Get Award
description: Bradford Morse, Under Secretary General of the United Nations, will receive the annual distinguished service award of the United Nations Association of New York. The presentation will be made next Sunday at a luncheon in the Tower Suite in the Time & Life Building, 111 West 50th Street. Representative Donald Fraser, Minnesota Democrat and chairman of the subcommitee on international organizations and movements, will speak.

title: Federal Judge Finds Coast Guard at Fault in Oil Spill Outside Maine Harbor
description: PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 11United States District Court Judge Edward T. Gignoux has ruled that a 100,000gallon spill of heavy oil in Hussey Sound just outside Portland harbor was caused by Coast Guard negligence.

title: The Lusitania Disaster
description: In 1915, the Cunard liner Lusitania was torpedoed off the southern coast of Ireland by a German submarine. Nearly 1,200 passengers, 128 of them Americans, lost their lives. In addition to her passengers, the Lusitania was carrying a cargo of fourmillion rounds of ammunition, which may have exploded and hastened the sinking. Her Captain Turner had neglected to steam a zigzag course and to observe other antisubmarine precautions ordered by the Admiralty. These facts not only have been on the official record for many years, but have appeared in books aimed at a general readership, among them, Walter Millis's notable book, The Road to War.

title: Babe Ruth Legend: The Timing Helped
description: Babe Ruth's success depended on his constitution and his temperament but it also owed much to the accident of timing. If he had come to New York before World War I he would have played with a weakly financed team much less able and popular than the Giants. He came to New York when the Yankees had rich, ambitious owners who were able to make the most of the interest he stirred.

title: West Coast Hybrids Are Fastand Fun to Drive
description: LOS ANGELESFuse the rear end of a Volkswagen with the long fork and small wheel of a motorcycle chopper. Cover the hybrid with a body the color of rancid plums, neon orange, electric blue or headjerking yellow, with gold or silver flakes. Chrome the back of the engine and put footwide tires on the rear.

title: Some Advice on Stalling and Accidents
description: Safety experts and elevator manufacturers are in accord about the two major concerns of passengers on elevatorsstalling and accidents.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Ed McBain has written many books about the 87th Precinct of his big American citya city that might just as well be New York. All of these procedurals are competently written, and most of them read pretty much the same. Perhaps McBain himself feels that; in his newest book, WHERE THERE'S SMOKE (Random House, $6.95), he has departed from the procedural into a privateeye operation. His new hero is a retired detective lieutenant named Benjamin Smoke, and McBain labors greatly to make him believable.

title: The Disposal of Liberty And Other Industrial Wastes
description: Edgar Z. Friedenberg has always had a fondness for aristocracy, and it is not surprising that in his latest book he finds kind words for Charles I, Haile Selassie and the King of Thailand. Of course, Friedenberg is not himself an aristocrat. Like H. L. Mencken, that earlier admirer of the Elite, Friedenberg is an impeccably bourgeois intellectual who has made something of a career excoriating the booboisie to the delight of an equally middleclass intelligentsia. Both Mencken and Friedenberg allow their readers, and themselves, a kind of social disclaimer, as attacks on the average man put social distance between the critic and them. But these critics often protest too much; their assaults on the ordinary citizen are too angry and too involved to reflect aristocratic detachment. Such socalled higher men, Nietzsche wrote, are driven by selfhatred, selfdoubt and a desperate desire for attentionthey are fatally bound to the things they affect to disdain. Mencken, who admired Nietzsche with a rather boneheaded devotion, predictably missed that point, but his political thoughtshallow, contradictory and muddleheadedis evidence for Nietzsche's argument. Friedenberg's The Disposal of Liberty and Other Industrial Wastes is another example of this phenomenon.

title: World News Briefs

title: On a big dig with Irving Stone
description: Irving Stone is far and away the most magisterial of all the popular novelists working today. Most authors aiming for the best seller lists try to make it easy for the reader. Harold Robbins unrolls such a good, yeasty story that even when you are faced with a 500pageplus novel you know his characters will be doing enough vile things to each other along the way to make the trip interesting. Herman Wouk will set up an expansive narrative, but he always remembers to keep a good plot turning. Even at his most epicminded, James Michener writes so clearly and lucidly that the reader never has to strain. Irving Stone, however, will have none of this pantywaisted coddling of the readers. His books come hurtling down on his audience like the tablets from Mount Sinai, only heavier. up an expansive narrative, but he always remembers to keep a good plot turning. Even at his most epicminded, James Michener writes so clearly and lucidly that the reader never has to strain. Irving Stone, however, will have none of this pantywaisted coddling of the readers. His books come hurtling down on his audience like the tablets from Mount Sinai, only heavier.

Why Some Fireplaces Don't Work Properly
description: Until recently most people did not really think of their fireplace as an actual source of heat. Its value was mostly estheticpeople love to stare at the cheery, crackling flames on, a cold winter night. However, in the past year or two the high cost of fuel, coupled with the possibility of shortages in some areas, has caused more and more people to think of their fireplace as a supplementary form of heating that can help reduce fuel bills, and possibly be used as an emergency source of heat in the event of a shortage of conventional fuel. Many have stocked up on firewood whenever they could, and some have even gone out with axes and chainsaws to chop down small trees which were then cut for use as firewood.

title: How to Become a Lightning Calculator Instantly
description: You are a literary type, not known to have an interest in any science more exact than psychoanalysis. However, one evening at a party you make deprecating remarks about pocket computers. Unlike those toys, you say you can multiply two ninedigit numbers and do it in your head. An accountant smiles. Get a piece of paper, you say. He does, along with a ballpoint pen clicked to the ready. I'll give you one ninedigit number, you say, and you give me the other. You write 142,857,143; under it he writes 123,456,789, intending a certain nonchalance in his choice of digits. Without hesitation you draw a line beneath both numbers and write 17,636,684,160,493,827. He takes the paper off to a corner. In five or ten min= utes he is back not knowing whether to feel had or admiring.

title: For young readers
description: A the end of the wind in the Willows the chastened Mr. Toad has cause for that feeling of triumph which practical Badger forces him to stifle. Toad and his friends have not only defeated the stoats and the weasels, but they have effectively done in that earlier Kenneth Grahame, the author of The Golden Age and Dream nays, woo was essentially an amateur helletrist like the Reluctant Dragon or Ratty in The Wind in the Willows, but with better publishing connections. When the essays  stories  memoirs (what should they be called?) that make up The Golden Age and Dream Days were first published in the 1890'smost of them in magazines like the National Observer and The Yellow Bookthey were welcomed as perspective recreations of childhoodabout, not for children. In tone, they suggest The Piper at the Gates of Dawn and Wayfarers All, those intrusive chapters that stop the action in The Wind in the Willows and make it, at best, a piebald classic. Yet, today, thanks to Toad and his crew, The Golden Age and Dream Days, when they are thought of at all, tend to be taken as rather strange children's books.

title: AUSTRIAN IS ACCUSED OF NAZI ROLE IN WAR

title: Lewis Mumford: intensely personal items
description: Lewis Mumford will be 30 years old on Oct. 19 and is privileged to look back on a grandly fruitful career. It is good news that he is working ahead on his autobiography, of which he tells us that the first volume is ready. Findings and Keepings comes as an interlude; also as a repository for personalsometimes intensely personalitems that found no place in the volume. Analects is his word for them, used in its dictionary sense of crumbs ... literary gleanings. I have to report that the crumbs and gleanings are, with a few exceptions, of unusual interest for the light they throw on Mumford's character, on the role he chose to play, and on the consistency of his ideas almost from the beginning.

title: A hairy river and a sick river
description: Ann Zwinger, author of two previous books on natural history  Beyond the Aspen Grove, and a National Book Award nominee, Land Above the Trees'now offers us a study of a littleknown American river, the Green. This river, on which I myself have spent many wet, hot and happy weeks, begins as a rivulet of ice water in the Wind River mountains of Wyoming and dies, alas, much too soon, in the slack and stagnant waters of Lake Powell National Sewage Lagoon, Utah. All the same before that ignominious anticlimax drowns in a tepid death the Green survives in southern Wyoming and northeastern Utah as a wild, free and sometimes hairy river. Hairy? Oh yes: several boatmen have lost their lives in the vigorous rapids of the Green's Desolation Canyon and in other reaches of the river.
