description: Five of the 10 largest bankruptcies in the history of American business have occurred in the past year, capped by the collapse Oct. 2 of the W. T. Grant retail chain.

title: Ford Visit Disappoints State Republicans
description: NEWARKA number of state Republican leaders have concluded that President Ford's fundraising appearance here last weekend proved to be a financial disappointment for the party and a highly unusual, and perhaps unsuccessful, exercise in political leadership for the President himself.

title: SaltHay Farming Dying Out
description: CAPE MAY  Southern New Jersey's picturesque salthay farmer is becoming a needle in his own haystack.

title: Jersey City Rail Depot Designated Historic Site
description: TRENTONAs New Jersey prepares for the nation's Bicentennial next year, Governor Byrne is moving quickly to have an increasing number of the state's historic sites designated as such by the Federal Government and thus preserve them long after the celebration is ended.

title: Memorial for Mrs. Murphy
description: A memorial service for Sara Murphy, the widow of Gerald Murphy and the model for Nicole in F. Scott Fitzgerald's Tender is the Night, will be held at noon Friday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, East Hampton. L. I. Mrs. Murphy died Friday in the Arlington (Va.) Hospital at the age of 91.

title: Shore Area Looms As U.S. Prison Site
description: MANCHESTER TOWNSHIP After more than 18 months of searching for a site for a new Federal mediumsecurity prison, the Bureau of Prisons has again turned its eye toward Ocean County.

title: Man o' War Chart
description: 1975. by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) EIGH??d The Man o' War, $100,000 added. 3YO and up, 1m. (turf). Start good, ??on driving. Ofl, 5:14. Winner, ch??, 4, by FirestreakSnow Blossom, by Flush Royal. Trainer, M. Miller. Verve to winner, $69,400; second, 528,030; third, $13,600; fourth, $6,840. Times24; 49 3/5; 1:15; 1:40; 2:05; 2:29 1/5.

title: Rockefeller's Remarks Food for Thought Only
description: Vice President Rockefeller's remarks on the city's fiscal crisis last night may have been of prime importance to local officials, but they had little preceptible impact on most of the WaldorfAstoria's 2,000 Columbus Day Dinner guests.

title: Old novel themes
description: Paul Perry and his wife, Grace, await the return of Paul's younger brother Harvey from Vietnam. Harvey has recovered from a wound, which cost him an eye. Paul, who wears glasses, has never left Sawmill Landing, Minn., where he is farm agent and farmers are scarce. Moody and ineffectual, Paul worries about his job, the fact that he didn't follow in his dead father's footsteps and become a minister, and about Addie, an elusive hometown beauty for whom he feels longings.

title: Fancy Ferns for Terrariums
description: Ferns are fascinating in terrariums. These naturally moistureloving plants thrive in glass containers, excellent substitutes for their native tropical homes.

title: We Always Wore Sailor Suits
description: Susanna Agnelli's book is an exquisite concoction. I read it twice in two weeks, not for the nourishment it provides, but for the perplexing mix of flavors, for the texture in which morsels of airy lightness are followed by dark, rich, grainy streaks. But there remains an aftertaste that troubles me; to search out its nature seems like approaching a cassata alla siciliana with a hacksaw.

title: Hearings to Begin on U.D.C. Collapse
description: The Moreland Act Commission hearings on the collapse of the Urban Development Corporation, which begin here Tuesday morning, will view the U.D.C. not as an isolated problem in the financing of public housing, but as an integral part of the state's growing credit crisis, according to Orville H. Schell Jr., the commission's chairman.

title: Closer to Lady Astor than Lord Astor was
description: Those were the days all right, when servants were servants and masters were masters and everyone knew his place. London dinner tables have been enlightened by the opinion of more than one stout party that it's the appalling uppishness of the British working classes that has brought England to its present sorry state.

title: 10Year Drive on Tropic Disease Set
description: GENEVA, Oct. 11The World Health Organization is launch ing a 10 year program to develop more effective medical tools to prevent and cure six infectious diseases that maim and kill many millions of people throughout tropical regions.

title: Calendar of Dog Shows
description: TodayRamapo K.C. allbreed and obedience, Mullers Park, Route 202, Oakland, N.J.; 1,172 dogs; 9 A.M.

title: 60 Hurt, 120 Held in Fighting in Oporto
description: LISBON, Oct. 11Sixty persons were wounded and more than 120 detained last night and early today in fighting, mainly between rival extremeleft factions, that raged through the night in the northern city of Oporto.

title: U.S.C. Wins, 2810
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 11 (AP)Ricky Bell ran for 217 yards, his third 200yard game of the season, and Danny Reece put on another dazzling punt return show today as thirdranked Southern California whipped Washington State, 2810, in a Pacific8 Conference game.

title: Lehigh Solves Defense Of Rutgers, Wins, 3420
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 11 Lehigh scored on the third play from scrimmage today and went on to defeat favored Rutgers, 3420.

title: Miss Hearst Called Confused
description: BOSTON, Oct. 11 (AP)Patricia Hearst was drugged by force and is not capable of standing trial or assisting in her own defense, one of her lawyers says.

title: Jacqueline Ann Van Cleve Bride Of James McMillan Hinshaw 3d
description: St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J., was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Jacqueline Ann Van Cleve, daughter of Mrs. Thomas F. Swan of Short Hills and the late John W. Van Cleve, to James McMillan Hinshaw 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hinshaw of Chatham, Mass., formerly of New Vernon, N.J.

title: A Special Kind of Solution
description: ATHENSIn Waiting for the Barbarians C. P. Cavafy, the greatest modern Greek poet, wrote: And now, what will become of us without barbarians? They were a kind of solution. Such is the case with Greece today.

title: Blow UpThe Story of Photography In Today's Art Market
description: Five years ago, in his first major photography exhibition, Georgetown art dealer Harry Lunn offered for sale signed prints by Ansel Adams at $150 per picture. Sales of works by the great West Coast nature photographer were extremely strong, and Lunn soon decided to invest heavily in photography and, in particular, to seek to establish himself as one of the leading dealers in Adams's works.

title: Anne McInnes Wed To Richard Ranck
description: Anne Brooke McInnes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kaighn McInnes of Penn Valley. Pa., was married yesterday afternoon to Richard Scott Ranck, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Ranck of Gladwyne. Pa.

title: The Region
description: At first glance, Elizabeth, N.J., seems to be just another example of the gradual urbanization of the suburbs surrounding New York City. But the Spanish signs above the stores on Elizabeth Avenue hint at the unusual ethnic makeup of Elizabeth. A large influx of Cuban immigrants more than a decade ago has not only radically altered the city's demography, but also may have saved the city from the decay common to similar cities, in the nation.

title: Few Styling Changes for '76, but Mileage Is Up
description: DETROITThe 1976 automobiles are like pizza with cheese but no anchovies, with pepperoni but no mushrooms, no peppers, no onions. They've got a little taste, but not enough to rave about.

title: SoHo Grows Up And Grows Rich and Chic
description: Only a few years ago, SoHo was a place where artists wandered, uninvited, into Larry Poons's loft for his weekly anybodydropin party. Nowadays, the social scene there is a great deal less casual. More characteristic, perhaps, is Robert Rauschenberg, wearing suits made entirely of sewntogether neckties, giving a chic byinvitationonly party for Princess Christina of Swedenwith salmon flown in fresh from the fjordsto the delight of such guests as Henry Geldzahler, August Heckscher, Robert Scull and other uptown culture mavens.

title: Battle for Control in Suffolk
description: RIVERHEADAs the 1975 political campaign in Suffolk County enters the home stretch, the mood among Democrats and Republicans is one of uncertainty as to which party will make the greatest gains in next month's elections.

title: FOUR ON SHIP LOST MUTINY INDICATED
description: MIAMI, Oct. 11 (Reuters)A Panamanianregistered freighter sank today after an apparent mutiny and her four German officers are missing, the Coast Guard said.

title: YOUTH KEPT ALIVE 3 WEEKS, IS DEAD
description: ELYRIA, Ohio, Oct. 11 (AP) Seventeenyearold Randal Carmen, who had been kept alive by machines for nearly three weeks after doctors said his brain had died, was declared legally dead today.

title: ConYess Likely to Put Off RevenueSharing Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9Congress is expected to defer until next year the issue of !renewal of general revenue sharing, a program whose continuation is being sought this year by the Ford Administration and by a bipartisan alliance of state and municipal officials from across the nation.

title: Events Today
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.,
description: Oct. 11 (AP)  Two blasts rocked the Broward County jail early today, and a man who said he was with Youths of the Star later claimed responsibility for the explosions in protest against imprisonment of Mr. Lopez.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONAlthough the Legislature's current twoyear session still has almost three months to go, its members already have established themselves as the most prolific when it comes to proposing new laws.

title: School Girl Challenges Ban on Contact Sports
description: SANTA FE, N.M., Oct. 11 Sally Gutierrez, a secondstring guard on the Quemado High School varsity football team, has filed suit in state district court here to have a state regulation struck down because it allegedly keeps her from playing contact sports with members of the opposite sex.

title: Survey Reports 4 Out of 5 Content With Neighborhood
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) Four out of every five Americans think their neighborhood is a good place to live, according to a Census Bureau survey.

title: Freehold Complex Gets State Backing
description: FREEHOLDThe New Jersey Economic Development Authority has agreed to help provide lowcost financing for a 21acre recreation complex that will be built near the Freehold Raceway.

title: Lamppost Reunion Puts Hoboken on Rialto
description: HOBOKENLouis LaRusso 2d is living proof that you can go home again and even write about it.

title: Use of Turnpike Services Up By 13% in First Half of 1975
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  The ontheroad restaurant and servicestation facilities provided by the New Jersey Turnpike served more than 7.5 million motorists during the first six months of 1975, an increase of 13 per cent over the same period last year.

title: But Withheld Information Is Unlikely to Change the Conclusion
description: WASHINGTONIn the White House of Richard M. Nixon, it was said that Watergate would become serious only if it got outside the Washington Beltway, if the depths of the disgrace were understood by the American people. In 1974, the truth of Watergate flooded the country, and the Nixon Presidency ended.

title: Passaic Valley Remains Unblemished
description: Passaic Valley, unbeaten, united and unscored upon, defied the sloppy weather yesterday and powered to a 210 victory over Teaneck in Teaneck.

title: SAN FRANCISCANS IGNORE ELECTION
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 11Somehow it has seemed this fall as if San Franciscans have hardly had time to notice the mayoralty campaign that is sputtering along in their midst.

title: HEODOREBOETTGER, INDUSTRIALIST, 99
description: Theodore Boettger, former president of the United Piece Dye Works and chairman in the nineteentwenties of the New Jersey Interstate Bridge and Tunnel Commission, died Friday at his home in Hackensack, N. J., at the age of 99.

title: SmallCity Aged Take Housing for Granted
description: HOLYOKE, Mass.For the elderly residents of this manufacturing center of 48,000 in western Massachusetts, apartment houses are as rare as leases, multiple dwellings are twofamily homes, and the prevailing relationship between landlord and tenant is one of easy camaraderie and mutual trust.

title: Bicentennial Guidebooks
description: On the autumneve of the Bicentennial Year, blazing foliage and racial memory send us in search of our national origins. Anyone bent on The Compleat Bicentennial Tour had better get packing and get cracking.

title: DATING OF PAYMENT TO MANDEL SCORED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP) A purported seven yearoldi agreement between Gov. MaH yin Mandel of Maryland and, W. Dale Hess calling for thel payment of legal fees to Mr. Mandel was written after Mr. Mandel became Governor ini 1969, The Washington Post' reported today.

title: Chess Master Sets Simultaneous Play
description: WESTFIELD  The PlainfieldWestfield Chess Club has announced that Michael Valvo, a United States chess master and its current club champion, will give a simultaneous exhibition against all challengers on Oct. 31.

title: He Trusts Plays, He Trusts Actors
description: Arvin Brown does not come on like a hotshot director; that is one of the secrets of his success. And his success, at the age of 35, is a matter of public recordnot least on Broadway, where his production of Eugene O'Neill's Ah, Wilderness! is currently selling out at the Circle in the Square.

title: Emilie Kellogg and George Hinman Jr. Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Sanford Kellogg of Greenwich, Conn., and Bar Harbor, Me., have announced the engagement of Mr. Kellogg's daughter, Emilie Leonard Kellogg, to George Roy Hinman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hinman of Port Washington, L. I. Miss Kellogg is also a daughter of the late Marilee Becker Kellogg.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: The reasons why Off Broadway has virtually wiped itself out and why Off Off Broadway is flourishing mightily were in evidence, almost back to back, for a short timea very short timea week ago. Off Broadway was offering, at the Theater de Lys, what is thought of as a professional production, which means, to begin with, that it cost somebody a bundle.

title: Susan Florence Valk Engaged To Andrew Baker Woolworth
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Earl Valk of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Florence Valk, to Andrew Baker Woolworth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Griswold Woolworth of Lancaster, Pa. A wedding is Planned next June.

title: Phaedra Spiced With Curry
description: LONDON Currying Racine's Pliedre by setting it in Victorian India is an ingenious idea, and in Phaedra Britannica Tony Harrison, the translator and adapter, has brought it off fairly well. Mr. Harrison effected a similar transposition some time ago with Moliere's The Misanthrope. Like The Misanthrope, Phaedra has been directed by John Dexter and has Diana Rigg in the cast. It has just come into the repertory of the National Theater, and as the first chills set into the. London autumn, the production at the Old Vic counterposes to them the heat of India and the fiercer heat of Racine.

title: Nassau Holding Environment Seminars
description: MINEOLANassau County's Environmental Management Council and its American Revolution Bicentennial Commission are cosponsoring a series of free environmental showcases and symposiums next month, Ralph G. Caso, the County. Executive, announced last week.

title: 500 in Louisville March To Support School Busing
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 11 (UPI)More than 500 supporters of courtordered busing for desegregation turned out today for a rally and march to counter the antibusing movement.

title: Fuel Economy Counts Most In New Cars
description: SUDDENLY, it's the mileage that counts. The good thing about most gasoline mileage figures you're likely to hear is that they provide a good indication of relative fuel economy. They'll tell you which model should get better mileage than another. The not so good thing about the figures is that they won't give you much of a clue about the specific fuel economy you can expect from your own automobile.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: In Memoriam
description: GREENBAUMSylvan. Oct. 17. 1974. Darling, you are so sadly missed. You will always be remembered. Love Bertha, Joanne, Carol & Lynn.

title: A Bumper Pop
description: The popping part of the American corn crop is expected to rise to a record 500 million pounds this year, after 1974's droughtshrunken 401 millionpound harvest.

title: Monmouth College Will Aid Elderly
description: WEST LONG BRANCHPatricia Q. Sheehan, the state's Commissioner of Community Affairs, will be the featured speaker at a meeting for the elderly that will be held at Monmouth College on Oct. 21.

title: A Return to Tradition
description: In the 14 months that he has been in the White House, Gerald Ford has restored the almost forgotten practice of permitting Cabinet members and other subordinates to disagree in public or speak out in advance, of the President on policy in the process of formation.

title: HOSPITAL AGENCY TOLD TO CUT COSTS
description: The city's Budget Director has warned the board of directors of the Health and Hospitais Corporation that within 4 to 8 weeks the municipal hospital system might not have enough money to meet its payroll, unless severe new economies are made.

title: Peru: River of Expense, Trickle of Oil
description: IQUITOS, PeruFour years ago, Peru embarked on the largest economic undertaking in her history in an attempt to uncover oil reserves in the northern jungles around this Amazon River town.

title: SCHUYLER C. STUART
description: Schuyler C. Stuart, who retired in June as Long Island sales representative of Texaco, Inc., died yesterday at St. Francis Cardiac Hospital, Roslyn, L. I. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhasset, L. I.

title: 5454 Overtime Tie: Guess What Sport?
description: INSTITUTE, W. Va., Oct. 11 (AP)A substitute quarterback, Mike Flannery; came off West Liberty's bench in the fourth quarter and threw four touchdown passes within 10 minutes, and then West Liberty and West Virginia State battled through three overtime periods before ending in a 5454 tie today.

title: For Born Loser: Course on Betting
description: TOMS RIVER (UPI)Stanley Canis has a system for betting on the horses. He says it is a winning one, and he is teaching it in college.

title: Canarsie's Running Tops Lincoln. 4013
description: Canarsie gained 388 yards on the ground game yesterday while trouncing Lincoln, 4013, in a P.S.A.L. Division A, Section I, game. Canarsie is 201, Lincoln is 12.

title: Breathing Life Into the Recorder
description: Playing an instrument like the recorder demands qualities similar to those needed for painting. It's an enclosed activity... you and your instrument... in your own room. It's not meant to be projected into a hall, to an audience, like violin playing, for instance, which by the nature of the sound and the position of the player is bound to be heard at a distanCe. It's a personal activity and far more intimate.

title: Allen Tate: the best uncollected essays
description: In the deepening twilight of a distinguished career, Allen Tate has brought together a selection of his best uncollected essays, only one of which has appeared in a previous book of his criticism.

title: The confidence of a halfbum/halfbard
description: William Eastlake is the funniest, most profound, most musical writer I have read in years. He has the greatness of soul not only to kid the characters in his book (Navajos, semiNavajos, quasiNavajos, lunaticfringe Navajosympathizers and antiNavajos) but also to kid himself and his own style and thought as a writer. He has the confidence, in other words, of a man halfbard and halfbum, yet undeceived as to the truth in all the confusion. Eastlake is wise: a poet in the best sense.

title: InWater Boat Shows Make Bigger Splash in Northeast
description: The inthewater boatshow season, launched last weekend with the North Atlantic Show in Stamford, Conn., has moved into high gear in Annapolis, Md. The United States Powerboat Show ends today followed by the United States Sailboat Show, the world's largest display of sailboats, which starts a fourday run Thursday.

title: Convicts in Texas Shootout All Died in Different Ways
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 11 (AP) The Authorities said today that three escaped convicts whose bodies were found in a burnedout house after a shootout with the police had all died in different ways.

title: Dance: Light and Dark in Program by Mary Anthony's Company
description: The light and the dark came together in the first program of a weekend engagement by the Mary Anthony Dance Theater at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Forced at gunpoint to name the greatest composer of vocal music in the history of Western music, most musicians would come out in favor of Schubert. Stray votes might be cast for Monteverdi, Mozart, Verdi or others, but Schubert would win handily, even if it meant that some of us zealots had to go around stuffing ballot boxes. Why is it then that except for a few specialists, nobody knows Schubert's operas and operettas?

title: CUBAN TERRORISTS SOUGHT BY F.B.I.
description: MIAMI. Oct. 11The Federal Bureau of Investigation is making a determined effort to halt terrorism here attributed to unidentified Cuban exiles.

title: EUGENE EXMAN, 75, BOOK EDITOR, DIES
description: Eugene Exman, author and former vice president of Harper & Row, Publishers, Inc., where he had directed the religious book department, died Friday of a heart ailment in Rhode Island Hospital in Providence. He was 75 years old and had lived in Barnstable, Mass., since his retirement in 1965.

title: Challenge to Stylists: Tailoring the Dwarf
Prisoners' Art at Newark Museum
description: NEWARKThe exhibition of prisoners' art at the Newa?? Museum stresses the value of artistic creativity as a means of rehabilitation.

title: AIR FORCE RISKS A RIFT WITH NAVY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11Force officers are promoting a plan to send tactical air power into virtually any corner of the world from American bases, thus impinging on the traditional domain of the Navy's aircraft carriers.

title: RELEASE OF PAPERS ON AGNEW ORDERED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) A Federal judge has given the Justice Department 10 days to disclose material on the prima facie case that forced former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew to resign from office and plead no contest to taxi evasion in 1973.

title: Advice From a Photograph Collector
description: In response to the question What do you look for in a photographic work?, I must respond, I look for nothing! It looks for me! It hits me first in the gut and then in the eye. It's visceral! I feel it first, then I see it. I've lived with photography for the last 30 years. I've looked at, read, absorbed and slept with every photographic book and album I could find, saw every art exhibition in museums and galleries, especially exhibtions of paintings and sculpture, then of prints, drawings and photographs. One must train one's eye by educating one's brain.

title: News of The Realty Trade
description: The assemblage of the western blockfront on the Avenue of the Americas between 55th and 56th Streets has been broken up by Mrs. Cecelia Benattar, the chief executive officer here for London Merchants Securities, Ltd., a British conglomerate.

title: Priest Helps Boys to Help Others
description: These boys have round that they have something to offer, too, said the Rev. Sam Joseph, the chaplain of St. Vincent's Hall, a nondenominational fostercare residence for boys in Brooklyn.

title: ART VIEW
description: An immense bath of exquisite visual sensation, sometimes a little stunning in its swift shift of scale and sometimes a little soporific in its endlessly intricate decorative elaborations, now awaits the visitor to the new galleries of Islamic art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Although somewhat daunting in the sheer variety of esthetic experience it contains, there is throughout this phenomenal new complex of galleries a pervasive emphasis on the uninstructed pleasures of the eye. The museumgoer in search of flawless and unfamiliar delectation will find a paradise here that invites an easy surrender to the beautiful. After enduring in recent years so much of our own art that is mysterious without being beautiful, one can perhaps be forgiven for responding with alacrity to this invitation to unalloyed delight. What our present culture sometimes denies, history is ready to supply in abundance.

title: CBS Gives Patents to School on L.I.
description: OLD WESTBURY  The Columbia Broadcasting System has made an unusual gift of virtually all of its patents in four fields of electronics, including holography and ultrasonic imaging, to the New York Institute of Technology.

title: Much Ado About Nothing
description: PORT WASHINGTON You, too, can be part of a work of art.

title: Heroin Sellers Turning To Use of Trademarks
description: Rival trademarks are now an important part of the illicit narcotics business in the city.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Fashion
description: Leg warmers are the hot new fashion accessory this fall. They're borrowed from ballet dancers, who traditionally have worn them to keep their muscles warm and loose. Fashion's leg warmers come in wonderful patterns, in solid colors for more subdued warmth, and can be worn thighhigh over tight pants (by the very young) or pushed low over boots or shoes. Some of the best leg warmers are handknit and ethnicpatterned. Others are soft, stretchy. All go to make this winter warmer.

title: Mary Katzin Married
description: Mary Beth Katzin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Katzin, and Charles E. Simon, son of Dr. and Mrs. Loron Simon, of Huntington, L.I., were married here yesterday by Rabbi Jose Faur at the Katzin home. Dr. Hatzin. an ophthomologist, is president of the hoard of the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital. Dr. Simon is a psychologist.

title: Dallas Police Hope TV Ads Can Help Cut Crime Rate
description: DALLAS, Oct. 11 (UPI)The police hope that advertising techniques can quickly relieve the rising crime rate.

title: JUDGE IS CRITICAL OF COURT BURDEN
description: PLEASANTVILLE, Oct. 11Justice James Hopkins of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court admonished the executive and legislative branches of government this week for adding to the burden of the judicial branch.

title: The Government as Employer
description: LINZ, AustriaThe story goes that Hitler wanted to something an for this town, where he went to high school before studying art in Vienna, and where, in a suburb, his parents lie buried.

title: Economic Indicators
description: WEEKLY COMPARISONS

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Surplus Schools the White Elephants of Suburbia
description: One school district in the metropolitan area is renting a building to a music center. Another, more lucky than most, has sold a school to a college fix the equivalent of almost $1.5Million. Still a third is proposing to give an excess junior high school to The town for $1.

title: Dave Anderson
description: BOSTON, Oct. 11Tomorrow's pitcher for the Boston Red Sox stood by his locker in the clubhouse.

title: Autumn
description: Autumn is the falling leaf and the wider horizons. The pace changes. It is not really the time for leisare, but a man can pause now and then and think thoughts not bounded by the height of a cornstalk or the breadth of a meadow. The rhythms of the seasons and the years can seep into a man's soul in place of the summers short nights and long days.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: On Pack Horses
description: DUBOIS, Wyo. On the morning of the fifth and last day of our trip to Bliss Creek Canyon in the Shoshone National Forest I elected to remain in camp to watch the outfitters pack the horses for the journey back to civilization, while my fishing and hunting companions rode on ahead.

title: Praying for Pay
description: Most expenses incurred by business are deductible for income tax purposes, but the United States Tax Court drew the line at payments to a minister who was asked, among other things, to pray for solutions to a company's problems.

title: Ideas for Engines Still Come and Go
description: Back In the mid1960's, an ambitious English poultry farmer named Harold Bate designed an engine that he believed could set the moguls of Detroit on their pistons. It was a chicken coupe, of sorts an automobile powered by methane gas from chicken droppings.

title: Havana Buys Ships To End Its Reliance On Foreign Vessels
description: HAVANA, Oct. 11 (Reuters)Cuba is building up her merchant navy to gain greater independence from foreign shipping companies.

title: Marvin Gaye at the Music Hall In Slick but Constrained Show
description: Marvin Gaye is a curious performer. The singer of some of the great soul songs of the nineteensixties and sev enties, he dropped off the per forming circuit five years ago, When he returned last year at both the Nassau Coliseum and Radio City Music Hall, the result seemed selfconscious and even amateurish.

title: Why Stix Nix Big Fix
description: LOS ANGELES Appearances can be deceiving, especially in Hollywooda phenomenon which may explain a series of recent rosecolored reports suggesting that the movie industry is enjoying its biggest economic boom since the blissfully busy 1940's. While it is true that profits this past summer were up approximately 23 per cent over those of the previous summer, this rise is due entirely to the huge success of a very small handful of films, including Shampoo, Tommy, White Line Fever, Benji  and most sensationallythe jumbogrossing Jaws.

title: Confusion Leads Nassau Ballot
description: MINEOLA  When Nassau County residents go to the polls on Nov. 4 they will be faced with lengthy ballots that are likely to cause confusion and uncertainty.

title: M'COYTYNER QUINTET AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: For the amount of sustained energy that McCoy Tyner, the jazz pianist, poured into his performance with his quintet at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening, surprisingly little developed. Using a heavy, twohanded attack, Mr. Tyner roared relentlessly up and down the keyoard, subsiding occasionally while his saxophonist, Azar Lawrence, took over in a somewhat similar style. In both cases, the playing was furiouly busy and cleanly articulated, supported in equally busy fashion by bass, percussion and drums.

title: Article 1  No Title
Michigan Scores; Ohio State Romps
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 11 (AP)Gordon Bell raced 18 yards for a touchdown and Bob Wood kicked his third field goal of the game in the, fourth quarter today as Michigan overcame its crossstate rival, Michigan State, 166, in a battle of Big Ten powers.

title: Lemon Law Effect Uncertain
description: A man buying a new car doesn't think about the warranty until he needs it, says David Prosky, a Manhattan Volkswagen dealer. But he added that dealers must think about what the warranty will cost them, even though the manufacturer is supposedly the one offering and paying for it.

title: To Save on Drawbridge Tenders, City Wants Ships to Give 6Hour Notice
description: The ripples of the city's economic crisis are about to reach some of the port's quieter backwaters.

title: National Book Awards Italianstyle
description: Italy's biggest literary prize, the Premio Campiello, is awarded annually in September at televised lateevening ceremonies in the courtyard of the Doge's Palace in Venice. Its sponsors are the equivalent of a manufacturers' association for the Venetothat city and its hinterlandwhere the Premio was thought up 13 years ago as a way to strike a blow simultaneously for two endangered institutions, Venice and the novel.

title: C. W. Post Beats Rhode Island, 30
description: KINGSTON, R. I. Oct. 11C. W. Post staged three goalline stands to hold off Rhode Island University, 30, and the Pioneers remained unbeaten with four victories.

title: SHIPSHORE CALLS COSTING MORE NOW
description: American travelers and merchant seamen using shiptoshore telephones from ships and aircraft to points within the United States are paying rates that have risen 150 to 300 per cent.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1975

title: High School Run Is Won. By Salazar
description: Alberto Salazar, who beat the Russians in 100degree temperatures in July, outran 4,300 Americans yesterday in the mud in the Manhattan College interscholastic crosscountry invitation meet at Van Cortland Park in the Bronx

title: Sunrise Bypass Is at Issue

title: Traffic Death Toll in 1974 18% Lower Than in 1973
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) Traffic deaths dropped almost 18 per cent in 1974 because Americans drove slower and less and were more careful, the Department of Transportation has said.

title: HUMAN DECENCY IS ANIMAL
description: During the American wars of this century, a large percentage of Congressional Medals of Honoi were awarded to men who threw themselves on top of grenades to shield comrades, aided the rescue of others from battle sites at the price of certain death to themselves, or made other, often carefully considered but extraordinary, decisions that led to the same fatal end. Such altruistic suicide is the ultimate act of courage and emphatically deserves the country's highest honor. It is also only the extreme act that lies beyond the innumerable smaller performances of kindness and giving that bind societies together. One is tempted to leave the matter there, to accept altruism as simply the better side of human nature. Perhaps, to put the best possible construction on the matter, conscious altruism is a transcendental quality that distinguishes human beings from animals. Scientists are nevertheless not accustomed to declaring any phenomenon off limits, and recently there has been a renewed interest in analyzing such forms of social behavior in greater depth and as objectively as possible.

title: Workshop Is Slated For Tutors of Aged
description: MONTCLAIRA free training seminar for teachers of older adults will be held at Montclair State College next Saturday. Lunch will be provided without charge.

title: New York Members of Congress Are Doing What They Can
description: The 41member New York State Congressional delegation, a generally disorganized group of individualists regarded by their colleagues collectively as a helpless giant, has belatedly united to help New York City fight for its fiscal life.

title: Regional Commission Adds $400Million to RoadBuilding Plan

title: Viral Disease Fatal To 500 State Deer
description: HUNTSVILLESince Labor Day, an estimated 500 deer have died in Sussex and Warren Counties of a viral disease that has not been seen in New Jersey since 1955.

title: The conquering antihero
description: Jack Nicholson sat in his dressingroom trailer on the rimrocks overlooking Billings, Mont., his strange felinegold eyes studying me as we talked, his entire being feigning ignorance of the turmoil that was transpiring outside the trailer. We both knew what was happening outside, but Nicholson chose to ignore it, possibly out of his undisguised heroworship of Marlon Brando, his costar in United Artists' Missouri Breaks, then filming amid the harshly beautiful Montana buttes. Brando was having a tantrum. He was storming about in an incongruous yellow bathrobe and yellow terrycloth slippers, enormously fat and almost unrecocnizable at 250 pounds, looking like a misplaced, pale sumo wrestler. Brando's ire had been aroused by the fact that a union protest had caused the removal from the location of his family friend and prot6gde, young Chinese Wt.l who had been there on a photographic assignment for a women's magazine. The magazine had withdrawn the assignment, thus negating her right to be on the set.

title: The Sports Factory
description: Sports in the United States is a bigmoney operation. Not just among professionals, but also in the college ranks, where revenue from TV appearances has become essential for many colleges to support their spiraling athletic department budgets. The pressure to produce a good show and winning teams grows and, among college coaches, the win at any cost ethic is endemic. (Job security for losing coaches is practically nonexistent.) And

description: MANILA, Oct. 11For the first time since September, 1972, when President Ferdinand E. Marcos assumed emergency powers with military support, voices are being raised, some more boldly than others, for a return to representative go vernment.

title: NarnathTarkenton In Key Matchup
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 11The New York Jets will go into tomorrow's confrontation against the Minnesota Vikings with a workmanlike feeling, according to Joe Namath.

description: The 11:30 movie on television begins with three bank robbers shooting two guards to death. It is hohum stuff. Fast shotgun blasts to head and chest.

The agreement has been rejected by the new statedominated Emergency Financial Control Board on the ground that the city cannot afford it.

description: PRESIDENT FORD proposed an $$11billion additional tax cut effective Jan. 1 and making permanent the $17 billion antirecession tax cuts of last spring.... Grant, operating under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act, will close 201 of its 1,275 stores

description: VIENTIANE, LAOSIn a narrow, potholed street by the Mekong River, dozens of Laotian boys and girls gather every evening to practice marching and dancing under the careful direction of the Communistled Pathet Lao.

description: ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 11 (Agence France  Presse) new legislative and administrative body, the Supreme Military Council, has been set up to replace Ghana's former ruling National Redemption Council, it was announced here this week.

title: GiantsCowboys Statistics
Restricted Diet Aid To Growth of Dogs
description: The American presumption that bigger is better can prove harmful to dogs, according to Dr. Lennart Krook, a professor of pathology at Cornell veterinary college. Breeders adher ing to the idea that bigger dogs are better dogs, feed and overfeed their dogs with meat, supplements and vitamins to get their size up as quickly as possible, said Krook. The owners often don't realize there is an optimal level of nutrition. Overnutrition can be as dangerous as undernutrition.

description: A new complication has arisen in the labyrinth of perplexities posed by Karen A. Quinlan as she lies comatose in the intensive care unit of St. Clare's Hospital in Denville, N. A consultant neurologist now reports that she would not fit any of the definitions of death that have been accepted to date.

But the money is not likely to provide immediate economic relief because Portugal's political situation is so unstable: Government officials are not able to agree on what to do with the funds.

title: Sander Wins Run

But the others will have to catch Brown now because the Bruins beat the leading contender and the defending cochampion, Yale, by 2712 here today and at the end no doubt remained about which the best team.

Having been quite wrong in their predictions last year, they would naturally prefer not to look back. (Their consensus 12 months ago was that the economy would expand by 1.7 per cent; it shrank by 5.4 per cent).

title: Kathleen Raine: taking stock
description: Like countless others before her and countless more still to come, Kathleen Raine decided to take stock of her life and try to understand it, not so much because it had been mine, but because our own lives are the only ones of which each of us has personal and immediate experience. A life, as such, is something so mysterious that to find its meaning seems allimportant. And if there is no meaning, has not meaning to be invented?

Ray, a retired Navy admiral. was reported in good condition at County Hospital where he was taken yesterday with multiple cuts and bruises and two broken fingers.

description: William Phelps Thompson, a Kansasborn layman who gave up a career in law nine years ago to become Stated Clerk (chief administrative officer) of the United Presbyterian Church, was elected yesterday president of the National Council of Churches, a federation of 31 Protestant and Eastern Orthodox denominations with a membership of 40 million churchgoers.

description: The diesels are coming . . . the diesels are coming.

description: BRANCHBURG Basketball Officiating for Women will be offered at Somerset County College, starting tomorrow. The 12session course will be given on Monday and Wednesday evenings from 7 to 9 o'clock.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx announced the conviction late Friday night of John Brown, 34 years old of 1341 Harrod Avenue, the Bronx, on charges of shooting Anthony Wingate, 23, son of Criminal Court Judge Livingston Wingate. Mr. Brown, who faces 7 15 years in prison, will be sentenced by Judge Joseph Sullivan on Nov. 19. Mr. Merola said the Dec. 12, 1973, shooting in a tavern at 1413 Bronx River Avenue took place after a woman asked Mr. Wingate's aid to prevent Mr. Brown from bothering her. The young man was shot in the jaw and the back of the head.

title: Tiant Says Dad Spotted His Mistakes
description: BOSTON, Oct. 11  Luis Tiant Sr. and Luis Jr. embraced, not as emotionally as they did seven weeks ago when they saw each other for the first time in 15 years. But they felt good for each other, nonetheless. Father was happy for son and son was happy that father was here today.

title: Chaminade Wins For New Coach
description: HICKSVILLE, L.I., Oct. 11 Chaminade, which unexpectedly dismissed its head coach, Tom Kiley, earlier this week, surprised Holy Trinity, 14.7, today for its first victory in three games. The home team has now lost its last two games after an opening game victory.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: Until recently collectors of photographic memorabilia usually limited themselves to vintage cameras and equipment, or the lovely cases that held daguerreotypes. The photographic images themselves were considered valueless and except for the works of well known early photographers, the bulk of the photographs made during the first century of photography went completely unnoticed and unwanted.

title: Bucknell Downs Lafayette, 155
description: EASTON, Pa., Oct. 11Scoring all of its points in the second half, Bucknell ended Lafayette's threegame winning string today with a 155 football victory. The Leopards had led, 20, a halftime on a safety.

Y., weekly, was married yesterday to Randall Paul Howell, associate editor of National Home Center News, published twice a month by LebharFriedman, Inc., of New York, publishers of trade journals. The couple will use the surname of CarolinHowell.

title: Government Foes in Turkey Clash 2 Hours With Police
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 11 (Reuters)Police and demonstrators clashed for two hours today in some of the worst violence the Turkish capital has seen for several years. At least one person was reported killed and 32 were reported wounded.

title: What did Lorenz Hart and Oscar Hammerstein II have in common?
description: Musical Stages is no hardknocks autobiography. In Richard Rodgers's home there was always food on the tableand a piano in the living room. By 6 he was playing by ear, by 9 he was improvising his own tunes and at 15 he wrote his first complete musical comedy score. Two years later he met Lorenz Hart and within months they had collaborated on their first song, Any Old Place With You, and had heard it performed in a Broadway show. The moment of their actual

title: Susan Tubbs Married To William A. Hamlin
description: Susan Pratt Tubbs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Durant Tubbs of Mantoloking, N.J., and William Armstrong Hamlin were married yesterday afternoon in St. SimonbytheSea Episcopal Chapel in Mantoloking. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David St. George.

title: No Change in Store for Asbury Park's Boardwalk
description: ASBURY PARKThis resort's welltrodden boardwalk will remain as it is, at least for the time being, and not be extended inland from the oceanfront to the downtown business district.

title: Music: Sister Pianists
description: Andree Juliette and Alberte Brun, Frenchborn sisters who are pianists, gave a joint recital at Carnegie Hall on Friday night. Andree lives in this country and has been heard previously in New York. Alberte teaches in Germany.

title: Notes: A Bicentennial Broadside from Paris
description: TWO centuries ago, the American Colonies, allowed to trade only with England, turned to France for help as partner in trade and war. Now the lines are being drawn for a new '76 battle. Like the old, it is concerned with merchandise  the goods being the American traveler. Both Britain and France are beating the drum for their associations with the United States and its Revolution; both are vying for Americans to pledge allegianceto themby celebrating the Bicentennial with a transAtlantic trip.

title: Letters of James Stephens
description: Most writers of modern Ireland made their family backgrounds into their subjectmatter, but James. Stephens sprang out of mystery and preferred to keep things that way. If there is no doubt that he is the sprightliest of modern Irish novelistpoets, there is doubt about his parentage and his name, and a fair certainty that the birthday and year he claimed for himselfFeb. 2, 1882were wrong. That day in time had already been preempted by James Joyce; and Stephens, who in youth detested Joyce, cannot knowingly have sought calendar kinship with him. More likely, because Stephens was invariably sympathetic to the intrusions of small creatures into the universe, he chose Feb. 2 because it was Groundhog Day. The matter of his illegitimacy is of no concern to his readers but was evidently of consequence to him, and it is sad that Mr. Finneran, in this scrupulous edition of selected letters, has resolve it.

title: Safe Landing at Dulles
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) An airliner made an emergency landing today at Dulles International Airport after its landing gear did not function properly, according to a duty officer at the Federal Aviation Administration. The plane, identified as American Airlines Flight 463 out of New York's La Guardia Airport, made a safe landing and there were no injuries to the 87 persons on board.

title: Car Strippers Prowl Streets Of the City
description: Police tell a story about the driver who returned to his stalled car on the CrossBronx expressway to find a man taking off a rear tire.

title: Red Bank Is Victorious, 1312, on Kick by Scoppetuolo
description: Steve Scoppetuolo's conversion kick with 27 seconds to play yesterday gave Red Bank a 1312 victory over Manasquan and extended the state's longest school football winning streak to 20 games.

title: TV DrugBan Sought
description: Seventeen state Attorneys General are seeking a ban on TV advertising of overthecounter drugs between 6 A.M. and 9 P.M. to discourage drug abuse among children. Details, Page 39.

title: Grow Something Different
description: The new popularity of terrariums has spawned a fine array of different and interesting plants to grow. They are well worth the time it takes to seek them out in specialty greenhouses, mail order catalogues and wellstocked garden shops.

title: TENSION IS HIGH IN SOUTH BOSTON
description: BOSTON, Oct. 11The 150 white students marched up the steep hill towards South Boston High School behind an American flag, They Massed behind the flag, facing lines of state troopers at the entrance.

title: The Ardennes Anomaly: Belgium's OtherWorldly Enclave
description: WITH the coming of autumn, my thoughts turn to the Ardennes, that strange, wooded anomaly which makes the southeast corner of otherwise urban Belgium one of the wildest places remaining in Europe. The summer heat and the vacationers fade fast, leaving the offseason traveler virtually alone in an antediluvian landscape of misty pine forest, fern and heather,, less than two hours by train or automobile from metropolitan Brussels. Those who have not forgotten how to use their feet or a bicycle can travel narrow roads and unsurfaced paths that wind through benign hills and verdant, quiet valleys where one hears the roar of waterfalls or the gentle splash of brooks long before they can be seen.

title: Patricia Gardiner Going ls Wed To William Barker Holmberg
description: Patricia Gardiner Going, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward John Going of Stamford, Conn., was married early last evening to William Barker Holmberg, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert E. Holmberg of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, and Lake Chatauqua, N.Y.

title: Marinaro Worries About Jets, His Job With Vikings
description: Ed Marinaro, the former Cornellian, has finally made it into the Minnesota Vikings' starting lineup and, if he keeps the job, you can watch him play fullback today against the New York Jets on television (Channel 2 at 1 P.M.). This is the fourth season at Minnesota for Marinaro, who at Cornell set the collegiate record for most yards gained. 4,715, in a career. His fourth Viking season almost did not come about because Bud Grant, the coach, had him on waivers late in the summer as Grant was arranging his 43man squad.

title: Anatomical Donations Law
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 11 (UPI)Gov. James A. Rhodes has signed legislation providing space on Ohio drivers'licenses for blood type and a statement of whether the holder wishes to make an anatomical donation in the event of death. Proponents said the law will facilitate the removal of vital organs from willing donors killed in accidents. The new law will enable potential donors to give notice of their intentions on their driver license application in the presence of two witnesses

title: Communists in Europe Reach Compromise on Congress Plan

title: MICHAEL KUTTNER

description: DETROITNever ... never, said Matthew S. McLaughlin, vice president of marketing at the Ford Motor Company, shaking his head. He had just been asked whether he had ever seen so many sudden shifts in the auto industry in so short a time.

title: Saudis Seek British Beer But Without Alcohol

title: Manes Denies Democrats Gave Payments to Attain Judgeships

title: Sports News Briefs
description: A. J. Foyt, a threetime Indianapolis 500 winner, strengthened his bid for 1975 driveroftheyear honors yesterday when he was named third phase winner in the quarterly Martini & Rossi balloting. Foyt, of Houston, received 103 points to 92 for the top stockcar driver, Richard petty of Randleman, N. C. A formula 5000 driver, Brian Redman of England, impressive with a victory in the inaugural race through the streets of Long Beach, Calif., in September, was third with 67 points.

title: JetsVikings Statistics
INVESTING

title: UNESCO Will Sell Medals For Funds to Save Temples
description: PARIS, Oct. II (Reuters)UNESCO, The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, has commissioned medals to raise money to preserve the Egyptian temples of Philae.

title: The Fun and Profit of Having Your Head in the Clouds
description: All of us at one time oranother have given the weather some thoughtif for no other reason than merely to grouse about it. And who hasn't taken a minute or two on a summer day to watch large white woolly clouds float by overhead? A little curiousity about these clouds will eventually lead to the knowledge that these fluffy clouds, are normally indicative of fair weatherthat is, unless they build up vertically in the afternoon to form anvilshaped, dark looking tops. Then they mean thunderstorms.

title: Greenland Patrols: 2 Long, Lonely Years
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 11 (AP)Cmdr. Mogens Guldbrandsen has issued his annual call for volunteers to join what Danish military men consider the world's loneliest patrol. For two years, it will travel over the icy wilderness of north and northeast Greenland.

title: Bill to Assist Alcoholics Gains

The bill would eliminate all criminal penalties for public drunkenness and establish regional treatment centers throughout the state.

title: OUTPUT PROBLEMS REPORTED BY HANOI
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 11 (AP) North Vietnam says its state production plan for 1975 has run into problems because of bureaucratic mismanagement and worker apathy.

title: Black Magic, Tight Defense
description: BOSTON, Oct. 11For three timings you'd have thought Luis Tiant was doing it with chicken entrails, fingernail parings and wax effigies of the Red menace from Cincinnati. Sparky Anderson's strongarm mob was massaging the old witch doctor's service, but the fiercest shots were line drives straight into Red Sox gloves. With his own black magic and the complicity of people named Doyle, Cooper and Lynn, Luis was pitching a perfect game. We may never know, said a man on the roof of Fenway Park, whether Tiant has a balk move or not.

title: Mrs. Mitchell Out of Hospital
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) Martha Mitchell has left Northern Virginia Doctors Hospital and will be treated for cancerous blood cell disease as an outpatient, she said today. Doctors have diagnosed Mrs. Mitchell's ailment as multiple myeloma and have prescribed chemotherapy every four to six weeks.

description: No one should go through life without having seen Kurt Jooss's great antiwar ballet, The Green Table. There are not many dance works about which such statements can he made, but certainly it can be justified on the grounds of this ballet's theatrical power and Humane message.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 (AP)A defensive back, James Wilson, Scored two touchdowns owns and helped set up another touchdown and a field goal as the University of Pittsburgh routed Temple, 556, in college football today.

title: The American Commonwealth Revisited
description: In 1888, when Lord Bryce wrote his classic volumes on The American Commonwealth, he thought America was sailing a summer sea and setting a course of responsible liberty that would be a model for the world. Now Irving Kristol and Nathan Glazer have produced a thoughtful and troubling tenthanniversary issue of The Public Interest, which looks at The American Commonwealth1976 and finds that the seas are stormy and the outlook for liberty and democracy is bleak and distressing.

description: LISBON, Oct. 11 (AP)Maria Morals says she is confused about the political situation in Portugal. She has a son who is a Communist and a soninlaw who she thinks may be a closet fascist.

Bogosian's first score came on a 17yard pass from Chris Yetten, the quarterback. In the third period, he picked off a Poly pass and returned it 72 yards for the winning score.

I., Oct. 11 mets Champ, who was convalescing from what see??ed to be a major ailment little more than a week ago, was the surprise winner of the $154,222 Messenger Stakes at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The 3yearold was clocked fo rthe mile pace in 1:59 15, eqauling the stakes record.

title: Chichi: Rites and Revelry
description: THE Mayas toil up the steep stone staircase, pausing at each step to swing their censers and repeat the ancient incantations. Blue clouds of incense darken the bright sun, turning the bowed figures into shadowy apparitions. At the base of the steps the witch doctor accepts coins from arriving pilgrims and drops more incense onto the blazing altar to frighten away evil spirits.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: What is a dance company? An agglomeration of dancers? An instrument for a choreographer? A receptacle for a repertory? An ego trip for a dance ego in need of exercise? All, or none, of the above? Perhaps a dance company can be best defined as a point of view about dancing.

title: Weapons, Cash and Files Seized in Raids in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 11 (AP)Federal agents and the local police today seized large amounts of records and equipment used in illegal gambling, activities throughout Hawaii, the authorities announced.

title: There's a Return to Faculty Surveillance
description: The essence of an honor system, widely regarded as one of the loftiest of academic ideals, is selfgovernance. Students generally sign a pledge on assigned papers and examinations to the effect that they have neither given nor received aid. Exams are normally held without proctors, and discipline for violations is handled by a student board. Integral to most systems is a commitment by students not only to behave honestly themselves but also to take action when they see others violating the code.

title: Old Sawmill is Used To Restore Buildings

title: SUPERDONE ISSUE IN LOUISIANA RACE

title: Julian Bream Shows His Usual Virtuosity On Lute and Guitar
description: Julian Bream is only 42 years old, but as far as Americans land probably many othersare concerned, he is the old master of the lute and guitar. (The oldest guitar master s, of course, Andres Segovia, and whatever peers Mr. Bream may have among Spanish guitarists of his own generation are not nearly so well known here.) He has been touring the United States annually since 1958, and in his only New York recital this season, Friday night in Town Hall, he drew the customary capacity audience, which listened with almost breathless attention to everything he played.

title: Headliners
description: Martha Mitchell's Illness Martha Mitchell has been hospitalized with what is described as a type of malignancy. Mrs. Mitchell, the estranged wife of former Attorney General John Mitchell, is suffering from myeloma, a rare form of cancer that affects the bone marrow cells. Despite the ominous history of the diseaseit is almost always fatalMrs. Mitchell's doctors are guardedly optimistic. Mrs. Mitchell says she was shocked by the suddenness of the disease's attack. I always have hope, she added.

title: 9 Arrested in Ansonia Racial Clash
description: Nine students were arrested in Ansonia, Conn., yesterday on charges stemming from what the police called a pitched battle between scores of black and white teenagers Friday in Ansonia High School. School officials yesterday minimized accounts of the fighting and denied that it had racial overtones.

title: FILM VIEW
description: About halfway through Hearts of The West, Howard Zieff's new comedy about Bpicturemaking in the Hollywood of the early thirties, you realize that the film's leisurely pace is not, as you might have expected, a prelude to something else, a slow buildup to a boff. It is, instead, the method and style of the film. Hearts of The West drags its foot, like Tom Sawyer on his way to school on a fine spring morning. It's a movie composed almost entirely of asides, of little narrative detours and of subsidiary characters who may not have a great deal to do with the principal plot line.

Whitener of Arlington and the late Mr. Whitener. Mr. and Mrs. John E. Platt of Alexandria, Va., are the parents of the bridegroom, who is a systems analyst with Donovan Data Systems.

title: A case of dj vu
description: Putting an idea in the form of a fable is a coward's ploy, or at least a hedge against a precarious bet. If your idea is howled down, you can always say, For God's sake, don't be so literal. Don't you know a metaphor when you hear one? I can't remember exactly, but I think I had some such defense ready to offer when this fable was first published in The New York Times Magazine, June 14, 1970, under the title of Once Upon a TimeA Fable of Student Power. But it is more than five years later and, like everyone else, I have observed with a sense of impotence the accelerating decline of civilized life in the cities, especially New York. It is now clearer than ever that some major redesign of social organization is necessary to halt the trend toward entropy now under way. Redesign, not overhaulfor we are past the point where making an institution work means replacing the wornout parts. And so, I resubmit the article for reflection, not as a metaphor but as an in urban planning.

It was Andover's first loss after two victories. while Lawrenceville's record is now 21.

title: RATE OF MARRIAGE DECLINES IN CITY
description: The marriage rate in New York City has declined to the lowest rate in six years, standing at 8.9 marriages for each 1,000 people in 1973.

title: Jazz Notes:
description: Although Duke Ellington composed music with some measure of success for ballet, films, symphony orchestras, television, and the church, as well as jazz and popular programs, his efforts to compose for the Broadway theater were largely frustrated. The score he wrote with John Latouche for Beggar's Holiday (en adaptation of John Gay's Beggar's Opera) was heard on Broadway for only three months early in 1947. PousseCafe (also known as Sugar City) lasted for three performances in 1966. Jump for Joy tried out successfully in Los Angeles in 1941 but could not make the crosscountry leap to New York.

title: Book Ends
description: Oldies. Elizabeth Seifert. Horatio Alger, Louis Bromfield, Bess Streeter Aldrich, Faith Baldwin, Elswyth Thane... do those names ring any bells? Not, perhaps, if you're under 40 tat least), but they were all bestselling authors in their day. Now the outofprint books by these authors live once again between hard coversfor that is the reinearnation they have been given by a small, new publishing firm called Aeonian Press. Aeonian is a reprint operation specializingunlike most reprintersin fiction and doing business out of the tiny town of Leyden, Mass. (with offices also in Jackson Heights, N. Y.). The firm was founded by Brooklynborn real estate entrepreneur Jed Clauss in the fall of 1973, and in its short life has built up a list of over 175 resurrected titles by authors like those named above, with sales mainly to libraries. Mr. Clauss, who is still a vice president of Cross and Brown, a real estate investment firm, started thinking about becoming a reprinter while on vacation in Jamaica when the conversation turned to certain old books and why they were no longer available. These reveries Ted Mr. Clauss eventually into partnership with an antiquarian book dealer (who has since died). He planned an initially modest operation financed entirely by his own capital, offering 16 or so titles. The list of titles has since ballooned, of course, and Mr. Clauss predicted in a recent interview that he would soon be over the 300 mark.

title: 'Lies My Father Told Me,' Memories of a Jewish Boyhood
description: Childhood memories, like too many successive sundaes, can be nauseating. But "Lies My Father Told Me," the Canadian-made comedy drama that arrived at the Paris Theater yesterday, makes its bittersweet nostalgia pleasurable without cloying aftereffects.Ted Allan's dramatization of remembrances of his own Jewish family in the Montreal melting pot of a half-century ago is brought appealingly alive with the aid of Jan Kadar's perceptive direction and some strong, natural performances.Father, mother, relatives and neighbors are important but not nearly as central to this memoir as 7-year-old David Herman and his bearded, Tevyalike, junkman grandfather (Zaida). They form a mutual admiration society that also includes Ferdeleh, the ancident nag that draws grandfather's creaking wagon (along with a happy David on Sundays) through slum backyard alleys and rich wooded areas in quest of castoffs.Grandfather's orthodox religious beliefs are transmitted to the loving youngster through parables and tall tales. If he accepts them and his Zaida on adoring, ingenuous faith, he is also confused and shattered by the reality of an irascible father, who is a failed inventor of creaseless pants and the like and is constantly seeking loans from the old man for pie-in-the-sky schemes.Of course, the teeming neighborhood scene's varied characters touch on and color the family's life. There are the local young prostitute, a friend of the clients and local kids, who is stridently done by Carole Lazare; the boy's truly doll-like little confidante-playmate, Cleo Paskal, and a gently argumentative Marxist tailor, portrayed to the manner born by the film's author.And there's a termagant housewife, played in vixenish style by Barbara Chilcott, whose complaints about grandfather's stable, its smells and the horse manure David spreads on her backdoor lead to the seriocomic denouement.A properly distraught performance by Marilyn Lightstone of David's hard-pressed young mother illuminates the tension of maintaining allegiances to her son, husband and father. And Len Birman's portrait of the luckless would-be inventor-husband is both brash and pitiable.Dominating the largely Canadian cast is the veteran Israeli actor Yossi Yadin, in a forceful yet tender delineation of the grandfather. His unwavering faith in ancient religious tenets is equal to his love of his grandson and his resigned but wise acceptance of his son-in-law's inadequacies. As the wide-eyed grandson, a newcomer, Jeffrey Lynas, reflects love, innocence, sibling rivalry and the ultimate shock of his grandfather's death with childlike but genuine conviction.The clashes between the grandfather and the father leave no doubts as to the boy's allegiance. And Mr. Kadar, the Czechoslovak director best known for his memorable "The Shop on Main Street," is equally pointed in his affection and professionalism. "Lies My Father Told Me" (actually the harsh truths the boy cannot understand or accept) may be somewhat sentimental and quaint in its Jewish rituals and traditions. But under Mr. Kadar's sensitive guidance, this journey back to lost youth modestly but touchingly reveals people as authentic as the settings in which they are captured.

title: Holiday Plans Vary
description: Stock exchanges, the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago and New York Mercantile exchanges will be open today. Other major commodities exchanges and banks in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will be closed in observance of Columbus Day.

title: Pornographic Periodicals Tied to Organized Crime
description: Nearly all of the major hardcore pornographic newspapers and periodicals in the United States are distributed by companies controlled by organized crime members, according to law enforcement officials, underworld figures and some of the newspaper owners themselves.

description: The now ratified settlement of the musicians strike that has darkened much of Broadway for nearly a month represents a recognition by both the striking union and the producers that prolongation of the tieup would be as destructive to the future of the theater as it already has been to the economic health of this metropolis.

description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 12 (UPI)Mite Air Force launched a satellite employing a Scout booster here last night. A spokesman said the 1unching occurred at 11:40 P.M. No other details were available.

title: The U.F.T. Settlement
description: One of the most important tasks. facing New York City in its financial crisis is to maintain essential services while holding down their cost. The new contract proposed by the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers is just the wrong kind of solution. It represents a continuing increase in costs, accompanied by drastic cut in services to children. In rejecting the proposed contract, the state's new Emergency Financial Control Board is raising issues that the Board of Education and the union have ignored up to now.

title: Mrs. Gunter Takes First Final Since 72
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 12 (AP)Nancy Gunter won her first tennis tournament in three years by beating Virginia Wade of Britain, 46, 75, 64, in the final of the 50,000 Phoenix Thunderbirds tocayi Mrs. Gunter earned $10,000.

title: Ethiopian Students and Farmers Share Reorganization of Nationalized Land
description: SABATA, Ethiopia, Oct. 10 In a sloping field of grass, lush at the end of a season of abundant rain, about 50 farmers surrounded five city youths in animated conversation.

title: Nothing but Class
description: BOSTON, Oct. 12The Boston Red Sox were three putouts this side of their second World Series victory in two games when Johnny Bench got his second hit of the day, a sliced drive that curled away from Dwight Evans in right field. Bench was Cincinnati's first batter in the ninth inning and the Sox were leading, 21, so when he steamed into second base he represented the tying run. His was the fifth hit off William Francis Lee 3d, tall, talented and lefthanded, who had stood off the Red Menace all through this raw and rainy afternoon. Out the dugout came the manager, Darrell of Johnson, waving to the bull pen for Dick Drago, who had saved two of Boston's three victories in the American League pennant playoff playoff.

title: U.S. PRODS CHILE ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The Ford Administration has told Chile that the United States will attend a proposed assembly of the Organization of American States in Santiago next year only if the Chileans cooperate with an international investigation of human rights.

title: The Dance
description: Embrace Tiger and Return to Mountain is the only ballet in the Eliot Feld Ballet's current repertory that is not by Mr. Feld. Seeing it at its first performance of the season Saturday night at the Newman Theater, one suddenly had a new awareness of why Mr. Feld chose a work by Glen Tetley for his company.

title: Andretti Car Is First in 5000 Race
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 12 (AP)  Mario Andretti of Nazarab, Pa., starting from the pole, led all the way today in.capturing the $60,000 Monterey grand prix for Formula 5000 cars at Laguna Seca.

title: Virginia Haight Bride in Illinois

title: Philadelphia Mayor Hurt At Scene of Refinery Fire
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12 (AP) Mayor Frank Rizzo was injured tonight when an oil tank exploded as firemen fought a ninealarm blaze at the AtlanticRichfield Company oil refinery along the Schuylkill River.

title: Bridge
description: The experiment of holding a major New York tournament in Queens instead of Manhattan seems to have been a failure, if judged simply by attendance.. The number of competitors in the Metropolitan Championships at Aqueduct Raceway last Friday and Saturday was 35 per cent less than the last comparable tournament at the New York Hilton, long the favored location.

title: Dickson Takes Title

Oct. 12 (AP) 1 Marvin Carman won both 50lap features at Winchester Speedway today as Larry Dickson clinched his third United States Auto Club sprint division championship. Dickson finished fourth and fifth in the twin features, good enough for the division title. He also won in 1969 and 1970.

Mr. Rodino said Saturday his bill would place new limits on the disclosure of confidential tax information and allow citizens to recover damages caused by unauthorizzed disclosures.

title: CONVICT CAPTURED IN HUNT IN ILLINOIS

title: CHOLERAEPIDEMIC HITS BANGLADESR
description: DACCA, BangladeshA severe cholera epidemic is striking Bangladesh, which had an outbreak last year that was the worst in the territory's recent history.

title: The Ford Strategy
description: The fundamental economic problem before the country is the underperformance of the economy. This shortfall means lost jobs, lost profits and lower tax revenues As President Ford's budget message pointed out February, if the economy were to be as fully employed in 1976 as it was in 1974, there would be an additional $40 billion in tax receipts, assuming no change in tax rates. A vigorous economic recovery would make that figure even higher.

title: 3Year Pact Reached By National Symphony
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)The National Symphony Orchestra and its musicians reached agreement on a new contract early today, averting the possibility of a work stoppage.

title: The Hubbub of Baseball Fills Hub of Universe

title: Exodus Picks Up Speed Among Skilled Britons
description: LONDON, Oct. 12Doctors, plumbers and a wide variety of other skilled Britons are emigrating this year in perhaps even greater numbers than aerospace experts did to the United States during the brain drain a decade ago.

title: KISSINGER EXPECTS ARMS ACCORD SOON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Secretary of State Kissinger said today that 90 per cent of the negotiations for a new agreement with the Soviet Union on limitation of strategic arms had been concluded, and that prospects were good for a completed accord in a few months.

title: Reds Beat Red Sox and Even World Series
description: BOSTON, Oct. 12  The Cincinnati Reds survived an afternoon of New England weather and New England pitching today, scored two runs in the ninth inning, edged the Boston Red Sox, 32, and evened the World Series at one game apiece.

title: VATICAN DISPUTED ON MARITAL LAWS
description: CORONADO, Calif., Oct. 12Legal authorities of the Roman Catholic Church in America are challenging as inconsistent, inadequate and unacceptable the Vatican's proposed additions to canon law governing denial of the sacraments to divorced persons who remarry.

title: Analysts Cheered By Signs Fed Eases Credit Conditions
description: Many Wall Street analysts see increasing indications that the Federal Reserve will continue to ease credit conditions in the weeks ahead. The possibility has rekindled their hopes for lower interest rates and higher prices for the bond market. The weakness in the credit and stock markets in recent months has been attributed mostly to Higher interest rates.

title: An Old Bar Gives Way To an Imitation Old Bar
description: A 19thcentury bar and restaurant incongruously tucked amid the skyscrapers of Rockefeller Center closed last night to make way for a new tenant who will renovate the buildinginto an imitation 19thcentury bar and restaurant.

title: Trifecta Bet Pays $33,423

Although the 29yearold Livingston finally got his chance to become the No. 1 quarterback this season, a shoulder injury kept him sidelined for the last two games, which the Chiefs lost under Dawson's direction.

description: PUSSELLAWA, Sri Lanka  Sheran de Aiwis is the manager of the New Peacock Group tea estate here, one of the largest Britishowned plantations in Sri Lanka. Yet he does not officially know that on Wednesday his 400acre tea estate will become Government property.

description: BOSTON, Oct. 12 The speed and alertness of Dave Concepcion, along with the imperfections of three members of the Boston Red Sox, produced the stolen base that positioned the winning run for the Cincinnati Reds today in their 32 victory that squared the World Series.

title: Kenya Frees ExOfficial
description: NAIROBI, Kenya. Oct. 12 (AP)Achieng Oneko, a former information minister who broke with President. Tomo Kenyatta and was arrested as a member of a banned leftist party, has been freed after six years in detention, a senior Government spokesman said today. Mr. Oneko was one of the founders of Kenya's independence struggle against Britain.

title: Kings Get 60 Lead, Post First Victory

description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 12Just about every Argentine is asking whether Isabel Martinez de Pern will return from her month's leave of absence and resume an active presidency.

title: Political Economics
description: Viewed as a tax program, the President's recommendations are seriously inequitable. Millions of the nation's poorest familiesthose with children and incomes under $5,000 a yearwould be worse off under the plan than they are now. This is because the President would drop the earned income credit that applies only to poor families where someone works and where there are children. This credit is an important innovation, added by Congress to this year's temporary tax reduction law, which deserves to be continued. Moreover, the President's plan would do nothing to close existing tax loopholes that primarily benefit those with high incomes.

title: Assault Suspect Hangs Himself In a Criminal Court Pen Here
description: A 45yearold prisoner accused of having shot three men earlier in the day in East Harlem hanged himself Saturday evening in an arraingnment pen in Criminal Court in Manhattan, police and correction officials reported yesterday.

title: Books of The Times

We have learned to make do with very little substance in the short story.
