title: Truffaut's 'Adele' Ends Film Festival
description: In 1863 Adle Hugo, the younger daughter of the great French poet and patriot, Victor Hugo, ran away from home on the Isle of Guernsey where her father was living in exile to follow a young English officer, a Lieutenant Pinson, to his new post in Halifax, Nova Scotia. Lieutenant Pinson was probably not a bad sort, not worse than most, but he wasn't very serious.It's thought that the young, inexperienced Adle had most likely been Lieutenant Pinson's mistress for a short time on Gurnsey, and it's known that she wanted desperately to marry him, though her father disapproved. In any case, Lieutenant Pinson was not interested  a circumstance that Adle was ill-equipped to understand or ever to support."The Story of Adle H.," Franois Truffaut's profoundly beautiful new film, is about Adle's journey, taken with measured steps, into a magnificent, isolating obsession, first to frozen Halifax and then, when Lieutenant Pinson is transferred to the West Indies, to Barbados, where Adle sweeps through the tropical streets and alleys of Bridegtown talking to herself, wearing a heavy black cloak, and looking like some mad, benign witch of the north.Unable to cope with the truth, and using her imagination and her feelings as carefully as someone writing a piece of fiction, Adle created another world where she became Lieutenant Pinson's wife, where love was her religion (and no humiliation too great a sacrifice), and where she kept a coded journal, only recently deciphered. It is this journal that is the basis for Mr. Truffaut's most severe, most romantic meditation upon love."The Story of Adle H." was shown last night at Avery Fisher Hall to close the 13th New York Film Festival, which, despite one spectacular disappointment and several others of a lesser order, has been one of the best festivals in recent years. Without question the Truffaut entry was the surprising highlight, even to one who has admired the French director's films over the years.One of the fascinations of the Truffaut career is in watching the way he circles and explores different aspects of the same subjects that dominate almost all of his films. However, "The Story of Adle H.," impeccably photographed by Nestor Almendros ("The Wild Child"), looks and sounds like no other Truffaut film you've ever seen.The colors are deep, rich and often dark, and the soundtrack is full of the noises that one associates with old costume films produced by M-G-M in its great dayscarriages riding over cobblestones, pens scratching across vellum, servants arriving and departing with important messages, bells that tinkle over the doors of bookshops. More important, there is the fine background score by the late Maurice Jaubert (he died in 1940), who composed for Vigo and Clair among others. The film has the manner of a romance but it's a romance from which all the conventional concerns have been eliminated.In the single-minded way in which the movie sticks to its subject, "The Story of Adle H." reminds one of "The Wild Child." It's virtually a one-character film. It contemplates the classic beauty of Adle, played with extraordinary grace by 20-year-old Isabelle Adjani of the Comdie Franaise, much as Catherine Deneuve was admired by the camera in "Mississippi Mermaid," and it appreciates the particularity of women in a fashion that recalls the erratic journey of Catherine to the crematorium in "Jules and Jim.""The Story of Adle H." is not a psychiatric case history, though all the facts seem to be there if one wants to accept it as such. Rather it's a poet's appreciation of the terrifying depth of Adle's feelings, which, early on, drive her to lying to her family, to making life miserable for Lieutenant Pinson in Halifax (including canceling his engagement to someone else), to spying on him, happily, as he makes love to another woman. She's willful and spoiled and, the film understands, impossible to deal with. Yet the film makes us see both the madness and the grandeur of the passion.It's this ability to allow us to see a subject from several different angles simultaneously that often proves most unsettling in a Truffaut film. Toughness and compassion get all mixed up. It's also this talent that separates his films from those of all other directors who are working in the humanist tradition today. "The Story of Adle H." is a film that I suspect Jean Renoir would much admire. He understands such things.

title: A Liquor War in New England
description: HOOKSETT, N. H., Oct. 13At 3:30 on this holiday afternoon, there were 37 cars in the parking lot of the new staterun liquor store here. Three were from New Hampshire and 34 fromMassachusetts.

title: Pricing Set Tomorrow on Week's Issue
description: With credit markets showing little activity yesterday because of the Columbus Day holiday, Wall Street analysts turned their attention to tomorrow evening's pricing for Exxon Pipeline's mammoth $400  million financing. This tripleA rated industrial, scheduled for public offering Thursday, ranks as the most important corporate deal of the week. Almost all proceeds of the sale by the Exxon Corporation subsidiary are earmarked to help finance the parent company's share of the Trans Alaska Pipeline.

title: Business Brief
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 13 (UPI)The Indonesian State Oil Company, Pertamina, confirmed today a 20cent increase in the price for Sumatran light crude oil retroactive to Oct. 1far less than the 10 per cent increase agreed by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Open Interest
description: Monday, Oct. 13, 1975 (In bushels, 000 omitted)

title: Dance: Feld Mazurka
description: A mazurka is a dance procession with stamping, a choreographic ritual with heart. A Polish scholar of the dance once described it very simply. It was Helene Wolska who once wrote: Originally it came from the province of Mazovia, a true folk dance for eight or sixteen couples in a circle. Skillful dancers engaged in much improvisation, so the dance was full of variety. It used to be sung; its chief characteristic is the strong accent on the second beat, and it is now often used as a stately dance to end a ball.

title: Net Imports of Oil Fe1113% for Half From Period of 73
description: Net oil imports of the seven. largest oilimporting nations in. the first half of 1975 fell 1$ per cent from 1973 levels because of high prices and economic recession, the Petroleum. Intelligence Weekly reported yesterday.

title: OCCIDENTAL TALKS WITH LIBYANS END
description: Negotiations in New York between the Occidental Petroleum Corporation and the Libyan Government were broken off yesterday without any progress on either the restrictions presently preventing nonLibyan employes of Occidental from leaving Libya or the oil matters in dispute.

title: Karl H. Helfrich, ExOfficer Of Forstmann, Kress, Dies
description: Karl H. Helfrich, a retired vice president in charge of public relations at the Forstmann Woolen Company in Passaic, N. J., and later in the same position at S. H. Kress & Co., the retail variety chain, died Sunday in Mountainside Hospital, Glen Ridge, N. J. He was 73 years old and lived at IS Edgecliff Road in Upper Montclair N. J.

title: Events Today
description: THE COLLECTED WORKS OF BILLY THE KID. A dramatization of poems by Michael Ondaatie. Directed be John Wood. At the Leperca Space, Brooklyn Acariemy Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at 7.

title: Guerrillas Are Said to Kill 7 In SouthWest African Raid
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 13 (Reuters)Nationalist guerrillas killed seven people in weekend raids into the northern area of SouthWest Africa, South African military headquarters announced today.

title: VW Is Adding Work Shifts Due to Increased Demand
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany. Oct. 13 (Reuters) Volkswagenwerk, A.G., said today it might have to bring in additional shifts and take on new and replacement workers next year because of Increased demand.

title: City Hall vs. Reform
description: New Yorkers who are fed up with mismanagement in City Hall and unwilling to settle for proxy rule from Wall Street or Albany will have a chance to strike modest blow for reform and selfrule next month when they are scheduled to vote on a series of proposals for revising the City Charter.

title: Taiwan, Diplomatic Ties Weak, Is Thriving on Its SelfReliance
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 13 Six months after the death of Chiag Kaishek, Nationalist China's longtime President, this island state seems to be growing stronger both economically and politically, even as it appomaches diplomatic extinction.

title: Market Place
description: Word from Washington last Friday that Iran might be interested in renewing her bid for a major stake in Pan American World Airways caused several Wall Street analysts to remark that a deal at this time would probably be on terms more favorable to Pan Am than were contemplated nine months ago.

title: 22 Food Outlets Told to Clean Up Or Face Being Shut
description: The Health Department has cited 22 more food businesses as failing a Health Code inspection and warned that they could be ordered closed if the violations persisted on a second and final inspection.

title: Foreman Ready for Comeback
description: Almost a year after losing his world heavyweight championship to Muhammad Ali in Zaire, George Foreman has overcome the confusion that beset him following his eighthround knockout and is setting out in quest of the title again.

title: W. R. NEW BURGHER, AIDED THE ELDERLY
description: Walter R. Newburgher, vice president of the National Council of Senior Citizens and president of the Congress of Senior Citizens of Greater New York, died here Saturday. He was 83 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: MUSICIANS REJECT PITTSBURGH OFFER
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13Members of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, who have been on strike since Sept. 29, rejected today by a vote of 185 to 13 a new offer submitted by management over the weekend.

title: LONGSHOREMEN BOW IN SAN JUAN DISPUTE
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Oct. 13 (UPI)  Longshoremen began unloading the Puerto Rican Government's container ship fleet today under a Federal court restraining order temporarily halting picketing in jurisdictional labor dispute that had threatened the island with a food shortave.

title: Nolan, Wise Put Healed Arms On Line in Third Game Tonight
description: CINCINNATI; Oct. 13Far from the great wall and rugged weather of Fenway Park, the Cincinnati Reds and Boston Red Sox switched cities today and prepared to resume the World Series tomorrow night all even at one game apiece.

title: Callaway Says He Is Going to Stay, but Turmoil Continues Over His Handling of the President's Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13I'm as sure as I'm sitting here I'm going to stay, said president ent Ford's campaign mianager, Howard H. Callaway, sounding a mite defensive but not quite anxious about the Republican turmoil in and Around the President Ford Committee.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market advanced yesterday in trading slowed by the observance of the Columbus Day holiday in many areas.

title: Vatican Theologian Says The Male Pill Is Illicit
description: ROME, Oct. 13 (AP)A leading Roman Catholic theologian said today that the church is against the use of contraceptive pills for men as well as for women.

title: FloodRelief Centers Closed in 12 Counties
description: Flooddisaster relief centers closed throughout the state yesterday after having prossed more than 3,300 claims for loans and grants submitted by victims of last month's heavy rains.

title: Democratic Women Form an Alliance and Will Seek Woman Vice President
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13A group of prominent Democratic women, including backers of at least six candidates for the Presidential nomination, announced today the formation of an alliance aimed at making sure that both the Democratic party's platform and its nominee supported a long list of women's issues.

title: A Move to Change Name of Mount McKinley Is Gaining Support
description: After more than a half century of onandoff controversy, a move to change the name of Mount McKinley, North America's highest peak, is gaining momentum.

title: Levi Panel on Crime
description: Attorney General Edward H. Levi has disclosed that he named a Justice Department panel to develop ways of moving against corporate crime. Page 15.

title: How Harry Stengel Manages the Reds
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 13Wearing his redsleeved sweatshirt, George (Sparky) Anderson, white haired at age 41, put his halfeaten bolognaandcheese sandwich next to the bottle of Dr. Pepper on his desk. As he talked today after a World Series workout, he lighted a cigarette but soon he placed it in an ashtray, the smoke curling up.

title: New National Klan Formed By Old Group's Dissidents
description: LODI, Ohio. Oct. 13 (UPI)Dale Reusch, former grand dragon of the Ohio Ku Klux Klan, said today that a new national klan had been organized under the group's old title of Invisible Empire of the Ku Klux Klan and would include women, children, Roman Catholics and naturalizd citizens.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: JONAS D. NASSAU
description: Jonas D. Nassau, former owner of the Nassau Furniture Company of Paramus, N. J., died yesterday in Paterson. N. J., where he lived. He would; have been 78 year old tomorrow.

title: MISS SCHLOMOVITZ GIVES HARP RECITAL
description: Since leaving her post as principal harpist of the Milwaukee Symphony, Phyllis Schlomovitz has become head of the harp department at the University of California, Santa Cruz, and has continued her crusading work for the instrument via master classes, concert transcriptions and a soontobepublished Harp Method.

title: Mutiny and 4 Slayings Laid to Seaman
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Oct. 13 (AP)The apparent mutiny aboard the Panamanianregistered freighter Mimi was the work of a single Indonesian sailor, an agent for the ship's charterer said today.

title: Bridge:
description: A foursome that is formidable in skill if not in reputation scored a convincing victory in the Swiss team championship that concluded the Greater New York Bridge Association's Metropolitan Championships at the Aqueduct Raceway Sunday.

title: J. ALEXANDER KERNS, CLASSICS PROFESSOR
description: Dr. J. Alexander Kerns, an emeritus pruiessor in the classics department at New York University and a former vice president of the Linguistics Society of America, died Saturday in Staten Island Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 855 Van Duzer Street, Stapleton, S. I.

title: Earthen Lines Thrown Up At Colorado Forest Fire
description: EAGLE, Colo.. Oct. 13 (UPI)Bulldozers gouged out 24footide earthen lines today to halt the spread of the worst forest fire in recent state history, Which has destroyed 4,500 acres of aspen spruce and pine in the White River National Forest of northcentral Colorado.

title: STUDY SET ON GIFTS TO PENTAGON AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) A Congressional investigation was announced today, into whether the Northrop Corporation and other defense contractors entertained and gave favors to Pentagon officials.

title: M'INTYRE MUSEUM DESTROYED BY FIRE
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 13 (AP)The Jerusalem Temple Museum, owned by the Rev. Carl McIntire, a radio evangelist, was destroyed by fire today, ard the authorities said they were investigating the possibility of arson.

title: PRESIDENT VISITS HARTFORD TODAY
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 13When President Ford comes here tomorrow to attend a Republican fundraising dinner, he will be assured of at least a modest crowd even if the public does not turn out to see him.

title: STRAINS BESETTING ECONOMY OF ZAIRE
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Oct. 13 (AP)After a period of stability and economic gains, President Mobutu Sese Seko is facing internal strains, caused mainly by the worldwide recession, as he prepares to observe his 10th anniversary as leader of this once deeply troubled Central African nation.

title: Turkish Premier Prevails With Thin Margin of Vote
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 13 The opposition Republican People's party scored gains in midterm parliamentary elections yesterday but not enough to change what has amounted to a stalemate in Turkish politics for the last two years.

title: Korea Talks Will Resume
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 13 (AP)The South Korean Goverment agreed to day to a meeting with North Korean representatives Oct. 23 to seek resump.; tion of Red Cross talks to reunite separated families. South Korea also proposed that political talks between the two governments be resumed. North Korea has boycotted the talks since 1973 because of the South Korea's stringent antiCommunits policies.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: United Press international

title: Kissinger Goes to Canada For Series of Talks Today
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (Reuters)  Secretary of State Kissinger will go to Ottawa tomorrow to accept a longstanding invitation for talks with the Canadian External Affairs Secretary, Allan J. MacEachen.

title: Astroturf Is Looming as Reds Weapon
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 13Riverfront Stadium, the fiveyearold edifice overlooking the Ohio River, looks like any other modern ballpark. But it is different and not as harmless as it pretends to be.

title: Compensatory Care Is Urged
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 13 (UPI)Robert Lerner, an associate counsel with the American Arbitration Association, suggested today that some persons awarded damages for negligent medical care would be better served if they were given a contract promising appropriate medical care for the rest of their lives. He made his remarks in testimony before the Maryland Medical MalpracTice Insurance study Commission.

title: Contract Awards
description: SEDCO, INC., has received a $IOR.3million contract from the NATIONAL IRANIAN OIL COMPANY for the construction of nineline systems from Esfahain to Tehran, Iran.

title: Helstoski Loses Bid To Court to Reveal His Jury Testimony
description: NEWARK, Oct. 13 (UPI)Representative Henry Helstoski, Democrat of New Jersey, made an unsuccessful bid today to release testimony he gave a Federal Grand Jury investigating shakedowns of illegal aliens.

title: DAVID R. GRACE, 57, LED BROKERAGE FIRM
description: David R. Grace, president of Sterling, Grace & Co., stockbrokers and investment bankers, died yesterday of cancer at Fitzgerald Mercy Medical Center, Darby. Pa. He was 57 years old and lived at Oyster Bay Cove. L. I.

title: Levi Panel on Crime
description: Attorney General Edward H. Levi has disclosed that he named a Justice Department panel to develop ways of moving against corporate crime. Page 15.

title: SINGER TO CONTINUE TO OPERATE UNIT
description: The Singer Company plans to continue to operate its busiiness machines division and we Shope to put it back on a profitable basis, Edwin J. Graf, new chief operating officer of the company, stated last night. We are the leader in the electronic terminal business in point of cash register sales and have a good customer base, Mr. Graf said.

title: 2 SUGAR CONCERNS SUING CUSTOMERS
description: In a suit filed yesterday in Federal District Court in San Francisco, the Great Western Sugar Company charged that eight of its customers had violated antitrust laws by pricefixing.

title: 8.2% CITY JOB LOSS IN 70's FORECAST
description: Even assuming a nationally economic recovery and a successful fight against inflation, New York City will have 313,732 fewer jobs in 1980 than in 1970, a net loss of 8.2 per cent over the decade, according to a State Labor pertinent forecast.

title: Russians Vs. Irish at Garden
description: Notre Dame's basketball team will play the Soviet Union's national team at Madison Square Garden, Thursday, Nov. 20, in the final game of the Soviet quintet's 11 game tour of the United States. A spokesman for the Amateur Athletic Union said yesterday: We expect that about 80 per cent of the Russian players on this team will be from their team that won the gold medal in the 1972 Olympics. The A.A.U. is sponsoring four of the games, including the finale.

title: Wellington Cross, 88, Dies
description: Wellington Cross, a stage and vaudeville actor who became vice president of Elizabeth Arden International, the cosmetic i house, died Sunday night at his home, 25 Tudor City Place. He was 88 years old.

title: WNYCFM to Broadcast Repeats of Goon Show
description: WNYCFM radio will broadcast repeats of The Goon Show, a British Broadcasting Corporation comedy series from the nineteenfifties. The halfhour programs are scheduled to begin on Thursday, Nov. 6, at 10:30 P.M. and are being presented in cooperation with National Public Radio.

title: Crisis in Dtente
description: Despite Secretary Kissinger's necessary public optimism, negotiations for a historic tenyear Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty (SALT II) with Russia are now in serious trouble, placing in doubt Leonid Brezhnev's thricepostponed 1975 visit to the United Statesand, with it, the future of EastWest detente.

title: College, School Results
description: SOCCER

title: LLOYD F. KAHN SR.
description: Lloyd F. Kahn Sr., chairman, of Alkahn Label, Inc., a division of Willcox & Gibbs, Inc., died Sunday in New York Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 120 East 81st Street.

title: All in the Family
description: Fresh revelations in The Times about the owners and purveyors of pornographic movies, magazines and newspapers help to remove any pretense that these are legitimate businesses operating within the law. Behind the scores of adult only peepshows, bookstores and garish movie marquees are organizedcrime families, which have taken over the supply and distribution of pornography. The same gangsters who have made illicit fortunes out of narcotics, broken legs and broken laws market this lucrative and flourishing cash crop.

title: Saudi Government Shuffled to Balance Power of Princes
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 13 (AP)King Khalid of Saudi Arabia formed a new Cabinet today in an apparent attempt to reapportion the political rower of the two most influencial princes.

title: QUARTER NET OFF AT FIRST CHICAGO
description: The First Chicago Corporation, parent of the First National Bank of Chicago, reported yesterday a decline in thirdquarter earnings.

title: Ousted Jesuit Floats In an Earthly Limbo
description: Since he was expelled by the Jesuits more than a year ago, the Rev. Joseph P. O'Rourke has lingered in ecclesiastical limbo.

title: Stylish First Night Is More Sedate Than in Past
description: The Metropolitan Opera opened its 91st season last night, doing it with style, verve, and, of course, attendant hysteria. Politicians were there, social people were there, people who just loved opera were there, too. Anthony A. Bliss, the executive director of the Met, was also there. In the old days, he said he would have avoided it.

title: Parent of Flyers Will Undergo Surgery Today for Neck Injury
description: Another star may have fallen in the National Hockey League. Bernie Parent, whose exploits in the Philadelphia Flyers net have earned him two Vezina Trophy Awards in the last two years, faces neck surgery this morning that will put him out of action for about a month.

title: Professor at Holy Cross Named Le Moyne President
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 13 (AP)  The Rev. William J. O'Halloran, chairman of the psychology department at Holy Cross College has been named president of Le Moyne College in Syracuse effective Jan. 1.

title: Schools Ordered to Desegregate Are Offered Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) The Administration offered S3,250.000 today in emergency aid to school districts under late court orders to desegregate.

title: STATE TOLD TO STOP NONUNIONJOBS BAN
description: TRENTON, Oct. I (UPI)Attorney General William F. Hyland has ordered the State Division of Building and Construction to stop rejecting construction bids by nonunion concerns as a means of avoiding labor unrest.

title: ABRAHAM BERMAN, LAWYER, 86, DEAD
description: Abraham L. Berman, a lawyer for more than 60 years for many leading theatrical figures, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 875 Park Avenue.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: Los Angeles 6, N.Y. Rangers 4. N.Y. Islanders 3, Boston 3. Buffalo B. Toronto 3. Chicago 3, Vancouver O. Philadelphia 4, California 1.

title: Television
News Summary and Index
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau announced that he would ask the Canadian Parliament today for authority to impose restraints on rises in prices and wages. The program, he said in a national broadcast, aims to cope with a more than 11 per cent rate of inflation and a jobless rate of more than 7 per cent. [Page 1, Column 11

title: BEAME SUGGESTS DEFICIT IN BUDGET IS OVERESTIMATED
description: The city's fiscal crisis took a sudden, surprising turn last night as Mayor Beame's office asserted that the city's budgetcutting burden for the next two years might have been overestimated by as much as $200million.

title: Tower's View on Texas: Ford Is Likely Winner
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 13 (AP) Senator John G. Tower, Republican of Texas, said today that President Ford could beat Ronald Reagan in a 1976 race in Texas for the Republican nomination.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York legislators sponsoring a bill that could bring casino gambling to the state in 1978 will take the idea on the road next month at a series of public hearings. The odds are long on its success, according to politicians.

title: AntiFranco Spirit Persists in Europe As Envoys Return
description: LONDON, Oct. 13 (AP) Ambassadors called home to protest Spain's execution of five terrorists last month are returning to their Madrid posts. But public resentment against the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franto persisted today in Western Europe.

title: WASHINGTON POST TO SUE ON DAMAGE
description: WASHINGON, Oct. 13 (UPI) The Washington Post will file a civil suit against those believed responsible for damaging its presses during a walkout by pressmen and will refuse to allow anyone found responsible back in the plant, a Post spokesman said today.

title: FASHION TALK
description: The padded jacket with its oriental overtones is not about to pass into limbo in the Western world after its sojourn in the fashion sun this fall.

description: World Series, third game, Reds vs. Boston Red Sox, at Cincinnati. (TelevisionChannel 4, 8:30 P.M.) (RadioWNWSFM, 8:15 P.M.)

title: Gulf Resources Proposes To Purchase Southdown
description: The Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation of Houston, a diversified company in coal mining, oil, gas, lead, zinc and silver mining and fertilizer production, has proposed to take over South. down, Inc., also in oil and gas operations and in production of cement, malt, soft drinks and candy. Gulf Resources contemplates issuance of 0.65 share of its common stock for each share of Southdown common and one share of a new series of cumulative convertible Gulf Resources preferred for each share of Southdown's 1.144,800 shares of $1.80 cumulative convertible preferred stock. If the merger is completed, Gulf Resources would issue 2,209,540 additional shares of common stock and 1.143,509 shares of new Gulf preferred with a total value of about $47.5mililon.

title: Carolina Water Ruled Safe After 7 in Town Became III
description: LANGLEY, S. C.. Oct. 13 (UPI)  State Health officials declared this town's water fit to drink this afternoon, 36 hours after chemicals contaminated the town's water supply and caused at least seven persons to become ill.

title: Booking of NaziEra Films Stirs Dispute in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 13A proposal to show two controversial Naziera films in Atlanta has divided this city's art community, probably the South's most active, and stirred hot debate about the fine line between art and propaganda. censorship and good taste and government support of and interference in the art.

title: College Conference Standings
description: METROPOLITAN

description: The New York Times/Frank C. Dougherty

title: School Board to Get BudgetCutting Proposals
description: Deputy Chancellor Bernard k. Gifford said yesterday he would submit budgetcutting proposals to the Board of Education tomorrow, and he acknowledged that some would violate contractual rights won by the United Federation of Teachers over the years.

title: KISSINGER BACKED IN HOUSE DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13More than 200 middlerank Foreign Service officers have signed a letter supporting Secretary of State Kissinger in his refusal to allow the House Select Intelligence Committee to interrogate the officers on internal policy disputes.

title: William H. Kane, 71, Dies; ExPolice Reporter Here
description: William H. Kane, a New York police reporter for The Associated Press until his retirement in 1968, died here yesterday in the Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Phoenix, Ari7

title: Explosions in South Dakota Damage Inman Agencies
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D. Oct. 13, (UPI)  A series of four explosions wracked this southwestern South Dakoia reservation community early today. damaging four Bureau of Indian Affairs and Oglala Sioux tribal build was.

title: Bolivia Pushin4 Into a Last Frontier
description: TRINIDAD, Volivia, Oct. 7 Workers carried big slabs of beef from the crude refrigerated warehouse to the airplane 20 yards away. The 100degree heat melted the thin layer of frost on the meat and blood drenched the workers rough cotton shirts. A cloud of red dust swirled up as the propellers roared and the plane hurtled down the only asphalted strip in the region.

title: BEAR SUGGESTS DEFICIT IN BUDGET IS OVERESTIMATED
description: Mayor Beame's budget aides, in a sudden and surprising move, asserted last night that the city's deficitcutting burden for the next two fiscal years might have been overestimated by $100million to $200million.

title: Leo Kottke Dazzles With Rock and Folk On 12String Guitar
description: Leo Kottke is a guitar player toiling in the folk and rock fields and possessed of a fine technique, particularly considering that he specializes in the 12string guitar, which is somewhat more difficult to maneuver. Mr. Kottke appeared at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday his second New York appearance in six months and his first as a headliner. The hall was packed with definite Kottke cultists, hanging on to the cornucopia of notes the guitarist was able to rip out of his instruments.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Bird Season
description: Waterfowl hunting seasons have already begun in certain Eastern states, although any mention of them must be made against the backdrop of lezal action now under way.

title: French Troops Leave Chad
description: NDJAMENA, Chad, Oct. 13 (Agence FrancePresse)  The first French force left here today for France as the withdrawal of over 2,000 French troops from Chad began. Chad. once part of French Equatorial Africa, demanded all French forces withdrawn after France went against Chadian wishes and negotiated directly with rebels for the release of a French hostage, Francoisc Claustre.

title: Girl Electrocuted in Tree
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 (AP) A 7yearold girl from suburban Radnor Township was found electrocuted, apparently by overhead wires, and lodged in the limbs of a tall tree near her home today after an intensive search for her, the police said. Elizabeth Russell, missing since yesterday afternoon, was dead or arrival at Bryn Mawr Hospital, the police said.

title: SUIT SEEKING END TO HUDSON TOLLS
description: FORT LEE, Oct, 13An Englewood Councilman, Jerry J. Hersch, is seeking court action to abolish tolls on the George Washington Bridge and other Hudson River crossings operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: British Energy Officials Split on North Sea Policy
description: LONDON, Oct. 13A split has developed among Britain's top energy offiicals over policy governing North Sea oil.

title: Wallace, Starting European Tour, Meets With Wilson.
description: LONDON, Oct. 13  The American diplomatic community and the people who run the British Government do not know how to assess the Presidential prospects of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama. But they were taking no chances today.

title: British Soccer
description: Second Division

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Political and Security Committee10:30 M. and 3 P.M.

title: 4 Hospitals in Montreal Win Court Order in Strike
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 13 (UPI)Major Montreal hospitals took court action today to halt a fourday strike by nurses that has reduced operations to a minimum.

title: Korea Talks Will Resume
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 13 (AP)The South Korean Government agreed today to a meeting with North Korean representatives Oct. 23 to seek resumption of Red Cross talks to reunite separated families. South Korea also proposed that political talks between the two governments be resumed. North Korea has boycotted the talks, since 1973 because of the South Korea's stringent antiCommunist policies.

title: A Liquor War in New England
description: HOOKSETT, N. H., Oct. 13At 3:30 on this holiday afternoon, there were 37 cars in the parking lot of the new staterun liquor store here. Three were from New Hampshire and 34 from Massachusetts.

title: W.F.L. Is Considering Possibility of Disbanding
description: The World Football League, shaken by a series of discouraging developments, met in an emergency session here yesterday to decide if it should disband.

title: LEVEL OF CONCORDE HIGH IN NOISE TEST
description: LONDON, Oct. 13 (Reuters)Concorde, the supersonic jetliner being built by Britain and France, exceeded noise limits at London's Heathrow airport on three out of four takeoffs during its recent endurance flying program, according to figures published today by Trade Secretary Peter Shore.

title: BANK IN SOMERSET ACCUSED ON GIFT
description: SOMERVILLE, Oct. 13 Somerset County Democrats charged here today that a local bank had given a $500 political contribution to a Republican fundraising event in apparent violation of the state's 1972 campaignfinancing law.

title: VIayor Rizzo Undergoes Surgery on Leg After an Accident at Refinery Blaze
description: PHILADELPRIA, Oct. 13Mayor Frank L. Rizzo underwent surgery today.to repair a leg fracture that he suffered last night at the scene of this Icity's second major oilrefinery fire in two months.

title: The Control Board And Howit Works
description: Six times now, the Emergency Financial Control Board has convened around a long walnut table in a windowless back room in Governor Carey's midManhattan office.

title: Meyner Warns Against Apathy And Urges a Big Vote on Nov.4
description: NEW BRUNSWICK. Oct. 13 (AP)Former Gov. Robert B. Meyner, chairman of the state's Bicentennial Commission, warned today against voter apathy and called for a significant turnout on Election Day. Nov. 4.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: United Press International

title: Berlin: Exhibition on the City's Turks
description: BERLINA graphic exhibition of the concealed miseries of Turkish life herethe run  down apartment buildings with high rents for the Turkish guest workers. the ghetto that has grown up around the tens of thousands of Turks who live in West Berlin the loneliness of men separated from their wives and childrenis a centerpiece of Berlin's 25th Festival of the Arts this fall. It is drawing visitors by the thousands.

title: Uniformed Services Studied for Savings
description: Some day soon police officers may be patrolling New York's streets in oneman cruisers instead of twoman cars and working 10hour shifts four days a week instead of their current 40 hours spread over five days.

title: Rumors of InterestRate Lowering is a Spur
description: The stock market, after opening yesterday in a holiday mood with light trading activity and no remarkable trend in prices, came to life in midafternoon and made an impressive advance. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 13.86 points to close at 837.77.

title: Music: Pleasant Lucia
description: The New York City Opera's repertory system stood revealed with all its faults and some of its occasional virtues Sunday night for the company's first performance of the season of Lucia di Lammermoor.

title: Suez Reopening May Force a Rise in Panama Tolls
description: PANAMA  Already squeezed by the slump in world trade, the Panama Canal may soon he forced to charge higher tolls in order to compensate for the new loss of traffic to the Suez Canal, which reopened four months ago after an eightyear closure.

title: Rhodesian Leader Denies He Assailed Vorster Diplomacy
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 13 (Reuters)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia today denied making any criticism actual or implied of Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa for the failure of settlement efforts in Rhodesia.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The bodies of two men were found washed up on a beach about three miles from where their cabin cruiser was spotted wrecked Sunday evening on Long Island Sound, a Coast Guard spokesman reported.

title: Housing Quality
description: Although setting standards for better housing may seem an exercise in futility when the problem right now is building any kind of housing at all, that is too pat a view of the problem. The proposal that has just come out of the City Planning Commission, called Zoning for Housing Quality, was begun in the days of housing activity and will be valid when that activity resumes.

title: U.N. Again Delays Any Action Linking Zionism With Racism
description: UNITED NATIONS,. N. Y., Oct. 13For the third time in 10 days, the General Assembly's Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee delayed today a vote on a proposed resolution that would condemn Zionism together with racial discrimination.

title: Births
description: Deaths

title: Wallace. Starting European Tour, Meets With Wilson
description: LONDON, Oct. 13  The American diplomatic community and the people who run the British Government do not know how to assess the Presidential prospects of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama. But they were taking no chances today.

title: Federal Police Cost Put at $2.6Billion
description: WASHLNGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) The first inventory of Federal police activities showed today that the Government spent $2.6billion last year to employ 169,625 persons for police, investi gative and intelligencegathering activities in 33 agencies.

title: MUSICIANS REJECT PITTSBURGH OFFER
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 Members of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, who have been on strike since Sept 29, rejected today by a vote of 85 to 13 a new offer submitted by management over the weekend.

title: Retail Sales Advance Slows
description: New York City's largest stores, whose August sales gain of 4.6 per cost was the best of the year so far, slipped bit in September with sales that averaged 3.9 per cent over the same month last year.

title: Soviet Press Agency Attacks Nobel Prize for Sakharor
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 13 (AP)The Soviet press agency Tass today resumed its criticism of the Nobel Peace Priie award to Andrei D. Sakharov; reproducting unfavorable foreign press commentary.

title: O. J. and the Bills On Stage for Giants
description: Next for the Giants is nationwide exposure of the team's natty new uniform over television on Monday night in Buffalo against the Bills, who are undefeated and to whom touchdowns are like grapes. They come in bunches.

title: AllGirl Rodeos: Riding For Love, Not Money
description: SPRING CREEK, Nev.It was 4 A.M. The rest of the family was asleep, but Rebecca and Jeanie Fuchs, in Berthoud, Colo., loaded their horses in the trailer and took off.

title: CORRECTION
description: The program for a concert by the Murray Louis Dance Company on Friday, Oct. 17, at the Bronx Community College's Gould Memorial Library was incorrectly reported in The New York Times Arts and Leisure Guide on Sunday. The company will perform Geometries, Chimera and Catalog.

title: TWO PARTIES LINKED TO JAI ALAI INQUIRY
description: Democrats and Republicans are being investigated in connection with the issuance of permits needed to open a jai alai installation in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Violence It's Not So Simple
description: LONDON, Oct. 13It is startling to find that even in the civilized city of London, hotels are posting people in the lobbies to check the handbags and packages of those who come in. But the bomb threat here, stemming from the unending violence in Northern Ireland, is real and the checking is prudent.

title: Books of The Times
description: On sleepless nights, Tim Neumiller tries to piece it back together. Every night when I'm not able to sleep, when scrolls of words and formulas unfurl in my mind and faces of those I love, both living and dead, rise from the dark, accusing me of apathy. ambition, selfindulgence, neglectall their accusations justand there's no hope of rest Tun Neumiller tries to remember. And what he remembersor rather what he reconstructs through the various narrative voices that inhabit Larry Woiwode's second novel, Beyond the Bedroom Wallis nothing less than the history of four generations of a Midwestern Catholic family named Neumiller from Otto Neumillers emigration from to North Dakota in 1881 down to a present time when Otto's greatgrandchildren, Tim's generation, are grown and starting to raise children of their own.

title: New Jersey's BondIssue Debate
description: TRENTON, Oct. 13 The prospects that New Jersey voters will approve the Byrne administration's proposal for a $922million bond issue were reported today to be worsening with every new warning that New New York City faces Analysis imminent default on its shortterm bond obligations.

title: Patient Hangs Himself In Hospital Shower Stall
description: A Jamaica, Queens, man a patient in the psychiatric ward of Bronx State Hospital, died yesterday afternoon after hanging himself in a restroom shower stall.

title: TRUDEAUPROPOSES TO CURB INCREASES IN PRICES AND PAY
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 13 Premier Pierre Elliott Trudeau announced tonight that he would ask Parliament tomorrow for the authority to impose restraints on prices and on the incomes of most workers.

title: A Fine Corinth Opens Met Season
description: For a company that had spent the last couple of months teetering on the brink of default, so to speak, the Metropolitan Opera looked and sounded thoroughly healthy last night when it opened its season with Rossini's The Siege of Corinth. With Beverly Sills in splendid voice and Shirley Verrett standing up to her idolized colleague and then some, the performance took shape as one of the most successful first nights at the Met in many a season.

title: Layoffs Announced By the Xerox Corp. Of 580 Workers
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday it had laid off an additional 580 workers at its computer operations at El Segundo, Calif.

title: Yonkers Miss America Has Her Homecoming
description: Not enough women from Texas and Oklahoma are entered in televised beauty contests to suit Anthony Savarese, a retired Yonkers electrician.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS HAS NEW COMPUTERS
description: Texas Instruments, Inc., announced yesterday a new family of micro and minicomputers ranging from a fingernailsize microprocessor chip to a fullsize minicomputer all using the same software language.

title: Dr. Rafael Guas Inclan Dies; A Former Leader in Cuba
description: MIAMI, Oct. 13 (AP)Dr. Rafael Guas Iriclan, former Vice President of Cuba, died yesterday. He was in his mid70's.

title: LISBON'S PREMIER BUS AUSTERITY
description: LISBON, Oct. 13  Premier Jose Pinheiro de Azevedo told the Portuguese people tonight that the nation's economic plight made austerity inevitable.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Banks in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were closed yesterday in observance of Columbus Day. Commodities exchanges, except for the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago and New York Mercantile Exchanges, were also closed. In Canada all banks and securities and commodities markets were closed for that country's Thanksgiving Day holiday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A report compiled by the state's Medicaid program said yesterday that New Jersey patients were making wide use of Medicaid funds for sterilizations. The report said that 3,237 New Jersey women underwent tubal ligation's and 221 others underwent other sterilization procedures in Medicaledfinanced operations during the first six months 1975. Among them were 22 girls 17 years old and younger. Thirtythree vasectomies were also performed during the period, according to the report, which is to be submitted to the Federal Government. One vasectomy was performed on a juvenile. In addition, 989 Medicaid patients underwent hysterectomies during the time.

title: Sony to Issue New Share
description: The Sony Corporation announced yesterday that it will issue one new share for each four shares held. The shares will be distributed in January to shareholders of record Oct. 31.

title: JAMES PICKERING, 69, OIL EXECUTIVE, DEAD
description: James V. Pickering, who retired in 1967 as chairman of Esso Eastern, Inc., a regional affiliate of the Exxon Corporation, died yesterday at his home, 975 North Street, Greenwich, Conn. He was 69 years old.

title: American Can Quarter Net Off 19.5%
description: The American Can Company, the giant metal container producer, reported yesterday profit decreases of 19.5 per cent for the third quarter and 24.2 per cent for the first nine months.

title: Vilas, Borg Score In Spanish Tennis
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 13 (AP)Argentina's Guillermo Vilas and Sweden's Bjorn Borg scored openinground victories in the $75,000 Spanish open tennis tournament today. Eddie Diblys of the United States also won.

title: NATO Arms
description: Defense Secretary Schlesinger's lowkey visit to the three chief NATO allies in EuropeBritain, France and West Germanyhas focused attention on critical problems sapping the morale of America's most vital alliance.

title: Venezuela Considers Borrowing To Finance Inland Development
description: LONDON, Oct. 13 (Reuters)Venezuela may borrow abroad to help finance her internal development over the next few years, Foreign Minister Ramon Escovar Salom said today.

title: Advertising
description: The bad news is that among member agencies of the American Association of Advertising Agencies bad debts last year were at the highest point since 1934 and late receivables have almost doubled in five years.

title: CORRECTION
description: The program for a concert by the Murray Louis Dance Company on Friday, Oct. 17, at the Bronx Community College's Gould Memorial Libtary was incorrectly reported in The New York Times Arts and Leisure Guide on Sunday. The company will perform Geometrics, Chimera and Catalog.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Prime Minipter Pierre Elliott Trudeau announced that he would ask the Canadian Parliament today for authority to impose restraints on rises in prices and wages. The program, he said in a national broadcast, aims to cope with a More than 11 per cent rate of inflation and a jobless rate of more than 7 per cent. [Page 1, Column 1.1

title: UGANDA NEWSPAPER ASSAILS MOYNIHAN
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 13 (AP)  Uganda's Governmentrun newspaper has accused Daniel P. Moynihan, the United States delegate to the United Nations of diplomatic insanity.

title: Primary Aluminum Shows Total Inventory Advance
description: LONDON, Oct. 13 (AP)Total primary aluminum inventory, as reported by members of the International Primary Aluminum Institute and corresponding companies was 3.39 million metric tons at the end of August, up from 3.34 million tons at endJuly and 1.47 million tons at endAugust 1974, the institute reported today.

title: Broadway Comes to Life With Opening of Musicals
description: With the end of the 25day strike of musicians, Broadway musicals were back in business and long lines formed at the box offices of the hit shows A Chorus Line: Chicago and The Wiz.

title: Who Gets Custody of Children? Fathers Now Are Being Heeded
description: It was, as Dr. Lee Salk sees it, another case of a marriage gone sour, of father fighting for custody of his children.

title: Sammartino, Kiloff Draw
description: Bruno Sammartino, the Worldwide Wrestling Federation champion, and Ivan Kiloff battled to a draw last night in Madison Square Garden before 25,202 fans, including 3,112 who watched on closed circuit in the Garden's Felt Forum.

title: Did Rockefeller Give Ford a Way Out?
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13Vice President Rockefeller's call for Congressional action to assist New York City, apparently totally at odds with President Ford's repeated opposition to Federal intervention, has led to confusion both in and out of the White House, and speculation over the possibility of a change in Administration policy. It's inexplicable. said one of the President's key economic advisers.

title: Karen Quinlan's Life Before the Coma
description: The night Karen Anne Quinlan was overcome by an apparent combination of alcohol and tranquilizer pills, one of her friends gave her mouth  to  mouth resuscitation to keep her alive until professional medical help could be summoned.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ROLL EM Four new projects uptown, downtown and in Greenwich Village attest to the everincreasing interest in films as entertainment, art and the reflection of an era.

title: Panel Studies F. B. I. Links To Oswald and Ruby in'63
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13A House of Representatives subcommittee has opened an investigation into the Federal Bureau of Investigation's relation. ship with Lee Harvey Oswald n d Jack Ruby before President Kennedy's assassination, the subcommittee's chairman said today.

title: DOLLAR AND GOLD DECLINE IN EUROPE
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 13 (UPI)The dollar fell on European money markets today, pulled down by prospects of lower United States interest rates and fear over New York City's financial crisis. The price of gold also fell.

title: U.S. Gets 3 Medals In Shoot
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 13 (UPI)The shooting team saved the day for the United States today after the track stars suffered a series of reverses on an opening day of competition at the PanAmerican Games in which the hostility between the Cuban and American athletes was plainly evident.

title: Radio
description: 67:25 A.M., WNYCFM. Morning from Peer Gynt Suite No. 1, Grieg; Brandenburg Concerto No. 5, Bach; Rossiniana, Respighi.

title: In Arkansas, Wolf and Pursuing Hounds Match Wits
description: PARKS, Ark., Oct. 5The gathering was relaxed for the first hour. Seven or eight men stood and talked in the circle of firelight, drinking coffee and warming themselves against the night.

title: Redskins Conquer Cards
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13After the Washington Redskins satisfying 2717 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight, the question for Billy Kilmer, the winning quarterback, was, What took you so long, Bill?

title: Arafat to Visit Moscow
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 13, (Reuters)  Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, will visit Moscow this month, Palestinian sources said here today. They said that he would confer with Soviet leaders on the situation in the Middle East in light of the EgyptianIsraeli Sinai agreement.

title: World Airline Unit Delays Accord on Fuel Surcharge
description: GENEVA, Oct. 13 (Reuters)The International Air Transport Association has extended a deadline for agreement on a proposed 3 per cent fuel surcharge on passenger fares and cargo rates because the idea has been opposed by several airlines, association sources said today.

title: Music: Pleasant Lucia
description: The New York City Opera' s repertory system stood revealed with all its faults and some of its occasional virtues Sunday night for the company's first performance of the season of Lucia di Lammermoor.

title: Eyeglass Prices Linked To Optometrists Groups
description: A study by a professor of economics at Washington University in Missouri has found that in states where optometrists are highly organized in professional associations the prices of eyeglasses are significantly higher thad in states where there is less organization.

title: Broadway Comes to Life With Opening of Musicals
description: With the end of the 25day strike of musicians, Broadway musicals were back in business and long lines formed at the box offices of the hit shows A Chorus Line, Chicago and The Wiz.

title: MERGER WEIGHED BY SMITH, BARNEY
description: Smith, Barney & Co., Inc., and Harris, Upham & Co., Inc., two oldline brokerage houses, announced yesterday that they were considering merging.

title: Rosewall, Mayer And Lutz Victors
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 13 (AP)Sandy Mayer, Bob Lutz and 40yearold Ken Rosewall won secondround matches tonight in the $100,000 Australian indoor tennis championships.

title: U.S. TRIES TO FIND OIL OVERCHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13Two years after adoption of the present system of controlling petroleum prices, Federal agents are beginning this month to check on the 30 largest oil companies to see if they have been overcharging for crude oil.

title: Production of Steel Shows Gain of 2.5% For the Latest Week
description: Steel production for the week ended Oct. 11 rebounded from two consecutive weeks of declines, according to figures released yesterday of the Amerran Iron and Steel Institute.

title: For Columbus Day, It Was Best Fobt Forward
description: It was a good day to be Italian, or to pretend you were Italian. It was also a good day to be a young person, a politician, a street vender or merely someone who had wandered out of doors.

title: Meddlers in God's Work
description: The Washington discussion of New York's financial trouble is taking a curious turn toward theology. This has been apparent lately in various suggestions from Washington that New York must undergo purification by suffering if it is to receive Federal absolution.

title: SINAI RESOLUTION IS SIGNED BY FORD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) President Ford signed a Congressional resolution today authorizing American civilians to operate early warning stations in Sinai.

title: DR. E. PARKER HAYDEN
description: BOSTON, Oct. 13 (AP)Dr. E. Parker Hayden, a surgeon at Massachusetts General Hospital for 50 years died there yesterday. He was 81 years old and had lived in Providence since his retirement two years ago.

title: Portugal's Most Militant Leftist Party, Led by a Woman, Seeks Victory With Violence
description: LISBON, Oct. 13Isabel do Carmo is 35 years old, with long, dark hair worn loose and a strong nose and facial bones softened by a dimple but no makeup. She is the leader of the most militant and most avowedly violent of the extreme leftists who, Premier Jose Pinheiro de Azevedo says, threaten his control of Lisbon.

title: LEVI PANEL WEIGHS CORPORATE CRIME
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13Attorney General Edward H. Levi has disclosed that earlier this year he appointed a committee within the Justice Department to develop means of coordinating law  enforcement efforts against whitecollar crime.

title: Walton: 2 Mishaps, 2 More Hospitals
description: Bill Walton left one hospital Sunday night and about one hour later he was in another hospital as mishaps continued to plague the highpriced, 6foot11inch Portland Trail Blazer center. Walton, playing in his first preseason game since recovering from a broken toe, was accidentally jabbed in the eye by John Haylicek of the Boston Celtics. Walton left the game in the third quarter after he had scored 10 points, grabbed six rebounds and was credited with two assists in 19 minutes of playing time.

title: Lloyd H. Fales Dead at 75; Got a Pilot's License at 16
description: MIAMI, Oct. 13 (UPI) Lloyd H. Fates, who was believed to have been the country's youngest licensed pilot upon graduation from the Glenn Curtis Flying School in 1916, died here during the weekend. He was 75 years old.

title: Chess:
description: Does Anatoly Karpov, the new world champion, have the Indian sign on Boris Spasskv?

title: Cyanamid Set to Expand
description: WAYNE, N. J., Oct 13 (UPI)  The American Cyanamid Comoar said today it would snend 5pillion to expand its pi:nt at Longview, Wash. The plant makes aconstrenath resin used in the production of unbleached kraft linerboard for hipping cartons.

title: Buckley Asks Change In Bankruptcy Laws
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 13 (AP) Senator James L. Buckley, repeating his opposition to Federal aid for New York City, said today that a revision of the Federal bankruptcy laws might see the city throueh its fiscal crisis.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEK CALM 1976 PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13Democratic party officials, who had their fill of convention turbulence in 1968 and 1972, moved in harmony today to make their 1976 convention in New York a model of decorum.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Is President Ford really as honest as the press has pictured him? There seems to be more sincerity behind his pieties and platitudes than there ever was behind his predecessor's, but the comparison can hardly be called favorable. Integration has been more successful in Boston than in South Africa too. Where Ford is sincere we often need to be less praising of his candor and more critical of his views, but his reputed honesty is one of the great myths of contemporary politics.

title: Carolina Water Ruled Safe After 7 in Town Became Ill
description: LANGLEY, S. C., Oct. 13 (UPI)  State Health officials declared this town's water fit to drink this afternoon, 36 hours after chemicals contaminated the town's water supply and caused at least seven persons to become ill.

title: Estialate Board Rescues State Agency
description: The Board of Estimate, by a bare 12to10 majority, yesterday authorized the city to pass along the S20million in state funds needed to keep the State Housing Finance Agency from default tomorrow.

title: Shots Fired at Busing Rally
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 13 (AP)Several shots were fired toward police officers tonight when antibusing, protesters gathered near a high school, the Jefferson County polirp said. But the shots ware wild. according to Bob Yates, a snokesman for the county nolire department, and neither officers nor cars were hit.

title: Atoms, Budgets
description: Another fundamental NATO problem is West Europe's concern over American proposals to modernize and reduce the stockpile of American tactical nuclear weapons in Europe, preferably in exchange for an agreement in Vienna negotiations with theWarsaw Pact countries for withdrawal of a Soviet tank army and its armor.

title: Bolivia Pushing Into a Last Frontier
description: TRINIDAD, Bolivia. Oct. 7 Workers carried big slabs of beef from the crude refrigerated warehouse to the airplane 20 yards away. The 100degree heat melted the thin layer of frost on the meat and blood drenched the workers rough cotton shirts. A cloud of red dust swirled up as the propellers roared and the plane hurtled down the only asphalted strip in the region.

title: Ships Avoiding Two Ports Hit by Strike of Tugboats
description: Striking tugboat operators in Hampton Roads in Virginia and Baltimore forced some ships to head for other ports yesterday, United Press International reported. Negotiations to end the strike that began Friday night are scheduled to resume today.

title: Soyuz and Apollo Crews Urge New Joint Missions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13American and Soviet astroil nauts spoke hopefully today of future joint missions, including a possible manned flight, to Mars, during a news conference.

title: HEARINGS ARE SET ON LEGAL CASINOS
description: State legislators sponsoring a bill that would bring casino gambling to New York in 1978 will take the idea on the road next month at a series of public hearings.

title: Negotiators Active, but Strikes Continue in 3 School District
description: The Howell Township Education Association said that negotiations were at a critical point as talks continued last night with the Howell Township Board of Education.

title: Brokers Earn Foreign Fees
description: The New York Stock Exchange estimated on the basis of sample data that member brokers earned $46million in commissions from foreign customers in the sedond quarter of this year, up from $39million in the first quarter. Europeans, as usual, provided the bulk.

title: Production of Plastic Resin Is Seen Dropping This Year
description: For the first time since the end of World War II, the production of plastic resin, the main ingredient in plastic products, is expected to decline in 1975, the Society of the Plastics Industry says.

title: Dr. Michael Dacso, 66, Dead; Was Expert on Rehabilitation
description: Dr. Michael M. Dacso, an early leader in the field of rehabilitation medicine, and his wife, Dr. Magda Rona Dacso, a highly regarded pathologist here, died Saturday in an automobile collision in East Hampton, L.I. He was 66 years old. The police said there were no fatalities in the other car.

title: Peking Group Arrives In Manila to Open Ties
description: MANILA, Oct. 13A 14member delegation from China arrived today to open an embassy here.

title: Statewide Standards Stir Education Board Dispute
description: TRENTON, Oct. 13 The State Board of Education, concerned that New Jersey's children are failing to learn to read and write properly, is in dispute over whether to mandate statewide academic achievement standards for the public schools.

title: Grant Credit Cards End; To Use 2 Bank Systems
description: The W.T. Grant Company, now in bankruptcy proceedings following aggressive expansion into credit and new stores, announced yesterday that it had discontinued its Grantcard credit plan and would rely only on bank cards.

title: LEBANON TO JOIN IN ARAB MEETING
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 13As relative calm continued in Beirut, the Government announced tonight that Foreign Minister Philip Takla would head a delegation to a meeting of Arab foreign ministers that is expected to gather in Cairo this week to consider the Lebanese crisis.

title: Standoff in Turkey
description: Turkey's partial parliamentary elections have ended in a standoff between the major parties, making it virtually certain that Premier Suleyman Demirel will struggle on at the head of a shaky coalition. The question is whether this resultkeeping essentially unchanged the balance between Mr. Demirel's Justice party and Bulent Ecevit's Republican People's partywill make it easier for the Premier to negotiate realistically on Cyprus and lift his threat to shut down American military bases in Turkey.

title: Sarah OsnathHalevy. 62. Singer. Dancer and Mime
description: Sarah OsnalhHalevy, an actress, singer, dancer and mime. who gave onewoman shows here and abroad featuring songs and dances of the Near East, died Sunday of cancerin Roosevelt Hospital. She was 62 years old and lived here.

title: F.B.I. Joins Search For 2 Who Robbed Bank in California
description: EUREKA, Calif., Oct. 13 (UPI) Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation joined the police today in a search for bank robbers who got away with $47,000 by strapping a bomb pack to the back of a bank president and threatening to hlow him uo by remote control.

title: Forego to Go In Laurel Turf Race
description: Lazy F Ranch's Forego, the 1974 Horse of the year who is likely to retain his title, will start in the $150,000 Washington D.C. International at Laurel on Nov. 8, provided the grass at the Maryland track that afternoon is not deep and holding. The decision to name the game 5yearold gelding for the prestigious 1%mile contest was announced shortly after he completed a sparkling workout on Belmont Park's main track. He was clocked in 23 seconds for the quarter, 0:45 3/5 for the half and 0:58 for five furlongs handily.

title: People and Business
description: George A. Stinson, president of the National Steel Corporation, warned yesterday that world steel usage is increasing at a rate that makes expansion of capacity imperative.

title: Kellogg Strike Averted
description: BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Oct. 11 (UPI)Negotiators for the Kellog Company and the American Federation of Grain Millers union said today that they had reached a tentative agreement and averted a scheduled national strike against the giant cerral company. Details of the proposed contract were not disclosed.

Ever since his extradition from Australia, where he had turned up a month later, the 50  year  old legislator, once a rising star in a former Labor administration, had been pleading to address his fellow M.P.'s.

title: Leaving, Hirohito Calls U.S. Visit Unforgettable
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 13(Reuters)Emperor Hirohito of Japan left for home today at the end of what he said was an unforgettable twoweek state visit to the United States.

description: BAHREIN, Oct. 13A bid to make Bahrein a dominant banking factor in the Arab world appears to be behind a decision, taken recently by the Bahrein Monetary Agency, to grant limited banking licenses to banks that wish to establish offices here for largescale regional loan and deposit business.

description: Some day soon police officers may be patrolling New York's streets in oneman cruisers instead of twoman cars and working 10hour shifts four days a week instead of their current 40 hours spread over five days.

description: NEWPORT, R. I., Oct. 13 (AP) Beneath the flapping sails of a copy of a British warship, the United States Navy celebrated its 200th anniversary today in this seaport city, which claims to be the Navy's birthplace.

description: CARBONDALE, Colo., Oct. 10The chill morning air was filled with sights and sounds so dear to the hearts of horsemen from Massachusetts to Middlesex.

title: WHEAT FUTURES PLUNGE IN PRICE
description: Excellent harvest weather and disappointment of farmers over continuation of the moratorium of grain sales to the Soviet Union combined to result in sharply lower prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. description: LISBON, Oct. 13  Premier Jose Pinheiro de Azevedo told the Portuguese people tonight that the nation's economic plight made austerity inevitable.

description: JERUSALEM Oct. 13 (AP)A foreigifregistered freighter I will learean Israeli port next week in the first attempt to carry Israeli cargo down the Suez Canal since 1956, Government officials said today.

title: ELECTRIC1TYRATES WILL CLIMB AGAIN.
description: Electric utility bills will have to go up again to compensate for the 10 per cent increase in the price of oil announced recently by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, according to officials of the nation's utilities that burn imported residual fuel oil to produce electricity.
