description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 15Somewhat to the surprise of many members of the American press, there is a growing split in their ranks over how to handle confrontations between the press and the courts.

title: PENTAGON REPORT CITES NORTHROP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) The Northrop Corporation spent $9.9million on questionable costs including a yacht and a hunting lodge to lift sales to the United States and foreign governments between 1971 and 1974, according to a Pentagon report released today.

title: Schweiker Predicts Collapse Of Warren Report on Kennedy
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 15 (AP)  Senator Richard S. Schweiker predicted today that the Warren Commission report on President Kennedy's assassination was about to collapse and said his subcommittee on intelligence was looking into three conspiracy theories. Senator Schweiker, Republican of Pennsylvania, said at a news conference here that the subcommittee had developed very significant leads about the murder and wants to investigate the following possibilities.

description: ATLANTA  Chef Franz Victor Eichenauer does not fear the French. It is the Japanese.

description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Oct. 15 (Reuters)At least 10 people were killed and 50 injured today when policemen used tear gas to break up a big political rally here.

description: Members of The Daily News unit of the Newspaper Guild yesterday authorized officers of the union to call a strike against the paper when and if they see fit. A vote on whether to authorize a strike is scheduled today by guild members of The New York Times.

description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 15 (Reuters)An unnamed American collector paid $31,000 for a Canadian 12penny black stamp here tonight. The auction here for one of the world's rarest postage stamps was organized by Stanley Gibbons, the London stamp dealer.

description: The New York Telephone Company will provide World Series scores on Sports Phone. The number is 9991313.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Vice President Rockefeller met today with President Ford and described as minimal their differences over Federal aid to New York, saying that their relationship had never been better.

title: 1 Bureaucratic Princes Mingle With City Paupers
description: On a usual working day, William K. Keesee, a highranking executive in the Defense Department, rises at 6:30 A.M. in his brickandframe fourbedroom house in a suburb of Washington, has breakfast with his wife and three children, leaves at 7:30 in his dark blue Austin Marino and is at his desk in a Pentagon annex Iby 8:30, ready to confer with his staff of 33 about audits of millions of dollars worth of defense programs all over the world.

title: Survival After Babel: II
description: PHILADELPHIA  In Stanley Kubrick's film 2001, an unusually transparent and memorable scene depicts a corporateexecutiv type who (as I recall) approaches a mirrored communicator and utters his complex message, which is then instantaneously translated into Russian, presumably by a hidden computer, and transmitted miles away to an interlocutor.

description: BASKETBALL.

Sanlurcar Recital Canceled

description: Net income of the Eastman Kodak Company rose 14.3 per cent in the third quarter to $183.48  million, or $1.14 a share, from $160.55  million, equal to $1 a share, in the comparable period a year ago.

description: Financial planning at the Urban Development Corporation was so haphazard for much of its existence that the agency committed itself to spending huge sums of money that it did not know it could raise, and evert lent money at a lower rate of nterest than it had to pay to borrow the money, an independent accountant said yesterday.

description: Prices of wheat, corn and soybeans declined yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as traders awaited news on further Soviet grain deals.

description: BANGKOK, ThailandPutt Lawlek, 138 pounds. Thailand, outpointed Lockie Austin, 138, Australia, 10 rounds.

description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 15 (AP)C. Arnholt Smith, once the ruler of a huge corporate empire, is reported to have had to borrow money from relatives to pay the bulk of his $40,000 in Federal fines.

description: When your name is Don Shula and the team you coach is the Miami Dolphins, memories are mostly glittering ones.

description: Alexander's, Inc., one of New York's largest retail chains, reported yesterday that it has been apprised of an impending offer for the company's common stock from an unidentified source. Alexander's common stock was halted on the New York Stock Exchange pending news.

description: PARIS, Oct. 15A new work by Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, Lenin in Zurich, is to be issued here tomorrow, in Russian, by Y.M.C.A. Press.

It was neither the first nor last time an umpire erred. Hours later a man entering Toots Shor's was greeted with friendly insults by Beans Reardon, a reformed umpire doing penance as a beer salesman.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW DECLINES
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished lower yesterday as volume declined somewhat from the previous day. In the overthecounter market, prices closed mixed as volume also fell.

title: U.S. Picks Connors, Tanner

title: BYRNE CLEARS WAY TO PARDON CARTER
description: Governor Byrne agreed yesterday to waive a time eligibility requirement that could have prevented Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis from applying for pardons of their triplemurder convictions.

title: None of That Jazz
description: Now It's jazz that Is Imperiled on the air Several months ago classical music returned to radio station WNCNFM because aroused listeners and community organizations in metropolitan New York fought the good tight in defense of Beethoven and friends. As a direct result of their protests before the Federal Communications Commission, WNCNFM was acquired by new management that threw out the rock and restored the classical format.

description: HACKENSACK, Oct 15 (AP) A Superior Court judge here sentenced 26 teachers and a custodian to 10 days in jail for contempt today as teachers strikes continued in Elizabeth and Bergen County.

description: Family Portrait Sittings is an album of reminiscences that is as much about the processes of remembering as it is about the things remembered. The featurelength documentary, which opened a week's engagement at the Whitney Museum of American Art yesterday, is the work of Alfred Guzzetti, currently visiting associate professor of film at the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: Turtles, Rabbits For Young Actors
description: Turtle! Rabbit! the children call out even though on stage the characters are properly referred to as the Tortoise and Hare of the play's title.

title: Notes on People

The small country in southern Africa was formerly the British territory of Bechuanaland.

title: KISSINGER OFFERS DATA COMPROMISE
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 15Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the State Department would provide the House Intelligence Committee with a full summary of foreignpolicy deliberations but without attaching the names of individual junior or middlelevel officers of the department to any recommendation they may have made.

description: George C. Miles, an Islamic scholar and a former director of the American Numismatic Society, died yesterday of cancer at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center: He was 71 years old and lived in ArdsleyonHudson, N. Y.

description: WETHERSFIELD. Conn., Oct.15Yesterciay's disclosure that the late John M. Bailey had allegedly accepted a $200,000 cash payment to help a Bridgeport jai alai fronton obtain a state gaming license sent waves of disbelief through this estate's political community today.

description: The Federal Government's Office for Civil Rights has hegun an intensive onsite investigation of six city community school districts here to determine whether school children have been discriminated against because of race, national origin or physical handicaps.

title: Quebec Law Making French the OfficialLanguage Divides Province and Stirs Nation
description: QUEBECIn mid1974 the government of predominantly Frenchspeaking Quebec made French its official language, giving it precedence over English for virtually all governmental, commercial and legal purposes in this huge eastern province, Canada's largest.

title: Fed Cuts Reserves Required of Banks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The Federal Reserve Board announced today a redudtion in reserve requirements against longterm time and savings deposits at member banks.

description: The Treasury's auction of $3billion in twoyear notes today will bring investors an average yield of slightly below 8 per cent, Wall Street analysts predicted yesterday.

title: Ford Administration Said to Have Aided Losers in Congress
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 15 (UP1)The White House asked Federal agencies to help find jobs for defeated Congressmen and their staffs less than three months after President Ford had said he would keep politics out of the civil service, The St. Louis PostDispatch reported today.

title: RENEWED FIRING KILLS 12 IN BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 15New fighting between Christian and Moslem factions erupted early today in downtown Beirut and in outlying neighborhoods and sputtered throughlout the day.

title: 1,000 Badly Disturbed Students Losing Their Special Schooling
description: About 1,000 severely emotionallv disturbed children who entered special private schools Sept. 4 will be forced to leave them tomorrow, destined fore public  school programs that city education official admit will not be ready for up to six weeks.

title: Sousa's Last Child, 88, Dies
description: Helen Sousa Abert, last survivor of the three children of John Philip Sousa, the bandleader and composer who died in 1932, died Tuesday at the Fairfield Nursing Home in the Bronx. Her age was 88. She leaves a daughter, Jane Priscilla Abert of Munsonville, N.H.

title: CHRYSLER SHOWS LUXURY COMPACTS
description: DETROIT, Oct. 15  The Chrysler Corporation showed off its two new luxury compacts today, the Volare and Aspen, which the company, hopes will keep it strong in they compact market, a segment that has emerged as one of its strongest since the energy Crisis.

title: Moment of Truth
description: Mayor Beame's showdown meeting with the state's Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday represented a moment of truth for all New Yorkers as well as for the city administration. Whether the board accepts the Mayor's plan for spending reductions or decides to impose new economies of its own, it is beyond dispute that this onceprofligate city is entering a new era of rigidly enforced austerity from which there is no rational escape.

title: Sakharov Calls Criticism Poison Pen Campaign
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 15(UPI)Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist, said a broadside against him in the Soviet press today was a poison pen attack oni the committee that had awarded him the Nobel Peace Prize.

description: Christy, the new Bernie SpiroLawrence J. Blank musical based on John Millington Synge's The Playboy of the Western World, applauds itself as a darlin musical about a daring deed,, but there is nothing darlin about it.

title: The Stage: Papp Transplants Pinero's Trelawny
description: Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival at the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center has apparently turned over a new leaf. Or has it? Certainly, its Lincoln Center season is devoted perhaps too devotedto solid Establishment playwrights, but this does not matter. People rightly expect such fare at Lincoln Center, and justice must be clone the classical theater. Moreover, the functioning of the Vivian Beaumont operation must be seen in conjunction with Mr. Papp's other season of alternative theater at the Booth Theater, where he is to present five new American plays during the season. The two plans are intermeshed.

title: On Closing Hurley's Bar
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15A generation ago, as a producer of radio and television programs on NBC's New York stations, I worked at the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center. At the end of each celebritystricken day, would wind upand wind downhaving a drink at a little bar on the corner named Hurley's, and it was there that I became a Republican.

title: Money

title: Budget Cutters Study City Fringe Benefits
description: Nearly 60 per cent of the city's $12.3billion budget goes to pay for the 300,000 or so public employes who do everything from putting out fires to selecting the music on WNYC. This year's price tag for them will be $7.3billion because each worker costs the city a lot individually and because there are so many of them.

title: Revolution in Economics
description: Students entering business school these days, whether in New York City, London or Moscow, are well advised to have a good foundation in mathematics, including calculus and matrix algebra, to prepare them for the revolution in economics that has created the new field of scientific managerial decisionmaking.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor In an article published on your OpEd page on July 21 I pointed out that the Ford Administration's restrictive fiscal and monetary policies were continuing to retard recovery. I recalled that the Nixon Administration, after starving the economy in 1971, came on in 1972 with a whopping $28billion deficit and easy money, and that the boom helped to reelect Nixon but resulted in severe Inflation and recession.

title: Personal Finance: New Checking Accounts Revive Old Battle
description: Newspaper, television and radio advertisements by some savings banks in recent weeks have focused the attention of many New Yorkers on a relatively new type of checking account. They have also renewed the long running battle between savings institutions and commercial banks over these accounts.

title: Concorde Tickets on Sale
description: PARIS, Oct. 15 (Reuters)Ai France opened its sales counters today for seats on the first scheduled flights by the BritishFrench Concorde supersonic airliner and nearly 700 people booked passages, a spokesman said. The bookings weer for the ParisRio de Janeiro route. Provisional cost of a oneway ticket has been set at more than $1,200, about 20 Percent above today's first class fare in a subsonic airliner.

title: O'Dwyer Tells Congressmen That Civil War Looms
description: An ad hoc Congressional forum heard a warning yesterday that fullscale civil war would sweep Northern Ireland unless the United States stepped in to negotiate the errd of the bloodshed.

title: Profits Off 64.8% At Reynolds Metals
description: The Reynolds Metals Company reported yesterday that its thirdquarter net income had fallen by 64.8 per cent as sales dropped by 17.7 per cent.

title: Air Pollution Is Termd Chief Peril to Acropolis
description: ATHENS, Oct. 15 (AP) Pollution over 40 years has caused greater damage to the ancient monuments on the Acropolis than they suffered in the four centuries previous, a United Nations report said today.

title: Yonkers Raceway Results
4 IN GUILTY PLEAS ON FUNDS MISUSE
description: Four former employes of the Franklin National Bank pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to charges of having been involved in a $30million misapplication of the bank's funds for speculation in foreign currency. Four other men await trial.

title: Companies Report Sales and Profits
PACT WITH SOVIET ON MISSILE CURBS REPORTED IN PERIL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Several authoritative Administration officials say the talks with the Soviet Union on strategic arms limitations are in trouble.

title: Earl J. Silbert, Soon to Be Sworn In as U.S. Attorney, Reflects on His Days as Prosecutor in Watergate Case
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 15A milestone on the road away from the unnatural disaster known as Watergate will be passed quietly this month when Earl J. Silbert puts his hand on a Bible and solemnly swears, for the second time, to uphold the Constitution as United States Attorney for the District of Columbia.

title: 8 Indicted in Graft In Garment District
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted eight persons, including two reputed underworld figures, two union officials and two leaders of a trucking association, on charges of conspiracy and extortion in an alleged shakedown operation in the garment district.

title: President to Appear On Meet the Press
description: President Ford will answer questions from newsmen on a special onehour anniversary edition of Meet the Press. Sunday morning, Nov. 9, on NBCTV.

title: A Day in Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Students as a group are not given to enthusiasms these days. They are romantic about neither existing institutions not imagined substituteslaw students, one might think, least of all. So there was something surprising, and possibly significant, in the reaction of a group of law students who visited the Supreme Court the other day to hear a case argued.

title: ARS. FREDERICK BRADLEE
description: Josephine de Gersdorff Brad lee, mother of Benjamin C. Bradlee, executive editor of The Washington Post, died yesterday in a nursing home in Beverly, Mass. She was 79 years old.

title: JACQUES CHARON OF FRENCH STAGE
description: Jacques Charon, a leading member of the Comedie Frangaise and a director of the company, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home in Paris. He was 55 years old.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: LAMPPOST REUNION, a play by Louis La Russo Ii. Directed by Tom Signoreill, cast includes Gabriel Dell. At the Little Theater, 240 West 44th Street, at 7.

title: New and Newer Concerts Shift Lincoln Center Locale
description: New and Newer Music, a se??? that has been presented in Alice Tully Hall by Lincoln Center, will be moved this season to the small auditorium in she Lincoln Center Library. It will he presented on four Thursday evenings at 7:30 P.M.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The lawyer for Marvin Cristenfeld, the Democratic party's Commissioner of Elections for Nassau County, said in Federal Court iii Brooklyn that his client would refuse to answer any questions before a Federal grand jury other than those pertaining to his job.

title: Budget Cutters Study City Fringe Benefits,
description: Nearly 60 per cent of thel Icity's $12.3billion budget goes to pay for the 300,000 or so public employes who do everything from putting out fires to selecting the music on WNYC. This year's price tag for then will be $7.3billion because each worker costs the city a lot individually and because there are so many of them.

title: All Sides in Puerto Rico Afiree That U.S. Tie Is a Key Problem
description: LAKES, P. R.The one thing that seems clear about contemporary politics in the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico is that no one is fully satisfied with. the island's political relationship with the United States.

title: Elizabeth Moves to Halt SickOut by Its Firemen
description: ELIZABETH, Oct. 15The city of Elizabeth moved to enjoin its firemen from continuing an allegedly illegal sickout today, and then withdrew its suit when the Union County Superior Court Judge, Harold A. Ackerman, refused to grant an immediate injunction.

title: Lon Nol Disputes Report Mob Killed His Brother
description: HONOLULU, Oct. l5 (AP)Former President Lon Nol of Cambodia says he does not believe reports that his brother. Gen. Lon Non, was killed by an angry mob when Phnom Penh fell to the Communists last April.

title: GAP IN NIXON TAPE STILL A MYSTERY AS INQUIRY CLOSES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The special Watergate prosecutor reported today that his office had failed to establish responsibility for the gap in a tape recording of a conversation between President Nixon and H. R. Haldeman his chief of staff, shortly after the 1972 Watergate breakin.

title: Offer for Shares Rejected by Board Of Otis Elevator Co.
description: The board of the Otis Elevator Company has unanimously decided that the offer of $42 a share for 4.5million shares of Otis made by the United Technologies Corporation is totally inadequate and not in the best interests of the company or its shareholders, Ralph A. Weller chairman of Otis, said yesterday.

title: Met's 1Vew Boris Triumph for Hines
description: Jerome Hines, who made nis Metropolitan Opera debut in 1946 as the Police Sergeant in Boris Godunov, began his 30th season with the company Tuesday night in the same Mussorgsky opera. This time, of course, the imposingly tall bass was in the title role as Pushkin's tragic czar, one of his famous parts for many years, and the night turned into a crowning triumph for him.

title: 8 Indicted in Graft In Garment District
description: A Federal grand jury has indieted eight persons, including two reputed underworld figures, two union officials and two leaders of a trucking association, on charges of conspiracy and extortion in an alleged shakedown operation in the garment district.

title: A.B.A.Head Seeks Aid To Schools
description: The battle to restore funds slashed from the Public Schools Athletic League budget has begun to involve figures in professional sports. Dave DeBusschere, commissioner of the American Basketball Association, said yesterday he would appeal to players in his league for contributions to the Save Our Sports Committee, which is marshaling the fundraising effort.

title: Tareyton Switches Over to SSC&B
description: American Tobacco apparently would rather switch than fight and has switched its Tareyton cigarette brand out of Batten. Barton, Durstine & Osborn and into SSC&B.

title: Triple Jump Record Set at PanAm Games
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15 (UPl)Joao Oliveira of Brazil, benefitting from Mexico City's altitude and raritied air in much the same way Bob Beamon did seven years ago, triple jumped an unbelievable 58 feet 8% inches today to set the first world record at the PanAmerican Games.

title: Composite Box of 3 Series Games
description: Composite Box of 3 Series Games.

title: Spain Frees 16 Moroccans Seized in Western Sahara
description: MADRID. Oct. 15 (Reuters)Spain today released 16 Moroc. ran soldiers captured inside the Spanish Sahara last July 22, the press agency Cifra said.

title: Liberal Resistance to Busing
description: BAYVILLE, N. Y.  Most Northern liberals do not favor busing. Their resistance to busing is based on resistance to the culture of what Whitney Young called the black underclass, on resistance to largescale social engineering, and on the selection of children as the subjects of coercion. Integration is not resisted. The instrument of busing is resisted.

title: Inventories Grow Ford Is Optimistic
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15United States business added to inventories in August after six months of massive inventory liquidation, providing further strong evidence of recovery in the economy, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Church Groups Ask Congress for F.C.C. Hearings
description: Several national religious organizations acting as publicinterest advocates have called for Congressional he Arings on attempts by the Federal Communications Commission to reduce its regulation of radio and television, in line with President Ford's call for less Government interference in private business.

title: Cornerstone Will Be Set For Sports Center Today
description: Mayor Beame is scheduled to lay the cornerstone todayl for the New York Sports Center, described by its developer as the largest facility in the world for participant sports.

title: japan Shelves Dow Plan For Two Chemical Plants
description: TOKYO, Oct. 15 Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry has decided to put off action on an application from the Dow Chemical Company to produce chlorine and caustic soda here because of fierce opposition from domestic industry.

title: Pfizer and Merck Show Profit Rises
description: Two major drug companiesPfizer, Inc., and Merck & Co. yesterday reported gains in sales and earnings for both the third quarter and first nine months of 1975. Pfizer placed its thirdquarter net income at a new high of $43.2million, or 61 cents a share, up 22.4 per cent over the $35.3million, or 50 cents a share, of a year ago. Sales rose by 8.6 per cent to $421.4million from $388.2million in the 1974 period.

title: Dividends
Campaign Gifts Returned
description: OMAHA, Oct. 15 (AP)Sen??? Carl T. Curtis and Roman L. Hruska, both Republicans of Nebraska, have returned checks for $1,000 to the Phillip Petroleum Company which listed the two men last month among 65 members of Congress to whom it made illegal campaign contributions The Senators campaign committees were ordered last week to return the checks.

title: U. S. Seeks Rapid Aid to Zaire but Congress Is Wary
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15A behindthescenes effort by the State Department to shore up the Government of President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire with an emergency infusion of $60million has so far failed to win Congressional backing.

title: Ten Receive Fellowships To Study Business Writing
description: Ten journalists have been awarded fellowships in business and economic reporting at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism, the University announced yesterday.

title: Allez France Joins Cast
description: Laurel's $150,000 Washington D.C. International, already packed with talent, drew another standout yesterday when Allez France was entered in the Nov. 8 ??? race.

title: I.B.M. REDUCING PERCOPY CHARGES
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday that it was reducing its percopy charges by 10 per cent on its Copier II office copier machines. Minimum and maximum monthly charges will be unchanged.

title: DEPUTY SPEAKER SEIZED IN KENYA
description: NAIROBI. Kenya, Oct. 15 (AP)  Plainclothes policemen entered the Parliament building here today and took into custoday the Deputy Speaker and a rankandfile member who is one of President Jomo Kenyatta's most persistent critics.

title: KISSINGER IS QUOTED ON NIXON'S TRAITS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said privately this week that President Nixon barely governed during his last months in office, The Washington Post reported.

title: Market Place
description: When ShellerGlobe, an autoparts maker, reached $7 a share on the New York Stock Exchange recently, some shareholders with losses in the stock were happy to sell out.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, Oct. 15, 1975

title: U.S. Expects More lndochina Refugees
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15From 2,000 to 3.000 more Indochinese refugees are expected to arrive in the United States in the next two weeks. bringing the total destined for resettlement here to about 134,000 by Christmas, Administration officials said today.

title: SYRIA, LIBYA, P.L.O. SHUN CAIRO TALKS
description: CAIRO, Oct. 15Syria, Libya and the Palestine Liberation Organization today boycotted the opening of a conference of Arab foreign ministers seeking to settle the communal strife in Lebanon.

title: Colby Concedes C.I.A. Failed To Report Watergate Promptly
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 15 (AP)William E. Colby, the Director of Central Intelligence, said today that the C.I.A. could have gone to prosecutors with information about Watergate earlier than it did, but we didn't fall all over ourselves rushing to the policemen.

title: HONEYWELL, XEROX REACH AGREEMENT
description: Honeywell, Inc., and the Xerox Corporation announced yesterday that they had reached a tentative agreement on the assumption by Honeywell of responsibility for the worldwide servicing and marketing support for the mainframe computer business of Xerox.

title: TV: NoHonestly, Fresh and Utterly Charming
description: It should always be remembered that impressions of British television in this country tend to be severely distorted. Program imports are generally limited to the best available. Actually, anyone sitting through a full average day of TV in Britain is likely to be confronted with as much mediocrity as can be found in the American counterpart. It's simply that the British high spots tend to be a bit higher with admirable consistency.

title: 2 Officers Shot by a Youth in BedfordStuyvesant
description: Two police officers were shot in the hallway of a Brooklyn apartment building last night by a youth who fired a single shotgun blast moments after the policemen had taken a weapon at gunpoint from another teenager, according to the police.

title: NAVY CENSURES 2 FOR ROLE IN BANK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The Navy reprimanded two retired admirals today for their role in establishing a private bank at the Naval Air Station in Pensacola, Fla. Nine other officers who held stock in the bank were absolved.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES.

title: PostHelsinki Germany
description: Historians long will argue whether Stalin's real postwar objective was to unify a broken Germany under Communist rule and whether his successors were serious in offering to a revived West Germany reunification in neutrality, as the alternative to integration in NATO, But since 1958, when the split with China showed how dangerous a united neighbor could be, all Soviet talk of German reunification through confederation or other schemes clearly has been nothing but lip service. Now even the lip service has come to an end.

title: REZONING SOUGHT FOR LOFT SPACE
description: Zoning changes to permit the conversion of loft space into iapertments in two lower Manhattan areas were proposed yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Attorney General's office said yesterday had ended a review of the state prison workrelease and furlough programs and saw no reason for further investigation of the two programs. Attorney General William Hyland said information gained in the examination of the two release programs for inmates would be sent to the Department of Institutions and Agencies, which operates the state prisons. A spokesman for Mr. Hyland said the study had been undertaken at the request of the institutions agency after it faced charges of improprieties in the workrelease and furlough plans stemming from several incidents in which inmates allegedly abused their release privileges.

title: Islip Is Planning to Establish An AdultEntertainment Zone
description: ISLIP, L.I. Oct. 15To stop the spread of bars featuring nude dancers into residential neighborhoods here, town officials are drawing up plans to create an adult entertainment zone.

title: Lynn to Testify
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 15 (UPI) Senator gdmund S. Muskie, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee said today that he had summoned Mr. Lynn to tell Congrass how President Ford plans to cut $28billion from the fiscal 1977 budget to cover an equivalent tax reduction. The Senator said Mr. Lynn would testify next Tuesday.

title: Chinese Unearthing 2,200Year Old Life Size Clay Soldiers
description: SIAN, ChinaLooking into the awesome excavation where a lifesize pottery army was recently found is like looking back more than 2,000 years in time at an ancient battlefield.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE.

title: 10 Held as Basque Rebels
description: BILBAO, Spain, Oct. 15 (Reuters)Ten alleged members of the illegal Basque separatist organization E.T.A. have been seized in this northern industrial city, the police reported tonight. They also reported seizing 50 pounds of explosives and three pistols.

title: Film: A Literary Sensibility at the Festival
description: At the recently ended New York Film Festival, one movie not reviewed by the press was a fiveminute short from Canada called Thanks Giving. Directed by Ken Wallace, Thanks Giving was filmed from the point of view of a turkey plucked and ready for the oven, with two sad, knowing eyes inserted into its hindquarters. The turkey, seeking to escape its fate, heaves itself out of the kitchen, down the stairs, toward the front door grunting all the while like three Martians looking for a fourth for sex. In the end, it looks up at the camera and is cleaved by an ax.

title: ,END OF MUTINY STIRS NEW LISBON DISCORD
description: LISBON, Oct. 15 (AP)  A leftist artillery garrison ended an eightday mutiny today after winning concessions that some influential military leaders said amounted to a sellout.

title: Red Sox Beat Reds, 54, to Tie Series at 2 Games Each
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 15The teams didn't squabble with the umpires or collide with the catcher or hit six home runs in the World Series game tonight. But paunchy oldluis Tiant did throw 163 pitches at the Cincinnati Reds while the Boston Red Sox scored five runs in the fourth inning and hung on for a 54 victory that deadlocked the Series at two games apiece.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Political and Security ComMittee  10:30 A.M. and Special Political Committee3 P.M.

title: Flames Bow To Rangers Here, 3 to 1
description: The Rangers picked on the slumping Atlanta Flames again last night, beating them, 31, for their first victory of'the season at Madison Square Garden. The loss was the Flames third in a row, two of them to New York.

title: Accord Reached for Parley in Paris of Rich and Poor
description: PARIS, Thursday, Oct. 16Representatives of industrial and developing countries cornpleted preparations early today for a 27nation conference on world economic relationships to be held here in December.

title: Almanac Editor Sees Chivalry in Cards
description: A campaign to bring courtesy and chivalry back to America in is Bicentennial year has just been begun by the almanac editor who persuaded the United States Postal Service to restore place names to postmarks.

title: Islip Plans  AdultEntertainment Zone
description: ISLIP, L.I. (Oct. 15)To stop the spread of bars featuring nude dancers into residential neighborhoods here, town officials are drawing up plans to create an adult entertainment zone.

title: NESSEN RETRACTS BUDGET COMMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The White House press secretary, Ron Nessen, announced today that he was mistaken when he said yesterday that President Ford had made a basic decision in July to couple a 1976 tax cut proposal with a demand for Federal spending cuts.

title: S.E.C. WEIGHS RULE ON POLLUTION DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today rules requiring 10,500 corporations to disclose publicly whether they are illegally polluting the nation's air and waterways.

title: People in Sports
description: Danny Murtaugh, the cigarsmoking, sockingchair manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates. said yesterday in Cinciiinati that he would return to his job for the 1976 National League season.

title: Italian President Portrays A Country in Dire Trouble
description: ROME, Oct. 15President Giovanni Leone today sent Parliament the first state of the union message in 12 years, reporting that the nation was in dire shape, suffering from two much corruption, crime, bureaucracy, absenteeism and a host of other ills.

title: Advertising
description: Sales of the Japanesemade Subaru automobile were up 336 per cent in July and 290 per cent in August compared with the corresponding months in 1974. So what if that meant only 5,175 cars sold in August compared with Toyota's 28,745, 290 per cent is still 290 per cent.

title: RENEWED FIRING KILLS 12 IN BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 15New fighting between Christian and Moslem factions erupted early today in downtown Beirut and in outlying neighborhoods and sputtered throughout the day.

title: ICELAND EXTENDS HER FISHING LIMIT
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Oct. 15 (Reuters)Iceland proclaimed new fishing limits in effect today, extending them from 50 to 200 miles off her coasts and becoming the first European count try to claim so wide a zone.

title: Mountbatten Tells Princeton U. It's All Out of Date
description: PRINCETON, Oct. 15Earl Mountbatten of Burma came to Princeton University today and told a distinguished luncheon audience: Without wishing to be rude to this venerable institution, I think you're all out of date.

title: FourthGame Scoring
Knicks Set Date With Wilt
description: The Knicks have scheduled a meeting with Wilt Chamberlain for tomorrow afternoon in Los Angeles. The 7foot2inch center, who could be the answer to many of the Knicks problems, was due to return from Hawaii late tonight.

title: Ali's The Greatest Is a Best Seller at Frankfurt Fair
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 14Muhammad All and his own story, The Greatest, has taken on the 1975 Frankfurt Book Fair and won. The German publisher Willy Droemer, looking groggy at 4 A.M. after an allnight session the other day with Random House, Ali's American publishers, emerged to tell reporters at the Frankfurter Hof Hotel that he had bought Germanlanguage rights for $200,000.

title: BAR PATRONS BEATEN BY 3 IN A HOLDUP
description: Three men, one carrying a shotgun, beat and robbed patrons of an Upper West Side bar last night, according to the police, but were caught at the scene by police units answering a hidden alarm set off by a barmaid.

title: Stamp Sold for $31,000
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 15 (Reuters)An unnamed American collector paid $31,000 for a Canadian 12penny black stamp here tonight. The auction here for one of the world's rarest postage stamps was organized by Stanley Gibbons, the London stamp dealer.

title: Governor Removes an Obstacle To Pardon for. Carter and Artis
description: Governor Byrne agreed, yesterday to waive a time eligibillity requirement that could have prevented Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis from applying for pardons of their triplemurder convictions.

title: Nyquist Hails Kibbee Aim For 20% City U. Cutback
description: The State Education Commissioner, Ewald B. Nyquist, who has been urging the City University to impose tuition as a way out of its financial problems, reacted generally favorably yesterday to the university Chancellor's proposals for a 20 per cent reduction in the system's scale. However, he said that tuition, combined with some of the plan's features, would be a preferable solution.

title: Perspective on Busing
description: Political attacks on school busing are smothering the real issues of school integration under a blanket of misleading oratoryon both sides. The basic questions remain how to put an end to discriminatory policies which condemn minority children to attend inferior schools and how to enlist public education more effectively in the creation of an integrated society.

title: GLADYS M. WRIGLEY
description: Gladys M. Wrigley, editor for 29 years of the American Geographical Society's quarterly, The Geographical Review, died Oast Thursday in New Milford, Conn. She was 90 years old.

title: Japan Lists Trade Deficit
description: TOKYO, Oct. 15 (Reuters)Japan had a foreign trade deficit of $1.12billion during the first half of this fiscal year, with both exports and imports down on 1974the first such decline in 17 yearspreliminary figures showed today. The trade deficit was smaller than the $3.61billion in the corresponding six months of 1974, because imports fell faster than exports, according to the Finance Ministry's figures covering April to September.

title: Northrop Profits Up 44% In Record Third Quarter
description: The Northrop Corporation, the West. Coastbased aerospace and electronics producer, reported yesterday profit in creases of 44 per cent in the third quarter and 42.6 per cent in the first nine months, both setting records. Sales increased 16.8 and 15.8 per cent in the third quarter and nine months.

title: GOLDWATER URGES FORD TO VISIT TAIPEI
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Senator Barry Goldwater urged President Ford today to drop plans for a visit to China and visit Taiwan instead.

title: About the Jets
description: If the World Series is played on Sunday, the JetsDolphins game will not be televised nationally or locally, but will be sent back only to Miami. If the Series is over or if the game is rained out by 1 P.M., then it will be seen here since it is a sellout Jamie Rivers, middle linebacker, had his first hard workout sinoe twisting his right foot and missing two games. Phil Wise, the club's best tackler among the defensive backs, is questionable for Sunday with a groin injury. Richard Neal, the defensive right end, also is a question mark The rival coaches, Don Shula of Miami and Charley Winner, think highly of each other's ability. I always thought I'd like Don Shula as my assistant coach if I ever got a head job, recalled Winner, talking about his days at Case Tech. Instead, Shula became head coach of the Colts and gave me a job as his assistant.

title: Penguins Gain 84 Victory Over Leafs
description: TORONTO, Oct. 15 (UPI)Rick Kehoe scored two goals tonight to lead the Pittsburgh Penguins to an 84 National Hockey League triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report of trading by leading stockholders.. directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Exchange did not make a list available this week.

title: STOCKS TOTTER BUT END HIGHER
description: The stock market vacillated yesterday, confined within a narrow range as trading activity on the New York Stock Exchange quieted down.

title: 42 MAY MERIT AID ON FUNDS FOR '76
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Twelve Presidential candidates have raised enough in private contributions to qualify for a total of more than $6million in Federal subsidies to help them run their 1976 primary campaigns, according to their own records.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES SHOWS PROFIT DROP
description: American Airlines, Inc., one of the most hard pressed of the nation's major domestic carriers, reported yesterday that its earnings plummeted to $7.4million, or 26 cents a share, in the three months to Sept. 30. This was a decline of nearly 71 per cent from the $25.2million, or 88 cents a share, profit reported in the same period a year ago.

title: U.S. Aids Pakistan on Malaria
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 15 (UPI);  The Agency for International Development announced to day it was providing Pakistan with a $35million loan and a $25.3million grant to help fight malaria, which has reached an epidemic level in the country, afflicting a sixth of the population.

title: A Radical Law School Enters Its 2d Year
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15When Robert Meola, Grosse Pointe, Mich., applied to Peoples College of Law in Los Angeles, he listed qualifications that he knew would win points with the admissions committee. At Michigan State University, he had been a member of the Students for a Democratic Society, and, after graduating, had worked in child care for two years in Pontiac, Mich.

title: Plays by Burleson Helped Boston Win
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 15Luis Tiant, the pitching victor in Game No. 1 of the World Series, had just defeated Cincinnati in Game No. 4 tonight and someone asked if he would be ready for Game No. 7.

title: An Editor Without Panache Finds He Has Many Friends
description: Kenneth D. McCormick, the senior consultant editor at Doubleday, hates big parties, but yesterday he went to one anyway. He had to; the party was for him.

title: Grant Urges First Creditors Meeting Not to Force It to Court Trusteeship
description: The W. T. Grant Company yesterday urged its creditors not to force it into a courtappointed trusteeship, saying such action would complicate reorganization measures and delay payment of debts.

title: Radio
Bridge:
description: Almost every mixedpair title in New York tournaments in recent years has been captured by Alvin Roth of New York City and Barbara Rappaport of Springfield. N.J. When they failed to win, it was usually because they were not competing.

title: Tonight's Yonkers Entries
College, School Results
GAP IN NIXON TAPE STILL A MYSTERY AS INQUIRY CLOSES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The special Watergate prosecutor reported today that his office had failed to establish responsibility for the gap in a tape recording of a conversation between President Nixon and H. R. Haldeman, his chief of staff, shortly after the 1972 Watergate breakin.

title: Miss Faye Juggles Songs of the Forties Up at the Spindletop
description: It has been more than a dolen years since Frances Faye last appeared in New York, an absence that has served to emphasize the uniqueness of her performance. Nothing like her has been seen in town since she played at Basin Street East in 1962. Most of those years have been spent overcoming the effects of a broken hip, but she is back at work again at the Upstairs at the Spindletop, 254 West 47th Street, seemingly un. changed and bringing with her a breath of the brash, light. hearted night life that could be found on 52nd Street in the nineteenthirties and forties.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL.

title: Chess:
description: Whoever first said, The thought is stronger than its execution, really knew what he was talking about. Countless games are lost because of overestimating a threat that, at most, required a minor concession or worse, none at all.

title: Sri Lankan May Head U.N. Assembly in 1976
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 15  Hamilton Shirley Amerasinghe, Sri Lanka's chief delegate, was chosen today by the Asian regional group for the presidency of the next General Assembly, which is slated by rotation to go to an Asian candidate. The group is made up of 35 members, including China.

title: Managing Editors Concerned Over Economics of Newspapering
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 16Some joker sits in front of his television set with a can of beer in his hand, and thinks he's getting the news, Jack Powers was saying today at the annual convention of the Associated Press Managing Editors

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: $17,000 Stolen From Ship
description: PORT CANAVERAL, Fla. Oct. 16 (UPI) Two bandits who surprised the sleeping captain of a docked British cargo ship made off with $17,000 in United States and British currency yesterday.

title: SUFFOLK REJECTS REQUEST BY D.A.
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Oct. 16After a day  long session marked by sharp exchanges, the Suffolk Legislature tonight overwhelmingly rejected a request by the county's District Attorney for an Independent 30man investigatory team that would have no links to the Police Department.

title: Lamppost Reunion
description: There is a curious Broadway specimen known as a sleeper. The unwary might think that a sleeper was a merely a walker who had dropped in his tracksbut, no, a sleeper is a show that has arrived in town with no pirticular attention or publicity being given to it, no particular star names hung on it and with about as much chance as might be accorded, say an attempt by Abraham D. I3eame to secure his party's Presidential nomination for 1976. Not much attention was paid to Lamppost Reunion, which opened at the Little Theater last night. But it might well prove to be sleepera play that is unexpectedly, although not at all, undeservedly successful. For it is a humdinger of a melodrama.

title: MOROCCANS PLAN MARCH IN SAHARA
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco, Oct. 16King Hassan II announced today that he would soon lead a march of 350,000 unarmed Moroccans, more than 30,000 of them women, into the Spanish Sahara to claim that territory for Morocco.

title: Jersey Police Scour Suburban Area For 2d Woman to Vanish in 8 Days
description: DEMAREST, N.J., Oct. 16Teams of policemen using dogs and scuba gear scoured 17 acres of woodland and a pond on the Alpine Country Club today in a search for Susan Reeve, a 22yearold woman who disappeared Tuesday after stepping off a bus near her home here. She is the second young woman to disappear in this affluent area of northeast Bergen County in eight days.

title: Market Place
description: While there is little joy tmong holders of municipal bonds here and elsewherethe entire market for taxexempt securities is at a historic lowthere are opportunities to improve positions by taxswapping in the remaining weeks of 1975.

title: Outgoing
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: HARRY M'CLURE DIES; UNION CARBIDE AIDE
description: Harrry B. McClure, who retired in 1963 as a vice president of the Union Carbide Corporation, died Wednesday at his home, 9 South Court, Port Washington, L. I. He was 72 years old.

title: Alcoa Earnings Slide 93.2% in Third Quarter; Caterpillar Net Climbs 115.6% in 3d Period
description: The world's leading aluminum producerthe Aluminum Company of Americahad an extremely depressed third quarter. Net income toppled by 93.2 per cent from the yearago level as sales fell by 16 ner cent.

title: STATE GAMING CHIEF ASKS LOTTERY AUDIT
description: Bertram D. Sarafan, chairman of the New York State Racing and Wagering Board, asked State Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday to audit the operations of the New York State Lottery, to allay the public's concern.

title: Reds Defeat Red Sox, 62; Take a 32 Lead in Series
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 16With Don Gullett pitching twohit bail for eight innings and Tony Perez supplying two home runs, the Cincinnati Reds finally cranked up their mean machine tonight and took a onegame lead in the World Series with a 62 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Theater: Al Carmines's Why I Love New York
description: Al Carmines's New York, as extolled in his new musical at the Judson Memorial Church. Why I Love New York, is no boost to tourism. There is one scene in the lofty Museum of Modern Art. but with its parade of street people  bums, ragpickers, prostitutes, hustlers  the show is much more at home on seedy Eighth Avenue. One of the most upbeat production numbers, the Judy Garlandish I'm Gonna Be a Star. is set in the Port Authority Bus Terminal.

title: Mine Families Lose Homes as Coal Prospers Anew
description: HUTCHINSON, W. Va., Oct. 16Thirtytwo families face eviction from their ramshackle homes here to make room for a $15million coal processing planta facility planned to help meet the nation's rediscovered need for coal as a result of the energy crisis.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN AMEX TRADING
description: Gains achieved early in the session were lost in late trading and stocks closed mixed on an increased volume on the American, Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market yesterday.

title: Reserve Report
description: (In Billions)

title: Freedom vs. Socialism?
description: President Ford has sought to justify his proposed $28billion tax cut and $28billion cut in the growth of Federal expenditures in longrange ideological terms. This program should be seen, he contends, as a step toward furthering fiscal reform and transferring the control of resources from public to private hands; as a shortterm measure, it would not, he maintains, affect the economy in any significant way.

title: West Side Center Funds Are Frozen by the Mayor
description: Mayor Beame moved ahead with his austerity drive yesterday by shelving the West Side Convention and Exhibition Center project, freezing the financing of what was to have been a major step in the program to upgrade the WestMidtown area.

title: Dissidents Won't Be Tolerated, Kenyatta Warns the Parliament
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 16 (Reuters)President Jomo Kenyatta today warned Parliament, which has just seen two of its most prominent members placed in detention, that dissidents would not be tolerated.

title: Hnueilings
description: FRIEDMANSamuel.. An unveiling will take place Sunday, Oct. 19, at 10:45 AM., at the New Montefiore Cemetery,. Block 12, Section. 4.

title: TEACHERS REJECT 150MILLION LOAN CITY NEEDS TODAY
description: The trustees of the City Teachers Retirement System refused last night to furnish $150million to the Municipal Assistance Corporationmoney that the city says it needs to meet bills due today.

title: Judge Hears Case 225 Miles Away Via Telephone TV
description: For the first time in American trialcourt history, lawyers in one city argued a case before judges in another city, 225 miles away.

title: About Real Estate
description: In the days not long past when electric power was cheap and plentiful, a practice known as rent inclusion became familiar in many large apartment developments. The tenant's utility bills were included in the rent. The owner bought power directly from Consolidated Edison at lower bulk rates, and master meters gauged use.

title: Music
description: Robert Goldsand is getting to the point where major anniversaries and celebrations will soon be in order. Next year the Viennaborn pianist will be 65 years old, and in 1977 he will be observing the 50th anniversary of his American debut. Meanwhile, there was his recital in Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night to testify to the continuing fascination of his individuality as an artist.

title: American Girl, 16, First at 200 Meters
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 16 (AP) Chandra Cheeseborough of Jacksonville, Fla., got off to a swift start and held off her teammate, Pamela Jiles, in winning the women's 200 meters today in record time at the PanAmerican Games track and field competition.

title: Highs and Lows
description: NEW HIGHS41

title: Surgeons
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 (UPI)The new head of the American College of Surgeons told his fellow doctors today that the gut issue of medical professional liability is far more than an insurance problem and suggested . they study the causes of patient injury.

title: ATHENS TRIAL HEARS PAPADOPOULOS PLEA
description: ATHENS, Oct. 16 (Reuters)Former President George Pa padopoulos told a high court today that as head of state he was not responsible for the bloody clashes at Athens Polytechnic University in November, 1973, when 34 people were killed and more than 1,000 injured.

title: Woman Injured in the Surf Says Municipality Is Liable
description: TRENTON, Oct. 16 (AP)The attorney for a woman injured in a beach accident says the municipality where the mishap occurred is liable for damages because it charged a beach fee.

title: Teamsters
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (Reuters) The Labor Department has started a new investigation into allegations of syndicated criminal infiltration into the International Brotherhood of Teamsters pension fund in the Midwest states.

title: Season's First Cosi
description: Some nice things could be said about the Metropolitan Opera's first Cosi Fan Tutte of the season on Wednesday night, such as that Kazimierz Kord continues to make an impression as one of the company's better young conductors. There was novelty to the casting, too, inasmuch as four of the six characters were making their Met debuts: Elizabeth Harwood as Fiordiligi, Anne Howels as Dorabella, Ryland Davies as Ferrando and Richard Stilwell as Guglielmo.

title: 5.4 Million Unemployed Get Benefits, an 8Month Low
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UPI) About 5.4 million persons were receiving unemployment insurance benefits during the week ending Sept. 27, a new low since the start of emergency jobless programs last January, the Labor Department said today.

title: INDUSTRY OUTPUT UP IN SEPTEMBER, 5TH MONTH IN ROW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 Industrial production rose in September for the fifth consecutive month and last month's gain was the largest of the five, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: THREE ARE INDICTED FOR CONTEMPT HERE
description: Three men described by the police as closely associated with the Queens underworld were arrested yesterday on an indictment accusing them of refusing to answer questions before a special grand jury Investigating the fixing of criminal cases by judges and lawyers in Queens.

title: United Press International and Associated Press THREE SHARE NOBEL PRIZE
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 16The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for 1975 was awarded here today to Drs. David Baltimore, Renato Dulbecco, and Howard Martin Ternin for discoveries concerning the interaction between tumor viruses and the genetic material of the cell.

title: Pistons Defeat Knicks, 118108
description: DETROIT, Oct. 16 (AP)Bob Lanier and Kevin Porter each scored 22 points, leading the Detroit Pistons to a 118108 victory over the New York Knicks tonight. It was the Pistons fourth straight preseason triumph.

title: Guild Authorizes Its Officers To Call a Strike at The Times
description: Members of the Newspaper Guild at The New York Times voted yesterday to authorize their officers to call a strike against the newspaper if they were unsuccessful in negotiating a satisfactory contract.

title: Ballet: Parade
description: Parade, that delightful ballet for children and adults alike, made its first appearance of the season Wednesday night at the City Center. The ballet has not been staged since 1974, when the City Center Joffrey Ballet lost some of the production's dcor and costuming through water damage or disappearance on the company's Soviet tour.

title: House Unit Presses H.E.W. for Data
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16A House subcommittee is increasing its demands for information from the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to justify the way the department regulates its $22billion in health programs.

title: Finley Is Ready To Dismiss Dark
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 16 (AP)Alvin Dark, the Oakland A's manager, will not be rehired next season and the club's owner Charles O. Finley, will offer the job to Gene Mauch.

title: FUND FOR BUILDING WEST SIDE CENTER FROZEN BY BEAME
description: Mayor Beame moved ahead with his austerity drive yesterday by shelving the West Side Convention and Exhibition Center project, freezing the financing of what was to have been a major step in the program to upgrade the WestMidtown area.

title: Judge Dismisses Criminal Charges Against Dairylea
description: Criminal charges that the Dairylea Cooperative filed false and misleading reports with the State Department of Agriculture and markets about the adulteration of milk were dismissed in Plattsburgh yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Norman L. Harvey.

title: Human Experimentation
description: A pending Senate bill to broaden the responsibilities of the National Commission for the Protection of Human Subjects of Biomedical and Behavioral Research offers a simple but promising approach to a difficult and often painful problem.

description: DETROIT, Oct. 16 (UPI)President Ford's limousine was flown to suburban Livonia today for repairs in a Ford Motor Company body shop. A spokesman for the auto maker said that the $500,000 Lincoln Continental would be repaired by specialists and flown black to Washington as soon as possible.

title: Hands Off Lebanon, Arabs Warn Israelis
description: CAIRO, Oct. 16Eighteen Arab countries warned today that they would use all their resources in coneorted action if Israel used the civil strife in Lebanon as a pretext for taking over southern Lebanon.

title: Bridge
description: Presidents of bridge organizations do not usually figure in the lists of titlewinners. If they can find the time to play, administrative cares may reduce their effectiveness. But in East Orange, N. J., last weekend, the president of the American Bridge Association, which provides primarily for black players, was apparently unaware of the general rule.

title: Arrest by Secret Service
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 16 (UPI)Secret Service agents arrested a Columbus man with a history of mental illness for allegedly theatening to kill agents trying to question him in connection with a visit here by Vice President Rockefeller, a Secret Service spokesman said.

title: Egg Harbor City Man, 30, Guilty in Murder of Woman,
description: MAYS LANDING, Oct. 16 (UPI)  An Atlantic County man was convicted today of the robbery and murder of an 83yearold woman.

Oct. 16Reginald Leslie Cleveland, who grew up among the buffalo herds and Eskimos of northern Alberta, walked out in front of the wolves of Riverfront Stadium tonight with visions of sugar plums, cheeseburgers and doublerich chocolatemaltedstoothickforastraw dancing in his head. If he could outpitch the Cincinnati Eagle Scout, Don Gullett, the Red Sox would go back Boston needing only one victory for the baseball championship of the world, and the $20,000 that goes with that

title: CAMPAIGN COSTS COVER LEGAL FEES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16The Federal Election Commission ruled today that the fees candidates pay to lawyers and accountants for political service come within the spending limits imposed by the new campaign law.

title: Helstoski Presses Judge to Release His Jury Testimony
description: NEWARK, Oct. 16 (AP)Representative Henry Helstoski, Democrat of Bergen County, who has been under investigation by Federal prosecutors, said today that he wanted his secret grand jury testimony made public. And a Federal judge said he probably would grant the request.

title: WEATHER SATELLITE IS LAUNCHED BY U.S.
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 16 (AP)A Delta rocket thundered away from Cape Canaveral tonight carrying a satellite that will monitor weather conditions and track tornadoes and hurricanes over the Western Hemisphere.

title: 1,600 Vietnamese Sail From Guam In Bid to Go Home
description: AGANA, Guam, Oct. 16 (AP) About 1,600 refugees who fled South Vietnam before the Communist takeover sailed for their homeland today with no assurance that they would be welcomed back.

title: Mrs. Cudone Wins NorthSouth Golf
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 16 (AP)Mrs. Philip Cudone won the North and South women's senior golf championship today for the fourth straight year. She shot a final 81 for a 54hole total of 239 and won by 13 strokes.

title: U.S.British Deal On Diego Garcia In 66 Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16The Slate Department said today that the United States had encered into a secret agreement in 1966 under which it reduced the cost of the Polaris missile to Britain in return for British establishment of a military base on the island of Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean.

title: About the Jets . . .
description: The Jets go into Sunday's games against the Dolphins with four straight victories at Shea Stadium, including the one game played there this season. They played their first game at Shea in 1964, and have won 43, lost 30 and tied on the homefield. . . . Jazz Jackson, who wasn't injured as a member of the suicide squad, pulled his right hamstring muscle running through plays in a workout. His status for Sunday is uncertain. . . . Rich Caster leads the pure receivers in the American Conference with catches. Lydell Mitchell, a running back, with the Colts, has 19. Caster is averaging 20 yards a reception. . . Jerome Barkum caught passes yesterday and apparently will be ready on Sunday. A decision on whether Jamie Rivers or Steve Reese will start at middle linebacker may not be made until game time.

title: One Giant Has Grudge With Bills
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 16If things had gone well for Larry Watkins in Buffalo, the New York Giants would be preparing to face him and O. J. Simpson on Monday night instead of Simpson and Jim Braxton. But as things worked out, Watkins will play for the Giants against his former mates.

title: 3 ARE FOUND GUILTY IN OBSCENITY CASE
description: The owners of an adult bookstore in Roxbury Township and a clerk there were convicted in Superior Court last night of possession and distribution of obscene films and magazines. The conviction was the first since a ban on enforcement of New Jersey's antiobscen ity statute was lifted last year after the State Supreme Court redefined it to give local juries the power to determine what is obscene, to conform with a United States Supreme Court ruling.

title: President Phones Driver of Car That Hit His to Tell Him of Jolt
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16President Ford, in a telephone conversation today with the young driver of a vehicle that crashed into his limousine Tuesday, said that he got kind of a jolt but no injuries in the collision.

title: Merrill Lynch Presents S.E.C. With Model
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 Donald T. Regan, chairman of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission today a model for an electronic national market system for securities transactions.

title: Rail Carloadings Off
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled 16.4 billion tonmiles, 5.1 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago. Carloading in the same period totaled 497,870 cars, 6.5 per cent below last year.

title: Cancer and Viruses
description: Renato Dulbecco, Howard M. Temin and David Baltimore won the Nobel Prize in Medicine yesterday for their research on viruses, motivated to a large extent by the hope that a viral cause of human cancers would be found, thus opening the way to curing or even preventing the disease. It came as a great shock to many, therefore, when Dr. Temin commented on being told of his award that he thought current research has shown that human cancer is not caused primarily by an infective virus. It is not an opinion universally accepted; in fact, there are quite a few researchers at work who hope to win a future Nobel Prize by proving that viruses do indeed cancer in humans.

title: JAMES WYNN DEAD; A TAX LAWYER HERE
description: James Oscar Wynn, a leading tax lawyer, died yestrday, at his home in Darien, Conn. He was 78 years old.

title: Gullett Exit a Bit Too Slow
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 16When Sparky Anderson went to the mound in the ninth inning tonight, he had no intention of taking Don Gullett back to the dugout with him.

title: Dr. Frank P. Jones, Classicist, Psychology Researcher, Dead
description: Dr. Frank Pierce Jones, professor emeritus of classics at Tufts University, who contributed to the psychological research in kinesthetics (bodily reactions), died Wednesday in Cambridge, Mass., where he lived. He was 70 years old.

title: Harpsichordist Plays Bach
description: Last winter when Edward Smith made his harpsichord recital debut here, the varied program he played was described as offbeat. The same adjective, compounded, would apply to the program Mr. Smith brought Wednesday night to Carnegie Recital Hall. It consisted of the 24 Preludes and Fugues of Book I of Bach's WellTempered Clavier.

description: PARIS, Oct. 16As industrial and developing countries ended a threeday meeting here early today, they published separate lists of priorities for what is expected to be a prolonged and heated attempt to modify world economic relationships.

title: PARENT/CHILD
description: Almost despite himself, Dr. Richard I. Feinbloom, who heads the family and child health division of the Boston Children's Medical Center, has put together an important book for those parents he describes as welloff and welleducated.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: What is a fourstar restaurant? By the yardstick applied in this column, it is a restaurant where the food, the service and the surroundings individually are at least threestar without question, with one or more of these factors so exceptional that the average is healthy three  and  a  half  plus; where there is no special defect, such as inconsistent performance, to lower the average to a sickly threeandahalfminus, and wherevery important, as a decisive subjective factorthe operation is carried on with a certain finesse, a feeling for style that goes beyond stylishness.

title: CORN, SOYBEANS AND WHEAT RISE
description: Traders pushed corn, wheat and soybean futures prices a little higher on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday while they waited hopefully for word that the Government had ended the moratorium on grain sales to the Soviet Union.

title: TV: Home of Our Own
description: A Home of Our Own is one of those exercises in inspiration that prompts thoughts of kicking a saint in the shins. Filmed on location in Mexico, the reallife drama, which will be shown this Sunday on CBS at 8 P.M., deals with Father William Wasson's founding of a home for orphaned children. A worthwhile ideaand what could have been most appealinghas been transmuted into sanctimonious clichs of sight and sound, the kind of tired formulae that executivesuite punjabs deem to be heartwarming.

description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 16 (AP)Miller Barber and young Gil Morgan carded 6underpar 66's today and shared the firstround lead in the $125,000 Texas open golf tournament.

title: BLUE CROSS REVISES RULE ON STUDENTS
description: NEWARK, Oct. 16 (AP)Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey announced today that they had removed a regulation that limited enrollment in their special student program to semiannual enrollment periods.

title: 4 Shorts at Film Forum a Blend of Charm and Naivete
description: The past never seems as frail and long gone as when it is asserting something about the future. It is the avant-garde that dies first.The point is evoked with eerie precision at a collection of four short films being shown by Film Forum to inaugurate its new premises at the Vandam Theater in SoHo. The four, all made in the nineteen-fifties, were considered more or less experimental in their day. All are interesting and two, at least, are masterpieces. But seen now, with many of their varying techniques having become familiar, the stylistic effect is a blend of charm and naivet.In fact their real impact, and it has almost the force of shock, is not in their style but in their viewpoint.All four are in some way about New York. What stands out is the buoyancy, the sheer optimism and exuberance that this city, 20 years ago, imposed even upon those who were out to set it on its collective ear. The pictures will be shown today through Sunday and again next Thursday through Sunday.If "On the Road" was the bible of the Beat Generation, the film "Pull My Daisy" was a kind of short breviary. With a voice-over narration by Jack Kerouac and the manic participation of Allen Ginsberg, Gregory Corso, Peter Orlovsky and others, it takes the more or less formal setting of a social call and tears it into shreds.The setting is a loft somewhere south of Greenwich Village. Lofts were still symbols of freedom and boundlessness: bodies with needle marks or stab wounds hadn't begun to turn up in them. It was littered with clothes: litter was still a statement and not a universal condition. A Tiffany lamp hung in it: Tiffany lamps were still found in junkshops and hadn't made their way uptown.For the Beats the seamless stability of American life was like a field just snowed on, in which almost any kind of caper would leave a significant mark. So in "Daisy" Messrs. Ginsberg, Orlovsky and Corso, laden with beer cans bounce into the residence of Milo, a seraphic brakeman, and his long-suffering wife.The three poets are young, their hair is slept-in but short, and they sit on Milo's couch like ruffled owls while sabotaging the visit of the Bishop and his mother and sister. The bishop is only about 17: still, he manages such lines as "A strange and interesting evening" while the air is full of talk about "tortured socks" and a short oratorio about cockroaches.This is Dada: maximum shock with a minimum of pain; the feeling that stones could be hurled through windows and nothing would really break. Like Dada from the nastier perspective of the late nineteen-twenties, it seems innocent and touching."Skyscraper," made by Shirley Clarke, is a short film classic; a funny, exciting and absorbing account of the building of a skyscraper from demolition to completion.We see old facades coming down and a great hole gouged out by power shovels, and with a sudden sense of time-warp we realize that what we see as not being deprecated or condemned but celebrated. A lilting voice sings about "this island, light as wine." Change is presented as triumph not loss, and the city is a place of limitless energies and possibilities.Using a dialogue between Murphya high-steel man who is the wisecracking, know-it-all New Yorker and totally capable of astonishmentand his boss, the entire process of building a skyscraper is laid out. The camera shows bedrock being hauled away"They're taking New York to New Jersey," Murphy protestsfoundations laid, steel uprights swinging into place.The bare girders frame towering views of Manhattan. The facade is laid on and, curiously, as the building is finished it becomes less real. The irony is unmeant and is only seen now in retrospect. Because all this romance, guts and imagination, all this high-flying geometry went to produce the gimcrack banality of Fifth Avenue's Tishman Building.The other two films are less thematic: they are poetic and affectionate explorations of the beauty of the city. "N.Y., N.Y." by Francis Thompson uses optical effectsmultiple images, distortion, color-blurring  to find geometric patterns in the city's bones. A morning cup of coffee is serialized into infinity; bridge-girders zigzag, framing the sky like stained glass.A much better picture, the best of the four, in fact, is Weegee's New York, particularly its Coney Island section. Made by the photographer Weegee, it follows the day and evening through a crowded Coney Island Sunday.

Born in 1899 into a poor Yorkshire family that, in spite of her father's indefatigable efforts, barely made ends meet, Miss Harrison seemed unlikely to realize her ambition. Her mother, however, saw a way. In service, she said, there are two servants who usually go everywhere with their masters and mistressesvalets and ladies maids. If you're prepared to smarten yourself up a bit, see no reason why you shouldn't be ladies maid.

title: Film: Italian 'Down the Ancient Stairs':Mastroianni Is a Satyr Treating the Insane Dialogue Is Ridiculous and Pace Leaden
description: Take an insane asylum whose staff members ask one another such questions as "What is madness?" and pretty much agree that sanity is only to be found inside the place. Stage a costume party where the inmates come as catatonic Pierrots, deranged Columbines and 15-foot giants and film it through gauze to drugged music. Let the star act at the party be a mime show where the actors, also inmates, sag sadly at one another.If I haven't lost count, Mauro Bolognini has managed to mount a metaphor upon a second metaphor that is mounted, in turn, upon a third metaphor. All were exhausted to begin with: Is he trying to kill them? He shouldn't, because he will undoubtedly want to use them again."Down the Ancient Stairs." which opened yesterday at the Little Carnegie, puts Marcello Mastroianni in the role of Professor Bonaccorsi, chief psychiatrist at the asylum. It is a Mastroianni role in that he is the lover of the wives of the asylum's director and surgeon and of one of the nurses. It also works up the actor's bent for being gloomy about it, as a man might be gloomy between bouts of compulsive overeating.Professor Bonaccorsi's satyriasishe fondles the patients as well as his colleaguesis metaphysical. He is obsessed with insanity: with establishing that there is indeed a difference between himself and the patients. At the asylum he sets himself up as a kind of godlike figure, running everything, holding off everyonestaff and patients  with busyness and with a show, often a physical show, of love.Into this closed world comes Anna Bersani, a young woman doctor played by Franoise Fabian. She resists Bonaccorsi's advances, she questions his methods. To nail down his insistence that there is a clear demarcation between the sane and insane, Bonaccorsi keeps searching for a physical determinant of insanity.One day he finds it, or thinks he does. He peers through his microscope, he exults. Insanity is a hairy splotch, he announces, appearing on the blood cells. Dr. Bersani checks the experiment and finds it is flawed.Bonaccorsi quits the hospital and gets on a train. But it is Italy of the nineteen-thirties, and the compartment is full of raving Fascists. Not only is there no difference between the inmates and the staff in the asylum, Bolognini suggests, but there is also no difference between the asylum and the rest of the world.It is relentlessly weary stuff; an image so venerable, a paradox so frequently trotted out that it has lost all its original force.Mr. Mastroianni, Miss Fabian and the actresses playing Bonaccorsi's mistresses perform routinely. The pace is leaden, the dialogue ridiculous.

title: Fiscal Crisis at a Glance
description: The city's fiscal crisis began to take shape in the late nineteensixties when the gap between municipal expenditure and tax revenues began to widen rapidly and dangerouly. Instead of imposing new taxes or reducing services, the city's elected officials chose to increase shortterm borrowings against anticipated revenues. This shortterm indebtedness grew seemingly out of control until, this year, it is double what it was two years ago; eight times what it was in 1969.

description: TRENTON, Oct. 17 (AP)The toll of injured was put at 10 today as officials continued their investigation into yesterday's bloody clash among inmates at Trenton State Prison. One man was killed. Six were reported injured yesterday.
