title: Screen: A Recycled 'Rooster Cogburn':Wayne and Hepburn in 'True Grit' Spin-Off Eccentric Chase Turns Into Cheerful Comedy
description: "Rooster Cogburn," which opened at three theaters yesterday, is a high-class example of the low Hollywood art of recyclingtaking bits and pieces of old stories and characters and making from them other movies that can never be described as completely new or fresh.For John Wayne, who has the title role, "Rooster Cogburn" is a continuation of the part he played in "True Grit," the film for which he was awarded his first (and fully deserved) Oscar. For Katharine Hepburn the film recalls her marvelous characterization opposite Humphrey Bogart in "The African Queen." The role of Eula Goodnight, the pastor's spinsterish Bible-quoting daughter in "Rooster Cogburn," is a lighthearted spin-off of the earlier role, but the important word here is lighthearted, not spin-off.Miss Hepburn has been too long glum in her recent films. It's good to see her looking as if she were having a lark for a change. Good causes ("Guess Who's Coming to Dinner") and art ("The Trojan Women") are all well and good, but too much of that sort of thing can get even a good woman down.In "Rooster Cogburn," Miss Hepburn has a roaring good timeso convincingly that you come to accept the movie on its own terms. It's a cheerful, throwaway Western, featuring two stars of the grand tradition who respond to each other with verve that makes the years disappear.In this new film you remember with immense pleasure instead of regret the Hepburn of the great Cukor films of the nineteen-thirties, forties and fifties. The comedienne has not disappeared, only the good roles.Martin Julien's screenplay for "Rooster Cogburn," using the Rooster Cogburn character from "True Grit," is hardly high comedy, but it gives Miss Hepburn and Mr. Wayne a number of decently funny lines and situations that Stuart Millar, formerly a producer, directs with goodhumored affection.Like "True Grit," the new film is essentially an eccentric chase film: Rooster Cogburn, the pot-bellied, whiskysoaked, one-eyed old Federal marshal, is commissioned to track down a gang of desperados in the Arkansas territory. In the course of his journey he is more or less forced to take along the woman whose father has been murdered by the outlaw gang and a young Indian boy.That's all the story there is, or need be. What makes "Rooster Cogburn" so pleasant is the quality of the encounters between the marshal and Eula, who, it turns out, is a crack shot and not above lifting a watch from the body of a dead bandit over whom she's saying a solicitous prayer.Mr. Wayne, of course, has played this role before, and there are signswhen Miss Hepburn is off-screenthat it would run away from him were he left to his own devices. He mugs, pouts and gets very close to playing it in the cute manner of the very young and very old. When Miss Hepburn is with him, however, a sense of discipline is established that brings out the best in both of them.It's rather like one of the film's better scenes: Rooster, Eula and the Indian boy have stopped on the trail to rest and Rooster has taken the opportunity to get drunk, at which point he starts using their food for target practice. "Shooting cornbread in a meadow," Eula reminds Rooster firmly, "is not taking us anywhere."When Miss Hepburn is not around, "Rooster Cogburn" is shooting cornbread in a meadow. Fortunately, she's on the screen most of the time.

title: VITTORIO GUI DIES; CONDUCTOR WAS 90
description: ROME, Oct. 17  Vittorio Gui, one of the bestknown Italian conductors of this century, died late last night of an attack of angina in his home near Florence. He was 90 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: For those who might confuse Rudolf Nureyev with Robespierre, John Percival, dance critic of The Times of London, has set out to help kill the widespread myth that Nureyev is some kind of monster. Unluckily, not only is there fire where there is smoke but also the idea that the most celebrated ballet star of our time is not a monstre sacre makes him less than he is. The monster myth itself might have been more easily discarded in this book its Festschriftlike tributes by Mr. Percival and prominent ballet figures did not take up so much room explaining that Mr. Nureyev's capacity for making waves was of no consequence.

title: Radio
The Collapse of Tomorrow
description: Much of the work in a civilized community rests upon the assumption that the show is good for a long run. The drama of the present tends to move in a given direction only when it receives the double impact of the past and the future; and if the past be too frightful for remembrance or the future too cloudy for anticipation, the present ceases to move in any particular direction, and teeters fitfully about from point to point.

title: What's New in Animated Films? Sex, Gluttony and Computers:What's New in Animated Films?
description: Ralph Bakshi revived public interest in animation as a medium for the seventies with a trio of controversial cartoon features: "Fritz the Cat," the first X-rated animated cartoon; "Heavy Traffic," the first portrait of the artist as a young drawing; and "Coonskin," which has been crusaded against by the Congress of Racial Equality as an animated racial slur.Whether you love Bakshi's films or hate themand you will have plenty of company in either campit must be admitted that the abrasive, innovative filmmaker has gotten audiences excited about the possibilities of animation in the seventies the way that Disney did in the thirties and forties with "Snow White," the first feature-length cartoon, and "Fantasia," his animated symphony concert.So what else is new in this frequently neglected medium? Well, among other things, a tug at the heart-strings by clay figures, a computer-assisted film about human beings, and the children's book illustrations of Maurice Sendak and Tomi Ungerer come to life. All this and more, as anyone who attended the Third International Animation Film Festival in New York at Columbia University can testify. Fred Mintz, director of the five-day festival which ended on Oct. 4, devised nine categories for the series, each defining a way in which animation can be used (for feature films, entertainment shorts, educational films, industrial films, films for children, films by students, television commercials, experimental films and computer films.)Although there were no feature films in competition in thisthe thirdNew York festival, audiences witnessed competition among 142 short films from 17 countries. Their techniques ranged from good old pencil and paper to clay to computer animation. Their subjects ranged from world hunger to the right of privacy to sexual fantasies.This year's festival winners were chosen by an international jury that included the animation directors Feodor Khytruk (Russia), Marcell Jankovics (Hungary), and Miroslav Kijowicz (Poland); Louise Beaudet, director of the Cinmathque Quebeoise in Canada; and Phil Kimmelman, who makes animated commercials in New York. The chairman of the jury was Frank Thomas of the Walt Disney Studio, one of the most important figures in the world history of animation who has helped bring to life such memorable characters as Bambi, the Lady and the Tramp, and the little rabbits in last year's "Robin Hood." Now, at 62, Thomas is helping to train the first post-Walt Disney group of young animators at the Disney Studio on the next Disney animated feature, "The Rescuers." When he was 24, Thomas achieved a break-through in animation toward the end of Disney's "Snow White" that most animators thought they would never see. When the dwarfs are gathered, sorrowing, at Snow White's bier, and Dopey breaks down and sobs in Doc's beard, members of the premiere audience actually wept. Cartoons had made audiences laugh for years, but never cry. For the first time in history, moving drawings had becomemoving drawings.It was a similar break-through that won for a film called "Whazzat?" the Grand Prix of this year's animation festival. Arthur P. Pierson of Chicago animated clay to retell an 11th-century Arabic folk tale about six blind men. In an amazing sceneamazing because it manages to communicate strong emotion with featureless clay figures and without dialoguethe six blind men try to cross a chasm. One of the little figures stretches itself across the chasm to make a bridge. Four of the others cross their pal (literally, not dishonorably), then wait on the other side for the last little guy to cross over. But he is immobilized by fear. So they hop up and down, urging him on. Finally, he tries, only to have the bridge collapse and leave him dangling over the chasm. Fortunately, the blind buddies on the cliff quickly haul him up and soon they are all jumping for joy."This is the first time that I've seen clay animation communicate an emotion," said Thomas. "Usually, you know what a character is doing; you may even, know what it's thinking; but you do not feel any emotion. 'Closed Mondays,' another clay film, got the Academy Award for animation last year, and it was like that. But Mr. Pierson has a group of six little characters, and though they don't have specific personalities, they have a group personality. When they're happy, you feel happy, when they're curious, you feel curious; and when they're apprehensive, you feel apprehension. And to get that out of little clay figuresand a group of themis either awfully lucky or pure genius."The winner in the category of computer animation, "Hunger," by Peter Foldes, is another triumph but one which uses a very different technique. Hungarian-born Foldes, 51, is a brilliant draftsman who has long been successful in translating his stark line drawings into the dimension of movement; but the computer gives these drawings an inhuman, flowing motion that perfectly suits his terrifying transformations. Foldes has learned to use a computer as another animation toollike a special kind of pencil. "Hunger" is the first fully animated figurative film ever made using computer techniques. Produced by the National Film Board of Canada, it was made with a digital computer at the National Research Council of Canada, utilizing the programs that N. Burtnyk and M. Wein have developed there.In "Hunger," Foldes takes a Dantesque view of modern gluttony, showing the metamorphosis of a slim, handsome young man into a grotesque and obese old man. When the old man dies of over-eating, he is cast bodily into hell, where his flesh is devoured by the spirits of those who have starved to death. In effect, the computer "draws" all the tedious drawings in between the extreme poses of an action, leaving Foldes free to concentrate on the key drawings.This year's student films reflected much more maturity and technical achievement than those entered in the first two festivals. The jury gave first prize to "Roll 'Em, Lola," a sexual fantasy conceived and animated by Fred Surns of the University of Southern California, in which two high-powered automobiles chase each other around the nude body of a giant woman in a four-minute-thirty-second feast for the Jung at heart.The violation of the human right of privacy is the theme of "Walls Have Ears," the surreal film directed by Poland's Andrej Ryska which won the prize in the festival's experimental film category. A terrible, ear-shaped protuberance grows out of the wall and drives a man insane before it is sliced off by a razor bladeonly to be replaced by a growth like an eyeball.The best example of the increasingly scarce "story" cartoon to be shown at the festival was "The Heron and the Crane," a wry, Chekhovian animal fable told by I. Norstein and R. Kachanov of Russia. Gag cartoons are also less in evidence at animation festivals since the major Hollywood studios closed their cartoon department in the fifties and early sixties. And yet, the Eastern European animators, who have only recently caught up with all the Popeyes, Tom and Jerrys and Roadrunners made during and immediately after World War II, are trying hard to revive the pure gag cartoon. The biggest bellylaughs of the festival were heard during a six-minute cartoon from Pannonia Film Studio in Budapest called "Let's Keep a Dog," which illustrated a number of arguments in favor of having a dog as a pet."Because it is faithful unto death" was Argument Number Seven, accompanied by the stereotype image of Man's Best Friend stretched out upon his master's grave. A comforting image until darkness falls, whereupon the dog suddenly leers, leaps up, and digs down into the grave for a bone. "Let's Keep a Dog" and "The Heron and the Crane" were the winners among entertainment filmsthe first in the six-minute and under category, the second in the category of shorts lasting more than six minutes.The best commercial was clearly "Trans-Siberian Express" from Richard Williams Animation in Londona studio which received a special award for the general high quality of its entries. Except for a brief pitch for Count Pushkin Vodka at the end, the commercial devotes its two minutes of screen time to an accelerating montage conjuring up a 10-day train journey from Moscow to Vladivostock. "This was staggering art workreal impact!" said jury chairman Thomas. "And it's hard to get outstanding art work on the screen as you go into animationbecause to do a strong still drawing and then move it and keep that strength is very difficult." The art work was done by Playboy cartoonist Rowland B. Wilson; it was moved by 23-year-old English animator Russell Hall; and it was edited by Art Babbitt, the man who made the mushrooms dance in Disney's "Fantasia."The problem of animating strong still drawings cropped up again in the category of children's film, where animated film versions of several respected children's books competed for the prize. "We on the jury asked ourselves is it primarily a filmor is it just putting the book's illustrations on the screen?" said Thomas. "In the case of Maurice Sendak's 'Where the Wild Things Are,' we felt that the director, Gene Deitch, did not improve it by putting it on the screen. It was better as a book."We gave the prize to 'The Beast of Monsieur Racine.' [Book written and illustrated by Tomi Ungerer; movie directed by Gene Deitch in Czechoslovakia for Weston Woods Studio, USA.] Deitch added elements of timing and staging that added a new dimension, which I think you have to do when you make a picture of a book, and it held up as a picture."The trick is to keep the same style and plot content, while translating the written word into moving images with sound. This "The Beast of M. Racine" does admirably, while telling the story of a Frenchman who won't sell his prize pears to anyone, but suffers the misfortune of having them eaten by a strange beast. However, he manages to capture the beast and boasts: "I lost my pears but I found a companion." Now, people want to buy his beast. "The beast is my friend," says M. Racine, "and friends are not for sale."But when he tries to show off his beastly friend at the National Academy of Science, a hoax is revealed: two children have been playing a trick on M. Racine by dressing up in a beast's skin. Undaunted, M. Racine adopts the children  and soon has "a new crop of pears which he happily shared with his two young friends." Summarized, it sounds goofy; visualizedas when M. Racine kisses his pears good night while crickets and frogs provide a little night musicit is charming.What was conspicuously missing from this year's competition was the art of personality animationthe ability to create characters with specific individual personalities, to put the spark of life into moving drawings so that pen-and-ink personages like The Three Pigs, the Seven Dwarfs or Fritz the Cat emerge on screen.There was only one such moment at the festival, and it occurred with an already established character. It happened during the showing of the animated title credits for the new Peter Sellers comedy. "The Return of the Pink Panther." Without a word of dialogue or a change of costume, the Pink Panther walked through the credits in six different waysand evoked six different personalities: Groucho Marx, Mickey Mouse, Charlie Chaplin, Frankenstein, a ballet dancer and a cowboy.To be sure, the animator for these lively "Pink Panther" credits was that veteran Bugs Bunny/Roadrunner animator, Ken Harris. But the director was the New Wave's Richard Williams, who won an Oscar in 1972 for a half-hour cartoon, edition of Dickens' "A Christmas Carol," which brought the original 1843 John Leech illustrations to magical life. And now that Williams has financing for his full-length animated "Raggedy Ann," we may hope for a new flowering of personality animation in 1976.John Culhane is a film historian and co-author of "Noah's Animals," a forthcoming animated television special.

title: PORTUGUESE TOLD TO YIELD WEAPONS

J., and Morton Finder of Pine Hollow Stud Farm, Pine Bush, N. Y. Nevele Thunder has won 18 of 21 races this year and has earned $150,617. The record price for a harness horse of any age was $3million, paid for Nevele Pride, Nevele Thunder's sire, as a 4yearold after three times being named horse of the year. title: TV VIEW
description: The fact of the matter is that CBS, one of the three major networks to turn down Space 1999, turned up Bronk. The splendid thing about being a major network is that you can hire an actor of genuine talent, like Jack Palance; surround him with writers who must be doing their typing at the laundramat, inside the machine, during the spin cycle; sentence him to directors who would have a hard time organizing a slice of buttered toast; concoct a fiasco; put it on in prime time Ind still be a major network. As a network, you should be whipp'd with wire, and stew'd in brine,/ Smarting in ling'ring pickle'that's Shakespeare, who is not, alas, one of Bronk's writersand yet the only one likely to be punished for Bronk is Jack Palance.

So many people think of character dancers as old people playing old parts, just hobbling around.

title: THE OTHER SIDE OF LSD
description: Authors of reports on moodaltering drugs come in two basic varieties: those who have taken the drugs and those who haven't. As an unavoidable consequence, nothing written about moodaltering drugs can he completely objective. For the decision to use or not to use a drug is a value judgment that imparts an clement of subjectivity from the very beginning. This is especially so when illicit drugs are being investigated. The best the reader can hope for is that the author he us fair and honest as possible. For my part, I have had extensive and predominantly good experiences with LSD and the other major psychedelics.

title: ...Essential Response
description: In view of the damage already done, legislation to aid New York City will have to be designed to avoid charges of being a costly bailout. Federal help should take the form of a guarantee of a new issue of taxable municipal securities. This guarantee should be only long enough and large enough to enable the city, by strict economies and reforms, to balance its operating budget within the next three years. The terms of the Federal guarantee should be stiff enough to discourage other cities from seeking such helpexcept under emergency conditions.

description: Critical Matters. When an author is hit by an unequivocatingly bad review there are various courses open to him. He can also write a letter to the editor of the kind that invariably begins. I ant surprised that the editors assigned my book to Harold Shrike, whose hostility to my theories of Transcendental Macrame Is well known or One wonders whether Harold Shrike actually read my book TM: A Guide to Transcendental Macrame, so full a errors his review

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Holy wars are the bloodiest wars, because the warriors on both sides know that Right marches with them. So we must expect streams of polemical gore to flow this season as those deadliest of enemies, the OperainEnglish and the OperaintheOriginal clans, have at one another. What makes the subject especially inflammable at this time is the arrival of the New York City Opera's new production of Die Meistersinger, which has its premiere on Thursday night in an English translation by John Gutman, the former assistant manager of the Metropolitan. This will be the first attempt at Wagner English by the City Opera (the company's 1950 production of Die Meistersinger was in German). Later on, in the spring, the battle lines will be drawn with rare neatness when the Met offers its traditional Die Meistersinger in Gernian.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: D on't waste any time worrying about Tennessee Williams's Summer and Smoke. It's a fragile play that won't break. Being fragile, it is subject to production mishaps that seem to endanger, even shatter it. Its original Broadway mounting in 1948, which I did not see, was apparently the victim of inept staging; the production had a moderate run but was marked a failure. Four years later director Jose Quintero and actress Geraldine Page turned the tables on those who had too soon lamented the play's passing and displayed plainly, at Circle in the Square, its vibrant, heartbreaking life. Overnight it emerged as one of Williams's finest. It remains that, now that Roundabout has brought it round about again, in spite of a few sledgehammer strokes that would crack it if anything could.

title: The fetus as guinea pig; Is such experimentation an insult to our humanity? Or is it a step toward lifesaving knowledge?
description: I can remember a situation in which a woman entered the hospital with a miscarriage. It was a case of spontaneous abortion, and she came in because she'd been told it was about to happen. The baby, however, was born alive. It weighed less than 500 grams, or just under a poundwhich was below the legal definition of a live birth (this was in Baltimore). No birth certificate was made out, therefore, and it wasn't legally born. Since it was alive, however, it was taken over to the premature unit where it survived for two days. Eventually, being at that very borderline weight, it did die. As it happened, the woman had given birth on Dec. 31; and so the two days of infant care had been during the first two days of the New Year. The parents, when they received the hospital bill. were unable to claim any tax deduction. The father was incensed and he took the position that since there never had been any legally born person'no birth certificate and no death certificatethey couldn't hold him responsible for the costs of treatment. Why should he be made to pay for the care of a child who had never even existed? The hospital, on its own part, was put in the odd position of having spent 48 hours treating an individual who wasn't even, technically speaking, born. They finally did cancel the charges, I believe, and they agreed to forget the whole thing.

Most persuasive have been the staged versions of old forms that combined music and drama, such as The Play of Daniel and The Play of Herod, the medieval liturgical plays so successfully restored by the now defunct New York Pro Musica.

title: One of the few on whom nothing is lost
description: It is high time we celebrated the achievement of Hortense Calisher in short fiction. Of course, she has been recognized before. Of the 13 books she has published, some have moved readers and critics to fulgurant praise. All but one of the 36 stories in this new collection have appeared in book form before,, in her first, The Absence of Angels, in Tale for the Mirror, and in Extreme Magic. These collections alerted critics and readers to her extraordinary recreative powers, her gift for conjuring time and place and the persons who belong properly to them. They revealed her evocative way with words, with phrases that pinned memoryher memoryirrevocably to the page, persuading us perfectly as she transferred it to our own store of experience.

Richmond, with a population of about 250,000, is the leading manufacturing city in Virginia, with the largest tobacco industry in the world, and ranking second in the South in per capita income (Miami is first). Fredericks Sets Mark
description: GREENVILLE, S.C. Oct. 18 (AP)Greg Fredericks of the Philadelphia Pioneer Club established a course record and the University of Tennessee captured the team title today in the sixmile Furman invitation crosscountry track meet. Fredericks time of 28 minutes 57.9 seconds on the Furman golf course was eight seconds better than the record set last year by Neil Cusacks.

title: Eight short Travens

A band of destitute robbers confronts him at a waterhole. Machetes flash. A stone thuds dully on skullbone. A dream of wealth fades like a mirage from the before us.

title: Murray Hill: The Old, the New, the Blue
description: Murray Hill is the territory that lies beyond B. Altman's back door. It is, if there is one, the quintessential New York neighborhood: the past is obliterated and preserved with equal fervor, and the vestiges of the genteel tradition linger until dark, when the street action grows shrill. Its Gilded Age reputation as an unimpeachable address drew any number of Rhinelenders, Havemeyers, Tiffany, Belmonts, Morgansand Polly Adler.

description: Behold the schwa. You know the schwa, of course, or you ought to. The schwa is an unaccented vowel sound indicated in dictionaries by an inverted lower case e. title: A New Militancy in the Church
description: In its historical context, the term church militant evokes the Crusades and Popes seeking to make the Holy Land safe for Christianity; or Pope Julius II at the head of a 16thcentury army, riding to secure the power and the reachof the Papal States. In the context of the old penny catechism, the term means the third element of Roman Catholicism's communion of saints': the union of the faithful on earth struggling to save their souls, so as to pass on to the church suffering (purgatory) and thence to the church triumphant (heaven).

title: Hijacker Sentenced

Hijacking charges were dropped yesterday against 43yearold Francis Page Covey in return for his guilty plea to two lesser chargesgiving malicious false information regarding airplane damage and interfering with a flight crew.

The Knick officials had flown to Los Angeles on Friday morning to try to sign the 39yearold center.

title: James Taylor Appears Alone In Fine Concert at West Point

The 1974 installment proved downright insensitive to the mellow intimacy of his songs. The 1975 version was better, but this observer still had occasion to regret that there weren't more songs with just Mr. Taylor and his guitar Calcine.

Oct. 18A high official at the American Mission to the United Nations charged today that Chile had voted for a draft resolution linking Zionism with racism last night to buy Arab support against charges that Chilean authorities were responsible for torture and other violations of human rights.

title: Up and in in Paris and London
description: The Henry James that many of us keep in our headsa master of difficulty and rare resource, formidable, magisterial, pollysyllabicmakes only occasional appearances in this book, the second volume of letters to be edited by his biographer, Leon Edel. We meet another James here. less imposing, more likable. He is a man in his thirties who can write his dearest Mammy about his pleasure at moving into a Paris apartment with a kitchen full of copper cusseroles. who keeps sending his invalid sister bushels of gossip and gifts of gloves; and who remains, toward his father, a tenderly deferential son. This James is a beginner, and a bit nervous like all beginners. He is eager for fame, quick to bruise, worried about earning his bread. Genius and articulation apart, his letters could almost

Because he is one of the few architects in our history whose name has been more or less familiar to the general public, he is constantly being said to have designed buildings with which he had nothing whatever to do. His name is frequently encountered in realestate advertisements in newspapers and magazines; in almost every the building being advertised will prove on examination not to be by White at all. title: An oddly misshapen novel by a highly accomplished novelist
description: A readeror reviewershould tread carefully whenever a writer decides to leave the turf on which he has established his success. It is too easy to chide him for not doing what he is good at. Admirers of Larry McMurtry will want to extend their close and sympathetic attention to Terms of Endearment, which moves even further than his last novel, All My Friends Are Going to Be Strangers, from the wide expanses and desolate small towns of western Texas, from the ranchers and waitresses and yearning adolescents who inhabit Leaving Cheyenne, Horseman, Pass By (Hud) and The Last Picture Show. They will discover McMurtry trying his hand at what seems, for most of the book's length, to be a kind of comedy of manners centered upon a welltodo widow of fortynine who lives in Houston with a Renoir, a Klee and circle of aging admirers. And for as long as possible they will resist, imagine, their swelling disappointment.

title: Work to Start at Last on Piping Water Out of Round Valley
description: TRENTONAfter two decades of controversy and delay the state has finally completed plans for pumping water from the Round Valley Reservoir in Hunterdon County.

title: Parent and Child
description: My husband and I are keeping our children out ot school, and I am teaching them myself at home. We have four childrenMary, 10; John, 9; James, 7, and Margaret. 4who were all born in New York, where we lived in the same apartment house in Manhattan for eight years. Owing to a temporary lapse of conviction on my part, the three oldest children did attend a public school in St. Louis from September, 1973, to June, 1974. They also attended a small, wonderful village school in England for three months from January to March, 1973, when we visited that country. This means that each of our schoolage children has spent 12 months in school.

title: Deaths

title: Music Notes: A Song Recital With a Whiff of Jazz
description: If there is such a thing as instant fame, baritone Alan Titus knows all about it. He sprang into it resoundingly when Leonard Bernstein cast him in the leading role of his Mass, which rocked the foundations of the Kennedy Center when it opened there in 1971. It was, as they say, a hard act to follow, but Titus went on to operatic roles in various good companies around the country and eventually joined the New York City Opera. He makes his debut atthe Metropolitan in March, but meanwhile, this Wednesday at Hunter College, he will undergo another rite of passage essential to the serious artist: a New York solo recital. It will not, however, he the standard Handel/ Brahms/etc. offering. It will hive a decided whiff of jazz. I was listening to Ravel's ptrino concertos, says Titus and was fascinated by the jazz idiom that creeps into them. I decided to look for sings of Ravel that had this quality, Unfortunately, there

We know that he is taking us upon an excursion into a dying timethe Fascist eraand into a place of his youth, Ferrara in northern Italy, among an illfated people, the Jewish families of the region. But we also know that an artistic intent lies behind the plots of his subtle tales. A

title: Fashion

Some are little more than the kind of dollsized reticules greatgrandmother stashed her mad money in; others are more like the neat pouches skiers wear attached to their belts. They could be used for carrying a couple tokens perhaps, or a latchkey or lipstick. Or they may be worn empty for no good reason except that they're pretty.

title: Charter Revision Proves a Mystery to Many Despite Briefings

description: AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Oct. 18.(AP)Al Hunter ran 43 yards to set up Notre Dame's winning touchdown today as the 15thranked Irish survived a determined challenge by Air Force to win, 3130.

description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 18 A growing body of evidence seems to be accumulating that indicates some resistance by military units of the former antiCommunist Government is persisting in scattered areas of South Vietnam.

title: Sunday Observer
description: This month's Utter Nonsense Award goes to the National Football League for sponsoring a Bicentennial essay competition in which entrants are invited to submit a paper entitled The National Football League's Contribution to American History. With the award, the League wins the following essay.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW; Photojournalism How Does It Stand Up as Art?; GENE THORNTON
description: As a photographer, Gordon Parks is best known for his photo essays in Life, particularly for his rM 1961 essay on the life of a slum boy in Rio de Janiero and his coverage in the sixties of the efforts of black Americans to achieve equality in their own country. Since Parks is black himself, tlikre was something thrilling about these, essays when they first appeared, as if they somehow gave the Public a more intimate and truer view of race and poverty than would the same pictures if taken by a white photographer.

title: Boston University Tops Bucknell
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 18Boston University scored three times in less than nine minutes and went on to a 160 college football victory over Bucknell today. With less than two minutes to play in the first half, a Boston defensive halfback, Bruce Rich, intercepted a pass by Kerry Snow and returned it 28 yards to the Bucknell 22. Four plays later, Tom Floyd, a fullback, ran 3 yards for a touchdown.

title: Lebanese Leaders Meet Amid Renewed Fighting
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 18 (UPI)Scattered shooting and new kidnappings were reported in Beirut today. Traffic was thin and barricades manned by rival gunmen again appeared in several sections of the capital.

title: Hijacking Suspect Escapes
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 18 (UPI)  Marshall Collins 3d, who allegedly attempted to hijack a plane last year, has been recaptured by agents ot the Federal Bureau of Investigation after escaping from a hospital where he was being treated for a skull fracture. M. Collins, 21 years old, was transferred from the Danbury, Conn. Federal prison to eVteran's Hospital in Boston a week ago. He was discovered missing yesterday.

title: Mass transit, little mass
description: OAKLAND, Calif.A few days before the sleek, aluminumskinned trains of the San Francisco Bay Area Rapid Transit system began hauling passengers three years ago last month, Bill R. Stokes, a former newspaperman and publicrelations man who had promoted construction of this system. and went on to become its general manager, took a visitor to a huge window in his fifthfloor office and pointed out the Nimitz Freeway short distance away. As usual in late afternoon, the Nimitz was a glacial stream of bumpertobumper cars and trucks, seemingly going nowhere. What we're trying to do, Stokes said, is to change the way people live, to get them out of their cars and off that freeway.

title: No business like show business
description: The 159 pages of Marcia Keegan's We Can Still Hear Them Clapping (Avon/Flare, $6.95) cover lot of territory. In part, it's a nostalgia trip. These reminiscences of showbusiness oldtimers are mostly about the heyday of the Great White Way and of the American theater when, from Broadway to Punkin Creek, all professional entertainment (except for some shadows on Celluloid) was provided by fleshandblood performers, not by radio waves or magnetic tape: Times Square used to be so beautiful. You could go up the street and you could be happy When people would go to the theater, they would dress in evening clothes and look beautiful.

title: ART VIEW
description: The Czech painter Frantisek Kupka was born in 1871 in Opocno, a small 6ity in eastern Bohemia, and he diedin 1957 in Puteaux; a suburb of Paris where he had lived off and on since 1906. Among certain Parisbased sects specializing in the origin and destiny of abstract art, his name has tong been held sacred, and he is, of course, much esteemed in Prague as the leading Czech Modernist. In this country, although accorded the modest recognition appropriate to his place in the first generation of European abstractionists, his art has had few ardent champion. I have never heardan American painter mention it, favorably or otherwise.

title: Sooners Win 26th, 25 to 3
description: MANHATTAN, Kan, Oct. IS (AP)  Secondranked Oklahoma, its wishbone running game ineffective, resorted to the passing of Steve Davis, the kicking of Tony DiRienzo and a tough defense today for a difficult 253 Big Eight Conference football victory over heavy underdog Kansas State.

title: Administration Will Resist Curbs on Overseas Spying
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The Ford Administration will stanchly resist a Congressional effort io bar the United States Government from undertaking covert intelligence operations or to intrude upon the President's prerogative to order such operations, interviews with high Administration sources disclosed

title: U.S. ArmsSale Rise Stirs Capital Concern
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The emergence of the United States as munitions king of the world and almost daily reports of new arms deals with foreign Governments are generating fresh sense of uneasiness among policy makers and Congressmen over the impact of the weapons on global affairs.

title: One Kind of Hunter: A Good Day in Vermont Without a Kill
description: MONTPELIER, Vermont's capital, is a quiet cluster of staid Yankee public buildings and old clapboard homes. At the end of November last year, the rugged hills surrounding the city were snowswept; the air was crystalline, almost rockhard with the cold. Even on the wooded ridge behind the bronzedomed Capitol building I could hear the occasional muffled thud of a big Remington or Winchester, and down along State Street and School Street there were carloads of men, whole families sometimes, dressed in electricorange caps and trousers and bulky redchecked coats. By evening, a lot of those cars would be back in town with deer slung over the roofs. By week's end there would be 24,000 fewer deer in the state of Vermont.

title: The Limits of Detente
description: LONDON, Oct. 18Reports from Moscow suggest that a most unusual event took place there the other evening. Two government leaders toasting each other actually said something worth sayingand hearing.

title: Food
description: This is a meal from Tuscany that has the virtues of not being expensive, of not requiring any lastminute cooking and of making una buona figura (a good impression). No Tuscan cooks by rote. A little less escarole here, little more garlic therethe meal will still taste good and authentic. Even if you should want to change the soup or dessert, keep the meat and beans together. They've been a traditional combination for centuries: Arista is dish of Renaissance origin; the beans are the staff of Tuscan life. For wine. have Chianti, the classic wine of Tuscany.

A spokesman at Colorado General Hospital in Denver identified the dead as Charles Garrison Jr.. 8 years old, Shawn 6, and Elizabeth, 5.

title: DANCE VIEW; Gerald Arpino Major Fake Or Minor Master?; CLIVE BARNES
description: There is no shortage of moderndance choreographers in this country. First and foremost, of course, there is Martha Graham but there are plenty of others, ranging from Merce Cunningham and Paul Taylor, to Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis, Alvin Ailey, Paul Sanasardo and Erick Hawkins; such varied freelancers as John Butler, Anna Sokolow and Donald McKayie; and such comparatively young choreographers as, say, Twyla Tharp, Manuel Alum and Dan Wagoner. The list is not intended to be exhaustive and is set down in no particular order I am merely trying to give some impression of the range of moderndance choreography, the sheer quantity of it. Why such abundance? Probably because modern dancers tend to be more dedicated, more devoted to their profession, than their classic ballet colleagues. And the reason is terribly simple. Most classic dancers have taken up dance before the age of ten; usually it was a decision made for them by their parents. They may love it, but they did not really choose itexcept in the manner that fiveyearold little Charlie might decide he would like to a fireman when he grows up. Now, modern dancers take up dancing far later, as a vocation, as a calling. Very often they take it up not merely because they want to dance, but because they want to create dances; they want, in fact, to choreograph. A girl in high school learning ballet wants to grow up to be Odette/Odile; a girl in college taking modern dance wants to grow to be Martha Graham.

title: Canadiens, Flyers Play A 22 Tie
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 18 (UPI) Gary Dornhoefer scored a powerplay goal at 15 minutes 38 seconds of the final period tonight as the Philadelphia Flyers remained undefeated by playing the Montreal Canadiens to a 22 tie.

title: In the wake of the assassins
description: The President had vowed, despite the recent attempts upon his life, to stand tall and strong, to refuse to capitulate to the lawless, to show he would not cower in the White House. Yet he had also said that he would take more care. He had promised Senator Howard H. Baker of Tennessee that he would carry in his pocket the lucky buckeye sent to him by the Senator's housekeeper and that he would duck the next time I hear shot rather than look up, as he had done in San Francisco. But on Tuesday, Sept. 30, with the dedication of the new F.B.I. building and a journey later that same day to the Middle West, the most venturesome President in history was venturing out of the White House again. Everyone in Washington and, it seemed, elsewhere was wondering what it would be like on the road with Gerald R. Ford. It would be like this:

The committee voted unanimously Tuesday to reject an offer by Mr. Wallace to computerize the local membership in return for their use in his bid for the Presidency.

title: The Seven Sisters
description: Exxon, Royal Dutch/Shell, Texaco, Gulf, Mobil, BP, Socal. The names have moved across our recent history like the harshly consonanted nouns of some alien language, befuddling our understanding of what would seem to be the relativeiy simple economic process of bringing oil from wellhead to market. In The Seven Sisters, Anthony Sampson. English author of Anatomy of Britain, a history of I.T.T., and other nooks has periormeo one of the higher functions of journalism. He has entered an area of baffling complexity and made sense of it. His title may evoke images of college teas to Americans, but his story is one of institutionalized greed, of amorality, of the abrogation of governmental responsibility, oftentimes of stupidity. It is the story of the cartelization of the earth's most precious commodity.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Perhaps when he started to write his book, THIS CITY IS OURS (Mason/Charter, $7.95), Denis Pitts had an original idea. But the idea was not so otiginal by the time the book was published. It deals with a group of dissidents hijacking a supertanker, bringing it into New York harbor and holding the city up for a tremendous ransom. If the ransom is not paid, a computer will ignite the ship in a colossal explosion that will destroy much of the city and pollute the waters for decades.

title: Have we learned anything new about madness and evil?
description: In an age punctuated by the sound of collapsing orthodoxies, the most recent topplings seem to be happening in what some once took to be the strongest citadel of all: medicine. Who would have predicted a few years back that acupuncture, herbal unguents and meditation would find their way into the physician's kit once more? But then perhaps, as Judith S. Neaman amply documents in Suggestion of the Devil, our theories of disease and insanity and our therapies for them have not really changed much in a milliennium. Centering largely on madness, Neaman argues that ...the psychiatric evaluation of causes of insanity in the Middle Ages bears some remarkable resemblances to that in the 20th century, in both specific and general cases. Her confident and engaginglycomposed trek through several centuries of medical and psychiatric thought is very convincing. We have not learned all that much in a thousand

title: Military Government in Nigeria Begins a Campaign Against Corruption and Is Purging the Civil Service
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 18(Reuters)  Nigeria's military leaders have begun a drive against corruption, which they say was rampant under the former government of Gen. Yakubu Gowon. In a purge of the civil service, nearly 600 people have lost their jobs since the Gowon government was overthrown in July.

title: FILM VIEW
description: To repeat the question for what will be the last time this year: Is the New York Film Festival necessary Well, this one was. This festivalthe 13thwas the best in years. There were no upsets in the event that closed one week ago tonight, but the general level of the entries was high. There even were times when I was glad to have been something I didn't like at all. The festival had its usual quota of stuff to avoid. That includes Miklos Jancso's Elektreia, which I've avoided so far (having seen everything he's done in recent years, rfeel I've earned that modest privilege), and Marguerite Duras's India Song, which I didn't avoid (see below).

Police officials said that live persons drowned in heavy flooding in Manila yesterday, when more than eight inches of rain fell on the city in a 24hour period.

title: Screen: Murky Whodunit:'Black Christmas' Is at Local Theaters
description: "Black Christmas," which landed on local screens a year after its release in Canada where it was produced, is a whodunit that begs the question of why it was made.The answer is hard to come by. This moody depiction of the Christmas slayings of university sorority sisters and their housemother, among others, is as murky as the script, which dotes largely on obscenities that are no more pointed than the violence, dull direction and pedestrian performances.Why this skulking psychopath is driven to making explicitly obscene phone calls in a variety of crazed voices to the girls before dispatching them remains a fairly foggy business. The slightly comic, alcoholic housemother, Marian Waldman, and Margot Kidder, who is also a drunk and as blatantly outspoken as the killer, and Andrea Martin and Lynne Griffin as the other victims, are obvious in perfunctory portrayals.Olivia Hussey, as the pregnant, sole survivor, is properly confused and terrified by the bloody events. But Keir Dullea, the neurotic music student-lover she rejects, does little but rant about the prospective child she doesn't want and smash his piano in a fit of rage.After several witless murders, John Saxon, the film's unflustered, if perplexed, detective, cynically asks a dumb cop, "Don't you think we ought to look into it?" Considering the ersatz tension and plotting, "Black Christmas" is hardly worth the efforts of all concerned.

title: BRUEGGEN PERFORMS BACH FLUTE SONATAS
description: Frans Brueggen is certainly one of the most eloquent and popular advocates of Baroque music performed on original instruments of the 18th century. His concert of Bach flute sonatas at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium Saturday night was especially interesting in this respect, for these familiar works sound entirely different when played on a recorder or a wooden transverse flute without keys as opposed to the more commonly encountered modern keyed metal flute.

title: Jackson Calls Price Issue Only Bar to Energy Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UPI) Senator Henry M. Jackson said today that the price issue was the only remaining oblstacle to agreement by Senate. House conferees on a Congressional energy bill.

title: Americans Adjust to Turkish Command of Bases

Norris, refused to yield them and heated words were exchanged. Within days, the Turkish officer was transferred.

title: Opera: Ponchielli's Gioconda

title: 'Yessongs' Pays Homage to Rock Group
description: "Yessongs," now at the National and RKO 59th Street Twin I theaters, is another of those visually repetitive, aurally hyperactive documentary valentines to a rock group.In this case, it is a group called Yes, which is worth remembering, because there is little else in this film to distinguish it from its predecessors.Here the group, which is not without talent, simply goes from one number to another performed at several concerts where the audiences cheer in quadraphonic sound and are seen occasionally on poorly matched film of quality ranging from blurry to downright pointillist.Other than providing closeups of the performers, the film makes no effort to add any dimension to their work. It seeks neither to inform, nor reveal character nor expand the vocabulary of film. Its true purpose seems to be an exploration of the limits of revenue derivable from concert appearances.It is really, an illustrated recording that has tightly circumscribed its appeal to those who already know and 1ike the music of Yes.The movie, which runs about 75 minutes, is accompanied by a short called "Death of a Red Planet." This film by Dale Pelton is said to be the first to use ion lasers to create images. The technique may be new, but the colorful viscous images and the sense of extraterrestrial excursion are not.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
. and Politics
description: The House bill in conference would set a ceiling price of $7.50 per barrel for most new oil, a sharply rolledback figure which the Administration rejects. Even inside the Capitol, a study by the Senate Budget Committee has shown that such a rollback would require vastly increased oil imports from abroad, and the immediate economic advantages would be wiped out by 1980 as the highercost imported oil commanded an ever larger share of the American market. A stronger case can be made for a $9 ceiling on new oil with controls on old oil phased out over 66 months. According to the Senate Budget Committee such a plan would add 1.4 per rent to inflation and raise unemployment by 0.4 per centhut these estimates are significantly less on both counts than the Administration's various alternatives.

Banks Make Intensive Efforts To Avert REIT Loan Losses
description: The nation's largest banks are making intensive efforts to avert losing millions of dollars lent to the onceattractive realestate investment trusts, many of which are now in severe financial trouble.

title: 3 Sought in Death of Girl, 7 PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 (AP)
description: The police searched today for three men, believed to belong to a motorcycle gang, who shot a 7yearold girl to death in her father's arms outside their suburban home. The girl, Ann Mauro, was shot by three men last night after her father, Joseph Mauro, 30, swept her Into his arms to protect her, according to Police Chief Paul Coleman of Darby Borough.

title: COMPLAINTS AIRED ABOUT PHYSICIANS
description: ALBANY, Oct. 19 (AP)The State Health Department said today that its newly created Board for Professional Medical Conduct had received 60 complaints against physicians since Sept. 1.

title: A Plan for CUNY
description: The proposals of Chancellor Robert J. Kibbee adjust the operations of the City University to what are certain to be serious longterm budgetary constraints represent a rational approach to the problem. At the heart of Dr Kibbee's outline for drastic changes in financing, admissions, academic priorities, staffing and calendar is the determination that CUNY must be preserved as a quality institution of higher learningand can be, despite the budgetary squeeze.

title: PANEL ON RIGHTS DUBIOUS ON SOVIET
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 19An unofficial international panel today completed three days of hearings on the state of human rights in the Soviet Union by concluding that there was strong reason to doubt that Moscow was observing international agreements on human rights.

title: Flyers Down Wings, 51; Unbeaten Streak at 20
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 (AP)The Philadelphia Flyers extended their regularseason unbeaten streak to 20 games over two seasons tonight by defeating the Detroit Red Wings, 51, in the National Hockey League.

title: Israeli Air Strike in 4th Day
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 19 (AP)Irael's national air carrier, El Al, was strikebound for the fourth day today. A company, spokesman said the dispute had already cost $2million and forced 9,000 passengers to be transferred to other airlines.

Learn was the Dallas Cowboys against whom Green Bay had won seven of eight decisions, including two championship games in which Starr quarterbacked the Pack to victory

title: 3 DEATHS ARE LAID TO A 2.5INCH RAIN

title: Personal Finance

The chances of such a disability are substantially greater than the chances of deathabout three times greater at age 30, twoandahalf times greater at age 40 and two times greater at age 50.

title: Ivy League Race Tightens As Brown Settles for a Tie
description: Brown's coach, John Anderson, had no doubts yesterday that he did the proper thing 24 hours earlier by ordering an extrapoint kick to tie Dartmouth. 1010, instead of going for a 2point conversion with 8 minutes remaining in the game.

title: Life Is a Gimmick, Sparky Says
description: BOSTON, Oct. 19People named Rose and Morgan and Bench were pounding line drives in!o big fishnets hung from the cciling of Cousens Gymnitsium at Tufts University in suburban Medford. while people named Gullett and Nolan and Borbon took turns throwing from portable pitching mound on the Tartan running track. People named Driessen and Crowley and Rettenmund also got to hit, Pat Darcy and Rav,.17 Eastwick and Clay Carroll stretched their pitching muscles and everybody who felt like it took wind sprints up and down straightway. Thus, the Cincinnati Reds whiled away a rainy Sabbath, leaving to Bowie Kuhn and his television pro erammers to tell them when, ever, Sports of The Timesthey would resume their joust with the Boston Red Sox for the national rounders championship. When that word came down, it was vague and indecisive. If the nor'eastern that had lashed this coast since Friday night were to blow itself out and Fenway Park could be sponged dry in time, they would go on the air at 8:30 P.M. tomorrow, replacing a movie called The U.F.O. Incident and bucking Monday night football on one network, All in the Family on another.

title: Society Votes to Admit Men
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 191 (UPI)  Mortar Board, Inc., a national wornen's bonor society, tentatively voted this weekend to admit men. The 60yearold society faced the possibility of a cutoff of Federal funds because it was not in compliance with regulations banning discrimination in federally funded programs. The delegates were students from 167 colleges.

title: China to Stress Steel
description: TOKYO, Oct. 19 (UPI)China's new fiveyear plan will give priority to agriculture and the steel industry, a Chinese leader said today. Japan's Kyodo news service quoted Tan Chenlin, deputy chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, as having said that an increase in the production of foods and of iron and steel would form the basis of the plan, which will cover the years 1976 to 1980.

title: Lack of Investigation On Montoya's Taxes Is Defended by I.R.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19The Internal Revenue Service said today that it had acted properly in not investigating the tax records of Senator Joseph M. Montoya, Democrat of New Mexico, who heads the subcommittee that oversees the I.R.S.

title: Criticism in U.S.
description: Leaders of major Jewish organizations in the United States yesterday sharply condemned the resolution adopted Friday by the United Nations committee equating Zionism with racial discrimination.

title: DR. OTTO G. LELLEP, ENGINEER, INVENTOR
description: Dr. Otto G. Lellep, a retired mining and metallurgical engineer, who specialized in energyefficient furnace construction design and held patents in his field, died Saturday in Fort Meyers, Fla., where he lived. He was 82 years old.

title: Bratip
30 Bretons Held in France
description: RENNES, France, Oct. 19 (Reuters)About 30 people believed to he members of Breton separatist movements were detained over the weekend, the police said today. The detentions follow three bomb attacks on homes of legislators in northwestern France.

title: Smashing of a Plot Reported by Dahomey
description: COTONOU, Dahomey, Oct. 19 (Agence France Presse)Dahomeyan security forces yesterday smashed a plot to overthrow the military Government and reinstate former President Emile  Derlin Zinsou, who was ousted in 1969, the Government of this small west African country announced last night.

title: 2 U.S. Agencies Join U.F.O. Conference
description: FORT SMITH, Ark., Oct. 19After 28 years of reports of flying saucers and other unidentified flying objects (UFO's). two agencies of the Federal Government have officially participated in an international conference dealing with the subject.

title: SATELLITE SURVEY IS STUDIED IN U. N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19A successful American experimental program using space platforms to survey the earth for mineral resources and signs of environmental changes is being watched with increasing interest and some anxiety, in foreign countries. And last week a United Nations body heard proposals to put the project under international control.

title: Arms Lobby Relies on Varied Sources, Including Liberals Seeking to ProtectWorkers

Hayes entered Congress last January he sought to concentrate his legislative efforts on problems of the economy and the control of water pollution, yet found himself embroiled in a totally unexpected areathe politics of munitions.

title: 7 of 25 ExG.O.P. Assemblymen Seek Comebacks
description: TRENTON, Oct. 19  Only seven of the 25 incumbent Republican legislators who were swept out of office two years ago by the Democratic election victory of Governor Byrne are attempting political comebacks in next month's Assembly election.

title: Double Agent
description: One day last summer two men knocked on the door of James Jelicks's home in Barnegat, N. J. The visitors, Mr. Jelicks says, were sent by the Mafia. They had tracked him because he was a former undercover informer and Witness for the Federal Government. Under threats that his family would be harmed, the 31yearold Mr. Jelicks said that he was forced to play a major role in a conspiracy to discredit Federal investigations of organized crime activities in Northern New Jersey.

With the musicians deployed in front of a; high, broad wall that has been taken down to the original brick and softly lit, this is one of the most pleasant settings for jazz in town.

title: No Link to Hoffa Found
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 19 (AP) Sheriff's detectives and Federal agents examined fingerprints of James R. Hoffa today against parts of a human body found in a dump near here, but there was no apparent connection. Partial fingerprints from Mr. Hoffa were sent to Tucson Thursday but did not match those that could he salvaged from two hands found in landfill Wednesday. More detailed prints arrived from Washington, hut no link was developed, a sheriff's spokesman said. Mr. Hoffa disappeared July 31.

title: Cambodia's Ordeal

They brought the outside world news of the ordeal imposed upon all who lived in Cambodia's cities, the forced eviction into the countryside regardless of age, sex or even state of health. Now further details of Communist Cambodia's transformation have come from Prince Norodom Sihanouk's entourage, following the visit Cambodia's nominal head of state was allowed to make to Phnom Penh last month.

title: Pathos and Wit Light Up 'Hester St.'
description: There is nothing very original about "Hester Street" except its loveliness.Literally, it is a small movie about the struggles and transformations of the Jews who settled in the Lower East Side and tried to reconcile the ordered values they brought along with the unmarked opportunities they found.The immigrant theme, with its anecdotes, its incongruities, its mixture of comedy and pathos, has been played through any number of stories, novels, memoirs, films. How, then, can this film be so good?Partly, it is because movies are performances as well as creations. The effect of seeing "Hester Street" is that of seeing a familiar play"A Midsummer Night's Dream" as done by Peter Brook or "The Wild Duck" as done by Sweden's Royal Dramatic Theaterlit up by an intent and flowering mind.Performance doesn't refer simply to the acting, though the cast of "Hester Street," which opened yesterday at the Plaza Theater, is superlative, and Carol Kane in the starring role is extraordinary. It refers to the whole framing of the picture by Joan Micklin Silver, its author and director: the rhythms, the acute selection of incident and character."Hester Street" tells of the comic and painful Americanization of Jake and Gitl, an immigrant couple from Russia. In the opening scenes Jake, who has come over alone, is adapting whole-heartedly although with an aim that is slightly askew. Played with vigor and humor by Steven Keats, Jake has found himself a tailoring job, a whole bed for himselfactually, he confesses to a friend, it's a couch, but he's still ahead of others who have to double upand a girlfriend.But then Gitl arrives and brings with her not only hideous complications for Jake's love life, but also the dress, the bearing, the language and the customs of the Russian ghetto that Jake has so exuberantly put behind.They settle in: Jake, Gitl, their little boy, and a lodger. The lodger is a former rabbinical student named Bernstein who went into tailoring because he couldn't keep his mind off women, but nonetheless spends his evenings studying.It is a series of battles, Jake pushing his wife to give up her shawls, her hair-covering, her Yiddish; her making adjustments at her own pace, and far too slowly for him. The marriage founders; Jake gets a divorce, financed by his girlfriend, and marries her. And Gitl in a beautiful reversal that is neither sudden nor unprepared, but flows out of her own slowly blossoming strength, comes out ahead.The film is constructed on a series of sharp, brief incidents. There is Jake at Ellis Island meeting Gitl, who is arrayed  clothes, bundles, bagslike a whole history of the Diaspora. "For what purpose are you bringing this woman in?" an official asks Jake. "For the purpose she's my wife," he answers in a near-howl.There is the owner of the tailor shop gloating at Bernstein's struggle with the unaccustomed manual work. "The peddler becomes the boss and the Yeshiva student sits by the sewing machine," he chortles. "Some country."And in the lodgings, when Jake has stormed out in one of his rages, Bernstein and Gitl sit in mutual misery. "When we come over here," he tells her, "we say 'Goodbye, Lord, I'm going to America.'"The camerawork, in black and white, is deliberately restrained, but there is a moment of pure virtuosity. The scene is in the country, the camera points through leaves at the sun, a piano rag jangles on the soundtrack, and suddenly the whole comically tormented group bursts through the trees and the glare for a picnic.Some picnic. Jake determinedly plays American ball with his son; Gitl and Bernstein droop in Old Country poses against a tree. There is a pause in the athletics. "Jake," she asksnever having been past Delancey Street"are there any gentiles in America?"Beyond all the details there is the magnificent performance of Carol Kane as Gitl. Big-eyed, scared and inaudible at first, a spark of allure pops out here, a spark of anger there, until by the end of the picture she is a triumphant bonfire. Miss Kane manages the high acting feat of seeming to change size physically, expanding and shrinking as she is happy or miserable.There is a defect in the picture, although it is not a major one. The street scenes are too fully packed with color: too many peddlers, too many mischievous children, too many barrows. It's like a stage set. Even the dresses hanging on racks seem instructed in their parts.But it is the only point at which Mrs. Silver's fine balance between realism and fable slips a bit into storyteller artifice. For the rest, "Hester Street" is an unconditionally happy achievement.

description: CONWAY, Ark., Oct. 19 (AP)While New York City totters on the brink of financial disaster, this Central Arkansas town of 18,500 has the problem of too much money.
