description: AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 19Some of the oncelong hair is thinning now, and corduroy sport coats have replaced denim jackets, but the band of aging young radicals who gathered here this weekend was still determined to change the system, though perhaps from within.

title: Complaints Flood Bureauin Newark On Homework
description: NEWARK  The advertisement in the newspaper says: HOMEWORK. Join our cooperative mailing association Work at home. Your own hours. Make up to $500 per week. Interested parties send stamped, selfaddressed envelopes to Afco. P.O. Box 5068F, Newark, N. J.

title: Digging Out the News in Soviet Bloc Is Not Any Easier Under Detente
description: BELGRADE. Yugoslavia, Oct. 19Despite the smooth treatment Western newsmen have generally been accorded in Eastern Europe since dtentel became a diplomatic catchword, correspondents are finding direct coverage of the workings of Communist power almost as difficult as in cold war days.

title: STATE ACTS TODAY ON CITY FINANCES; NEW CUTS LIKELY
description: The State Emergency Financial Control Board's final action today on Mayor Beame's threeyear austerity plan reportedly will include measures to shave the construction budget even further than the Mayor intends and safeguards to see that the city lives up to the details of its new economy vows.

title: City Slide Show Flashes Back to 1776
description: Click! A British gunboat appears in the Bay. Click! Another gunboat. Abruptly, there is an ominous armada facing the cluster of small brick and wood buildings that crowd the lower tip of Manhattan.

title: A Torah Lost in the Holocaust Carried Again by Czech Rabbi
description: A 200yearold torah, one or, 1,564 scrolls desecrated during the Nazi occupation of Czechoslovakia end lost for nearly

title: ISLAND REJOICES AS NAVY DEPARTS
description: CULEBRA, P.R., Oct. 19Dancing in the town plaza, speeches by visiting dignitaries and a beach picnic in this island municipality marked the end yesterday of a fiveyear struggle to get the Navy to stop using the island as a target area.

title: American Steel Executives Expect Recovery to Start
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 19American steel executives are optimistic that a recent modest rise in steel demand is signaling the start of a recovery from the industry's worldwide recession.

title: In Memoriam
description: COLELoeb, Oct. 20, 1971 In memory of a gentle man, loved and ?? by his family and friends.

title: STEEL IMPORTERS HAIL REBATE MOVE
description: Steel importers yesterday said they welcomed a decision by the Treasury that European rebates of valueadded taxes on exported steel did not constitute a subsidy.

title: OFFICIAL IN NEWARK RESIGNS UNDER FIRE
description: NEWARK, Oct. 20John J. Grexa, the city's director of finance, submitted a brief letter of resignation today in the wake of a City Council investigation into three controversial actions he took since assuming the post on June 30 of last year.

title: SCHLESINGER FINDS ARMS CUT SAVAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that the House Appropriation Committee had made deep, savage and arbitrary cuts in the defense budget, which, if not reversed by the Senate, would have a severe effect upon the nation's defense posture.

title: The Mourning After a Jet Lag
description: Tha Jets and theft fans knew what Coach Charley Winner was talking about yesterday.

title: SOYBEAN RISE CUT BY PROFIT TAKING
description: Profit taking cut sharply into early gains in the prices of soybean futures, but those of wheat, corn and oats remained strong right up to the final bell on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. Soybean meal and soybean oil prices were irregular at the finish.

title: ECONOMIC HEARING A HEATED DEBATE
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 20  Economists, labor and civil rights leaders, politicians and unemployed workers clashed sharply here today over economic philosophy and policies, and over Federal aid to New York City, at the first of a series of hearings around the country by the SenateHouse Joint Economic Committee.

title: President, Suffering Head Cold, Cancels Public Activity to Rest
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20President Ford, described as feverish with a sinus infection and a persistent head cold canceled his public activities today to rest in the White House.

title: Restless, Bored Players Waiting It Out
description: BOSTON, Oct. 20Tom Yawkey the 72 year old owner of the Bostorr Red Sox who often plays pepper games at Fenway Park when it's dry, was in the visiting clubhouse today meeting some of the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Kremlin Worries About Grain, But Shelves at Bakers Are Full
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 20In the vake of bad harvest, the first signs have appeared indicating Government concern over the prospect of a grain shortage.

title: Papp Drops 5Play Series at Booth
description: Joseph Papp, producerfounder of the New York Shakespeare Festival, announced yesterday that he was discontinuing his season of five new plays by contemporary American playwrights at the Booth Theater because of catastrophic financial difficulties.

title: STATE UNIT BACKS CITY BUDGET PLAN, ORDERS NEW CUTS
description: The state's Emergency Financial Control Board last night approved a threeyear austerity plan for the city that Will mean more than $700million in budget cuts and additional thousands of layoffs whose total has not yet been determined.

title: Washington Confidential
description: Gerald Ford's diary:

title: Recital
description: On Oct. 18. 1925, Elena Gerhardt, the famed German lieder singer, gave a recital of Brahms and Schubert songs in New York's Aeolian Hall. Her accompanist on that occasion was a 24yearold pianist named Carroll Hollister, who was making his New York debut.

title: Giants Top Bills, 1714, On Kick With 0:06 Left
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 20A successful 37yard field goal by George Hunt with six seconds left in the game was the nexttolast play and the decisive one here tonight as the New York Giantsthose poor bedraggled Giantspulled off a major upset by defeating the unbeaten Buffalo Bills, 1714. before stunned crowd of 79,518 in Rich Stadium.

title: Quarterly Output Up 11%, Fastest Rate in 20 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The economic recovery in the JulySeptember quarter was even fasterpaced than the experts had expected, Commerce Department figures disclosed today.

title: A CLASH ON GOLAN REPORTED BY SYRIA
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 20The Damascus Radio announced tonight that Syrian troops clashed with an Israeli patrol on the Golan Heights this morning, wounding four enemy soldiers.

title: Du Pont 3dQuarter Earnings Off 28%; Carbide Net Down 49.9%
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, Inc., reported yesterday a decline of 28.1 per cent in thirdquarter net income, although sales edged ahead by 1.1 per cent.

title: Unmanned Soviet Spacecraft Approach Venus
description: As two Soviet spacecratt approach Venus for landings expected this week, preparations are believed to be under way for a new manned flight in earth orbit.

title: Kissinger Confers With Chou's Deputy In Peking 4 Hours
description: PEKING, Oct. 20 (Reuters)Secretary of State Kissinger reviewed the international situation with Chinese leaders here today, but the substance of his talks remained secret.

title: A Summary of the Actions Taken by the Supreme Court Justices
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Kenyatta Says Stability Is Key to Kenya's Progress
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 20 (Reuters)President Jomo Kenyatta today declared that political stability was the vital foundation for human progress and fulfilment in Kenya.

title: Planters Plats Move To Benton & Bowles
description: Here's a nutty one. Benton & Bowles has just been named the agency for Planters. Nut products, peanut oil and peanut butter.

title: Jockeys Don Robes of Academe For Seminar on Thoroughbreds
description: Four Belmont Park jockeys Angel Cordero Jr., Mike Hole, Jose Amy and Vincent (Jimbo) Bracciale  went to college last night, but not as students. They were guest lecturers. The ocAt the casion was the fourth in a series Race of five seminars, Tracks titled Thoroughbred Racing, at the New School for Social Research. The series ends next Tuesday when the them is The RaceIts Conduct and Control. The faculty then will be headed by Nathaniel J. (Bud) Hyland, one of Belmont's three stewards.

title: SAIGON FOREIGNERS MAY BE EVACUATED
description: GENEVA, Oct. 20Americans and other foreigners who were stranded in South Vietnam when it was overrun by Communist troops are to be repatriated shortly, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees announced today.

title: ATKINSON IS FETED BY JOURNALISTS HERE
description: Brooks Atkinson, the former drama critic of The New York Times, was honored last night by the Society of the Silurians for continued distinguished journalistic achievement over more than 25 years.

title: RABBI NUTA SHAINBERG
description: Rabbi Nuta Shainberg, spiritual director of the First Warshauer Congregation on the Lower East Side since 1947, died Saturday in Beth Israel Hospital.

title: A Renort on Expulsion
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 20The Copenhagen newspaper Berlingske Tidende said today that the Soviet Union had reportedly decided to expel Andrei Sakharov. It said the report came from what it described as a well informed source on an international panel that organized three days of hearings here last week on the stateo human rights in the Soviet Union.

title: HARRIS ENDORSED BY UNION LEADER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Fred Harris's campaign for the Presidency won its first support within the Democratic establishment today from George Hard, president of the 600,000member Service Employes International Union.

title: Shoulder to Shoulder
description: [Shoulder to Shoulder, a sixpart Masterpiece Theatre presentation focusing on the women'ssuffrage movement in England, begins Sunday, Oct 5, on most PBS stations. To supplement your viewing of the series, we are providing the following background information. See Sports and Specials column in the program section for time and channels.Ed.]

title: Test For Discovering Defects in Fetus Called Safe
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 20The procedure called amniocentesis for discovering defects in babies developing in the womb is both safe and accurate, according to scientists who took part in a major Governmentsponsored study.

title: HIGH COURT RULES PUPIL SPANKINGS ARE PERMISSIBLE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The Supreme Court ruled today that states may permit school teachers to spank misbehaving students, even over the objections of parents, as long as the teachers use lesser punishment when appropriate and also give the children some procedural safeguardssuch as warning them ahead of time what misbehavior warrants a spanking.

title: The Common Denominator at Coma Trial Is Youth
description: MORRISTOWN, Oct, 20They seem so young to be arguing about death, an observer remarked at the opening of the Karen Quinlan hearing at the historic Morris County Courthouse here today.

title: U.S. Said to Assure Israel Of Delay in Arms to Egypt
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The United States has reportedly assured Israel that although President Anwar elSadat of Egypt will probably bring a shopping list of American military equipment to Washington next week, there are no current plans to sell arms to Egypt for at least a year.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 2 Held in Florida in Upstate Killing

title: Standout U.S. Day: 12 Gold Medals Won
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 20 (UPI)  The United States wAn six gold medals today to end the track and field competition at the PanAmerican Games with 19 top awards, while the swimming and diving stars bagged six of seven events.

title: Justices to Weigh Curbs On Pornography Centers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The Supreme Court took up today the question of just what a city can do to prevent the development of a highly concentrated cluster of shops and theaters that specialize in socalled adult, or pornographic, materials.

title: School Football
description: LOCAL

title: Philadelphia Fire Contained
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 (AP) A sixalarm fire raged out of control for three and a half hours today at th Gulf Oil Company refinery, the site of an August blaze that killed eight firemen. There were no injuries.

title: U. S. AND RUSSIA AGREE ON 5 YEARS OF GRAIN EXPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The White House announced today a fiveyear agreement with the Soviet Union, effective next Oct. 1, under which the Russians would buy six to eight million tons of American grain a year.

title: HOUSE REJECTS BILL ON WOMEN'S RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI) The House rejected today a bill that would have authorized $10million for a national conference on women's rights.

title: Notes on People
description: The search for a new head of the Federal Aviation Administration, which began months before Alexander P. Butterfield's resignation last March, has ended with President Ford's nomination of John L. McLucas, Secretary of the Air Force since 1973. Dr. McLucas, a 55yearold physicist who was appointed Air Force Under Secretary soon after Richard M. Nixon's inauguration in 1969, had previously served in the State Department and as NATO assistant secretary general for scientific affairs. A native of North Carolina, he received his Ph.D. from Penn State University and was president of the Mitre Corporation, a research organization in Bedford, Mass.

title: Laver Defeats Ashe 20th Time, 64, 64
description: HILTON HEAD, S. C., Oct. 20Rod Laver continued his mastery over Arthur Ashe today with a 64, 64 triumph at the start of the $135,000, eightpiayer World Invitation tennis tournament. The 37yearold Australian raced to a 40 lead in the first set and to 51 in the second. It was his 20th victory in their 22 matches.

title: River Dell Teachers End 15Day Strike With Raise of 5S%
description: ORADELL, Oct. 20The River Dell Board of Education and the River Dell Education Association reached agreement on a new contract this morning shortly before striking teachers had to decide whether to go back to work or to jail for 10 days.

title: TAX AUDIT CHARGES DENIED BY MONTOYA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI) Senator Joseph M. Montoya, the New Mexico Democrat, chnrged today that overzcalnus persons in the Internal venuc Service were leaking false information to the press in retaliation against his attemps to insure fair treatment for taxpayers.

title: City Slickers Meet Country Cousins And All Find They Are Both Alike
description: GREENWICH, N. Y.A lawyer and his family from Brooklyn spent the weekend with a dairy farmer and his family here, and by the time it was over, some preconceived notions about city slickers and country bumpkins had evaporated into the crisp Washington county autumn air.

description: READY AND WAITING

title: PUPILS FACE RISE IN TRANSIT FARES
description: The Board of Education announced new economies yesterday that will, among other things, make traveling to and from school more costly to the 358,000 pupils who ride public buses and subways.

title: Claire Egtvedt of Boeing, Developer of B17, Is Dead
description: Claire L. Egtvedt, the Boeing engineer who developed the B17 Flying Fortress of World War II and headed the company for more than 30 years, died Sunday night at his home in Seattle. He was 83 years old.

title: Conference Debates the Limiting of Economic Growth to Conserve Resources
description: WOODLANDS, Tex., Oct. 20 Are economic growth and the steady increase in population about to clash catastrophically with the finite limits of world resources? Or, conversely, is mankind heading toward a golden age of leisure, when such problems will be behind it?

title: Reagan Is Backed by Conservatives
description: Conservative party leaders declared yesterday that they would support Ronald Reagan over President Ford for the Republican nomination and that it Mr. Ford was named they would oppose endorsement of him in the 1976 general election if Vice President Rockefeller was his running mate.

description: Morning

title: U.S. List of Arms Producers and Exporters Shows More Than 1,000 Concerns!
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 Making and selling munitions to foreign armies is so lucrative that more than 1,000 American companies are legally engaged in either producing or exporting weapons.

title: Doctor Tells Court He'd Refuse to Let Woman in Coma Die
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 20 The physician who has cared for Karen Anne Quinlan for the six months she has been in a coma said today he would refuse to obey a court order to turn off a mechanical respirator that is supporting her breathing.

title: Spain, at U. N., Warns of Danger of March in Sahara
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20Spain called on the Security Council today to appeal urgently to Morocco to refrain from carrying out planned march by 350,000 civilians into disputed Sahara territory.

title: Scotto Blames Poor Rail Links For Maritime Decline Here
description: Anthony M. Scotto, the Brooklyn longshore union leader, told a State Senate Labor Committee here yesterday that inferior rail transportation had been a major factor in the decline of the maritime industry in both the Port of New York and in the Great Lakes.

title: Satyajit Ray's Films Take New Directions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Satyajit Ray's film about the Bengal famine of 1943, in which 5 million people died, ends with a spectral procession of numberless starvation victims stumbling across a suddenly darkened landscape.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20 (UPI)Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California said today that New York City's financial crisis was not a local but an international problem.

title: HIGH COURT TO RULE ON BANK LAWSUITS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a bank may be sued for alleged violations of Federal securities laws in locations other than its home city.

title: Britain's Health Service To Undergo Investigation
description: LONDON, Oct. 20A series of disputessome financial and some intensely ideologicalforced Prime Minister Harold Wilson today to order an investigation of the National Health Service.

title: Haber Will Mediate Dispute of Drivers And 2 Newspapers
description: The appointment of Herbert L. Haber as mediator in the contract dispute between the Newspaper Deliverers Union and The Daily News and The New York Times was announced yesterday by Paul Yager, regional director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

description: BASEBALL

title: JOHN B. COTTRELL
description: PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 20John B. Cottrell Jr., a retired teacher and former sixterm representative in the Maine Legislature, died here yesterday in the Maine Medical Center. He was 77 years old.

title: 7 A.B.A. Clubs Apply to N.B.A.
description: Seven more American Basketball Association teams, in a surprise move, applied yesterday for membership in the National Basketball Association, commencing with the 197677 season. They took the action in individual telegrams to Larry O'Brien, the N.B.A. commissioner.

title: Series Reset Tonight
description: BOSTON, Oct. 20For the third straight time, the sixth game of the World Series was postponed today by the storm that has been soaking the Northeast since Friday. But the go signal was hoisted for tomorrow night, when Luis Tiant will try to keep the Cincinnati Reds from finally subduing the Boston Red Sox, the best mudders in the American League.

title: General Foods Net Climbs 23.8% on a 14% Sales Gain
description: The General Foods Corporation reported yesterday earnings gains of 23.8 per cent for the three months ended Sept. 27 and 20 per cent for the fiscal halfyear period over the depressed levels of the previous year.

title: 2 Charged With Plotting to Kill Ford Sept. 5 in Sacramento
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20 (UPI) Two men in custody in Santa Barbara, Calif., were indicted today by a grand jury on charges of conspiring to assassinate President Ford last Sept. 5 in Sacramento, Calif., by shooting him at the State Capitol after blowing up street sewers as a diversion.

description: Using a bouquet of odors generated by bark beetles and by the elm trees on which they are preying, scientists have tested an inexpensive method for fighting the blight that has killed a large percentage of American elms.

description: Canarsie High School has finally won its neighborhood football championship. After four years of trying, the Chiefs defeated their Brooklyn neighborhood rival, South Shore. 320. yesterday and thereby claimed the socalled Bragging Rights Trophy.

title: U.S. URGED TO STUDY SCHOOL INTEGRATION
description: Theodore M Black, Chancellor of the State Board of Regents, called yesterday for a nationwide study by the Federal Government to determine whether minority children benefitted educationally from attending integrated schools.

description: A scramble appears to ne developing among three different groups of creditors of the W. T. Grant Company over which has the prior claim on liens on inventory of the giant retail chain.

description: Because one man's proposal is another man's poison in the volatile areas of housing reform and rent policy here, suggestions to revitalize New York's depressed housing picture are often more contradictory than comolementary.

description: United States Attorney Paul J. Curran moved in Federal Court here yesterday to block an order requiring that telephone subscribers be alerted that their toll records had been requested by investigative bodies.

description: Rubin (Hurricane) Carter and John Artis are expected to appeal formally this week to Governor Byrne for pardons or some form of executive clemency in their 1967 triplemurder conviction.

Hugo Zacchini, 77, Dies; First Human Cannonball
description: Hugo Zacchini, a circus performer who originated the human cannonball act in which he was catapulted from a cannon 200 feet into a net, died yesterday of a stroke in San Bernardino, Calif. He was 77 years old.

title: What Price Luxury?
description: In a report issued last spring a Federal interagency task force made a preliminary finding that unless new scientific evidence is found to remove the cause for concern, some restrictions on the use of fluorocarbons would be advisable. More recently, Dr. Warren R. Muir, cochairman of that panel, warned a subcommittee the Senate Committee on Aeronautical and Space Sciences that continuing experiments reinforce rather than diminish that concern.

title: Burglars Fail to Open Cabinet In Ford Campaign Headquarters
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Burglars tried without success over the weekend to pry open locked file cabinet in an office at President Ford's downtown campaign headquarters here, campaign official said today.

title: BANK OF AMERICA IS SUED IN THEFT
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20The Bank of America has been sued for $6million by three depositors for alleged negligence in the theft from a London branch of the bank of what they claim was $15million.

title: COLORS MAY GUIDE RIDERS ON SUBWAY
description: Red trains. Blue trains. Yellow trains. Different colors for different subway lines to make identification easier and to brighten the drab underground system. And timetables for subway riders, too.

description: TRENTON, Oct. 20  Ann Klein, Commissioner of the State Department of Institutions and Agencies, is prepared to eliminate all reimbursement for optional Medicaid services in New Jersey, including dentistry, optometry, and podiatry reported today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The White House announced a fiveyear accord with the Soviet Union, effective year from now, under which the Russians would buy six to eight million tons of American grain a year. Also, President Ford lifted a twomonth embargo on further grain sales to the Russians this year. The White House further announced a letter of intent, signed in Moscow, to buy up to 200,000 barrels of Russian oil a day. [Page 1, Column 1.]

Lipsig, a New York trial lawyer, filed a multi milliondollar class action suit here yesterday against the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, accusing the huge New York bank of withholding information about the Urban Development Corporation in a S200million bond sale two years ago.

description: Chou Enlai is very ill and I think he's dying, Henry Kissinger told some Canadian friends in Ottawa the other day when he thought he was speaking privately, but was actually being overheard by a reporter.

title: Willie Davis Sent To Padres by Cards
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 20 (AP)  The St. Louis Cardinals have traded Willie Davis, an outfielder to the San Diego Padress in exchange for Dick Sharon, also an outfielder, the club announced today.

title: Legislature Chides Ronan On Gift From Rockefeller
description: TRENTON, Oct. 20A special legislative committee concluded today that Dr. William J. Ronan did not use good judgment in failing to disclose a $625,000 gift from Vice President Rockefeller at the time of his appointment as chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey last year.

Ronan did not use good judgment in failing to disclose a $625,000 gift from Vice President Rockefeller at the time of his appointment as chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey last year.

title: Steel Production Fell 1.4% in Week To 2,108,000 Tons
description: Steel production for the week ended Oct. 18 slipped by 1.4 per cent to 2,108,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This lowered the production index to 86.4 from 87.6 in the preceding week when production reached 2,138,000 tons.

title: Dividends
TV: The Tribal Eye
description: Last Wednesday, The Tribal Eye, a series of seven hours produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation in association with Warner Brothers TV, made its debut on public television with Crooked Beak of Heaven, a survey of the art and rituals of some of America's Northwest Coast Indians. Tomorrow at 8 P.M., the series continues with Behind the Mask, a portrait of the Dogon people of Africa's Mali and their ceremonial wood carvings.

title: Bank of America Sued
description: The Bank of America has been sued for $6million by three depositors for alleged negligence in a theft from a London branch of the bank. Page 62.

title: Ford Is Reported Ready To Accept Plan to Aid City
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 President Ford would reluctantly sign legislation to ease New York City's fiscal crisis provided that it contained the stringent restrictions that Congress is likely to insist upon, a high Administration official said today.

title: Monster Madness Revives DraculaIn Annotated Form
description: Blood red, the book Jacket shows an ominous turreted castle on an abrupt mountain, just below the title: The Annotated Dracula.

title: Indian Gas Plant Is Based on Cow Dung
description: KACCHRAULI, India, Oct. 16  One innovative farmer of this village in Haryana state is not bothered by fuel prices, fertilizer shortages and electricity cuts that worry other Indian farmers.

title: Fear and Chaos Rule in Ethiopia
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 18The military regime that has ruled Ethiopia for 13 months has bitterly disappointed the hopes of the politically conscious minority of this country of 27 million and has pushed them either into fearful opposition or into prison.

title: S.E.C. URGED: KEEP OFFBOARD RULES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The Securities Industry Association and the United States Treasury reconimended today that until a national market system was in operation the Securities and Exchange Commission should not eliminate stock exchange rules restricting offboard trading in their listed stocks.

title: Ford Is Reported Ready To Accept Vote to Aid City
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20President Ford would reluctantly sign legislation to ease New York City's fiscal crisis provided that it contained the stringent restrictions that Congress is likely to insist upon, high Administration official said today.

title: SAKHAROY APPLIES FOR VISIT TO OSLO
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 20 (Reuters)  Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and outspoken advocate of civil liberties, said today that he had formally applied for permission to travel to Oslo, Norway, next month to receive his Nobel Peace Prize.

title: Threat Reported Against Umpire
description: BOSTON, Oct 20 (AP) The lives of Larry Barnett, a World Series umpire, his wife and daughter have been threatened and all have been placed under police guard, the Boston Herald American reported today in a copyright story.

title: Sakharov Doubts Ouster
description: Andrei Sakharov told the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation by telephone yesterday, in a taped interview, that he had not been subjected to any pressures and did not believe that he would be expelled from the Soviet Union.

title: Paine Webber Lists Profit After Loss a Year Ago
description: Paine Webber, Inc., parent of the brokerage house of Paine Webber, Jackson & Curtis, Inc reported yesterday that profits for the fourth fiscal quarter ended in September rose to an estimated $900,000 from a loss a year earlier of $885.000.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The United States Supreme Court refused yesterday interfere with the ruling by the New Jersey Supreme Court that the state provide school aid that would equalize per pupil expenditures throughout the state. The justices turned down an appeal brought by Assemblyman Herbert C. Klein Democrat of Passaic, who contended that the state court had exceeded its judicial authority by rewriting the state school aid plan for the 197677 school year. The state court ruled in 1973 that more state school aid must be spent in poorer school districts than in those with high property valuations. Under existing state law, each pupil in the state receives the same amount of state aid without regard to the wealth of an individual district.

title: SALT II Threatened ...
description: For thirty years, from the atom bomb to the MIRV multiple warhead, American inventive genius has sought increased security for the country through a series technological marvels that, when inevitably acquired by the Soviet Union, have heightened the nation's danger. The latest, the cruise missile, has yet to be flighttested. But it already threatens the negotiations for a historic tenyear Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty (SALT II), placing in doubt Leonid Brezhnev's thricepostponed 1975 visit to the United States and, with it, the future dtente.

Since mortgages are a money instrument, the ups and downs of mortgage future prices reflect interest rates.

title: What About the Temperature, Bowie?; Dave Anderson
description: BOSTON, Oct. 20While the World Series waited to resume, rain has been the primary topic of conversation, as if rain were the only weather factor involved. In again postponing the sixth game today, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn spoke mostly of ground conditions at Fenway Park that have been created by rain. Bowie Kuhn continues to ignore the temperature, as if that had no bearing on a baseball game. He has decreed the remainder the World Series to be conducted at night because that way we are better able to accommodate our fans and our national TV audience. He has ignored his basic responsibility in providing the best possible weather conditions at World Series games, both for the teams and the public. Baseball is a warm  weather sport; the Summer Game, the poets say. But its most important contests are scheduled in the autumn chill. Baseball occasionally is fortunate when World Series weather is unseasonably warm, as it was for the third and fourth games in Cincinnati last, week or when warm  weather cities are involved. But that is luck, not design.

Yesterday Joseph Papp, founder, producer and Big Daddy of the New York Shakespeare Festival, announced that he had to give up his Broadway enclave at the Booth Theater for, fundamentally, economic reasons. Last night his first and presumably last play at the Booth, Dennis J. Reardon's The Leaf People opened. It bombed. But it bombed with decent reverberations. It bombed with class.

What threatens SALT II are two delivery systems that were not discussed at Vladivostok, but have loomed large in the thinking of the military on both sides since then: the new American cruise missile and the new Soviet supersonic, swingwinged jet bomber known as Backfire.

An Oriental singer in this role is hardly a novelty, hut there's no question that Miss Lee brought a natural delicacy of movement and authenticity of manner that contributed greatly to the effect of her characterization.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The White House announced a fiveyear accord with the Soviet Union, effective year from now, under which the Russians would buy six to eight million tons of American grain a year. Also, President Ford lifted a twomonth embargo on further grain sales to the Russians this year. The White House further announced a letter of intent, signed in Moscow, to buy up to 200,000 barrels of Russian oil a day. [Page 1, Column 1.]

Such an increase would be less than the 10 per cent announced last month by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, of which Venezuela is a member. The OPEC increase amounts to $1.46 a barrel.

description: Douglas Samuels spends most of his days looking for work. The only difference between him and the 385,000 people or so in New York City who are out of work is that he looks for jobs not for himself, but for others.

description: The two heroic marble lions guarding the entrance the New York Public Library (tradition has it that they were placed there so that readers could read between the lions) ale about to be given a bath.

title: 40 Soviet Films of 20's, A Mishmash at Modern
description: Morning, in a hideously cluttered oneroom Moscow apartment. The man sits up in bed, in the most objectionable good humor. He takes the cat and lays it on his sleeping wife's face. Bony shoulders protruding from his underwear, he does his exercises and strips a leaf from a calendar with a grubby picture of Stalin on it. He stands in a washtub, showering under a trickle of water from the samovar overhead.

title: Accord Reached in Elizabeth Strike
description: The Elizabeth (N.J.) Education Association reached a tentative contract settlement with local school officials last night, ending a 12day strike that disrupted classes for 15,000 pupils. A union spokesman said the rankandfile would meet at 7:30 A.M. today to give final approval to the twoyear pact. If the pact is approved, the teachers were expected to report to classes later in the day. Details of the agreement were not immediately available.

title: How To Cut The Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger has hit on an original way to defend the Pentagon's budget. He has attacked the House Appropriations Committee and got into a scrap with its venerable 75yearold conservative chairman, Representative George H. Mahon of Texas. In Washington, this is a little like blowing up your own arsenal.

title: Pilot Critical Of Cornell Soccer Unit

We're not shootinz well. said Dan Wood Cornell's coach. Our wings and halfbacks play well and create opportunities, but when it comes to shooting we've done poorly, particularly the middle of our offense.

Harris, 33 years old and in his fourth season with the club, has been plagued by knee problems. He suffered his latest injury last season and the effects lingered, bothering him since the beginning of training camp this season. In the two games he played he did not score and had assist.

S grades of fresh fruits and vegetables in place of the current ones, which the department's experts recognize are confusing the trade specialists as well as the consumer.

title: The Fate of a City. . .
description: The prospects for Congressional action to save New York City from bankruptcy improved marginally yesterday when the Senate Banking Committee voted 7 to 6 to begin work on the necessary legislation. But it is clear from the narrowness of the committee's partisan vote, the widespread hostility to this city that is being voiced in Congressional hearings and the still uncertain attitude of the Ford Administration that New Yorkers continue to face an excruciating uphill battle for fiscal survival.

title: A Physical for Britain

He said he did not want the commis sion to discuss whether doctors Should spend part of their time in private practice, or the related question of whether hospitals in Britain's socialized system should have special wines for freepaying patients.

title: Lottery Drawing Changed To Use Only Sold Tickets

title: JOAN ARMATRADING AT THE BOTTOM LINE

She sings in a gruff, percussive style, for the most part, and is backed by a crisp and lively sixpiece band called the Movies (no relation to the New York underground ensemble tailed Movies).

title: JUDGE ASKS HALT TO EXXON SUIT

title: Football Ratings
New York Times Profits Drop As Newspaper Reports Deficit
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its thirdquarter consolidated net income fell 33.7 per cent to S3million or 26 cents a share despite an increase of 3.7 per cent in consolidated revenues to $96.9million.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Appellate Division Ruling Supports New York Times
description: The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court upheld yesterday a decision that The New York Times had not aided discriminatory employment practices in printing helpwanted advertisements seeking employes for jobs in South Africa.

title: Meadowland Neighbors Fear Complex's Side Effects
description: EAST RUTHERFORDAnyone passing the new Sports Complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands here can sec the steel girders and concrete ramps that herald the progress being made in completing the football stadium and horse racetrack expected to open next fall. The early problems are a thing of the past. But as workmen fit the pieces into place, residents of this part of New Jersey are worried because they see little evidence that masstransit facilities are being developed.

title: London Metal Market
Indonesian Seaman Describes Killing Four and Scuttling Ship
description: MIAMI, Oct. 21 (UPI)  An Indonesian seaman has described how he killed four German officers aboard the Panamanian freighter Mimi and then scuttled the ship.

title: Today's Entries at Belmont
Television
description: 8:15 P.M. World Series (4)

title: WINE TALK
description: Two weeks ago this space was given over to a report on a judging of 140 wines produced in Sonoma County, Calif.

title: Box Score of Sixth Game
3 Meat Union Aides Guilty in Tax Case
description: Three leaders of a meatcutters union pleaded guilty to taxevasion charges in Federal District Court after the Government agreed to drop a unionracketeering charge against them. The men are Irving Stern, Nicholas Abondolo and Moe Flass. Mr. Stern is an international vice president of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen of North America, director of organization of Local 342 and president of the Greater New York Labor Food Council, consisting of 22 retail food unions in the metropolitan area. Mr. Abondolo is president of Local 342 and Mr. Fliss is vice president.

title: Reagan Berates ThirdWorld Governments Over Hostility
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21Ronald Reagan, in what aides billed as a major address, berated third  world governments here today for what he termed antiAmerican hostility and the United Nations for allowing them what he called a disproportionate role in its decisions.

title: AIR FRANCE FLIGHTS DELAYED BY STRIKES
description: PARIS, Oct. 21Ground personnel for Air France have been disrupting traffic at Charles de Gaulle and Orly Airports here by wildcat strikes since Sunday.

title: Hunger and Politics
description: President Ford has just renewed his antihunger war in which the target seems to be hungry Americans rather than hunger itself. The Administration's latest sally, though billed as food stamp reform, actually amounts to a substantial evisceration of the program.

title: Music: Singing With Joy
description: Every year Winifred Cecil gives a series of public master classes called Joy in Singing, in which students are instructed by her and then perform. And each year a panel of judges selects the best of the singers, who is then presented in a formal recital. This year's winner was Eunice Hill, who appeared at Alice Tully Hall Monday night.

title: ANGELO DI LEO
description: Angelo Di Leo, a retired men'sclothing tailor, died yesterday at his home in Granitvine, Staten Island of a cerebral hemorrhage. His age wa: 83.

title: Postal Strike in Canada Halts Mail Service From the U. S
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 21Canadian post office employes called strike today over wage demands and other issues, halting mail service throughout the country.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Iris Lane says she doesn't care a jot about mahjongg, but she snapped up the three sets of the game she came upon while shopping for antiques. She did so because she was charmed with the delicate Chinese symbols and characters engraved on the ivory tiles and immediately saw their possibilities as jewelry.

title: 4 Ousted House Chairmen lust Watch Parade
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 He often sits on a leather bench just outside the House chamber, a lone figure watching the passing parade of old colleagues who once clamored for his attention and the young ones who never knew him in his days of power.

title: DeMarco Appeal Is Planned By Watergate Prosecutors
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) The Special Watergate Prosecutor's office will appeal the dismissal of all charges against Frank DeMarco Jr., who was accused of obtaining an illegal tax break for former President Richard M. Nixon, a spokesman for the office said today.

title: Moroccan Spectacular
description: it is a dangerous spectacle that King Hassan II is now providing for the world in place of the statesmanship that ought to accompany Morocco's claims to the Spanish Sahara. Desperately poor Moroccans have flocked enthusiastically to fill the 350,000 places in the unarmed force that the King promises to lead into the disputed territory by way of dramatizing his claims and setting up a provisional administration.

title: Press Association Elects
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (UPI)Robert Roth, vice president for production of the KnightRidder newspapers, today was elected president of the Inland Daily Press Association for the 197576 term.

title: Professional Football
NITRITE REDUCTION IN MEATS PLANNED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) The Agriculture Department said today that it would soon propose Federal regulations aimed at reducing the amount or sodium nitrite permitted in processed meat such as ham and bologna.

title: New Look in Paris: Market for Couture
description: PARIS  French women living near the Opera may head for the nearby outdoor St. Honore market intent on buying a mutton or a roast. But these days they may come home with a dress or a coat instead.

title: RALPH D. PRESCOTT
description: Ralph D. Prescott, who retired in 1969 as vice president of the J. L. Prescott Company, manufacturer of household cleaning products, died yesterday at his home, 530 Valley Road, Upper Montclair, N. J.

title: U.S. Will Resume Talks With Turkey On Use of Bases
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UPI) The United States and Turkey will resume negotiations next week on United States use of military bases in Turkey, the State Department announced today.

title: Wilentz Asks Reinstatement As a Lawyer in State
description: TRENTON, Oct. 21 (AP)Warren W. Wilentz, a former candidate for the United States Senate, asked the State Supreme Court today to let him resume his law practice in New Jersey.

title: Eurobond Ratings Set By Standard & Poor's
description: Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday in London that it would begin rating Eurobonds. This is the first time that the financial services concern has extended its ratings to issues sold outside of the United States.

title: Challenge Called Premature
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UPI) Attorney General Edward H. Levi told the Supreme Court today that it was too early to decide whether the 1974 law limiting campaign contributions and expenditures violates the Constitution.

title: KODAK INTRODUCES PLAINPAPER COPIER
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 21 (Reuters)The Eastman Kodak Company announced today that it is beginning to market a plainpaper copier in eight American cities.

title: Tonight's Yonkers Entries
Deaths
SENATORS ASSAIL FORD BUDGET AIDE ON ECONOMIC PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21James T. Lynn, the Director of the Budget, was criticized today by Republicans as well as Democrats as he went before the Senate Budget Committee to explain the Administration's program to tie a spending reduction to a tax cut.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Market Place
description: After an extensive review of the past performance of the nation's money managers, two scholars at the University of Chicago law school have concluded that it is not only futile to attempt to beat the market averages but also unduly costly.

title: Spare the Child
description: If In an extraordinarlly retrogressive ruling, the Supreme Court has effectively decided that teachers may resort to corporal punishment in disciplining pupils under state law. In letting stand a lower court decision that so held, the nation's highest tribunal has set back the cause of sound pedagogy and of humane treatment of children. Instead of dealing with the rights of parents and children, the Court has allowed a highly questionable tradition to take on the force of law.

title: Radio
Bridge:
description: A process begins tonight that could lead a handful of players, by a long and devious route, to a world team title in the spring of 1977. Thousands of players throughout North America will compete in the Grand National Team Championship.

title: Deaths
U.N. Deadlock Reported
description: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 21 (Reuters)  Security Council members were reported tonight to have failed to agree in private talks on how to deal with Spain's request that the proposed Moroccan march in the Spanish Sahara be called off.

title: Sadat Expected to Ask 10Year U.S. Arms Aid
description: President Anwar elSadat of of Egypt is expected by United States officials to ask during his visit here for SSbillion to S7billion in arms aid over a period of at least 10 years.

title: One Terrible Pitch Costs Eastwick Car
description: BOSTON, Wednesday, Oct. 22Rawley Eastwick sat slumped on his chair in the Cincinnati clubhouse, staring alternately into his locker and at the floor. He rubbed his face, but the look on his face was blank

title: Logue Attributes Collapse of U.D.C. To Miscalculation of City's Bankers
description: Edward J. Logue, the former president of the Urban Development Corporation, said yesterday that the agency's final collapse last February had been brought about by the miscalculation of the city's bankers, who he said exploited the uncertainty of the 1974 gubernatorial campaign by trying to force Gov. Malcolm Wilson to bail the U.D.C. out of imminent default.

title: Bayh Is Ninth Democrat In Presidential Contest
description: Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana is the ninth declared Democratic candidate for the party's Presidential nomination in 1976. Already in the field are the following listed in alphabetical order:

title: HOUSE ACTS TO EASE A CURB ON POLITICS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UPI)The House overrode Republican charges of political immorality and payoff for union bosses today and voted to liberalize a law that restricts Federal employe participation in politics.

title: DAVID BLUE OPENS AT THE OTHER END
description: David Slue, who opened a threenight run at the Other End, 147 Bleecker Street, on Monday, has been around for 10 years. He started as a folkie on the New YorkCambridge circuit in the midnineteensixties, then made a record in Nashville under his given name of S. David Cohen, and finally wound up in Hollywood, where he has put out records on the Asylum label that haven't really established him beyond a small circle of admirers.

title: I.B.M. Seeks to Void Order
description: The International Business Machines corporation has filed a motion in Federal Court for the Southern District of New York that the pretrial order issued in the Justice Department's antitrust action against I.B.M., that prevents both and the Justice Department from commenting on matters having to do with the case, be vacated. The pretrial order was originally made at the request of I.B.M.

title: Taylor Law Invoked Against L.I. Police
description: Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso is notifying 262 county policemen that he is invoking the penalty provisions of the Taylor Law against them for engaging a strike last Sept. 20. Mr. Caso said he had made the determination on the basis of information given to, him by Louis J. Frank, the Police Commissioner. The Taylor Law provides for a fine equal to twice the daily rate of pay for each day on strike and a oneyear probation period with loss of tenure.

title: U.N. FAILS TO AGREE ON COUNCIL CHOICE
description: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 21 (Reuters)The General Assembly adjourned for 48 hours today after failing again to elect either Pakistan or India to twoyear term on the Security Council beginning Jan. 1.

title: Saigon Calls U.S. Return Of Refugees Gross Farce
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam (Agence FrancePresse)  The newspaper Giai Phong, in the first official comment on the departure from Guam of a ship carrying 1,600 refugees back In Vietnam, today called it gross farce on the part of the Ford Administration.

title: KISSINGER AND MAO IN USEFUL
description: PEKING, Oct. 21Chairman Mao Tsetung met with Secretary of State Kissinger today symbolically dramatizing what both sides have sought to convey: the idea that ChineseAmerican relations are getting better all the time.

title: ADDED CONTROLS ARE PUT ON GAS
description: Continued From Page 65 presented to the Senate antitrust subcommittee at a hearing on a bill to prevent petroleum companies from engaging in development of energy sources other than oil and gas.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Open Interest
description: Tondo', Oct. 21, 1173

title: Carter Files a Request for Clemency With Byrne
description: Asserting that Rubin (Hurricane) Carter was innocent of a triplemurde conviction, defense lawyers yesterday formally petitioned Governor Byrne for executive clemency.

title: Lynn Heads A.P. AllStars
description: Fred Lynn of the Boston Red Sox received the most votes in The Associated Press allstar baseball team that was announced yesterday.

title: REP. HARRINGTON IS FACING INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The House Ethics Committee voted 7 to 2 today to investigate formally charges that Representative Michael J. Harrington violated House rules by discussing with unauthorized persons secret testimony on the Central Intelligence Agency's political activities in Chile.

title: 2 KOREAS, AT U.N., SEE WAR DANGER
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21  North Korea and South Korea warned today against the danger of a new war on their peninsula as the annual Korea debate began at the United Nations.

title: CHINESE PREPARE TO SPUR FARMING
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 21China announced plans today to improve agriculture by trying to upgrade standards in onethird of the nation's 2,100 countieS to match those of a commune noted for selfreliance, mechanization of production and the raising of grain under severe conditions.

title: WASP's on Wall Street Criticized by DeLury
description: John J. DeLury, the head of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, has accused the local financial community of cutting off credit to the city, in part because Mayor Beame is Jewish.

title: MISS ATTIE OFFERS SONGS AT GRENADIER
description: Paulette. Attie, a singer who is the first entry in a cabaret policy that the Grenadier, a restaurant on First Avenue at 48th Street, has instituted on Mondays and Tuesdays, has a good ear for show tunes that are familiar but not overdone. And she concentrates on the masters of the genreHarold Arlen, George Gershwin, Stephen Sondheim, Cole Porter, Cy Coleman heard her list.

title: Bobick Stops Foe
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 (UPI)Undefeated Duane Bobick stopped Rochelle Norris in the second round of their heavyweight bout tonight. It was his 31st victory and 28th knockout.

title: Chicago Board Options Exchange
Music: Computer Help
description: Emmanuel Ghent's Lustrum Given Its Local Premiere by Speculum Musicae

title: BroadBased Tax Urged To Reduce Transit Fares
description: David L. Yunich said yesterday that a broadbased transportation tax plus the placing of tolls on bridges over the East and Harlem Rivers that are now free would permit sharp cuts in transit fares and save New York City $190million annually in subsidies.

title: The Talk of the Sports Cornplex
Water Tunnel and Schools Face Construction Cutoff
description: The State Emergency Financial Control Board's recommended cuts in city construction projects include halting work on the huge water tunnel being built under Manhattan s well as on various schools lready as much as 70 per ent completed, city officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Occidental NonLibyan Workers Can Leave if They Are Replaced
description: LONDON, Oct. 21The Occidental Petrofeum Corporation said today that its 520 nonLibiyan employes and their families, including 230 Americans, have been told they can leave that North African country provided that they are replaced.

title: Woman Is Fatally Stabbed In West Side Apartment
description: The 26yearold wife of a psychiatrist was found stabbed to death in the couple's apartment on the upper West Side late last night, according to the Police.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Judge Tells Ford to Give Fromme Trial Deposition
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 21 President Ford was directed today by Federal District Judge Thomas J. MacBride to give a videotaped deposition for the trial of Lynette Alice Fromme, who is charged with attempting to assassinate the President on his visit to Sacramento Sept. 5.

title: Indiana Standard Net Off 28.2% in 3d Quarter
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) reported yesterday that its net income in the third quarter fell 28.2 per cent.

title: SENATORS ASSAIL FORD BUDGET AIDE ON ECONOMIC PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21James T. Lynn, the Director of the Budget, was criticized today by Republicans as well as Democrats as he went before the Senate Budget Cornmittee to explain the Administration's program to tie a spending reduction to a tax cut.

title: TV FAMILY HOUR TO BE CHALLENGED
description: A spokesman for three Hollywood talent guilds and a group of producers and production companies said yesterday that the parties would shortly file as lawsuit to challenge the legality of the sotermed family viewing hour, which the three television networks have adopted this year.

title: Pentagon Plans to Sell Seoul 18 More Jet Fighter Planes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) The Pentagon said today it planned to sell South Korea 18 more F4E fighter planes for $177.9million.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Kissinger met yesterday with Chairman Mao Tsetung in Peking and a press release on the meeting said the conversation had taken place in a friendly atmosphere. The invitation was seen as symbolic endorsement by Mr. Mao of what both sides so far have sought to convey: the idea that ChineseAmerican relations are getting better all the time. [Page 1, Cols. 12.]

title: Canada Puts Off Opening Of New Montreal Airport
description: Operations at the Mirabel airport outside Montreal, the world's largest have been put off until the end of November because of delays in the completion of support facilities, the Canadian Transport Ministry has announced.

title: ELAINE N. BURROWS
description: Elaine Nelthrop Burrows, Harlem businesswoman, died Sunday of a heart attack in Harlem Hospital. She was 66 years old and lived at 441 Convent Avenue.

title: Lebanese Debate Steps to Settle Strife
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 21Scattered shooting and sniping and occasional rocket explosions continued to paralyze life throughout Beirut today, though large scale violence did not break out.

title: TV: Woman Alive!
description: At a Manhattan dinner party the conversation flickered briefly on Susan Brownmiller's new study of rape, and one woman, an active Upper West Side sort, explained that she didn't have to read the book because she was already familiar with the subject's historical and social details. Obviously, she was at least familiar with the vanguard of contemporary women's movements and, just as obviously, she is not likely to be overly impressed by the moderate tone and approach adopted by Woman Alive!, a new TV magazine that begins a 10week run on Channel 13 tonight 10.

title: A.B.A. Extends Helping Hand To Only 7 ExClaws in Draft
description: The American Basketball Association dispersed the players from the defunct Baltimore Claws franchise in a special draft yesterday, leaving nothing behind of the team but undisclosed debts, legal problems and dissatisfied veterans.

title: Canucks, Islanders In 55 Tie
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 21 Scoring four goals with exceptional powerplay work but negating them with lax skating and little checking the New York Iclanders pieced together a 55 tie tonight with the Vancouver Canucks before 14,414 fans in Nassau Coliseum.

title: Cherry Hill Pact Approved
description: CHERRY HILL, Oct. 21 (UPI) Teachers in Cherry Hill, who threatened to strike two weeks ago, overwhelmingly voted yesterday to approve a new oneyear contract calling for a 9.5 per cent pay increase.

title: Treemonisha, the Legend Arrives
description: The time is the legendary past1866, to be precisein the legendary State of Arkansas, where, in the words of Scott Joplin's preface to his opera Treemonisha, the recently freed blacks live in dense ignorance, with no one to guide them. As often happens in legends, and sometimes in real life as well, a great and good young leader comes forward. Her name (for this is a women's liberation legend, not only a parable of black history) is Treemonisha, who believes that education (and no doubt neighborhood control) is her people's salvation.

title: Besieged Irish Kidnappers Hold Police at Bay
description: MONASTEREVIN, Ireland, Oct. 21 (AP)Armed troops and police tried to rescue a Dutch industrialist from his kidnappers today by storming a house in this sleepy market town. But the abductors held authorities at bay by threatening to blow his head off. the police said.

title: No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The Senate Banking Committee voted 7 to 6 today to consider legislation that would provide $6billion in loan guarantees to New York City, require the state to levy $420million in new taxes, and place the city's fiscal management under a threemember Federal board headed by Treasury Secretary William E. Simon.

title: Stocks Rise 4.57 as Trading Picks Up; Prices Rally in Most of Bond Market
description: Stock prices advanced moderately yesterday, continuing the upward move that be ??an Monday as the Commerce Department disclosed that the real gross national product had jumped at an 11 per cent annual rate during the third quarter.

title: Composer Attempts To Soften Discord Over U.N. Cantata
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21The Austrian composer of a controversial cantata won applause today from the choir that is to sing it here Friday. But the delegate of Israel said he would not attend the United Nations Day concert.

title: FRANCO STRICKEN BY HEART AILMENT
description: MADRID, Oct. 21Generalissimo Francisco Franco, Spain's ruler since the 193639 Civil War, fell seriously ill with a heart ailment today, setting off rumors that a transfer of power to Prince Juan Carlos de Borbon was imminent.

title: Moynihan Says U.N. Must Bar Resolution Condemning Zionism
description: The United States chief delegate to the United Nations, Daniel P. Moynihan, said yesterday that a controversial draft resolution that would equate Zionism with racism must not pass the General Assembly.

title: The Now York Times/Teresa Zabala Wright Batman, shown in his office, led Banking and Currency Committee.
Stage: Acting Company's Edward II
description: With a bare stage, bloodscarlet curtains, a few banners and a whole army of handsome costumes, John Houseman's Acting Company went into the second phase of its current season at the Harkness Theater with Ellis Rabb's staging of Marlowe's Edward II

title: Rochester Sells 27Million In Notes at 6.83 Per Cent
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 21 (AP)The City of Rochester sold nearly $27.1million in bond anticipation notes today at an intcerst of 6.83 per cent.

title: ... and a Nation?
description: Washington cannot rationally remain indifferent to the wider repercussions of a New York City default. The potential magnitude of those repercussions has by now been substantially established. They include the certainty that New York State, its vital agencies, many of its school districts and many local units of government will also be forced into default, according to the governor's testimony yesterday.

title: U.S. IS CONTINUING AID TO ETHIOPIA
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 18The United States continues as Ethiopia's principal single source of economic assistance and almost exclusive provider of military aid, despite misgivings about the course that the Ethiopian revolution has taken.

title: Father Testifies It's Lord's Will That His Daughter in a Coma Die
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Oct. 21 Breaking down frequently and calling for divine guidance, Joseph T. Quinlan cried out at a hearing here today that it's the Lord's will that his daughter, Karen Anne, be allowed to die.

title: Water Tunnel and Schools Face Construction Cutoff
description: The State Emergency Financial Control Board's recommended cuts in city construction projects include halting work on the huge water tunnel being built under Manhattan as well as on various schools already as much as 70 per cent completed, city officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Newspaper Talks Resume
description: With a drivers strike threatened for midnight tonight at The Daily News and It possible shutdown by The New York Times as well, negotiations resinned yesterday between the newspaper deliverers union and the two papers. The talks were broken off by the union on Friday.

title: National Airlines Cutbacks Planned When Strike Ends
description: MIAMI, Oct. 21 (UPI)Strikebound National Airlines disclosed today that it had sent layoff notices to 100 supervisory employes, anticipated further cutbacks and planned to sell its two Boeing 747 jumbo jets.

title: U.S. Sets 6 Marks In PanAm Swim
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 21 (AP)United States swimmers set PanAmerican Games records in every event held tonight, adding six gold medals to America's leading total.

title: Red Sox Win to Tie Series
description: BOSTON, Wednesday, Oct. 22The Boston Red Sox rose to dramatic heights early this morning when they defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 76, on a 12thinning home run by Carlton Fisk and stretched the World Series into a seventh and deciding game.

title: Drug Abuse Control Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UPI) President Ford yesterday proclaimed this week as Drug Abuse Prevention Week, saying that American cities were reporting an increase in the spread of heroin use.

title: BudgetBuilding an Artistic Science
description: The major reason that budgetmaking is so imprecise is that it is a scienceaccountingthat rests upon an artforecasting. The forecasting comes in the form of assumptions; assumptions about tax revenues, the growth rate of the city, the national economy and other such riskladen imponderables.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Atlantic City Police Department is conducting an investigation to determine whether two officers should charged with assault in an alleged shoplifting incident. The two officers are alleged to have tried to steal flashlight bulbs from a department stoke Friday, and when apprehended assaulted the store's security guard, according Public Safety Director Mario Florian. The two men were in plain clothes at the time of the incident, Mr. Floriani said. The two officers deny the account, and instead have charged the security guard with assaulting them. J. Smith, regional security manager for the Two Guys DiscountStore, filed the charges against Officers Albert PayLon and Bahouder Ali.

title: L.I. Police Using Repair Vehicles For Hiding Radar
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., Oct. 21Starting tomorrow, the mechanized lawnmower on the grass at the edge of one of Long Island's parkways may be a radar trap set up by the Long Island State Parkway Police to help curtail an increasing number of automobile accidents.

title: BANK COMPANIES IN TEXAS MERGING
description: The Federated Capital Corporation and the Mercantile National Corporation announced in Houston yesterday an agreement in principal to combine the two bank holding companics. If consummated, the agreement would create Texas's fifth largest bank holding company, with toLai assets or more $2.2billion. The share value of the Iwo companies, whose stocks are traded overthecounter, is more than $113million at current bid prices.

title: Lisbon Names 4 New Governors To Bolster Rule and Check Left
description: LISBON, Oct. 21New governors for Lisbon and three provincial capitals will be sworn in tomorrow in an effort by the Government to strengthen its authority against a Communist and extreme left offensive.

title: Chris Evert Routs Miss Casals, 60, 61
description: HILTON HEAD, S. C., Oct. 21Chris Evert recorded her 89th consecutive victory on clay today, crushing Rosemary Casals. 6.0, 61, in the women's singles semifinal of the eight player $135,000 World Invitation tennis tournament.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (APY)  Money rates for Tuesday.

title: Short Interest Advances Slightly on the Big Board
description: The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange rose slightly by 7,484 shares to a total of 24,485.559 shares in the month ended on, Oct. 15.

title: Wajima in International, Raising Field to 10
description: The $150,000 Washington D.C. International, which already had been assured dream world field representing seven nations, acquired added appeal yesterday when Wajima was named to take part in the 1  mile turf classic at Laurel on Nov. 8. John D. Schapiro, the president of the Maryland track, announced the entry of Wajima at a luncheon at the United Nations. The addition of the 3yearold son of Bold Ruler, recently syndicated for a record S7,200,000. increases the number of probable starters to 10.

title: Nigeria Plans News Agency
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 21 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Government is planning a national news agency and has given the goahead for a nationwide color television network, the federal Information Commissioner announced here this week.

title: C.I.A. MAIL COVER PUT AT 27 MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The Central Intelligence Agency opened more than 215,000 pieces of mail in a New York operation that many senior agency officials knew to be illegal, it was disclosed today at a Senate committee hearing.

title: People and Business
description: A senior business executive, with a corporate interest in journalism, believes that business and the press have too little mutual respect and too little understanding for each other's vital role within the American system.

title: Prosecutors Say Tapes Involve Michigan ExGovernor in Plot
description: DETROIT, Oct. 21 (UPI)Government prosecutors said today that a2ents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, using an exconvict with a transmitter, had taped conversations allegedly linking State Supreme Court Justice John B. Swainson with a $30,000 bribery conspiracy.

title: City Hospitals Role A Fiscal Crisis Issue
description: Does the city need its municipal hospital system?

title: Swedes Propose Reform To Widen Worker Role
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 20The Swedish Government and the Confederation of Trade Unions have proposed a set of radical measures that would alter the relationship between Workers and employers in a country where labor relations have proved extraordinarily harmonious in the last three decades.

title: Kennecott Shows Loss for Third Quarter
description: A number of major metals companies released yesterday disastrous thirdquarter earnings reports. The Kennecott Copper Corporation suffered the biggest decline with a loss of $20.5million, contrasted to net income of $45.5million, or $1.37 a share, in the corresponding period a year ago.

title: REV. DR. P. F. STURGES JR.
description: The Rev. Dr. Philemon F. Sturges Jr., rector of the Episcopal Church of St. MartinintheFields, Chestnut Hill, Mass., for 22 years before his retirement in 1967, died Sunday at his home in Princeton, Mass. He was 72 years old.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
Mediator Strives to Settle Jersey Symphony Strike
description: NEWARK, Oct. 21A state mediator met separately with representatives of the management of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra and its striking musicians today in an effort to settle a contract dispute that has forced the cancellation of all concerts through Sunday.

title: Umpire Gets Death Threat
description: BOSTON, Oct. 21Larry Barnett the umpire in the controversial bunt play in the third game of the World Series, said today he was concerned over a letter that threatened his life and the lives of his wife and 2yearold daughter. The writer demanded that Barnett pay him $10,000 or face a 38 caliber bullet in your head if Boston loses the Series.

title: Brokerage Firm Dissolving
description: Lawrence M. Rosenthal, board chairma nof L. M. Rosenthal & Co., Inc., members of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday the firm was discontinuing its securities business and that its personnel would join the New York office of Prescott, Ball & Turben, a Cleveland stockbroker. Last week the brokerage house of Delafield Company, formerly Delafield Childs, Inc., said it was leaving the brokerage business. Trading volume on the exchange has been down sharply for the last few months.

title: About Education
description: Not everyone interested in doing advanced graduate studies has wanted or needed a Ph.D., but until recently there was virtually no alternative.

title: Embargo by the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (Reuters)The United States Postal Service said today that an embargo had been placed on mail to Canada. No mail will be accepted, and mail now in the system wll he returned to the sender. A postage refund can be claimed on mail returned.

title: Carter in Bid to Byrne For Executive Clemency
description: Asserting that Rubin (Hurricane) Carter was innocent of a triplemurder conviction, defense lawyers yesterday formally petitioned Governor Byrne for executive clemency.

title: Old Treasures Stolen From Pompeii Museum
description: POMPEII, Italy, Oct. 21 (AP)Ancient Roman statuettes, pots, coins and jewels were stolen from the museum of this city, which was buried by a volcanic eruption 19 centuries ago, the police said today.

title: From the Police Blotter:
description: An employe of the United Parcel Service reportedly shot and killed his wife and himself in a secondfloor bedroom of their home at 9722 97th Street, Woodhaven, Queens. The police identified the couple as Raymond Tanon, 33 years old, and Carol Ann, 32. Mr. Tanon was reported to have been under medical treatment for depression. They leave two children, f and 9 years old.... A man and woman were found shot to death in the woman's groundfloor apartment at 207 Quincy Street, in Brooklyn's BedfordStuyvesant section. They were identified as Norman Jones, 25, and Alberta Evans, 30. The police said there was no known motive for the laying. . A man identified as Frank Asiel. 30, jumped or fell to his death from a 120floor room at the Martinique Hotel, 49 West 32d Street.

title: Kentucky Quilters Take Art to Connecticut
description: WESTPORT, Conn.Walklog around the large room where a few do7en women sat at tables talking softly and sewing on quilted pillow squares, Bessie Cromer was a long way from home.

title: New Hadassah Hospital Dedicated in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 21 Some 3,000 people gathered on Mount Scopus this morning for the dedication of a new $40million Hadassah University hospital designed to serve both the Arab and Jewish residents of East Jerusalem.

title: Ford Is Recovering From Cold, But Wife Has Nasal Congestion
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21PRESIDENT Ford showed signs today of substantial recovery from a sinus Infection and head cold, but his wife, Betty, began displaying cold symptoms, the White House announced.

C.I.A. MAIL COVER PUT Al 2.7 MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The Central ,Intelligence Agency opened more than 215,000 pieces of mail in a New York operation that many s'enior, agency officials knew to be, illegal, it was disclosed today, at a Senate committee hearing.

title: Justice Department Decides Against Prosecution in Destruction of Note From Oswald
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The Justice Department has decided not to bring charges against any of the individuals purportedly involved in the destruction, two days after the assassination of President Kennedy, of a threatening note previously delivered to the Dallas F.B.I. office by Lee Harvey Oswald, Mr. Kennedy's accused assassin.

title: Elizabeth Teachers Reach Tentative Accord on Pact,
description: ELIZABETH, Oct. 21 (AP)The Elizabeth Education Association reached a tentative contract sot tlement with local school officials tonight, ending a 12day strike that disrupted classes far 13,000 pupils.

title: L. I. MAN FLEES TURKISH PRISON
description: NORTH BABYLON, L.I., Oct. 21After serving five years in Turkish prisons for possession of hashish, Billy Hayes is on his way home to Long Island.

title: Sleeping Giants Awaken With Challenge by Bills
description: It is easier to explain how the Giants upset the Buffalo Bills on Monday night than why. The winning points of a 1714 game came on a 37yard field goal by George Hunt with six seconds to play and three minutes 10 seconds after John Leypoldt, the Buffalo kicker had missed a 19yard attempt. The Giants defense held O. J. Simpson to 126 yards rushing in 34 attempts, his lowest total of the season and more significantly his longest gain was merely 13yards.

title: 4 Ousted House Chairmen Just Watch Parade
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 He often sits on a leather bench just outside the House chamber, a lone figure watching the passing parade of old colleagues who once clamored for his attention and the young ones who never knew him in his days of power.

title: Nessen Denies a Shift Ry Ford on Aid to City
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21President Ford was said to be curious today about a report in The New York Times this morning that a senior administration official had said privately that Mr. Ford would reluctantly sign legislation to ease New York City's fiscal crisis if Congress included stringent restrictions in the bill's provisions.

title: Commuter Train Dropped
description: BOSTON, Oct. 21 (AP)  A commuter train scheduled between Boston and Worcester has been discontinued, the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority aid.

description: SHIRKIEVILLE, Ind., Oct. 21 Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana, betting that he can bridge the gap between left and right in his party better than any of his rivals, announced today his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: CONGRESS WEIGHS ANTIU.N. MEASURE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21Several key members of Congress today called for condemnation of a resolution adapted by United Nations committee that classifies Zionism as a form of racism.

title: WESLEYAN APPROVES A BUDGET CUT OF 5%
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 21The hoard of trustees of Wesleyan University has unanimously approved budget cuts averaging almost $1million a Year for the next five years.

title: Andrei Amalrik, on Dtente
description: MOSCOWAssessing the advantages of dtente over the cold war, we don't have the right, it seems, to say that dtente is the alternative to war. The cold war, being a form of sublimation of hot war, was not less effective than dtente in averting a real war, because peace depended, and still depends, on the balance of nuclear power. Therefore, even a mutual reduction of weapons, should it ever be achieved, would not reduce and would not increase the risks of war.

title: Ideology vs. Economics
description: More than economic analysis is needed to explain such Ford Administration policies as the proposed $28billion cut in both taxes and spending, proposed cuts in food stamps and increases in military spending, opposition to Federal aid to New York City, retroactive condemnation of the loan guarantee to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and its designation of inflation rather than unemployment as Public Enemy No. 1.

title: Borman to Succeed Hall As Chief of Eastern Air
description: Floyd D. Hall, chairman of Eastern Air Lines, announced yesterday that effective Dec. 16, following expiration of his 12year employment contract, he would cease being chief executive officer but would continue as chairman.

title: A 7Game Series for 26th Time
description: With the World Series going to a seventh game, it will be the 26th time that the championship of baseball has been decided in an ultimate game: one game, with no tomorrow for either side.

title: CONSUMER NOTES
description: Consolidated Edison, the Long Island Lighting Company and five other electric utilities in the state want to get out of the business of building new power plants. Not only are new plants expensive, but each new plant mobilizes community opposition and becomes a major public relations headache.

title: Fire Damages Smith College

title: 3 Towns in Jersey End a Disputed CulturalStudies Course as U.S. Cuts Off Funds

description: Burlington Industries, Inc., the nation's largest and most diversified textile company, yesterday reported improved business from the depressed levels earlier this year, but said that earnings for the September quarter still lagged by 20.1 per cent from the yearago period. For the fiscal year ended Sept. 27, earnings plunged 60 per cent from the preceding year.
