title: State Workers Told to Vote on Union
description: A state laborrelations official ordered an election among 40,000 state workers to determine whether they want to keep their present union representative, the Civil Service Employes Association, or join a new coalition five unions. Paul Klein, director of publicemploye practices for the Public Employment Relations Board, ordered the election between the C.S.E.A. and the newly organized Public Employes Federation for representation of the professional, scientific and technical unit of the state work force. A preelection conference will be held on Oct. 27.

title: Books of The Times
description: There is something very winning about Larry McMurtry's latest novel, Terms of Endearmentsomething that makes one keep reading along despite the book's many obvious faults. Partly, I suppose, it's simply trust in Mr. McMurtry, who in his rive previous novelsamong them Horseman, Pass By (out of which the movie Hud was made) and The Last Picture Showhas never been less than winning. Partly, It's the star of the story. Aurora Greenway of Houston by way of New Haven, an impossibly selfcentered widow with the redeeming virtue of knowing how difficult she is. (Only a saint could live with me, and I can't live with a saint. Older men aren't up to me, and younger men aren't interested.) Or is it Aurora's several suitors, as she insists on calling them: Edward Johnson, a normally urbane bank executive who gets so rattled by Aurora that he addresses lunch orders to busboys; Alberto, a retired opera singer who once knew that what worked with women was the direct approach but with Aurora could no longer find the direct approach to the direct approach; Gen. Hector Scott, a retired armored corps commander who dreams of assaulting Aurora's home with tanks but whose dreams end in frustration because he is too much of a realist to imagine a machine in which to climb to her bedroom; and Vernon Dalhart, a shy Texas oil millionaire who lives in his white Lincoln Continental and spends his most creative hours on the top floor of his 24story parking

title: GOING OUT Guide

Their I Remember You, from back when, gradually filled the room of this new club at 7 West Eighth Street, a cheerful and informal place tunneling through the former premises of a Greenwich Village delicatessen  restaurant. Each member of Mr. Brown's jazz crew, playing here for several weeks, had an improvisational turn. Then the pianist and bassist went into a duet session, starting with Autumn Leaves.

There is living with relatives, providing there are any, but many an elderly man or woman is the last leaf on the family tree. Then there is dragging out the days in shabby walkups or hotels, with fear and loneliness the only companions. Or there are nursing homes.

title: Red Smith
description: BOSON, Wednesday, Oct. 22It is going on 1 o'clock in the mnrning now and as groundskeepers replace the tarpaulin on the meld, a folk hero named Carlton Fisk goes capering across the grass in Fenway Park waving to baseball fans who stand in the aisles unwilling to go home, just bawling and rending their haberdashery. It was 12:33 A.M., when Fisk lifted a fly bail into the screen above the Great Wall pf Boston and put an end to the sixth game of the 72d World Series. The home run won for the Red Sox in the 12th inning, 76, and brought them even with the Cincinnati Reds in their struggle for the championship of baseball's narrow world. Yet it was no more than punctuation, a period marking the conclusion of an utterly implausible tale.

It was a condition of the offer that bidders use no subcontractors doing business with Israel, and promise generally to observe the terms of the Arab boycott of Israel. Taken literally, that might require assurance that a company making a bid has no Jews on its board of directors.

title: The Chicago Machine

Chicago is as wellgoverned as, and probably better governed than, any other big city in America today. This is not to say, however, that Chicago is wellgoverned.

Dr. Sawhill attributed the deficit to unexpectedly high costs, especially for fuel and electricity, and on shortfalls in tuition and gifts because of the recession, along with a decline in state aid.

description: BERLIN, Oct. 22  Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama visited West Berlin today, saw the Berlin Wall and said that. like President Kennedy, I feel, too, I am a Berliner.

title: A Roman Bargain, the 8c Bus Fare, Is in Trouble
description: ROME, Oct. 22  The 67 Bus begins in the Piazzale delle Provincie, winds its way through the congested streets of central Rome past the cafes, the art shops and the Spanish Steps, and ends up 10 miles away.

title: Egypt's 'Night of Counting Years'
description: "The Night of Counting the Years," which opened yesterday at the Regency Theater, is said by its distributors to be the first Egyptian movie to be shown in the United States. It has some beautifully composed shots of the desert and the Nile, and a few moments where the drama inhabits the actors instead of giving them orders from far away, but it isn't a success.It is set near the site of ancient Thebes, burial place of the Egyptian kings. A mountain clan, the Horrabat, has lived for generations by stripping artifacts and ornaments from a burial mound known only to itself, and selling them to dealers.The head of the clan dies; his two sons, learning for the first time of the trade off which they have lived, refuse to carry it on. One is murdered by their uncles; the younger one, Wanniss, hesitates but finally notifies the authorities. Soldiers remove the sarcophagi to Cairo, and the Horrabat's way of life is at an end.There are possibilities in the theme. It is a conflict between the down-to-earth traditions of the clan for whom the dead are their dead andin a true Nilotic cyclethe source of their life; and the larger, impersonal concern of Cairo with preserving history.Shadi Abdelsalam, the author and director, manages only once or twice to capture the proper human scale of the conflict. There is a scene where the graybeard uncles urge their followers to attack the procession of troops and bearers that is removing the sarcophagi. Nobody moves; the uncles start forward with their ancient rifles and then halt, aimlessly. A tiny, hopelessly bypassed community has just expired.Most of the movie, however, is done with stupefying grandiloquence. Wherever the camera touches, it sticks and won't let go. Landscape, brooding close-upsand how they all do broodinterminable patterns of black-robed figures against the white sand: Every shot lingers and lingers.The acting is heavy and hieratic, fogged with a pretentious mysticism. As Wanniss sulks about, trying to decide whether to serve the interests of his uncles or those of archeology, a mysterious stranger appears, hangs around for a while and vanishes; all to no apparent purpose."Follow, observe but do not question," one of the uncles says early on, as he shows the brother the burial crypt. The dialogue is mostly in this style, accompanied by portentous background music. "The Night of Counting the Years" often feels like years of counting the minutes.

title: Heading Into the PostFranco Era
description: Madrid, a sleepy desert town when Generalissimo Francisco Franco assumed power 36 years ago, is now the fastestgrowing modern capital in Europe. It is a city consumed by political hysteria and political maneuver that has intensified to fever pitch during the last eight years.

title: Arnold Toynbee, Who Charted Civilizations
description: Arnold Toynbee, the historian of the rise and fall of civilizations, died yesterday at a nursing home in York, England. He was 86 years old and had been incapacitated for the last 14 months as a result of stroke.

title: Crackdown in Kenya
description: Jomo Kenyatta will delude himself if he believes that Kenya's political crisis has been substantially dissolved by the National Assembly's unanimous vote of confidence in his leadership. The vote demonstrated only that the President's harsh tactics in jailing two members critical of the Governmentone of them the Deputy Speakerhave temporarily cowed a Parliament that on occasion has shown admirable courage and independence.

title: Me and Bessie
description: One of the nicest things my grandmother could say about anyone was that he or she had a heart as big as a frying pay. I never quite knew what it meant but Linda Hopkins has a heart as big as frying pan. Her soul is O.K. for size too.

title: SHIFTS ARE MINOR IN GRAIN FUTURES

title: Sensible Grain Deal

title: New Jersey Briefs

Gregory Sunkett, 21 years old, is being held in default of $35,000 bail in Camden County Jail. He was arrested by Patrolman Gary Sunkett. Their father, Councilman Golden Sunkett, is a retired Camden city detective. The police said Gregory Sunkett was one three men armed witha shotgun who held up a Palmyra bar for $225 on Sept. 3 and also one of three armed men who forced themselves into a Palmyra home Sept. 18, took $110 and locked the occupants in the basement. A Paulsboro warrant also alleges that Gregory Sunkett was one of three men who stole $2,000 worth of tools in an auto shop burglary last Dec. 11. Woman Bypassed Wins Tax Post

But he said he assumed that Allen W. Dulles, the intelligence agency's director who started the operation in 1953, had made his legal peace with it.

title: Reds
description: BOSTON, Oct. 22When it was done, Johnny Bench said it all. For three years he and his accomplices on the Cincinnati Reds have believed in the deep heart's core that they were the best baseball team in the world. But for 35 years, somebody else had been champion of the world.

title: Screen: 'Undercovers':Sellers Plays 6 Roles in Boultings Comedy
description: The time is late spring, 1940. France is falling with a snicker. An aged marshal of the Army retreats from the front to his favorite Paris brothel, where he had left his corset when the blitzkreig began. The brothel is also the hideout for a dashing English twit, a Royal Air Force officer who uses the place as a base for underground operations. The brothel is visited by Hitler and later, when German officers keep disappearing from its bedrooms, the house is investigated by a pinchnosed Gestapo chief, a former income-tax examiner.The faces aren't familiar but the actor underneath all that plasticine is. It's none other than Peter Sellers in the Boulting brothers' new comedy, "Undercovers Hero," which may possibly be the most awkward title of the week, next to "The Night of Counting the Years," which has an excuse. It was translated from the Arabic.In "Undercovers Hero," which opened yesterday at theaters around the city, Mr. Sellers also plays a Japanese prince and a president of France, a total of six roles, three more than he played in either "The Mouse That Roared" or "Dr. Strange-love," and five more than he played in "The Return of the Pink Panther."The suspicion that he plays five more roles than are absolutely necessary in "Undercovers Hero" is both unfair and inaccurate. One could just as well argue that "Jaws" would be a more serious film without the shark. Multiple-role playing, so dear to the heart of revue comics (and Mr. Sellers is one of the best), is the entire point of this film, though whether by design or default. I can't tell."Undercovers Hero" is an almost creepily witless endeavor, and one that should make you appreciate the true lunacy of the Blake Edwards-Sellers collaboration on "The Return of the Pink Panther." Roy Boulting, who directed and co-wrote the screenplay of the new movie, and John Boulting, who produced it, have made a sketch film with very few jokes and of such incoherence that they have an actor feeding us a lot of dumb voice-over narration in the vocabulary and cadences of former President Nixon. What could they possibly have been thinking of?Two of the Sellers impersonations are amusingthe British officer who sounds like a frightfully grand idiot and the seedy Gestapo officer whose dark plans are forever being sabotaged by Curt Jergens, who plays a nice German officer. The other members of the cast include Lila Kedrova, as the brothel's cheery madame, and Beatrice Remand (of "Claire's Knee") as an innocent brothel slavey, a girl who dreams of one day of having her own career.They don't do very much, as if they feared that if they did, Mr. Sellers would take their roles for himself. All of the Sellers impersonations are impressive, which means they may be technically good even when they aren't funny at all.

The mine, employing 350 workers, will be operated in the Kamloops area by a Teck subsidiary, Afton Mines. Ltd., under an incentive agreement with the provincial new Democratic Party Government.

title: Quarter Profit Up by 26% For Santa Fe Industries
description: Santa Fe Industries, Inc., which owns the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway, Ithe third largest railroad in the country, reported yesterday a profit of $44.9million, or $1.75 a share for the quarter to Sept. 30. It was the best quarter in the company's history with earnings up 26 per cent from the same period a year ago. when net income was $35.8million, or $1,39 3 share.

title: Officials Respond to Law By JOAN COOK
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 22Governor Byrne today described as a giant step forward the 'egislature's revision of New Jersey's system of school support to conform with a court mandate to provide the state's children with a thorough and efficient education. He added that two more important steps remainedimplementation and financing.

title: Jailing of Silent Witness Sought In HearstScott Harboring Case
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 22 (AP)The Government asked a Federal judge today to jail a reluctant witness for refusing to tell a grand jury what he knows about the alleged harboring of Patricia Hearst in a Pennsylvania farmhouse last year.

title: Default, Dear Brutus...
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22Federal money or Federal troops! cried New York Gov. Hugh Carey, in effect threatening violence if the rest of the country did not assume responsibility for New York City's debt. Were it not for the windage we allow political rhetoric, such a demand for money accompanied by a prediction of riot would be called extortion.

title: A Legality Clouds Letting College Use Harriman's Name
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Oct. 22W. Averell Harriman, the, diplomat, may not, after all, get a college named after him at the State University of New York's Center here because, there already is another college in the state named in honor of his family.

title: CBS SCORED BY G.O.P. OVER HOTEL ROOMS
description: KANSAS CITY. Mo., Oct. 22: (UPI)The Republican party's national committee has cornplained that CBS News has reserved more than 700 prime hotel rooms here for the 1976 convention without going through the arrangements committee.

title: Norman Kaplan, Sociologist, Chairman at Northeastern
description: Norman Kaplan, chairman of. it he department of socioin..iy, and anthropology at Northeastern University, died Tutis: day in Boston, where he lived. He was 52 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: Hoping to resume an active. public life in about six months, Richard M. Nixon is interested in becoming a radio or television commentator. according to a Los Angeles columnist and television producer. Wally George. who writes for four weekly papers and produces The Sam Yorty Show for the former Los Angeles Mayor, said Tuesday that Mr. Nixon had invited him to San Clemente after he wrote a column defending the former President. He said he found Mr. Nixon vibrant and vital and interested in doing a commentary program such as that by Ronald Reagan, the former California Governor, which has hundreds of radio stations subscribers.

title: Judge in Coma Case Is LowKey and Keeps the Atmosphere Calm
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 22 The fate of Karen Anne QuinIan continues to be debated quietly and almost informally in court, which is widely considered here as a tribute to Judge Robert Muir Jr., a 43yearold State Superior Court judge who almost never uses a gavel or raises his voice.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22Scientists have reported suc cessfully transferring symptoms of a mysterious disease called myasthenia gravis to animals by repeated injections of material from the blood serum of human victims of the disease.

title: F .D. A. Bids Food Canners List Drained Weights to Aid Buyers
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 22 (AP), The Food and Drug Administration proposed today that the contents of canned fruits and vegetables be declared in drained weight to help consumers get the best buy for their food dollars.

title: HOUSEUNITBACKED ON BOYCOTT ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22A Constitutional scholar today urged a House subcommittee not to contribute to the continued destruction of Congressional authority by allowing the Commerce Department to withhold information about the Arab boycott of companies that trade with Israel.

title: Trudeau Cancels U.S. Visit
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 22 (AP)Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has canceled a trip to Washington tomorrow because President Ford has a cold, a spokesman said today. Mr. Trudeau had been scheduled to act as host at a Washington performance of a play. Louis.Riel, that Mr. Ford was to have attended. The play is part of a Canadian salute to the United States Bicenlennial.

title: Arnold Toynbee, Who Charted Civilizations
description: Arnold Toynhee, the historian of the rise and fall of civilizations, died yesterday at a nursing home in York, England. He was 86 years old and had been incapacitated for the last 14 months as a result of stroke.

title: Peking Atmosphere Chilly As Kissinger Ends Talks
description: PEKING, Thursday, Oct. 23Secretary of State Kissinger's fourday visit to China ended last night as it began, with disagreement over Washington's policy of dtente with Moscow, but with relations between the United States and China intact.

title: State Phone Rate Increase Of 12 Per Cent Approved
description: The New York Telephone Company was authorized yesterday to increase its rates by $297,989,000 annually, or abouti 12 per cent over current intrastate revenues, in a decision by the State Public Service Commission. The major effect will be on businesses, whose costs may rise 15 to 25 per cent.

title: Staten Island Is Heart of Murphy's Shifting District
description: John Michael Murphy, the Staten Island Democrat, has run for Congress seven times and won six times. In five of those elections, he had to run in a partly new district.

description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 22Jamie Rivers finally got a good night's sleep last night after playing nursemaid to his daughter, who is 10 days old today.

title: Police Seek Killer of West Side Nurse
description: A team of 30 detectives fanned out across Manhattan's West Side yesterday searching for the killer of a 26yearold registered nurse who was found slain in her apartment on West 87th Street shortly before midnight Tuesday.

title: Ways and Means Panel Yields to Kissinger
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22The House Ways and Means Committee, at the request of Secretary of State Kissinger, decided today to postpone indefinitely any change in the taxexempt status of various living allowances for Federal employes who work overseas.

title: Books of The Times
description: Sometimes it seems as if every other serious nonfiction book published now is an exhortation to live differently: more rationally or more irrationally; more consciously or more unconsciously; more spiritually or more physically. We are witnessing with a vengeance what Philip Rieff called the triumph of the therapeutic. Whatever we are doing, we seem to be doing it wrong. The age of anxiety has escalated to the age of hypochondria. Our soul is in a sling, our heart is on our sleeve and our body is an embarrassment.

title: MAN'S HAIR CITED IN MURDER TRIAL
description: The prosecution contended yesterday at the opening of the trial of David Allweissd a freelance writer accused of murdering a young woman, that a particle of his hair had been found wedged in the teeth of the murder victim.

description: The dividend table in yesterday's editions of The New York Times Incorrectly reported a reduced dividend for Valley Industries, Inc. The company made no report. Three other companies, the Itel Corporation, the Peavey Company and Tannetics, Inc., were listed as reporting reduced dividends. All three reported initial .dividends, The correct listings appear in today's dividend table, which appears on Page 64.

title: Master Historian
description: With limpid prose, civilized argument and felicitous examples, Arnold Toynbee wrote history much as an erudite journalist might explain and interpret an unfamiliar society or an intricate problem to his readers. Instead of national societies or the contemporary scene, however, Toynbee in his 12volume work, A Study of History, focused on earlier civilizations and tried to account for their rise and decline. He moved surefootedly in the realm of the past and, having been steeped in its knowledge at Winchester and Balliol College, Oxford, exemplified the tradition of scholarship that has been one of the auiet glories of the British heritage.

title: 3 R.I. Plants Struck
description: NORTH KINGSTON, R. I., Oct. 22 (AP)Machinists began a strike at the Brown and Sharpe Manufacturing Company plants in Rhode Island early today. Picket lines were reported up at plants in North Kingstown, Providence and North Providence. No new contract negotiating sessions ha % been scheduled,

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI)The Federal Trade Commission said today it has started an antitrust investigation of the tuna industry.

title: Miss Hearst Called Unfit To Help in Her Defense
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22Patricia Hearst is not able to help in her defense even if she is ruled competent to stand trial on armed bank robbery charges, one of her lawyers said today, and the Government prosecutor replied that generally speaking, being a little bit competent is like being a little bit pregnant.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP 0.5%, HALF RATE OF EARLY SUMMER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22Consumer prices rose fivetenths of 1 per cent in September, more than in August but only half the worrisome inflation rate of early summer, the Labor Department reported to day.

title: Knicks OpenTonight
description: Tom Riker and Jesse Dark. in whom the Knicks invested heavily for future delivery, were cut yesterday after the final practice before New York's season opener against the revamped Los Angeles Lakers tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DESIGN FOR MOVING There should be plenty of human elasticity on the stage of the Felt Forum tonight, starting at 8 o'clock, when the Chinese Acrobats of Taiwan exhibit their skill in an ancient tradition of their homeland with balancing, juggling, kung fu ch'i kung inner strength and other feats. Sixtyfive young artists, representing the new generation of Chinese acrobatic families, will be giving five performances at the Forum (ending with a Sunday matinee) during their first American tour.

title: Capital Construction
description: The news that New York cannot build the Convention Center now or in the foreseeable future, while unwelcome, is no surprise. The announcement of its suspension (technically it is not dead) confirmed Controller Goldin's capital budget report statement that the city is unable to fund any new building at all. This is underscored by the state's order to review all current construction work. Every project in process is being examined to see if it can be stalled or stopped.

description: It's an old story for stockholders of Canadian Javelin, Ltd. The stock has been suspended from trading on the American Stock Exchange nearly six monthsone of several halts in trading in recent yearsand there is no indication when the Securities and Exchange Commission will permit trading to resume.

title: AID PLAN FOR CITY, BALKED IN SENATE, GAINS IN THE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22Congressional action to enable New York City to avert a default suffered a parliamentary setback in the Senate today, but gained support in the House.

title: DOLLAR AND PRICE OF GOLD OFF ABROAD
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 22 (UPI)The dollar fell on European money markets today, weakened by stronger European currencies. Gold lost $1 an ounce in London, closing at $144.75 and $1.25 in Zurich to close at $144.75.

title: Jersey Pastor Surprised
description: The Rev. Thomas Trappasso, pastor of Our Lady of the Lake Church in Mount Arlington, N. J., which the Quinlan family attends, said he was surprised by the article in the Vatican newspaper. It's very obvious someone over there is getting the wrong picture, he said.

description: The World Football League, beset by financial problems since its inception a year ago, announced it would cease operations immediately. Page 51.

title: Giant Heads Fail to Swell Over Upset
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 22Although the playing of a Monday night game and then having to play again Saturday afternoon has shortened the New York Giants work week by two days, Coach Bill Arnsparger refuses to complain.

title: Reds Win First Series in 35 Years
description: BOSTON, Oct. 22In the final inning of the final game, the Cincinnati Reds finally subdued the rambunctious Boston Red Sox, 43, tonight and won the 72d World Series in seven games.

title: A NEW FORD THREAT REPORTED ON COAST
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 22 (AP)Federal agents are investigating reports of another threat on the life of President Ford by an inmate of the Santa Barbara County jail. Two other men charged in art alleged assassination plot are confined there, and one of them was reportedly involved in the most recent incident.

title: Vatican Newspaper Publishes an Article Opposing Quinlans
description: ROME, Oct. 22 (Reuter)An article in the Vatican daily, Osservatore Romano, said today that Karen Anne Quinlan should not be allowed to die, as her parents wish.

title: PACT WITH MADRID TO GO TO CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22The State Department will break with precedent and submit for Congressional approval the military, political, economic and cultural agreement with Spain that is close to completion, high Administration officials said today.

title: Franco Is Reported Gaining, With His Continued Rule Uncertain
description: MADRID, Oct. 20Generallissimo Francisco Franco was reported today to be recoverling quickly from an acute heart ailment, but the question of his remaining in power was unresolved.

The correct listings appear in today's dividend table, which appears on Page 64.

title: 9 Maritime Aides
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 22 Nine policylevel officials of the Federal Maritime Commission owned stocks in companies that they directly or indirectly regulated as employes of the cornmission, the General Accounting Office charged in a report made public today.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 22The Security Council sought tonight to head off a possible armed clash over the Spanish Sahara by appealing for restraint and moderation by the countries disputing control of the territory.

description: The New York Telephone Company was authorized yesterday to increase its rates by $297,989,000 annually, or about 12 per cent over current intrastate revenues, in a decision by the State Public Service Commission. The major effect will be on businesses, whose costs may rise 15 to 25 per cent.

title: FORD IRRITATED ABOUT AID TO CITY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22President Ford, warning against the false anticipation of an easy solution, said today through his spokesman that he was irritated by published accounts of his willingness to sign legislation easing New York City's fiscal plieht.

title: Redemptions Increase In Mutual Fund Shares
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP)The rate at which mutual fund investors reslempdons of their shares exceeded new purchases picked up in September, the Investment Company Institute said today.

title: The Arms Business
description: The tripling of American arms sales abroad in little more than two years to about $11 billion in the last fiscal year may have stirred concern and debate in the Congress and even in the Administration, which originally encouraged it. But a significant move to restrain this pernicious trade has yet to develop, despite a succession of Congressional studies. Why?

title: Reds Win First Series in 35 Years
description: BOSTON, Oct. 22In the final inning of the final game, the Cincinnati Reds finally subdued the rambunctious Boston Red Sox, 43, tonight and won the 72d World Series. It was Cincinnati's first championship since 1940.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) Commerce Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton indicated today that United States companies doing business overseas at times had little choice but to take part in kickback schemes.

title: Court Approves Settling Of Suits on Dye Pricing
description: A $.15million settlement of pricefixing claims against several major dye manufacturing companies was approved yesterday by Judge Dudley B. Bonsal in Federal District Court.

description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 22 (UPl) Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz said today t no United States could easily supply the Soviet Union an extra 7 million tons of grain this year if the Russians sought it under the new loneterm agreement.

title: Pentagon Sees Soviet Union Widening Lead Over U.S. in Defense Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22At a time when the defense budget is in serious difficulty in Congress, the Defense Department is letting out new, still preliminary intelligence estimates suggesting that the Soviet Union is widening its lead over the United States in defense spending.

description: ROME, Oct. 22 (Reuter)An article in the Vatican daily. Observatore Romano, soid today that Karen Anne Quinlan should rot be allowed to die as her parents wish.

title: DANCES BY 3 WOMEN GIVEN AT CUBICULO
description: The generally high level of performing at the Cubiculo on Tuesday evening was in the service of generally lowlevel creativity. Valerie Bergman, Joya Granbery Hoyt and Katherine Liepe presented a joint program that toyed with the tag ends of what were once fresh ideas.

title: Kathleen Battle Is Standout As Treemonisha
description: People who go to the matinees of Treemonishawhich will move from the Uris Theater to the Palace Theater on Nov. 4 for a run through Dec. 21have no need to feel cheated because the title part isn't being sung by Carmen Balthrop. Kathleen Battle, her substitute, has a perfectly lovely lyric soprano that meets the demands of the role with gracious eaase.

description: ROME, Oct. 22  President Costa Gomes of Portugal visited Rome today for a private audience with Pope Paul VI and meetings with Italian Government leaders.

title: Athens, Tenn., Sends $25 to Help the City
description: ATHENS, Tenn., Oct. 22 (AP)The Athens City Council has appropriated $25 toward New York City's debt.

title: Modern Museum, In Economy Move, Shuts Wednesdays
description: Citing a $1million operating deficit, Richard Oldenburg, director of the Museum of Modern Art, announced yesterday that the museum would close its galleries to the public, every Wednesday beginning next month.

title: Must Be Curbed
description: Until a decade ago, most arms exports were grants, given to allies to enable them to defend themselves; with Congress appropriating taxpayers funds for this purpose, arms went to countries where an American national interest was perceived. Now 95 per cent of the exports are cash or credit sales on commercial or nearcommercial termsand almost any buyer is welcome.

title: For Children, Sugar Without Spice
description: One of the major problems in children's theater is a lack of good scripts. A poor one in the hands of professionals might get by, but in the hands of thespiansbyavocation, the faults glare more. Yet, when nonprofessionals are involved, one is less offended by imperfections.

title: U.S. Says Mexico Fails to Respond To Jail Protests
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) The State Department said today that the Mexican Government had responded to only four of 23 notes it had sent to protest the treatment of United States citizens held in Mexican jails.

title: HUNTING TRIPS CITED TO GAIN CONTRACTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UPI) Several more defense contractors, like the Northrop Corporation, have used hunting lodges or other facilities to entertain Pentagon brass, according to published reports.

title: OIL REFINERIES RAN AT 85% OF CAPACITY
description: The nation's oil refineries operated at 85.8 per cent of capacity last week compared with 87.1 per cent in the preceding week and 87.4 per cent in the comparable week a year ago, according to the American Petroleum Institute's weekly statistical report.

title: REAL ESTATE ILLS FATAL FOR BANK
description: A series of shaky real estate loans and the weakening of the commercial real estate market led to the insolvency of the American City Bank and Trust Company of Milwaukee in the largest bank failure so far this year. according to Government sources.

title: An Unofficial Opinion
description: Father Concetti, who teaches theology in Rome at the Lateran University, a conservative institution is not a member of the church's International Theological Commission. His viewpoint, like many that are expressed in Osservatore Romano, does not necessarily reflect the Vatican consensus.

title: Helms Says Search Of Mail Was Illegal
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 Richard Helms, Director of Central Intelligence from 1966 to 1973, testified today that he knew then that'the agency's mailopening program was illegal. But he said he assumed that Allen W. Dulles, the intelligence agency's director who started the operation in 1953, had made his legal peace with it.

title: Testifies Daughter Said Don't Keep Me Alive by Unusual Means
description: MORRISTOWN, Oct. 22Mommy, please don't ever let them keep me alive by extraordinary means, Karen Anne Quinlan said several times in the three years before she fell into a coma in April, according to her mother, Julia Ann Quinlan.

title: Israeli Army Reinstates an Arab as Gaza Mayor
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 22 (AP)The city of Gaza, in the Israelioccupied Gaza Strip, was partly returned to Arab rule today.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22Consumer prices rose fivetenths of 1 per cent in September, more than in August but only half the worrisome inflation rate of early summer, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Entertainment Events Today
Canada Tackles Inflation
description: The tough but balanced antiinflation program launched by Prime Minister Trudeau of Canada is long overdue. Mr. Trudeau was apparently moved to action by the resignation from his Cabinet of Finance Minister John Turner, generally regarded as the probable future leader of the Liberal party, who had long pressed for the kind of strong measures now adopted to check the deteriorating economy.

title: Advertising

title: TOWN TO CONTRACT FOR POLICE SERVICE
description: WRIGHTSTOWN, Oct. 23 (UPI)  The Borough Council here has decided to abolish its fivemember Police Department to save money. In a 3to2 vote last night, it decided to buy police protection from the 110member force in neighboring New Hanover Township beginning Nov. 10.

title: Buckley Asks Ford to Order an Inquiry Into the City's Borrowing Practices
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Senator James L. Buckley, ConservativeRepublican of New York, called on President Ford today to order a Justice Department investigation of whether New York City had violated Federal laws by overstating the amount of money available to cover its borrowines.

title: PLANFORSANITATION TO SAVE 2.7MILLION
description: The Acting Sanitation Commissioner, Martin Lang. yesterday announced costcutting and efficiency measure, that he said would save the city about $2.7million in the next year.

title: LOUIS MANN
description: Louis Mann, founder and retired president of the Dolly Varden Shops. women's apparel chain in Brooklyn and Queens, died Wednesday of heart attack in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 166 East 63d Street

title: LawyerPriest Loses Case of Clerical Collar
description: The State Court of Appeals yesterday confirmed a court's authority to prohibit a lawyerpriest from wearing clerical attire while defending a client before a jury.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 12%

title: Alcoa Offers 7% Discouunt To Its Cash Distributors
description: A new round of competitive price cutting in aluminum began yesterday with the announcement by the Aluminum Company of America that it matched Martin Marietta Aluminum Inc.'s recent move, which gives distributors larger discounts for paying cash as opposed to buying on consignment.

title: COAST TUNNEL BLAST LEADS TO FINES FOR 2
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 (UPI) The Lockheed Shipbuilding and Construction Company and two of its employes pleaded no contest today to misdemeanor charges in connection with the 1971 Sylmar Tunnel explosion that killed 17 persons.

title: Blacks Sue 6 Mississippi Towns In a Demand for Equal Services
description: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 23Civil rights lawyers have filed suit on behalf of black citizens against six Mississippi municipalities, seeking to impound More than $4million in Federal revenuesharing funds until the towns equalize public services in black and white neighborhoods.

title: Man Carrying a Loaded Pistol Is Arrested Near White House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) A young man carrying loaded pistol was arrested outside the White House today, but the Park Police and Secret Service officials do not believe that he represented a threat to the life of President Ford.

title: Spectators at Trial Are Few and Sedate
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 23The crowd trickles in sedately, up the stately courthouse staircase and along the hall outside Courtroom Number One on the second floor of the Morris County Courthouse.

title: Charles Reidpath. 85, Dies; Won Olympic Gold Medal

Carloadings in the same period totaled 480,289 car, 11.4 per cent below last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 9.6 per cent below last year.

But then Mr. Eto returned, to his native Japan to become head of the violin department at the Toho School of Music. His appearance Wednesday night in Carnegie Hall was his first here in seven years. He will be back only once more this season, on Dec. 1 after a European tour. But next season he plans a full schedule of Western concerts.

title: Simple Eloquence and Poetic Precision
description: Every time the Nobel Prize for Literature is awarded, someone writes an article explaining why the choice was politically predictable and inevitable. In hindsight it was therefore easy to explain awards to such writers as Bunin, Pasternak and Neruda. It was especially easy when the Italian writer Salvatore Quasimodo, writing odes to Sputnik, won the prize in 1959.

title: Byrne to Ask $20Million to Avoid Medicaid Reduction
description: TRENTON, Oct. 23Governor Byrne today confirmed that he would ask the Legislature to make a $20million emergency appropriation to avoid further cutbacks in health services for the State's 640,000 poor.

title: Flu Kills 500 in New Guinea
description: PORT MORESBY, PapuaNew Guinea, Oct. 23 (Reuters)More than 500 people have died in an influenza epidemic sweeping the remote areas of PapuaNew Guinea's highlands, Health Minister Donatus Mola said today.

title: Inco and Asarco in Drops; American Express Net Up
description: Earnings of the International 4ickcl Company of Canada, Ltd., fell 45.9 per cent in the third quarter and 36.2 per cent in the first nine months this year, while sales were down 7.3 per cent and 5 per cent in the respective periods. according to the company's report issued yesterday.

title: China a Blur of Images on Kissinger's Trip
description: TOKYO. Oct. 23On Monday morning, copies of Jenmin Jih Pao, the Chinese Communist party newspaper, were deosited in the rooms of the American correspondents who traveled with Secretary of State Kissinger. Covering most of the top of the front page was a picture of Chairman Mao Tsetung shaking hands with the wife of the President of Mali. On the bottom right, a modest photograph of Mr. Kissinger and Deputy Premier Teng Hsiaoping announced the Secretary's arrival.

title: Expectations Center on Cut in 8% Level
description: Firm prices prevailed yes. terday in the credit markets, fueled by the expectation of a cut in the 8 per cent prime rate by major banks and rumors of a reduction in the

title: Cynical Diplomacy
description: The socalled Social. Humanitarian and Cultural Cornmittee of the United Nations General Assembly has decided that Zionism is equivalent in perfidy to racism. This spurious judgment lacks even the slightest element of social, humanitarian, cultural or any other kind of justification.

title: Bomb Kills a Doctor Near London Home Of Caroline Kennedy
description: LONDON, Oct. 23A bomb exploded this morning under a car parked outside the home of a Member of Parliament who is serving as host to Caroline Kennedy, 17yearold daughter of the late President. The blast killed one of Britain's leading cancer specialists.

title: In Memoriant
description: GREENBERGBenlamln, October 28, 1950. Although a quarter of a century has posed we still love and miss you.

title: Mandate of U.N.'s Sinai Force Extended
description: >UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 23The Security Council today extended the mandate of the international peace  keeping force in the Sinai buffer zone by a year.

title: Money Supply Moves UpSharply
description: The nation's money supply moved up sharply in the week ended Wednesday, Oct. 15, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Bayh Asks Aid for Troubled Cities
description: In search of anointment as the official liberal in the New York Presidential primary, Senator Birch Bayh proposed yesterday a big Federal spending program to aid troubled cities, while his supporters distributed a rating sheet to counter opposition assertions that his record is not as liberal as it should be.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: F.T.C. REJECTS BID TO DROP OIL CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23The Federal Trade Commission rejected today a recommendation that it withdraw a 1973 antitrust complaint aimed at breaking up eight major oil companies.

title: New Medical Form Urged In Checking Rape Victims
description: A new medical form for proposed use by physicians examining rape victims was introduced yesterday during the first citywide conference on treatment and counseling for victims of sexual assault.

title: Nightwatch
description: AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 23  In the seven seconds before he was restrained by a guard and an onlooker at the Rijksmuseum here on Sept. 14, a knifewielding mental patient cut six gaping slashes and numerous scratches in Rembrandt's Nightwatch, the prize of the museum's rich collection.

title: Houston Astro Bank Is 10th 75 Failure; F.D.I.C. Action Is Set
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced yesterday that a small bank in Houston had failed last week and that its deposit liabilities had been taken over yesterday by a new bank in the same location.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
MARSHALL GRANGER
description: Marshall Granger, founder and retired president of the public accounting firm of his name, with quarters here and in Mamaroneck. N. Y., died yesterday at Central Suffolk Hospital in Riverhead, L. I. He was 81 yearg old and lived in Westhamntrm Reach. L

title: I.R.S. INVESTIGATING MONTOYA TAX CASE
description: WASNINTGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) The internal Revenue Service is conducting an internal investigation into allegations that the agency's Commissioner, Donald C. Alexander, blocked tax audits and investigations of Senator Toseph M. Montoya, Democrat of New Mexico, an I.R.S. official said today.

title: State University Calls Halt to Expansion
description: ALBANY, Oct. 23The State University of New York has declared a moratorium on all new construction and a freeze on enrollment at 20 of the institutions it operates.

title: Flyers Lose First, 3 to 0, To Islanders
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 23 Breathing new life into his recently lethargic team with some line changes, Coach Al Arbour sparked the New York Islanders tonight into a 30 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers. It was the 1975 Stanley Cup champions first loss of the season in seven games.

title: The Few Spectators at Trial Are Sedate
description: MORRISTOWN, Oct. 23. The crowd trickles in sedately, up the stately courthouse staircase and along the hall outside Courtroom Number One on the second floor of the Morris County Courthouse.

title: U. S. SAID TO DROP IN CHINA'S ESTEEM
description: TOKYO, Oct. 23 (UP1)Secretary of State Kissinger came nut of Peking today with the news that Chinese leaders consider the United States less impressive in world affairs now than it was a few years ago.

title: LEFTISTS DEMAND QUSTERS IN LISBON
description: LISBON, Oct. 23Portugarl's Communist party and other leftist groups sent thousands of demonstrators into the streets of this capital tonight in a determined effort to demonstrate their strength and to undermine: the monthold Government.

title: City on the Ohio Celebrates Its Reds
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 23 After 35 years of gloryhunger; after half a decade of painful nearmisses; :Mar a wrenching shift in moodfrom superconfidence to nagging doubt; after three days of rain took the edge off the World Series, and the sixth game restored it; after the Reds finally rallied in the ninth inning last night to seal their championship, after all that, Cincinnati had a crushing hangover today.

title: INDUSTRY CHIEFS SEE SOLID
description: The steel industry expects 1976 to be a reasonably solid year, with some relief from the recession and inventory overhang woes which have beset us in 1975, Thomas C. Graham, president of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation, said yesterday. He spoke at the 1975 marketing conference of The Conference Board in the New York Hilton Hotel

title: King Hassan Assures Opponents in Spanish Sahara
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco, Oct. 23 (AP)King Hassan II promised today to forgive all inhabitants of Spanish Sahara who have opposed Morocco's ambitions to take over the disputed territory on the northwest coast of Africa.

title: U.S. AFRICAN AIDE REPORTED CHOSEN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23secretary of State Kissinger has decided to recommend the nomination of William E. Schaufele Jr., Inspector General of the Foreign Service, to head the African affairs section of the State Department,

title: Composite Box of 1975 Series
JOSEPH J. CAZANA
description: Joseph J. Cazana, a civil engineer with Sanderson & Porter. Inc., who specialized in structuralsteel work and had served on projects for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, died Wednesday of cancer at his home in Ridgewood, N. J. He was 61 years old

title: Wind Overturns Bus
description: GALLUP, N.M., Oct. 23 (UPI) A Continental Trailways buss carrying 19 persons was overturned on an embankment by high winds today, but the police said none of the passengers was seriously injured. The bus was going from New York to Los Angeles.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
JOAN LITTLE LAWYER IS SCORED BY JUDGE
description: RALEIGH. N. C., Oct. 23 (AP) The American legal system, not money, should be credited with the acquittal of Joan Little, according to the judge who tried the murder case.

title: Exxon, Shell and Marathon Oil Report Sharp Profit Declines
description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, announced yesterday 31.3 per cent decline in profits in the third quarter. The Shell Oil Company and the Marathon Oil Company also reported steep drops.

title: 3 OF HANOVER UNITS TO REMAIN SEPARATE
description: Gabriel Hauge, chairman of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, announced yesterday that the hank holding company would continue to have three regional banks in upper New York State after next Jan. I, rather than a statewide branching system.

title: Titus Sings Offbeat Program at Hunter
description: In the four years since he came to public attention as the Celebrant in Leonard Bernstein's Mass, Alan Titus has established a solid foothold for himself in opera here and abroad. He is to make his Metropolitan Opera debut this season and, in the spring, will appear at England's Glyndebourne Festival as Pelltts in Debussy's Peflas et Melisande.

title: Worldl Church Group Bids Mrs. Gandhi Restore Rights
description: GENEVA, Oct. 23The World Council of Churches announced today that it had appealed to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India to restore the democratic rights of the people for political expression.

title: Boston Rallies Round Red Sox
description: BOSTON, Oct. 23 The man was slouched, somehow, on his feet on the sidewalk in front of the Eliot Lounge a few blocks from Fenway Park around 1 o'clock this morning. Both side pockets of his ski parka held a declining pint of Jack Daniel's.

title: Fiscal Cutting Underscores Flaws in the Justice System
description: By improving the administration of the sprawling criminaljustice system and by making the concept of speedy trials a reality, experts believe the city could save million of dollars.

title: 39 Hospitals in the State Face Loss of Malpractice Insurance
description: TRENTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) Almost onethird of the hospitals in New Jersey may soon lose their medical malpractice insurance, according to officials of the New Jersey Hospitals Association.

title: New York's E.R.A.
description: Some people in New York State actually think that the vote next month on the Equal Rights Amendment to the State Constitution is a plebiscite on unisex public rest rooms. In fact, the proposed revision of the Constitution is less revolutionary than that and substantially more important. It would write into the state's governing charter the principle of equality between the sexes which would provide the legal underpinnings for women's struggles to obtain equality of treatment before administrative bodies and in the courts.

title: EDWARD HERNDON, SECURITIES OFFICIAL
description: Edward T. Herndon. who retired in 1971 as a limited partner in Eastman Dillon. Union Securities & Co., died yesterday of cancer at Doctors Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in New Canaan Conn., and at 770 Park Avenue.

title: Hydrogen Fusion Studied As New Source of Energy
description: BOSTON, Oct. 23 Microscopic pellets of fusion fuel have been crushed to 1 /1,300th of their original volume, in rapidly advancing efforts to release energy by fusing the heavier forms of hydrogen.

title: Charles Brokaw Dies at 77; Acted on Stage and in Films
description: Charles Brokaw, an actor who had appeared on the Broadway stage and in films, died Thursday at New York Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived here.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GOING OUT GUIDE

title: 2 Octogenarian Ad Men Honored
description: Raymond Rubicam, 84yearold retired chairman and founder of Young & Rubicam, and Maxwell Sackheim, the genius of direct mail who is still writing it at age 85, were formally installed in the Copywriters Hall of Fame at luncheon given yesterday by the Copy Club in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Music: Bach Aria Group
description: The Bach Aria Group devotes itself largely to the cantata excerpts that have given it its name, yet the best pirt of its programs are often the cantatas presented in full. This was the case Wednesday evening at Alice Tully Hall in the opening concert this season of the ensemble, which will be 30 years old next year.

title: Speed and Pot: A Mirror Image
description: BOSTONThere now appears to be little doubt that among the commonly used psychoactive drugs amphetamines have a formidable potential for harm psychological, physical and social. It is clear that while they may be used, particularly in small doses over limited periods of time, without creating dependency, their use imposes the risk of severe dependency on many, and outright addiction on some.

title: Rise in Inmates Strains Jails in South; Florida Jams 10 Into 12by15 Foot Cells
description: LAKE BUTLER, Fla., Oct. 21 Throughout this year, Florida's bursting correctional institutions have gained 93 new prisoners every weekyounger, more hardened and serving longer sentences than those who came before.

title: NATO Hears Soviet Canal Is Enlarged For Naval Use
description: The Soviet Union has enlarged a canal linking the Baltic and White Seas, thereby significantly increasing the flexibility of its two fleets in northern Europe. North Atlantic Treaty Organization sources disclosed today.

Sabotage Added to Inquiry On State Lotteries Errors
description: State investigators said yesterday that they were looking into the possibility that the computer errors that led to the suspension of the state's lotteries might have been a result of sabotage by disgruntled former Lottery Commission employes.

title: Owners Stir Baseball Front
description: With all of baseball's onfield confrontations settled for the year, warfare erupted off the field yesterday between the Players Association and the club owners.

title: SELFSTYLED KILLER GUILTY IN 2 MURDERS
description: WALLACE, Idaho, Oct. 23 (UPI)A former church sexton, Thomas Eugene Creech, who claims involvement in the killing of 42 persons by satinists and a motorcycle gang, has been found guilty of murdering two itinerant painters.

title: CONGRESS IS URGED BY ALBERT TO ACT ON BILL TO AID CITY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Speaker Carl Albert, in an uncharacteristically strong state. ment, called on Congress today to enact legislation to avert New York City default.

title: Grant Creditor Rebuffs Guarantees on Salaries
description: The W. T. Grant Company, financially distressed and anxious to put together a new management team, is seeking a top retailer as president but its principal creditor banks are refusing to guarantee a fiveyear contract at a high salary to attract him. The salary being offered is $150,000 per annum.

title: Bomb Kills a Doctor Near London Home Of Caroline Kennedy
description: >LONDON, Oct. 23A bomb exploded this morning under a car parked outside the home of a Member of Parliament who is serving as host to Caroline Kennedy. 17yearold daughter of the late President. The blast killed one of Britain's leading cancer specialists.

description: RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 23 (AP) The North Carolina Highway Patrol was charged with racial and sexual discrimination today in a suit filed by the United States Department of Justice.

description: TRENTON, Oct. 23Governor Byrne today proposed legislation that would make the state boards that regulat profession and trades more responsive to the public.

description: TEL, AVIV, Oct. 22 (UPI) A court here today sentenced a 60yearold mother to a year in prison for the mercy killing of her 37yearold son, who suffered from cancer.

title: Schmitz to Run for Senate
description: LOS ANGELES. Oct. 23 (AP) John G. Schmitz, American Independent party Presidential candidate in 1974, announced yesterday that he would seek the Republican nomination for the United States Senate next year.

title: Depression Is Called More Common in Women
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Serious and prolonged depression is far more common among women than among men and is destructive of families as well as individuals, the director of Yale University's DepresSion Research Unit said today.

title: N.F.L. Eyes W.F.L. Jobless
description: The agent for Anthony Davis was expected to tell the Jets today how much it would cost to add the World Football League star to their roster. The agent, a 23yearold classmate of Davis from Southern California named Mike Trope, was also bargaining with the Toronto Argonauts of the Canadian League.

title: A LEBANESE PARTY ACCUSED IN CRISIS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 23Premier Rashid Karami today accused the National Liberal party, headed by Interior Minister Camille Chamoun, a Christion. of being involved in the prolonged factional violence in Beirut.

title: SURVIVAL IS SEEN FOR VENUS CRAFT
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23 (UPI)A Soviet scientist indicated today that the instrument capsule that landed on Venus yesterday was still functional despite the planet's severe atmospheric conditions.

title: DOW CHEMICAL ENDS BID ON JAPAN PLANT
description: TOKYO, Oct. 23The Dow Chemical Company's subsidiary here accepted today a demand from the Japanese Government that it withdraw its application to build a major chlorine and causticsoda plant in Japan.

title: Mediator Says Times and News Are Close to Pact With Drivers
description: The New York Times and The Daily News were reported yesterday In have reached agreement will the deliverers union on all but a handful of contract issucs, leading the deliverers to drop their threat of a strike against The News.

title: 3 Testify Karen Quinlan Can Never Function Again
description: MORRISTOWN, Oct. 23Superior Court Judge Robert Muir Jr. recessed the Karen Anne Quinlan trial today until Monday after hearing three expert medical witnesses testify that the 21yearold coma victim was legally and medically alive, but would never recover her ability to function as human being.

title: The Bases in Spain
description: Secretary Kissinger has taken a necessary and overdue first step in agreeing to seek the approval of Congress for the accord about to be concluded with Generalissimo Franco's Government for continued United States use of military bases in Spain. Given the importance and magnitude of this pactit will cost the United States $700 million in military aidthe next step should be decision to submit it as a treaty, requiring a Senate majority of twothirds for ratification.

title: F.B.I. Is Said to Retain File Of Most on Detention List
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Despite recent statements to the contrary by director Clarence M. Kelley, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has maintained intact a file of most of the 15,000 names of individuals once targeted for detention in a declared national emergency, sources familiar with the workinac of the F.B.I said today.

title: Senate Unit Likely to Clear Aid to City, but Stays Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Several members of the Senate Banking Committee said today that William Proxmire, the panel's chairman, probably had the bare minimum of votes to bring to the Senate floor a bill that would save New York City from default.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) Congressional tax experts have prepared figures showing what the House Ways and Means Committee's 1976 individual income tax reduction plan would mean to some typical taxpayers.

title: Miss Croog Is Wed To Dr. H. K. Varmer
description: Elizabeth Ann Croog of Chevy Chase, Md., assistant general counsel of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, was married there yesterday to Dr. Hans K. Varmer of College Park, Md., a dentist. United States District Court Judge Gerhard Gesell performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: F.P.C. Aides Unsure on Natural Gas Delivery Data
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Senior Federal Power Commission officials told Congress today that they did not know how many natural gas producers might be failing to meet delivery obligations to interstate pipelines or by how much deliveries could be increased.

title: Former Intelligence Officer Sues for C.I.A. Files on Him
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) A former intelligence officer, John Marks, has filed a freedom of information suit against the Central Intelligence Agency seeking all files or other documents the agency has compiled on him, the Center for National Security Studies announced.

Forego was not named to start in the twomile classic yesterday morning when entries closed because the 5yearold gelding, last year's Horse of the Year, had suffered a slight filling in the left front ankle and was being sent to

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Several members of the Senate Banking Committee said today that William Proxmire, thel panel's chairman, probably had the bare minimum of votes to bring to the Senate floor a bill that would save New York City from default.

description: The First National City Bank of New York, the Bank of America in San Francisco and more than a dozen other major banks around the country announced quarterpoint reductions yesterday in their prime lending rates.

title: F.D.A. Recalls 87,000 Cans of Hearts of Palm
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) 1More than 87,000 cans of palm hearts packed in Brazil were recalled by the Food and prug Administration because of ipossible bacteria contamination, the agency said yesterday.

description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Friday.

title: KISSINGER IS HOME FROM CHINA TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) Secretary of State Kissinger returned today from a weeklong visit to China and Japan, saying that he had held very useful talks and found Chairman Mao Tsetung in full control.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES Winnipeg 5, Denver 7. New England 1., Toronto 4. Phoenix 4, Calgary 3.

title: PASADENA MUSEUM RENAMED FOR SIMON
description: PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 24 (AP)Over objections by some local citizens on its board and a donor's threat to withdraw support, the name of the Pasadena Art Museum has been changed to the Norton Simon Museum of Art at Pasadena.

title: Hughes and Fellow Judges Tour Prison
description: CLINTON, Oct. 24Richard J. Hughes, Chief Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court, led a group of about 40 judges on a tour of the Correctional Institution for Women here today and then told some troubled inmates that they could expect improvement in the state's parole procedures.

title: Officials Foresee Dire Effects On Businesses if City Defaults
description: City and state officials warned members of a House of Representatives subcommittee here yesterday that a default by New York City would have a disastrous effect on small businesses, leading hundreds of them into bankruptcy and throwing thousands of people out of work.

title: Consultants Scale Down Proposals for Stewart Airport
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Oct. 24Sharply scaling down its blueprint to turn Stewart Airport into the metropolitan area's fourth major jetport, the consulting concern that proposed a $1billion development plan in 1973 now says it sees the airport serving a far more limited market of charter flights and local air traffic for at least another decade.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: As decade followed decade, it did not always seem that Mr. Davie's work was sustained by any particular principle of inner growth. Attitudes aged. Surprises were not renewed: But those early paintings still have their power to invigorate, and at Gimpel & Weitzenhoffer, 1040 Madison Avenue at 79th Street, 10 of them are on view through Nov. 13. They transfer commendably well from their European context.

title: Bach's Violin Partitas Played By Leonhardt on Harpsichord
description: What might have looked like a gimmick turned out to be an unusually provocative evening of music making Thursday at Alice Tully Hall. Gustav Leonhardt was the recitalist, and his programafter the introductory Toccata in E minor (B.W.V. 914) consisted of his own harpsichord arrangements of the solo violin Partitas in B minor, E and D minor.

title: Bank of Japan Cuts Back Its Discount Rate to 6.5%
description: TOKYO, Oct. 24The one percentage point cut by the Bank of Japan in its central discount rate, which went into effect today, was part of a Government effort to get the' nation's stagnant economy moving again.

title: PRESIDENT SCORES TAXCUT IN HOUSE AS NOT BIG ENOUGH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The White House attacked today as too small the tax reduction measure approved yesterday by the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: Slater, Walker Chief Resigns in Britain
description: LONDON, Oct. 24James D. Slater, a millionaire who had meteoric rise in the last decade, announced tonight that he was quitting his floundering company, Slater, Walker Securities, Ltd. The resignation was reportedly forced by a scandal brewing around a company in Singapore.

title: Stock Prices Slump; Prime Rate Is Cut
description: The stock market dropped sharply yesterday amid growing concern that the Federal Government would not rescue New York City from default. The DowJones industrial average declined 14.64 to 840.52, relinquishing more than half the gain it made in advancing from Monday through Thursday.

title: Soviets Seen Extracting More Oil and Gas in 75
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 24 (Reuters)The Soviet Oil Minister Valentin Shashin, said today the Soviet Union would extract about 490 million metric tons more than last year, the newspaper Trud reported.

description: BASEBALL

title: Cardinals Giants Foe Here Today
description: For a day, at least, a Saturday in New York will again be dominated by a bigtime football game.

title: Bank Branch Robbed
description: MALDEN, Mass., Oct. 24 (AP)Three men, one of them carrying a revolver, robbed a branch of the Malden Savings Bank of $4,000 today, the police said, No injuries were reported.

title: U.S. Will Construct Facilities For Saudi National Guard
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) The Defense Department said today it planned to build a headquarters complex for the Saudi Arabian National Guard at a cost of $158.7million.

title: State Board Orders Cuts By Hospitals Corporation
description: The State Emergency Control Board yesterday ordered the Health and Hospitals Corporation to reduce its spending as Mayor Hearne had directed before it would meet with the corporation on its objections to the budget cuts.

title: WILLIAM SEEBOLD
description: SIERRA MADRE, Calif. Oct. 24 (AP)William (Dutch) Seebold, a former catcher for the Chicago Cubs baseball team of the National League, died here after a brief illness. He was 67 years old. Seebold played for the Cubs from 1930 to 1934. He is survived by his wife, Eleanor.

title: ARBITERS DETERMINE AN OIL OVERCHARGE
description: The New York office of the American Arbitration Association ruled yesterday that the Asiatic Petroleum Corporation of New York had overcharged the New England Petroleum Corporation and its Bahamian subsidiary, the Grand Bahama Petroleum Company, for fuel oil sold to the companies earlier this year.

title: In Memoriam
description: PRESTONEugenla. In loving memory of Family and Friends.

title: Cable Companies Seen Paying City 25% More in TV Rate Rise
description: The city's revenue from the two cable television channels serving Manhattan is expected to increase by 25 per cent to more than $1million in the next 12 months as a result of increased subscriber rates that were approved Thursday by the Board of Estimate.

title: Rozelle Orders a Season Ban On Signing of W.F.L. Players
description: Commissioner Pete Rozelle ordered his National Football League clubs last night not to sign any players from the defunct World Football League for the rest of this season.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Four Advertisers Drop Spots On Repeat of Born Innocent
description: Four advertisers have withdrawn from the repeat showing on NBC tonight of Born Innocent, saying they considered the controversial film to be an inappropriate context for their commercials. Other advertisers have taken their place, NBC officials said yesterday.

title: Soviet Accord Is Signed
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 24 (AP)Corning Glass Works signed a technological cooperation agreement with the Soviet Union, Tass reported today. The Soviet Press agency said the agreement involved cooperation in biochemical research and the production of glass and glass ceramics.

title: Aviation Pioneer Scored A First in WatchWearing
description: RIO DE JANEIRO (AP)Alberto SantosDumont, a pioneer of aviation, once visited Mai son Cartier, the Parisian jewelry house.

title: Shipping/Mails
The Wrong Appeasement
description: The Watergate experience has alerted the American public to the great harm that can be done by scoundrels in high places, and the need to prevent ignoble officials from rising to positions of power. Such a cleansing operation may, however, be relatively easier to accomplish than the reversal of the even more corrosive trend that leads otherwise honorable public servants to ignore the law by persuading themselves that they are acting in a good cause.

title: Turks Ambassador Murdered in Paris; 2d Slain in 2 Days
description: PARIS, Oct. 24The Turkish Ambassador to France, Ismail Erez, was killed today by gunmen, two days after Turkey's Ambassador to Austria was slain in his Vienna office.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: To Market, to Market To Buy a Fat Profit (or Loss)
description: I marvel to this day at the business acumen and plain gutsiness that my parents had to have to be in the market back in the thirties. Without a high school diploma between them, and only the handtomouth salary of a garmentcenter pieceworker, they managed to invest in America in terms that first became familiar to me when I was old enough to play Monopoly: stocks, bonds, railroads, utilities, dividends, real estate, interest, taxes, bankruptcy.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Net savings flows to savings and loan associations revived in September and reached record for the month, the United States League of Savings Associations reported today.

title: Don Juan Said to Tell Son He Won't Interfere
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Oct. 24 (UPI)Family friends said today that Don Juan, Count of Barcelona and pretender to the Spanish throne, has agreed to stay out of Spanish politics for the time being.

title: FEDERAL AGENTS CATCH DRUG DEALER
description: NEWARK, Oct, 24 (UPI)Federal agents here have recaptured one of six convicted drug dealers who escaped last year from Manhattan's Federal House of Detention.

title: Auto Engine Is Designed to Cut Fuel Use and Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 A consulting scientist has invented an automotive power system that he believes will greatly reduce motorists fuel consumption and air pollution.

title: Hair Appointment Points To Time of Nurse's Death
description: Rosalie DiPaola Reisberg had an appointment to have her hair cut at a midtown beauty shop at noon on the day she was murdered in her West Side Manhattan brownstone. She never appeared.

title: H.E.W. to Publish Rules on Health Maintenance Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The Department of Health, Education and Welfare will publish next week the final rules that will make employers with more than 25 workers offer them prepaid health maintenance plans as an alternative to standard health insurance.
