description: (In pounds sterling per inetrIC ton)

title: WOMEN ARE URGED TO PRESS FOR E.R.A.
description: Working women were urged yesterday to push for the Equal Rights Amendment and complete childcare facilities so that they could finally achieve true and full equality.

title: Mrs. Peron Asks UnionBusiness Pact to End Crisis
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 24 The Government of President Isabel Martinez de Pern called today on organized labor and business organizations to join in a social pact to halt runaway inflation and labor anarchy.

title: Associated Press Carlos Giron, center, platform diving champion in the PanAmerican Games, saluting during playing of Mexican anthem. He Is flanked by Tim Moore of Cincinnati, left, second, and Kent Vosler, third.
Mitchell Denies He Knew of Mail Opening
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell told a Senate committee under oath today that officials of the Central Intelligence Agency and Federal Bureau of Investigation had never told him that the agencies were secretly opening mail.

title: GANDY BRODIE, 51, PAINTER, IS DEAD
description: Gandy Brodie, an expressionist artist and art teacher, whose paintings appear in leading museums, died here Wednesday of a heart attack. He was 51 years old and lived in West Townshend, Vt.

title: Issues in Quinlan Case Divide Clerics in Rome
description: ROME, Oct. 24  Roman Catholic theologians here have begun to debate publicly the moral issues surrounding the case of Karen Anne Quinlan, the 21yearold coma victim in New Jersey whose parents have asked the court for permission to turn off the mechanical equipment keeping her alive.

title: GRAIN PRICES OFF AFTER EARLY RISE
description: News of Soviet corn purchase through three large American export companies sent grain and soybean prices up yesterday morning on the Chicago Board of Trade, but then active selling tumbled prices back to below the previous day's levels.

title: Spain's Law of Succession
description: MADRID, Oct. 24 (UPI)The transfer of power from Generalissimo Francisco Franco to his designated successor, Prince Juan Carlos de Bolton, will follow a cumbersome procedure laid down in the Spanish Constitution.

title: HEALTH PACT LINKS U.S. SOVIET STUDY
description: BETHESDA, Md., Oct. 24 (AP)United States and Soviet scientific delegations signed a new agreement today calling for an expanded joint study of environmental health problems.

title: Rights Act Does Not Apply In Sex Change, Court Says
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 (UPI)The civil rights act, which prohibits discrimination because of an individual's sex, does not protect those who plan to undergo a sex change, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: 96 JUDGES HERE SUE TO KEEP AIDES
description: Ninetysix of the city's 120 Civil Court judges sued yesterday to retain their law secretaries, who face dismissal on Nov. 21 because of the city's budget crisis.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Today's Entries at Belmont
Bridge:
description: There are times when a defender can foresee, with fascinated horror, that his partner is about to make a normal but disastrous play. In rare cases, it may be possible to divert partner from the wrong track to the right one, but it may take heroic measures.

title: VENTURE IS HALTED BY GULF AND SHELL
description: General Atomic, a joint venture of the Gulf Oil Corporation and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, confirmed yesterday that it was quitting production of high  temperature nuclear gas reactors. The company was the only maker of these reactors.

title: BURROUGHS TO BUY JAPAN UNIT STOCK
description: The Burroughs Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to purchase an additional 45 per cent interest in the TakachihoBurroughs Company of Japan from the Takachiho Koheki Company, a Japanese trading company. With the additional interest, Burroughs will have a 95 per cent interest in the Japanese company. TakachihoBurroughs was established in February, 1974, to import and market Burroughs business machines and computers. It was capitalized about 59billion. Merger News Otis Elevator Plans To Study Dividend Rise

title: Franco Reported Worse; Succession Believed Near
description: MADRID, Oct. 24Generalissimo Francisco Franco's heart condition deteriorated again today, a team of 10 doctors reported.

title: Today's Football at a Glance
description: 1975 Score

title: Harris Poll Shows 73% of Public Favor Registration of Handguns
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) Lou Harris, the pollster, said today that an overwhelming majority of Americans favored handgun registration and he advised politicians to campaign strongly for gun controls.

title: In the Shawangunks
description: Five years ago the State of New York acquired wooded tract in Ulster County's Shawangunk Mountains as the basis of Minnewaska State Park. With hundreds of acres of forest lands, hiking trails, waterfalls, two glacial lakes and a mountain peak just tall enough to afford splendid views of the Catskills and the Hudson Highlands, Minnewaska gives promise of becoming one of the gems in the park system of the state. But cannot fulfill that promise unless it secures the remaining privately held land needed to round it out and protect its very core from being turned to incompatible uses.

title: PAPERS CONTINUE CONTRACT TALKS
description: The New York Times and The Daily News met yesterday with three craft unions and The Times met separately with the Newspaper Guild, but no agreements were reached on contracts to replace those that expired last March 30.

title: Kidnappers in Ireland Display Dutch Victim
description: MONASTEREVIN, Ireland, Oct. 24 (AP)A kidnapped Dutch industrialist appeared at a window today and pleaded with police to save my life by staying away from the house here where two Irish guerrillas have held him for more than three days.

title: ATLANTA UPHELD ON SCHOOL PLAN
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 24  The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, the top Federal court in the South, has upheld a highly controversial school desegregation plan in which Atlanta blacks gave up demands for massive crosstown busing in return for jobs within the school administration.

title: Step Right Up, Rubes
description: Almost everybody involved in the New York money caper is now treating us like hicks, including the slick hick Congressmen who have the country folks halfpersuaded they are going to walk away with the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Eleanor Roosevelt's Old Acquaintances Remember Her With Flowers
description: A group of Eleanor Roosevelt's longtime and intimate friends gathered yesterday, as they have for the last 10 years, to lay autumn flowers at the slab granite sculpture that fronts the Eleanor Roosevelt Bench in the United Nations Park.

title: JULIET BLUME FURMAN
description: Juliet Blume Furman, former acting administrative assistant to the principal of Julia Richman High School, died yesterday at her home, 165 west 66th Street. She was 63 years old.

title: Terry Metcalf Faces Giants today
Metropolitan Briefs
description: A druggists association in Suffolk County said that about 250 pharmacists had begun refusing to fill Medicaid prescriptions to protest a backlog in reimbursements. Edward N. Cantor, a spokesman for the NassauSuffolk Pharmaceutical Society, said the pharmacists were withdrawing from the Medicaid program until the county paid them for an estimated total of $1million in prescriptions already filled. However, County Executive John V. N. Klein said: I can't give any exact figure, but our survey shows that it is nowhere near that amount.

title: Islanders Await Ranger's
description: Last spring's banners came out, of storage a couple of weeks ago when the Rangers played the Islanders in an exhibition game. Beat the Manhattan misfits, Long Beach Loves the Islanders read familiar signs that had graced the stands during the heated playoff battle between New York's two hockey clubs.

title: Market Place
description: Even in the worst of times, there are optimists in Wall Street. The present offers no exception.

title: The Cast
description: THE MASTERSINGERS OF NUREMBURG. Opera in three acts by Richard Wagner. Libretto by the composer. English trans iation by John Gutman. Conducted by Ju'ius Rudei. Directed by John Cox. Sets and costumes designed by Carl Toms. ChoreograPhy by Thomas Andrew. Lighting by Hans Sondheimer. Chorus master. George B. Gray. The New York City Opera Company at the State Theater.

title: Chinese Acrobats Begin A Spectacular Run Here
description: Nothing is impossible as far as the company called The Chinese Acrobats of Taiwan is concerned. Even their press agent's word is as good as gold when he describes them as spectacular. That they are, and family entertainment would not be misnomer for their remaining performances at the Felt Forum through tomorrow afternoon.

title: South Boston High School Shut As Racial Fighting Breaks Out
description: BOSTON, Oct. 24Troubled South Boston High School closed early today as fighting broke out between black and while students despite a heavy police presence.

title: Events Today
description: Theatre

title: Mrs. Ford to Speak
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 (AP)Betty Ford will speak tomorrow, at the opening of a threeday observance of International Women's Year.

title: Housing New York
description: Does this city want more housing? Does it want maintain and upgrade the housing it already has, and the same time promote a cycle of renewal, replacing economically weak structures?

title: Work on the Railroad
description: The economic recession has induced most railroads to skimp once again on basic maintenance of their roadbeds and facilities. The results not only for the bankrupt railroads of the Northeast but also for more prosperous lines in other regions are increased risks for passengers and crewmen as well as further deterioration of a transportation network that is essential to the nation's economic vitality.

title: F.D.A. Is Assailed for Keeping a Controversial Food Dye on Market
description: A Congressional report criticized, the Food and Drug Administration yesterday for keeping Red No. 2, the controversial food dye contained in almost every processed food, on the market while the question of its safety remained unresolved.

title: Byrne Says Voter Polls Gained 86,000 in Year
description: TRENTON, Oct. 24 (AP)Governor Byrne tody announced tht an dditional 86,000 people had been registered to vote this year in New Jersey, bringing the eligible registration to 3,511,164 for the Nov. 4 election. The final registration list was 9,000 higher than a year ago.

title: Frances V. GuilleSecor, Ohio Professor and Editor
description: Dr. Frances V. GuilleSecor, edited The Diary of Adele Hugo, the book from which the Francois Truffaut film The Story of Adele H., the story of Victor Hugo's younger daughter, was made, died Wednesday at the Community Hospital in Wooster, Ohio. She was 67 years old.

title: A Laser System Quickly Identifies Cancer Cells
description: BOSTON, Oct. 24 (AP)Scientists say a new laser system for identifying cancer cells is faster and possibly more accurate than the familiar Pap test.

title: HERBERT BERGAMINI, A SURGICAL PIONEER
description: Dr. Herbert M. Bergamini, pioneer in the surgery of the hip and in teaching in the field of fractures and trauma, died Thursday at Placid Memorial Hospital, Lake Placid, N.Y. He was 85 years old and had lived in Lake Placid since World War II.

title: Antiques: Tiffany Quest
description: Wisdom dictates that collectors of moderate means avoid the most popular period wares on which prices have escalated and are continuing in an upward spiral.

title: Ford Limousine Was Also Hit By Second Car in Hartford
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The Secret Service acknowledged today that there was a second accident involving President Ford's limousine a few moments after it was struck broadside by an automobile Oct. 4 in downtown Hartford.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: COME ON UP The New York Zoological Park at 185th Street and Southern Boulevard, is having a fall festival this weekend, adding some seasonal inducements for city dwellers to get closer to nature and, of course, nearly 3,000 specimens of wild life.

title: Yonkers Results
description: (OTB Payoffs sublecf to 5% State tax.) FIRST$6,000. Pace, mile.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: United Press International NOW CONVENTION BEGINS IN PHILADELPHIA: Karen de Crow, center, president the National Organization for Women, leading a march past Independence Hall at the start of a fourday meeting of the women's group.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: About 500 Newark policemen are planning to form motorcycle caravan for a 50mile ride along the Garden State Parkway when the toll road is opened to motorcycles Nov. 1. The New Jersey Turnpike Authority, which has agreed to end its 14year ban on motorcycles on trial basis, said the caravan would be illegal because parades and motorcades were prohibited on the Parkway. The Newark Policemen's Benevolent Association, sponsor of the caravan, disagreed. Ronald Gasparinetti, president of the P.B.A., said the policemen were staging their ride to show that cyclists were law abiding citizens.

title: Music: Entirely Mozart
description: This week's subscription program of the New York Philharmonic is devoted entirey to Mozart, and the newsiest item on the bill the Concerto for Three Pianos and Orchestra in F (K. 242). The concerto itself isn't newsworthy, actually, although it's not played that often and is a pleasant enough piece. But what is unusual is that Carlos Moseley, the orchestra's former manager and now president, plays the firstpiano part.

title: ALBERT P. MORTOLA
description: Albert P. Mortola, assistant professor of chemistry at Cooper Union since 1973, died yesterday of Hodgkin's disease. He was 29 years old and lived at 554 Monroe Court, River Edge, N. J.

title: Foreign Workers Quitting West Germany
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Madeleine de Witt, an American citizen who has spent all but five of her 25 years in West Germany and speaks German better than English, came close to panic last Sept. 5, shortly after reporting for work at a I big Munich brewery where she made architectual drawings.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday Oct. 24, 1975

title: Intrauterine Device Also Patented
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24A patent for an intrauterine contraceptive device, issued this week, is assigned to the United States Government. The device was i nvented under a contract granted by the Agency for International Development, which handles assistance to foreign nations.

title: Griffin Has Chance to Set Career Yards Mark Today
description: Archie Griffin will probably become the first collegiate player in history to run more than 5,000 yards with a football when Ohio State meets Purdue today. He may also break the official collegiate career record for yards gained rushing of 4,715 yards. The Ohio State tailback, who won the Heisman Trophy last season, needs 81 yards to reach 5,000 for a career total and 115 to tie the official mark of 4,715 set by Ed Marinaro of Cornell, 1969 through 1971.

title: Opera: Mastersingers of Nuremburg
description: Unless you fancy long odds, what could have seemed a worse bet than that the New York City Opera would be able to mount triumphant new production of Die Meistersinger, and in English at that? But they did it Thursday night, and though the perfect Wagnerite could have remained somewhat glum over the heavy cutting that was required to bring the score in before midnight, when all good union members turn into expensive pumpkins, this turned into one of the highwater marks in the history of the company.

title: PORTUGAL ORDERS A MILITARY ALERT AFTER EXPLOSIONS
description: LISBON, Oct. 24Portugal's armed forces were ordered on a nationwide alert today after six small explosions here in the early morning and new rumors of an impending coup.

title: PROSECUTOR GOT KAPLAN REPORT
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office announced yesterday that it had erred in saying that it did not receive from then Mayor Robert F. Wagner in 1960 a copy of a report by Louis I. Kaplan, then City Commissioner of Investigations, on abuses in the nursing home industry.

title: Nets Top Spirits in Opener
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 24The New York Nets new frontcourt muscle outrebounded and outpushed the tough Spirits of St. Louis at the Arena tonight, propelling the Nets to a 10994 victory in their American Basketball Association opener.

title: Tombstone Dedication For Warren Is Tuesday
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (24)A tombstone with an inscription from the writings of the late Chief Justice Earl Warren will be dedicated at his grave Tuesday in Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Yields Show a Decline On U.S. Treasury Bills
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

title: Court Orders Doctors to Feed A Woman Who Wants to Die
description: A Newark judge yesterday ordered the Jersey City Medical Center to feed a 39yearold woman patient, despite her expressed wish that she be allowed to starve to death.

title: FIRE TRUCKS BACK IN TRENTON: More than 250 vehicles and 500 fire fighters lined the street in front of the State House, but this time there was no water emer
description: Associated Press gency. The men represented fire companies from around the state protesting bill that does not specifically call for fire fighters in buildingcode safety inspections.

title: Iceland: Women Strike
description: REYKJAVIK, IceIand, Oct. 24 (Reuters)Women went on a oneday strike today to demonstrate their importance to the country. About 25,000 of the women flocked to rally in the center of the city, creating the biggest traffic jam the police could recall.

title: SHARP RISE MADE IN PRODUCTIVITY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) The Government reported today that the productivity of American workers took its largest jump in more than four years in the threemonth period ended in September.

title: Art. Works by Marsden Hartley
description: Two years hence we shall be observing the centenary of the birth of Marsden Hartley. Had this extraordinary painter been born in France or

title: George P. Meade Is Dead at 91; Expert on CaneSugar Refining
description: George P. Meade, a chemical engineer and a foremost authority on canesugar refining, idled Wednesday in New Orleans, where he lived. He was 91 years old.

title: Leafs Set Back Capitals, 6 to 3
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 24 (AP)  Lan'y McDonald's breakaway goal with S minutes 57 seconds gone in the third period proved to be the gamewinner as the Toronto Maple Leafs beat the Washington Capitals, 63, tonight in a National Hockey League game.

title: Police Spurn Bid To Return or Quit In Oklahoma City
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 24 (UPI)  State troopers and sheriff's officers patroled Oklahoma's capital today and city officials failed in a payday efiort to force nearly 600 striking officers to resign in writing or go to work.

title: Franco Reported Worse; Succession Believed Near
description: MADRID, Oct. 24Generalissimo Francisco Franco's heart condition deteriorated again today, a team of 10 doctors reported.

title: U.N. Marks Its 30th Year; Waldheim Cites Purpose
description: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 24 (Reuters)The United Nations marked its 30th anniversary today, and in a message honoring the occasion Secretary General Waldheim said that the world organization was involved in the creation of a better world for all.

title: Scores on WQXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given over WQXR, on the 6 P.M. news broadcast and in other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times for scores; the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and radio station.

title: TOYOTA SWITCHES A BIG AD ACCOUNT
description: Dancer  Fitzgerald  Sample, Inc., has won the $30million Toyota advertising business in what is one of the largest account switches in history.

title: Moroccan Aide Goes to Spain to Discuss Sahara
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco, Oct. 24 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Ahmed Laraki of Morocco left here today for Madrid, saying he was going, on behalf of King Hassan II in a spirit of dialogue to discuss the Spanish Sahara conflict.

title: Ferry Capsizes in Burma; 100 Are Reported Missing
description: RANGOON, Burma, Saturday, Oct. 25 (Reuters)More than 100 people were reported missing after a ferry capsized and sank near here yesterday, officials said today.

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M., WQXR: Breakfast Symphony. Flute Concerto in G, Bach; Paris, Delius; Overture to Ariodante, Handel; Trumpet Concertino, Porrino; Symphony No. 2. Schumann; Overture to The Merry Wives of Windsor, Nicolai; On the Campagna from Aus Italien, Strauss; Violin Concerto in C, Khrennikov.

title: U. S. Protests To Libya Over Transfer of Fighters
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (Reuters)  The United States has protested to Libya over the transfer of seven F5A jet to Turkey, the State Department said today.

title: People and Business
description: The antitrust division of the United States Departrnent of Justice is ciiscontinuthe practice of holding advance negotiations with companies to be named in civil antitrust suits. In a talk yesterday to the Oregon Bar Association in Portland, Thomas E. Kauper, head of the division, said in practice the prefiling procedure has proved disappointing.

title: MobileHome Business Has Fallen on Difficult Times
description: DENVER, Oct. 24  Along Mobile Home Row on 92d Avenue just beyond the northern city limits of Denver, empty spaces punctuate the landscape of one of the largest concentrations of trailer villages in the country.

title: A Mushroom Crisis Troubles the French
description: CHATELLERAULT, France, Oct. 16It is partly a matter of taste, said a welldressed woman in a delicacy shop on the Boulevard Blossac. Taste is changing. And of course, the Germans are not eating ourmushrooms any more.

title: Portent for a King
description: When Francisco Franco designated Prince Juan Carlos de SorbOn as the future King of Spain in 1969, he said this action would insure political continuity and stability. The validity of that prognosis may shortly be put to the testwhether Juan Carlos becomes chief of state by a formal transfer of power from the ailing Generalissimo or must await Franco's death.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly described an action by the State University's board of trustees as a freeze on enrollments on 20 campuses. In fact, the trustees action will limit future admissions at the campuses to keep total enrollments at the university at their present ratio to enrollments in public colleges.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday incorrectly described an action by the State University's board of trustees as a freeze on enrollments on 20 campuses. In fact, the trustees action will limit future admissions at the campuses to keep total enrollments at the university at their present ratio to enrollments in public colleges.

title: Tonight's Yonkers Entries
description: Horses listed In order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing. FIRST$6,000, Pace, ClasS C3, mile.

title: 2 Ferries Are Pirated Back to West Germany
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Oct. 24 (UPI)A West German shipping concern has pirated two of its own ferries from Sweden and Denmark and sailed them back into this country's waters, in what it called a fully legal action.

title: Common Cause Urges Votes For Equal Rights Amendment
description: TRENTON, Oct. 24 (AP)The proposed state equal rights amendment picked up the support of Common Cause, the public interest lobby, today.

title: HAGUE ORCHESTRA PLAYS AT CARNEGIE
description: Carnegie Hall's 13th International Festival of Visiting Orchestras got under way Thursday night with a concert by The Hague Philharmonic underl the direction of Jean Martinon, the orchestra's principal conductor. It was, in effect, the return of old friends, since both Orchestra and conductor are familiar here from previous appearances. So also was MyungWhun Chung, the piano soloist of the evening. Nor did the program offer any surprises. It consisted of SaintSaens's Symphony in A, Beethoven's Piano Concerto No: 4 and Nielsen's Symphony No. 4 (Inextinguishable).

title: How Education Lost Out in Lottery for Education
description: When the battle was being waged in 1966 over the controversial amendment to the State Constitution that would permit a lottery in New York, the most persuasive argument in behalf of the proposal was that the proceeds would go entirely to education.

title: Dave Anderson
description: The new name in college football is Ricky Bell, the nation's leading runner. Ricky Bell is the successor to Anthony Davis, O. J. Simpson and Mike Garrett at the University of Southern California, where a tailback is always more prominent than a professor. Other recruiters had hoped to persuade Ricky Bell not to enroll at U.S.C. because you might not play much there, the team's too good What the recruiters really meant was, don't go there because then U.S.C. will be even better. But on a visit

title: Wilson Blames Carey in U.D.C. Default
description: Former Governor Malcolm Wilson blamed Governor Carey yesterday for the default of the Urban Development Corporation, saying that Mr. Carey had failed to act on a plan Mr. Wilson had devised to hold the insolvent agency together

title: Celtics Triumph, 109 to 94
description: BOSTON, Oct. 24 (AP)The Boston Celtics, sparked by Jo Jo White and a new backcourt partner, Charlie Scott, pulled away late in the first half for a 10994 victory over the Houston Rockets tonight in a National Basketball Association opener. John Havlicek led the Boston scorers with 24 points.

title: Dismissal of a Clerk For Long Hair Held Sex Discrimination
description: A Federal judge has ruled that it is sexually discriminatory for a company to discharge a male employe for wearing long hair while permitting women employes to wear long hair.

title: Judge Forestalls a Strike Against Puerto Rican Fleet
description: SAN JUAN, P. R. Oct. 24 (UPI)A Federal district court Judge, Hernan Pesquera, forestalled today a possible renewed strike against Puerto Rico's public merchant fleet, but the question of union jurisdiction on four of the fleet's ships still remained muddled.

title: VENUS SPACECRAFT NO LONGER WORKING
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 24 (Reuters) A Soviet newspaper today confirmed that an unmanned Russian spacecraft that landed on Venus two days ago was now dead after working nearly twice as long as scientists had hoped.

title: Escapee From Turkey Describes Return
description: Billy Hayes returned home yesterday after five years in Turkish prison from which he said he escaped by rowboat on a stormy might.

title: DR. MILDRED WEBB
description: Dr. Mildred M. Webb, who retired in 1970 as a sociology teacher at C. W. Post College and had earlier taught in the Manhasset (L.I.) public schools, died Thursday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L. I. She

title: F.T.C. Curtails the Promotion Of All Psychic Surgery Tours
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) The Federal Trade CommisSian today ordered four West Coast travel agencies to stop promoting psychic surgery tours to the Philippines and told the agencies to warn hundreds of patients who had gone there that the hopedfor miracle cure was a total hoax.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES New York 114, St. Louis 94. Denver 120, San Diego 10?? Indiana 112, virglrla 101. Kentucky 100, San Antonio 94.

title: SWEDEN AND U.S. IMPROVING TIES
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 20Relations between Sweden and the United States, which soured during the Vietnam war, are slowly improving. But wariness and some tension mark the links.

title: Miss Evert Takes Final, Routing Miss Goolagong
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., Oct. 24 (UPI)Chris Evert trounced Evonne Goolagong, 61, 61, today in the singles final of the World Invitation tennis tournament. It was'Miss Evert's 19th straight tournament victory on a clay court.

title: PRESIDENT SCORES TAX CUT IN HOUSE AS NOT BIG ENOUGH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The White House attacked today as too small the tax reduction measure approved yesterday by the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: Hull Benches Himself In Brutality Protest
description: To protest what he calls growing violence and brutality. Bobby Hull has temporarily withdrawn from playing for the World Hockey Association's Winnipeg Jets. Angered over the league's failure to act against what he called goons who began trying to intimidate the Jets European stars last season, Hull was furious after Tuesday night's game in which Perry Miller suffered an eye injury when hit from behind during a fight against Cincinnati.

title: CONSULTANT HIRED ON STATE LOTTERY
description: The Arthur D. Little Company, a systemsanalysis and managementconsultant company with wide experience in setting up governmentrun lotteries, has been retained by Governor Carey to undertake what he called a toptobottom, insideout examination of the New York State lottery's computer operations.

title: Notes on People
description: The Harvard Law review announced this week the election of Christopher F. Edley Jr. of New Rochelle as its first black member since William T. Coleman Jr., Harvard Law, class of 46, who is now Secretary of Transportation.

title: F.B.I. Is Said to Retain File Of Most on Detention List
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Despite recent statements to the contrary by director Clarence M. Kelley, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has maintained intact a file of most of the 15,000 names of individuals once targeted for detention in a declared national emergency, sources familiar with the workings of the F.B.I. said today.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 25, 1975

title: Commission Advises Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) A commission created to recommend ways to improve the operation of the Senate elected former Democratic Senator Harold E. Hughes of Iowa as its chairman today. The commission is to advise the Senate on lawmaking, constituent representation and oversight of the functioning of Government agencies.

title: The Cast
description: ABDUCTION, directed by Joseph Zito; screenplay by Kent E. Carroll, based on the novel Black Abductor by Harrison James; produced by Mr. Carroll; director of photography, Joao Fernandez; music, Ron Frangipane and Robbie Farrow; editor, James Macreading; released by Venture Distribution Company. Running time: 100 minutes. At the Penthouse Theater, Broadway at 47th Street, and other theaters. This film has been rated R.

title: U.S. Takes Four More Swim Titles
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 24 (UPI)Kim Peyton wan her fourth gold medal at the PanAmerican games tonight, as United States swimmers swept all four finals and concluded the competition with 27 of 29 titles.

title: Judicial Nihilism
description: Jerry Paul, the 33yearold lawyer who gained nationwide fame for his defense of Joan Little, has stated in an interview that, given enough money, he could buy justice regardless of any client's guilt or innocence. With total cynicism he says: A jury is twelve people deciding who has the best lawyer.

title: PENTAGON WARNS OF DEFENSE PERIL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger has warned ConIgress that the United States: will reach a peril point in the relatively near future if Congress continues to cut the defense budget while Soviet military spending increases.

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: 1975. by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Friday, Oct. 24. 52d day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Haywood Wants DeBusschere's No. 22
description: Bill Fitch, coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers, has a reputation as a gagster. But yesterday he was not fooling about the Knicks acquisition of Spencer Haywood from the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: Curbs on Pollution For Motorcycles Proposed by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed the first standards to control air pollution from motorcycles, requiring a 90 per cent improvement in new cycles by 1980.

title: Mitchell Denies He Knew of Mail Opening
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell told a Senate committee under oath today that officials of the Central Intelligence Agency and Federal Bureau of Investigation had never told him that the agencies were secretly opening mail.

title: GiantsCardinals Statistics
Physician Assails Reluctance to Use Lithium to Help the Depressed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 Many lives and millions of dollars are being wasted by the failure to use widely a common substance called lithium carbonate in controlling recurrent attacks of severe mental depression, scientist said here today.

title: New M.D.'s in Plan Here Must Serve Poor 2 Years
description: ALBANY, Oct. 24The State Board of Regents today required that doctors who graduate from the City College's sixyear biomedical training program would have to serve for two years in areas of New York City that are short of doctors.

description: ALBANY. Oct. 24The State Board of Regents today required that doctors who graduate from the City College's sixyear biomedical training program would have to serve for two years in areas of New York City that are short of doctors.

title: Spiritual Parley Hears Living Saint
description: Mother Teresa, the Roman Catholic nun honored around the world for her care o the poor and dying, yesterday paid tribute to a stricken woman she recently found near death in a crowded street in Calcutta.

title: Pennsylvania Plans to Buy Kahn Architecture Materials
description: Gov. Milton J. Shapp yesterday signed a bill authorizing the appropriation of $450,000 to enable Pennsylvania to purchase the drawings, models and papers of the architect Louis IL Kahn.

title: The Municipal Bonds That Count
description: Hundreds of editorials, think pieces and news columns have been written about the New York City financial experience and its implications for the other cities of the United States. But one critical fact seems to be missing from a lot of the discussion: We are talking about people and what is going to happen to them and not just about the Municipal Assistance Corporation and bankers and government officials.

title: Omphaloskepsis in the Dark
description: An average English word is four letters and a half, said Mark Twain. By hard, honest labor I've dug all the large words out of my vocabulary and shaved it down till the average is three and a half. . . . I never write metropolis for seven cents, because I can get the same price for city. I never write policeman, because I get the same money for cop.

title: Nerola Will Press Case Thrown Out On Rights Violation
description: Bronx District Attorney Mario Merola said yesterday that he would present evidence in a robbery case to a grand jury, even though a Bronx Criminal Court judge dismissed the case Wednesday on the ground that the suspects constitutional rights had been violated by the police.

title: Spanish Exiles in Paris Offer To Form Madrid Government
description: PARIS, Oct. 24A group of exiled Spanish leaders, representing both leftist and rightist parties, said today that they were prepared to return to Spain to help form a provisional government.

title: In Madrid, a Tense Drama Over Transfer of Rule Is Under Way
description: MADRID. Oct. 24What appeared to be an extraordinary drama was taking place at the very center of the Spanish Government tonight.

title: BUSINESS TO STUDY PROBLEMS OF CITIES
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 24 (AP)The leaders of some of the nation's major corporations said today that they would volunteer their resources to study urban economic problems and would lobby in state and Federal Government for relief for the cities. The project would be conducted in cooperation with the United States Conference of Mayors.

title: SARA JANE MOORE INDICTED ON COAST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24Two days ago a Federal grand, jury secretly indicted Sara Jane Moore on a charge of attempting to assassinate President Ford by the use of a pistol, it was disclosed today.

title: Beacon Hill Series Is Canceled by CBS; 60 Minutes Moved
description: CBSTV yesterday canceled the ratingtroubled Beacon Hill series and said it would be replaced sometime in November with a new show, not yet determined.

title: Hearst Case Figure Tries To Curb Wife's Testimony
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 (UPI)A motion has been filed here to prevent Micki Scott, the wife of Jack Scott, the radical sports figure, from testifying before a Federal grand jury in Harrisburg that is investigating reports that Patricia Hearst hid in Northeastern Pennsylvania last year.

title: British Women Top U.S. for Tennis Cup,
description: TORQUAY, England, Oct. 24 (AP)Linda Mottram led' Britain's under21tennis team to a 64 victory over the United States today, earning the British women their first Maureen Connolly Trophy.

title: Two ExInternal Revenue Aides Here Indicted in $60,000 Bribery Scheme
description: The former chief collection officer of the Internal Revenue Service office in Mitleola, L. I., who also served as one of the three top I.R.S. collection officers in Brooklyn, was indicted yesterday on charges of conspiring to ask for and receive $60.000 in bribes in return for favors to taxpayers.

title: Books of The Times
description: Violence, like a highcaloric intake, is regarded as a disease in our time and place. And like a highcaloric intake, it can look quite different from the perspective of other times, or even from that of our time in other places.

title: Progressive Doctors, Not Incompetents, The Most Often Sued, Hearing Is Told
description: TRENTON, Oct. 24 (UPI)A spokesman for the Medical Society of New Jersey said today that the increase in malpractice suits was caused by vast improvements in livesaving technology that result in greater risks, and not by incompetent physicians.

title: Major Banks Cut Primeto 7%; Default Fears Depress Stocks
description: Stock prices dropped sharply yesterday as Wall Street became more apprehensive that the Federal Government would permit New York City to default.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.Soviet Grain Deal Nearly Failed
description: PARIS. Oct. 24A fiveyear grain agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union nearly fell through during 27 days of tense negotiations in Moscow because of Soviet unwillingness to make it longterm purchase commitment and American unwillingness to lift a moratorium on grain sales without such a commitment.

title: Socialist Workers Seek To Keep Donors Secret
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. (UPI)The Socialist Workers party today asked the Federal Election Commission to provide a way to exempt some campaign committees from reporting the identities of contributors.

title: Herzog Asserts Jews Didn't Aid Israelis in U.N. Zionism Debate
description: Israel's representative at the United Nations, Chaim Herzog, publicly complained yestei day that the Jewish community in New York and Jews elsewhere had let his delegation down during a bitter committee debate on Zionism earlier this mouth.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold prices Friday. London: Morning fixing $143.50, down $0.65; afternoon fixing $143.50, down $0.65.

title: Court Orders Feeding Of Jersey City Patient
description: A Newark judge yesterday ordered the Jersey City Medical Center to feed a 39yearold woman patient, despite her expressed wish that she be allowed to starve to death.

title: The Screen: 'Abduction'
description: "Abduction," which opened at the Penthouse and other theaters yesterday, is bargain-basement movie-making of the least interesting sort, an ineptly produced ripoff of the Patricia Hearst story. Though it's based on a novel that was actually written before the kidnapping, it seeks to exploit the real events in a manner that defames almost everyone, including the alleged kidnappers and their prey.It's about a pretty girl named Patty Prescott, whose father owns most of California, and her abduction by a small group of radicals who want Patty's father to blow up a high-income housing project that had originally been designed for poor people.Unless Patty's dad meets their demands, say the kidnappers, they will murder his daughter. In the meantime they seek to convert her to their play-school politics by sexual humiliation, first a rape by one of the men, then a seduction by one of the women, video tapes of which are sent off to dad to convince himof what I'm not sure. After a certain amount of rapping as well as raping, Patty has thrown in with her abductors and is really getting into group politics and sex.According to Variety, "Abduction" was originally planned as a soft-core porn film, but most of that footage has been left out. What remains is numb, cruel and mingy. The writing, directing and acting are so astonishingly below par that one wonders what Dorothy Malone and Leif Erickson, who play Patty's parents, are doing in the same cans of film with these other people.

title: Lebanon, in a Shift, Sends Military to Curb Strife
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 24small numbers of Lebanese Army units were positioned in several quarters of Beirut to1 day, but the Government did not apply a threatened 24hour curfew in troubled neighbor1 hocids where shooting persisted throughout the day and into the night. Fifteen people were reported killed during the day.

title: Issues in Quinlan Case Divide Clerics in Rome
description: ROME, Oct. 24  Roman Catholic theologians here have begun to debate publicly the moral issues surrounding the case of Karen Anne Quinlan, the 21yearold coma victiml in New Jersey whose parents have asked the court for permission to turn off the mechanical equipment keeping her alive.

title: Chile Says Press Is Welcome To Investigate Human Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The Chilean Minister of Justice said today that he would welcome investigations by journalists of alleged humanrights violations in his country.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Guidelines on Court Coverage Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) The guidelines proposed by the American Bar Association could encourage rather than curb court orders restricting trial coverage, news media representatives said today.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX LOWER AT CLOSE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market finished lower yesterday as pessimism increased over New York City's chances of avoiding default.

title: India Moves to Abolish Old Bonded Labor System
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 24 (UPI)The Indian Government today renewed an order to abolish bonded labor, a form of slavery that has been in existence for centuries in this country.

title: Art: Invigorating Paintings by Davie; Sculpture in Fields of a Jersey Estate
description: It was a good day for British painting when Alan Davie surfaced, just over 20 years ago, and made mock of certain genteel local traditions. His was a punchy, forthright art heavy with private symbols. The hesitant good taste of British postwar painting was pushed aside. Disquieting forms were firmly and thickly outlined. Emblems of motor energy were allowed to fizz and sizzle on their own. For all that Mr. Davie is himself the most pacific of men, the canvas became a battlefield. from commanding the landscape, it exists in complicity with it, and in many cases it would be quite difficult to find without the map that is so thoughtfully provided.

title: Humphrey Asks Aid to City Before Zaire
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, who heads a key foreignaid committee, exploded in anger today at a Ford Administration plan to save the central African country of Zaire from financial ruin, asserting that the country should not get one damn dime until New York City was helped.

title: Spiritual Parley Hears Living Saint
description: Mother Teresa, the Roman Catholic nun honored around the world for her care o the poor and dying, yesterday paid tribute to a stricken woman she recently found near death in a crowded street in Calcutta.

title: 21 Die in Indian Storm
description: NEW DELHI Oct. 24 (Reuers)At least 21 persons died, 45 were injured and several thousand were left homeless when a storm battered the coast of India's western state of Gujarat for two days, officials reported today. There also was extensive damage to crops, they added.

title: Pennsylvania Prisoners Flee
description: GRATERFORD, Pa., Oct. 24 (AP)Francis L. Tomlinson, 31 years old, a prisoner serving life for the rapemurder of a widow, and John H. Dickel, 50, a convicted armed robber, escaped from the state prison here today, apparently by lambing over a 30foot wall with a handmade rope. The state policemen scoured the Montgomery County countryside with dogs and helicopters at dawn today but a heavy fog hampered the search.

title: School Board Assailed on Target of Cuts
description: A charge that the Board of Education had spared central headquarters while sharply cutting local school staffs and Programs touched off an angry clash between the city's top education officials and legislators at a public hearing yesterday.

title: 3 More Concerns Cut Gasoline Cost By Cent a Gallon
description: A cut in gasoline prices spread further yesterday with announcements by the Mobil Oil Corporation, Standard Oil Company (Ohio) and the Getty Oil Company that they were reducing prices by 1 cent a galon. This follows a trend established by most major oil cornpanies over the last two weeks.

title: 2 COPPER COMPANIES BLOCKED IN MERGER
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 24 (AP)A Federal court judge has blocked the proposed merger of two of the nation's largest copper companies, Amax Inc of Greenwich, Conn. and Copper Range of White Pine, Mich.

title: U.S. Official Links Polyvinyl Chloride To Birth Defects
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 (UPI) Birth defects are up to three times higher than normal among babies born in three Ohio towns where polyvinyl chloride, a cancer causing chemical, is manufactured, a Federal health official said today.

title: Opera: Barbiere Is Offered at Met
description: The revival of II Barbiere di Siviglia at the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday night may not have had the sparkle of champagne, but it did have the enjoyable fizz of good soda pop. Rossini's comic opera had been absent from the repertory for season. It was brought back with a new Rosina, Figaro and conductor, in a performance that was expertly integrated.

description: The Singer Company suffered a $34.7million loss in the third quarter compared with a loss of $31.5million a year ago, it was reported yesterday.

description: LISBON, Oct. 24Portugal's armed forces were ordered on a nationwide alert today after six small explosions here in the early morning and new rumors of an impending coup.

description: PARIS, Oct. 24North Korea, whose rigidly controlled economy last year became the first: in the Communist world to default on loans from the West, has begun paying interest on $500million of overdue trade bills from Western European hanks, Paris banking sources said today.

description: LUANDA. Angola, Oct. 24 (Reuters)The Angolan Interior Ministry ordered all foreign residents today to report to the police within three days as the liberation organization in control here began a recruiting drive to repel what it has reported as an invasion from South Africa and Zaire.

description: WASHINGTONDetente is not very popular word to describe a foreign policy in an impatient country like the United States. For better or worse, Americans prefer a gogogo approach to life: Monroe or Truman Doctrines, dynamic slogans like fiftyfour forty or fight and rollback.

description: PARIS, Oct. 24The Turkish Ambassador to France, Ismail Erez, was killed today by gunmen, two days after Turkey's Ambassador to Austria was slain in his Vienna office.

description: OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) The Rev. C. L. Gibbs of The Galilean Church has started what he calls a drivein, walkin ministry.

Off the bench, the judge is known as the took for an informal luncheon club that other jurists and county officials retire to two or three times a week.

title: Legislative Notes

title: A Nation of Cities
description: These are two books about American cities. A Nation of Cities describes the cities in the period 19331965, when a good deal of energy and willpower was spent trying to get the urban centers and their problems on the national agenda. The Politics of Neglect begins where the first book leaves off (although the books are separately published and no connection is intended. It describes some of the things that happened to cities after 1965well after the Federal commitment to the city had been clearly announced, the agenda published.

title: Colgate 56, Lafayette 2
description: HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 25 (AP)  Bruce Basile threw three passes for touchdowns and ran for one today in leading Colgate to a 562 rout of Lafayette in football. Keith Polito scored twice for the victors.

description: Outgoing

title: Italian Socialists Are Searching for Their Future
description: ROME, Oct. 23A leading Socialist official was asked this week how the Italians viewed his party. He smiled and said: They see it as the party that gets only 12 per cent of the vote.

description: The prospects for a revival of the 2cent coin, which looked bright a few weeks ago, have dimmed considerably. The office of Mint Director Mary Brooks has released a transcript of her recent testimony at a hearing of the Coinage Subcommittee of the House Committee On Baking and Currency.

title: Night the Martians Landed Recalled
description: GROVERS MILLThis tiny Mercer County community of woodlands and meadows appears to have changed little since that Sunday night of Oct. 30, 1938, a night on which it leaped into the imaginations of radio listeners across America as the site of the biggest Halloween scare of all: a Martian invasion of New Jersey.

title: Stanford 54. Wash. St. 14

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: A good movie should tell a story, regardless of whether it is merely a pleasant documentation of a vacation, a tale of a child's development, a commentary on a social cause, or the imagination's roaming over an event of fiction. Whatever the theme, the movie's eloquence is derived from two main factors; one obvious, the other more subtle and more prone to being overlooked.

title: Monahans Have Child
description: A daughter was born Oct. 15 to Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Monahan of Norwalk, Conn., at the Norwalk Hospital. Mrs. Monahan is the former Cynthia Rush, daughter of Kenneth Rush, United States Ambassador to France, and Mrs. Rush of Washington. Mr. Monahan is a stockbroker here with Wood, Struthers & Winthrop. The child, the couple's second, has been named Jane Gilbert.

title: W. Virginia 10, Virginia Tech 7
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 25 (AP)West Virginia overcame a 70 deficit to defeat Virginia Tech, 107, today on a 20yard field goal by Rill McKenzie early in the third quarter.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25The Senate Budget Committee, attempting to establish the battle lines for the Senate's defense debate, has informed the Senate Appropriations Committee that there is no leeway under Congressional budget guidlines for increasing the Houseapproved defense budget.

title: Widows' Workshop Slated in Paramus
description: PARAMUS  Learning to cope will be the theme of a oneday program, Being Alone: A Workshop for Widows, which will be held at Bergen Community College on Nov. 8. The program is designed for women who have been widowed and who want to learn to cope with the emotional, financial and legal aspects of their situation.

title: The Homosexual Matrix
description: C. A. Tripp claims the authoritative impartiality of a sex researcher, a psychologist and a psychotherapist for his examination of sexuality. He is, in fact, a practising New York psychotherapist and was for nine years on the faculty of the State University of New York's Downstate Medical Center. But The Homosexual Matrix is a work of pseudoscience and its argument is tainted by the distortions and tone of an erudite con man making this pitch: love is hate, all passionate sex is eroticized anger, and, of all the sexual couplings in history, myth or fantasy, the very best are between two men.

title: HOUSING AGENCY ASKS INDUSTRY AID
description: With the borrowing market closed, the state's Housing Finance Agency will turn to the building trades industry and unions tomorrow in an attempt to tap their private welfare funds and stay solvent for another month.

description: ROADSTOWNFor many years now, a lot of people who have had difficulty finding water for their wells have been calling on Clifford Winfield.

description: MADRID, Oct. 25  Few events in contemporary Spanish history have been so eagerly awaited or so greatly feared as the departure of Generalissimo Francisco Franco from power after 36 years.

Colin, Administrative Vice President of the Art Dealers Association of America, in the Oct. 19 issue, the ADAA was reported to have appraised $3million, instead of $300million, worth of art for tax purposes during its 14year history.

When I interviewed her in New York recently, before the release of the film, she was still an unknown on these shoresbut her reviews have since corrected that.

title: Aid for New York City?
description: When Senators like Harry Byrd of Virginia and James Allen of Alabama threaten to filibuster any bill that would aid New York City in its financial crisis, the traditional animosity of less urban states toward the big cities obviously has survived into an era when almost everything is urbanized. At least, Senators Byrd and Allen think it has among their constituents.

title: Answers/Questions
description: A: UNWANTED BEEHIVE (Oct. 12) J. L., White Plains, N. Y., claimed that bees made a hive in one of their dense evergreens and asked how to get rid of it without killing them. Mary Ann Karpel, a Westchester County reader, writes, The unwanted bees are probably baldfaced hornets; their conical nests are common in shrubs. (The true honey bee makes a more permanent nest in trees, attics, etc.) Hornets are more aggressive than honey bees, but are beneficial as they feed on caterpillars. The hornets' hive or nest is a large but temporary structure made for one season only. Just the impregnated queens overwinter in crevices in trees, etc. and the other hornets die at the onset of winter. The hive will be abandoned, naturally.

title: Virginia Minstrel To Sing in Newark
description: NEWARK  Cliff Williams of Virginia, a minstrel, will present a program of Colonialand Revolutionary Warperiod songs Wednesday during an appearance at the Newark campus of Rutgers University.

title: Sales of CarPool Toll Books Top 10,000
description: FORT LEEMore than 10,000 carpool toll booklets have been purchased by motorists since last May, when the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey raised the regular roundtrip rate to $1.50. The carpool tickets enable vehicles carrying three or more passengers to use any of the New YorkNew Jersey crossings at a roundtrip rate of 50 cents. The books cost $30 for 60 rides and are valid for six months, thus, commuters have the flexibility of carpooling only several days of the week or every few weeks.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Cut peony foliage to the ground and destroy; do not compost...If frost has blackened dahlias, dig, and store tubers; don't forget to label them.... For Christmas cactus bloom, keep cool each night, until midNovember when flower buds set.

title: Double Bass Is Beautiful
description: When Gary Karr made his New York debut 13 years ago, he was acclaimed the world's leading double bass player and only the fourth bass virtuoso in history. But unlike the other promising young soloists who launched their careers that year, Karr felt he had reached a dead end. At 20, he was master of an instrument which had no solo tradition, no following, little repertoire and less class.

title: The Need for Ethics in a Sports World of Cheating and Violence
description: Sports ethics go back nearly 150 years to the time when the great British educator Thomas Arnold and his colleagues of the public schools and universities, anxious to improve a barely satisfactory educational situation in their establishments, invented, pragmatically, modern sport from the former desport of the 16th and 17th centuries. These new activities were subject to rules that were totally and faithfully respected to the letter in spirit.

title: FILM VIEW
description: The dreams haven't changed, only the dreamers. If you squint your eyes as you look at three new, apparently very successful, commercial American movies you might Think that World War Two had never happened, that Korea was simply an obscure name for Chosen, that the French were still playing in their compounds around Saigon, and that no scandals could possibly develop of a magnitude that would unseat both an American President and a VicePresident during the same Administration.

title: U.S. Victor In 3 Finals Of Boxing
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 25 (AP)Ray Leonard, a lightwelterweight, Clinton Jackson, a welterweight, and Davey Armstrong, a featherweight, bagged gold medals for the United States tonight in the PanAmerican boxing championships, but other Americans suffered losses through the first six bouts.

title: Michigan Routs Indiana, 557;
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 25 CAP)Jim Smith, a wingbacic, ran 77 yards for a touchdown on the second play, and Rob Lytle scored four touchdowns today as seventhranked Michigan routed Indiana. 557, in the Big Ten.

title: New &Novel
description: I gave Richard twenty years, says his widow. And you took twenty years, says the girl he was with just before he died. Spouse and paramour are two sides of the same coin Richard's things bereft of their owner.

title: Dutch Cancel Defense Cuts
description: THE HAGUE, Oct. 25 (Reuters)The Netherlands has dropped plans to cut defense spending next year. Premier loop den Uyl, in a letter made public here yesterday, told Seeretary General Joseph V. A. N. Luns of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that the Netherlands would not withdraw seapatrol aircraft in Jannary as planned and would not scrap the 11,850ton guidedmissile cruiser De Zeven Provincien. Nato had criti?? the plans.

title: Newark Show: Art of East and West
description: NEWARKThere has always been a sociopolitical and cultural fascination between the East and West, and the current exhibition at the Newark Museum explores the visual exchanges between the two in the decorative arts. The period covered runs from ancient times through the turn of the 20th century.

title: Struggle Over Holding Tanks Moves Into the Final Round

In the three years since the E.P.A. declared holding tanks mandatory for boats, boatmen have claimed the ruling unfair, impractical and unenforceable. The E.P.A. retaliated by saying that apparently boatmen didn't want clean water.

title: Ga. Tech 23, Tulane 0
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 25 (AP)Danny Myers, Georgia Tech's quarterback, scored two touchdowns and ran for more than 100 yards to lead the nation's top collegiate rushing team to a 230 victory over Tulane tonight.

title: Watergate in hoodlumese
description: If you are either a George V. Higgins fan or, a Watergate buff (and I am both), you will want to rush right out and buy this book.

title: Agreement in Utility Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) Negotiaaors for the Union Electric Company of St. Louis and three striking electrical workers union locals reached a tentative agreement last night following discussions at Federal Mediation Service headquarters.

title: 90Yard Run Helps Kent Win Clash of Unbeatens
description: WATERTOWN, Conn., Oct. 25  Ike Bogosian, a junior halfback from Messina, N.Y., ripped off a 90yard touchdown run among his 190 yards gained today to lead undefeated Kent to a 288 victory over previously unbeaten Taft. The triumph snapped the home team's 18victory streak in league play.

title: Families Fight Eviction From Wilds of Vermont
description: BRISTOL, Vt.For 85 landholders around this small village in the Green Mountains, wilderness area is more than a legislator's phrase or an urbanite's dream. It is where they live.

The pictures below illustrate the steps of grain inspection.
