description: Evelyn Anderson Oakes and Steven Alan Miller were married yesterday afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd in Lookout Mountain, Tenn. The Rev. Robert E. Woods performed the ceremony.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Peculiarly, one of the most significant differences between the season currently being given by the Eliot Feld Ballet at Joseph Papp's Newman Theater and the spring season earlier this year has passed virtually unnoticed. It is the absence of the company's previous senior dancer, Lawrence Rhodes.

title: The Path to Easy Failure
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.The United Nations is an increasingly inconvenient organization for democratic societies because it can now be seen plainly as a builtin paradox from the start. More than half its current problems stein from the fact that its Charter was drafted largely by democratic constitutional lawyers who understandably lacked the foresight to realize Western democracies were doomed to a decreasingly effective position.

title: QUARREL WITH S.L.A. PLAID TO MISS HEARST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 (AP)The magazine Rolling Stone said that Patricia Hearst became disillusioned with the socalled Symbignese Liberation Army during the last few months before her capture by Federal agents, and had been getting homesick for her family.

title: Raenell Haring Married Here
description: Catherine Raenell Haring, fashion designer for Glen of Michigan, Inc., maker of women's sportswear here, was married here yesterday afternoon to David Lawrence Murray, vice president of the executive recruiting firm of Owen, Webb Associates.

title: Ann R. Thompson Is Remarried
description: Ann Robertson Thompson of Rye, N. Y., a partner of Roth, Robertson Interiors, was married yesterday afternoon to Richard N. Cohen of Stamford, Conn.. a vice president of John M. Riehle & Co., Inc., insurance brokers.

title: Compromise Offered to Brookhaven Bus
description: A band of 120 commuters from Port Jefferson to Manhattan won a reprieve Thursday in the threatened shutdown of a bus service they have been operating as an alternative to the Long Island Rail Road for the last two and a half years.

title: Art: New Look at George Washington
description: TRENTONVisitors to the State Museum will have to hurry if they want to see one of the wittiest and most entertaining Bicentennial exhibitions of the year.

title: 3 HOSPITALS REJECT ABORTION DIRECTIVE
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 25Sparked by a rebellion by the board of directors of Scranton State General Hospital, three stateowned hospitals in this area have defied a state directive to permit abortions and sterilizations at those institutions.

title: B'nai B'rith Will Counter Vote in U.N. on Zionism
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) The AntiDefamation League ?? B'nai B'rith has announced a nationwide education program to counter the Arabled antiZionism campaign in the United Nations.

title: Hester
description: If you're looking for bubbling cauldrons, eerie incantations, and a book to make your hair stand on end, this isn't it. It's just a very simple story, and not even scary.

title: Musical to Mark Bow of Black Theater in Montclair
description: MONTCLAIRBlack theater will come to Montclair State College the weekend of Nov. 6 with four performances of Neffie's Dance, a musical fantasy produced and acted by students.

title: Jersey Ballet Faces Financial Crisis
description: ORANGE  Despite widespread critical acclaim, the New Jersey Ballet Company faces a threat of failure if it does not drastically increase its financial support within the next three months.

title: The great train robber
description: Ronald Biggs is a petty crook who won a place in British hearts as one of the Great Train Robbers. He was among the 17 masked men who, in the early hours of August 8, 1963, hijacked a post office train on its way to London and made off with a cool 2.6million pounds in used banknotes (over $7 million at the thencurrent rate of exchange). For his part in this classic caper, the smalltime Biggs earned a bigtime $442,000 and, shortly afterwards, an even biggertime 30year sentence.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: UMass Wins, 2914 From Connecticut
description: STORRS, Conn., Oct. 25 (AP)Rich Jessamy ran 55 and 67 yards for firsthalf touchdowns today in leading undefeated University of Massachusetts to a 2914 Yankee Conference bootball victory over Connecticut.

title: 18 Flee Fresno, Calif., Jail In 3d Escape Since July
description: FRESNO, Calif., Oct. 25 (UPI) Eighteen prisoners followed a leader today to escape from the Fresno County Jail. Within a few hours, nine of them were back in custody. Those al largo included men accused of murder, bank robbery and assault. It was the third escape since July, and Sheriff Harold McKinney attributed his troubles to the jail's construction in 1941. He called it a crackerbox.

title: Simmons College Will Begin 15Million Development Plan
description: BOSTON, Oct. 25 (AP)Simnions College has announced a 10year, $15million development plan beginning with renovation of the 73yearold main academic building.

title: Chile Admits She Holds 507 as Political Prisoners
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 25 (Reuters)  The Interior Ministry here said yesterday that there were now 507 political prisoners in Chile.

title: Alice J. Rush To Wed Jan. 10
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Allen Rush of Dimmitt, Tex., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Alice Jeanne Rush, to Franklin Chevalier McRoberts 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. McRoberts Jr. of Locust Valley, L. I.

title: Community Center Opens in Lawrence
description: A new facility representing a cooperative community and county effort after more than a decade of planning will be dedicated Nov. 2 at 270 Lawrence Avenue in Lawrence.

title: Danbury, Trumbull Are Upset
description: Trumbull, the state's secondranked team, and Danbury, ranked fourth, suffered their first losses of the season, in a ramshortened schedule yesterday.

title: Six Hunters Are Killed in Crash Of a Private Plane in Hunterdon
description: Six hunters were killed yesterday morning when their private plane crashed in an open field near Whitehouse Station. N. J., a rural community in Hunterdon County.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A listing of brokerage stocks in this section last Sunday failed to reflect the fact that the common stock of Reynolds Securities, Inc., was split threefortwo last May. Therefore, the original offering price of the shares should have been listed as 13, not 20.

title: Lady Oakes Is Remarried
description: Lady Oakes, the former Nancy Hoyt and widow of Sir Sydney Oakes of Nassau. the Bahamas, was married yesterday afternoon to Colin Ernest Ratsey. Both are of Greenwich, Conn., where the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church was performed by the Rev. Sam Walker with the Rev. Joseph Bishop of Rye, N. Y., a Presbyterian minister.

title: The Nation
description: The Nation

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Everything is even better at A Chorus Line. During the months of playing, first at the downtown Public, then during previews at the Shubert on Broadway, certain mysterious and possibly miraculous changes have taken place. Actually, nothing of Michael Bennett's brilliant surfacehis godlike way with instantaneously shifting shafts of light, his powerhouse advances of the full company on an audience already mesmerized has been altered. What seem thunderclouds clap the bright stage into a blackness relieved only by three crossed magenta spotlights feverishly following Donna McKechnie as she dances to give herself identity among seven mirrors, the heads of 17 aspirants for a tight eight jobs drop sharply to their quivering shoulders before torsos turn to strut forward to a raggy, nagging, powerfully arranged tune called One, individuals step front to mouth their life histories in mime while those waiting in halfshadow behind them sing the buzz in their heads: what can they say that will please the director doing the hiring, what are they doing here, what absurd passion made them want to dance? All as before.

title: New Seal for Rockefeller Depicts Aggressive Eagle
description: Vice President Rockefeller has a new official seala bold, aggressive eagle rather than the limpwinged bird that he said looked like a wounded quail.

title: Rangers Subdued By Islanders, 71
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 25 With clear, strong voices. the New York Islander fans in Nassau Coliseum put into words what the Islanders had said in action tonight by beating the New York Rangers, 71.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: What else is new?
description: There is, alas, very little new in Nouveaumania,  a book that tries to explain why we, one nation under McDonald's Golden Arches, are addicted to change for its own sake; why we're suckers for thousands of new, often useless products; why we tear down old wonderful buildings, replace them with new hideous ones. But like so many pop theories of social change, indeed like Silly Putty itself, the argument can be stretched only so far. It asks a jumbosized question: where did we go wrong? Whence came the American persuasion that new is inherently better than old, that fast food is better than slow food? Just how can they sell us the notion that Pringle's newtangled potato chips are better than the oldfangled kind?

title: Linda Dornfield Is Bride
description: Linda Dornfeld. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kivie Dornfeld of Teaneck, N.J., was married early yesterday evening to Dr. Arthur E. Appel. Rabbi Judah I. Washer performed the ceremony in the Teaneck Community Center. Mr. and Mrs. Leo Appel of Mamaroneck, N.Y. are the parents of the bridegroom, who is an internist.

title: News of The Realty Trade
description: Two Madison Avenue office buildings between 38th and 39th Streets have leased nearly 150,000 square feet of space to 18 different tenants in the last 12 months for a combined aggregate rent of more than $13million. They are now more than 98 per cent rented.

title: BOB COLTMAN OPENS FOLK MUSIC SERIES
description: Bob Coltman is a folksinger who not only collects songs but also collects styles.

title: TV VIEW
description: According to JeanPaul Sartre, Everything we see and experience impels us to say, This can't last And yet change is not even conceivable, except in the form of a cataclysm. He wasn't talking about the new TV season, but he could have been. On the other hand, Norman Lear, a kind of electric toaster out of which sitcorns pop like slices of Wonder bread every morning before breakfast, is talking about the new season, and he sounds pretty much like Sartre: There's something wrong all over the dial.

title: A City Aide Opposes Changes in Charter On Service Districts
description: The director of the city's Office of Neighborhood Services called yesterday for rejection next month of the Charter revision proposals that would coordinate the boundaries of the city's service districts and set up district managers answerable to the communities in each one.

title: Headliners
description: Eugene Montale, widely esteemed in Italy as that country's greatest poet, has been awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature. Though Mr. Montale's total literary output has been smallhe has published only five volumes of poetrythe award committee hailed him as one of the most important poets of the contemporary West. His poetry is not open to easy interpretation, and follows his own credo that poems should express what words cannot convey. My poetry cannot be understood as a message, he said, but as an invitation to hope.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: I have whomped a small talent into a large volume of work
description: A familiar story, peculiarly American, seeming at times a selfconscious attempt at creating a legend of his life, a version rendered from its actual substance. Steinbeck often said in his letters that for him fiction and fact tended to dissolve into each other, he even had occasion, late in his life, when he was contemplating a book on the recently slain Launcelot, to explain to Mrs. Jacqueline Kennedy the difference between myth, as the term is popularly misunderstood, and Myth, as his revered Sir Thomas Malory would have understood it (had he, Malory, read Sir James Frazier). It is just as well he never wrote the book Kennedy.

title: Why My Technology Company Failed to Survive
description: Entrepreneurs with new technical ideas have long been floating stock issues to start new ventures. In America, scientists and engineers, at least until the past few years, have been able to attract seed money and put it to good use to develop technological innovations while creating a productive climate for scientists.

title: Events Today
description: Project H.A.N.D. Senior Citizen Center Bazaar: crafts, ceramics, food, made by senior citizens for benefit of Project H.A.N.D. Center; 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., 1380 Metropolitan Avenue, Bronx.

title: STATE TO APPEAL DAIRYLEA RULING
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that he would appeal the dismissal of indictments against the Dairylea milk cooperative as quickly as possible and that, he remained hopeful that the company and some of its employes would be convicted in the cooperative's admitted adulteration of millions of quarts of milk.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: If you saw a man collapse, fall down a flight of stairs and die, would you applaud? Not likely. But that is precisely what happened at the Metropolitan Opera the other night at the climax of the death scene in Boris Godunov. When Jerome Hines, a gaunt and haunted Boris, gasped out his last wordsProstite! Prostite! (Forgive me! Forgive me!)and went toppling down like a felled tree, a flurry of applause broke out. It was immediately hushed, but to anyone who had been in the grip of the drama up to that moment, the outburst was a slap in the face. Outrage, in fact, could be felt on all sides.

title: BAM Opening New Performance Space
description: As the final touchups and brushups are put on the last in a series of major renovation projects at the Brooklyn Academy of Music (BAM), the cultural institution is nearing readiness for a season of events designed to well utilize each of its three performance spaces.

title: Music in Review
description: Margaret Birkeland, a young American pianist who is an assistant professor at St. Olaf College in Northfield, Minn., is a decent technician and honest interpreter. This made her a good guide through the intricacies of Ben Weber's Fantasia (Op. 25), with which she opened her local debut recital in Carnegie Recital Hall last Monday night. For this attractive American work, modern in technique but romantic in outlook, the performer communicated its structure and mood surely and directly.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two public forums on mass transit will be sponsored by the Institute for Public Transportation. The first, on Nov. 19, will cover the Tristate Regional Planning Commission's plan for regional transportation through the year 2000: the second, on Dec. 2, the impact of bus and subway fare increases after three months. Both forums will be held at the Carnegie International Center, 345 East 46th Street, at First Avenue, at 9:30 A.M.

title: FORD TRIPS SPLIT ELECTION PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25The issue of whether President Ford is to be held politically accountable able for the cost of his current party leader travels has embroiled the Federal Election Commission in a partisan battle and divided its members somewhat unpredictably.

title: Short stories
description: One can hardly mention the short story nowadays without an obligatory reference to its moribund state, as though the demise of The Saturday Evening Post were a cultural catastrophe and hundreds of deserving short stories were now homeless waifs. It may be so there must be some beliefs that are popular yet accurateand certainly publishers themselves, even while refusing to print short stories, seem quite willing to admit that the situation is somehow wrong. Taking this position, the University of Illinois Press has set up a program called Illinois Short Fiction. Designed to provide one more outlet for talented short story writers, who are finding it increasingly difficult to publish their work, the series will include four collections each year. Illinois has announced. In a sobering analysis of what an author can expect, Illinois publisher Richard Wentworth describes the sales of their test collection, Mark Costello's Murphy Stories, which was reviewed positively in The New York Review of Books and The Washington Posts Book World, and sold about 3,200 copies. Moderately successful, Wentworth concludes, pointing, out that Costello probably made less than $400.

title: U.S. Welcomes Offer Of Magna Carta Loan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP)Britain's offer to display Magna Carta in the United States Capitol during the Bicentennial year has been accepted by Congress.

title: Rutgers Is Offering Entomology Course
description: NEW BRUNSWICKInsects and Man's Health, a noncredit short course in basic and applied entomology, begins No. 8 at Cook College, Rutgers University. To be held on Saturdays through Feb. 7, except Nov. 29, Dec. 20 and 27 and Jan. 3, the course closely paralcourse offered for credit at the stale university.

title: Recruiting Change, Injuries Hurt U.C.L.A.
description: There are several reasons why the University of California, Los Angeles, which made it to the National Collegiate Athletic Association semifinals the last three years is not ranked in the top 10 college teams in its region. Steve Gay, the coach, tried to explain.

title: How the New Trade Law May Backfire
description: WASHINGTONAlthough it was not widely realized at the time, the complicated new foreign trade law passed by Congress last year contained in it a kind of potential time bomb for United States relations with foreign countries.

title: State Foresees Economic Gain
description: TRENTONThe recession appears to be at or near its end in New Jersey, and there are increased signs that recovery is on its way.

title: Hundreds of Hobbies Via the Mails
description: From accident prevention to zookeeping (beginning level), and from television writing to doll repair or fingerprinting, one can learn almost anything through a correspondence course while studying at home in spare time. At present, there are about 1.4 million people in this country who are completing lessons in some 500 different academic, vocational and avocational courses that come through the mail from 130 accredited private home study schools located in various parts of the country.

title: The Sweet Smells That Sell
description: The tiny yellow flowers of ilangilang trees on the plush Indian Ocean island of Nossibe are far from the shores of Americabut not from the noses of Americans.

title: The kind of biography that gives the genre a bad name
description: Better than anyone else, he told the truth about his time, the first half of the twentieth century. This was John O'Hara's own estimate of his career, and one to which the American public would probably assent more readily than literary critics. His novels were always immensely popular, despite the indifferent critical reception some of them received; and even though no single work of his after Appointment in Samarra, his first, was all that favorably reviewed, his reputation was so great that by the end of his life he had become, at least in his own mind, a serious contender for the Nobel Prize.

title: A SomethingforNothing Swing Along the Coupon Trail
description: DENMARK and the Netherlands are two of the more expensive countries in Europe, but both are doing something to ease the financial strain on the offseason traveler. In the case of Denmark, some genuine bargains can be obtained with the help of a coupon booklet entitled Day on the Danes, which became available earlier this month and will remain valid until April 30, 1976. In the Netherlands, a similar program, entitled StayontheHouse in Holland, takes effect Saturday and will continue through March 31.

title: Oregon Victor, 187
description: EUGENE, Ore., Oct. 25 (AP) Stan Woodfill kicked three field goals as Oregon defeated Utah. 187, today.

title: TAX PLANS RAISE STORM IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, Oct. 25  President Valry Giscayd d'Estaing's efforts to modernize and liberalize French society are colliding with deeply entrenched notions of the sanctity of land and priority of capital in a storm over tax changes.

title: Article 1  No Title
Welcome to the Lodge
description: GROTON, Mass., Oct. 25Making news in Massachusetts is nothing new for the Lodges, but George Lodge, grandson of Henry Cabot Lodge, had his family's most productive day in football today. The senior quarterback for unbeaten Groton threw five touchdown passes as he led the home team to a 3412 rout of Governor Dummer.

title: So. Connecticut Wins
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 25Ed Swicklas completed 20 of 38 passes for 193 yards today to lift Southern Connecticut State College to a 1913 victory over Kean College at Bowen Field. The Owls, who have a 42 wonlost record, opened a 100 halftime lead on a 4yard run by Brian Small and a 25yard field by Jim Satagaj.

title: Food
description: That there are vogues in food is a commonplace. Within the past couple of decades, America has adopted such dishes as quiche Lorraine, beef Wellington, salmon with sorrel sauce and, most recently perhaps, chicken with a tomato and vinegar sauce. The thought of vinegar in a main course may seem strange, but it actually can be a tempting addition. Here are a recently conceived version of chicken with a vinegar and cream sauce, a chicken saute with vinegar and tomatoes and a traditional Brittany fish soup lightly laced with oil and vinegar and served with croutons.

title: Parent and Child
description: For the first time in the United States (and maybe the world), a publicschool system has become an active partner in bringing up hundreds of babies. Since 1972, the schools of Brookline, Mass., have deliberately helped raise many of the infants born in the area, hoping to reap a crop of bright, eager learners when these children enter the first grade in a few years. In this process, the school system has launched an experiment that may revolutionize both the education of babies and their pediatric care.

title: Citibank's OneStockholder Meeting
description: The adage that there is an exception to every rule doesn't seem to have much application to the banking business. The role in question, a section of the National Banking Act of 1865 that requires four weeks of continuous newspaper advertisements of banks' merger plans, still applies. There is no exception made even when there is only one shareholder to he notified and it is located on the same premises as the bank.

title: Fla. State Loses, 1714, To Auburn
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 25 (AP)A 92yard kickoff return by Rick Neel and clutch running by Mitzi Jackson enabled Auburn to rally in the second half tonight and defeat Florida State, 1714.

title: Letters: No Break On DutyFree Gifts
description: To the Editor:

description: The Nation

title: Prince Charles in Collision
description: SANDRINGHAM, England, Oct. 25 (Reuters)  A car ?? by Prince Charles was involved in a collision with another car today, but there were no injuries.

title: Politicians Differ on Inquiry in Maryland
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 25When the Unites States Attorney here subpoenaed the entire Maryland State Senate this week to appear before the Federal grand jury that has spent months investigating the affairs of Gov. Marvin Mandel and his wealthy friends, some streetwise conclusions were drawn by politicians.

title: Giants Suffer 4th Loss As Cards Score, 2013
description: Like a sleeping midget for most of the game, the Giants awoke in the fourth quarter yesterday, but it was too late for them to follow up their dreamlike victory of five days ago. With Norm Thompson intercepting Craig Morton's pass in the final seconds, the St. Louis Cardinals held on for a 2013 victory.

title: STAMPS
description: The heritage and history of the United States and the basic rights Americans hold precious are the themes of new stamps and postal stationery with higher rates.

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: Polling Encounters Public Resistance; DecisionMaking Process Is Threatened
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25It's called the twitching curtain phenomenon by one survey expert. The interviewer approaches a suburban home's clutching a questionnaire. Hamburgers are sizzling on the patio grill, the television flickers in the den. But the only sign of human habitation elicited by the visitor's persistent knock is a slight twitching of the curtains.

title: 3 Make Debuts in Handsome Turandot
description: There were three newcomers to the cast of Turandot at the New York State Theater yesterday afternoon, and all were at least satisfactory. But it would take rank incompetence to blunt the positive impact of Julius Rudel's conducting and the Dino YannaopoulosBeni Montresor Production. This is the finest work this listener nas heard from Mr. Rudelexciting and sensitive to the singers and the shape and color of the music. And the production must be one of the most handsome this opera has ever received and is certainly one of the finest in the Nw York City Opera's current repertory.

title: Martha Johns Becomes Bride
description: Martha D. Johns and D. Gregory Lambert, who are with the Bank of New York, were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. R. Bricker Gibson in the Church in the Highlands (Congregational) in White Plains.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayProgressive Toy Dog Club, McAlpin Hotel, Broadway and 34th Street; 358 dogs;: 9 A.M.

title: Soviet Cosmonauts Receive City Honors
description: Aleksei A. Leonov and Valery A. Kubasov, the Soviet Union's cosmonauts who took part in the joint ApolloSoyuz mission last July, were granted honorary citizenship yesterday by Mayor Beame in a reception at Gracie Mansion.

title: The Nation
description: The Nation

title: In Summary
description: The House of Representatives has diminished the likelihood that the Federal Election Commission will be a potent enforcement agency by disapproving a second of the commission's proposed campaign regulations. The disapproval was another indication that Congress, which created the commission, now considers it too independent. A leader in the fight against the board was Representative Wayne Hays, Democrat of Ohio.

title: Canarsie Running Swamps Lafayette
description: Canarsie, led by Dave Wiltshire and Vern Jenkins, crushed Lafayette, 3820, yesterday in a Public Schools Athletic League Division A, Section I contest on the loser's field. It was Canarsie's fourth victory. Its other game ended in a tie.

title: Lot Change Approved
description: The City Planning Commission has approved conversion of a former municipal parking lot on Belmont Avenue in the East New York section of Brooklyn into a public recreational facility. The lot, between Grant and Sheridan Avenues, is south of Conduit Boulevard.

title: Steven Ziven Fiance of Lynn Weberman
description: The engagement of Lynn Susan Weberman to Steven Lewis Ziven has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Ben Weberman of Kings Point, L. I., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Ziven of Appleton, Wis.

title: Will a Vote for the E.R.A. Be a Vote for a New Era?
description: TRENTONFrom Tshirts to bumper stickers, the campaign to add an equalrights amendment to the State Constitution is in full swing, and early indications are that the public will approve the measure at the polls next week.

title: Council Committees List Public Meetings
description: The following public hearings will be held by City Council committees this week:

title: Freedom at Midnight
description: No worse luck could have befallen a book recalling the deeply moving story of India's achievement of freedom from an outside ruler than for it to make its appearance so soon after that freedom had suddenly and brutally been destroyed from within. There is a very cruel irony in this that no one could have possibly foreseen.

title: Buckley Throws For Five Scores
description: EXETER, N. H., Oct. 25Brian Buckley played only about half the game today at quarterback for Exeter but still managed to throw five touchdown passes as he led Exeter to a 427 victory over Worcester.

title: Device Reclaims Waste Heat
description: In these days of high heating costs anything that can save fuel or cut down on the amount of heat wasted is welcome news to most homeowners  and at least one company is producing a device which can do just that for many houses. It's a type of space heater that uses no fuel of its owninstead it reclaims much of the waste heat that normally goes up the chimney by using a device known as a heat pipe.

title: Economy Mars Belief In the American Dream
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 Americans, who for generations have been riding an economic wave of rising expectations, confident that every year will be better than the last, have experienced in the last year a substantial decline in optimism about the future.

title: Concert: New Work Is Tribute to U.N.
description: The founding of the United Nations is customarily celebrated by a concert, and on Friday night the 30th anniversary of that event was observed in the General Assembly Hall here.

Television This Week
description: Television This Week

title: The Golf Clinic
description: How much easier golf would be if every putt were dead straight. Well, it can beand you don't even have to deal with the devil.

title: French Plan New Status For Islands Off Canada
description: STPIERRE, Oct. 25 (Agence FrancePresse)  The French Secretary of State for Overseas Territories announced here this week that France plans to change the status of St. Pierre and Miquelon islands, which are situated off the coast of Newfoundland, from a territory to a department of France.

description: ART

title: Charninade Wins 3d Under New Coach
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 25 Gus Nuzzalese gained 190 yards rushing and scored three touchdowns in leading Chaminade to a 4014 victory today over Mercy in a Catholic Schools Football League Long Island Division game.

title: Recycle Geraniums For Another Year
description: Few plants take as big a chunk of the annual flower money as geraniums. Each spring prices range from one dollar to onefifty or more apiece.

title: Barbara Deren, James Goldman Are Wed Here
description: Barbara Deren, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. M. David Deren of Fairfield, Conn., was married here yesterday to James Goldman, the playwright and novelist. Criminal Court Judge Ernst H. Rosenberger performed the ceremony at the couple's apartment.

title: 138.000 Workers Underpaid
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) Nearly 138,000 workers were underpaid between July and September of this year, according to a report issued today on violations of Federal wage and haur laws. The Labor Department said the worksr protected by Federal law were underpaid by a total of $29.2 million in the threemonth period.

title: MOSCOW ATTACKS EGYPTIAN POLICY
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 25On the eve of the visit of President Anwar elSadat of Egypt to the United States, the Soviet Union today issued a highlevel criticism of Cairo's new proWestern orientation.

title: Backgammon Class Set in West Orange
description: WEST ORANGEA fourweek class providing backgammon instruction for beginners has been scheduled by the Y.M,Y.W.H.A. of Metropolitan New Jersey.

title: ExNets Aid Rout By Spurs
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 25Buoyed by an enthusiastic crowd, a scrappy defense and the play of two former New Yorkers, the San Antonio Spurs rampaged to a 131111 victory over the Nets tonight.

title: 72 Soviet Academicians Assail Sakharov on Prize
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 25 (Reuters) Seventytwo members of the Soviet Academy of Sciences today denounced the award of the Nobel Peace Prize to Andrei D. Sakharov as blasphemy against the ideals of humanism, peace and international friendship.

title: CANADIANS BEGIN A NEWS MAGAZINE
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 25Since the beginning of this month, a Canadian news magazine has been appearing on Canadian newsstands. It is the first such Canadian magazine in the country's history.

title: Moscow Airlifts 120,000 Somali Nomads
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 25 (UPI)Tens of thousands of starving Somali nomads have been airlifted by Soviet aircraft to new homes In a huge resettlement program, relief officials report.

title: BergenMall Will Display Newspapers of Old
description: PARAMUS  A collection of more than 600 historic newspapers dating back to 1646 will be on display at the Bergen Mall from Nov. 4 to Nov. 8.

title: Bruins Beaten By Holy Cross
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 25 (AP)A wobbly 40yard field goal by Jerry. Kelley provided Holy Cross with the winning margin today for its first football victory of the season, 2120, over previously unbeaten Brown.

title: Wagner Is Defeated On Missed Kick, 76
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., Oct. 25Paul Brown, a junior tailback, ran 4 yards for a firstquarter touchdown and the United States Merchant Marine Academy held on to score a 76 victory over Wagner today in a Metropolitan Conference came.

title: Court Ready to Act On Atom Plant Fine
description: TOMS RIVER  The State Supreme Court is set to determine the winner of a battle between nuclear energy and the environment.

title: A Winter Boarding House Takes in Cold Fish
description: SADDLE RIVERIt has become an annual rite. With the first hint of a cold snap. William Tricker, Inc., an aquaticplant concern here, can expect an influx of more than 200 pond owners, not only from New Jersey but from New York and Connecticut as well.

title: Mayer, Solomon in Tennis Final
description: PERTH, Australia, Oct. 25 (Reuters)  The success of American tennis pros on the Australian circuit continued today as the third straight allAmerican final came up. Harold Solomon and Sandy Mayer won semifinal matches in the $46,000 HitachiDatsun indoor tournament and play tomorrow for the $8,700 first prize, plus an $11,000 car.

title: DAVID ESSEX SINGS AT BOTTOM LINE
description: Next to nothing is predictable in the world of pop music, and certainly anyone who tried to guess which British rock stars would make it in this country and which wouldn't, would be courting the gods' displeasure. That said, one can go on to speculate that David Essex, who completed his first run of live performances in this country last night at the Bottom Line (he had previously appeared here on television), seems to have as good a chance as anyone.

title: W. A. Vitriol to Wed Edwina Riker
description: Edwina Jean Riker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David E. A. Riker, and William Adam Vitriol, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Vitriol, plan to be married in June. Both families ate of Brookville, L.I.

description: Continued

title: One Woman's Goal:
description: She has dined in the Elyse Palace with French President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, lunched with Prince Rainer and Princess Grace of Monaco, had her autobiography published Women at the age of 28 and won nearly every naSports tional accolade in homeland of France.

title: Troubled Building In Boston to Install Shock Absorbers

title: How I Flopped As a Paramount Script Reader
description: It isn't every day one gets to identify with Robert Redford, but at last he and I have something in common. In Three Days of the Condor he plays a professional readera man who's paid to sit in his office all day with his nose in a bookand that's a role I, too, have played. Redford reads spy novels for the C.I.A.: my employer was Paramount Pictures, and spy novels were only a small part of the material I covered. I approached each book or screenplay with three questions in mind: Is there a movie in it? A commercial movie? A Paramount movie? Unlike Redford, as often as not I guessed wrong.

description: David Griffith, a New York City Opera tenor whose versatility has already been demonstrated in roles ranging from highly stylized characters in Turandot and The Mikado to that of an Emperor in L'Incoronazione di Poppea and of a foolish husband in Die Fledermaus, has now added another variety to his list. On Friday night, in the company's presentation of Delius's A Village Romeo and Juliet, he took over the role of Sali (Romeo, if you will) for the first time.

Berk of New York. Judge Morton R. Tolleris of the New York Criminal Court performed the ceremony in the Versailles Room of the St. RegisSheraton.

description: WELLENDAM, South Africa, Oct. 25 (Reuters)  Nineteen schoolchildren, six teachers and a driver were feared to have been killed today when the truck in which they were traveling plunged over a bridge into a river here.

description: Performance contracting, once highly touted as a method for improving student achievement, has not lived up to expectations, according to a study conducted by the Educational Testing Service of Princeton, N.J.

Is New York treated justly in the Federal aid return on the revenues it generates?

Tall, elegant and tailored by Savile Row, the 64yearold German born economist spent 20 years as a top official of the British National Coal Board and still looks like one of those benign silverhaired aristocrats who offer Scotch to the discriminating in glossy magazine ade.

description: When Lisa Pulling was teaching English at St. Ann's School in Brooklyn Heights three years ago, her responsibility was for what the children learned in school.

description: Next Friday, Oct. 31, is the final day of the ordering period for the nexttolast units in two popular series of Bicentennial medals offered by U.S. Government agencies.

description: TRENTONThe state's Department of Environmental Protection is abandoning a policy under which it has forced communities to maintain a clean water supply by imposing upon them sewerconnection bans that prohibited new construction.

title: A talent that didn't unfold
description: Alison Lurie's memoir raises questions about the importance of its heroine: Bunny Lang, a gifted eccentric who lived in Cambridge in the fifties and was one of the founders of the Poets' Theatre. The banality of her conversation as it is here recorded and the lists of her costumes do not convey the querulous warmth and astounding energy which made Bunny a queen to her circle of friends. Her peculiarities separate her; she is surrounded by a thorn hedge of privilege and arrogance which can only be pierced, in memory, by a few loyal friends. For who would have put up with her, as she is described in Alison Lurie's fascinating memoir, where resentment and affection are so thoroughly mixed? Bunny Lang's hostility was occasionally inspired: to revenge herself on a man she didn't like, she had thousands of pink labels printed, proclaiming My name is Parker and I am a pig, and pasted them up all over the wretched man's neighborhood. On a smaller scale, she wished her cat off on a devoted friend whose inability to say no reduced her life to a shambles dominated by guilt, rage, the cat and a litter of kittens. It sometimes seems that the vapidity of her friends' lives alone made Bunny's friendship worth the price she exacted; yet she was surrounded not by nonentities but by gifted writers such as Miss Lurie herself (author of The War Between the Tates), Frank O'Hara, Kenneth Koch and John Ashbery. So the mystery remains.

title: Sunday's Racing Will Start at 1:05
description: Starting this afternoon, because of the end of Daylight Savings Time, post time for the first race at Belmont Park on Sundays will be advanced from 1:30 P.M. to 1:05. Eight races instead of the usual nine will be held on Sundays through the winter.

description: To the Editor:

title: Notes: Conclaves for A Feminist Traveler
description: THE women's liberation movement has spawned a new breed of traveler who has deserted the sewing circle to circle the globe attending international women'srightsoriented conventions. One side eftect has been the appearafice of travel agencies run for and by feminist women.

title: Are the Old Men Fit?

title: Nation's Name Is Changed but Congo Policy Persists
description: United States policy is once again focusing more sharply on Zaire, the former Belgian Congo, which became synonymous with chaos after its illprepared independence in 1960. Secretary of State Kissinger is urging on a reluctant Congress the importance of voting $60million of emergency aid to the regime of President Sese Seko Mobutu, who was helped to power by United States policy but who nevertheless expelled the United States Ambassador last June after alleging that the Central Intelligence Agency was behind an attempted military coup.

description: ANDOVER  Now that summer is over, sports shops throughout the state have packed away their tennis and golfing gear and replaced them with a variety of jackets, vests and bright orange hats for the hunting season, which began this month.

description: The exhibition devoted to women's art at the Brooklyn Museum marks an important event in the history of art by women and in the evolution of attitudes by museums toward this art.

description: What do Phyllis Kind, Holly Solomon, Mary Lee D'Arc and Angela Westwater have in common? Optimism! In these lessthanrosy times, each has openedor is in the process of openinga new art gallery.

title: Test for TaySachs Set in Morristown
description: MORRISTOWNA specialized team from the New Jersey Medical School will conduct a mass screening here next Sunday in an effort to detect carriers of TaySachs disease. The screening will be held at Temple B'Nai Or, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.

description: The National Horse Show will conduct a short show in the plaza in Rockefeller Center Saturday at 12:30 P.M.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW
description: The light dim on the Carnegie Hall audience, and the conductor leads the orchestra through a medley of her greatest hits, every one of which is instantly recognized and applauded. As the bolero rhythm of the finale builds in intensity, a spotlight hits stage left; she enters and the audience rises cheering. The star, a glamorous figure in a black sequined gown with maraboutrimmed slit skirt, is in superb voice, all energy and warmth and command. At the end of two halfhour sets, bouquets are rushed onstage, and she is pelted from every direction with flowers. Fans clog the aisles to shake her hand or touch her, and four encores are demanded before the house lights can come up again.

title: People/Business
description: Back in 1922, two Russian refugees, Abraham Levy and Morris Charin, went into the lumber millwork business in Newark and grossed $32,000 during their first year of operation. The concern is now known as Channel Companies, Inc., has its headquarters in Whippany and last year had sales of nearly $50million.

title: Edison: Catnaps In the Alcove
description: FROM Newark (where he set up his first manufacturing plant) to Ogdensburg (where he tested an orerefining process) and on to Union (where he erected Poured Cement Houses) northern New Jersey abounds in places associated with Thomas Alva Edison. At West Orange, his last and largest laboratory is open to the public, as is the mansion In which he resided during more than half his life. And in Menlo Park, the first Edison town that comes to mind, there stands a strange shrine.

title: Talks on Ballot Set in Nassau
description: Representatives of the League of Women Voters are speaking on the issues on the November ballot at local libraries throughout Nassau County.

title: The pulse of hippiedom and the pitch of insanity
description: It's an uphill fight, with a crag or two to scale along the way, but the persistent reader will find some unusual terrain in this memoir by Mark Vonnegut, exhippie, recovered schizophrenic, Swarthmore '69. During the summer of 1970, Vonnegut packed his VW and set out with his girl friend for British Columbia to start a commune. Fellow fugitives still abounded then, of course, trying on alternative life styles and embracing counterculture values, but Vonnegut differed from most of them in at least two ways (three if you count Swarthmore he does): his father was one of their heroes, and his idyll ended in a Vancouver mental hospital. Not surprisingly, it is this last experience, the special region of interior extremity, that occasions The Eden Express's most considerable moments.

title: Rockaways Hearing Set for Tomorrow
description: Land development policies on the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens, long a subject of controversy, will be the focus of a daylong hearing tomorrow by a state legislative committee.

It was the first National Basketball Association triumph for New York in two starts, and the Cavaliers, who looked ragged and disorganized, lost their second straight game.

description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 25 (AP)  The Fraternal Order of Police rejected a compromise contract offer made by the City Council today and a strike by nearly 600 policemen entered its fourth day.

description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 25, (AP)Scott Burk and Robert Turner each ran for two touchdowns to lift Oklahoma State to a surprisingly easy 3519 Big Eight football victory over Kansas today.

description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 25 (UFl)Former Depul Foreign Minister Dim??e Belovski has been named Ambassador to Washington, the official press agency Tanyug announced. Mr. Belovski succeeds Toma Granfil in the post.

title: McGovern Takes Major Share Of Blame for His 1972 Defeat
description: AMES, Iowa, Oct. 25Senator George McGovern said tonight that his defeat in the 1972 Presidential campaign resulted not from a pu??c repudiation of change but from the electorate's rejection of what they perceived to be a confusion and uncertainty of leadership.

title: The Men Who Run Baseball
description: Baseball must be a great game, a wise man wrote many years ago. It survives the men who run it. The men who were running baseball then are all gone today, but the breed is not diminished. Somehow the game continues to attract a familiar typeupright, Godfearing men, more or less lawabiding, with few noticeable flaws except selfishness, arrogance, insensivity and bullheaded obstinacy. It is a pity so few of the men who own baseball attended the World Series. They probably would have enjoyed it and they might have learned something about the product they have for sale. It is a measure of their dedication to the sport that most of them found something else to do.

title: California Upset, 2814, By U.C.L.A.
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 (AP)John Sciarra, a quarterback, scored two touchdowns and passed for one today as U.C.L.A. upset 19thranked California, 2814, in a Pacific8 Conference game.

title: The Visit
description: My mother has four rooms with a balcony on the 16th floor of the Seward Park Project. Her windows look onto Grand Street and East Broadway. The park lies between these streets. Daylong it's wild with kids and pigeons. People sit on the benches under the trees, gossiping, watching the crowd that strolls bymommas and babies, gangs of adolescents, women with shopping bags, men with newspapers. Puerto Ricans, Chinese, Jews. Nameless elements enter the park at night.

title: Double Bogey Golf:
description: Our ancestors knew. They knew that what a man was born to, he would remain all his life. Don't struggle. Accept things as they are. Your reward is in Heaven. In the meantime, float uncomplainingly on the choppy river of life, occasionally submerging and gulping huge mouthfuls of water before coming up for air.

title: Lions Fall, 410, to Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 25Jeff Rebholz, a sophomore quarterback making his second varsity start, plunged a yard for one touchdown and connected on a 62yard pass play for another, leading Rutgers to a 410 victory over Columbia today in a renewal of college football's second oldest rivalry.

title: Of Things To Come
description: Solid is the word for Ursula K. LeGuin. In contrast to the flimsy plots, slapdash syntax and seethrough characters of all too many S.F. novels, LeGuin's THE DISPOSSESSED (Avon, paper, $1.75) is obviously built to last. She writes what might be called anthropological science fiction. First she invents a world, complete with its own flora and fauna, ?? graphy and climate. Then she constructs a human society whose customs, technology, politics and religion seem like natural outgrowths of the physical surroundings. Finally she organizes her book around a strong central figure, whose pattern of behavior appears exotic to us but who is considered perfectly normal in that particular society on that particular world. The result is a seamless creation: everything is made up, nothing seems arbitrary.

title: BIRTH OF A SALESMAN
description: Since his forced resignation from the VicePresidency of the United States two years ago, Spiro Theodore Agnew has shown a remarkable ingenuity. He startled enemies and friends alike, even his own family, by launching a novel set to be published next year. Though he avoided the press as if it were a gang of angry antiwar activists, circa 1970, Agnew's name continually popped up under datelines from world capitals. Despite his plea of nolo contendere to a felony count on income taxes and despite a voluminous document, prepared by the Justice Department, accusing him of bribery and extortion, Agnew steadfastly maintained that he was innocent of those charges. One day, he prophe sized, he would be vindicated. Stripped of his salary, barred from practicing law and beset with legal bills, Agnew made a quick financial recovery by becoming an instant, international business broker. Whereas, normally, a man suffering his kind of disgrace might prefer to forget his years as a celebrated controversialist, Agnew regrets that no one has stepped in to invigorate his old constituency and wonders whether . . . there might be just possibly . . . an Agnew comeback?

title: Jewish Congregation Begun in 1657
description: SAG HARBORThe voices of some 20 men and women joined in prayer and song at a recent sabbath eve service at Temple Adas Israel here and shared what was left of the traditions of a Jewish community that started here in 1657. There were no young people among them, nor were there any children.

title: ART VIEW
description: Has the art of painting fallen on evil days? Many people seem to think so. It is commonplace now to speak of a lull In the art world, and one of the things taken to signify this becalmed conditionassuming, for the moment, that it existsis the general absence of new energy or new ideas in the medium that has for so long occupied the central place in our sense of what art is and where it is going. Whether or riot the complaint is justthe point is arguablewhen people speak about the drift of contemporary art and about their dissatisfaction with it, they speak primarily about painting. Nothing that has occurred in the development of the other media, not even in the much heralded distractions of multimedia, has changed this fundamental disposition to regard painting central.

title: LEANBURN ENGINE DELAYED TILL 1976
description: The leanburn engirtethe Chrysler Corporation's new entrant in the contest to achieve fuel economy and low pollutionis going to make a lowerkeyed debut than was originally expected.

description: LONDON, Oct. 25 (UPI)Unemployment rolls in Britain shrank by 83,881 this month after the return of jobseeking students to school. But the number of adult unemployed went up by 56,386 to 1,077,726, according to the Employment Department.

title: Navy Beats Pittsburgh, 170;
Edison: Blighted Housing Divides Township
description: EDISON  The northern precincts of this sprawling Middlesex County community contain a desolate sweep of sparsely wooded land that surrounds a multipledwelling complex known as North Edison Gardens. Built nearly 20 years ago as part of an urbanrenewal project, the 90unit development was intended to be temporary housing for a group of black families that had once owned singlefamily homes in the area.

title: DRIVE FOR BLACKS PRESSED BY C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25There were cocktails and an ample buffet, featuring Southern fried chicken, in the executive dining room of the Central Intelligence Agency last night for a group of college placement officers. As it happened, most of the guests were blacks.

title: SOVIET, U.S. SCORED ON POLICY ON JEWS
description: Jewish leaders and specialists on Soviet Jewry yesterday criticized both the rulers of the Soviet Union for their attempts to obliterate the ethnic existence of Russian Jews and the Ford Administration for not taking an aggressive position on this problem.

description: HAUPPAUGE  The most notable thing of the 1975 political campaign in Suffolk County so far was the appearance here last week of Ronald Reagan, the former Governor of California, who is wooing support for his unannounced Presidential bid.

title: Saigon Tells of Appeals To ExSoldiers in Hiding
description: HONG KONG, Oct, 25 (Agence France Presse)  The Saigon radio says that the Government is trying to persuade thousands of defeated South Vietnamese soldiers to leave their jungle hide outs and surrender.

title: Egypt, Crowded and Poor, Looking Ahead With Hope
description: CAIRO, Oct. 25Egypt, in a strange mood for a country with 5.000 years of history, seems to he living forever in the futurein the hope that tomorrow will be better than today.

title: Janet Healey Sets Nuptials on Dec. 27

Healey of Middlebury, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Janet May Healey, who graduated this year from Newcomb College of Tulane University, to Peter James Lampros, who is studying for a doctorate in Latin American history at Tulane. He is the son of James Lampros of Fayetteville, N. C., and the late Mrs. Lampros.

Motor By the time it is Sports wrapped up next Sunday afternoon, national champions will have been crowned in 21 racing classes. To a casual motor racing fan, the S.C.C.A., club racing structure is a complex one, but it is not so difficult as it seems.

title: Ferryboat In Use Again, as a Restaurant
description: EDGEWATERJust seven months ago, the ferryboat Binghamton, gutted and vandalized, languished on a Hudson River mudflat. Since her retirement in 1967, after 62 years of service between Hoboken and Lower Manhattan, principally Barclay Street, the vessel had deteriorated almost beyond recognition.

title: Why ITE Is a TakeOver Target
description: SPRING HOUSE, Pa.  In mapping corporate strategy a year ago, William C. Musham, chairman of the ITE Imperial Corporation, thought his most difficult task would be guiding the company through the coming recession. What he did not know then was that the $500million powerequipment supplier, was about to become one of the hottest acquisition prospects on Wall Street.

title: Hurricane Hits Mexico Coast
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 25 (AP) A hurricane struck the Pacific coast today in a lightly populated region 12 miles south of ?? resort town of Mazatlan.

description: CAMDENIf you know that a combat implacement evacuator is a shovel, then you know what doublespeak is and why a committee of the National Counsel of Teachers has been formed to fight it.

Arnold of Oberlin, Ohio, an associate development scientist for the B. F. Goodrich Technical Center at Avon Lake. Ohio.

title: ESKIMOS HARRIED BY SNOWMOBILES
description: A change in the lifestyle of Canadian Eskimos, who now hunt with snowmobiles rather than with dog teams, has brought with it serious problems of hearing losses, a study conducted by a group of scientists and audiologists from McGill University has disclosed

title: Colleges Schedule Interterm Courses
description: MADISONMost of New Jersey's private colleges and universities are again offering extensive programs of special courses between the autumn and spring sessions, mostly in January. So popular has the program become that some of the classes were fileld by midOctober.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Jack Dempsey, the 80yearold former heavyweight boxing champion known as the Manassa Mauler was reported in stable condition yesterday at New York University Hospital, He was admitted earlier in the day for observation after becoming ill at his midtown apartment.

title: Book Ends
description: Early Curtain. Publication dates these days are sometimes as arbitrary as Washington's Birthdayespecially in the case of big books with a good deal of advance interest assuring strong sales. In such cases reviews, if good. are considered the icing on the cake and, if badwell, like the offBroadway show that never opens to the critics, they have been at least partially circumvented. With most books, of course, the publishers want review attention and deplore toopremature reviews on the theory that if they send customers into the stores clamoring for books that aren't there. the ardor will be permanently quenched, or at least dampened.

title: BRIDGE
description: A golf pro, challenging for a major title, who achieved victory by holing out from an impossible lie in the depths of a wood might feel much the same as the Israeli team did in the recent European Bridge Championships in Brighton, England. With three rounds remaining Italy had a commanding lead, but what mattered was the second position, which carried with it the right to represent Europe in the 1976 world championship.

title: C. O. Taplin, Miss Laundon Plan Wedding
description: Lloyd Carpenter Laundon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Samuel Laundon of Darien, Conn., and Paget, Bermuda, plans to be married in May to Courtenay Olney Taplin of Painesville, Ohio.

title: An Interim Successor to Curran Is Expected to Be Named Here
description: An interim United States Attorney is expected to he appointed this week to replace Paul J. Curran in the key post of chief Federal prosecutor here.

title: ATOM POWER CURB WEIGHED ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25The newest hit show in California is a marathon debate over atomic power.

title: Counting the Employed, Not the Unemployed
description: The third quarter's rebound in economic activity should have dispelled the notion that the recession is lingering, but it hasn't, for some feel recovery has yet to begin. A large number of peoplewellintentioned, to be sureargue that the unemployment rate, at 8.3 per cent, is still about twice as high as normal and is unlikely to fall below 7 per cent for another year.

title: Carey, Before a Jury, Denies He Aided Brother's Company
description: Governor Carey testified under oath on Friday before a Federal grand jury here that is looking into allegations that he intervened with Government officials to assist his brother's oil company when the Governor was a Representative from Brooklyn.

title: Mansfield Gives Warning On Arms Sales to Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI)  Mike Mansfield, thej Senate Majority Leader, warned today that large sales of arms to Middle East countries could jeopardize the stability of the region and world peace.

title: Braves Top Warriors; McAdoo: 36
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 25 (AP)Bob McAdoo scored 36 points, including 23 in a devastating secondhalf performance, in leading the Buffalo Braves to a seasonopening 10492 victory over the defending National Basketball Association champion Golden State Warriors tonight.

title: South African Is Seeking To Buy Newspaper Chain
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sunday, Oct. 26 (Agence FrancePresse)  Louis Luyt, who controls this country's fertilizer industry, says he plans a financial takeover of the South African Associated Newspapers chain.

title: The Region
description: As with most other things in New York State these days, the state lottery has been suffering from falling revenue and rising criticism, particularly over its failure to award certain prizes. Last week, the lottery was suspended by Governor Carey when printing errors were found on some ticket numbers.

title: Codd Assails the City for Failure To Apply for Special U.S. Funds
description: In his first open disagreement with the Beame administration, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd complained yesterday about City Hall's failure to apply for special Federal funds to save police jobs.

title: Events Today
description: Protect H.A.N.D. Senior Citizen Center Bazaar: crafts, ceramics, food, made by senior citizens for benefit of Project H.A.N.D. Center; 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., 1380 Metropolitan Avenue, Bronx.

title: Mississippi Houseboat: Delights and Disasters
description: WHEN I was invited to share a week with friends just idling around on a houseboat among the islands and bottomlands of the tipper Mississipi River, it seemed a drea?? vacation come true. I had visions of us drifting through the soft currents of those isolated backwaters looking at wildlife and sleepy Victorian rivertowns and painted sunsets.

title: Program of Rock At Garden Headed By Isley Brothers
description: Friday was dubbed Fight the Power Day in New York, but it had nothing to do with Con Edison. The designation was for the Isley Brothers soul group on the occasion of its Madison Square Garden concert in the evening. Fight the Power is the title of the group's latest recordingthere are no coincidences in the popmusic business.

title: CHINA REBUILDING AREA HIT BY QUAKE
description: DAIREN, China, Oct. 22 (Reuters)Eight and a half months after a devastating earthquake that rocked Manchuria, a train journey across the region disclosed ample evidence of the scale of the disaster.

title: Tufts Is Crushed By Williams, 436
description: MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 25 (AP)Don Wallace, a substitute quarterback, passed for 238 yards and one touchdown today to lead Williams to a 436 victory over Tufts.

title: Carol Brown Is Bride of S. K. Evans
description: Carol Ann Brown and San ford King Evans, graduates of Muskingum College, were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Dr. Cuyler Ferguson in the First Presbyterian Church in Corry, Pa.

title: Laurie Nelson To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stuart K. Nelson of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Nelson, to Edward A. Fagin, son of Ruth V. Fagin of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Harold A. Fagin of Scarsdale and La Jolla, Calif.

title: Haydee Diaz, a Teacher, Bride Of Mark Robert von Sternberg
description: Haydee Diaz of New York, daughter of Mrs. Manuel J. Diaz of Miami Beach and the late Mr. Diaz, was married yesterday afternoon to Mark Robert von Sternberg, a lawyer with the Securities and Exchange Commission here. He is the son of Mrs. Dorothy von Sternberg of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., and Jule R. von Sternberg of Garden City, L. I.

title: If Progress Comes, However, It Will Come Slowly
description: ATHENS  The Balkan Peninsula has always caused more trouble than it was worth. Relatively poor in resources, splintered into divisive ideological and ethnic groupings, the Balkans have become synonomous with the worst sort of national rivalry and discord.

title: Endpaper
description: Mikhail Barysnikov: I was very young and it was a very sunny day in Riga, Latvia, and my mother and I were outside. I couldn't walk very well yet and I was holding onto my mother's skirt for support and looking up at her. I remember that she was wearing a dress of chiffon with yellow and purple flowers. I remember her ashblonde hair and bright blue eyes and thinking how incredibly beautiful she looked in the sunlight.

title: Thomas Tarpey Marries Lucy Flippin
description: Lucy Lee Flippitt, an actress, and Thomas Francis Tarpey, an actor, were married yesterday afternoon in St. Gabriel's Episcopal Church in Douglassville, Pa. The Rev. Kenneth Cosbey and the Rev. Gerald Barnes of the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Birdsboro, Pa., performed the ceremony.

title: Epilogue
description: Title: In the Shade of Watergate.

title: School in Montclair Is Host to Writers
description: MONTCLAIRWriters and wouldbe writers will meet with wellknown authors, editors and agents at the Montclair Adult School's second Writers' Conference, which will be held next Saturday at the Montclair Kimberly Academy.

title: TALKS BREAK DOWN ON PACT FOR AIRLINE
description: MIAMI, Oct. 25 (AP)  A tentaive agreement that was to have endded the strike against National Airlines broke down today and negotiations were called off, Federal mediators said.

title: Article 5  No Title
Prices of Buildings in Manhattan Falling Sharply
description: Prices for Manhattan apartment buildings have plummeted in the last two years, with the values of some elevator apartment houses dropping by as much as 50 per cent in that period.

title: Byrne Critics Plan 3d Party
description: NEWARKJeffrey C. Ketterson, who rocked the state government last spring with charges of improprieties in the Byrne administration, has left Trenton and returned to his job as an assistant dean at Seton Hall Law School here. He is quietly using his new image as a crusader to establish what he hopes may become a third political party in New Jersey.

title: U.S. Will Close Offices Here on Veterans Day
description: Tomorrow is the Federal observance of Veterans Day, and post offices and all Federal offices will be closed.

title: Carey Downs New Hyde Park, 228
description: Carey handed New Hyde Park its first defeat yesterday, 228., New Hyde Park's loss left Great Neck, North, a 227 victory over Island Trees, alone at the top of Conference V.

title: Acting Company
description: they would just as soon settle down here permanentlya step which Houseman thinks would be the kiss of death.

title: Northeastern Routed
description: DURHAM, N.H., Oct. 25 (AP), A sophomore tailback, Bill Burnham, scored two touchdowns as the University of New Hampshire erupted for a school record 35 points in the second quarter and went on to trounce Northeastern, 567, today.

title: Foster Homes: A Matter of Loving, But Not Too Much
description: Four young sisters who say they never want to return to their natural mother are waiting anxiously with their foster parents for a judge's decision that will determine whether the girls are returned to their mother or remain with their foster parents.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1975

title: SUICIDE DEBATED BY PSYCHIATRISTS
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 24Is suicide necessarily a negative act? Are there circumstances under which it is a courageous choice of death rather than a pathological escape from life? Should psychiatrists always intervene in the plans of a suicidal patient?

title: Rutgers Fund Names Talbott as Head
description: NEW BRUNSWICKMalcolm D. Talbott of Newark has been named president of the Rutgers University Foundation.

title: Volunteers Play and Coo to Try to Stimulate Retarded Babies
description: LIVINGSTONIt would be easy to dismiss the scene as just another group of doting grandmothers playing with their grandchildren. Only after moving slowly through the crowded room does it become apparent that the babies are different, that the intensity of the playing, the coddling and the cooing is special.

title: The Movement Man
description: He grew up in Detroit but Spencer Haywood sounded as if he understood New York as much as he understood the Knicks.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: World Series Interference/Good English
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SOLAR PARK CITIES IN DESERTS URGED
description: In an effort to make arid lands more habitable, specialists from those regions, which cover more than a third of the earth's land surface, met in Boston in the last two days and heard some novel proposals.

title: Cipriano Mera Sanz Dies at 78; A General in Spanish Civil War
description: PARIS, Oct. 25  Cipriano Mera Sanz, one of the top generals in the Spanish Civil War on the republican side, died today of cancer at a hospital in suburban SaintCloud. the was 78 years old.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: SOME of the darkest clouds overhanging the American economy have been wafted away in recent weeks by the winds of a brisker business rebound than expected. The fresh atmosphere should have created a more sanguine outlook, butfor various reasonsdoubt remains that the storm has passed.

title: Passaic Valley Routs Bergenfield, 28 to 0
description: Passaic Valley, unbeaten, untied and unscored upon, continued yesterday, defeating Bergenfield, 280, for its fifth victory.

title: Washington novels
description: Ward Just made the wise observation elsewhere that the eternal enemy of the Washington novel is melodrama. William Bradford Huie's new novel In the Hours of Night, about the atomic bomb secrets of the 1940's, is an unfortunate illustration of that dictum. In endless Bmovie scenes you can almost hear the sweet strings and the kettle drums of a secondrate soundtrack Huie has turned real historical characters (Roosevelt, Truman, Niels Bohr, Stimson, Byrnes et al.) into pasteboard and added a fictional cast of stereotypes on whom the burden of great events is registered. The story is historically unsound, full of surface implausibilities, a dud as drama.

title: R.P.I. Beaten, 2613
description: TROY, N. Y., Oct. 25 (AP) Paul Adamo passed for two touchdowns as the Rochester Institute of Technology defeated Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, 26.13, today.

title: SWEDEN PROPOSES EASED RETIREMENT
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 20The Swedish Government, seeking to cope with an increasingly large population over the age of 65, has devised an unusual national pension plan designed to ease retirement for men and women long accustomed to busy workaday living.

title: CHESS
description: While the Najdorf Sicilian makes more severe demands on the defense than any other opening, it continues to attract the greatest number of practitioners. For all of their tortuous complexity, the slowly developing formations of the Najdorf are fundamentally sound: if the treacherous storms of the opening and early middle game can be surmounted, a bright rainbow of victory beckons.

title: Togetherness Is The Acting Company
description: At one point in The Robber Bridegroomthe musical folk fantasy with which John Houseman's Acting Company opened its current engagement at the Harkness Theatera Mississippi River steamboat leaves the wharf amid a flurry of smoke, a flashing of paddlewheels, a churning of waters, and cheers and songs from the assembled crowd. Only there is no steamboat, no wharf, no smoke, no paddlewheels and no water. The whole thing is accomplished with a few planks and sawhorses, superb timing, and lots of youthful verve.

title: Pumpkin Is More Than Pie
description: The question is: How many pumpkins, picked or purchased during October's glowing russet days, actually make it to the dinner table in some form other than a centerpiece? And of those, how many are destined to become something other than pie?

title: Home Clinic
description: Q. Our house is 10 years old and we have a problem with our driveway. It has cracked horribly in big chunks and also sunk so that it is now at least 2 inches lower than the sidewalk next to it. What went wrong, what can we do to correct this?Mrs. P.M.C., Jersey City, N. J.

title: Quakers Win in 2d Half, 2420
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 25 Penn beat Princeton, 2420. today in another of those Ivy League results that was supposed to come out the other way.

title: Mondale Found He Wasn't
description: WASHINGTONWalter Mondale's conscience still stands as a commentary on the developing frenzy of next year's Presidential campaign. The Minnesota Senator was out fishing with his teenaged son in the northern wilds of his home state during the recent Congressional recessa suitably rich but private reward for the man who bailed out of the Presidential race a year ago just as the first of a swarm of candidates, all seemingly lusting for the hustings, were getting in.

title: J. B. Black Fiance Of Joyce Fenmore
description: Joyce Rochelle Fenmore, an assistant to the city's Deputy Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, plans to be married next month to Jerry Bernard Black, who is with the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore.

title: FOLK MUSIC OFFERED BY AZTEC TWOSTEP
description: When the opening performer, Billy Mernit, sings of the Big Apple Fantasy, the group Aztec TwoStep gives out with Lullaby of New York and the whole affair takes place at the Other End club on Bleecker Street on Thursday, it's fairly safe to assume a little more life is being kicked into the Village folk music scene of late.

title: STUDY ON BUGGING BY N.S.A. REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 The Department of Justice is conducting a top secret special project to wrestle with the legal questions raised by the National Security Agency's domestic and international electronic eavesdropping, according to law enforcement sources.

title: Wallace Ends 2Week Tour Abroad
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 25 (UPI)Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama ended his twoweek European tour today still looking like a Presidential candidate but saying nothing to confirm that he is in the race.

title: LETTERS
description: Planning

title: Striking Teachers Post Bond
description: BELLEVILLE, Ill., Oct. 25 (UPI)More than 100 striking, teachers marched to the St. Clair county jail and turned themselves in today, obeying court orders to surrender or he arrested in their homes Three judges arraigned the 105 teachers on charges of disobeying orders to stop picketing Cahokia District schools. Each was, released after posting $100 bond.

title: Correction
description: In last week's Book Review the credits for the three major photographs on page 5 should have read, From the top, Thomas Victor. Jill Krementz, Jerry Bauer.

title: Hell on Venus
description: The engineers and scientists responsible for the Soviet Unio Venera 9 and 10 probes of Venus have accomplished some very remarkable feats.

title: The World
description: Spain finally is moving into the postFranco era, yet even without the dictator to thwart liberalization, there are many obstacles that will make it difficult for the nation to achieve democracy.

title: Elmont Runners Take Home Title
description: KINGS PARK, L. I., Oct. 25Elmont scored 57 points to win the Nassau County South Shore Scholastic CrossCountry Championship today at Sunken Meadow Park. Kennedy of Bellmore was second with 74. Rich Paperno was the individual winner, clocking 15 minutes 37 seconds for the hilly 3mile course.

title: Ballet: The Panovs in Bridgeport
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 24The appearance here tonight of Valery and Galina Panov with the Greater Bridgeport Ballet Company at the Klein Memorial Auditorium was the first time the Panovs had appeared in the East Coast area in the circumstances of a normal auditorium. Other appearances had all been made either in arenas or summer theaters.

title: Baruch Project Amassing Data to Help City in Its Fiscal Crisis
description: Secreted in ledgers, file cabinets, desk drawers and computer memories around the city are millions of facts about New York that, if they were made public and put together in meaningful ways, could point toward new and more effective strategies for moving the city out of its economic troubles.

title: British Champion To Risk Ring Title
description: LONDON, Oct. 23 (AP)Richard Dunn, who has been British and Commonwealth heavyweight, boxing champion for only three weeks, will defend his title against Danny McAlinden at Wembley on Nov. 4, Harry Levene, the promoter, has announced.

title: 300 Apply as Interviews Begin For Job as Barnard's President
description: The Presidential Search Committee of Barnard College has begun interviewing the more that 300 persons who applied for the post of president, which has been vacant since the resignation of Dr. Martha E. Peterson last June.

title: Miss Fitzmaurice Wed to Boyd Finch
description: Christopha Anne Fitzmaurice, daughter of Mrs. Richard L. Duncan of New York and Newfane, Vt., and the late Michael Fitzmaurice, was married yesterday afternoon to Boyd Finch, son of Mrs. George Boyd Finch of Branford, Conn., and the late Dr. Finch, a dentist.

title: Group Plan Beats Wajima by Neck
description: H. Allen Jerkens, who through the years has gained the reputation as being a trainer who produces giantkillers, did it again yesterday at Belmont Park as he saddled Hobeau Farm's Group Plan to an upset triumph, by a neck, over EastWest Stable's highly favored Wajima.

title: A ragbag of history continued
description: On they go, the Durants, telling what they believe to he the Story of Civilization. Well promoted, neatly packaged, their books sell massively. However, I suspect they are but rarely read from cover to cover. Probably the Durants do not intend that their books should he, for their technique is very much biased against a steady read. I suspect the books are merely used fly schoolchildren for a potted paragraph on a project, or picked up to fill in an idle ten minutes by those who have succumbed to the alluring blurb or to a sycophantic reviewer. At such a level, the Durants are, in a sense, most accomplished. But their publishers promote them as historians of outstanding genius and, although this is no longer so widely believed as it was, such serious claims must be treated seriously.

title: State Owns Three Nude Bars in Islip
description: ISLIPThe State Department of Transportation is the owner of three bars here that offer nude dancers as entertainment.

title: Patsy Mink Announces Bid For Hawaii Senate Seat
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 25 (AP)Representative Patsy T. Mink, Democrat of Hawaii, announced today that she would seek the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate seat now held by Hiram Fong, a Republican.

title: Soviet Expands Weapons Aid to Syria
description: Expanded deliveries of arms and munitions by the Soviet Union to Syria and an expected increase in the number of Russian military advisers there are causing concern among Israeli and United States military sources.

title: Quintets At Garden On Dec. 4
description: Madison Square Garden announced yesterday that it would open its 42d college basketball season Dec. 4 with the first of 16 doubleheader and tripleheader programs. The season will end with the 39th annual National Invitation Tournament next March.

title: Latin Press Ends Its Meeting, Resolving to Resist Despotism
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Oct. 25 (AP)  The InterAmerican Press Association says the press possesses the moral strength and unwavering determination to defend America from the totalitarian forces which everywhere are baring their ugly claws.

title: School Immunization to Start
description: TRENTONPhysicians and school authorities throughout New Jersey are receiving instructional material to guide them in enforcing a new program designed to immunize all of the state's 1.5 million students against serious communicable diseases.

title: Petro Bras Is Not Petrobras
