description: New Jersey motorists who have noticed a sprinkling of gasoline stations carrying the name Petro Bras may be thinking that they represent another entry onto the American retailing scene of a foreign company such as British Petroleum or Shell.

title: Adjani as Adele H.intense and innocent
description: When she was 14 she was discovered by film producer Bernard Michel, who cast her in a small role. That led directly to other parts on television and on stage, including a performance in Reims in Garcia Lorca's The House of Bernarda Alba which, in turn, led to the Comedie Francaise. Soon she was alternating nightly as Giraudoux's Ondine, and in Moliere's School for Wives and Montherlant's Pont Royal.

title: At 71, Isaac Bashevis Singer Makes His Broadway Debut
description: When he was a boy in Poland, Isaac Bashevis Singer heard his rabbi father preach a sermon in which he said that the wicked sit day and night in the theater, eat pork, and sin with loose women. The part about pork horrified Singer to the point where he stayed away from all contact with the theater until he was 24.

title: Rozelle Edict on W.F.L. Called Illegal by Garvey
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP)The National Football League Players Association said today that the refusal of Pete Rozelle, the N.F.L. commissioner, to permit the league to sign players from the defunct World Football League is a violation of Federal antitrust laws.

title: Toy Poodle Named Best At Queensboro's Show
description: A white toy poodle, Ch. Peeples Sahara, took the top award yesterday at the Queensboro Kennel Club show in the State Armory at Jamaica, Queens. There was a field of 1,515 dogs at the 51st event of the club.

title: Good News! Dollars Again for Waste Paper
description: There's good news in old news these days.

title: DALEY, GOVERNOR CLASH ON SCHOOLS
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 25The long simmering political dispute between Mayor Richard J. Daley and Gov. Daniel Walker, the two leading Democrats in Illinois, exploded in the State Capitol this week into what looked as if it would be a major battle.

title: Christmas Boutique to Aid Day School
description: PEAPACKLa Belle Boutique, a Christmasaccented event sponsored by the Far Hills Country Day School. will be held Tuesday and Wednesday at the Essex Hunt Club. Proceeds from the sale will aid the school.

title: Tarzan was a problem
description: Edgar Rice Burroughs was born a century ago. Irwin Porges has produced for his centennial a commemorative biography, more than 800 doublecolumn pages filled out with more than 200 photographs, drawings and other memorabilia from the vast authorial archive stored in a warehouse in Tarzana, Calif. What Porges has compiled is commemorative in a large sense, also, for Burroughs was very much a child of our second century: a Bicentennial Boy. Born and raised in Chicago, he was the son of parents with Massachusetts and Virginia forebears, and his father was sui generis of the American industrialist type, a veteran (brevet Major) of the Civil War who became a wealthy Chicago distiller, a stern, disciplinarian presence.

title: Food News
description: TENAFLYThere is a mint of sorts in New Jersey, only this one turns out a product to sweeten the palate, not the pot.

title: Clinic Is Concerned With Mind and Body
description: The next patient who walks into the Psychosomatic Clinic at Long Island JewishHillside Medical Center complaining of a skin rash, heart pains, or impotence, may be examined by a physician, interviewed by a psychiatrist and treated by a social worker.

title: The Supplicants
description: Mayor Beame and Governor Carey went to Washington for help last week, alternately demanding and pleading before committees of Congress. If their intention was to play on both the conscience and the fear of the rest of the country, as it seemed to be, they probably failed. There was in the Congressional response something of the Romans considering the Christians at the Coliseum.

title: Gail Rothrock Bride of Charles L. Trozzo
description: Gail Chardon Rothrock and Charles Louis Trozzo were married at noon yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Shirley Rothrock of Wilmington, Del. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John O'Hear, rector of Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred, in Greenville, Del.

title: Jets Brace for Visit by Colts
description: An angry, frustrated Jets' defense, which has allowed an average of more than four touchdowns and almost 400 yards a game, faces one of its most troublesome opponents, the Baltimore Colts, at Shea Stadium today.

title: The Gulag Archipelago
description: It is good that the second volume of The Gulag Archipelago should appear in English within months of Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's recent political pronouncements in the United States. Uneasiness among many of his admirers grew into dismay as he offered instruction, judgments and proposals intended to reverse the course of EastWest relations. His appearances on public platforms and on TV presented the spectacle of a writer genuinely persuaded that he might change the minds of politicians by the force of the Word. The stirring hyperbole of his Nobel Prize lectureone word of truth shall outweigh the whole worldwas being put to the test. It was cause for worry; the passage from inquiry to advocacy, from exposition to exhortation, from literature to politics (or proselytism) has disabled many a Russian writer, including Gogol and Tolstoy. Gulag II comes to us now as a reminder of Solzhenitsyn's immutable achievements.

title: Arkansas 31, Utah St. 0
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 25 (AP)Arkansas' running back. Ike Forte, rushed for 142 yards, scored two touchdowns and completed his first pass for 51 yards, as the Razorbacks walloped Utah State, 310, tonight.

title: Washington 35. Ore. State 7
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 25 (AP)Washington took advantage of turnovers and bewildered Oregon State with the running of James Anderson and Robin Earl and the passing of Cris Rowland and swamped the Beavers, 357, today in a Pacific 8 game.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange moved higher for the first four trading days last week but then tumbled Friday following news accounts of a hardening attitude in Washington toward financial aid for New York City. The late decline, which totaled 14.64 points on the Dow Jones industrial average, came in spite of a point cut in the prime rate to 7 per cent by several major banks.

title: The hatred that destroys the haters and the hated
description: To be haunted by a subject, to be hunted down and inescapably chosen, as Jewish writers like Elie Wiesel have been chosen, must seem not only a gift of clear mission but at times a tangled burden. For being compelled to take up a great and terrible subject is not the same as finding a fresh way to see it.

title: 3.000 March in the Capital To Protest School Busing
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP)  Chanting Wake up America, wake up, nearly 3,000 demonstrators marched on the Capitol today to protest school busing. They were mostly from the Louisville, Ky., area, and were joined by contingents from Illinois, Indiana and West Virginia and the Boston area.

title: Twain: Pajamas On the Landing
description: SO, In 1887, Samuel I. Clemens saluted the vermilion and black extravaganza which still causes traffic accidents at 351 Farmington Avenue, Hartford, Conn. Time has mellowed the house not one whit, thanks to meticulous maintenance by staff of the Mark Twain Memorial. It Maps from the leafy surroundings of Nook Farm (see box on Page 14) like a monstrous, manyheaded turkey, claws and pinions protruding in all directions. The simile is not farfetched. Turkeyred was Mark Twain's favorite color, and this house, built in his 39th year when he was beginning to feel his wings as a writer, is a compulsive squawk for attention.

title: SUICIDE DEBATED BY PSYCHIATRISTS
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 24Is suicide necessarily a negative act? Are there circumstances under which it is a courageous choice of death rather than a pathological escape from life? Should psychiatrists always intervene in the plans of a suicidal patient?

title: Benefit for Lighthouse
description: The Lighthouse will hold its annual theater benefit Thursday at a preview of Kennedy's Children at the Golden Theater. Theater tickets are $40, $35 and $25 from the beneficiary, 111 East 59th Street. A buffet supper at Sardi's is an additional $15.

title: Alabama Routs T.C.U.
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 23 (AP)Johnny Davis ran 66 yards off tackle today, opening the flood gates, and Alabama poured through for a 450 football victory over outmanned Texas Christian University.

title: Article 14  No Title
description: TRAVEL TRAVEL

title: Goolagong Conquers Nastase
description: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., Oct. 25  Inspired by the Chalienge of the Sexes, Evonne Goolagong took four games running in a brilliant series of shots and defeated Ilie Nastase, 75, before a sellout house of 5,000 in a oneset handicap tennis match today.

title: The Fiscal Crisis Is Viewed With Alarm All Over
description: The New York City fiscal crisis is having political as well as economic reverberations, which are evident even in the local contests that will dominate the balloting in the region on Election Day.

title: Soviet as an Agripower
description: WASHINGTONThe Soviet Union, free to purchase United States grain now that this country's moratorium on further sales has been lifted and a new purchase agreement signed appears to have shifted its posture from pursuer to pursued and to be in no rush to lock in vast amounts of additional supplies.

title: Holding Municipal Bonds Up to the Light
description: Three days after A.A. Sommer Jr., a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, acknowledged that he was amazed that no one had ever sued a municipality for failing to disclose all to its bondholders, New York City was named in a $2billion fraud action.

title: ColbertRefram Ahead
Bicentennial Topic Of 8Month Forum
description: SOUTH ORANGE  The American Issues Forum, a national project, is providing a provocative intellectual element for the South OrangeMaplewood area's observation of the nation's Bicentennial. On the basis of attendance at the first several sessions, the program's local sponsors predict a popular response to the eightmonth event.

title: By the time it gets to Phoenix
description: PHOENIX, Ariz.On a typical 111degree Saturday afternoon in August, a slim, rich 23yearold heroin user named Gary kept an appointment at a dimly lit steakhouse on North Central Avenue, the main drag here. He wore a white crepe seethrough shirt and a necklace of white puka shells and chainsmoked as he discussed his fiveyear habit. Gary lives on the affluent North Side, where tall palms nod over the red tile roofs and swimming pools of $150,000 Southwestern architectural gems. It is also where the newer Anglo addicts hang out, a research team from the Drug Abuse Council, Inc., of Washington, D. C. recently informed the municipal government.

title: U.N.'s Moral Weapons
description: Three decades after the United Nations Charter was adopted in the semieuphoria of early autumn 1945, dedicated jurists arc still trying to codify the better angels of human and national conduct. There is no guarantee that putting it down on paper will make it so; but the draft recommendation adopted by the Fifth U.N. Congress on the Prevention of Crime and the Treatment of Offenders in Geneva, banning torture and other degrading forms of punishment, could be a guideline principle for U.N. member states within their own borders.

title: Linda J. McCall Bride Of Edward Matthews
description: Linda Joan McCall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. McCall of Princeton, N.J., and Edward Whitehouse Matthews were married yesterday afternoon in the Princeton United Methodist Church by the Rev. Donald Dyson and the Rev. Charles Marker.

title: Et tu, John New Revlon Products
description: The risk factor in marketing new products is high enough to topple careers and dismay stockholders suddenly confronted with big writeoffs for product failures.

title: Ode to the Lowly Slug
description: Aside from being a link reluctant in a fleshly chain Lord Byron could find nothing to loathe in nature. One can only assume his garden was never inundated by terrestrial slugs.

title: Clarkstown South Takes First Place
description: Mike DeFloremonte returned a kickoff 90 yards yesterday as he sparked Clarkstown South, the defending champion, to an 187 victory over Nanuet and into first place in the Rockland Public Schools Athletic League.

title: School Hones Skating Skill
description: SHORT HILLSIn the last 15 years, more than 10,000 persons ranging in age from 3 to 80 have sharpened their skills, as well as their skate blades, at the Ralph Evans IceSkating School here.

title: Missouri 35, Kan. State 3
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 25 (AP)Curt Brown, a juniorcollege transfer, took advantage of his first starting assignment and ran for two touchdowns, sparking Missouri to a 353 rout of Kansas State in a Big Eight game today.

title: Theft, Misgrading
description: The investigation of the grain export trade that began last year has produced evidence of some of the most pervasive corruption that has ever infected an American industry. The full dimensions of the pattern of bribery and payoffs are not yet visible, but the emerging scandal has already harmed America's foreign trade.

title: CENTENNIAL NOTED BY REFORM JEWS
description: One hundred years ago this month, Rabbi Isaac Mayer Wise founded the Hebrew Union College in a basement of the Mound Street Temple in Cincinnati.

title: Molloy Sets Dialogue on Jews
description: ROCKVILLE CENTREMalloy Collegefounded by the Sisters of Saint Dominichas started a sevenweek institute entitled Jewish Experience and the Catholic Teacher, designed to inform Roman Catholic educators on various phases of Judaism, Jewish culture and contemporary concerns confronting the Jewish community here and the world over.

title: At 60, Artist Lifts Cloak of Anonymity
description: HIGHLAND PARKWhen the Old Queens Gallery opens an exhibit of the works of Ben Joseph tonight, people will learn for the first time that Ben Joseph, the artist, and Meyer Frischling, the gallery's codirector, are one and the same.

title: Neerja Bhatnagar Plans Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Inder M. Bhatnagar of Douglaston, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Neerja Bhatnagar, to Arvind Sahay, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. P. Mathur of New Delhi, India.

title: Half Hollow Hills Takes Over Top Spot
description: Half Hollow Hills, which practiced without its firstyear coach, Bill Brown, until opening day because of a teacher strike, downed North Babylon, 200, yesterday and moved atop the AAA1 league with a 301 wonlosttied record.

title: L.I. MAN DESCRIBES TURKISH ESCAPE
description: NORTH BABLYON, L.I., Oct. 25Billy Hayes, back home after five years in a Turkish prison for possession of hashish, today described his escape, a flight in which he said he passed himself off as a drunk, used disguises, was pursued by the police and was nearly killed in a mine field on the border between Turkey and Greece.

title: LEFTWING BOMBING IS LINKED TO CUBA
description: MIAMI, Oct. 25 (UPIAmericans who joined the Venceremos Brigades to help with Premier Fidel Castro's sugar cane harvest were taught how to make bombs while in Cuba, the head of the Dade Count bomb squad said yesterday.Thomas Brodie testified this week before the Senate Internal Security subcommittee, along with three police bomb experts, Donald L. Hansen of San Francisco and Terrence McTegue of New York City and Arleigh McCrmee of Los Angels.

title: Texas 41, Rice 9
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 25 (AP) Marty Akins riddled Rice's defense with last  second pitchouts and Gralyn Wyatt ran for three touchdowns as eighthranked Texas beat the Owls. 419, tonight.

title: For young readers
description: Here's a problem Roald Dahl has written an entertaining new book about a motherless boy named Danny who lives with his father, a filling station operator addicted to poaching pheasants. After four chapters on the super qualities of Father, Danny relates their magnificent discomfiture of an enemy, Victor Hazell, a fat nouveauriche brewerlandowner with a face pink as a ham, all soft and inflamed from drinking too much beer.

title: Illinois Chamber Players Present Modern Works
description: Since the University of Illinois has been identified for some years now as a center of contemporary music activity, the visit by its Contemporary Chamber Players to Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon was anticipated with more than ordinary interest.

title: Front Page 4  No Title
MRS. FORD TERMS RIGHTS PLAN VITAL
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 25 (AP)Betty Ford said today that the cloud of fear and confusion must be lifted from the battle for the Equal Rights Amendment because it is vital to undo laws that lock women out of the mainstream of opportunity.

title: Sirica Receives Award
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) John J. Sirica, the Federal judge at the Watergate coverup trial, received the Cardinal Gibbons Medal from the Catholic University alumni association Saturday. The medal is awarded each year to a person who has rendered distinguished service to the United States, the Roman Catholic Church, or Catholic University.

title: Rutgers Parley to Weigh Fourth RReasoning
description: NEW BRUNSWICKHow can schools help children develop their reasoning ability? That and related questions will be explored at Rutgers University Tuesday at a meeting that is expected to attract educators, civil libertarians, psychologists and philosophers from throughout the Northeast.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: Rod's 1920 Road House, 525 Northfield Avenue, West Orange. (201) 7312222.

title: Fashion
description: Some people sleep late on Sunday. Others go to church. Many regard brunch as the high point of the day. But, a very special breed of New Yorker goes shopping on Sunday. Not on Fifth Avenue or Madison Avenue but on the Lower East Side.

title: Brooklyn Heights Group Is Helping Elderly to Find Jobs to Supplement Income
description: William A. Kregeloh, who is 68 years old, is job hunting. He is being aided by the Heightside Center, a newly formed Brooklyn Heights group seeking paying jobs for those over 60 who need money to supplement inadequate finances.

title: DR. JOHN FERREE, AIDED THE BLIND
description: Dr. John W. Ferree, who retired in 1969 as executive director of the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness. died Friday of cancer at his home in Pleasantville, N. Y. He was 71 years old.

title: Criminals At Large
description: By now Quiller, the British secret agent active in the Adam Hall novels, has achieved an identity very much his own. But it is a curiously disembodied identity. We know a great deal about how he works; we know almost nothing about him as a human being. James Bond was a bon vivant and womanizer. Jonas Wilde has temperament and is a oneman army. But Quitter? Quitter is the superpro, the Spy as Professional, the Man as Machine.

title: SENATORS SEEKING COMPROMISE PLAN TO ASSIST THE CITY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25Senate Banking Committee members are formulating legislation that would reduce and delay income for New York City bondholders and pensioners, in a compromise proposal intended to broaden Senate support for Federal loan guarantees for New York.

title: Design
description: Nineteenthcentury Paris. Vie de Bohme. Artists in garrets. The Beaux Arts ball. The architecture students of the Ecole des Beaux Arts in M. Gaudet's famous atelier on the Left Bank, smocks stained with encre de Chine, working on palatial projects for the Prix de Rome. They run careful washes behind meticulously rendered public monuments or ink in painstaking reconstructions of ancient Greek temples. A few nouveaux clean brushes for les anciens. The drawings are enormous, skillful, representations of classical grandeur. Stoves at either end of the large, cluttered room barely heat the chill air. Along one wall, untidy bookshelves hold dusty copies of Vitruvius and Palladio and the prizewinning designs of students who have gone on to fame. The Ecole des Beaux Arts is more than a school. It is la source, the fountainhead of official architecture for Old and New Worlds.

title: CONTRACTORS URGED TO SEEK VETERANS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI) The Labor Department has proposed procedures under which Federal contractors would be required to follow to provide more jobs for 400,000 unemployed Vietnamera or disabled veterans.

title: Unbeaten Matawan Trounces Jackson
description: Ken Mandeville and Gary Weber each scored two touchdowns yesterday as unbeaten Matawan powered to a 528 decision over Jackson.

title: Caring and Serving
description: The United Hospital Fund of New York has long had a goal of finding alternatives to institutional care for the aged and disabled. For the last year or so the fund has helped support several creative projects that are succeeding in helping to solve this problem. One hospital's project sends doctors and nurses to the homes of elderly people, three of them more than 100 years of age, who are in the institution's neighborhood and are in need of medical care.

title: YIDDISH THEATER HAS CENTENNIAL
description: Yiddish theater made its first formal appearance in Rumania a century ago, when the United States was observing its Centennial. The two had nothing In common then, but now, when Yiddish theater is 100 years old and the United States is 200 years old, they are celebrating together.

title: Portuguese Crime Has Risen Sharply Since Revolution
description: LISBON, Oct. 25 (AP) AI sharp increase in crime, accompanied by an acknowledged breakdown in police morale) and effectiveness, has been one of the striking social phenomena of the Portuguese revolution.

title: Two Prose Poems
description: The Boston College team has gold helmets, under which the long black hair of the Roman centurion curls out, . . . and they begin. How weird the goalies look with their African masks! The goalie is so lonely anyway, guarding the basket with nothing in it, his wide lower legs wide as ducks'. . . No matter what gift he is given, he always rejects it. . . . He has a number like 1, a name like Mrazek, sometimes wobbling his legs waiting for the puck, or curling up like a baby in the womb to hold it, staying a second too long on the ice.

title: Upstate Cities Observe Opening of Erie Canal
description: One hundred and fifty years ago today the Erie Canal was completed, making New York the greatest seaport of the New World and the metropolis of the nation.

title: PikeKissinger Dispute
description: The struggle between Congress and the Presidency is an evershifting battlefield. After a period of Presidential excesses, the executive branch and others are now suggesting that Congress is going too far in its efforts to obtain information, to the extent that there are echoes of the McCarthy era of the nineteenfifties.

title: Big Grain Exporting Houses Try New Areas
description: With none of the secrecy that shrouds their commodity deals, the Big Six grain exporting houses are striding boldly into new fields.

title: Miss Porter Gets FourStroke Lead
description: RANCHO SANTA FE, Calif., Oct. 25 (AP)Mary Bea Porter of Phoenix, Ariz., shot her third consecutive subpar round today, a twounder 71. to increase her lead to four strokes after 54 holes in the $53.000 Ladies Classic.

title: 4,000 March in Istanbul, Blaming Greeks for Role in Envoys' Deaths
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 25 (AP)An angry crowd of about 4,000 people demonstrated here today against the assassination of two Turkish diplomats in Europe. The protesters stormed into St. Sophia Museum, once a landmark Byzantine Greek church, and said Moslem prayers.

title: Pop Notes: Can the Tubes Squeeze Out the Who?
description: There are two events in popland that can always be depended upon to produce major excitement: the debut of a new act with legitimate superstar potential and the return of a group of authentic superstars.

title: Big Hazards Found in Small Cars
description: Small cars have definite advantages: They're chaeper and use less fuel. But unless compact models are equipped with safety features such as air bags, their occupants are 38 per cent more likely to be injured and 75 per cent more likely to be killed in an accident, according to a study conducted by the John Z. DeLorean Corporation for the Allstate Insurance Company.

title: Kissinger Says Zionism Vote Threatens U.N. Mideast Role
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) The recent United Nations social affairs committee. resolution linking Zionism to racial discrimination threatens the organization's capacity as mediator in the Middle East, Secretary of State Kissinger said tonight.

title: Ideas & Trends Education, Space, Labor
description: Two unmanned Soviet probes, Veneras 9 and 10, landed on the surface of Venus last week after fourandahalfmonth journeys. Before their instrument transmissions of approximately one hour ceased, the probes relayed 186 million miles home, through an orbiting communications satellite, the first photographs of the Venusian surface.

title: Colleges Study Sports Bets for Revenue
description: Alarmed by rising deficits, college athletic directors and coaches are taking a new look at sports betting as a possible source of campus revenue.

title: HELENE PARKER
description: Helene O'Hara Parker, a merchandising consultant, who was assistant director of fashions and promotions at Stern Brothers department store here from 1948 to 1962, died Friday at her home 500 East 85th Street. She was 64 years old.

title: The Game Plan: Go Slow
description: WASHINGTONAn apparently classic, normal recovery from recession is under way in the United States economy. All the indicators show it. It is reasonable to ask, therefore, why unemployment should still amount to more than 8 per cent of the labor force and how long it will remain high.

title: Grumman Airfield Proposal Is Rejected
description: OYSTER BAYThe Oyster Bay Town Board approved amendments to the town's building zone ordinance last week that restricts the operation of general aviation airports to heavy industrial zones within the town.

title: Ghost Stories for
description: It was a dark and cobwebby Victorian, high on a hilt, overgrown with weeds, overrun, quite possibly, by ghosts.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
The Tall Man From Boston
description: With Halloween spooks and witches just around the corner, this is an appropriate time for the appearance of Marion L. Starkey's The Tall Man From Boston, about those strange Salem witch hunts that stirred 17th  century Massachusetts even more violently than 19thcentury abolitionism or 20thcentury school busing. Since Miss Starkey's highly acclaimed account of these witch hunts. The Devil in Massachusetts, appeared in 1999, she has dealt with the subject in several other volumes, including, two years ago, The Visionary Girls, also for young readers.

title: Oklahoma 39, Iowa State 7
description: NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 25 (AP)  A swarming Oklahoma defense, spearheaded by 260pound Leroy Selmon, pressured Iowa State into several early turnovers today that put the Cyclones in a 260 hole at the half as the secondranked Sooners gained a 397 triumph in a sloppily played Big Eight football game.

title: Eli 2014 Victor On Late Score
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 25After squandering a twotouchdown lead midway in the third quarter today and allowing Cornell to tie the game with two quick scores, Yale recovered to march 55 yards for a touchdown and a 2014 triumph over the Big Red at Yale Bowl before a dampened crowd of 13,988.

title: The hot deals and cold wars of
description: In bringing about the latest ArabIsraeli accord in the Sinai, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger demonstrated the talents that have made him one of the most successful negotiators of the postwar period. He was able to work effectively with both antagonists in the bitterest of disputes. He coerced and cajoled the Israelis, but not to the point where their confidence in him was fatally undermined; he knew how far each side could ultimately go in meeting the demands of the other, and he was able to frame the terms of the negotiations accordingly. His exquisite sense of timing enabled him to come forward with his own final compromise formula at the precise moment when both sides were most inclined to accept it. He himself was a profoundly interested party to the negotiations, yet he managed to look like nothing more than a disinterested go between.

title: My Search For the Elusive Jennie Churchill
description: Every British schoolkid knows that Guy Fawkes tried to blow up King James I and the Houses of Parliament on Nov. 5, 1605. So when I was asked to write a movie about him a few years ago, I thought all I'd have to do was look up the established facts and dramatize them. Only when I did look them up, it turned out that not one fact had actually been established. Every single piece of evidence is suspect, and there's a plausible theory that the whole thing was a fix by James I's dirty tricks department. There may never even have been a Guy Fawkes at all.

title: Penn Central Making a Profit From Terminal, City Charges
description: In an apparently new twist in the fight over Grand Central Terminal, the city has told an appeals court that contrary to Penn Central's assertions, the railroad is making a profit from the facility if rent for space used by the trains is considered.

title: U.S.C. Tops Irish, 2417;
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 25 Ricky Bell, the nation's leading collegiate bailcarrier this season, picked up 165 yards and scored one touchdown for undefeated Southern California today, but the heavily favored Trojans still had to scramble back from a 3point deficit in the fourth quarter to defeat Notre Dame, 2417.

title: Maria T. Mullen, R. F. Thompson Have Nuptials
description: Maria T. Mullen, who is studying for a Ph.D. degree in philosophy at the University of Pennsylvania, was married yesterday afternoon to Radclyffe Furness Thompson of Chester Heights, Pa.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Lo, in the land of the Ford, the Chevrolet, the Plymouth, the Rockefeller and the Simon, there bode a prodigal city, the name whereof was New York, and its father was called Gerald, and his fist was sore tight.

title: A Talk With Amos Oz
description: Amos Oz sits in a small studio on Jerusalem's Mt. Scopus and writes; shares his thoughts on Chekhov and Kafka in the summer with a group of Hebrew University students; returns home on the weekend to his wife and two daughters at Kibbutz Hulda; pulls guard duty or waits on tables or picks oranges for hours under the sun. Although only in his mid  30's, Oz remembers the sounds of World War 11, of the 1948 War of Independence, and of the recent wars in which he has participated as soldier or reservist. He compares this to living through his country's American Revolution and Civil War.

title: GUN BATTLE RAGES IN CENTRAL BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. Sunday Oct. 26After one of the most violent nights in Beirut's street war, roaming gangs of gunmen spread terror and death in the center and in wide sections of the capital yesterday. There was heavy fighting on the edges of Ras Beirut, where many foreigners live.

title: ARGENTINES BACK ECONOMIC ACCORD
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 25The Argentine Government obtained a commitment today from organized labor and part of the business leadership to support a program to fight acute inflation, rising unemployment and anarchy among workers.

title: Queens Master Plan Is Fought
description: More than 1,000 northeastern Queens residents, civic groups and public officials turned out last week to oppose the City Planning Cortimission's North Shore Study and to urge Community Board 7 to reject the proposals.

title: DETROIT JOBLESS RETURN TO SCHOOL
description: DETROIT, Oct. 25  After graduating from Wayne State University here last spring with a bachelor's degree in German, Jenifer Fabyan spent the summer trying to find a job, with no success.

title: President Wants To Cancel Food Stamps for Many
description: President Ford has proposed a substantial cutback in the Federal Government's food stamp program, eliminating 3.4 million recipients and reducing the benefits for others. The proposal apparently was designed partly to alleviate problems in the food stamp program and partly to further Mr. Ford's campaign plans.

title: QUARREL WITH S.L.A. LAID TO MISS HEARST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 (AP)The magazine Rolling Stone said that Patricia Hearst became disillusioned with the socalled Symbionese Liberation Army during the last few months before her capture by Federal agents, and had been getting homesick for her family.

title: What's Doing in THE RIO GRANDE VALLEY
description: OVERVIEWAlong the bottom of Texas, the Rio Grande pours sandcolored water into the Gulf of Mexico through a shallow valley, rich in alluvial soil that support a huge agricultural industry, chiefly citrus and cotton. The river sets the pace in this semitropical region. Life is lived more slowly. One seeks cool shade from the hot sun in the afternoon or welcomes fresh Gulf breeze that pushes the sticky humidity back a little; a tequila or rum drink is meant to be sipped slowly at sundown. However, there is an undercurrent of activity below the placid surface: a burgeoning tourism industry. For many years Texans have been going to the valley, as it is colloquially known, for deepsea fishing off the coast or whitewinged dove shooting in the cornfields and meadows of northern Mexico. In 1967, Hurricane Beulah leveled the area, blowing away most of the tacky old wooden fishing shacks and resorts. Faced with a clean slate, developers began thinking about upgrading tourist facilities, paticularly on Padre Island. They've taken their time about it, carefully building while maintaining much of the natural surroundings and promoting the area as a vacation and retirement center. It must be working, because more and more tourists are coming to the valley during the winter in cars bearing Illinois, Wisconsin, Minnesota and other Midwestern license plates. Residents say the valley will boom like Florida, but I think the region is just inaccessible enough to keep from exploding in a wave of concrete highrises and trailer parks that would push prices out of the reach of the middle class. It is unlikely to get to the stage where one can't pack up the family and spend two weeks in a tent on the beach.

title: Complaints Mount Over New Law On Closings
description: When William T. Gallagher was hired early last summer by the Seatrain Shipbuilding Corporation in the Brooklyn Navy Yard, he left his family at their home in Mobile, Ala., while he came to New York to buy a house. His intention was to have his wife and children settled in their new home well before school started in September.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
Wood, Field and Stream: 3 Hunters Find There's Nothing to Grouse About
description: HANCOCK, N. H.In a few moments as we moved across a red and gold hillside in quest of ruffed grouse and woodcock, I thought of our trio as the guns of autumn.

title: Quiet Jackson Campaign Puzzles Both Rivals and Supporters
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 24Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington is running such a quiet underground campaign for the Presidency that his rivals for the Democratic nomination have begun to wonder out loud whether he is hiding a secret lead to avoid the vulnerable front runner's position, or whether the real secret is a story of disappointment and decline.

title: Chester M. Mayer, 64. Dies; Founded Air Cargo Network
description: Chester M. Mayer, a founder, chairman, president, and more recently a director of the Air Express International Corporation, a cargo carrier, died Thursday in Singapore. He was 64 years old and lived in Orient, L.I.

title: Thinking about the thinkable
description: Despite the attacks that will be leveled against it, there is nothing really controversial about this book. All Drew Middleton does is to lay out in dear, concise prose what any reader of the studies of London's International Institute of Strategic Studies or the Defense Department's reports to Congress knows well: The Soviet leadership expects further wars and... is making a gargantuan effort to prepare for them. Middleton documents the resultsin depth, weapon by weaponand, more important, looks at both the United States and the Soviet Union in terms of their political and social preparedness what the Soviets refer to as the total correlation of forces.

title: The retread culture
description: If it were possible to isolate a single identifying characteristic of American culture over the past decade, it would likely be the element of reproduction: The representative form of our time is a remake.

title: BATTISTA ENJOYING UNUSUAL SUPPORT
description: Vito Battista endorsed by the Citizens Union? Vito Battista, who once campaigned in Wall Street with a pinkdraped elephant, outside the Governor's office with a Diogenesstyle lantern and at City Hall with a mock rocket ship?

title: CITY STUDY ASKED ON PENSION FUNDS
description: The state's Emergency Financial Control Board has asked Mayor Beame's management advisory panel to study the city's pension systems to determine if there will be money in the systems' reserves to meet all retirement payments in the years ahead.

title: A Dedicated Cyclist Reflects on Victory
description: WOODBRIDGEWhen the Garden State Parkway opens its toll gates to motorcyclists next Saturday, the man who led the battle to end the 14year ban on bikers will not be there.

title: TV VIEW
description: One of the more sensitive and crucial issues connected With television massaudience programing has been raised with the recent saga of Harlem: Voices, Faces on public television. Made in the summer of 1973 by two Swedish filmmakers, Lars Ulvenstam and Tomas Dilien, the TV documentary originally ran for three hours and had been shown in Sweden and elsewhere in Europe. An excerpt also was presented on CBS News's 60 Minutes, provoking very little public comment. Then WNET/13 decided to show a specially edited 90minute version of the film, and the project exploded in controversy.

title: Belgian to Compete On U.S. Fall Circuit
description: Three years ago. Eric Wauters and his Belgian equestrian team were alsorans on the European circuit. The group finished 11th in a field of 17 in the 1972 Olympics in Munich and didn't show much promise of doing any better in the 1976 games. Wauters. to be sure was charged with only two faults in the team competition.

title: 2d Soviet Craft Lands on Venus
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 25The Soviet Union landed a second spacecraft on the surface of Venus today and it sent back to earth photographs showing a terrain far different from the rugged, rockstrewn landing site of the first craft.

title: Christie Bader Married to Marine
description: Christie Pierpont Bader, daughter of Mrs. Victor D. S. Troxell of New Canaan, Conn., and Charles DeGroat Bader of Los Angeles, was married yesterday afternoon to Second Lieut. Andrew Davidson Walker of the Marine Corps. He is the son of Col. Anthony Walker, Marine Corps, retired, and Mrs. Walker of Middletown. R. I.

title: Price Freeze in Canada
description: VICTORIA, Canada, Oct. 25 (UPI)British Columbia has imposed a 68day price freeze on hundreds of basic commodities and essential services to help citizens combat inflation. The freeze covers food, pharmaceuticals, fuel, oil, electricity, bus and ferry fares, some trucking rates and rail passenger fares.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was stated incorrectly in last Sunday's New York Times that Samuel Chambers was the Conservative candidate for Westchester Board of Legislators in Greenburgh. In fact, the Conservatives have endorsed William Crosbie, the Republican incumbent.

title: D'Agostino Excels
description: Ralph D'Agostino scored four touchdowns yesterday as Mendham defeated Bernards, 290, in Mendham for its fourth victory in five games.

title: OnceIsolationist Midwest Now Cheers Detente
description: Of course, there are a few old Joe McCarthyites around here who still don't want to have anything to do with the Russians or the Chinese Communists, a prosperous Iowa grain farmer remarked recently. But if detente has improved our exports, then let's have even more of it.

title: MABEL TYLER HACKETT
description: Mabel Tyler Hackett, a music teacher in Julia Richman High School here for many years before her retirement in 1954, died yesterday following surgery in Camden, Me. She was 86 years old and lived in Lincolnville, Me., and Huntington, L. I.

title: . . . Democratic Response
description: The Democrats for their part are still floundering in the search for Presidential leadership that offers promise of transforming the mood of doubt and disillusionment.

title: Outlook On Bonds Improves
description: TRENTONProspects for the Byrne administration's $922million bond program being approved by the voters on Election Day are reported to have improved now that New Jersey environmentalists have dropped their opposition and announced their support of the proposal's key transportation segment.

title: CREDIT NO WORRY FOR WEST BERLIN
description: BERLIN, Oct. 20The city of West Berlin, facing its largest deficit in 30 years, has just slashed its budget, applied to borrow money from banks and announced increases in the rates of almost all services. Subway and bus fares are to go up by 30 to 40 per cent.

title: No pardon for Gerald Ford, no pardon for Richard Reeves
description: 1) Who ever doubted that Richard Reeves is more interesting than Gerald Ford? 2) Wherefore it follows, doesn't it, that a book whose developing thesis is, substantially, that Reeves has more in common with Lincoln than Ford does is a work of supererogation? 3) Made worse, moreover, because the book in question too often reads like Gerald Ford, the Man and the Myth, by Richard Reeves, as told to Victor Lasky.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Period pieces. Mention Sherlock Holmes and the picture that leaps to mind is that which an artist named Sidney Paget created to illustrate the first collections of stories published between 1892 and 1905. Most of the stage and film actors who have assumed his role since have tried to bring that image to life. Now you won't have to possess copies of the rare original editions to savor Paget's sketches as you read Conan Doyle's Victorian melodramatics. Softcovered facsimile editions of the first four volumes have just been released: The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes and The Memoirs of Sherlock Holmes (A & W Visual Library, $3.95 each) and The Hound of Baskervilies and The Return of Sherlock Holmes (Schocken, $2.95 each).

title: Chaplain at Belmont Park
description: Among the hundreds of persons ministering to the needs of the thoroughbreds at Belmont Park there is one whose business is not horses, but people.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Making the Buyer BegAnd Other Tricks of the Art Trade
description: As the art market gathers momentum this fall with a round of gala gallery openings, champagne receptions and other rituals and razzmatazz calculated to fight off the recession blues and pep up sales, many of the truly bigtime transactions will take place, as in the past, out of the limelight, behind closed doors. And one of the people certain to play a key role in these transactions is Leo Castelli, the urbane, witty, 68yearold art dealer generally recognized as the greatest salesman the art market has known since Joseph Duveen, the master merchant of the twenties and thirties.

title: Nebraska Wins 7th;
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 25 (AP)Vince Ferragamo threw two touchdown passes and John O'Leary ran for two scores to power Nebraska to a 6321 Big Eight victory today over a Colorado team plagued by penalties and turnovers.

title: Quinlan Family Gets Advice and Sympathy in Mail
description: LANDING, N. J., Oct. 25We, too, had a daughter also named Karen who was 16 when she died from brain damage caused by a mystery illness, wrote an English couple to the parents of Karen Anne Quinlan, the 21 yearold girl who lies unconscious in a New Jersey hospital while a court debates her fate.

title: Editors' Choice
description: General

title: NepalWhere Art Explained The Universe
description: The only possible objection to a joyous new exhibition at Asia House, Nepal: Where the Gods Are Young, is that the title is cast in the wrong tense. The gods are no longer young in Nepal, as anyone who has visited it lately can tell you. They have aged terribly and not very gracefully since the 18th century, the latest date of the sculptures in this beautiful group, and are hardly recognizable in the 20th. They were really at their youthful best between the 10th and 17th centuries, from which the bulk of the exhibition is drawn. It was a nice, long time to have stayed young.

title: Independence for Surinam Is Voted by Dutch House
description: THE HAGUE, Oct. 25 (Reuters)The lower house of the Netherlands Parliament, has approved a hill to grant the South American territory of Surinam independence on Nov. 25, after 308 years under colonial rule.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
FollowUp on The News
description: Last Sept. 8, Continental Trailways, reacting to rising national unemployment, offered a new ride on its national bus system: Opportunity Fare, a chance for the unemployed to ride at half fare in search of new jobs (and an opportunity for the company to increase business).

title: Carole C. McNamara Is Wed to Euan C. Malcolmson
description: Carole Charlotte McNamara, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. McNamara of DeKalb, Ill., formerly of Far Hills, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Euan Clive Malcolmson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ian Malcolmson of StowontheWold in Gloucestershire, England.

title: Faltering Leadership ...
description: America today is a troubled country, disappointed with its recent past and uneasy about the future. Much underlying strength remains but a more competent and more inspiring leadership is needed to restore the nation's optimism. Both political parties are failing sadly in Providing such leadership.

title: POWER RATES CUT FOR AGED IN MAINE
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Oct. 25Older residents in six Maine communities are eligible to participate in an experimental Lifeline Electric Service plan that begins Dec. 1. The program will mean lower electric rates for households with persons 62 years or older who qualify.

title: Chief of State Receives Last Rites at Palace
description: MADRID, Sunday, Oct. 26Spain waited uneasily today as death seemed imminent for Generalissimo Francisco Franco, who has ruled the country for 36 years.

title: Carey Energy's Corporate Structure
description: The structure of Carey Energy Corporation, the billiondollar petroleum network owned by Edward M. Carey, brother and chief political bankroller of Governor Carey, has been made public for the first time.

title: NijinskyStill the Ultimate Male Dancer
description: For a half century, the name Nijinsky has stood for the epitome of the male dancer. His career lasted for less than a decade, but his legend persists into our time as evidenced by the opening tomorrow of the Lincoln Center Dance Collection's first public exhibit of the important Roger Pryor Dodge Collection of Nijinsky photographs, and the publication of Lincoln Kirstein's book, Nijinsky Dancing, which is illustrated with photographs from the same collection. Photographs of the elusive Russian are as close as we'll ever get to seeing him at work, for unfortunately there is no record of Nijinsky in performance on film.

title: Aggies Win, 1910, From Baylor
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Oct. 25 (AP)Lester Hayes of Texas A. and M. grabbed a fumble in midair today and raced 77 yards for the touchdown that beat Baylor, 1910. Mark Jackson, the Baylor quarterback, fumbled when tackled behind the line of scrimmage in the third quarter.

title: Grambling Loses
description: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 25 (AP)  Jackson State's defense stymied Doug Williams as the Tigers upset Grambling, the nation's topranked collegedivision team, 2414, today.

title: LINER QUEEN MARY LOSING HER APPEAL
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 25 (Reuters)The luxury liner queen Mary, hurt by sharply reduced attendance and major operational problems, has lost its appeal as a tourist attraction, according to officials here.

title: A PUBLIC SERVANT MAY HEAD LOTTERY
description: The placing of a highly qualified Civil Service administrator instead of a political appointee in charge of the controversial New York lottery is expected to be recommended this week by the State Senate Finance Committee.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: MAJOR BANKS led by the First National City reduced their prime rate from 8 per cent to 7 per cent . . . Gross National Product in the third quarter rose to $1,497.8billion in current dollars, a 16.7 per cent increase on an annual basis. Adjusted for inflation the rise was 11.2 per cent, the largest in any quarter since the spring of 1955 . . . The Consumer Price Index rose 0.5 per cent in September to 163.6 [1967=100]. The transit tare increase pushed the index up 1.1 per cent in New York.

title: U.S. Lifts Ban on Hunting Greater Snow Geese
description: TRENTONFor the first time in 44 years, the Greater Snow Goose can he hunted in New Jersey next month. Also. Atlantic brant can he hunted in the state for the first time in four years.

title: BRUCE ALAN LUDGATE
description: Bruce Alan Ludgate, who resigned as sales manager of the glass closure division of the Armstrong Cork Company in 1963 to become a Christian Science practitioner, died yesterday at his home, 164 East 72d Street. He was 79 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Ford Is Scored on Busing
description: AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 26 (UPI) Nathaniel Jones, chief counsel for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, has described President Ford and other school busing opponents as screaming, irrational chestbeaters. Speaking in suburban Fairlawn during a meeting of the Great Lakes Regional Conference of National Neighbors yesterday, Mr. Tones said that the President was undermin, ing respect for the law,by opposing busing. His pronouncements on school desegregation are ridiculous, Mr. Jones said.

title: Senate Unit to Get 3 Plans On U. S. Role in City Crisis
description: Staff members of the Senate Banking Committee will present three option papers today outlining advantages and disadvantages of aid to New York City, but any proposal that eventually goes to the floor still appears to face strong opposition.

title: Radio
CORRECTIONS
description: CORRECTIONS

title: Ne Win to Visit China
description: PEKING, Oct. 26 (Reuters)President Ne Win of Burma will visit China in midNovember, the Press Agency Hsinhua announced today. It will be his second trip to China.

title: Final Witnesses Are Set For WomaninComa Trial
description: The defense in the Karen Anne Quinlan case will begin presenting final witnesses today and prepare for summation before Superior Court Judge Robert Muir Jr., who could hand down his ruling as early as tomorrow.

title: Political Prisoners in Spain Charge Jail Treatment Is Becoming Harsher
description: MADRID, Oct. 26Fortyfive lawyers for political prisoners made public today on appeal to the Minister of Justice for correction of what they said were harsh new conditions in jail.

title: City Opens Rockaway Area to Builders for a Second Tivoli Gardens
description: the Beame administration announced plans yesterday to make available a large slice of a longstalled urbanrenewal project on the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens to private developers who might want to build a recreational and entertainment complex similar to the famous Tivoli Gardens in Copenhagen.

title: Peter Fosco, 82, President Of Laborers Union, Is Dead
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (UPI) Peter Fosco, general president of the Laborers International Union and a member of the A.F.L.C.I.O. Executive Council, died today of a heart attack in his home. He was 82 years old.

title: JUDGE BLOCKS PLAN FOR AMAX MERGER
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 26 (AP)A Federal court judge has blocked the proposed merger of Amax, Inc., of Greenwich, Conn., and the Copper Range Company of White Pine, Mich.

title: John D. Warren, 71. Is Dead; An Officer of White, Weld
description: John D. Warren, a vice president of White, Weld & Co., Inc., investment bankers, died yesterday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 71 years old and lived at 185 East 85th Street and in Essex, Conn.

title: U.S. SYSTEM USED ON SOVIET PHOTOS
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Oct. 26 Soviet scientists have used threedimensional laserphotography methods devised at the State University of New York's center here to deblur satellite photos of areas in the Soviet Union thought to have oil and natural gas reserves.

title: 5 MORE POLICEMEN DIE IN ARGENTINA
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 26While taps was sounding today for a young army lieutenant slain by guerrillas in the hills of Tucuman, terrorists in a suburb of Buenos Aires killed live more policemen.

title: U.S. AIDE DIFFERS ON CANCER PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26At the request of the steel industry an official of the Feaerai agency that makes decisions about the levels or cancercausing agents to wmcm workers may he exposed will testify at Government expense against. a new cancer standard proposed by the Government.

title: BRIEF STRIKE ENDS ON ALASKA PIPELINE
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct., 26The puzzling walkout of 877 pipeline welders on the Trans Alaska pipeline project has, ended as mysteriously as: it started with all members of Pipeline Welders Union Local 798 back on the job yesterday.

title: French Free 14 Armenians In Slaying of Turkish Envoy
description: PARIS, Oct. 26Fourteen Armenians rounded up yesterday as possible suspects in the slaying of the Turkish Ambassador and his chauffeur were released today, the police reported.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Catherine de Medici and the French cuisine, conlinued ad infinitum: The foundation for this discussion was a query from a reader as to whether Catherine was responsible for haute cuisine in that she brought Italian conks with her when she married Henry II of France in the lath century.

title: Solomon Beats Mayer in Final
description: PERTH, Australia, Oct. 26 (AP)Harold Solomon of Silver Spring, Md., defeated Sandy Mayer of Mendham, N.J., 62, 76, 75, today and won the $7,000 first prize in the $46,000 HitachiDatsun indoor tennis tournament.

title: Foreign Investment in U.S. Declined in First 9 Months
description: Despite concern in Congress and among the public about the possibility of takeover of American business by the Winch Arab nations, actual announcements of foreign investfi nents in United States manufacturing facilities declined in the first nine months of 1975. toe Conference Board reported yesterday.

title: Israeli Widow Deals With Own and Others
description: KFAR HABBAD, IsraelA young war widow was resentful when Schifrah Golombowitz, a stranger, tried to comfort her in her bereavement.

title: Y.&R. Localizes
description: If the theme is, We've got the right time and the right place for you. who would the advertiser he?

title: Senate Unit to Get 3 Plans On U. S. Role in City Crisis
description: Staff members of the Senate Banking Committee will present three option papers today outlining advantages and disadvantages of aid to New York City, but any proposal that eventually goes to the flow still appears to face string opposition.

title: Amy Rapoport Bride of Hugo Nurnberg
description: Amy Barbara Rapoport, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Rapoport of Southfield, Mich., was married there yesterday to Dr. Hugo Nurnberg, visiting professor of accounting at the University of Chicago. Rabbi William Rudolph performed the ceremony at the Adat Sholom Synagogue in Southfield.

title: Humphrey Leads in Poll of Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26The Gallup pollsters are not sure what to make of their figures, but their new national survey of rankandfile Democrats gives a lead in Presidential preference for the Campaign first time to Notes Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota, avowedly a noncandidate. Mr. Humphrey is the choice of 23 per cent of his party, the Gallup organization reportsup from 20 per cent in July, and ahead of Gov, C. Wallace of Alabama, who is in second place with 19 per cent this month, down from 23 per cent three months ago.

title: Oklahoma City Police Back New Pact and End Walkout
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 26 (UPI)Police officers voted tonight to accept a contract proposal offered by the city, ending a walkout that began Thursday by almost all of the 698 police officers.

title: SPACECRAFT TAKE PICTURE OF VENUS
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 26 (AP) Two unmanned Soviet spacecraft circling the planet Venus began taking pictures today of the mysterious cloud cover that spins around the earth's sister planet.

title: Undaunted by Disease, a Utah Poet Fights to Save Wilderness
description: SOMEWHERE IN THE ESCALANTE CANYONS, Utah  Gary M. Smith laid his guitar across his knees and looked at the eight friends gathered around the campfire beneath the eerie full moon. Thank you, he said with a bit of catch in his voice, for bringing this invalid out of his cage.

title: Peggy Lee Sings Old Songs of Success
description: Peggy lee is still singing Is That All There Is? her hit of six years ago, in her current program at the Empire Room of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. And it proves to be rathor fitting

title: Charles Regatta
description: Veterans Single ScullsEd Lynch, Cambridge Boat Club, 22 minutes 30 seconds.

title: New Orleans Widow, 83, Freed After 2Year Drugged Captivity
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 26 (UPI)A wealthy 83yearold widow rescued by firemen from two years of drugged captivity in her own home was recovering from her ordeal in a hospital today.

title: Television
Young Women, Blacks Still Have High Hopes
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26At a time when the nation's collective sense of faith in the future has faltered, there is a surge of optimism among two groups of Americansyoung women and young blacks.

title: SADAT IN THE  U.S. IN QUEST FOR ARMS AND ECONOMIC AID
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 26 President Anwar elSadat, the first Egyptian President to pay an official visit to the United States, arrived today to seek economic and military help from Washington and to explain his policies to the American people.

title: B. D. Stephens Marries Miss Butterfield
description: Marion Anne Butterfield and Bruce David Stephens were married yesterday afternoon in the Good Shepherd Community and Ecumenical Center, the restored 19thcentury chapel beside the apartment complex on Roosevelt Island, where they live.

title: An Electricians
description: Electricians who maintain 70 per cent of the elevators in this area went on strike early today after contract negotiations broke down. Page 32.

title: Minister Urges Boycott of Church Council Dinner
description: The Rev. Dr. Eugene S. Callender, Pastor of the Presbyterian Church of the Master in Harlem and former president of the New York Urban Coalition, called on the New York business and religious community yesterday to boycott the annual Family of Man award dinner on Nov. 6 because its sponsor, the Council of Churches of the City of New York, had selected President Ford as a recipient.

title: Screen
description: Distant Thunder was shown at the 1973 New York Film Festival. The following excerpt is from Vincent Can by's review, which appeared in The New York. Times on Oct, 12. 1972. The film opened yesterday at the Beekman Theater, Second Avenue at 65th Street.

title: United Press International
description: MOROCCAN KING CONFERS ON MARCH: Hassan II, left, with U.N. Secretary General Waldheim at a dam project in Sidi Cheho. Mr. Waldheim called plans for march by 350,000 Moroccans into Spanish Sahara an explosive situation and went on to Mauritania, which also has claims. A Spanish Government newspaper reported a move for talks.

title: Team Golf To Colbert And Refrain
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, F1a., Oct. 26 (UPI)Jim Colbert and Dean Retram won golf's $200,000 National Team Championship today with a 36underpar total of 252 at Walt Disney World.

title: Carter Appears to Hold a Solid Lead in Iowa as the Campaign's First Test Approaches
description: AMES. Iowa, Oct. 26Former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia appears to have taken a surprising hut solid lead in the contest for Iowa's 47 delegates to the Democratic. National Convention next year.

title: Miss Alkins Wed To Martin Appel
description: Patricia Alkins, a social worker at the Bronx Municipal Hospital, and Martin Appel, director of publicity for the New York Yankees, were married yesterday at the Lakeover Country Club in Bedford Hills, N.Y.. Rabbi Hillel Friedman performed the ceremony.

title: Swiss Mime Makes a Clownish Debut
description: Words cannot express what Dimitri of Switzerland does onstage, and frankly he does not use them. At his local debut Saturday night at Hunter College Playhouse, this deli ahtful 40yearold child could have been billed as still another exponent of nonverbal theater. Actually, he is a clown.

title: Editorialists Split Ideologically On U.S. Aid for New York City
description: Like the politicians who have been forced to deal with New York City's fiscal tribulations. the editorialists who have been moved to comment on them split along ideological lines.

title: CITY FISCAL CRISIS FEEDS ON ITSELF
description: In a new illustration of the old business adage that you have to spend money to make money. New York City is finding that money it hasn't got and can't borrow is imperiling such revenueproducing projects as piers, markets, industrial parks and shopping centers.

title: Plunkett Hurt Again; Bartkowski Injured
description: Jim Plunkett, the New England Patriot's quarterback, reinjured his separated left shoulder and Steve Bartkowski rookie signalcaller of the Atlanta Falcons, suffered a dislocated left elbow Yesterday, and will be out at least three weeks. The loss was harder for the Falcons, who also lost their game, 2114, to the visiting Cincinnati Eengals.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1975

title: Police Identify Six Killed in the Crash Of a Private Plane
description: Six New Jersey men who died in a plane crash Saturday morning as they were en route to a Pennsylvania hunting trip have been identified by the New Jersey state police.

title: Sooners Survive Fumbles, Others Don't
description: Only a team as powerful as Oklahoma could fumble 13 times, lose six of the fumbles to the opponent and still finish with a lopsided victory. The Sooners trounced Iowa State, 397, despite toe sloppy ballhandling. Iowa State fumbled six times, and the Sooners scored their first touchdown shortly after Leroy Selmon recovered one of Iowa State's fumbles at the Cyclones 13yard line.

title: Michener Fears Publishing TakeOvers May Ground Fledgling Novelists
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 25When RCA bought Random House, I went to Bennett Cerf to protest, James Michener recalled today.

title: United Press Internationl
description: MOROCCAN KING CONFERS ON MARCH: Hassan II, left, with U.N. Secretary General Waldheim at a dam project in Sidi Cheho. Mr. Waldheim called plans for march by 350,000 Moroccans into Spanish Sahara an explosive situation and went on to Mauritania, which also has claims. A Spanish Government newspaper reported a move for talks.

title: LIBERALS FACING ASSEMBLY LOSSES
description: TRENTON, Oct. 26A number of liberal Democratic Assemblymen who were swept into office with Governor Byrne in 1973 face the possibility of being swept out again in traditionally Republican New Jersey's election Nov. 4.

title: General Is Worsening By HENRY GINIGER
description: MADRID, Monday, Oct. 27Generalissimo Francisco Franco clung to life last night and at one point yesterday even showed slight improvement in his weeklong fight against heart problems.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
The Case for Aid . . .
description: Two critical issues emerge from the clamor of national politics and local prejudices that has confused the debate in Washington over aid to New York: Does the city's default pose a sufficient threat of wider repercussions to warrant preventive Federal action? And, if so, what restrictions and penalties should be written into legislation to insure that New York does not revert to the fiscal practices that precipitated the current crisis? In our viewand that of a growing number of members of Congressthe first question has already been more than adequately answered in the affirmative. Prof. Otto Eckstein of Harvard, a former member the President's Council of Economic Advisers, last week added another authoritative voice to those of governors, mayors and fiscal experts from across the country when he told a House committee:

title: Events Today
Tool Orders Off From 74
description: The machinetool maustry continued to work off its inventories through September according to figures released over the weekend by the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

title: Suits on 72 Jet Crash Killing 22 to Start Today
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 26 (UPI)Three years after a Korean War era jet fighter barreled into an ice cream parlor killing 22 persons lawsuits that could yield millions of dollars in damages will go to trial tomorrow.

title: I.R.S. Head's Old Firm in Bank Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Internal Revenue Service agents have discovered a possible link between the former law firm of Donald C. Alexander, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, and a Bahamian bank suspected. of being a haven for Americans attempting to evade taxes sources familiar with the investigation said today.

title: U.S. Newsman Says Leftists in Beirut Shot Him Purposely
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. Oct. 26 (UPI)An American newsman said today that leftist gunmen had deliberately shot him after checking his credentials and then allowing him to walk down a street in Beirut.

title: Rights and Security
description: The Administration's decision to see to it that surveillance carried out by the National Security Agency is conducted lawfully clearly tends in the right direction; but it is not so clear that the course of action now being considered inside the White House is the most effective means of achieving the desired result.

title: Lawyer Reelected President of NOW
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 Karen DeCrow, a lawyer from Syracuse, was reelected today as president of the National Organization for Women, running on the slogan, out or tne mainstream, into the revolution.

title: HERZOG ASSAILS VOTE ON ZIONISM
description: Chaim Herzog, head of Israel's delegation to the United Nations, called, on Jews the world over last night In speak out against what he described as a new international outburst of anti  Semitism.

title: British Roch Group Called 10 cc Begins Major U.S. Tour
description: 10 cc is a British rock quintet that first made an impact here with some clever progressirerock LP's that received much play on FM. Then the group broke through to a wider American market this summer with a dreamy single called I'm Not in Love As a direct result of that success, 10 began its first major American tour as headliners Saturday night at the Beacon Theater.

title: WOMAN IS SUICIDE 2 AFTER SLAYING 2
description: A 48yearold woman fatally shot her estranged husband and their 20  year  old retarded daughter and then killed herself yesterday in the twofamily house she shared with her parents on a quiet residential street in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn.

title: Annett Garrett Rewed
description: At Temple Rodeph Shalom here yesterday afternoon, Annett Garrett of New York was married to Herbert C. Keilson of Franklin Square, L.I., an assistant vice president for group and charter sales with American Airlines. Rabbi Gunther Hershkowitz performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Henry O. Garrett of Louisville and the late Mr. Garrett. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. Mr. Keilson is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Keilson of New York.

title: PINS
description: What was first heralded as a landmark decision by the State Court of Appeals in 1973, has failed to make any significant improvement in the care of troubled children, according to the Institute of Judicial Administration.

title: HIGH AIDE TO MARCOS SHOT DEAD IN MANILA
description: MANILA, Monday, Oct. 27 (AP)An assistant to President Ferdinand E. Marcos was shot and killed just after noon today at his office, members of Mr. Marcos staff reported.

title: Undaunted by Disease, a Utah Poet Fights to Save Wilderness
description: SOMEWHERE IN THE ESCALANTE CANYONS, Utah  Gary M. Smith laid his guitar across his knees and looked at the eight friends gathered around the campfire beneath the eerie full moon. Thank you, he said with a bit of catch in his voice, for bringing this invalid out of his cage.

title: Hobbling the U.N.
description: Whatever temporary emotional comfort is derived from antiIsraeli drafts and exclusionary efforts at the United Nations, these bring no relief where it truly countswithin lands in the Third or Communist worlds where racism or dictatorship denies human rights, in villages where health and education remain at primitive levels and along tense national borders.

title: Princess Anne Thrown
description: LONG BIJCKBY, England. Oct. 26 (UPI)Princess Anne's horse collided with a horse ridden by her husband, Capt. Mark Phillips, in a crosscountry riding event today. She was thrown to the ground bur uninjured.

title: 13 Americans and a Dane To Get Japanese Awards
description: TOKYO, Oct. 26 (AP)The Japanese Government plans to award the Cordon of the Third Order to three Americans and a Dane for contributions to the development of fellowship and cultural exchanges between Japan and their countries, Premier Takeo Miki's office has announced.

title: About New York
description: The police officer was giving a peddler a summons at what was alleged to be Union Square when the woman came over and began berating the officer for annoying the man.

title: Kashmir Dispute Losing Its Urgency After Three Decades of Bitterness
description: SRINAGAR. Kashmir After nearly three decades of angry confrontation and armea conflict, the international dispute over this strategic mountain territory in Central Asia is losing its urgency. In a criange as quiet and gentle as the Himalayan starlings that flutter over the Kashmir Valley's still, green lakes, the argument over whether this is part of India or part of Pakistan has, according to many people here, become largely academic.

title: Editorialists Split Ideologically On U.S. Aid for New York City
description: The Abilene (Kan.) ReflectorChronicle Like the politicians who have been forced to deal with New York City's fiscal tribulations, the editorialists who have been moved to comment on them split along ideological lines.

title: Kaden Acknowledges Driver's Payroll Status
description: Lewis B. Kaden, Governor Byrne's chief counsel, yesterday acknowledged published reports that his chauffeur's yearly salary, $8,500 was being paid from the budget of the State Energy Office, but he dismissed its significance.

title: For Elitism
description: HALIFAX, Nova ScotiaThe people I respect most, E. M. Forster observed in a 1939 wartime British Broadcasting Corporation program later included in his generously titled book Two Cheers for Dernoracy. oenave as it tney were immortal, and as if society were eternal. Both assumptions are false: both of them must be accepted as true if we are to go on eating and working and loving and are to keep a few breathing holes open for the human spirit.

title: Commission of Medical Association Endorses a Controversial Technique to Save Choking Victims
description: A commission of the American Medical Association has concluded that the controversial Heimlich maneuver is a most important addition to the ernergency care of persons who cannot breathe because they are choking on food or other objects.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: W. Preston Corderman, accused of conflict of interest two years ago has stepped down as chairman of the board of trustees of Brookdale Community College in Monmouth County. Freeholder Director. Philip Gumbs said that new chairman would he named at a Freeholder meeting on Nov. 5.

title: Dempsey's Status Called Satisfactory
description: Jack Dempsey, the SOyearold former heavyweight boxing champion, was reported in satisfactory condition yesterday at New York University Hospital.

title: . . . and Discipline
description: If the decision to intervene is made during the next few weeks, as it must to be effective, there is no question that Congress and the Ford Administration will insist on firm controls to insure that the city moves even more resolutely to reform its fiscal practices, balance its budget and pay off its debts. No New Yorker can object to conditions which would reinforce disciplines that are already being imposed by the state's Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: WomaninComa Trial Is Drawing to a Close
description: The defense in the Karen Anne Quinlan case will begin presenting final witnesses today and prepare for summation before Superior Court Judge Robert Muir Jr. who could hand down his ruling as early as tomorrow.

title: Rangers Booed in 72 Defeat
description: The nightmare continued for the Rangers last night. Hoping to revorse their oneway trip to oblivion in the friendly confines of Madison Square Garden, the slumping New Yorkers took a 72 pasting from the Philadelphia Flyers for their third straight onesided heating.

title: MRS. JOSE M. BOSCH
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas, Oct. 26 (AP)  Enriqueta Schueg Bosch, wife of Jose M. Bosch, president of the rummaking Bacardi company, died yesterday at her home here. She was 78years old.

title: `Dimbaza,
description: Five church organizations. two small foundations, a labor group, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and a private Individual have pooled funds and contributed $39,750 to put a documentary film smuggled out of South Africa on public television.

title: Maro Ajemian, Pianist, Returns to Concert Scene
description: Maro Ajemian, a pianist who was very active in New York concert life for about two decades following her debut in 1940 but who has made only a few appearances here in the last 15 years, came to Tully Hall for a recital Saturday night. Her program listed two Intermezzos by Brahms (Op. 117, No. 2, and Op. 118, No. 6), Schubert's Sonata in C minor (Op. Posth.), Mozart's Sonata in B flat (K. 333), Ben Weber's Intermezzo (Op. 64) and a Debussy group concluding with L'Isle Joyeuse.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Joseph V. Gemmiti, the Social Services commissioner of Saratoga County, has become the first government official to be indicted by any of the 15 grand juries now hearing evidence gathered by Charles .J. Hynes, the special state prosecutor for health and social services. Mr. Gemmiti, who had sought unsuccessfully to block the investigation in court, is accused of using public funds to pay the wages of the cook and housekeeper at his personal residence.

title: Grant Asks Court Approval For Professional Liquidator
description: The W.T. Grant Company, currently in Chapter XI bankruptcy proceedings, will ask John Galgay, the bankruptcy judge, for approval to hire professional liquidating company to help it dispose of assets in the 301 stores to be closed Dec. 31.

title: The New York Times/Paul Hosefros
description: REMINDERS OF YESTERDAY: The schooner Pioneer sailing past Ellis Island in Upper New York Bay yesterday. The 102foot iron coastal vessel sailed from South Street Seaport, near Fulton Street, taking passengers on excursions in New York Bay. Here, the twomasted Pioneer passed what had been a Federal immigration station until it was closed in 1954. and began to furl her sails in chilly, misty weather in preparation br docking.

title: Namath Sacked 7 Times in 4528 Jet Loss
description: Joe Namath was knocked down a career high (or low) of seven times yesterday in gritty performance that was wasted as his Jets dropped 4528 decision to the Baltimore Colts.

title: Englewood Names Jews Official Minority Group
description: ENGLEWOOD. N.J., Oct. 26What do Jews, American Indians, Americans of Asian descent and all women regardless of race, creed or color have in common in this suburban Bergen County community?

title: Heinz Heir May Oppose Scott
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI)Representative H. John Heinz, 3d, heir to the Heinz food fortune, announced today that he had registered a fundraising committee for a possible campaign for the seat now held by Hugh Scott, the Senate minority leader. The 74yearold Pennsylvania Senator is expected to announce his decision whether to seek reelection in early December. Mr. Heinz, 37, is a thirdterm Republican from Pittsburgh.

title: 10 Coast Prisoners at Large
description: FRESNO, Calif., Oct. 26 (AP) Ten felony prisoners were still at large today after an 18man escape from the county jail yesterday. Sheriff Harold McKinney, who has complained about his crackerbox jail built 34 years ago, noted it was the third escape since July.

title: Deaths
2 Charged With Holding Family in South Dakota
description: PIERRE, S. D., Oct. 26 (UPI)A couple and their three children touring the South Dakota Capitol today said two men had held them captive, made them drink whisky, robbed them of about $100 and terrorized them for an hour before they escaped. Two suspects were later captured by the police.

title: The New York Times/Pool Hosefros
description: REMINDERS OF YESTERDAY: The schooner Pioneer sailing past Ellis Island in upper New York Bay yester day. The 102foot iron coastal vessel sailed from South Street Seaport, near Fulton Street, taking passengers on excursions in New York Bay. Here, the twomasted Pioneer passed what had been a Federal immigration station until it was closed in 1954, and began to furl her sails in chilly, misty weather in preparation for docking.

title: 3 Die in Coast Plane Crash
description: VACAVILLE, Calif., Oct. 26 (UPI)At least three persons died in the crash of a light plane near here last night, the authorities said today. The victims, two women and a man, were not immediately identified.

title: Books of The Times
description: Of all the cities in the world, Marrakech is probably the most mysterious to Americans. Right now, it is the in place to go. While all cities are novel in myriad ways, the American traveler feels, about most of them, a sense of dja vu. Perhaps A STREET IN MARRAKECH. By Elizabeth Warnock Fernea. 382 pages.
