Doubleday. $8.95. he has seen them on television, or in a movie, or read too much about them. They are no longer virgin, or pure. After rummaging through France, England, Italy, Spain, Greece, Yugoslavia, India, Turkey, Egypt and Central Africa, the sophisticated traveler has elected Marrakech, Morocco, as the ultimate city, the only remaining place that one can go.

title: News Summary and Index
description: At least 52 persons were reported killed as warfare between leftist and rightist mobs spread through the downtown hotel district of Beirut. The towering Holiday Inn complex in the Lebanese capital became a strategic battleground, and more than 100 persons were reported wounded in the city and its suburbs. [ Page 1, Column 8. ]

title: Bridge: Borderline Bids Are Clarified By   Intentions of the Player
description: A player who opens with one of a suit holding less than eight highcard points is making a psychic bid. A player who opens with 9 or 10 points is simply making a light opening.

title: Young Women, Blacks Still Have High Hopes
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26At a time when the nation's collective sense of faith in the future has faltered, there is a surge of optimism among two groups of Americansyoung women and young blacks.

title: SERENA AT CUBICULO IN MIDEAST
description: Serena's attempt to reconcile the distant worlds of the leopard and harem pants was only partly successful Saturday evening at the Cubiculo. For the most part it was a tug of war between a Western esthetic and sensuous Middle Eastern movement.

title: Cowboys Beat Eagles, 2017, On Fritsch's LastSecond Kick
description: A 42yard field goal by Toni Fritsch sailed through the uprights just as time ran out, lifted Dallas to a 2017 triumph over the Philadelphia Eagles yesterday, and kept the oncedefeated Cowboys alone atop the National Football Conference East Division.

title: Negativism Held Peril to Amendments
description: Democratic and Republican politicians are predicting that the New York electorate is in such a negative, apathetic mood that voters are very likely to reject all or almost all of the seven statewide constitutinnal amendments, a statewide $250,000,000 housing construction bond issue and the 10 proposed City Charter amendments on Election Day, next Tuesday.

title: Thomas Conducts Rousing Symphony No. 4 by Ives
description: Since its first performance by Leopold Stokowski and the American Symphony Orchestra on April 26, 1965. the Symphony No. 4 of Ives has been gaining a foothold in the repertory. This glorious ruckus of a work, composed between 1909 and 1916 (some preliminary work on it dates from before 1900), still annoys many listeners by what they regard as its banal use of popular tunes and its pastiche construction. But the number of people who can take pleasure in the Ives Fourth in spite of or even because of, such matters has multiplied with improbable speed 1:1 the last decade.

title: The New York Times/William E. Sauro
description: MARCHING TO BEAT THE BANDS: Members of the Hanover Park marching band, led by a color guard, during band competition held yesterday at Waldwick High School in Waldwick. The Morris Knolls High School band, from Denville, took the honors as best overall band and also won three other bests. The Randolph Hgh School band from Randolph Township, was picked as the best band in a class for small high schools.

title: GOING OUT Guide

Knopf), Lincoln Kirstein's picture book with text on the nearly legendary Russian ballet performer, has prompted a photographic display by the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, whose large, comprehensive Roger Pryor Dodge Collection, depicting Vaslay Nijinsky's carrer, is the core of the new book. The late Mr. Dodge was a dancer  choreographer and student of Legat, Nijinsky's teacher, who traveled over Europe collecting photographs of the Russian dancer's personal triumphs, beginning with his early appearances in the Ballets Russes de Diaghilev.

Alexander, the Cornmissioner of Internal Revenue and a Bahamian hank suspected of being a haven for Americans attempting to evade taxes, sources familiar with the investigation said today.

title: Screen: 'The Devil Is a Woman,' Import With Glenda Jackson
description: You might imagine that anyone would have to be kidding to call a movie "The Devil Is a Woman" in this day and age. Not at all. "The Devil Is a Woman," the British-Italian co-production that opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse, means to be quite serious.It has nothing to do with the 1935 film of the same title  the great Josef Von Sternberg-Marlene Dietrich collaborationnor is it about diabolism. That is, it's not about diabolism as movie buffs in the last half of this century have come to recognize the symptoms: rocking beds, vomit, levitating children and the voice of Mercedes McCambridge running off at someone else's mouth.This "Devil Is a Woman" was directed by Damiano Damiani, an Italian director whose earlier credits are none too promising ("Arturo's Island," "The Empty Canvas"), but originally it may not have been quite so foolish as it now is. The film seems to have been so badly edited for its American release that it contradicts its own plot at key places. Also, some of the post-sychronized English dialogue is impossible to understand.Behind this cracked facade one occasionally glimpses the traces of an interesting if overwrought intellectual drama of the kind that Europeans take more seriously than we do. The setting ia a religious hostel-convent in Rome, a place that doesn't look much different from thousands of other Roman buildings on the outside but that on the inside suggests a series of sets that haven't yet been fully dressed for a Ken Russell movie.Running the establishment is Glenda Jackson, playing a character named Sister Geraldine, a handsome, frosty-mannered nun who enunciates so perfectly she always sounds as if she were in a speech competition. Sister Geraldine is big on the possibilities of redemption through prayer, group therapy (called "community meetings"), chastity and various other forms of self-denial.Because of this she neglects her duties at the convent to devote herself to the saving of a motley group of souls who have sought voluntary refuge in her art-deco hostel. Among them are a beautiful young Latin American woman who fingered her right-wing husband for assassination by associates of her left-wing lover; a young Roman prince whose family won't allow him to marry the girl he loves (his sister); a Cuban bishop who sided with Fidel Castro in the revolution, and a Polish monsignor accused of working with the Nazis against the Russians.Into this atmosphere, which is never as charged as it's supposed to be, comes a youngish Italian journalist who has been commissioned by the Polish monsignor to write the monsignor's defense. The journalist, who goes around preaching reason and the therapeutic value of not brooding too much, nearly wrecks Sister Geraldine's world, but he's a lazy fox in the hen house. How Sister Geraldine triumphs is the foggy point of the film.Neither Miss Jackson nor the other performers is especially convincing meeting the film's sometimes operatic requirements, including suicide, self-abuse (a priest's discreet term), fetishism and the like. Moral dilemmas are introduced, labelled and then passed over, like the fancy decor seen by the camera. Nothing is explored in depth. "The Devil Is a Woman" sort of scratches ideas as if they were minor itches.

description: There was almost unanimous agreement among the agencies in the race for the Toyota accountwon Friday by DancerFitzgeraldSample that the competition was one of the most sophisticated and efficiently managed in which they had been involved.

Britain and France have invested enormous sums and prestige in their supersonic airliner and urgently want an O.K. for commercial service. But the environ mental safety objectionsnoise, threat to the atmosphere, marginal fuel reservesare all so formidable.

description: RANCHO SANTA FE, Calif., Oct. 26 (AP)Mary Bea Porter almost lost her sevenstroke lead but recovered to turn hack a late challenge from Donna Caponi Young and win the $53,000 Ladies Classic today.

description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 26 (UPI)The United States gained its 116th gold medal of the PanAmerican Games today when the equestrian team brought 13 days of competition to a conclusion by winning the grand prix lumping event.

title: Inge Summer Brave Transcends Picnic
description: William Inge's spectacular, if comparatively brief, career as a popular American playwright was really established by his second big Broadway hit, Picnic, in 1953. Three years earlier he had a major Broadway success with Come Back, Little Sheba, but Picnic won its year's Pulitzer Prize and New York Critics Award, and helped place Inge into the major league of American playwriting.

title: Brazil Devalues Cruzeiro
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 26 (Reuters)  Brazil's central bank has devalued the cruzeiro for the 11th time this year, bringing the total devaluation for 1975 to 14.2 per cent. From tomorrow the new rates of buyerseller exchange will be 8.62/8.67 to the United States dollar, compared with the previous rate of 8.47/8.52.

title: Divisive Languages
description: Viewing the growing language conflict in Canada, Americans can be grateful that this country has no great region of nonEnglishspeaking citizens such the Province of Quebec. Puerto Rico, where Spanish the official language, is hardly comparable, since it an internally independent commonwealth associated with the United States but not an integral part of it. The very different Canadian situation tragically demonstrates the awesome power of bilingualism to perpetuate differences within a country, deepen antagonisms and make national politics an endless walk on an ethnic tightrope.

title: Italy's Inflation Rate Fell
description: ROME, Oct. 27 (Reuters) Inflation in Italy fell to an annual rate of 13 per cent in September compared with n'early 25 per cent in 1974, according to figures released by the National Statistics Institute today. title: Brazilian TV Man Held as Communist Is Reported Suicide
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 27 (Reuters)The Brazilian military said today that a television news editor committed suicide while in detention in Sao Paulo after having admitted to being a Communist party member.

title: SICILIAN DEFENSE
TATIANA LADY ADAMS
description: Tatiana Lady Adams, widow of Sir Walter Adams, retired director of the London School of Economics and Political Science, died Friday of a heart attack in Hyannis, Mass. She was 70 years old and lived in Sandwich, Kent, but had been visiting family and friends in this country.

title: Four Luxury Towers To House the Poor Opening in Harlem
description: A federally subsidized housing project for the poor is scheduled to open in East Harlem in about two months with luxury features never before included in lowincome housing in the United States. Depending on the point of view, the project is regarded as a monument to government compassion or an epitaph on bureaucratic folly.

title: Records of College Football Teams for This Season and Schedules of Their Remaining Games
A CHICAGO HOSPITAL STRUCK BY DOCTORS
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (UPI)Resident doctors and internes went on strike today at Cook County Hospital in a dispute over salaries, fringe benefits, union security and patient care.

title: Play and Musical to Open On Broadway in January
description: Two new productions, a play and a musical, were announced yesterday for Broadway presentation.

title: Nekoosa Price Rises Set
description: The Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation announced yesterday that effective Jan. 1 prices of its kraft linerboard and semichemical corrugating medium sold in the United States would increase $20 a ton.

title: Roundabout Stage Notes 10th Birthday
description: Off Broadway ventures can be as evanescent as passing summer clouds. But the Roundabout Theater, now celebrating its 10th anniversary season, is made of durable stuff.

title: Attica Defendant Reported To Have Died in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 27 (AP)John Mitchell, who was among the former Attica prison inmates indicted on charges growing out or the 1971 prison revolt, died over the weekend, the court was informed today.

title: People and Business
description: The Vshaped recoverya sharp economic upturn following a sharp downturnthat many economists predicted earlier this year may develop, according to conclusions of a new study by Geoffrey H. Moore, vice president of the National Bureau of Economic Research.

title: Quarter Slides 39.4%
description: The Norfolk & Western Railway reported yesterday a 39.4 per cent drop in its earnings in the three months to Sept. 30. John P. Fishwick, president, attributed the drop to the loss of $13.3million of coal traffic last month as a result of the wildcat coal strike in West Virginia and to recession conditions.

title: Rex Stout, Creator of Nero Wolfe, Dead
description: Rex Stout creator of Nero Wolfe died yesterday of natural causes at his home in Milltown Road, Danbury, Conn. He was 88 years old and had published last month his 46th Wolfe mystery A Family Affair,

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Chase Mortgage Loss
description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust, one of the big realestate lenders and the nation's largest realestate investment trust, reported yesterday a $166.4million loss for the fiscal year ended May 31. Page 43.

title: Bill From Hartford ForFord's Guard AgainGoesBegging
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 27  This city has twice tried to bill a Republican State Committee for $9,093.98 for overtime work by policemen and firemen, on the evening the President was here, two weeks ago. Once, the bill was bounced back to the city. Now the Republicans seem resolved to sit on it forever, if need be.

title: Nonunion Police Get Coast Teamster Aid
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 27Arguing that its image as labor's bully on the block gives it a formidable negotiating weapon the International Brotherhood of Teamsters is selling its services as a bargaining agent for nonunionized police forces in a growing number of California cities and towns.

title: Mayor Plans New Times Square Cleanup
description: Another campaign to rid Times Square of its reputation as a lurid crossroads was announced yesterday by Mayor Beame, who vowed that it would not be a glossedover, oneshot publicity drive but a successful challenge to public nuisances ranging from potholes to prostitutes.

title: AGENT BACKS SUIT AGAINST THE I.R.S.
description: An Internal Revenue Service agent from Miami and an informant who worked With him in investigating the secret flow of money from the United States to the Bahamas to avoid taxes have filed court papers to join a suit by six I.R.S. agents who are challenging a directive that all agents turn in the names of their confidential Informants.

title: 2 S.L.A. Members, Convicted of Murder, Facing 3 Additional Trials in California
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 27Although already sentenced to life in prison for murder, two members of the socalled Symbionese Liberation Army are facing three additional trials that state officials hope will result in further convictions to help insure lengthy prison terms for both.

title: Chess:; When Is a Tie Not a Tie? Why, Right Now, in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 27After 10 rounds of the Alekhine Memorial Tournament here in the Central Railwaymen's House of Culture, four players share the lead. Two former world champions, Boris Spassky and Tigran Petrosian. Efim Geller, a longtime contender for the title, and the upandcoming Armenian grandmaster Rafael Vaganian have taken 61/2 points each.

title: Dr. Chester Barrows Dies; Led Adelphi History Staff
description: Dr. Chester L. Barrows, who retired in 1963 as chairman of the history department at Adelphi University, died Friday of a heart attack in Chestnut Hill Hospital, Philadelphia. He was 83 years old and lived in Philadelphia with his wife at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Calvert Hall.

title: Business Briefs
description: Mortgage Loans Up in State

title: Reforming the Charter: I
description: Next Tuesday's vote on Charter reform offers the citizens of this debtridden city an opportunity to begin to redeem their civic selfrespect and solvency.

title: Dutch Debate Unpolished Army
description: SEEDORF ARMY BASE, West GermanyBrig. Gen. Hann Roos, the commandant of this Netherlands Army base near Bremen in West Germany, seldom gets a salute when he passes one of his soldiers on the sidewalk, and it still bothers the 31year veteran.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Manslaughter Conviction Reversed

title: Radiologists Want Their Fees Met by a Blue Shield Schedule
description: TRENTON, Oct. 27 (AP)The state radiologist society recommended today that payment for radiological services in hospitals be covered by a fee schedule arranged with Blue Shield of New Jersey.

title: GRAIN FUTURES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Contracts for grains and soybeans dropped sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, amid reports that the record corn crop and the abundant soybean crop are being piled up outside alreadyfilled grain elevators, along railroad sidings, and even op streets in small Midwest towns.

title: TRUMAN FOUNDATION GETS 8 TRUSTEES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) President Ford today named eight persons to serve on the board of trustees of the newly created Harry Truman Scholarship Foundation, which will make awards to outstanding individuals who plan a career in public service. Those named were:

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
British Soccer Standings
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Unbeaten Vikings Win, 139
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP)Fran Tarkenton sparked a 97yard drive capped by a 45yard scoring pass to Jim Lash. in the second quarter and Fred Cox boomed two long field goals to give the unbeaten Minnesota Vikings a 139 victory over the Chicago Bears in the National Football League tonight.

title: A Blue Monday for the Jets After Another Black Sunday
description: Mondays are for forgetting for football teams that get trounced by 452S on Sundays.

title: NOW Elects New Officers Pledged to Expand Group's Activities
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 The National Organization for Women ended a fourday national conference here today with the election of a new group of officers pledged to expand the organization's activities on behalf of poor women, minority women, housewives and lesbians.

title: Javits Supports Charter Reform
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits added his voice yesterday to those who favor the first six charterchange proposals on the city ballot, but Mayor Beame, according to City Hall sources, will add his voice to the opposition by the end of the week.

title: Coleman Offers Plan For Open Enrollment
description: Dr. James S. Coleman, the controversial sociologist who recently repudiated mandated busing for school desegregation after having provided research that supported busing, called yesterday for a new alternative: an open enrollment plan that would allow black students to cross into suburbs.

title: Late Canadien Surge Ties Islanders, 4 to 4
description: MONTREAL. Oct. 27In this FrenchCanadian city they call the New York Islanders La Bete Noire literally, the black beast, for they haunt the Montreal Canadiens like a black cat or something, said Michel (Bunny) Larocque, the Montreal goaltender.

title: Why CBS Killed New `Beacon Hill
description: Born in the patrician manner, with expectations and wide public notice. Beacon Hill stumbled in television's niarketplace and late last week was wheeled out of CBS through the servant's door.

title: EMBASSY ADVISES SOME AMERICANS TO QUIT LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, Oct. 28The United States Embassy yesterday advised American citizens to evacuate dependents and nonessential personnel from Lebanon as gun battles continued to spread in the capital.

title: Nat'l Football League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME Minnesota 13, Chicago 9.

title: Notes on People
description: Accompanied by a minor migration of his countrymen, including a Volkswagen executive, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany will leave today on the first trip to China by any West German leader. With him will gt, about 40 journalistsonly Germans, by his hosts decree; a score or Stair aloes and political figures; two labor union leaders and two industrialists (Hans Birn baum of Volkswagen and the Salzgitter steel works, and Herbert Grnewald, chairman of the Bayer chemical concern.) Max Frisch, a Swiss writer and amateur China expert, will also be with the party.

title: Nonunion Police Get Coast Teamster Aid
description: SAN DIEGO. Oct. 27Arguing that its image as labor's bully on the block gives it formidable negotiating weapon, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters is selling its services as a bargaining agent for nonunionized police forces in a growing number of California cities and towns.

title: ARCTIC PIPELINE IS SET FOR STUDY
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 27Hearings opened today on the applications of two rival companies, one an American Canadian consortium and the other all Canadian, to build a pipeline for Arctic natural gas.

title: College Conference Standings
DISSIDENTS ACTIVE IN SPANISH FORCES
description: MADRID, Oct. 25A clandestine association of Spanish military officers believes that civil war could follow the Franco era if it becomes apparent that the only alternative is 40 more years of fascism.

title: 341 MoreVietnameseComing
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 27 (UPI) A group of 341 South Vietnamese refugees left here today for the United States aboard a chartered plane. The refugees were among 4,000 South Vietnamese who fled to this colony after their country fell to the Communists last April.

title: Practical Feminist
description: PHILDELPHIA  I wasn't a feminist. I just wanted more money.

title: 3 Liquidators Fight for W.T. Grant
description: Three retail liquidating companies yesterday fought over a plum in the Federal Bankruptcy Court heredisposal of the W. T. Grant Company's $116,1million inventory In 301 stores to be closed by year's end. The fee could be as much as $1million.

title: French Quit Chad Bases
description: NDJAMENA, Chad, Oct. 27 (Reuters)France today completed evacuating her military bases here in accordance with a demand by the Government that followed negotiations between French representatives and the kidnappers of Francoise Claustre. The Government said France had interfered in Chadian affairs by dealing diectly with the rebels who have held Mrs. Claustre, an archeologist and Fench national, since last year.

title: Jimmy Caruthers, 30, Dies; Race Driver Fouaht Cancer
description: TUSTIN, Calif., Oct. 27 (UPI)  Jimmy Caruthers, race driver, who returned to competition after being hospitalized with cancer last winter, died yesterday at the age of 30.

title: Very Good Eddie
description: EAST HADDAM, Conn.The Goodspeed Opera House, despite its unlikely name and even more unlikely location, happens to be a quite extraordinarily beautiful theater. Built in 1876, it is a truly interesting little opera house and it has been quite exquisitely restored. With its riverside views, its handsome bars, its popcorn machine in the foyer, and indeed its general air of community attachment, the Goodspeed seems to be a nice place. Even for theater.

title: Moroccans Stream Toward the Sahara Shouting Slogans
description: AIT MELLOUL, Morocco, Oct. 26Beating tambourines, tooting horns, waving flags and shouting slogans, Moroccans are rolling south toward Spanish Sahara on every available truck.

title: PROXMIRE PUSHES COMPROMISE PLAN ON AID TO THE CITY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27Senator William Proxmire, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said tonight that he was hopeful of working out a compromise on legislation to provide Federal guarantees for New York City loans. He hopes to obtain committee approval for the measure tomorrow.

title: Leo J. Corcoran, 74, Dead; Was Bartender at Bleeck's
description: Leo J. Corcoran, who retired in 1973 as a bartender at the Artist and Writers Restaurant, a gathering place for newspapermen at 213 West 40th Street, died yesterday in his sleep at the home of his daughter, Betty Dodd, 330 Maitland Avenue, Teaneck, N.J., where he lived. He was 74 years old.

title: PROXMIRE PUSHES COMPROMISE PLAN ON AID TO THE CITY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27Senator William Proxmire, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said tonight that he was hopeful of working out a compromise on legislation to provide Federal guarantees for New York City loans. He hopes to obtain committee approval for the measure tomorrow.

title: Russians Reported Building a Third Aircraft Carrier
description: The Soviet Union has begun construction of a third aircraft carrier, according to Defense Department analysts.

title: Market Place
description: Owners of coupon bonds would be welladvised to reflect on the fate of hundreds of holders of the bonds of the bankrupt Penn Central railroad who failed to submit interest coupons promptly.

title: BYRNE GETS REPORT ON CARTER INQUIRY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 27 (AP)Assemblyman Eldridge Hawkins, Democrat of Essex County gave Governor Byrne a progress report today on his investigation of the case of Rubin Hurricane Carter.

title: About the Giants.
description: Henry Stuckey will be lost for the season following surgery yesterday to repair ligaments in his right knee. He suffered the injury last Saturday against St. Louis. Earlier, the cornerback had leftknee problems from an injury at Miami. ... Another Saturday at Shea Stadium looms, this time against the San Diego Chargers, who have scored only 37 points in six games. The Giants defense has yielded only six touchdowns in the last 3 games. The Chargers defense is young, like we are, said Coach Bill Arnsparger. The line is big and tough to run against. They fight and scratch for everything, just like we do. ... The backfield situation remains flexible. I'll keep working five guys and find the one or two who are having the good day and use them that game, said Arnsparger. Ron Johnson ran well against Buffalo. Joe Dawkins ran well against St. Louis.

title: Stroessner's Party Victor In Paraguay Local Polls
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, Oct. 27 (Reuters)  President Alfredo Stroessner's Colorado party won a landslide victory in local elections yesterday, according to results published here today.

title: FORD WELCOMES SADAT AND VOWS TO PURSUE PEACE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27President Ford gave a warm welcome to President Anwar elSadat of Egypt today and later pledged that the United States was determined not to tolerate stagnation or stalemate in the quest for peace in the Middle East.

title: Beame Says No to Welcome for Sadat
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that he would not officially welcome President Anwar elSadat of Egypt during his 24hour visit to the city over tomorrow and Thursday or present him with a key to the city.

title: Juan Carlos Aide Responds To an Article in Newsweek
description: A spokesman in Madrid for Juan Carlos de BorbOn said yesterday that the Prince had not given an interview to a correspondent for Newsweek magazine, which reports in this week's issue that Juan Carlos would like to be the symbol of national unity and reconciliation as the new King of Spain.

title: Streamlining in Britain
description: LONDONWhen President Ford was explaining to the leaders of the United States Conference of Mayors some weeks ago why he found the whole idea of Federal financial aid for New York City so revolting, the horrible example he kept citing of a government that spends itself sick was Britain's, with its Labor Government and its welfare state.

title: Chavez Farm Workers Gain Over Teamsters
description: FRESNO, Calif. Oct. 27 (AP) The United Farm Workers has surged ahead in union elections over the representation of California field hands.

title: GeorgiaPacific Plant Study
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 27 (UPI)Directors of the GeorgiaPacific Corporation authorized today a feasibility study for an expansion into ammonia production, using hydrogen produced by the company as feedstock. The proposed plant would utilize hydrogen gas, byproduct from the company's methanol and chlorinecaustic plants at Plaquemine, La. The company said initial capacity would be about 55 tons of ammonia a day if the project is finally approved.

title: Fiscal Changes
description: Many of the fiscal changes contained in Proposition One have long been advocated by budget experts and civic groupsincluding some groups which are now inexplicably opposing the Charter recommendations. The list includes such basic reforms as the requirement for a balanced budget, using accounting principles approved by the State Controller; elimination of expense items from the capital budget; prohibition of shortterm borrowing against uncertain revenues, and provision for an annual audit.

title: COVERUP IS LAID TO RAYTHEON CO.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UPI) The Raytheon Company attempted to cover up a $300,000 agent's fee in connection with the sale of Hawk antiaircraft missiles to Israel, accordtng to Representative Les Aspin.

title: PUERTO RICAN UNIT SAYS IT SET BOMBS
description: A leftist underground group that is demanding independence for Puerto Rico took responsibility yesterday for nine almost sumultaneous earlymorning bomb explosions at government buildings, corporate offices and banks in New York, Chicago and Washington.

title: Music: A Vocal Display
description: Last March Katia Ricciarelli, Jose Carreras and Martin Katz, their accompanist, gave their first joint recital in Carnegie Hall. Sunday night they returned for another, similar affair. This time they had been billed all along (the first time they were substituting for Montserrat Caballe) and their program concentrated even more on obscure 19thcentury Italian music than before. Vocally speaking, the two gingers make a curious pair. Mr. Carreras had the crowd more raucously with him, at least at first, but for this listener Miss Ricciarelli is the far more satisfying technician and artist.

title: REPORT ON ATTICA GIVEN TO GOVERNOR
description: Bernard S. Meyer, who was named last April to head an independent inquiry into the charge that the chief Attica prosecutor had covered up possible crimes by law enforcement officers, submitted a threevolume, 570page report yesterday to Governor Carey and Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

title: GAMEY INTERPRETS SCHUMANN'S WORKS
description: To restate an old joke, if there are 10 pianists in a room, they will have 11 different ideas of how to play Schumann. With this most personal of composers, it is easy to get so possessive about a preferred interpretive approach that all others are discounted.

title: ACTIONS OF JUDGE RULED MISCONDUCT
description: The state's special judicial disciplinary court yesterday found Supreme Court Justice Wilfred A. Waltemade guilty of misconduct.

title: Maddox Sues City For Knee Injury
description: Elliott Maddox, the Yankee center fielder, has filed a claim of $1million against the city, contending that negligent design and inadequate drainage of the playing field at cityowned Shea Stadium caused him to slip on wet outfield grass and injure his right knee in the ninth inning of a game against the White Sox on Friday night, June 13.

title: Associated Press Daniel P. Moynihan, U.S. delegate to the United Nations, views windows damaged In blast at his headquarters
ARGENTINES ABDUCT MERCEDES MANAGER
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 27 Leftwing Peronist guerrillas claimed responsibility today for the kidnapping of the West German production manager of the MercedesBenz truck plant, where 4,000 workers have been on strike for three yeeks.

title: Chase Mortgage Loss
description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust, one of the big realestate lenders and the nation's largest realestate investment trust, reported yesterday a $166.4million loss for the fiscal year ended May 31. Page 43.

title: The Farms of Suffolk
description: John V. N. Klein, the Republican candidate to succeed himself as Suffolk County Executive, has been the prime mover of a plan for saving some 12,000 acres of eastern Long Island from the threfitening blight of real estate development. His Democratic opponent, Joseph A. Clemente, favors the Klein approach but, like some Democrats in the County Legislature, argues that it does not go far enough.

title: Senator Backs Harrington
description: BOSTON, Oct. 27 (AP)The chairman of the Senate Committee on Intelligence has defended Representative Michael J. Harrington's disclosures of C.I.A. involvement in Chile. The chairman, Senator Frank, Church, Democrat of Idaho, said that Americans might never have known what went on in Chile if Mr. Harrington, a Massachusetts Democrat, had not spoken up.

title: Experts Fear Turkey Will Permit Wider Opium Poppy Cultivation
description: AFYON, Turkey  Turkey did a good job of controlling the production of opium poppies during the growing season that ended in September, according to American and United Nations experts.

title: Waldheim in Madrid For Talks on Sahara
description: MADRID, Oct. 27 (Reuters) Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations arrived here today for talks with Spanish rofficials on the Sahara dispute after having visited Morocco, Mauritania and Algeria.

title: Lowered Confidence in Nation: Its Effect on Spending and Votes
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 27It is only the suggestion of a trend, and so far it is probably felt more as a big apprehension than a conscious thought. But a fear appears to be growing among many Americans that the News party may be over, Analysis The Great American Dreamsome but not everybody, would define it as more money, a good job with a good future. a better home, peace of mind seems somehow less attain able to many people after a year of economic difficulties and a longer period of national setbacks that appear to have reduced the confidence of many Americans in their institutions and their country.

title: In Paris, It s Pants In a Myriad of Styles (Plus a Skirt or Two)
description: PARIS  Long pants. Short pants. Bloused legs. Jumpsuits. Just when you'd imagine everything possible that would be done to pants had been done to them, Paris designers come out with a whole new bag of tricks for spring.

title: Five Hurt as Greek Tanker Explodes Near Singapore
description: SINGAPORE, Tues., Oct. 28 (UPI)  A Greek tanker exploded and broke into two sections off Singapore today. The police said that 53 crewmen had been rescued, five of them badly burned. No fatalities were reported.

title: Buckley Leads in Senate Campaign FundRaising
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 27 (UPI) Twenty of the 33 Senators up for reelection next year have already started raising money for their campaigns, according to the Federal Election Commission.

title: GUAM REFUGEE SHIP IN VIETNAM WATERS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 27 (Agence FrancePress)The ship bringing home 1,500 South Vietnamese regugees from the American island of Guam has entered Vietnamese territorial waters, an authoritative source disclosed here today.

title: Envoy Tells Pelham Immunity Extends To His Biting Dog
description: The chief delegate from Bar bados to the United Nations has written the Mayor of Pelham, N.Y., to warn of possible international consequences if his dog is shot for biting Pelham residents.

title: Innovative Designs in the City
description: Scattered about the city are examples of innovative, lowincome housing projects, built with government subsidies, that put particular emphasis on esthetics and are a far cry from earlier public housing.

title: Bureau of Indian Affairs Is Struck by Blast. Too
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 27 (AP) An explosion at the Bureau of Indian Affairs. apparently set off at the same time as one reported earlier at the State Department, was discovered late this afternoon.

title: ELIZABETH T. WILLIS
description: Elizabeth Tooker Willis, who operated the Scarsdale Book Shop for many years, died Sunday at her home, 294 Old Colony Road, Hartsdale, N.Y. She was 64 years old, the wife of J. Brooke Willis, a retired banker.

title: Ball Says Default by City Would Help Communism
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27Congress has been given wideranging advice on what it should or should not do about New York City's fiscal crisis by dozens of witnesses before Senate and House committees studying the problem. Many have warned of possible adverse national and international repercussions from a city default.

title: Idle Dice Takes Evening Event
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 Alligator Farm's Sympatico, handled by Tony D'Ambrosio Jr., and the United States Equestrian Team's Idle Dice, ridden by Rodney Jenkins, each won a jumper class at the Washington International Show today.

title: A LARGE DEFICIT REPORTED BY LTV
description: The LTV Corporation reported yesterday a large deficit for the third quarter after showing profits in the two previous quarters. As a result, the company made some money in the ninemonth period, but only about a tenth of what it earned in the 1974 period.

title: QuinlanCase Ruling Due in 1014 Days; Final Arguments in Case Take 2 Hours
description: MORRISTOWN, Oct. 27Superior Court Judge Robert Muir Jr. said today that he would decide in 10 to 11 days whether to Karen Ann eQuinIan's father to withdraw a mechanical respirator so that she may die with peace and dignity. The respirator has been sustaining the breathing of the 21year old woman. Who has been in a coma for six months.

title: Radio
description: 67:25 A.51., WNYCFM. Overture to Prometheus, Beethoven; Minuet, Boccherini; Recorder Sonata in F, Scarlatti; Sonata for Strings No. 4, Rossini; Bassoon Concerto in B flat, Mozart. 9:0610, WQXR: Piano Per sonalities. Alfred Brendel. Piano Sonata No. 32 in C minor, Beethoven.

title: Consumer Goods Cited
description: The National Steel Corporation's thirdquarter earnings fell 90 per cent behind the yearago level as sales dropped by 26,8 per cent, according to the quarterly report yesterday. Net income for the first nine months ran 68 per cent lower and sales were 16.8 pet rent below the like 1974 period

title: Maybe the New Boys Can Win
description: Two headlines on facing pages of The New York Times suggest another of the many complexities facing the Democratic paryy. Humphrey Leads in Poll of Democrats, says one. Carter Appears to Hold a Solid Lead in Iowa, says the other, as the Campaign's First Test Approaches.

title: Mysterious New Disease Said to Spread in 8 States
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 27 (AP)A mysterious and sometimes deadly new disease discovered two years ago is becoming increasingly prevalent, a state health official says.

title: Government Reform
description: Proposition Three is generally concerned with strengthening the role of the City Council and Board of Estimate as checks against the abuse of mayoral powers. establishes an Office of Budget Review, a tool long missed by those conscientious Council members who know they need help to evaluate and challenge mayoral budgets. This proposition also gives Council committees new investigative and oversight powers and creates city information and comolaint units.

title: Chicago Council Votes to Replace Civil Service System
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 27As of Jan. 1, Chicago's 80yearold Civil Service Commission, affecting 40,000 city workers, will be scrapped in favor of a new system that critics of Mayor Richard J. Daley say will further enhance his already tight grip on city government.

title: About the Islanders.
description: The Islanders boarded the Montreal metro along with the rushhour commuters for a 10minute subway ride the Forum. ... Ralph Stewart sat out his third consecutive game last night. Andre St. Laurent also sat out. Both the Canadiens and the Islanders have young clubs. The Canadiens average age is 25.5; the Islanders 25. Jude Drouin celebrates his 27th birthday today and Denis Potvin, playing his third year in the N.H.L., will be 22 tomorrow. ... The hottest lines in the league are Buffalo's French Connection, Rick Martin, Gil Perreault and Rene Roberts with 39 points and the Islanders Bryan Trottier, Billy Harris and Clark Gillies with 37 points.

title: Socialists and Reds Seek Common Ground in Spain
description: MADRID, Oct. 27Two major opposition groups in ISpainone basically Socialist and the other basically Commuinistare preparing joint action in an effort to assure that what they call a new, democratic Spain will follow the end of Ithe Franco regime.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a typographical error, it was reported erroneously in some editions of The New York Times yesterday that Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. of West Virginia had pleaded guilty to Federal fraud and securities charges. No such charges have been made against the Governor. The reference was to Theodore Price, former head of the bankrupt Diversified Mountaineer Corporation of West Virginia.

title: Belmont Race Charts
description: 1975. by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Monday, October 27. 55th day, Weather cloudy, track good.

title: Deaths
description: ADAMSTatiana, wife of the late Sir Walter Adams, C.M.G., 0.B.E., mother at Michael, Peter, George and Natalie, sister of George Makaroff. Funeral service on Wednesday at 9 A.M., Holy Trinity Church, 253637th St., Astoria, Queens.

title: White House Connection
description: The Domestic Council's white paper on drug abuse makes a good deal more sense than anything else that has been issued from the White House on that subject. The white paper avoids both the shrill cries of alarm and the dramatic overpromising which have characterized the approaches of previous White Houses to drugs and drugrelated problems.

title: Writing Team Details the Freeing of India
description: As Larry Collins recalls it, he was in an auto in London when his companion, Earl Mountbatten of Burma, turned to him and said:

title: Books of The Times
description: Peter Maas's King of the Gypsies is, must be conceded, an extremely neat piece of journalisma textbook lesson, almost, in what an interesting story ought to be. It deals with a difficult, inaccessible subject KING OF THE GYPSIES. By Peter Maas. 171 pageses. Illustrated. Viking. $7.95. the culture of the million or so gypsies in America, whose first rule of survival is to remain unaccounted for and who have managed to swim in our computerized society without ever getting themselves, folded, spindled or mutilated. It is built around a dramatic and significant event in American gypsy lifethe 1969 deathbed decision of King Tene Bimbo,accordirig to Mr. Maas the most powerful of the gypsy chieftains in this country; the King of Kings, they used to call him, a kind of Mafialike Boss of All Bosses to pass on his title and the equipage of his office, not to his son Carranza, a man of violence fully committed to the gypsy way of life, but instead to Carranza's son, Steve Tene, youngster barely of age and with only tenuous connection to the ways of his

title: Wood, Field and Stream: State Guides Have Errors
description: There are several errors in the published hunting regulations of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, includingboth the smallgame and biggame hunting guides and a news release involving biggame hunting in Albany County.

title: ARTHUR L. FRIEDMAN
description: Arthur L. Friedman, a retired textile merchant and music patron, died Saturday at his home, 150 Central Park West. His age was 95.

title: Going Out Guide
description: HARD MITER The jolting humor and merciless satire of an art exhibition opening today in Greenwich Village may not be for everybody's taste, but the sponsors of The National Lampoon probably don't care, since Their publicatiort was cited this year for outstanding achievement in visual excellence by the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism. The sixyearold magazine's first showcase display of its art includes 50 paintings from its covers and pages that lambast miscarriages of justice linked to American history in such actions as riots, rigged elections, executions, massacres and even fish kills.

title: Socialists and Reds Seek Common Ground in Spain
description: MADRID, Oct. 27Two major opposition groups in Spainone basically Socialist and the other basically Communistare preparing joint action in an effort to assure that what they call a new, democratic Spain will follow the end of the Franco regime.

title: Nine Banks Tell Yonkers It Might Default  in Month
description: YONKERS, Oct. 27  The City of Yonkers was told today that it might default next month largely because of its proximity to New York City.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Equal Rights Amendment states, as constitutional principle, men and women are equal before the law. It does not say men and women are the same. Nor does the First Amendment say all religions are the same. But the First Amendment does say Government may not discriminate for or against Protestant, Catholic or Jew. In the same way the E.R.A. says Government may not discriminate because of gender.

title: Executives Learn How to Operate Newspaper Equipment at Center in Oklahoma City
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Oct. 24Seventeen newspaper executives and supervisors from the United States and Canada put away their ties and suits last Monday, donned work clothes and reported for pressroom training and duty at the Newspaper Production and Research Center here.

title: Pottery Takes Shape In Burst of Spontaneity
description: Raku is the name given to a form of pottery, of Japanese origin, that is attracting increasing attention among contemporary ceramists.

title: The N.H.S. Dilemma
description: After resisting the idea for many months, Prime Minister Wilson has finally set up a royal commission to investigate the National Health Service (N.H.S.). His decision is an explicit admission that the British system of socialized medicine is now in deep trouble.

title: Procter &
description: The Procter & uamoie Lompany, the nation's largest manufacturer of soaps and detergents, reported yesterday record eanings, with net income for the first fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30 up 11.3 per cent on a sales gain of only 3.9 per cent over the corresponding anarter last year.

description: OLTARSHEdna C. Unveiling of foot stone in her beloved memory on Sunday. November 2d at 1 P.M. at Unionfield Cemetery, Bklyn Plot 2012, Path 7. NO postpocement.

description: LOS ANGELESCarlos Palomino, 147 pounds, Long Beach, Calif., knocked out Eddie Alexander, 153, Sacramento, Calif., 5 rounds.

title: New York's Welfare Problem
description: There is almost complete unanimity that welfare costs are a primary cause of New York City's problems.

title: FORD WELCOMES SADAT AND VOWS TO PURSUE PEACE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27President Ford gave a warm welcome to President Anwar elSadat of Egypt today and later pledged that the United States was determined not to tolerate stagnation or stalemate in the quest for peace in the Middle East.

title: Stevenson Takes Spotlight In Senate on Aid to the City
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27For the first time since he came to the Senate nearly five years ago, Adlai E. Stevenson 3d is in the forefront of a major running Senate debate.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 2.5 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 200.2 for the week ended Oct. 21, compared with 202.7 the previous week.

title: Use of Psychology Ruled Basis to Void Confession
description: TRENTON, Oct. 27 (UPI)New Jersey's second highest court ruled today that a confession elicited by authorities using psychological tactics was just as invalid as one forced out of a suspect by a beating.

title: BYRNE ASSAILS U.S. ON MEDICARE CUTS
description: TRENTON, Oct. 27 (AP)Governor Byrne said today that proposed Federal Medicare cuts would cost residents of New Jersey at least $37million.

title: Drop Kick by New Dorp Beats Jefferson, 1514
description: As time ran out, Frank Perotta of New Dorp High School drop kicked a 26yard field goal yesterday as the Centrals ended Jefferson's winning streak at 15 games with a 1514 football victory at the Jefferson field.

title: Music Lovers Camp Out for Horowitz Tickets
description: Led by a 13yearold boy who said he had been studying the piano seriously for only two years, more than 100 music lovers took up positions outside Carnegie Hall last night to insure themselves tickets to a rare concert by Vladimir Horowitz, the 72yearold pianist, scheduled for Nov. 16. Eighteen hundred tickets were scheduled to go on sale at 10 this morning. By 10:30 last night, Alexander Stein, the 13yearold who started the line at 1 P.M., had registered 112 enthusiasts for the periodic rollcalls he had scheduled to guarantee places in line. Many had brought sleeping bags, food and books, ranging from a Mozart score to Conversations in the Raw by Rex Reed.

title: Moroccans Stream Toward the Sahara Shouting Slogans
description: AIT MELLOUL, Morocco, Oct. 26Beating tambourines, tooting horns, waving flags and shouting slogans, Moroccans are rolling south toward Spanish Sahara on every available truck.

title: Dietitian Shot to Death In Her Home in Flushing
description: A 54yearold dietitian at Queens hospital was shot to death in her Flushing home late yesterday afternoon, and the police began a search for a man who had reportedly lived with her off and on for several years.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1975

title: FMC TO CONSIDER FIBER UNIT'S SALE
description: The FMC Corporation, a diversified company that had over $2billion in sales of chemicals, fiber, film, machinery and equipment in 1974 said yesterday that it intended to explore the possibility of selling Merger its fiber division. News Last year the division, which makes rayon, acetate, and polyester yarn and staple fiber, reported sales of $317million and incurred an aftertax loss of $17.2million. In the first nine months of 1975, the division incurred an aftertax loss of $4.8million on sales of $152million.

title: Associated Press Daniel P. Moynihan, U.S. delegate to the united Nations, views windows damaged in blast at his headquarters
Paradox in Women's Movement: Feminists Who Are Mormons
description: SALT LAKE CITYMormon feminists are stepping out of the closet, and for many the trek is symbolically as hard as the crosscountry journey their persecuted ancestors took more than a century ago to reach the Utah desert.

title: EMBASSY ADVISES SOME AMERICANS TO QUIT LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, Oct. 28The United States Embassy yesterday advised American citizens to evacuate dependents and nonessential personnel from Lebanon as gun battles continued to spread in the capital.

title: Management Changes
description: No one familiar with the way New York now operates can doubt the need for sweeping changes in municipal management, as set forth in Proposition Two. As the case of fiscal reforms, calls for new management practices have been sounded for decades by experts whose recommendations have gone unheeded in City Hall.

description: Carlisle De Coppet & Co. the nation's last remaining odd lot brokerage house, disclosec yesterday that it had askec the New York Stock Exchang( to buy the company and oper ate it on behalf of small in vestors.

title: HIGH MARCOS AIDE IS SLAIN IN MANILA
description: MANILA, Oct. 27 (AP)A presidential assistant was shot to death today In his office 200 yards from the presidential palace, members of President Ferdinand E. Marcos's staff said.

title: Oil Concerns to Answer Venezuela Tonight
description: By midnight tonight the 31 American and other foreign oil companies operating in Venezuela are required to say yes or no to the terms of nationalization offered them by the Venezuelan Government.

title: School Football
Bridge
description: Any player is entitled to feel victimized by the fates when his opponents bring home a terrible slam contract they have reached as a result of a misunderstanding. But the victim's blood pressure is liable to mount even further if he then finds that he has missed a highly ingenious line of defense that would have succeeded.

title: Stage: Fable
description: A Fable begins once upon a time in the village of People Who Fish in the Lake, where almost everyone longs nostalgically for, The Golden Time When people spoke music and people moved dancing. A haughty king sends a traveler (Tina Shepard) in pursuit of a mysterious beast and on the road she participates in a series of perilous and humorous adventures. The tale is Thurberish, William Steiglike, a picaresque journey filled with pluck, luck and comic roadblocks.

title: HighYield Nuclear Test Set for Today in Nevada
description: MERCURY, Nev., Oct. 27 (AP) A highpowered nuclear de vice will be exploded underground tomorrow at the Nevada test site in a weapons development test, the Energy Research and Development Administration said today.

title: UNIONS IN JERSEY SEEK DEFEAT OF 6
description: TRENTON, Oct. 27True to a September promise, the New Jersey state A.F.L.C.I.O. has called for the defeat next Tuesday of the six Assemblymen who voted against a $40million addition to highway construe[don funds in the Byrne administration's $922million bond issue.

title: Dibbs Captures Final in Teheran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 27 (AP)  Fifthseeded Eddie Dibbs of Miami beat unseeded Ivan Molina of Colombia, 16, 64, 75, 64, today and valued at $1,000. Molina won S9.000.

description: Theater

title: A Cash Shortage Found In State's July 4 Lottery
description: State auditors disclosed yesterday that income from the state's special million  dollar lottery last July 4 was more than half a million dollars short of the amount needed to guarantee payment of the three top prizes.

title: Saints (15) Drop North As Coach
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 27 (UPI)John Mecom Jr., owner of New Orleans Saints, discharged Coach John North tonight and named the director of personnel, Ernie Hefferle as the interim coach.

title: State Judge Throws Out Monaghan Perjury Case
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed a 19monthold indictment against George P. Monaghan, a former Cify Police and Fire Commissioner who had been accused of lying before a grand jury investigating a loansharking operation.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Judge Throws Out Monaghan Case

title: FIRST INMATES FREE UNDER GEORGIA PLAN
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 22 (UPI)Some 330 inmates left the Georgia prison system today and 1,000 more are expected to be freed in the next six months to relieve severe overcrowding.

title: HIGH PRICES HURT DEVELOPING LANDS
description: GENEVA, Oct. 27The oilpoor developing countries are as hard hit by the higher prices they must pay for the producti of the industrialized nations as by the higher cost of petroleum, according to an international study.

title: Picasso Painting Missing From a Storage Building
description: A Picasso painting entitled Hommesa1aCasquette, (Man With a Hat),valued by its owners at $50,000, was reported yesterday missing from the Auer Van and Express Company storage building at 1721 Park Avenue in East Harlem.

title: LISBON MILITARY BLOCKS LAND GRAB
description: LISBON, Oct. 27 (AP)An army cavalry unit swept onto a farm in the central Ribatejo region today and blocked a seizure by Communistled squatters in the first decisive military crackdown on illegal land seizures.

title: Changes at Fuller &
description: Fuller & Smith & Ross, one of the few double ampersand agencies, has just made some major changes at the top. Arthur E. Duram, president for the last seven years, has been named vice chairman and chairman of the newly formed executive cornmittee, and Paul Brickman, a native of Mount Vernon, N. Y., and now senior vice president and general manager of the agency's Chicago office, has been made president and chief operating officer.

title: For British Cars, a Rocky Road
description: LONDON, Oct. 25A $3,000 minicar called the Kitten was a significant new model at London's big Earl's Court motor show, which closed here today.

title: The Credit Market Takes Breather
description: After a threeweek rally in prices, the credit market took a breather yesterday as Veterans Day observances outside the New York area reduced trading activity considerably.

title: Printing Shops and Union Agree on a 10Year Pact
description: Typographical Union No. and the Printers League, representing 400 commercial printing shops in the area, announced yesterday that they had reached tentative agreement on a 10year contract that opens the way for unlimited automation, provides wage and costofliving increases and guarantees full dayscale pay for all current employes.

title: I.M.F. Weighs Ending Its Special Oil Facility
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 27 (Reuters)The International Monetary Fund may not continue its special Oil Facility next year, the fund's Managing Director, Dr. H. Johannes Witteveen, said today.

title: BOND ISSUE IS SOLD
description: PARIS, Oct. 27The French steel industry, which functions as a unit when It raises money from the public, is marketing the largest bond issue in Its history in an effort to complete capital  expansion projects threatened by this year's redink ooerations.

title: ACTIONS OF JUDGE RULED MISCONDUCT
description: The state's special judicial disciplinary court yesterday found Supreme Court Justice Wilfred A. Waltemade guilty of misconduct.

title: Sylvester Morey, Chairman Of Myrin Institute, 79, Dies
description: Sylvester M. Morey, chairman of the Myrin, Institute, Inc. for adult education, and former chairman of Geyer, Morey, Ballard, Inc., advertising, died Sunday in Great Barrington, Mass., where he lived. He was 79 years old.

title: Document That Doomed Marie Antoinette Stolen
description: PARIS, Oct. 27 (AP)The order that sent Marie Antoinette to the guillotine in 1793 has been stolen from the French historical museum, the museum's curator told the police today.

title: People in Sports
description: While accepting a new AMC Pacer yesterday at the Plaza Hotel for being voted the most valuable player in the World Series, Pete Rose admitted there was one point in his career with the Cincinnati Reds when Charley Hustle (his popular nickname) dogged it.

description: KERNHanry Charles, Beloved son, cherisied brother, adored uncle, Forever in our hearts. Mom and Dad, Dorothe and Joe, Susan And Debbi.

title: Sadat Tells of a Rebuff By a Zionist
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27President Anwar elSadat of Egypt struck out against Zionism today, asserting that he could not buy a radio in 1950 because a Jewish shopkeeper in Cairo, under orders from Zionism, refused to sell him one.

title: Sharnik New CBS Director Of PublicAffairs Programs
description: John Sharnik has been appointed vice president and director, publicaffairs broadcasts, for CBS News, succeeding Bill Leonard, who last Week was named Washington vice nresident for CBS, Inc.

title: Yonkers Results
ExRep. John J. Rooney Of Brooklyn Is Dead at 71
description: John J. Rooney, once one of the most powerful men in Congress, died in Washington Sunday night after having undergone surgery at Georgetown University Hospital. He was 71 years old.

title: Boston Whites March in Busing Protest
description: BOSTON, Oct. 27Thousands of white demonstrators marched through the main streets of South Boston today to protest courtordered busing for school desegregation.

title: Women Priests Opposed
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 27 (UPI)Delegates to a weekend Diovese of Oregon rejected a resolution favoring the ordination of women to the priesthood. Delegates from the clergy voted 49 to 37 against the measure while the lay delegates voted 121 to 92 against it.

title: Stock Index Drops 2.04 As Trading Volume Falls
description: After Friday's substantial drop in the stock market, yesterday's performance was anticlimatic. Stock prices wavered up and down within narrow limits and the Dow Jones industrial average closed with a small decline. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was light.

title: Sohio Net Fell in Quarter; Phillips Petroleum Is Off
description: Net income from operations of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) fell in the third quarter of 1975 to $32.7million. or 89 cents a share, from $37.2million, or $1.02 a share, in the third quarter of 1974.

title: Miss Hearst and Miss Moore Share Coast Prison Corridor
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Oct. 27Patricia Hearst and Sara Jane Moore shared a jailhouse corridor here this weekend.

title: National Airlines Cutting Supervisory Staff by 10%
description: MIAMI, Oct. 27 (UPI) Strikebound National Airlines is trimming the rolls of its executive and supervisory personnel by 10 per cent, and the 100 layoffs announced last week represent jobs being permanently abolished in a costcutting move, a spokesman announced today.

title: Tens of Thousands at Rites In Ankara for Slain Envoys
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct 27 (Reuters)Tens of thousands of people lined the streets of Ankara today, some weeping, as Turkey gave a state funeral to its two slain ambassadors.

title: Japan Curbs Toyota View
description: TOKYO, Oct. 27 (AP)Japans Environment Agency has requested the Toyota Motor Company to collect and destroy all copies of a pamphlet distributed to the auto makers employes that criticized the Governments antipollution policy.

title: 70 BELIEVED LOST IN CRASH IN ANDES
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 25 (UPI)A Bolivian Air Force transport plane crashed in the Andes today, apparently killing all 70 persons aboard, most of them army officers, their wives, children and other relatives.

title: Music: A Dazzling Debut
description: Viktor Fnedman's New York debut recital on Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall stamped the Moscowborn pianist as a strong technician whose playing invariably dazzled the ear. The darkhaired musician, who seemed to be in his middle 40's, emigrated to this country last year and now teaches at the Philadelphia Musical Academy.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1973

title: Rex Stout, Creator of Nero Wolfe, Dead
description: Rex Stout, creator of Nero Wolfe, died yesterday of natural causes at his home in Milltown Road, Danbury. Conn. He was 88 years old and had published last month his 46th Wolfe mystery, A Family Affair.

title: Dempsey Continues To Be `Satisfactory
description: Jack Dempsey, the former heavyweight ... boxing champion, continued in satisfactory condition yesterday at New York University Hospital where he is undergoing evaluation tests.

title: DETROIT TO PRESS RESIDENCY LIMIT
description: DETROIT, Oct. 27  Officials here are preparing for crackdown on city employes who live outside Detroit in violation of the city's residency ordinance.

title: Soviet in TextileExport Drive
description: The Soviet Union is seeking to increase its exports of finished textiles to the United States, officials of V/O Exportljon, the Soviet State fiberexporting agency, said at the opening of an exhibit in the World Trade Center. The Soviet Union is already a major exporter of textiles to Europe, Asia and Africa, and it achieved a $2billion volume of shipments to other countries last year.

title: Hospitals Criticized by Survey On Treatment of Rape Victims
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) Many of the nation's hospitals make it difficult, expensive and embarrassing for a rape victim to obtain an examination and treatment, according to a new Governmentfunded survey.

title: Volunteers Help Revitalize Jersey City's Village Area
description: JERSEY CITY  A yearlong campaign to save a colorful, vanishing section of downtown Jersey City is beginning to pay off.

title: SnowKnight Pointed for International
description: Having just returned from Woodbine, where a day earlier he had saddled Snow Knight to victory in the 188,700 Canadian InternaAlonal Championship, Mack At the Tracks Race MiIler was at Belmont Park yesterday discussing training plans for the strapping Engish  bred colt. There will be nothing complicated about the program, said Miller. The colt came out of that Canadian race in fine shape. I went over to sea a few hours after he had won. I fed him a carrot nd, as usual, he was very appreciative.

title: Chase Bank Cites Own Loan Woes
description: A dramatic improvement in the profitability of the Chase Manhattan Bank is unlikely in the near term because of continuing problems with domestic loans, the bank's top management indicated yesterday.

title: Quinlan Trial Ends, And a Ruling Is Due In Next 1014 Days
description: MORRISTOWN, Oct. 27Superior Court Judge Robert Muir Jr. said today that he would decide in 10 to 14 days whether to allow Karen Anne QuinIan's father to withdraw a mechanical respirator so that she may die with peace and dignity. The respirator has been sustaining the breathing of the 21yearold woman, who has been in coma for six months.

title: Vote in U.N. Unit Asks Black Rule in Rhodesia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 27  A General Assembly committee today condemned the racist minority resolution calling on Britain to assist the black liberation movement in securing its aim of majority rule.

Dave Anderson
description: To be a winner the Jets need to keep losing. Phil Iselin then presumably would be forced to discharge Chancy Winner as coach.

title: 3 Guards Held as Hostages In Oklahoma Prison Dispute
description: GRANITE, Okla., Oct. 27 (AP) Nine Granite Reformatory inmates took three guards hostage today and demanded a?? turn of their Christmas package privilegas.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a typographical error, it was reported erroneously in some editions of The New York Times yesterday that Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. of West Virginia had pleaded guilty to Federal fraud and securities charges. No such charges have been made againiit the Governor. The reference was to Theodore Price, former head of the bankrupt Diversified Mountaineer Corporation of West Virginia.

title: Rangers Seek to Untrack
description: A sentence in the New York Rangers yearbook states: The Rangers 50th season will probably become one of the most memorable in the club's history. After giving up 23 goals and scoring only four in their last Three games, the National Hockey League club seems on its way to fulfilling that promise.

title: BRITAIN CITES RISE IN TRADE DEFICIT
description: LONDON, Oct. 27 (Reuters) Britain's visible trade deficit in the first nine months of this year was $565million higher than first reported, the Department of Trade said today.

title: U.N. DIPLOMAT SAYS DOG IS IMMUNE, TOO
description: The Ambassador from Barbados to the United Nations has written the Mayor of Pelham, N.Y., to warn of possible international consequences if his dog is shot for biting Pelham residents.

title: Crucial Default Date Appears Closer
description: The prospect that a New York City default may come several weeks earlier than is now assumed was raised yesterday when top state fiscal advisers said they had not yet found a source for the $150million the state must channel to the city to meet the city's November obligations.

title: Four Luxury Towers To House the Poor Opening in Harlem
description: A federally subsidized housing project for the poor is scheduled to open in East Harlem in about two months with luxury features never before included in lowincome housing in the. United States. Depending on the point of view, the project is regarded as a monument to government compassion or an epitaph on bureaucratic folly.

title: F.D.I.C. TAKES OVER VIRGIN ISLANDS BANK
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, announced yesterday in Washington that it had assumed control of the insolvent Peoples Bank of the Virgin Islands after being appointed receiver by Chief Judge Almerio Christian of the Virgin Islands District Court.

title: TV: Life,
description: One of NBC's more ambitious Bicentennial projects is a threepart series exploring the inalienable rights in the Declaration of Independence'Life. Liberty and the Pursuit of Happiness. Life, the first 90minute installment, will be televised tonight at 8, a special halfhour children's version of the program will be presented Saturday at 12:30 P.M. Liberty and The Pursuit of Happiness are scheduled for broadcast next year.

description: SMITHTOWN, L. I., Oct. 27The body of a 19yearold wornan who the Suffolk County Medical Examiner said had! been brutally beaten and strangled was found near a discotheque here today.

description: Prices on the American Stock lExchange closed mixed yesterday as volume declined slightly. In the overthecounter market, prices dropped as volume fell sharply.

description: A leftist underground group that is demanding independence for Puerto Rico took responsibility yesterday for nine almost sumultaneous earlymorning bomb explosions at government buildings, corporate offices and banks in New York, Chicago and Washington.

title: Bill From Hartford For Ford's Guard Again Goes Begging
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 27  This city has twice tried to bill Republican State Committee for S9,093.98 for overtime work by policemen and firemen on the evening the President was here two weeks ago. Once, the bill was bounced back to the city. Now the Republicans seem resolved to sit on it forever, if need be.

title: Concert
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center puts on excellent concerts with such monotonous regularity that Writing reviews of them is like reviewing an endless succession of gorgeous sunsets: You run out of adjectives. The concert late Sunday afternoon  to be repeated tonight at 7:30 in Alice Tully Hall  hardly broke the pattern; this was music and musicmaking of a high order Indeed.

title: LISBON'S TROUBLES HIT SCHOOLS HARD
description: LIBSON, Oct. 28 (AP)The want ad in the newspaper was seeking an electrical engineer. Recent graduates, it said need not apply. It ruined Carlos Ribeiro's morning.

title: French Nuclear Spread
description: By deciding to sell South Korea equipment and technology to produce weaponsgrade plutonium, the explosive material for atomic bombs, France has taken mankind a long step toward worldwide spread of nuclear weaponsand ultimate disaster.

title: Time Inc. Books Dismisses 24 From Domestic Editorial Staff
description: Time Inc.'s books division dismissed onetenth of its domestic editorial staff yesterday, saying that the 14yearold TimeLife Books department was overstaffed.

title: Airline Competition
description: The domestic airline industry has been in a holding pattern ever since Congress passed the basic aviation law in 1938. The Civil Aeronautics Board has never allowed a new trunk carrier to enter the business. The law enjoined the C.A.B. to promote what was then an infant industry and to permit competition only to the extent necessary.
