title: MIDTOWN MURAL: A new mural on the sides of buildings behind a parking lot on the corner of Eighth Avenue and 42d Street that was occupied by the recentlyrazed Franklin Savings Bank. The work was the combined
description: The New York Times/Edward Harmer effort of eight artists from the City Arts Workshop. The mural, paid for by grants totaling $15,000 from the State Council of the Arts, Bankers Trust Company and the Chase Manhattan Bank, depicts man's search for himself.

title: TV: Van Dyke Slips Into Stage Style
description: A confession: Going back at least as far as the 1960 stage production of Bye Bye Birdie, I have never been able to work up much enthusiasm for the comedy of Dick Van Dyke. It has been largely a matter not of active dislike but of puzzlement.

title: France Told to End Tax on Italian Wine
description: LUXEMBOURG. Oct. 29 (Reuters)The Common Market Commission ordered France today to end her import tax on Italian wine within seven days or face proceedings at the Market's Court of Justice here.

title: REUBEN H. FLEET, AIR PIONEER, DIES
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 29 (AP)Reuben H. Fleet, an aircraft pioneer, early airmailservice pilot and later an aircraft manufacturer, died today in a hospital here from injuries he sufiered in a fall. He was 88 years old.

title: Bergen Senators to Block Selection of Carey Friend
description: TRENTON, Oct. 29A bipartisan coalition of State Senators from Bergen County said today they had agreed to block Governor Byme's prospective nomination of a New Jersey friend of Governor Carey of New York to the Palisades Interstate Park Commission.

title: GRAIN PRICES RISE ON SALE TO SOVIET
description: A rumorand then the confirmationof a corn sale to the Soviet Union. helped lift grain prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Knicks' LineUp
Day of Reckoning
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The essence of President Ford's speech on the bankruptcy of New York City was in this line: New York City's officials have proved in the past that they will not face up to the city's massive network of pressure groups as long as any alternative is available.

title: New York's Fiscal Crisis Is a Political Issue in Texas
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 29With great delight, Texans have made New York City their mafor political issue this fall. Politicians here have found that the easiest way to get a standing ovation is to shake their fingers at New Yorks naughty spending habits.

title: GOV. MOORE REJECTS BID IN WEST VIRGINIA
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 29Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. declined to appear today before a Kanawha County grand jury that has been investigating allegations that he and other West Virginia officials received illegal, unreported campaign contributions in 1972.

title: Midtown Architecture Institute Flowering as a Student Mecca
description: In one room, a group of highschool students was discussing how symbols of home, like chairs and books, relate to the making of architecture. In another room, college students were grappling with the problem of evolving a house design from three abstract planes. And down the hall, page proofs were being read for a new issue of a scholarly journal on architecture.

title: N.S.A. CHIEF TELLS OF BROAD SCOPE OF SURVEILLANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The National Security Agency secretly scanned international telephone and cable traffic to intercept the messages of 1,680 American citizens and groups and of 5,925 foreign nationals or organizations, its director testified today.

title: Opera: A Staging for 1739 Dardanus
description: Can the operas of Rameau, with their highly rhetorical style of singing and corseted theatrical manner, ever be brought back into general circulation? Certainly not as long as the public to which works of the French baroque master might appeal has no chance to become acquainted with them in productions that do justice to their peculiar blend of spectacle, song and dance.

title: Leafs End Streak Of Sabres by 32
description: TORONTO, Oct. 29 (UPI)The Toronto Maple Leafs sent the Buffalo Sabres to their first loss of the National Hockey League season tonight, 32. The Sabres had won eight straight, equaling the fastest start in league history set by the 1934 Leafs.

title: Movies and Jackie De Shannon Head the Bill at Reno Sweeney
description: Reno Sweeney, at 126 West 13th Street, has a particularly strong club bill running through Sunday. Jackie De Shannon is the headliner, and she deserves to be. But The Movies, which opens the show, are pretty engaging, too.

title: Suez Canal, After 8Year Close, Is Finding Activity Has Ebbed
description: LONDON, Oct. 29 The Suez Canal, a cornerstone of the Egyptian economy and a vital EastWest thoroughfare for more than a century, is doing substantially less business than it did before the ArabIsraeli War in 1967.

title: U.S. Pianist 5th in Chopin
description: WARSAW, Oct. 29 (AP)Dean Kramer of Cherry Hill, N. J., won fifth place today in the Chopin Festival cnmpetition for young pianists. The contest was won by Krystian Zimerman of Poland. Three Soviet contestantsDiana Joffleon, Tatiarta Fiedkina and Pavel Gililovwon the second to fourth places.

title: City Jobs Hit Low Mark, Dimming Recovery Hopes
description: The number of jobs in New York City fell last month to the lowest level since employment recordkeeping began in 1950, the State Labor Department reported yesterday, with the job count down by 78,900 since August and by 136,000 since the previous September to a record low of 3,290,300.

title: Lutz Overcomes Solomon, 61, 60
description: MANILA, Oct. 29 (AP) Manuel Orantes of Spain advanced to the quarterfinals of the $75,000 Philippine International tennis tournament today by beatin' Australia's Kim Warwick, 62, 46, 64.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY RAISES TAX RATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) About 18 million workers will each pay up to $70.20 more in Social Security taxes next year to help finance higher benefits for retired persons, the Federal Government announced today.

title: ExDetective Indicted as Plotter To Balk Inquiry in Drug Theft
description: Frank E. King, a retired narcotics detective who is considered the prime suspect in the socalled French Connection theft of $70million worth of narcotics from police custody, was indicted yesterday on a charge of conspiracy with a group of narcotics dealers to thwart a special grand jury's investigation of the case.

title: Speech on Federal Aid to City Brings Sharp Decline
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday as President Ford declared that he was prepared to veto ary bill to provide Federal financial aid for New York City. The market erased its Tuesday advance.

title: RISE IN OIL PRICE WORKING OUT TO 9%
description: The 10 per cent crude oil price increase voted by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in September has turned out to be an advance of about 9 per cent, based on the actual price changes announced by the individual members of the oil producers cartel.

title: Ford Says Lockheed Bill May Have Been Error
description: President Ford drew a distinction at his news conference yesterday between the Federal Government's rescue of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and its position on rescuing New York City, but acknowledged that the Lockheed action might have been an error.

title: Burt Manning Named To New York Office
description: Burt Manning, a copywriter out of Chicago, has made it big on the fastest advertising track of allMadison Avenue in the Big Apple, the advertising capitol of the world.

title: Contract Award
description: The El Paso Company signed yesterday a 20year contract with the Algerian state oil and gas concern, Sonatrach, for the supply of 270 billion cubic feet of liquefied natural gas yearly, beginning in 1981. The value of the contract was not disclosed but the value of one it replaces was estimated to be worth $1.7billion.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: Orlando, Fla.Gene Wells, 156 3/4 pounds, Orlando, outpointed Mike Baker. 158, Spartanburg, S.C., 10 rounds.

title: Free Buses Aim at Reduction Of Congestion in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 29Westchester County announced today that it would begin free daytime bus travel Saturday within the downtown shopping areas of its six cities.

title: OLD RIFFS DOMINATEI CONCERT BY GARCIAI
description: Jerry Garcia arrived at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Street, on Tuesday to face the customary massive adulation from his fansadulation that seemed somewhat out of key for what he was actually doing. It is normal for the rock world to deride middleofthe1 road entertainers who trundle out their old hits time after time, and this seemed to be what Mr. Garcia was doing.

title: PACT ON RESCUES REACHED IN BERLIN
description: WEST BERLIN, Oct. 29After two and one half years of negotiations, East and West Berlin reached an agreement today on a seemingly simple humanitarian issue, that of allowing West Berliners to rescue people from drowning in the city's border canals and rivers.

title: Charter Reform: III
description: When the State Charter Revision Commission was established by the Legislature three years ago, its primary mandate was to encourage genuine citizen participation in local city government; but the intrusion of the budget crisis prompted a shift in emphasis. Thus Questions One, Two, Three and Four on next week's ballot encompass the commission's recommendations for reform in the problem areas of fiscal affairs, city management, governmental structure and planningrecommendations which we have already strongly endorsed.

title: G.O.P. TO SEEK FUNDS TO AVERT SHUTDOWN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) The Republican National Committee is putting the finishing touches on a fundraising drive to keep from having to shut its doors and stop paying its staff for two weeks in December.

title: 2 Jersey Women Died of Strangling
description: POMONA, N.Y., Oct. 29Two bodies found seven miles apart in wooded areas of Rockland County this week have been identified as those of two young women who disappeared earlier this month from an affluent area of northeastern Bergen County, N.J.

title: BAILOUT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29President Ford said today that he was prepared to veto any bill that would rescue New York City by having the Federal Government guarantee the availability of funds to prevent a default.

title: FEW COUNCILMEN DISCUSS CHARTER
description: A workshop on Charter revision for members of the City Council drew only 13 of the 43 members yesterdaya fact that Councilman Edward L. Sadowslcy said was a reflection of the low level of voter interest in the proposed changes.

title: Presidential Default ...
description: Like a bemused stranger from another place and time, President Ford yesterday addressed the contemporary crisis in urban America's largest city in terms of the political and economic dogmas of an 18thcentury rural confederacy.

title: Constitutional Questions And Guarantees at Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The municipal bankruptcy bill that President Ford proposed yester day for New York City is nearly identical to the one put together by the House Judiciary Committee, which has been working quietly on such a measure with lawyers sent there by Mayor Beame.

title: A Union Proposes CostTrimming Plan For Hospitals Unit
description: A municipal employes union has submitted a series of moneysaving proposals to the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation for consideration today in achieving cuts asked by Mayor Beame, a union official said last night,

title: Inflation and Inequality
description: Inflation is always accompanied by a redistribution of income and wealth; who gets what is a reflection of the balance of political power in society.

title: Today's Entries at Belmont
Sports News Briefs
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 29 (UPI) Bowie Kuhrr, the baseball commissioner, said today at a news conference that he had talked with several prospective owners or persons representing groups that could operate a major league team in Seattle. He declined comment on impending litigation brought by Seattle and the state against the American League in connection with the transfer of the former Seattle Pilots to Milwaukee. But Slade Gorton, state Attorney General, said, The trial is still on but we are optimistic the suit will be dismissed if Seattle is promised major league club in 1976. Kuhn said those to whom had spoken were more interested in obtaining an existing club than an expansion franchise.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Status Quo Urged On Blackouts Law
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI)Pro basketball and hockey representatives opposed a permanent ban on local television blackouts of soldout sports events today and, instead, suggested Congress extend the present 3yearold law for another trial period.

title: SovietItalian Industry Pact
description: ROME, Oct. 29 (Reuters) Italy and the Soviet Union today signed a 10year agreement on industrial cooperation, covering raw materials energy and technology. Two days ago, Italy agreed to lend the Soviet Union $900million to be used to buy Italian industrial equipment.

title: Yonkers Raceway Results
Chrysler Steps Set
description: John Riccardo, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said that the company was prepared to take ultimate steps to eliminate operations that continue to lose money. Page 63.

title: Western Electric's Telephone Installers on Strike
description: Union telephone installers went on strike here yesterday, virtually halting new installations and severely curtailing repairs on old ones in the city and suburbia.

title: 23 MILLION IN U.S. FOUND ILLITERATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) The United States Office of Education today released results of a fouryear study that indicates that more than 231 million adults throughout thel nation are functionally illiterate, meaning they are unable to do such things as read helpwanted ads or make the most economical purchases.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
Advertising
description: Esquire magazine, which cut its circulation guarantee by 100,000 in October, will cut it by 150,000 in March to a nice round 1 millionits natural circulation.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SHORT AND STERLING Animated films, a cinema species rarely exhibited any more in commercial theaters, are the order of the afternoon at 5:30 o'clock at a free runoff at the New School of the winners in the International Tournee of Animation, an animation showcase held every spring at Annecy, France. The 90minute program includes 17 works on a variety of subjects from the United States, Italy, Yugoslavia, Belgium, Canada and Poland. They were cited from more than 300 festival entries.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL HAS PROFIT DROP
description: ThirdQuarter Net Off 66% $74Million Tax Credit Prevented a Deficit

title: Energy Conservation Is Becoming a Habit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29Despite their reputation for profligacy, most Americans seem to be trying to save energy. At least, they say they are.

title: The District Attorneys
description: Elections for District Attorney will be held in only two counties in New York City next Tuesday. The Times' recommendations follow:

title: COMPANY REPORTS
Age May Be Slowing Down O. J., but the Jets Aren't
description: The disclosure should make the harried Jets defense snicker. 0. J. Simpson said yesterday that he was slowing up.

title: Two Developers Acquire Dodge Mansion
description: The Dodge property at Fifth Avenue and 61st Street, one of the most coveted realestate parcels in the city, has been sold to two developers who plan to demolish the sixstory mansion on the site and erect a high  rise luxury apartment building.

title: Books of The Times
description: William Gaddis does drunks. Longwinded, funny, imaginative drunks. For pages and pages he does drunks. He also does publicrelations men, who speak compulsively of utilizing technological hardware to maximize ongoing benefits publicitywise. For pages and pages, sometimes overdone wisevrise. And he does business JR. By William Gaddis. 725 pages. Knopf. Clothbound, $15; paperback $5.95.

title: N.S.A. CHIEF TELLS OF BROAD SCOPE OF SURVEILLANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The National Security Agency secretly scanned international telephone and cable traffic to intercept the messages of 1,680 American citizens and grouos and of 5,925 foreign nationals or organizations, its director testified today.

title: Key Games Coming Up in P.S.A.L.
description: Competition in Public Schools Athletic League football has not suffered despite budget cuts, a strike and rainy Saturdays. This week there are several big games High School Sports that will help decide sectional titles, weather permitting. In the A division, Brooklyn section, Canarsie will play Brooklyn Tech, which has won four of five games, with four shutouts. Canarsie, the league's leading offensive team, has four victories and a tie. Tech's only loss was to Jefferson, which leads the section with a 40 record.

title: ANTIPOLLUTION PLAN IS VOIDED BY COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) A Federal antipollution plan that would have forced motorists to have emission control devices installed on cars driven in Washington has been struck down by the United States Court of Appeals.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Jury Told to Acquit Judge on 3 Counts In Trial for Bribery
description: DETROIT, Oct. 29 (UPI)Judge Carl B. Rubin of Federal District Court ordered a jury today to acquit Justice John B. Swainson of the Michigan Supreme Court on three charges, but rejected a defense motion to dismiss bribery and perjury charges.

title: Price Council Backs Increase for Flour
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) The Council on Wage and Price Stability absolved today three flour manufacturers of any wrongdoing in the recent raising of their wholesale prices for family flour.

title: BEAME AND CAREY DECRY FORD PLAN
description: Mayor Beame denounced President Ford's proposal for the city fiscal crisis yesterday as a default of Presidential leadership that could revive the national divisions of the Civil War era and prove costly far beyond the city's boundaries.

title: SIR ALFRED OWEN,67, INDUSTRIALIST, DEAD
description: SUTTON COLDFIELD. England, Oct. 29 (AP)Sir Alfred Owen, who ran Britain's largest family business and invested millions of dollars in racing and speedrecord automobiles, died in a hospital today. He was 67 years old.

title: Drafting of Pistol Control Bill Is Delayed by Dispute in Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29A House Judiciary subcommittee met today to begin drafting a pistol control bill, but it was sidetracked into a partisan, parliamentary dispute among its members.

title: SOCAL POSTS DROP OF 32.7% IN PROFIT
description: Net income of the Standard Oil Company of California fell 32.7 per cent in the third quarter to $191mililon, equal to $1.13 a share from $284million, or $1.68 a share, in the period a year ago.

title: SADATCAREY TALK IS THWARTED HERE
description: Governor Says the Meeting Turned into Some Sort of a Photography Session

title: Radio
Kidnappers Fail to Free A Woman, Despite Ransom
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Oct. 29 (AP)The kidnapers of a 51yearold Pensacola real estate saleswoman abduaed Friday did not release her today as the Federal Bureau of Investigation had expected, agents said.

title: Reconsiderations on the Art of Detente
description: Future historians of the American art museum, when it comes time to chronicle the peculiar features of the nineteenseventies, will be obliged to deal with a startling new phenomenon: the foreignAn policy exhibition, Appraisal otherwise known as the dtente show. The latest of these politically determined exhibitionsa show of 53 rarities of Egyptian art from the tomb of Tutankhamen, including 19 works never before allowed to leave Egypt was announced in Washington on Tuesday, when a formal agreement was signed between Secretary of State Kissinger and the Egyptian Foreign Minister, Ismail Fahmy, on the occasion of President Anwar elSadat's visit.

title: NEW AMERICAN TRIO IN CARNEGIE RECITAL
description: The New American Trio, a clarinet (Esther Lamneck), bassoon (Michael McCraw and piano (Thomas Hrynkiv) ensemble that played here in 1974, returned to Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night for another appearance.

title: Personal Finance: Keeping Tax Down
description: Judge Learned Hand, the distinguished American jurist, once expressed his views about taxsaving techniques.

title: . . . Presidential Piety
description: Although it was not clear that President Ford had a firm grip on just how his plan to sweep up after a default would actually work, he displayed a firm grasp of his own particular vision of sin and sinners. The President's rigid and punitive moralism pierced several secondary targetscities generally, profligate urban officials, doomsayers and welfare cheats among thembefore hitting the principal source of his dismay, which is adequate funding for public programs designed to improve American society by meeting urgent human needs.

title: Bridge
description: The International Team Playoff matches of the American Contract Bridge League began in Palo Alto, Calif., last night, with four teams fighting for the right to represent America in the 1976 world team championships in Monte Carlo. For the first time, two such contests will be played consecutively, one a zonal contest for the Bermuda Bowl, with North America competing in a field of six teams, the other a Team Olympiad, with the United States battling 40 countries.

title: BEAME AND CAREY DECRY FORD PLAN
description: Mayor Beame denounced President Ford's proposal for the city fiscal crisis yesterday as a default of Presidential leadership that could revive the national divisions of the Civil War lera and prove costly far beyondl the city's boundaries.

title: One killed, 13 Hurt in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 29 (Reuters) Guerrilla gunmen shot and killed one man and injured 13 persons tonight in a series of raids that seemed part of a new feud between rival wings of the Irish Republican Army.

title: P .B. A. Calls on Byrne to Deny Clemency in the Carter Case
description: The New Jersey policemen's Benevolent Association yesterday urged Governor Byrne to deny executive clemency to Rubin (Hurricane) Carter.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Rental Agent Sued as Discriminatory

title: Tap on Marina Oswald's Room Reported by ExF.B.I. Official
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The Federal Bureau of Investigation tapped the telephones and bugged the living quarters used by Marina Oswald after the assassination of President Kennedy, but it failed to report either the fact of the surveillance or its product to investigators for the Warren Commission, according to a former F.B.I. official.

title: 11 States Sue to Block FirstClass Mail Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP)Eleven states seeking to block a planned rise in firstclass mail rates sued the United States Postal Service in Federal court today.

title: ThaiLaotian Friendship Unravels on the Mekong
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 29 The historic friendship between the peoples of Laos and Tha:land, united by ancient bonds of blood, language and culture, is crumbling along the Mekong River that separates the two nations.

title: Friend Who Got a School Post Gave Monserrat $3,000 Loan
description: Joseph Monserrat, the suspended member of the Board of Education, took a personal loan of about $3,000 in 1969 from a friend who latcr became the board's $40,000ayear director of community school affairs, officials disclosed yesterday.

title: DECISION BY FORD FOLLOWS PATTERN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Over the last two weeks, President Ford's advisers presented him with a series of options for dealing with New York City's plight, ranging from undertaking a complete financial rescue operation to doing nothing.

title: WALWORTH GOES TO ANACONDA CO.
description: The Anaconda Company has, acquired the business and opcrating assets of the Walworthl Company, Bala Cynwyd. Pa., for cash and notes totaling about $40million, John B. M. Place, president and chief executive officer of Anaconda, announced late yesterday. Walworth was acquired from IU International Corporation, a major diversified company with headquarters in Wilmington, Del. and will be operated as a wholly owned subsidiary of Anaconda. It will continue its business under its existing name, officers and employes as one of the largest industrial valve manufacturers in the United States. Anaconda is engaged in mining, processing and the manufacture of nonferrous metal products.

title: SCHLESINGER GETS ARMS FUND REBUFF
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The Senate Defense Appropriations subcommittee, in a serious setback for Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger, voted today to restore only $406million to a defense appropriations bill that was reduced $7.6billion by the House.

title: SOLIAH INDICTED IN BANK ROBBERY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29Steven Soliah, a former college athlete who became involved with the radical group that reportedly hid Patricia Hearst, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury in Sacramento for an armed robbery in which a death occurred.

title: Stocks Fall on Ford Veto Plan; Municipal Credit Also Affected
description: Prices weakened in the secondary municipal credit market yesterday after President Ford's speech on New York City's financial problems. but elsewhere in the money markets prices were stable or Credit slightly ahead on Markets the day.

title: Yonkers Seeking a Loan To Avoid Default Nov.14
description: YONKERS, Oct. 29The City Controller of Yonkers, Joseph Gulia, said today he was seekig a 'bridge loan from banks dealing with the city in an effort to avoid default next month.

description: C1975. be Triangle Publications, Inc. The Daily Racing Form)

title: AMEX PRICES DIP IN QUIET TRADING
description: Prices dropped in quiet but increased trading on the American Stock Exchange and in the OvertheCounter market as investors seemed discouraged by President Ford's pledge to veto any legislation that would rescue New York City from its fiscal morass.

title: Franco Rallies Again but Doctors Report Outlook Is Unchanged
description: MADRID, Thursday, Oct. 30 Generalissimo Francisco Franco was reported yesterday to have rallied again from a crisis that brought him closer to death Tuesday night than at any time since he fell ill 10 days ago.

title: Fun for Families: Together at the Y
description: With so many elements of contemporary life conspiring to keep parents and children apart, the people at the West Side Y.M.C.A. have been working to get the family together, almost by force.

title: W. Virginia Bonds Feel Ripple
description: CHARLESTON, W.V., Oct. 29 (AP)Bids received today on $50million in West Virginia road bonds caused Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. to say New York City's money problem is imposing penalties on other jurisdictions in the country that are sound fiscally.

description: Tour Match

title: Sadat Urges U.N. to Help In Resuming Geneva Talk
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said today that present circumstances provided a unique opportunity for peace in the Middle East, and formally requested the United Nations to help reconvene the Geneva conference.

title: Court Rules $71,000 in Lulus For 45 in Legislature Is Illegal
description: ALBANY, Oct. 29Justice Edward S. Conway of State Supreme Court today ruled as unconstitutional a law passed by the 1975 State Legislature and signed by Governor Carey that provided $71,000 in extra allowances for 45 legislators.

title: CHANGE IS BACKED ON CAPITAL GAINS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to lengthen the period of time over which individuals must own capital assets before selling them to be taxed on any profits at the favorable capital gains rate.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Soviet Aides Urge Farmers to Raise Grain Production
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 29 (Reuters) Soviet farmers facing what may be their worst harvest in nearly 10 years were told today that an increase in grain production remains the key aim in Soviet agriculture.

title: Dorothy Wayman, Author. A Boston Globe Writer, 82
description: Dorothy G. Wayman, author of more than a dozen books and a writer for The Boston Globe for 30 years before her retirement in 1955, died Monday at her home in Olean, N. Y. She was 82 years old.

title: Don Juan, in Switzerland, To Await Spanish Events
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Oct 29Don Juan, father of the designated successor to Generalissimo Francisco Franco, will remain in this city to await developments, an aide said today.

title: 52Player Limit Up For Vote
description: Major college football teams will be permitted to suit up as many players on the road as they do at home next season if a proposed compromise is passed by NaCollege Sports Notes tional Collegiate Athletic Association members in convention next January. This equalization proposal calls for 52 players for both, the visiting and home teams.

title: LEONARD R. HANOWER
description: Leonard R. Hanower, a Long Beach, L. I., city judge from 1934 to 1954, died ynterday at Long Beach Memorial Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Long Beach.

title: Joffrey Ballet Brings Reflections
description: Just when a newcomer to the City Center Joffrey Ballet might get the idea that Gerald Arpino's ballets are flashy, theatrical and swinging, the company revives his quiet neoclassical Reflections.

title: Fear and Anger Grip Demarest Residents
description: DEMAREST, Oct. 29The residents of this pastoral subu'rban town in the northeastern corner of New Jersey stood about today in shops and on the main street and spoke with fear and anger in their voices about the murder of 22yearold Susan Reeve, who disappeared two weeks ago near her home here.

title: EXECUTIVE CLEARED OF FRAUD CHARGES
description: OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 29 (AP) Federal fraud and conspiracy charges against Robert E. Lee, vice president of .American Beef Packers, were dismissed today in Federal court.

title: Fetus Murder Trial Begun
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (UPI)Melvin Morgan of Chicago went on trial yesterday on charges of murdering a fetus. Mr. Morgan, 21 years old is accused of killing the 8monthold fetus in January when he allegedly shot and wounded Bessie Conners, 24 years old.

title: Treasury Official Is Named As Deputy Counsel to Ford
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) The Under Secretary of the Treasury, Edward C. Schmults, was appointed by President Ford today as deputy counsel to the President.

title: $3Million Police Station Dedicated at 123d and 8th
description: They laid to rest a number of memories and spoke of new hopes yesterday at the Police Department's 28th Precinct Station on Eighth Avenue and 123d Street.

title: 11 States Baffled by Mutilation of Cattle
description: DENVER, Oct. 27Who has been killing cattle in Colorado and at least 10 other states the last few months?

title: Chrysler Seeking to End Its Losses on Operations
description: DETROIT, Oct. 29John Riccardo, chairman of the troubled Chrysler Corporation, said today at a news conference that the automobile company was prepared to take ultimate steps, whatever it takes to eliminate operations that continue to lose money.

title: President Is Commended And Assailed on Stand
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29President Ford's speech today announcing that he opposed any bill to bail out New York Cityand thus prevent a defaulttouched off a new round of debate in the Congress, where speeches about New York now outnumber those on energy legislation.

title: Stanley Steingut Under Inquiry for His Role in Son's Campaign
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office is looking into the role of Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut in alleged illegal job promises during the campaign of Mr. Steingut's son, City Councilman Robert Steingut, lawenforcement sources said yesterday.

title: Grant's Downfall: Suburban Blight and Competition
description: FREEPORT, L.I.Suburhan blight, like the physical and economic deterioration that hurt the urban shopping sections, contributed to the current problems of the W. T. Grant Company, in the view of customers and competitors of two Long Island stores on the chain's list for closing.

Film: 'Take a Hard Ride':Black Western Goes on in Fits and Starts
description: "Take a Hard Ride," which opened at three theaters on Tuesday, is a black Western that has something of the ingenuousness of a story being made up by a child as he tells it to his friends. It goes on and onit lurches, really  in little fits and starts of inspiration from dimly remembered earlier movies.It's about an honest cowboy (Jim Brown), a cheerfully dishonest gambler (Fred Williamson) and a mute Indian scout (Jim Kelly) and their efforts to transport $86,000 across hundreds of miles of Western wilderness to the families to whom it belongs in Mexico. The trail is fraught with dangers, and busier than Eighth Avenue on a Saturday night. There's a gun waiting behind every bush and lots of incredibly good marksmanship by the stars, and incredibly bad marksmanship by the villains, which is the only way a movie like this keeps going.The villains include Lee Van Cleef and Barry Sullivan and are mostly white. The film was shot in the Canary Islands by an Italian director who calls himself Anthony M. Dawson, though his name is actually Antonio Margheriti.Mr. Williamson works hard to achieve a light touch but all his efforts are immediately absorbed by Mr. Brown, whose impassive performance acts as a kind of blotter. The two have a long way to go before they give Paul Newman and Robert Redford any competition.

title: Health Corporation Votes To Shut Fordham Hospital
description: The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation voted yesterday to close another municipal hospitalFordham in the East Bronxand cut $18.25million more from its budget to meet the demands of the fiscal crisis.

description: Buffalo, Oct. 30Although their trains may run behind schedule, commuters can start setting their watches by the stickups at the Penn Central's Credit Union here.

title: Going Out Guide
description: COME ON ALONG Those festive, late afternoon, sounds emanating from downtown should be the preparations for the second annual Greenwich Village Halloween Parade. Starting at 5:30 P.M., the 75 actors, dancers and poets of the Theater for the New City will lead a masked and costumed procession across the Village area, moving from Jane Street at the West Side Highway to Washington Square, where the troupe will perform a Fire and Brimstone Finale around 7 P.M.

title: Panel Kills PistolControl Plan, Dimming Hope for Bill in 1975
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) A House subcommittee rejected today a bill to prohibit the private ownership of pistols, and all but killed any chance for the House to pass handgun legislation this year.

title: In Ohio, a New Look at Art of Louis XV Era
description: TOLEDO, OhioThe painting of 18thcentury France has long been recognized as one of the incomparable delights of Western art. For sheer charm, for frothy grandeur and beguiling flights of fancy, there is nothing to equal it. What the Goncourt brothers said of Watteau, in their classic study French 18thCentury Painters'that his painting contained a thousand enchantments . . . magical visions, an ideal world'applies generally our conventional image of French painting in this era preceding the deluge of revolution.

title: Man Traced 3.75 Million Years By Fossils Found in Tanzania
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30Fossil evidence that true man had evolved and lived in East Africa by almost 3.75 million years ago, nearly a million years earlier than had been previously established, has been found in Tanzania by Dr. Mary Leakey.

title: Music
description: Musica Aeterna, an extraordinary organization that year after year presents costly concerts in small halls at low ticket prices and seems never to have any money problems, opened its Tully Hall series Wednesday night with another expensive event.

title: LUKE B. LOCKWOOD, LAWYER, 74, DIES

title: College Aide Pleads Guilty
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Oct. 30 (AP)M. Norvell Young. the 59yearold chancellor of Pepperdine University, pleaded guilty today to a misdemeanor manslaughter charge arising from the death of two women in a traffic accident. Mr. Young had been charged with two counts of felony manslaughter and one count of drunken driving in the Sept. 18 accident. The other charges were dropped.

title: Ford Holds Rockefeller Blameless for Troubles
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30President Ford, making New York City's fiscal crisis the focus of his political rhetoric. derided New York officials here today for seeking Federal aid to prevent a default.

title: Agnew Denies His Guilt; Cites Pressure to Quit
description: CROFTON, Md., Oct. 30 (AP) Saying that some day the whole story can be told. former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew denied again today that he was guilty of anything except a single count of incometax evasion, to which he had pleaded no contest.

title: Hockey, Basketball Standings
description: Nat'l Hockey League

title: 12 Guerrillas Here To Attend Session In U.N. on Palestine
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30Twelve members of the Palestine Liberation Organization arrived here today to take part in a General Assembly debate on Palestine, beginning Monday.

title: CLAIR JOHN KILLORAN
description: Clair John Killoran, Attorney General of Delaware from 1943 to 1947 and Republican state chairman of Delaware fromd 1950 to 1956, died Wednesday in Wilmington, Del., where he lived. He was 70 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: While The ealms of Gold is drenched with intelligence, that is not enough to make it work. Margaret Drabble seems to know a bit about everything, except, perhaps, the evolution of the novel form. For example, she tells me much more than I want to know about Frances Wingate, her heroine. There is a limit to what one cares to hear,'even about an attractive, vital and accomplished woman. If Frances Wingate were a close friend of mine, I would still feel impatient with Miss Drabble's endless cataloguing of Frances's thoughts and feelings. And she is not a close friend, only a character in a novel.

title: Mt. Vernon Nurse Raped and Beaten; Suspect, 22, Seized
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Oct 30A 22yearold unemployed laborer who entered Mount Vernon Hospital late last night unnoticed by security guards raped one nurse and attacked two others in an empty Xray waiting room, according to the police.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Charter revision Question No. 9 is designed to go a long way in politically decentralizing service delivery in city government by initially handing over control of a limited number of services to elected community boards and providing the mechanism for expanding their sphere of controL

title: Corporate Profits In a Mixed Trend
description: Profits of United States corporations in the three months ended Sept. 30 were sharply higher than in the second and first quarters this year, but still lagged behind the third quarter of 1974 by n per cent, according to a preliminary survey of the results of 1,163 concerns compiled by the First National City Bank.

title: ARNOLD HERZFELD
description: Arnold Herzfeld, an international insurance broker and former director and chairman here of Bleichroeder, Bing & Co., died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 35 East 84th Street.

title: Old Order of Privilege in Lebanon Crumbling in Street Warfare
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 30Lebanon has always prided herself on being a crossroads of civilizationsa haven over the centuries for persecuted religious minorities that found refuge amid magnificent mountain News ranges, a meeting Analysis place of Christianity and Islam and a gateway between the Arab East and the industrial West.

title: Public's Confidence in U. S. Polled at an AllTime Low
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30Leading experts on public opinion told a Congressional committee today that public confidence in the Government and in the country's economic future is probably lower than it ever has been since they began to measure such things scientifically.

title: 25 Years of Cardin: Couture to Wine
description: In the beginning, he designed as everybody else did. There were the tight waists and rustling skirts of Christian Dior, the slight flamboyance of Jacques Fath, the barrel shapes of Balenciaga. The year was 1950, and Pierre Cardin had just opened his couture house.

title: SADAT ENDS VISIT TO THE CITY AREA
description: President Anwar elSadat of Egypt ended his 28hour visit to the New York area yesterday with Vice President Rockefeller toasting him for courage, vision, faith and determination in working for peace and greater opportunity for people.

title: Wielder of a Toy Gun Seized Near Ford Talk
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 (AP)A man carrying a toy gun who said he was trying to protect President Ford was taken into custody today at a parking garage about a block from the downtown hotel where Mr. Ford spoke to a political luncheon.

title: 3 Unions Joinin Suit to Halt Television Family Hour
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 Three entertainment industry trade unions filed suit today in Federal District Court to force the Federal Communications Commission and the three major television networks to end the controversial family viewing hour, which bars violence and adult themes from early evening proeraming.

title: Price Rise in U.S. For 76 Announced By MercedesBenz
description: Mercede5Benz of North America announced yesterday that it is increasing prices on its 1976 care, in this country an average of $883, or 6.4 per cent .

description: As long as any officer could remember, New York's Police Department had one unbreakable tradition: A policeman never testified against a fellow officer.

title: NEW RULES PROPOSED FOR DATA AT S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) The Securities and Exchange commission proposed today a set of regulations that would oroaden the power of the public to obtain corporate information filed with the commission and would give Congress and other government agencies access even to information declared confidential.

title: Rep. Albert's Secretary Is Guilty of Extortion
description: DALLAS, Oct. 30. (AP)Pauline Girven, secretary to House Speaker Carl Albert, pleaded guilty today to a misdemeanor extortion charge.

title: United Technologies
description: A ruling in Federal Court here has temporarily halted an effort by the United Technologies Corporation to acquire control of the Otis Elevator Company for $189million.

title: Restaurant Reviews
description: Tito's, a small Greenwich Village restaurant with an uptown air about it, has been in operation for about six months now at 125 Seventh Avenue South, between West 10th Street and Sheridan Square. Uptown air? Well, something having to do with neatness and reserve in quarters of intimate scale, but ask me to name a comparable uptown example, and I'm lost. Let it go.

title: Shanker Doesn't Oppose Aid From Pension Funds
description: Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, who reluctantly and at the last minute consented to the release of teachers pension fund money that prevented the city's default two weeks ago, said yesterday that he was not opposed in principle to a plan that wouid use city pension funds to guarantee loans and prevent future default.

title: Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 30 Every afternoon, a school bus filled with prepubescent girls passes the Jets training camp along Hempstead Turnpike. There is always a shriek that goes, Oh, Joeeeey!

title: U.N.Envoy Called Home In Incident Over Dog
description: BRIDGETOWN: Barbados, Oct. 30 (AP)The Barbados representative at the United Nations was called home today after threatening possible international consequences if his dog was shot in New York.

title: HOME PANEL, VOTES HARRINGTONINQUERY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) The House Ethics Committee bucked the Democratic leader ship yesterday and voted to go ahead in its investigation of Representative Michael J. Harrington, Democrat of Massachusetts.

title: State E.R.A. Gains Support of Deans At 3 Law Schools
description: NEWARK, Oct, 30 (AP)The deans of New Jersey's three law schools threw their support today behind the state's proposed Equal Rights Amendment but warned that its adoption would constitute only an initial triumph in a continuing struggle.

title: Earnings Fall at Texaco and Sun Oil; Ford Shows a 3dQuarter Profit Rise
description: Texaco, Inc., and the Sun Oil Company announced yesterday sharply lower profits for the quarter and ninemonth periods ended Sept. 30, continuing an almost unbroken string of lower earnings reports by the major oil companies.

title: SEARCH WIDENED IN JERSEY DEATHS
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., Oct. 30A coordinated effort by New Jersey, New York and Federal law enforcement agencies to find the murderer of two New Jersey women was announced late today by the Rockland County District Attorney.

title: U. S. Interests and Priorities in Relations With the Soviet
description: The luminous courage of the Soviet historian and dissident Andrei Amalrik has earned our respect many times over. But his advice regarding our policies toward the Soviet Union requires thoughtful examination, particularly because it comes at a time when some fateful decisions are being made in Washington about our military policies and their effect upon the prospect for a treaty on the limitation of strategic arms.

title: Rozelle'sTV Plea Scores No Points
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI)  Commissioner Pete Rozelle testified today that pro football owners lost $9million in two years under the television antiblackout law but he failed to score any points with a Congressional subcommttee considering a bill to make the ban permanent.

title: Railroad Profits Lag
description: Thirdquarter earnings of two of the bigger Western railroads the Union Pacific and the Southern Pacificlagged behind the similar quarter of last year, but they reported yesterday that traffic in the last several weeks has improved considerably from the deeply depressed levels reached in the first half of the year.

title: Dunk Leads at 65 In Australian Open
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 30.Bill Dunk of Australia set a course record with a 65, seven under par, today and took a onestroke lead over Fred Clark of Buffalo and Eric Cooper of Australia in the first round of the Australian open golf tournament.

title: Chicago Cancels Sale Of Construction Bonds
description: CHICAGO. Oct. 30 (UPI)Chicago's Public Building Commission today canceled its proposed sale of $36million in bonds because of the chaotic conditions brought on in the municipal bond market by New York's financial crisis.

title: What Do We Stand For?
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The Economist of London is worried about the United States, which is fair enough, since we are worried about Britain and ourselves. But as it looks forward to America's Third Century, this most moderate and proAmerican magazine beyond our shores wonders in melancholy tones about a recessional for the second great empire.

title: In Moroccan March, Sand Stifles Fervor
description: TARFAYA, Morocco, Oct. 29South of Agadir, the joy goes out of the Moroccan march to annex Spanish Sahara, and the sandstorms take over.

title: BACKING ALLEGED FOR 40 SPY PLOTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30Some 40 clandestine operations between April, 1972, and December, 1974, were approved by the secret fourman 40 Committee, a former State Department official told the House Select Committee on Intelligence today.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: The Salesman.

title: Wood Has Lead in Dazzling Play at Barrymore
description: They are serving free champagne at the Ethel Barrymore Theater. Well, not quite free. You still have to pay for your ticket, but in return you get Tom Stoppard's new play, Travesties, and the Royal Shakespeare Company, here on a commando visit, led by John Wood. And if that is not champagne enough  you simply cannot have been listening to the razzlingdazzling effervescence of language that erupts and bubbles throughout the evening.

title: Swiss Will Accept American Selection Of Davis as Envoy
description: GENEVA, Oct. 30The Swiss Government, overriding trade union and leftist objections, said today that it had no ground to refuse to receive as United States Ambassador Nathaniel Davis, the former American envoy to Chile.

description: The New York Times Company told Wall Street security analysts yesterday that, if strikes continued through the rest of the year at two Canadian newsprint companies in which the company has major linterests, newsprint operations are expected to show a fourthquarter lossdown sharply from the 14centashare participation in company profits year earlier.

title: PRICES DECREASE ON AMEX AND OTC

description: EAST BRUNSWICK, Oct. 30 (UPI)The housing slump has drained $4.7billion out of New Jersey's economy in the last three years, the state's builders said today.

title: CHILE TO ABSTAIN IN ZIONIST

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30President Ford and his advisers have found what they consider a central and potentially highly productive theme for his 1976 campaign: New York

title: Inviting Default
description: In his pulpitpounding speech on the plight of New York, President Ford repeatedly insisted that the city still could save itself from default without Federal assistance. Thus he directly contradicted the reiterated assertions of Mayor Beame, Governor Carey and the city's assorted financial managers that only action in Washington could stave off default.

description: John Montefusco, who not only talked a good game of baseball but also played one this year with the San Francisco Giants, was named the National League's rookie of the year yesterday.

title: Nassau Legislature
description: The people of Nassau County, which has a population of nearly 1.5 million, have a clearcut choice on the ballot betweenliterallyboss rule and legislative rule. Every other chartered county in New York State has a representative oneman, onevote legislative body: Nassau, a tight little political island on Long Island, is run by a board of supervisors with weighted votes that debases the principle of majority rule.

title: Hudson Candidate Dies
description: HUDSON, N. Y., Oct. 30 (AP) Thomas I. Shriver, the Democratic nominee for mayor in this city's election next Tuesday, collapsed and died at a hospital here last night. He was 54 years old. Mr. Shriver was running against Paul Colwell, Republican.

title: Big Board Trading Mark
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported that trading volume reached the fourbillionshare mark early yesterday. The only two prior occasions when trading reached that level, the exchange said, were in 1972 and 1973 but both times it did not touch that mark until December.

description: After deliberating two hours, a State Supreme Court jury early yesterday evening convicted a 24yearold selfdescribed writer of slaying Carol Hoffmann in her Murray Hill apartment two years ago.

description: PARIS, Oct. 30 (AP) Topseeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, the leader in the Grand Prix standing was upset today by Ray Moore of South Africa, 46, 76, 63, in the second round of the French indoor tennis tournament.

title: At the Helm in Spain
description: MADRID, Oct. 30Prince Juan Carlos de Borbn, who assumed power temporarily in Spain today, comes to his task with a stronger sense of duty Man than enthusiasm. in the He is more at News ease at the helm of his racing yacht than at a Cabinet meeting and much more expert in sports than in politics.

description: Retail sales in October were up from last year's levels but drifted downtward in percentage gains compared with re1 cent months, according to reports of major chains issued, yesterday.

title: Great American, Real Estate Trust, Reports Big Loss
description: Great American Mortgage Investors, the nation's fifth largest real estate investment trust, reported yesterday $116.3million loss for the 1975 fiscal year ended July 31. This compares with a profit for the 1974 fiscal year of $1.7million, equal to 37 cents a share.

title: The Charter Proposals
description: Citing the fiscal crisis, critics of proposed Charter changes that will appear on next Tuesday's ballot have questioned whether New York City can afford at this time to tinker with its governmental machinery. It is more appropriate to ask whether New Yorkers can afford not to act now to reform a structure of government that has so conspicuously failed.

description: A 76yearold woman was found beaten and stabbed to death yesterday morning in one of the notorious singleroomoccupancy hotels on the Upper West Side on the day she was to have moved to another hotel.

title: Corn Crop Harvest Report
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) Harvesting on the record 1975 corn crop mane good progress in most major states last week and the quality of the crop is good to excellent in most areas, the Agriculture Department says. The department's weekly crop weather report, released yesterday, said about 68 per cent of the nation's corn had been harvested by the end of last week compared with only 49 per cent at the same time last year.

Malmgren, who was chief trade negotiator for the United States from 1972 to 1975.

title: MOSCOW AND HANOI SIGN AN AID ACCORD
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 30 (AP)Soviet and North Vietnamese leaders today signed declarations providing for Soviet aid to rebuild North Vietnam's economy.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: (Some of Major Corporationt Reporting Yesterday)

title: SUSPENDED TERMS FOR 2 IN LLOYDS CASE
description: LUGANO, Switzerland, Oct. 30 (Reuters)Two Swiss bankers were given suspended prison terms here today on charges stemming from unauthorized currency dealings that cost Lloyds Bank International $64million last year.

title: PRESIDENT ASKING $4.7BILLION IN AID, MOST FOR MIDEAST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 President Ford asked Congress today to approve foreign aid of nearly $5billion for the current fiscal year, an unusually large amount that includes $3.4billion for Israel and the Arab countries.

title: Retail Store Sales Up 14%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $1.14billion, up 5 per cent from the yearearlier $1.08billion, total retil store sales were about $11.78billion, up 14 per cent from last year's $10.36billion.

title: A FEW COMPANIES VOTED TAX BREAK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The House Ways and Means Committee, approaching the end of its work on legislation revising the tax laws, approved today a number of provisions for special tax relief for just one company or a small group of companies.

title: Economists Find Month of Confusion
description: Perhaps it is appropriate that economic policy in October was masked somewhat by confusion between illusion and reality1 after all, October is the month of hobgoblins.

title: Exact Effects of City Default Impossible to Predict
description: If no way can be found to avert it, what would be the impact of default upon the life of the city? Would there be any noticeable difference right away? How would it affect

title: 14 CAPTIVES FREED BY VIETNAM REDS
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 30 Nine Americans captured in South Vietnam in the spring arrived in Bangkok today, ending more than seven months in Communist detention camps. Two Canadians, two Filipinos and an Australian were also freed.

title: New Executive Roles
description: The American Electric Power Company, the nation's largest electricutility holding company, reported yesterday a 41.2 per cent increase in 1975 thirdquarter net income over the comparable period last year. It attributed most of the improved earnings to rate increases and sales of power to other utilities.

title: McDonnell Douglas Earnings Rise
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, whose earnings have been declining for the last six quarters, reported yesterday marked improvement in its results for the quarter ended Sept. 30.

title: Jets
description: Channel 4 has reembraced the Jets, who were rejected last Sunday, and it will televise their game at Shea Stadium against Buffalo this Sunday starting at 1 P.M.

title: Guild Sets Nov.11 As Date for Strike At Times or News
description: The New York Newspaper Guild announced last night that its members would strike either The New York Times or The Daily News on Nov. 11 if a satisfactory contract was not reached before then.

title: Drawing Up a Cartoonists
description: You might see him on a Tuesday or a Wednesday, wandering around midtown at noontime, groomed, usually wearing a tie, rather suburban, as if he secretly raised flowers and fed birds. Yet there is in his eyes a certain blank uneasiness, a hint of something seething inside all that punctilio. Perhaps he is Eliot Nailles in John Cheever's Bullet Park, full of erotic depths, origins, memories, dreams and seizures of melancholy and enthusiasm, even though he doesn't look like it. Perhaps he has just escaped from a Peter DeVries novel, and comeuppance stalks him like a Mafia torpedo.

title: Lockheed Backing Earns Income for U.S.
description: The 1971 loanguarantee to save Lockheed to which President Ford referred Wednesday in saying, I'm not sure we didn't make a mistake, is generally credited with saving the West Coast aerospace giant from bankruptcy.

title: Washington Post Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) Negotiators for The Washington Post and the striking pressmen held a twohour meeting today that a Federal mediator described as very constructive. The mediator, Kenneth E. Moffett, said the two sides would meet again tomorrow.

title: Music: Turn of Screw
description: The Turn of the Screw, one of Benjamin Britten's striking operatic conceptions, was revived by the New York City Opera on Wednesday night. It is good that the company keeps this unusual work alive (although other local groups have staged it), because the score is so superbly calculated. With an orchestra of only 13 instruments to support the singers onstage, the composer has retold the Henry James ghost story and its theme of innocence corrupted with an extraordinary economy of means and a maximum of atmosphere.

title: Sanderson Is Traded For Blues
description: Derek Sanderson, the brawling center who is one of the most flamboyant and controversial players in hockey, was traded yesterday by the New York Rangers to the St. Louis Blues.

title: Professional Football
Advertising
description: Playboy magazine has no intention of abandoning its sexual orientation but it is withdrawing from the explicitness race that has engaged its competitors.

title: Stocks Climb, Then Fall; Average Advances 0.79
description: In its secondday reaction to President Ford's statement that he would veto financial aid for New York City, the stock market yesterday made a small gain and then lost almost all of it.

title: Americans in London Blast
description: LONDON, Oct. 30 (UPI)The names were disclosed today of the four Americans among the injured in a bomb blast at an Italian restaurant in London's Mayfair district yesterday. Alan and Ruth Ward of Riverside. Calif., were among seven persons detained in a hospital overnight. A spokesman said both were being treated for head and neck injuries, but did not release details of their conclition. Two other Americans, Edwin Daly and his 10year old daughter, Ruth, were discharged from the hospital after being, treated for cuts from flying glass.

title: ADM. PREOBRAZHENSKY
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 30 (UPI)Rear Adm. Valery Preobrazhensky, deputy commander of the Soviet Union's Baltic Fleet, died Saturday, according to a provincial newspaper that reached here today. He was 50 years old.

title: Fraud Laid to Head of Nursing Home
description: New York and New Jersey officials took action yesterday, against nursing homes that allegedly collected overpayments from Medicaid funds for services not rendered, or for unjustified expenses.

title: Gelding, Belgian Up, Wins Jump
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 30 (UPI)Pomme D'Ati, a 9yearold Hanoverian gelding ridden by Eric Wauters of Belgium, won the $1,400 General Dwight D. Eisenhower InternationalOpen in the 17th annual Washington international horse show.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Court Halts Otis Bid
description: A ruling in Federal Court here has temporarily halted the $189 million acquisition of the Otis Elevator Company by the United Technologies Corporation. Page 49.

title: MISS HEARST TRIAL HINTED BY JUDGE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30It appeared today that Patricia Hearst would be held competent to stand trial on a bank robbery charge when she goes to court on Tuesday.

title: Beirut Shooting Abates After New Truce
description: LEBANON, Beirut, Friday, Oct. 31Fighting continued here yesterday despite a new ceasefire arranged by Premier Rashid Karami.

title: Death of Newsman Held by Army Stirs Brazilians
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil. Oct. 30 (AP)  The army's assertion that a newsman committed suicide while in Government custody for questionirig over the weekend has set off ripples of fear, doubt and anger among some journalists, students and other opponents of the Government.

title: SPAIN SAID TO ARREST LEADING SOCIALIST
description: MADRID, Oct. 30 (Reuters)Socialist sources here reported that Dr. Luis Yanez, a leading member of the illegal Spanish Socialist party, had been arrested today. They said that the police arrested Dr. Yanez, who is in charge of international relations for the party, as he left his office.

title: State Grand Jury Critical Of Municipal Investments
description: TRENTON, Oct. 30 (AP)The first presentment ever handed up by a state grand jury today declared that New Jersey municipalities were losing substantial amounts of money by failing to make good shortterm investments of surplus public funds.

title: City Businessmen Oppose Carey Plan to Raise Taxes
description: Governor Carey's proposals for higher corporation taxes and other state levies to ease New York City's financial plight drew a sharply negative reaction from a crosssection of the city's businessmen yesterday.

title: PORTUGUESE TROOPS OCCUPY AN ARSENAL
description: LISBON, Oct. 30 (Reuters)Rebellious Portuguese troops sealed off the main Lisbon arsenal today to protest demobilization plans.

title: Rumania to Portugal
description: Nicolae Ceausescu, President of Rumania, is the first Communist chief of state to visit Portugal. The unofficial explanation in Lisbon is that Mr. Ceausescu may be of help in solving Portugal's problems in Angola, where the two largest armed native groups fighting for postcolonial control of that country are supported by Moscow and Peking respectively. Presumably the Portuguese leaders hope that Mr. Ceausescu, who is on speaking terms with both Leonid Brezhnev and Mao Tsetung, can help apply pressure through those contacts for a truce in Angola that will allow the Portuguese to make a graceful exit.

title: STAN STUTZ, STAR FOR OLD KNICKS, 54
description: Stan Stutz, an outstanding basketball player on the original New York Knicks of the Basketball Association of America (now the National Basketball Association) and threetime allAmerica with the basketball team of Rhode Island State College, now the University of Rhode Island, died Tuesday of a heart attack at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at 10 Cherry Avenue in New Rochelle.

title: Playwright, Star Provide a Little Curtain Raiser
description: As a curtain raiser to Travesties, the play's author, Tom Stoppard, and its star, John Wood, met in an anteroom at the Ethel Barrymore Theater (where the play opened last night) and batted a dialogue back and forth. Alter egos, kindred spirits with tall spindly bodiesthey have known each other for years, ever since Mr. Wood acted in an early television play by Mr. Stoppard.

title: To Be Young and an Islander
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Oct. 30With the same quiet aplomb that has character ized his play on the ice and his ascent to the No. 3 spot on the National Hockey League's scoring chart, Bryan Trottier of the New York Islanders picked up the guitar and started singing:

title: Sephardic Song Gets New Staging By Feld Company
description: The Eliot Feld Ballet presented a fresh production of Mr. Felds Sephardic Song on Wednesday night at the Newman Theater.

title: Basketball League Set In CUNY
description: The formation of a new basketball league comprising the nine fouryear colleges in the City University of New York was announced yesterday at City Hall. The league plans to begin play in the 19761977 season.

title: F.T.C. PLANS CURBS ON SLEEPING AID ADS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission plans to issue regulations prohibiting false advertising for nonprescription sleeping aids instead of initiating suits against individual manufacturers, an official of the agency said today.

title: Gustav Hertz, Physicist, Nobel Winner, 88, Dead
description: BERLIN. Oct. 30 (APDr. Gustav Hertz, the nuclear physicist who won a Nobel Prize for physics in 1925 and worked for the Soviet Union after World War II, died today, the official East German press agency reported. He was 88 years old.

title: Spain to Evacuate All 5,000 Civilians From the Sahara
description: AIUN, Spanish Sahara, Oct. 30 (AP)The Spanish Government plans to evacuate the 5,000 Spanish civilians in the Sahara by Nov. 15.

title: 68 Killed in Crash Of Chartered Plane At Prague Airport
description: PRAGUE, Oct. 30 (UP1)A Yugoslav charter jetliner trying to find its way through dense fog to the Prague airport crashed on the outskirts of the city today, killing 68 persons returning from a vacation in Yugoslavia.

title: Giants
description: Most followers of the New York Giants are aware that the team has done well in the last six seasons only when Ron Johnson has functioned well. But the extent to which the record demonstrates this general observation is startling.

title: City a 76 Issue for Ford; Democrats Doubt Its Value
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30President Ford and his advisers have found what they consider a central and potentially highly productive theme for his 1976 campaign: New York City must pay for its sins, and the rest of the country must learn from New York's errors or be doomed to repeat them.

title: Backer of African Detente Quits Rhodesian Cabinet
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 30 (Reuters)An influential Rhodesian Cabinet minister quit tonight in the first sign of open conflict in the Government over dealings with the country's black majority.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates for Thursday.

title: Bridge:
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 30  The chance that the solitary New York representative, Ira Rubin of Paramus, N. J., will compete for the world team title in Monte Carlo next spring increased markedly in the first 16 deals of International Team Trial play here last night.

title: A One  Wornan Force Polices Oregon Town
description: ECHO, Ore.Halloween vandalism started so early and was so serious here this year that the community's entire Police Department was called out to handle the situation.

title: Beaths
description: ALLEBTUCKDr. Samuel. beloved brotner Muerte Klan, Robert Allentuck ana Anna Michaels. Loving uncle. Services Fhcay, 11:00 A.M. The Riversize, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: G.M. Resuming Payments to Jobless
description: DETROIT, Oct. 30The General Motors Corporation said today it was resuming payments of special unemployment benefits after an eightweek interruption. A spokesman said about 11,000 of 46,000 laid off G.M. workers would be eligible.

title: Today's Entries at Belmont
description: Horses listed In order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: City Fiscal Crisis Intrudes On Assembly Campaigns
description: TRENTON. Oct. 30  New York City's fiscal crisis is now among a number of factors. combining to make the election. campaigns for the New Jersey: Assembly one of the least exciting in memory.

title: Joint Bidding Barred For 9 Oil Companies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI)Nine big oil companies will be barred from bidding jointly for offshore oil and gas leases for the next six months, the Interior Department announced today.

title: JURY GETS VIEWS OF RUCKELSHAUS
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 30Former Deputy Attorney Genleral William D. Ruckelshaus; said today that he could not rule out the possibility that he was told in 1970 that a Justice Department aide received documents and a tape recording allegedly obtained through the burglary of a close associate of Senator Vance Iliartke, Democrat of Indiana.

title: Policemen Seek Parity For Woman on Force
description: WOODBURY, Oct. 30, (UPI) The only policewoman in town touched off a protest demonstration today because she is paid less than the men on the forceend it was some of her fellow officers who swelled the ranks of the demonstrators.

title: Continued Gain in Auto Outlook Is Forecast
description: DETROIT, Oct. 30The Ford Motor Company reported today, improved earnings for the third quarter. At the same time Ford executives forecast continued improvement in the immediate future.

title: For Angola Refugees in Portugal, a Life of Despair
description: BARREIRO, Portugal, Oct. 29This new home for 2,000 refugees from Angola is five miles south of Lisbon, 4,500 miles north of their old homeland and a million miles from any of the comforts of life.

title: Troubled Oil Men Blaming Government for Problems
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 3OFrom their luncheon tables at the Houston Petroleum Club atop the Exxon Building, oil and energy executives look with wrinkled brows these days over booming Houston, the selfproclaimed energy capital of the world.

title: Open Interest
description: Thursday, Oct. 30. 1975 (In bushels, 000 omitted) Wed Thurs. Open

title: Dr. Samuel Allentuck Dies; Psychiatrist With Bellevue
description: Dr. Samuel Allentuck, a psychiatrist practicing here for many years, died Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital. Dr. Allentuck, who lived at 350 West 57th Street, was 71 years old.

title: Business Briefs
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 30 (UPI)The dollar declined sharply on European money markets today, weakened by President Ford's opposition to Federal aid for New York City and by the prospect of lower United States interest rates.

title: U.S. Rules Out Intervention in Lebanon
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The State Department said today that the United States was giving absolutely no consideration to military intervention in Lebanon and was continuing to urge other countries to stay out of the conflict.

title: Democratic Hopefuls Here Blame Ford for City Plight
description: A standingroomonly crowd heard four of the announced candidates for the Democratic nomination for President and the wife of former Senator Fred Harris of Oklahoma castigate President Ford last night for his threat of a veto of any bill to help New York City avoid default.

title: GOLD
description: Selected world gold Prices Thursday, London: Morning fixing $144.00, up $1.25, afternoon fixing $143.75, up $1.00.

title: Monsanto Unit Expanding
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 30 (UPI)Monsanto Polymers and Petrochemicals Company said today it would build a plant at Wingles in the PasdeCalais area of France to make 50,000 metric tons of lustrex impact polystyrene yearly for the packaging industry. Monsanto already makes general purpose polystyrenes at Wingles.

title: SENATE UNIT, 8 TO 5, BACKS LOAN GUARANTEE FOR CITY DESPITE THREATENED VETO
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The Senate Banking Committee approved 8 to 5 today legislation that would provide a $4billion loan guarantee to prevent default by New York City. It rejected the argument that such action was futile because of a threatened filibuster and veto.

title: They Need Lights
description: HIROSHIMA, Japan, Oct. 30 (AP)  The Hankyu Braves, champions of the Pacific League, and Hiroshima Toyo Carp, champions of the Central League, played to a 33 t'e in Japan's baseball series today. The game was called because of darkness after 13 innings.

title: JUDGE RULES ALIOTO IN CONFLICT ON PORT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 (AP)A judge ruled today that Mayor Joseph L. Alioto had violated the conflict of interest section of the city charter through his connection with family shipping interests.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Someplace in the nether regions of Halloween's history, when All Hallow's Eve was linked to the dying of the old year and demons were believed to issue from the earth, children received the injunction: Stay off the streets, for this is a scary night.

title: John Scott Trotter Dead at 67; Music Director for Bing Crosby
description: HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 30 (UPI) John Scott Trotter, whose entertainment career spanning a half century took him from the side of Hal Kemp in the bigband era to Bing Crosby on radio and records and George Gobel on television, died yesterday of cancer at Mt. Sinai Hospital. He was 67 years old.

title: Hard Day for the City on Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30One New Yorker got relief from the United States Senate today. In a matter of seconds, in an almost empty chamber, the first item on the agenda passed without objection. It was a bill for the relief of Mrs. Hope Namgyal.

description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

description: Another saga in our series of homilies on rockconcert mores:

title: RABBINIC SCHOOL CITES ROCKEFELLER
description: Vice President Rockefeller was honored last night as an outstanding public servant who in highest offices has represented government in noblest responsibilities.

title: Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Thursday, Oct. 30, 1975

title: Red Smith
description: Pete Anderson, 12,000 Pounds Later

title: Senate Committee Kills Coors's Bid For Broadcast Post
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) The Senate Commerce Committee today killed the nomination of Joseph Coors, the brewing executive, to be member of the board of directors of the Public Broadcasting Corporation.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater
